- Liver/kidney failure or nephrotic syndrome

- Malabsorption (Crohn's, Coeliac's, CF, Whipple's)

- Obesity

 

Consequences of Vitamin D Deficiency

- Rickets, osteomalacia, osteoarthritis, osteoporosis and muscle aches/weakness

- Depression, schizophrenia and anxiety

- Asthma and increased risk of upper respiratory tract infections and TB

- T2DM, HBP, CHD and Syndrome X

- Autoimmune diseases (e.g. T1DM, MS, Crohn's, RA)

- Cancer
Tags: case 11, Lower GI, Vitamins and Minerals, Nutrition

Question:
A 35 yo female visits her GP with concerns that she may have a genetic predisposition for bowel cancer.

 

She is tested for Lynch Syndrome and comes back negative. You inform her of certain lifestyle factors that would increase/decrease her risk of developing colorectal cancer.

 

Which of the following is NOT associated with a decrease in her risk of developing CRC?
Explanation:
Environmental factors that increase risk of CRC in general population:

- Red meat

- Wheat bran

- High BMI in men

- Smoking and alcohol

 

Environmental factors that decrease risk of CRC in general population:

- Vegetables

- Oily fish

- High BMI in women

- Exercise

- NSAIDs

- Calcium

 

NB. these are different to the environmental factors that affect risk of developing CRC in LS patients

Question:
A 7 yo female presents with a history of abdominal pain, weight loss and diarrhoea.

 

Following investigations, you diagnose her with mild Crohn's disease.

 

What is the most appropriate course of action?
Explanation:
The disease is active so you need to induce remission.

 

Treatment to induce remission in CD:

- Budesonide

- Dietary therapy (i.e. cutting out solid food - popular for children but has a high rate of relapse once stopped)

- Antibiotics

- (Only use corticosteroids or anti-TNF if it is severe)

 

NB. 5-ASA is for UC and azathioprine is for for maintaining remission in UC and CD

Question:
A morbidly obese 18 yo male is considering gastric bypass surgery and would like to know more. You explain that the procedure will result in food bypassing the stomach and duodenum.

 

You explain that some of the side effects are micronutrient deficiencies. Which of the following is most likely?
Explanation:
(he's actually most likely to get iron deficiency but that's not one of the options because that'd be too easy)

 

Calcium (and iron) are absorbed in the duodenum.

 

- FAs and vitamins in general are absorbed in the jejunum

- Vitamin C in the beginning of the ileum

- Vitamin B12 in the terminal ileum
Tags: Vitamins and Minerals, case 11, Lower GI, Nutrition, Upper GI

Question:
Addison's disease is an insidious disease due to its non-specific set symptoms. It is tragically sometimes confused for anorexia nervosa.

 

How would you differentiate between the two?
Explanation:
Anorexia causes everything to drop (BP, Na+, glucose, K+).

 

Addison's causes everything to drop except K+, which is elevated (due to inactivation of RAAS).

Question:
A 48 yo male with T2DM is getting checked for any diabetic retinopathy. 

 

Upon examination, you find hard exudates, CWS, IRMA (intraretinal microvascular abnormality) and microaneurysms.

 

What is the most appropriate course of action?
OptionA: Advise him on how to improve lifestyle factors and monitor his progression
OptionB: Laser new vessels, anti-VEGF injections and observe every 4 months
Explanation:
This is pre-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

 

Treatment for PPDR is laser new vessels, anti-VEGF injections and check every 4 months for signs of neovascularisation

 

---

 

- Treatment for background or non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (i.e. blot haemorrhages and hard exudates) is advise on how to improve lifestyle factors and monitor progression.

- Treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy (i.e. new vessels!) is laser, anti-VEGF, pharmacological vitreolysis

- Vitrectomy is only if there is a bleed.

Question: In which of these locations is the egg most commonly fertilised?
Which of the following induces the formation of ectodermally and mesodermally derived organs
Explanation:
Refer to Professor Wilson's lecture on somitogenesis from Case 7

 

  • TAU is irrelevant to this case - it's increased in cases of Alzheimers
  • TRP is also irrelevant- its a type of channel protein
  • Wnt proteins appear periodically during development and are associated with tissue formation
  • Shh proteins initially expressed in notochord (what starts neurulation) - Shh induces neural patterning and patterning of the somites
  • TGF-B proteins regulate cell differentiation

Question: A persistent infection of which virus cause Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis?

A 26-year-old male has been suffering from depression for 5 years and insomnia and has tried various antidepressants over the years. The GP decides it is time to prescribe a Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), clomipramine. However, the GP didn’t read the patients’ medical history properly and didn’t notice he takes a barbiturate called amobarbital for insomnia. What is the likely contraindication when the patient takes the TCA and the barbiturate together?
OptionE: There is no contraindication of taking a TCA and a barbiturate
Explanation:
Answer D is correct

A: adrenergic vasoconstrictors and TCAs cause arrhythmias as well as acetaminophen and TCAs

 

 

B: acetaminophen and TCAs cause reduced metabolism of the TCAs and consequently toxicity

 

 

C: Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) and meperidine hydrochloride taken together cause severe hyperthermia and arrhythmias

 

D: CORRECT ANSWER: TCAs and barbiturates taken together cause severe respiratory depression

 

E: see above answer

 

Barbiturates are drugs known to depress the CNS and therefore can be utilised as sedation in surgery or as anticonvulsants.They can also can be used to treat insomnia, anxiety or seizure activity. They also can be used recreationally.

 

A helpful way to remember this: barbiturates are used as sedation in surgery, in surgery under general anaesthetic you are normally placed  on a ventilator - without this ventilator - likelihood of respiratory depression! 

 

 

 

See neuropharmacology lecture 1 for more detail
Tags: Case 12, Pharmacology, contraindications, Case Group 84, drugs

Question: A patient has problems converting Noradrenaline to adrenaline in adrenergic neurones and in the adrenal medulla which enzyme is affected?
Explanation:
Answer E is correct:

A: in dopaminergic neurones L-DOPA is converted to Dopamine by L-aromatic amino acid decarboxylase (AACD)

 

 

B: In noradrenergic neurones dopamine converted to Noradrenaline by dopamine--hydroxylase (DBH)

 

C: tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) to form L-DOPA

 

D: Tryptophan is converted to 5-hydroxytryptophan by Tryptophan hydroxylase (TPH)

 

E: In adrenergic neurones and adrenal medulla Noradrenaline is converted to Adrenaline by Phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT)

Question: A 28-year-old female presents to a GP with weight gain, blurred vision, constipation and spouts of dizziness. During the history taking you discover she is taking antidepressants. Which antidepressant is she likely taking to give her these symptoms?
Explanation:
Answer A is correct

 

 

A: Clomipramine is a Tri-cyclic antidepressant (TCAs), it inhibits SEROTONIN and NORADRENALINE reuptake

It also blocks

mACH: which causes drowsiness, blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation

H1 histamine: which cause weight gain, drowsiness

alpha1 adrenergic: which causes dizziness, hypotension, CNS problems, arrhythmia (block voltage gated sodium channels), seizures and comas.

 

B: Duloxetine is a Serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) and inhibits serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake.

This drug can cause hepatotoxicity, tremors, increase heart rate and blood pressure and anticholinergic effects.

 

C: Fluvoxamine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) which selectively inhibits serotonin transporter to increase synaptic levels of serotonin. Most commonly prescribed as has the best side effect profile.

Side effects include, sexual dysfunction, weight gain, nausea and vomiting.

 

D: Atomoxetine is a noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor (NRIs) which inhibit noradrenaline reuptake.

Side effects include: nausea and vomiting, increased sensitivity to light, dry mouth and headaches.

 

E: Phenelezine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOIs) which non selectively inhibit monoamine oxidase enzymes.

Side effects include: cold sweats, swelling, tremors, overactive reflexes, confusion and dizziness.
Tags: Case 12, Pharmacology, contraindications, Case Group 84, drugs

Question: A deficiency in serotonin has been linked to symptoms of depression. In which region of the brain is serotonin produced?
Explanation:
Norepinephrine is produced in the Locus Coeruleus, located in the pons

Dopamine is produced in the VTA

Serotonin is produced in the Raphe Nuclei

Substantia Nigra - the location where neuromelanin is directly biosynthesised from L-DOPA, precursor to dopamine

Question:
A 23 year old woman presents to her GP with reduced energy, lack of pleasure from her hobbies and reduced concentration and self esteem. The GP has also noticed that she appears tired and has lost weight since her last visit.

 

Which condition is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Moderate depression - 2 core symptoms, 3 associated symptoms

 

Core symptoms = low mood, anhedonia, anergia

Question:
21 year old male presents with auditory hallucinations, delusional thoughts and anhedonia. He went to his GP who suggested his symptoms may be due to low chemicals in a pathway in his brain. 

Which pathway is responsible for the negative symptoms in the condition described?
Explanation:
This condition is schizophrenia. 

Underactivity in the mesocortical pathway leads to the negative symptoms (ie anhedonia, alogia, avolition etc.) and overactivity in the mesolimbic pathway will contribute to the positive symptoms (ie delusions, hallucinations etc)

Question: John presents to A&E with fever, rigors and a sore throat. John has a history of paranoid schizophrenia, which he says he takes medication for, and admits he has missed appointments for his blood tests recently. What drug is most likely to cause John's symptoms?
Explanation:
1) Clozapine causes agranulocytosis (low granulocyte count) in 1-2% of patients and is an atypical antipsychotic medication

2) Olanzapine is not associated with agranulocytosis

3) Haloperidol is more associated with extrapyramidal side effect, not bone marrow suppression

4)Carbimazole is prescribed for hyperthyroidism, however can cause agranulocytosis

5) AZT is used in the treatment of HIV, however does also cause agranulocytosis

Question:
A 32 year old male patient presents to A&E with sepsis. On history taking you find out he was diagnosed with schizophrenia 5 years ago. 

After a blood test, his levels of neutrophils are dangerously low and is diagnosed with agranulocytosis. 

 

Which antipsychotic drug was the patient taking?
Explanation:
Answer D: Clozapine 

 

It is a second generation a typical antipsychotic and has to be prescribed only by consultants as one of its rare side effects is: agranulocytosis. 

This depletes the stores of neutrophils in the bone marrow and patients treated on clozapine must go for regular blood tests, as they can be more prone to infection. 

 

if the patient gets agranulocytosis then a bone marrow transplant is needed.

Question:
A 25 year old male with known schizophrenia explains to his GP that his flatmates are planning to kill him.

What sort of delusion is this?
Explanation:
Auditory hallucinations would be hearing voices.

Delusions of thought interference are feelings that thoughts have been inserted into their head (insertion) or broadcasting (thoughts are being broadcasted)

Nihilism is a delusion that you are already dead.

Grandiose Delusions are of superiority e.g. I am the Messiah

Question:
a 28 year old women has been taking Amitrypiline for 6 months after her GP diagnosed her with depression.  In the past couple of weeks she has noticed that her vision has become blurred and her mouth is dry.

 

What action of Amitrypiline is likely responsible for her symptoms?
Explanation:
Antagonism of D2 receptors in an action of antipsychotics. Antagonism of D2 receptors of extrapyramidal motor system i.e. the nigrostriatal pathway produces the Parkinson-like side effects of conventional antipsychotics. 

 

Tricyclic Anti-depressants such as amitriptyline also block receptors causing side effects.

H1 receptors: weight gain, drowsiness

mACH: Blurred Vision, dry mouth, constipation

a1: Dizziness, hypotension

Question:
Prader-Willi Syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused by 15q11-q13 mutation. Children with the syndrome eat an excessive amount of food. 

 

Which hormone is responsible for this hyperphagia?
Explanation: Hyperghrelinemia is seen in individuals with PWS, and levels stay high after feeding. There is a failed satiety response and so they constantly feel hungry.

Question: GABA is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. It is selectively permeable to which ion?
Explanation: Because GABA is inhibitory, the chloride ions hyperpolarise the neurone, therefore reducing its excitability.

Question: A 20 year old male presents in A&E having taken illicit drugs. After performing a toxicology screen, it is clear he has taken MDMA. MDMA works mainly by releasing and inhibiting the reuptake of a certain neurotransmitter, but which one?
Explanation: MDMA and LSD are the only drugs that work by principly increasing serotonin levels

Question: Which option best describes the  anatomical position of the AV node?
OptionA: Between the base of the anterior papillary muscle and the interventricular septum
OptionB: Wall (myocardium) of the right atrium near the junction of the Superior Vena Cava (SVC)
OptionD: Directly above the insertion of the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve
OptionE: Interventricular septum lateral to the septomarginal trabecula
Explanation:
The correct answer is D. The AV node is located in the inter-atrial septum, near the opening of the coronary sinus, directly above the insertion of the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve.
Option A refers to the anatomical position of the septomarginal trabecula (moderator band)
Option B refers to the anatomical positon of the SA node
Options C and E do not apply to specific anatomical structures within the heart.

Question: M3 receptor subtype is usually located:
OptionC: On effector cell membranes of glandular and smooth muscle cells

Question: Which of the following clients is at greatest risk for digital toxicity?
OptionA: An 80-year-old client with CHF- congestive heart failure
Explanation: Extremely old clients are at greater risk for digitalis toxicity. Remember when it comes to adversity, the very old and very young are always at highest risk.

Question: Which of the following is a contraindication for digoxin administration?
Explanation: The apical heart rate must be monitored during therapy with digoxin, and the drug held for pulse below 60 and above 120. Remember that digoxin lowers the heart rate; therefore, the choice that reflects a low heart rate is the best selection.

Question: The action of medication is  inotropic when it:
Explanation: Inotropic drugs increase the force of contraction. Preload, not afterload, is decreased. Chronotropic drugs increase heart rate. Treatment of CHF is an indication for use not an action of inotropic drug.

Question: Which is the MOST appropriate action for the nurse to take before administering digoxin?
Explanation: Monitoring potassium is especially important because hypokalemia potentiates digoxin toxicity. B and C are incorrect because these data reflect overall CV status but are not specific for digoxin. Choice D are drugs usually administered with digoxin.

Question: The therapeutic drug level for digoxin is:
Explanation: BNF

Question: Blurred vision or halos are signs of:
Explanation: Halos is a hallmark sign of digoxin toxicity. A, C and D are incorrect because subtherapeutic digoxin levels have no such effects.

Question: Amrinone (Inocor) is used for short term therapy for CHF and acts by which of the following mechanisms?
OptionB: Slowing ventricular rate and increasing cardiac output
OptionD: Increasing cardiac output and enhancing renal perfusion
Explanation: The action of amrinone (Inocor) is to increase stroke volume, ejection fraction, and heart rate. Lanoxin, not amrinone, slows ventricular rate and increases cardiac output. The vasodilator effect of amrinone decreases peripheral vascular resistance. Any increase in cardiac output will enhance renal perfusion; this is not just specific to amrinone.

Question: Johanna has ventricular ectopy, which of the following drugs is the first line used to treat her condition?
Explanation: Lidocaine is the only choice used to treat ventricular ectopy. A and C are class IA antiarrhythmics. Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside.

Question: Class IA antiarrhythmic agents have little effect on:
Explanation: class Ib = fast Na voltage gated ; Class Ic = slow NA voltage gated; class Ia = between 1b and 1c

Question: Which of the following drugs can cause severe hematologic disorders?
Explanation: procainaminde = Class Ic ,Pronestyl is known for this serious side effect. Associate Pronestyl with plasma — P and P. This drug is known for its hematologic side effects

Question: When administering an antiarrhythmic agent, which of the following assessment parameters is the most important for the nurse to evaluate?

Question: The most toxic antiarrhythmic agent is:
Explanation: This is the most toxic drug and should be used only if other less toxic agents have been tried. Digoxin, on the other hand, is cardiotonic, not antiarrhythmic agent. B and D are not known for their toxicity.

Question: Which of the following calcium channel blockers has the most potent peripheral smooth muscle dilator effect?
Explanation: Nifedipine has the strongest peripheral smooth muscle dilator effect of all the calcium channel blockers. Other choices have less of a vasodilator effect.

Question: Which of the following calcium channel blockers is used to counteract or prevent cerebral vasospasm?
Explanation: Nimodipine is given in the neurologic client to prevent cerebral vasospasm. Choices A, C, and D are given in cardiac disease and in the management of hypertension only.

Question: Which of the following effects of calcium channel blockers causes a reduction in blood pressure?
Explanation: One of the effects of calcium channel blockers is to decrease peripheral vascular resistance. A, C, and D describe the opposite effects of calcium channel blockers.

Question: ß blockers should be avoided in which of the following conditions?
Explanation: ß blockers should be avoided in bronchoconstrictive disease. B, C, and D are indications for the use of ß blockers.

Question:
A 64 year old man has central chest pain. Which single set of findings is most likely in the
diagnosis of myocardial infarction?
OptionA: A. high troponin T and high creatine kinase (muscle-brain) (CK-MB)

A. Both of these indicate myocardial damage in the context of myocardial infarction. Serum
LDH activity does not increase until 24-48 hours after chest pain and peaks at three days

Question: A 23-year-old man is stabbed in a bar ﬁght. The blade of the knife enters his chest in the left 5th intercostal space, just lateral to the sternum, and pierces to a depth of approximately 4 cm. What structure is most likely damaged?
Explanation: Due to the location of the stab wound, the pericardial sac and the right ventricle of the heart (the most anterior chamber of the heart) are most likely damaged. The pericardium is a ﬁ brous, unyielding sac that surrounds the heart. Lesion of the right ventricle would cause blood to spill out of the heart into the pericardial space, causing a pericardial effusion (blood accumulation within the pericardial sac

Question: A coronary artery angiogram is given to a 68-year-old man with recurrent angina. It reveals 90% stenosis of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. Based upon this ﬁnding, which portion of the heart is most likely susceptible to ischemic damage?
Explanation: As its anatomical name implies, it supplies the anterior two thirds of the interventricular septum, so this portion of the heart would most likely be damaged following an ischemic event due to a 90% stenosis of the LAD

Question: A child is born at home without difﬁculty. Two weeks later, the mother takes the infant to her doctor, reporting that he “turns blue” when he cries. Explanation:

Question: An 87-year-old woman with a history of metastatic adenocarcinoma of the breast presents with difﬁculty in breathing. A plain chest ﬁlm reveals massive left pleural effusion. A thoracentesis is an invasive procedure to remove the excess ﬂuid from the pleural sac. In the midaxillary line, the lung resides at the 8th rib and the parietal pleura would reside at the 10th rib. The space between the parietal pleura and the lung is the costodiaphragmatic recess, and it gives space for the lung to inﬂate within the pleural cavity/ 

 

6th midaxiliary line - chest tube remove air or fluid of lung after it has collapsed due to pneumothrowx

6th parastenal - a lot of heart tissues 

parasternal 2th - for auscultation

Question: Disruption of parasympathetic input to the thorax may be related to damage to which of the following structures?

During this procedure, iatrogenic injury to the coronary artery supplying the conduction system of the heart, including the sinuatrial (SA) and atrioventricular (AV) nodes, occurred, resulting in a heart block. What artery was most likely damaged by the surgeon?
Explanation:
Right coronary supples both SAN and AVN

Anterior IV = LAD

Question: Hans Solo, a 23-year-old man playing squash on a Saturday night, begins to feel light-headed and experiences palpitation. On Monday, he goes to the GP, and was prescribed Amiodarone. He returns 2 weeks later, and an ECG shows he has a QT interval of 533ms. Which arrhythmia is he most vulnerable to developing?
Explanation:
Answer = Torsade de Pointes (Polymorphic VT)

 

Prolonged QT interval may lead to triggered activity mechanism of arrhythmia caused by delayed after depolarisations. If an ectopic beat occurs during the T wave or during ventricular repolarisation, this could lead to Torsade de Pointes (polymorphic VT)

Question:
In a GP surgery, you meet a 25 year old male experiencing symptoms of shortness of breath and 'fluttering' in his chest that he describes as coming and going. After taking a full history, you perform a 12-lead ECG and these are your findings:

 

From this ECG, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: This ECG shows WPW syndrome due to the presence of delta waves in the chest leads V1-6, and a dominant R wave in V1 and right precordial T-wave inversions simulating RVH.
Tags: Case group 64, cardiovascular, Case 13, ECG, arrhythmias

Question: A patient presents to the cardiac ward with palpitations. The registrar orders an ECG to be done. looking at the ECG the doctor notices a fibrillating 'saw toothed' baseline with regularly irregular beats. what is he likely to have?
Explanation: Look at the ECG tutorial

Question: A 62-year-old female patient has come into the A&E. You are a tired F2 junior doctor examining her ECG and you notice abnormalities in leads V5, V6 and I, what is the most likely vessel affected?
Explanation: Left circumflex artery supplies the lateral region of the heart.

Question: A 60 year old woman comes to the hospital and the doctor suspects it is Torsades de pointes (polymorphic ventricular tachycardia). Which of these drugs would you definitely NOT prescribe?
Explanation: Amiodarone is a Class 3 drug which has a risk of ventricular pro arrhythmia, especially Torsades de Pointes, therefore its not used for patients which that condition.

Question: Uzair, a 19 year old sports science student has recently started to feel palpitations. He visits his GP as he is concerned that the palpitations may affect his future rugby career. The GP does an ECG on Uzair and finds that he has Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome. What characteristic features would be seen on the ECG?
OptionC: Delta wave, short PR interval, broad QRS complex

Question: A patient comes in to your clinic for a review on the management of his Atrial Fibrillation. He is currently on diltiazem but he still complains of experiencing palpitations and gets breathless, which interferes with his job as a tennis coach. You perform an ECG in clinic and you see that he has what you consider a fast AF. What are you going do next for his management?
Explanation: NICE guidelines recommend 2 of a beta-blocker, digoxin and diltiazem when monotherapy doesn't alleviate symptoms and doesn't control ventricular rate. Digoxin isn't recommended with his job. Combining verapamil and beta-blocker is dangerous and not recommended.

Question: A 65 year old man comes to A&E with a sudden onset of palpitations, breathlessness and dizziness. You perform a 12 lead ECG. What is his most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia is an irregularly irregular atrial tachycardia arising from many different ectopic foci. It differs from Atrial Fibrillation as it has some P waves present (at least 3 to be MAT) and it is not Atrial Flutter as has an isoelectric line present and doesn't have the distinct 'sawtooth' pattern. It is a type of SVT but MAT is a more specific choice. JET is another narrow complex tachycardia, however JET has AV dissociation, i.e. QRS complexes don't correspond with P waves and are at a faster rate than the atrial rate.

Question: Which molecule is thought to be responsible for the principle clinical toxicity (side effects) observed in patients taking Sulfasalazine?
Explanation:
The correct answer is B – Sulfapyridine
Sulfasalazine molecule comprises both sulfapyridine and 5- Amino Salicylic acid (5- ASA, an aspirin analogue), which are linked together via a di-azo bond. Once sulfasalazine is ingested, about 30% of the intact molecule is absorbed in the upper GI tract either to be carried by the enterohepatic circulation, or to be excreted in the urine by the kidneys. The remaining 2/3rd of the intact sulfasalazine molecule ultimately passes down the lower GI tract, where the intestinal bacterial enzymes cleave the di-azo bond, thus releasing Sulfapyridine and 5-ASA. Sulfapyridine has a bioavailability of 60% (better absorbed) whereas 5-ASA has a bioavailability of 10-30%. It is the circulating levels of Sulfapyridine that are responsible for the principle clinical toxicity and side effects of Sulfasalazine (i.e. agranulocytosis and hypospermia), especially in those who are slow acetylators. Meanwhile, the 5-ASA remains in the bowel lumen, where it is thought to exert its therapeutic effect locally, (by decreasing the synthesis of inflammatory leukotrienes and cytokines) prior to elimination in the faeces.
Therefore, 5-ASA and its derivatives are now usually preferred given alone (i.e. mesalazine), despite their increased cost, due to their more favourable effects. NB. Mesalazine is only given in mild to moderate UC.

 

Hope this helps.

Question: Which NOAC/DOAC has an antidote?
Explanation: Dabigatran is the only NOAC/DOAC to have an antidote - idarucizumab

Question: A 65-year-old man presents with central crushing chest pain for the first time. He is transferred immediately to the closest cardiac unit to undergo a primary percutaneous coronary intervention. There is thrombosis of the left circumflex artery only. Angioplasty is carried out and a drug-eluding stent is inserted. What are the most likely changes to have occurred on ECG during admission?
OptionC: ST depression in leads II, III and AVF
OptionE: ST elevation in leads II, III and AVF
Explanation: Time equates to muscle. Judging from the urgency, this male presented with an ST elevation MI (STEMI) which is an indication for urgent primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Compare this to a non-ST elevation MI (NSTEMI) which indicates ischaemia rather than infarction and PCI should be carried out within 48 hours (answers A and C). The angiogram shows that the left circumflex artery is occluded, resulting in a lateral infarct.

Question: A 78-year-old woman is admitted with heart failure. The underlying cause is determined to be aortic stenosis. Which sign is most likely to be present?
Explanation:
Aortic stenosis will first result in left ventricular failure as a result of increased ventricular pressure as the ventricle tries to pump blood across a narrowed valve. Initially the pressure load will cause a backlog of blood into the lungs, resulting in pulmonary oedema – the first sign of which will be bibasal crepitations- the cracking sound of the basal lung.

 

LV blood pressure greater than alveoli pressure and results blood into the lung and pulmonary oedema.

Question: A patient is admitted with pneumonia. A murmur is heard on examination. What finding points to mitral regurgitation?
OptionB: Murmur louder with patient in left lateral position
OptionC: Murmur louder over the right 2nd intercostal space midclavicular line
Explanation:
A murmur heard loudest on inspiration (A) points to a right-sided valve lesion. The right intercostal space midclavicular line (C) is the anatomical landmark for the aortic valve. The mitral area is over the apex. A murmur louder with the patient in the left lateral position (B) (as opposed to leaning forward) is associated with mitral lesions. If heard, you should determine whether the murmur radiates to the axilla.

 

Narrow pressure = sign of aortic stenosis 

Corrigan sign = hyperdynmaic circulation associated with aortic regurgitation

Question: A 79-year-old woman is admitted to the coronary care unit (CCU) with unstable angina. She is started on appropriate medication to reduce her cardiac risk. She is hypertensive, fasting glucose is normal and cholesterol is 5.2. She is found to be in atrial fibrillation. What is the most appropriate treatment?
Explanation: Ideally this patient should be started on antihypertensives, a beta blocker and a statin. There is no indication for hypoglycaemics at present. There is no indication that this is acute atrial fibrillation and she does not seem to be compromised in a female of this age, cardioversion (C) is unlikely to be successful. She should be rate-controlled but the beta blockade is more appropriate in light of her ischaemic heart disease. Whether to start anticoagulation (A) is a decision that has to be tailor-made for each individual patient.

Question: A 55-year-old man has just arrived in accident and emergency complaining of 20 minutes of central crushing chest pain. Which feature is most indicative of myocardial infarction at this moment in time
Explanation: Acute coronary syndrome is a spectrum of cardiac ischaemia-infarction determined by the presence of two out of three factors: chest pain, ECG changes and cardiac enzyme rise. Depending on these results, patients will fall into one of the following categories: unstable angina, NSTEMI or STEMI. Inverted T waves (A) and ST depression (B) are signs of ischaemia. ST elevation, Q waves and raised troponin are indicative of infarctio

Question: While on call you are called by a nurse to a patient on the ward complaining of light headedness and palpitations. When you arrive the patient is not conscious but has a patent airway and is breathing with oxygen saturation at 97 per cent. You try to palpate a pulse but are unable to find the radial or carotid. The registrar arrives and after hearing your report of the patient decides to shock the patient who recovers. What is the patient most likely to have been suffering
Explanation: This patient is suffering from a life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmia of which there are two types, sustained ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. In ventricular fibrillation (B) the patient is pulseless and cardioversion is required. A sustained ventricular tachycardia (C) is usually recognized by cannon ‘a’ waves on JVP and broad QRS complexes if an ECG is available. If stable, patients can be cardioverted with amiodarone, if unstable, electrocardioversion is required. Torsades de pointes (A) presents with irregular QRS complexes and prolonged QT interval, a non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (D) is defined by more than five consecutive heart beats within 30 seconds, while a normal heart ventricular tachycardia (E) is a benign tachyarrhythmia. Answers (A), (D) and (E) are not shockable rhythms.

Question: A 56-year-old man presents to your clinic with symptoms of exertional chest tightness which is relieved by rest. You request an ECG which reveals that the patient has first degree heart block. Which of the following ECG abnormalities is typically seen in first degree heart block?
Explanation:
The PR interval is usually measured from the start of the P-wave to the start of the QRS and the normal range lies within 0.12–0.2s (i.e. 120–200 ms). In
Answers 23


first degree heart block, the PR interval is prolonged, greater than 0.2 s (200 ms)

 

(D). Shortened PR interval (i.e <120 s or <0.12 s) (E) results from fast AV conduction, usually down an accessory pathway seen in Wolff– Parkinson–White syndrome.

Question: You see a 57-year-old woman who presents with worsening shortness of breath coupled with decreased exercise tolerance. She had rheumatic fever in her adolescence and suffers from essential hypertension. On examination she has signs which point to a diagnosis of mitral stenosis. Which of the following is not a clinical sign associated with mitral stenosis?
Explanation: Malar flush (A), atrial fibrillation (B), a tapping apex beat (D) and right ventricular heave (E), which occurs secondary to pulmonary hypertension, are all clinical signs associated with mitral stenosis. On auscultation of the praecordium, a mid-diastolic murmur (±opening snap, representing a mobile valve) is heard rather than a pan-systolic murmur (C) which is usually heard in mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation and ventricular septal defects.

Question: A 48-year-old woman has been diagnosed with essential hypertension and was commenced on treatment three months ago. She presents to you with a dry cough which has not been getting better despite taking cough linctus and antibiotics. You assess the patient’s medication history. Which of the following antihypertensive medications is responsible for the patient’s symptoms ?
Explanation:
ACE inhibitors (e.g. lisinopril (B)) commonly cause a dry cough in some patients. If this occurs, patients are usually taken off the ACEI and started on either an ARB (e.g. irbesartan, losartan, telmisartan) or different class of antihypertensive. Amlodipine (A), bendroflumethiazide (C), frusemide (D) and atenolol (E) do not commonly cause a dry cough as a side effect

she is below 55 years old and non afro-carribean .

Question: A 62-year-old male presents with palpitations, which are shown on ECG to be atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of approximately 130/minute. He has mild central chest discomfort but is not acutely distressed. He first noticed these about 3 hours before coming to hospital. As far as is known this is his first episode of this kind. Which of the following would you prefer as first-line therapy?
OptionA: Anticoagulate with heparin and start digoxin at standard daily dose
OptionC: Administer bisoprolol and verapamil, and give warfarin
OptionE: Wait to see if there is spontaneous reversion to sinus rhythm
Explanation:
Acute AF - If unstable DC cardioversion is considered

 

The onset of the arrhythmia is recent, and there is a good chance of successful cardioversion (B) at this point without the need for anticoagulation. Conservative management (E) is also reasonable, though the patient is in some discomfort. ‘Chemical’ cardioversion (D) may be somewhat less likely to succeed than DC cardioversion but may be preferred by the patient. Digoxin (A) may eventually control resting, but not ambulant heart rate, but would probably take several days before it did so. Option (C) is certainly suitable in cases of persistent or permanent atrial fibrillation where it is decided to opt for rate control.

Question: A 76-year-old male is brought to accident and emergency after collapsing at home. He has recovered within minutes and is fully alert and orientated. He says this is the first such episode that he has experienced, but describes some increasing shortness of breath in the previous six months and brief periods of central chest pain, often at the same time. On examination, blood pressure is 115/88 mmHg and there are a few rales at both bases. On ECG there are borderline criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following might you expect to find on auscultation?
OptionA: Mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the apex
OptionB: Crescendo systolic murmur best heard at the right sternal edge
OptionC: Diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal edge
OptionD: Pan-systolic murmur best heard at the apex
OptionE: Pan-systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal edge
Explanation: This is a classical presentation of aortic stenosis, with syncope following a period of increasing shortness of breath on exertion and angina, with relatively narrow pulse pressure and ECG (or echo) indications of left ventricular hypertrophy

Question:
A 57-year-old male is admitted complaining of headaches and blurring of vision. His blood pressure is found to be 240/150 mmHg and he has bilateral papilloedema, but is fully orientated and coherent. He had been known to be hypertensive for about five years and his blood pressure control had been good on three drugs.

 

However, he had decided to stop all medication two months before this event. Which of the following would be your preferred parenteral medication at this point? - hint a rapid blood pressure lowering drugs is required
Explanation:
tI is generally agreed that in situations where relatively rapid blood pressure lowering is indicated, sodium nitroprusside (D) is the most effective and reliable drug.

 

 

However, it can only be used safely if there are facilities for continuous intra-arterial blood pressure monitoring, since it can produce very rapid drops in blood pressure which can lead to acute cerebral, cardiac or optic hypoperfusion. GTN (A), hydralazine (B) and labetalol (C) have also been used in hypertensive emergencies but are less reliable, GTN is the drug of second choice. They may be preferred if intensive monitoring is not available. Phentolamine (E) is used in phaeochromocytoma-caused hypertensive crises. It should be noted that the evidence base for the management of hypertensive emergencies is still under review.

Question: A 21-year-old man is on his way home from a party when he experiences the sudden onset of rapid palpitations. He feels uncomfortable but not short of breath and has no chest pain. He goes to the nearest accident and emergency department, where he is found to have a supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) at a rate of 170/minute. Carotid sinus massage produced transient reversion to sinus rhythm, after which the tachycardia resumed. What would be the next step in your management?
Explanation:
IV adenosine (D) has a very high likelihood of success, with rapid onset and offset.

 

It may cause very brief chest pain (which is not ischaemic) and very occasionally bronchospasm. Verapamil (B) and beta-blockers (C) may also be effective but have a longer duration of action which is unnecessary here, may cause excessive bradycardia, and are in any case less effective than adenosine.

 

If the patient has severe haemodynamic compromise, DC cardioversion (E) could be considered but would be excessive here.

 

Carotid sinus massage (A) is likely to remain ineffective.

 

SVT is common in young people and may be associated with excessive nicotine, caffeine and alcohol , although they may not take much notice!

Question: A 69-year-old woman complains of intermittent palpitations, lasting several hours, which then stop spontaneously. She also suffers from asthma. Holter monitoring confirms paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the management of this patient?
OptionA: Digoxin effectively prevents recurrence of the arrhythmia
OptionE: Flecainide orally may be an effective as-needed treatment to abort an attack
Explanation:
Oral flecainide (E) is now widely recommended to avoid continuous therapy. Propafenone is used in a similar way.

 

Digoxin (A) is not effective in this situation; sotalol (C) may be used but should be avoided because of this patient’s asthma.

 

Amiodarone (D) is effective, but has numerous serious adverse reactions including pulmonary fibrosis, liver damage,

Question:
A 23 year old male is rushed into A&E following a head injury. 

He doesn't open his eyes upon command but his eyes do open when pressure is applied to his fingers. He is making moaning and groaning noises but is not using recognisable words. 

When a peripheral stimulus is applied, his elbow moves slowly, so that his arm comes across his body. This is abnormal flexion.

 

What score would this man be given on the Glasgow Coma Scale?
Explanation:
Eyes:

 4: Open spontaneously 

3: Open to speech

2: To pain

1: No response

 

Verbal Response

5: Orientated, 4: Confused, 3: Inappropriate words, 2: incomprehensible sounds, 1:No response

 

Motor

6: obeys commands, 5: moves to pain, 4:normal flexion, 3: abnormal flexion, 1: No response.

 

A score of 3 means the patient is unresponsive in all 3 categories. A score of 3-8 is severe. A score between 9-12 is moderate. A score os 12-14 is mild. 15 is the best response.

Question:
A 55-year-old man experiences severe lower back pain for 4 days after moving heavy furniture. After a thorough back evaluation and review of associated radiological imaging, a surgeon removes the herniated portion of the L3-4 intervertebral (IV) disc.

 

What type of cartilage most likely gives the tensile strength of the disc extracted from this patient?

Fibrous cartilage, or ﬁ fibrocartilage, is one of the three types of cartilage composed of chondrocytes that secrete, and are surrounded by, an extensive extracellular matrix composed of collagen ﬁ fibers, elastin ﬁbers, and a plethora of ground substance rich in proteoglycan.

Question: A 45-year-old man goes to his family physician complaining of lower back pain after spending a weekend clearing trees off his property. During examination, the doctor notes a tuft of hair and a dimple on the skin of the patient’s lower back. A plain ﬁlm reveals a congenital defect in his L5 vertebra, indicated by the black arrow in the given X-ray. No other structural abnormalities are noted. Based on these ﬁndings, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
Explanation:
Spina biﬁ da occulta is the mildest form of spina biﬁda (L: split spine). In this developmental disorder, the left and right neural arch elements fail to fuse completely in the dorsal midline. However, the split in the vertebra is so small that the meninges and elements of the spinal cord do not protrude through the defect. In the given plain ﬁ lm, the black arrow indicates a failure of fusion of the laminae of L5, producing a cleft

 

a tuft of hair and/or dimple in the skin overlying the affected vertebral levels, as noted in this patient. Other individuals with this condition may have no visible evidence, a lipoma, or even a birthmark in the overlying skin of the affected region.

Question:
Uzair, a 28-year old cross fit fanatic presents to his GP with left leg pain. On examination of his left leg it was found that he had pain in the lateral aspect of his thigh to the medial side of his calf, sensory loss in the medial aspect of his calf and shin, his knee jerk reflex was absent, grade 3 power on ankle dorsiflexion and grade 3 power on knee extension.

Which nerve root is the GP most likely to suspect is causing his symptoms?
Explanation: L4 nerve root symptoms. The motor symptoms apply to both L3 and L4. However when you contextualise these symptoms with the sensory symptoms then you can conclude that these are L4 nerve root symptoms.
