Question: A patient presents to you in A&E with hypoflexion of elbow joint and lack of sensation over the upper lateral arm. You attempt a bicep tendon reflex but it is absent in the patient. What intervertebral disc is likely to be affected?
Explanation: the C5 nerve root that is affected because the nerve roots exit above the vertebrae in the cervical region. because this lies between C4 and C5, these are the vertebrae affected.

Question: A 59 year-old male enters your GP clinic complaining of leg stiffness and pain. He says that she has difficulties when driving, especially when accelerating her car and sometimes gets a burning sensation across the soles of her right foot. Based on this information, which nerve might most likely be affected?
Explanation: Ans: tibial nerve: as it has both motor and sensory modalities- plantar flexing the foot (e.g. accelerating when driving), and sensory innervation to the soles of the feet (via 3 branches- lateral and medial plantar nerves and the calcaneal branch)

Question: A 45-year-old patient is admitted after an RTA with a possible spinal injury. Upon investigation, you suspect he has a lesion on the left side of his spinal cord at the T4 level as you have found he has muscle weakness in his left leg. What is the specific tract that has been affected by the lesion? :
Explanation: The patient has motor deficits on the left side of his body and since the lesion is below the pyramidal decussation it is the Lateral Corticospinal tract that is being affected ipsilaterally.

Question: You are an F2 on a cardiology block. The consultant shows you the ECG of a 60 year old female with a history of hypertension. She has recently been diagnosed with a left atrial enlargement as a result of her systemic hypertension. What would you expect her ECG to look like?
OptionA:
Sinus rhythm, 75 BPM;

P-wave: bifid P-wave (pronounced notch in P)

QRS complex: normal

T wave: normal
OptionB:
Sinus rhythm, 75 BPM;

P-wave: normal

QRS complex: normal

T-wave: inverted
OptionC:
Sinus rhythm, 75 BPM

P-wave: tall, peaked P-wave

QRS complex: normal

T-wave: normal
OptionD:
Sinus rhythm, 75 BPM;

P-wave: normal

QRS complex: normal

T-wave: pointed and elevated
OptionE:
Sinus rhythm, 75 BPM;

P-wave: wide P wave

QRS complex: normal

T-wave: normal
Explanation:
A left atrial hypertrophy is often associated with systemic hypertension (or can be caused by a congential heart defect). As the atria are what is affected by this condition, it is clear that the p wave is what will be affected in on the ECG. Left atrial enlargement is marked by a normal p-wave which continues into a negative deflection, the p-wave is also wider than usual. This type of P-wave is termed bi-phasic.

 

other notes:

B- an inverted T wave may be caused by left ventricular hypertrophy or ischemia (however, it may be normal)

C- tall, peaked P-wave (also called P-pulmonale) is associated to enlargement of the right atria, this again could be case by congenital heart disease or pulmonary hypertension.

D- pointed and elevated T wave is caused by hyperkalemia

Question: How many vertebrae make up the adult vertebral column?
Explanation:
Answer: C - 33 vertebrae 

 

The adult vertebral column consists of 33 vertebrae arranged into 5 regions;
• 7 cervical
• 12 thoracic
• 5 lumbar
• 5 sacral - fused in adults to form the sacrum
• 4 coccygeal – fused to form the coccyx

 

REF: Essential Clinical Anatomy Moore 5th Edition Pg 266

Question: Between which two vertebrae is there no IV disc?
Explanation:
Answer: A - C1/C2

 

There is no IV disc between the C1/C2 vertebrae.

 

REF: Essential Clinical Anatomy Moore 5th ed Pg. 280

Question: Where does the spinal cord end in adults?
Explanation:
Answer: B - L1/2

 

• In newborns it ends opposite the IV disc between L2 and L3
• In adults it ends opposite the IV disc between L1 and L2

 

REF: Essential Clinical Anatomy Moore 5th ed Pg. 288

Question: How much of the spinal cord is supplied by the anterior spinal artery?
Explanation:
Answer: B - Anterior 2/3

 

The anterior spinal artery supplies the anterior 2/3 of the spinal cord. The other 1/3 is supplied by the two posterior spinal arteries. 

 

REF: Essential Clinical Anatomy Moore 5th ed Pg. 292

Dr McCarthy Cord Syndrome Tutorial

Question: What is the route taken for a Lumbar puncture?
Explanation:
Answer: A - 

Skin
Subcutaneous tissue
Supraspinous L.
Interspinous L.
L.Flavum
Epidural space
Dura

 

REF: Essential Clinical Anatomy Moore 5th ed Pg. 294

Dr Johnston Lumbar Puncture Tutorial

Dr De Lloyd Anaesthesia and analgesia in childbirth

Question: What route is taken for an Epidural?
Explanation:
Answer: D - 

Skin
Subcutaneous tissue
Supraspinous L.
Interspinous L.
L.Flavum
Epidural space

 

REF: Essential Clinical Anatomy Moore 5th ed Pg. 294
Dr De Lloyd Anaesthesia and analgesia in childbirth

Question: What are the features of anterior cord syndrome?
OptionA:
Bilateral spastic paralysis

Loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure

Some degree of sacral sparing

Preservation of proprioception, vibration and 2-point discrimination
OptionB:
Bilateral spastic paralysis
Loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure
Some degree of sacral sparing
Loss of proprioception, vibration and 2-point discrimination
OptionC:
Bilateral spastic paralysis
Loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure
No of sacral sparing
Preservation of proprioception, vibration and 2-point discrimination
OptionD:
Loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure
Some degree of sacral sparing
Preservation of proprioception, vibration and 2-point discrimination
OptionE:
Bilateral spastic paralysis
Loss of light touch and pressure
Some degree of sacral sparing
Preservation of proprioception, vibration and 2-point discrimination
Explanation:
Answer: A - 

Bilateral spastic paralysis
Loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure
Some degree of sacral sparing
Preservation of proprioception, vibration and 2-point discrimination

 

There is damage to the corticospinal tract on both sides - Bilateral spastic paralysis

There is damage to both the lateral and anterior spinothalamic tracts - Loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure

The dorsal column pathways are located posteriorly and are supplied by the posterior spinal arteries - Preservation of proprioception, vibration and 2-point discrimination

There is also some degree of sacral sparing

 

REF: Dr McCarthy Cord Syndromes Tutorial

Question: What is the recovery pattern of central cord syndrome?
Explanation:
Answer: E - Lower limbs > Bladder > Upper limbs > Sensory

 

The spinal cord has a laminated structure and where the lower limbs are on the periphery and upper limbs are towards the center. This means that the inner (center) aspect is most like to be damage as it is more likely to get ischaemic. 

 

REF: Dr MacCarthy Cord Syndrome Tutorial

Question: What are the features of Brown-Sequard syndrome?
OptionA:
Contralateral paralysis
Contralateral loss of proprioception and vibration
Contralateral loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure
OptionB:
Ipsilateral paralysis
Contralateral loss of proprioception and vibration
Contralateral loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure
OptionC:
Ipsilateral paralysis

Ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration

Contralateral loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure
OptionD:
Contralateral paralysis
Ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration
Contralateral loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure
OptionE:
Ipsilateral paralysis
Ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration
Ipsilateral loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure
Explanation:
Answer: C - 

Ipsilateral paralysis
Ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration
Contralateral loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure

 

The corticospinal tract decussates at the brain stem - this means that the same side will be affected

The dorsal column pathway decussates at the medulla oblongata - this means that the same side will be affected

The spinothalamic tract decussates at the spinal cord - this means the opposite side will be affected

 

REF: Dr McCarthy Cord Syndrome Tutorial

Question: A patient presents to her GP with a 2-day history of lower back pain, pain and weakness in her right leg, urinary, and bowel incontinence. You decide to do a rectal examination and notice that she cannot squeeze her rectal sphincter. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Answer: B - Cauda Equina syndrome

 

A spectrum of low back pain, uni / bilateral
sciatica, saddle anaesthesia and motor
weakness in the lower extremities with
variable rectal and urinary symptoms
– Usually due to a canal filling disc compressing
the entire cauda equina
– Others causes = Tumour Infection Trauma

Sphincteric disturbance is seen on rectal examination

 

This patient should be sent to the hospital for rapid treatment to relieve compression of the nerves- timing is very important.

 

REF: Dr McCarthy Serious Spinal Pathology 1 Lecture

Question: What percentage of patients with a spinal infection will have a genitourinary tract source?
Explanation:
Answer: C - 50%

 

The Rule of 50%

 

REF: Dr McCarthy Serious Spinal Pathology 2 Lecture

Question: What are the features of posterior cord syndrome?
OptionA: Loss of proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination
Explanation:
Answer: A - Loss of proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination

 

The dorsal column pathways located at the dorsal aspect of the spinal cord - they carry information to the brain about proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination. Posterior cord syndrome affects these pathways and results in loss of its functions. 

 

REF: Dr McCarthy Cord Syndrome Tutorial

Question: A 23-year-old man presents to the rheumatology clinic with lower back and hip pain. These have been occurring every day for the past two months. Pain and stiffness are worse in the mornings. He also mentions that his right heel has been hurting. He is previously fit and well, but had occasions of lower back pain when he was a teenager. His symptoms have stopped him from playing tennis. Recent blood tests organized by his GP have shown a raised C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). What is the most appropriate treatment?
Explanation: This is a difficult question as it requires knowledge of the diagnosis and then knowledge of the treatment. The case presented is of a patient with ankylosing spondylosis. The diagnosis is clinical, with involvement of the sacroiliac joint as the earliest manifestation. The disease course is variable and may progress to a marked kyphosis of the spine. Other features include enthesitis (such as the Archilles tendon enthesitis in this case), costochondritis, peripheral joint involvement (usually asymmetrical and involving the large joints), aortic regurgitation, apical pulmonary fibrosis and amyloidosis. The ESR and CRP are usually raised. Initial x-rays may be unremarkable. However, later in the disease, syndesmophytes (bony spurs due to inflammatory enthesitis) may be seen between vertebrae resulting in the characteristic bamboo spine appearance. Ankylosing spondylosis is managed with exercises, not bed rest. NSAIDs are given, unless there are contraindications, for the management of pain. Therefore, NSAID and spinal exercises (A) is the correct answer and NSAID and bed rest (B) and bed rest (E) are incorrect. Local steroid injections may be used for pain relief, particularly for peripheral arthritis and enthesitis. However, oral prednisolone (C) is not normally used. Methotrexate and sulfasalazine (D) may be given to patients with peripheral arthritis, but do not help the back pain, making this answer incorrect.

Question: A 32-year-old man presents to the minor injuries walk-in clinic, complaining of back pain. This had started suddenly that morning after he had lifted a heavy box at home. He mentions that the pain has been shooting down his left leg and he cannot walk without the support of his friend. He has not passed urine since the onset of pain. On neurological examination of the lower limbs, tone and power cannot be assessed due to pain but there are decreased ankle reflexes and a sacral anaesthesia. What is the most appropriate next step?
OptionA: Give NSAID analgesia and complete neurological examination
OptionB: Send the patient home with NSAID analgesia and bed rest advice
OptionD: Give NSAID analgesia and catheterize the patient
OptionE: Send the patient home with NSAID analgesia and advice to avoid heavy lifting
Explanation: The history and examination should raise the suspicion of cauda equina syndrome. This is a medical emergency and permanent neurological deficit may occur without urgent intervention. The shooting pain down the left leg, absence of ankle jerk reflex and urinary retention suggest that the L5/ S1 disk has prolapsed into the cauda equina and nerve root. The patient must be sent to accident and emergency (C) without delay for assessment, MRI of the spine and subsequent neurosurgical referral. Therefore, sending the patient home, as described by options (B) and (E) is inappropriate. A complete neurological examination (A) is desirable, but should not delay transfer to accident and emergency for MRI. Similarly, the patient will require a catheter (D), but this should not delay transfer to accident and emergency. It is important to note that while intramuscular NSAID analgesia can be used for patients with cauda equina syndrome, stronger opiate analgesia may be required.

Question: A 70-year-old woman with a history of vertebral crush fractures presents to the osteoporosis outpatient clinic. Which of the following investigations is most useful to assess the extent of her osteoporosis?
OptionC: Full blood count, bone and liver biochemistry blood tests
Explanation: Osteoporosis is a loss of the bone mass. It is important to note that the mineralization of the bone is normal. This loss of bone mass means there is an increasing likelihood of fracture with increasing age. Due to the accelerated loss of bone mass following the menopause, elderly women are at a higher risk of osteoporosis than men. There are numerous risk factors for the development of osteoporosis. Among them are Caucasian and Asian ethnic groups, female sex, increasing age, early menopause, smoking, excess alcohol, corticosteroid use, hypogonadism and rheumatoid arthritis. The reduced bone mass of osteoporosis may result in vertebral crush fractures, the majority of which are asymptomatic. The extent of osteoporosis is best investigated with a dual energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan (E). This gives a T score, which is the number of standard deviations the patient’s bone mineral density differs from the population average for a young healthy adult. The World Health Organization defines osteoporosis as a T score of −2.5 or greater (i.e. the bone mineral density of more than 2.5 standard deviations below that of the average for a young healthy adult). A T score of between −1.5 and −2.5 is defined as osteopenia.

Question:
a 71-year-old-man’s car is struck from behind by a truck going approximately 30 mph (48 kph). The man is brought to the ER suffering from a severe hyperextension neck injury due to the crash.

 

The given T2-weighted MRI shows a rupture of the anterior anulus of the C4-5 intervertebral disc, inﬂ

inﬂammation of that disc (the white appearance), and a prevertebral hematoma, which compromised his airway and required intubation. Which of the following ligaments is disrupted in this injury?
Explanation: The anterior longitudinal ligament is a vertical connective tissue band that attaches along the anterior aspects of the vertebral bodies. Its peripheral ﬁ bers have strong attachments to the intervertebral discs. The anterior longitudinal ligament resists hyperextension of the vertebral column. However, in this patient, the extreme forces involved with the hyperextension of the neck overpowers the resistance of this ligament, rupturing it as well as displacing part of the C4-5 intervertebral disc

Question:
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS; Lou Gehrig’s disease) is a progressive, fatal neurodegenerative disease caused by degeneration of the motor neurons controlling skeletal (voluntary) muscle movement. Postmortem analysis of which of the following structures would show the cell bodies of neurons affected by this disease?

 


Ps: ALS  = UMN lesion
OptionA: Anterior gray horn of the spinal cord
OptionB: Lateral gray horn of the spinal cord
OptionC: posterior gray horn of the spinal cord
OptionE: Lateral column of spinal cord white matter
Explanation: Cell bodies of somatic motor neurons (a-motor neurons) innervating skeletal muscle are located within the anterior (ventral) gray horn of the spinal cord, at all segmental levels throughout the entire length of the spinal cord. The innervation of the skeletal muscles affected by ALS is through somatic motor (general somatic efferent or GSE) neurons and branchial motor (special visceral efferent or SVE) neurons (neurons that supply the embryonic pharyngeal arches). In ALS patients, postmortem analysis of the anterior gray horn of the spinal cord would show signiﬁ cant degeneration. In the given diagram, the anterior gray horn of the spinal cord is labeled as “A.” The locations for all ﬁ ve possible choices for this question are also indicated in this ﬁ gur

Question: A 19-year-old girl gives birth to a baby girl diagnosed with a meningomyelocele, as seen in the given midsagittal MRI. The mother lived in a rural area and did not have prenatal visits with her obstetrician. Which of the following drugs, if taken in the proper doses during the periconceptional period, would have greatly reduced the chances of her fetus having a neural tube defect (NTD)?
Explanation: Supplementing a diet with folic acid (vitamin B9 or folacin) has been shown to reduce the incidence of NTDs up to 70%. Neural tube closure occurs within the ﬁ rst 28 days after conception, and at this time in the pregnancy, many mothers do not realize they are pregnant. Women anticipating getting pregnant should take 400 mg of folic acid daily beginning 3 months prior to conception and continue the folic acid supplement throughout their pregnancy. NTD prevention is best achieved by adequate daily folic acid intake throughout the reproductive years. In this neonate, the sagittal MRI revealed a neural tube defect called a meningomyelocele, so the defect in the cervical region involves the meninges (meningo-), the spinal cord (myelo-) and the membranous sac (-cele). A meningomyelocele is the most common form of spina biﬁ da cystica

Question: An internal medicine attending physician asks a medical student to place the bell of her stethoscope on the triangle of auscultation to hear a patient’s breathing sounds. Which of the following structures make up the boundaries of this triangle of back breathing?
Explanation: The triangle of auscultation is a space in the back bounded by the lateral edge of the trapezius muscle, medial border of the scapula, and upper edge of the latissimus dorsi muscle. Placing a stethoscope within the triangle of auscultation enables the medical student to hear breathing sounds because (1) this site offers a gap between layers of bone and muscle, and (2) the location lies directly over the midposterior chest wall and the lung, which is ideal for auscultation

Question: A 34-year-old man fell 25 ft out of a barn loft, landing on his back. He was found unconscious and taken to the ER. The given sagittal CT reformat image reveals a T9 spinal fracture dislocation, as noted by the black arrow. The patient had unequivocal clinical findings indicating spinal cord transection at T9. Given the results of this CT image and the clinical information, what deficits will the patient incur?
OptionD: Loss of only sensory information below the lesion
OptionE: Loss of only motor function below the lesion
Explanation: Transection of the spinal cord results in loss of all motor and sensory functions movements that emerge from the cord inferior to the site of the lesion. General sensory, somatic motor, and visceral motor ﬁ bers for the pelvis and lower limbs would be lost inferior to the level of T9 due to the transection of the spinal cord. Also, parasympathetic outﬂ ow to the pelvis and perineum would be eliminated due to the origin of these nerve ﬁ bers from S2-4. The CT image reveals a T9 spinal fracture dislocation, and the clinical ﬁ ndings indicate a spinal cord transection. Therefore, this patient would present with paraplegia (or paralysis of both lower limbs), fecal and urinary incontinence, impotence, and loss of motor functions and sensation below the level of the T9 lesion, which is right above the level of the umbilicus (supplied by T10)

Question: A 35-year-old woman suffers intractable pain in her left forearm. Neurosurgical consultation leads to a decision to conduct a rhizotomy to relieve the condition. At which of the following locations is the rhizotomy best performed to relieve the patient’s pain?
Explanation: A rhizotomy is a neurosurgical procedure that selectively severs problematic spinal nerve roots to relieve pain or spastic paralysis (e.g., as often seen in cerebral palsy patients). The posterior roots are the only site where afferent (sensory) ﬁbers are segregated from efferent (motor) ﬁbers. In selective dorsal rhizotomy (SDR), severing the left C6-8 posterior roots could relieve the pain symptoms in the left forearm of this patient because they carry only sensory information

Question: An 81-year-old woman visits her family physician for an annual physical examination and complains of weakness and loss of sensation in her legs. Radiological studies show bony spurs (osteophytes) narrowing the intervertebral foramina at levels T12-L3. Which of the following structures is most likely to be impinged in this condition?
Explanation: The posterior (dorsal) and anterior (ventral) roots of spinal nerves typically merge within the intervertebral foramina to form individual spinal nerves. Because the spinal (dorsal root) ganglia are located at the distal ends of the posterior roots, they are also normally found within the intervertebral foramina. Thus, narrowing (stenosis) or compression of the intervertebral foramina may cause impingement of the posterior and anterior roots, spinal nerves, and spinal ganglia due to the presence of bony spurs (osteophytes) in this patient

Question: A 16-year-old male soccer player was brought to the A  & E  because of the acute lower back pain he experienced after performing a high-velocity kick of the ball. The given right posterior oblique X-ray reveals pathology within the L5 vertebra that has the appearance of a “headless Scottie Dog” when outlined. Based upon the X-ray results, which of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of his lower back pain?
Explanation: “headless Scottie Dog = spondolysis / defect in pars interarticularis of the vertebrae

Question: A physician orders a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) for his 43-year-old female patient in order to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal ﬂ uid (CSF). He explains to her that this procedure will be done in the lower back, between the spinous processes of the L3 and L4 vertebrae. What is the best reason for performing the lumbar puncture at this location?
OptionA: The medullary cone (conus medullaris ) ends at or above the L3 level
OptionB: The subarachnoid space ends at the L3 level
OptionC: The intervertebral foramina at L3-4 are large and easy to penetrate
OptionD: No vertebral venous plexuses exist below the L3 level
OptionE: The ligamenta ﬂava are absent below the L3 level
Explanation: spinal colrd = conus medullaris

Question: A 22-year-old man is brought to the A&E with severe back pain and lower limb weakness after falling off the top of a 16-ft ladder and landing on his feet. The A&E physician orders a CT scan, and the given midsagittal CT directs the physician toward making which of the following diagnoses?
Explanation:
The sagittal CT clearly shows a burst (crush or compression)
fracture of the 12th thoracic vertebral body (T12). This T12 burst fracture also presents with a fracture fragment that is displaced posterior into the vertebral canal where it would compress the terminal end of the spinal cord, the medullary cone (conus medullaris), which typically lies within the T12-L3 vertebral levels. Compression of the spinal cord would lead to pain within the lower back that would likely extend in the lower limbs

Question: After several months of engaging in a vigorous exercise program, a 28-year-old woman experiences periodic pain and muscle spasms in her left upper limb. Thorough physical and radiographic examinations by her primary care physician and a consulting surgeon determine that she suffers a posterolateral herniation of the C5-6 intervertebral disc. Which of the following structures is this herniation most likely impinging?
OptionE: C7 posterior horn segment of the spinal cord
Explanation: Classic posterolateral herniation of the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc occurs most often within the C4-5 and L4-5 intervertebral discs. A herniated nucleus pulposus may displace or disrupt the posterior longitudinal ligament and extend into the vertebral canal and impinge upon spinal nerve roots either within the vertebral canal or as they traverse the intervertebral foramen (or both).

Question: During a head-on motor vehicular accident (MVA), the upper cervical vertebrae of a 34-year-old woman are ﬂ exed violently forward until her head impacts the steering wheel and is thrown into hyperextension and slight rotation. She is immobilized and brought to an A&E. The given sagittal CT of her upper cervical vertebrae is viewed by a radiologist and reveals which of the following diagnoses?
OptionD: Ruptured intervertebral disc between C1 and C2
OptionE: No pathology is apparent on the CT scan
Explanation: The sagittal CT clearly shows a Type II dens axis (odontoid process) fracture, which is the most common type of fracture (approximately 60% of cases) involving the dens. This fracture occurs at the base of the dens where it extends superiorly from the axis (or second cervical vertebra). The precise mechanism for odontoid fractures is unknown, but it most likely includes a combination of ﬂ exion, extension, and rotation

Question:
As a result of multiple vertebral fractures incurred in an
automobile crash, an 8-year-old girl suffers a series of torn posterior primary rami of spinal nerves C1-6. Which of the following muscles will be paralyzed as a result?
Explanation: Splenius capitus are superficial intrinscis back muscles supply by posterior rami of spinal nerve, rest of them are supplied by brachical plexus .

Question: A 73-year-old man comes to his physician complaining of a tingling numbness within the fourth and ﬁ fth digits of his right hand. These symptoms are exacerbated when he looks up at the ceiling. The given sagittal T2-weighted MRI reveals degenerative changes in his cervical vertebrae. Which of the following diagnoses is conﬁrmed by the MRI and would result in the symptoms of this patient?
Explanation: Cervical spinal stenosis describes a narrowing of the vertebral canal that is typically seen in older individuals with degenerative change in the cervical spine . In the given MRI, the vertebral canal, which houses the spinal cord, is impinged by intervertebral disc degeneration in the midcervical region, which results in no cerebral spinal ﬂuid (CSF), which appears as a hyperintense (white) signal in this MRI, being visible anterior or posterior to the spinal cor

Question: A 17-year-old gymnast grips a high bar with his arms outstretched and begins to pull himself straight upward to the level of the bar, as in doing a chin-up. Which of the following muscles is the prime agonist in this action?
Explanation: The latissimus dorsi (L: widest muscle of back) is a large, fan-shaped muscle and a member of the superﬁ cial extrinsic layer of back muscles, which connect the upper limbs to the trunk.  Powerful chin up muscle

Question: 77-year-old man presents with shingles on his anterolateral abdomen and umbilicus, as shown in the ﬁ gure. Shingles (or herpes zoster) is caused by the varicella zoster virus, which resides latent in sensory ganglia in the body for many years. When a patient is immunocompromised, this virus can cause a painful skin rash called shingles, which usually presents unilaterally along the infected nerve’s dermatome distribution. Given the location of the rash, what ganglion is most likely affected in this patient?
Explanation: T10 abodmen

Question: A 35-year-old man presents with pain radiating from his lower back into his left lower limb, periodic sensory loss and paresthesia in that limb, and associated motor weakness. His physician suspects unilateral entrapment of lumbar nerve roots secondary to a herniated lumbar intervertebral disc. In examining the patient, the physician conducts a straight-leg raising test. Which of the following best describes a positive straight-leg raising sign (Lasèque’s sign) for this condition in this patient?
OptionA: Walking while keeping the left leg in a straight position (i.e., the knee is kept straight) relieves the pain in the back and limb
OptionB: Flexing the hip by raising the straightened left leg (i.e., the knee is kept straight) with the patient lying in the supine position relieves the pain in the back and leg
OptionC: Abducting the hip by raising the straightened left leg with the patient lying on his right side relieves the pain in the back and leg
OptionD: Flexing the hip by raising the straightened left leg with the patient lying in the supine position increases pain in the back with radiation down the left leg
OptionE: Extending the hip by raising the straightened left leg with the patient lying in the prone position increases pain in the back with radiation down the left leg
Explanation: straight leg test for sciatica

Question: An anesthesiologist administers epidural anesthestic immediately lateral to the spinous processes of vertebrae L3 and L4 of a pregnant woman in labor. During this procedure, what would be the last ligament perforated by the needle in order to access the epidural space?
Explanation:
The ligamentum ﬂ avum (L: yellow ligament) consists of yellow elastic ﬁ brous
tissue, which binds together the laminae of adjoining vertebrae and forms the posterior wall of the vertebral canal. During proper administration of an epidural anesthetic, the needle will pass (in order) through the supraspinous ligament overlying the spinous processes of the lumbar vertebrae, the interspinous ligament connecting the spinous processes of adjacent vertebrae, and ﬁ nally the ligamentum ﬂ avum

Question: During a routine prenatal examination of a pregnant 16-year-old woman entering her second trimester (15 weeks of gestation), elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels were detected and later conﬁ rmed by amniocentesis. A follow-up diagnostic ultrasound examination reveals defects in the lower back of the fetus. In the given longitudinal ultrasound scan, open arrows indicate the bases of the vertebrae, and solid arrows point to a cyst-like sac containing protruding neural tissue. Which of the following terms best describes this neural tube defect?
Explanation: A meningomyelocele is the most common form of spina biﬁ da cystica. In this developmental disorder, the unfused portion of the vertebral column allows the meninges and the spinal cord to protrude through the structural defect, as noted in this longitudinal ultrasound

Question: A 46-year-old supervisor was reading a work order on a construction site when a 60 lb bag of concrete mix was accidentally dropped on the apex of his head. He was immobilized and brought to the A&E where he presented with upper neck pain but no neurological signs. Based upon the given axial CT scan and the patient’s presentation, which of the following diagnoses is most likely
OptionB: No pathology is apparent on the CT scan
Explanation: The C1 vertebra, or atlas, is normally a closed ring with no vertebral body. Excessive vertical, or downward, force on the top of the head can fracture the anterior and posterior arches of C1 in multiple places, leading to a Jefferson (burst) fracture of C1. Due to the vertical force of the concrete mix striking the top of the man’s head, the lateral masses of C1 are driven laterally due to the oblique articulation between the occipital condyles and the superior articular processes of the lateral masses of C1. This vertical compression force fractures the anterior and posterior arches of C1 bilaterally, as conﬁ rmed by the axial CT scan. Jefferson fractures of C1 often occur with axial loading force when the top of the head is impacted by a hard or heavy object. Because the fractures within the bony ring of the atlas actually increase its dimension, this type of fracture does not usually result in spinal cord injury; however, upper neck pain would be present. The axial CT scan conﬁ rms the diagnosis of a Jefferson (burst) fracture of C1.

Question: A 12-year-old girl is examined by a school nurse who notices the girl’s right scapula is more prominent than the left, her head is not centered directly over the pelvis, and her right hip is raised and more prominent. When the girl is asked to bend forward at the waist, the nurse observes asymmetry of the trunk. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
Explanation: coliosis (G: crookedness) is abnormal lateral and rotational curvature of the spine that may present with uneven hips, shoulders, and rib cage, a head that is not centered over the pelvis, the entire body leaning to one side, back pain, and/or fatigue. The given AnteriorPosterior (AP) X-ray shows an S-shaped curvature of the spine or vertebral column in this patient. In this X-ray, no apparent vertebral anomaly is apparent, so the diagnosis is most likely adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, which has an onset of 10 to 18 years of age and has no known cause. Most cases of adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (with curvatures of less than 20 degrees) require no treatment; however, if the curvature goes above 25 degrees, a back brace can be implemented to slow the progression of scoliosis.

Question: After moving his parents’ heavy furniture out of their house, a 38-year-old man experiences lower back pain and presents to his doctor with tingling numbness radiating down his right lower limb to the lateral part of his foot. A thorough physical examination reveals weakness when standing on the toes of his right foot. A T1-weighted MRI revealed an intervertebral disc herniation, as indicated by the white arrow. Which of the following structures is most likely impinged by this disc herniation?
Explanation:
L5/S1 herniation hence S1 compression . 

 

Approximately 90% of intervertebral disc herniations occur toward the bottom of the spine at the L4-5 or L5-S1 segments. This T1-weighted MRI reveals posterolateral herniation of the nucleus pulposus of the L5-S1 intervertebral disc, as indicated by the white arrow. Remember that a herniated nucleus pulposus may displace or disrupt the posterior longitudinal ligament and extend into the vertebral canal and impinge upon spinal nerve roots either within the vertebral canal or as they traverse the intervertebral foramen (or both)

Question:
Attempting to do a backﬂ ip with his bicycle off a high ramp at the ﬁnish line of a race, a 24-year-old professional BMX rider fell from a height of 20 ft and attempted to land on his feet.

 

A sagittal CT reveals a burst fracture of the L5 vertebral body with a posterior displaced fracture fragment compressing the medullary cone (conus medullaris). Which of the following spinal cord segments would most likely be impinged by the bone fragment in this injury?
Explanation:
Compress the nerve below 

 

The medullary cone (conus medullaris) is the tapered terminal end of the spinal cord, composed of the sacral and coccygeal segments. In adults, the conus medullaris typically lies within the T12-L3 vertebral levels, but it generally ends at approximately L2. Thus, displacement fractures of these vertebrae are likely to affect one or more of the sacral-coccygeal spinal cord segments.

 

 

In this case, given the statistical range of variation for the medullary cone, the displaced fracture fragment of the L1 vertebral body is more likely to impinge the lower lumbar and upper sacral segments of the medullary cone. S1 is the only choice from this region. When thinking of the spinal cord, remember the “rule of 2,” which states the conus medullaris usually ends at the second lumbar vertebra (L2); the subarachnoid space ends at the second sacral vertebra (S2); and the terminal ﬁ lum (ﬁ lum terminale), a long connective tissue (pia mater) strand extending from the end of the medullary cone that anchors the inferior aspect of the spinal cord, usually attaches to the second coccygeal vertebra (Co2). Due to the location of the displaced fracture fragment of the L2 vertebral body, the higher sacral segments of the spinal cord related to the medullary cone are more likely to be damaged.

Question:
A 45 year old woman of African family origin, has been hypertensive despite making lifestyle changes.

Her GP is considering anti-hypertensive therapy.

What would be the most appropriate first line medication?
OptionC: An Angiotensin II Receptor Antagonist e.g. Losartan
Explanation:
First line treatment for patients under 55 is an ACE inhibitor (or an ARB if not tolerated) Step 2: ACE/ARB+ Calcium channel blocker

 

For patients over 55/ patients of African or Caribbean family origin, the first line treatment is a Calcium channel blocker (or a thiaide related diuretic if not tolerated or heat failure.) Step 2: Calcium channel blocker/ diuretic +ACE inhibitor or ARB. 

 

Steps 3 and 4 are the same: 3)  ACE inhibitor+ Calcium channel blocker + Thiazide-related diuretic 

Step 4: specialist advice--> Spinoloatone.

 

NICE guidance

Question: A woman comes into clinic at 24/40 and is told her baby is at a high risk of hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN). To prevent the mother producing anti-D antibodies, injections of anti-D are administered to destoy any fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation before she can start producing her own antibodies to them. Which of the following options is the highest risk for HDN?
OptionA: Privigradia RhD negative mother with a RhD positive fetus
OptionB: Second pregnancy RhD negative mother with a RhD positive fetus
OptionC: Privigradia RhD positive mother with RhD negative fetus
OptionD: Second pregnancy RhD positive mother with RhD negative fetus
OptionE: Privigradia RhD positive mother with RhD positive fetus
Explanation: If a mother is not Rhesus D positive, the Rhesus D antigen will not be present in her blood. If her first child was Rhesus D positive, they will have the antigen. During a sensitising event, such as childbirth, the mother may be exposed to the antigen resulting in her producing antibodies. The first child is not likely to be affected, because during the pregnancy, unless there is a sensitising event, she will not produce the antibodies. However, if the second baby is also Rhesus positive, because the antibodies the mother has produced are IgM, they can cross the placenta, come into contact with the baby and cause HDN.

Question: Which of the following interventions has been shown to best improve the BMD in osteoporotic patients?
Explanation: Normal bone health and bone disease lecture

Question: What is the normal range of serum calcium levels in mmol/L?
Explanation: Normal Bone Health and Bone Disease Lecture

Question: What biochemical changes are observed in patients with osteomalacia?
OptionA: Low Phosphate, Low calcium, High ALP, High PTH
OptionB: Normal Phosphate, normal calcium, normal ALP, normal PTH
OptionC: Low phosphate, high calcium, high ALP, high PTH
OptionD: High phosphate, low calcium, high ALP, high PTH
OptionE: High phosphate, high calcium, high ALP, low PTH
Explanation: Normal Bone Health and Bone Disease Lecture

Question: Which of the following environmental risks do not increase the chance of developing colorectal cancer?
Explanation:
Factors that increase the risk of colorectal cancer include; red meat, wheat bran, high BMI in males, smoking 

 

Factors that lower the risk of colorectal cancer include; fruit and vegetable consumption, oily fish, high BMI in females, exercise and NSAIDs.

Question: Roughly how many people in the Western world will develop colorectal cancer?
Explanation:
The correct answer is B) 1 in 20. 

1 in 5 patient with bowel cancer will have a close relative with bowel cancer. CRC mainly occurs near the sigmoid colon and rectum. 

 

In Lynch syndrome patients, the lifetime cancer risk for CRC in men is 20-55% and 19-52% in females.

Question: Mutations in which of the following genes is associated with Familial Adedomatous Polyposis (FAP)?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C. Mutations in APC are associated with FAP. FAP follows an autosomal pattern of inheritance. 

 

The other gene mutations i.e. PMS2, MLH1, MSH6 and MSH2 are all mutations associated with Lynch Syndrome.

Question: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding environmental factors associated with Lynch Syndrome?
OptionB: Having more children increases the risk of developing CRC in LS patients.
OptionC: Hormone replacement therapy decreases risk of CRC.
OptionD: Oral contraceptive pill has no effect on the risk of CRC.
OptionE: A high BMI in females increases the risk of CRC in Lynch Syndrome patients.
Explanation:
B is incorrect. Having more children actually decreases the risk of CRC in Lynch syndrome patients. 

 

Interestingly,  a high BMI in females in the general population is associated with a reduced risk of CRC. However, in LS patients having a high BMI for females does in fact increase the risk of CRC.

Question: Which of the following drug/ drug classes is most likely to be used for mild-moderate active disease in Ulcerative Colitis patients?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C) Mesalazine. 

Mesalazine is standard treatment for mild-moderate UC. However, it is not used for Crohn's Disease. It can be given by oral, enema, suppository route. 

 

Corticosteroids and anti-TNF drugs are only indicated for severe active disease for UC. 

 

Mesalazine can also be used for maintenance of remission.

Question: Which of the following treatments is not indicated for Crohn's Disease?
Explanation:
Mesalazine is not indicated for CD but it is indicated for mild-moderate active disease in UC patients. 

The treatment for CD is as follows: 

 

Mild - moderate active disease: A locally active corticosteroids such as Budesonide, dietary therapy, antibiotics 

Severe active disease: corticosteroids, Anti-TNF 

Maintenance of remission: azathioprine, anti-TNF drugs

Question: Which of the following anti-TNF antibodies are gut specific?
Explanation: D is the correct answer. Vedolizumab is a newer, targeted antibody that works in the gut. The drug is a gut-specific lymphocyte traffic inhibitor. It binds to integrins a4b6 that sit on the surface of leukocytes. It prevents the traffic of lymphocytes to the gut. It is a good drug as it does not effect the immune response in other parts of the body.

Question: Which of the following is used as a treatment for influenza?
Explanation:
The correct answer should be: amantadine

 

A) Fentanyl - this is an opioid used in spinal injections (labour). It is an agonist at μ-opioid receptors.

 

B) Digoxin - this is used to treat AF and atrial flutter

 

C) Ranitidine - this is a histamine (H2) receptor antagonist. It blocks acid secretion from gastric parietal cells.

 

D) Amantadine - it works by blocking the pore of the M2 ion channel located within the virus envelope, preventing virus replication. However, efficacy of this drug is negligible. 

 

E) Cetirizine - this is a histamine (H1) receptor antagonist. It suppresses the hyper-sensitised immune response to allergens.

 

Neuraminidase inhibition is also used as a treatment for influenza. Neuraminidase enables viruses to leave the host cell, so inhibition prevents the virus from leaving host cells and subsequently prevents further infection. However, the inhibitor is only effective if used immediately after the onset of symptoms, and overall only shortens the duration of infection by 1 day.

Question: When is a CT scan indicated in spinal injury?
OptionB: Plain radiographs have failed to visualise all the cervical spine
Explanation: Spine Dragon's Lecture

Question: Adam is an 18-year-old boy who has been brought into A&E after being stabbed in a fight. He has been stabbed at the left of T8, and the doctor in charge suspects Adam is suffering with Brown-Sequard syndrome. What symptoms is Adam likely to be presenting with?
OptionA:
Right side paralysis, loss of pain and vibration below the injury

Left side loss of proprioception, temperature and light touch below the injury
OptionB:
Right side loss of pain and light touch below the injury

Left side loss of proprioception and vibration below the injury

Retained motor function on both sides
OptionC:
Right side loss of pain, temperature and light touch below the injury
Left side paralysis and loss of proprioception and vibration above the injury
OptionD:
Right side loss of pain, temperature and light touch below the injury

Left side paralysis and loss of proprioception and vibration below the injury
OptionE:
Right side loss of proprioception, temperature and light touch below the injury

Left side paralysis, loss of pain and vibration below the injury
Explanation:
The correct answer should be: D - Right side loss of pain, temperature and light touch, left side paralysis and loss of proprioception and vibration (all below the injury)

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome is a spinal cord lesion following lateral hemisection of the cord, usually due to a penetrating injury (in Adam's case, a stab wound). Because Adam has been stabbed in the left portion of T8, he would have ipsilateral (left) paralysis, loss of proprioception and vibration and contralateral (right) loss of pain, temperature, and light touch. This is to do with the spinal tracts:

 

The spinothalamic tracts carry pain, temperature and light touch, and decussate (cross over) in the spinal cord, so any of this information coming from the right side of his body below the level of injury would have immediately crossed over and be ascending in the left side of his body - where the lesion is - so cannot travel any further.

Information coming from the left would immediately decussate to the right where there is no lesion so there is no loss of spinothalamic tract information on the left.

 

The corticospinal tracts carry motor function and decussate in the medulla (mostly) so it makes sense that motor control information descending on the left side of his body would not be able to travel past the left sided lesion, and so he would be paralysed on the left side of his body below the level of injury.

The right side would not be paralysed because information intended for the right side of the body would have already decussated to the right in the medulla, and there is no lesion blocking this on the right, hence the lack of right-sided paralysis.

 

The dorsal column pathway carries vibration and proprioception and decussates in the medulla, so only the left side is affected. This pathway is ascending so information from the left side of the body below the lesion cannot travel past the lesion to decussate in the medulla - hence why only the left is affected.

The right side has no lesion so information from the right can ascend without interference and decussate in the medulla.

Question: A short teenage girl with neck webbing comes into your clinic with concerns about lack of periods. You ascertain this is primary amenorrhoea. An ultrasound shows her to have streak ovaries and few ovarian follicles. You suspect a chromosomal abnormality. Which is abnormality is this girl most likely to have?
Explanation: Chromosomal abnormalities plenary

Question: Which of the following groups of congenital heart defects are characteristic of tetralogy of Fallot?
OptionA: Ventricular septal defect, transposition of great vessels, valvular stenosis
OptionB: Right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis
OptionC: Ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, patent ductus arteriosus
OptionD: Patent ductus arteriosus, left ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect
OptionE: Valvular stenosis, patent ductus arteriosus, transposition of great vessels, pulmonary stenosis
Explanation:
The correct answer should be B - Right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis

 

These four defects tend to present together in tetralogy of Fallot (and are most characteristic of the condition), although other defects can present as part of the condition e.g. left pulmonary artery stenosis etc.

 

Other congenital heart defects listed above:

  • Ventricular septal defect - not always confined to the membranous part, it can involve the muscular part of the septum
  • Patent ductus arteriosus - failure of ductus arteriosus to close after birth (risk is increased in pre-term babies)
  • Transposition of great vessels - abnormal spatial arrangement of any of the great vessels e.g. SVC/IVC, pulmonary artery, pulmonary veins, aorta
  • Valvular stenosis
Tags: embryology, Cardiology, Foetal Anomalies, Heart, case 8

Question: Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) is an adverse reaction that occurs due to a rapid transfusion of a large volume of blood. TACO can present with acute respiratory distress, tachycardia, increased BP, and/or acute or worsening pulmonary oedema. Which of these factors increases the risk of TACO in a patient?
Explanation:
The correct answer should be C - patient has chronic anaemia

 

The risk factors for TACO are:

  • Patient is female
  • Elderly
  • Co-morbidities
  • Chronic anaemia
  • Transfusion is rapid
  • Transfusion is unnecessary
  • Overtransfusion
  • Left ventricular dysfunction
  • Positive fluid balance
  • Recent vasopressors
  • Hx of congestive heart failure
Tags: Blood transfusion, Cardiology, cardiovascular, Haematology, case 8

Question: Xerophthalmia, Night blinds, Keratomalacia and Follicular hyperkeratosis are all major clinical features of which vitamin deficiency?
Explanation: The correct answer is Vitamin A. However Vitamin A deficiency is very rare in the UK.

Question: Which of the following is not a symptom of type 2 diabetes?
Explanation: Weight loss is not a symptom of type II diabetes. However, weight loss is a symptom of type 1 diabetes.

Question: Which of these Cranial Nerves does not supply the motor action of the eye?
Explanation: Cranial nerve V, Trigeminal, only receives SENSORY input from the eyes

Question: The a wave (ascent) of the JVP wave represents which of the following?
OptionE: Opening of the tricuspid valve and subsequent rapid inflow from RA to RV.
Explanation:
The correct answer is b) atrial contraction. During atrial contraction blood moves from the RA to the RV which puts press on the atria. A rise in the pressure in the RA gets reflected to the SVC which is reflected in the Internal Jugular Vein (IJV). Thus when the atria contracts get an 'a wave'. 

 

The other phases of the JVP waveform are as follows: 

a) atrial contraction 

x descend - atrial relaxation 

c - ventricular contraction 

x' - downward movement of the tricuspid valve when ventricle contracts and continued atrial relaxation. 

v: passive filling of the atria 

y: opening of the tricuspid valve and subsequent rapid flow from RA to RV.

Question: What is the most popular substance used for measuring GFR in clinical practice?
Explanation:
In order to measure an accurate GFR it is desirable to use a substance that is normally present in the plasma, is freely filtered, but is neither secreted nor reabsorbed by the renal tubules.

 

Inulin is not at a continual steady concentration in the plasma so does not provide an accurate measurement.

 

Creatinine (a metabolite of creatine) meets most of the criteria and the measurement is called the creatinine clearance

Question: A 57-year-old male patient who has a history of compensated heart failure, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the A&E with acute dyspnoea while sleeping at night for 30 minutes. Despite having no pre-existing respiratory disease, on examination, you noted signs of tachycardia, raised JVP, pulmonary oedema and pleural effusion, alongside with pitting oedema in both ankles. What would consider as the next most appropriate action to do?
OptionA: Start him on bisoprolol 10mg PO and continue on his imidapril 20mg
OptionB: Arrange an urgent echocardiogram and check the BNP levels.
OptionC: Sit the patient upright and start him on 100% Oxygen
OptionD: Give him diamorphine 1.25mg slowly via IV route.
OptionE: Give him Furosemide 40mg slowly via IV route and add Spironolactone should his [K+] levels drop
Explanation:
In the presentation of acute pulmonary oedema (presented with dyspnoea, orthopnoea, PND, raised JVP, pleural effusion and lung crackles), it is very important to assess the patients according to the DRSABC.

Airway comes first before anything else, so because he is short of breath (without any pre-existing lung disease) we need to start him on O2 therapy as soon as possible (this will also recruit move alveoli and shift the fluid out of the lungs).

 

Starting bisoprolol (A) is not the main point here as this is a presentation of decompensated HF, therefore lowering CO and HR is not in the patient's best interest as that is probably what is keeping him alive right now.

Investigations shown in B is not very useful given his diagnosis of heart failure *this would be the first step management in acute heart failure

Diamorphine would be the next step of management following O2 therapy.

Furosemide would also be the next step for management (+ the Spironolactone for the keen).

 

AW

Question:
It is 6.49AM and you are a medical registrar working in A&E. Suddenly a 54-year-old Mrs Freeman presents to A&E with symptoms of acute heart failure. She is known to be already taking amlodipine for her hypertension. Following initial investigations, you found out the following results:

  • BNP: 450 pg/ml
  • NT-proBNP: 218 pg/ml

Due to the busy situation in A&E, you asked one of your F1s to do a trans doppler 2D echocardiogram (remembering the NICE guidelines you read in med school a few years ago). Following the echocardiogram, he was not able to get a clear view of what is happening i

n the heart but he mentioned that the heart is beating in a rather circular motion and all that he can gather is the ejection fraction which is 38%.

What is your initial treatment?
OptionA: Find your consultant and ask him for input from his specialist heart failure team
OptionB: Start her on Furosemide 40mg, ramipril 20mg, and add bisoprolol 10mg an hour later.
OptionC: Start her on bisoprolol 10mg IV and continue her amlodipine
OptionE: Take a full history to find other diagnosis because her BNP levels shows that she is not having a heart failure
Explanation: NICE guidelines!

Question: A 69-year-old man has had a bad cough and worsening dyspnoea for 4 years. On examination, there is dullness to percussion at both lung bases and poorly audible breath sounds. On physical examination, pulse is 82/min and BP is 112/84 mm Hg. His liver span is increased to 14 cm. He has pitting edema to his knees. He does not have anginal pain. Raised JVP is noted to the angle of the jaw at 45-degree elevation of his head while lying down. Which of the following is most likely causing his heart disease?
Explanation:
These findings are consistent with right-sided congestive heart failure leading to peripheral oedema, body cavity effusions (pleural effusions in this case), passive congestion of the liver, and jugular venous distension. Pure right-sided failure is less common than left-sided failure, and the former most often follows pulmonary disease (cor pulmonale). Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is more common than restrictive lung disease, and smoking leads to COPD.

 

Can't see anything wrong with the kidneys from the history so need to do further investigations.

 

Atrial myxomas are uncommon, more often on the left side of the heart, and may produce intermittent valvular obstruction.

Essential hypertension is systemic and places a pressure load on the left side of the heart. Hyperlipidemia is a risk factor for ischemic heart disease that is more likely to involve the left side of the heart. Rheumatic heart disease may produce heart failure, but it is more often left-sided.

Question: A 52-year-old man has had increasing abdominal discomfort and swelling of his legs for the past 2 years. He has smoked cigarettes for 35 years. On physical examination, he has jugular venous distention, even when sitting up. The liver is enlarged and tender and can be palpated 10 cm below the right costal margin. Pitting edema is observed on the lower extremities. A chest radiograph shows bilateral diaphragmatic flattening, pleural effusions, and increased lucency of lung fields. Thoracentesis on the right side yields 500 mL of clear fluid with few cells. Which of the following is most likely to be the underlying disease in this patient?
Explanation: The findings point to pure right-sided congestive heart failure. Rarely, this can be caused by right-sided cardiac valvular lesions, such as tricuspid or pulmonic stenosis. Pulmonary hypertension resulting from obstructive lung diseases, such as emphysema or chronic bronchitis, most often caused from smoking cigarettes, is much more common. Primary pulmonary hypertension also can cause right-sided heart failure, but it is a much less common cause than obstructive lung diseases. Because acute myocardial infarction usually affects the left ventricle, left-sided heart failure would be more common in these patients. Chronic left-sided heart failure eventually can lead to right-sided heart failure.

Question: An infant born at term is noted to have cyanosis during the first week of life. On examination a heart murmur is auscultated. Abnormal findings with echocardiography include an overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, right ventricular thickening, and pulmonic stenosis involving the fetal heart. This infant is most likely to have an inherited mutation involving which of the following genes?
Explanation: There are a number of mutations in genes linked to congenital heart disease that encode proteins in transcription or signaling pathways. The NOTCH pathway plays a role in modulation of vascular development, including cardiac outflow tracts. NOTCH2 mutations are associated with tetralogy of Fallot, as in this infant. β-MHC gene mutations are associated with some cases of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene mutations underlie Marfan syndrome. KCNQ1 mutations may be seen with long QT syndrome. One form of cardiac amyloidosis is linked to transthyretin (TTR) gene mutations.
Tags: Cardiology, Foetal Anomalies, Case 15, Heart, Case 7

Question: Delayed after-depolarisations in cardiac tissue typically result from an increased influx of...
A patient with heart failure loses 8kg in a week and 6 days after taking a diuretic. He has a history of high blood potassium. what medication was he most likely on?
Explanation: furosemide is the strongest diuretic meaning he was most likely to lose the large amount of weight. Also good choice as he has hyperkalaemia

Question: Derek, a 77 year old Afro-Caribbean male comes to clinic, complaining of shortness of breath when he goes to get his paper in the morning. He says he sometimes wakes up at night with breathlessness and runs to the window to catch his breath. His BNP is 250pg/mL (<100pg/mL). He is unresponsive to ACE inhibitors, what would you teat him with?
Explanation:
First line for black patients with heart failure is hydralazine + isosorbide mononitrate

 

https://www.google.co.uk/search?q=heart+failure+management&espv=2&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj5us_w4cvSAhXlKsAKHUyWDKQQ_AUIBigB&biw=1040&bih=878#imgrc=83i69e8CIHGH_M:

Question:
Pauline is an 60 year old afro-caribbean woman who presents with breathlessness at A&E. Upon examination you find: 

- Raised JVP

-Conjunctival pallor

-Pitting oedema

-Crackles at the base of the lungs

 

What would your first line pharmacological treatment be based on these outcomes?
Explanation: Refer to NICE guidelines

Question: An elderly male has come to the GP complaining of fatigue, difficulty breathing, and a swollen abdomen. On inspection, his JVP has a steep “y” wave descent and Kussmaul’s sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Constrictive pericarditis is the only answer that gives both a steep "y" wave and Kussmaul's sign. Tricuspid stenosis and cardiac tamponade both have a slow rather than steep "y" wave, fluid overload has a normal waveform, and pulmonary hypertension/tricuspid stenosis have a large "a" wave.

The fatigue, breathing difficulty and swollen abdomen are also symptoms of constrictive pericarditis.

Question: 45-year-old Bill comes to see you as he has a new job working in a prison and has heard that he will need some jabs before he can start working. What immunisations will Bill need?
Explanation: The correct answer should be E - BCG and HBV

Question: A 16 year old boy walks into your GP surgery complaining of trouble sleeping.  On questioning you find that he is on his phone late into the night because he gets bored of lying awake doing nothing.  You suspect that the bright light from his phone effects his levels of melatonin which makes it harder for him to sleep. Where in the body is melatonin made (from it's serotonin precursor)?
Explanation:
A. The adrenal gland produces: steroids,  androgens and catecholamines. Aldosterone (mineralocorticoid) is produced in the adrenal cortex (specifically zona glomerulosa).  Cortisol (corticosteroid) is produced in the zona fasciculata. Androgens are produced in the zona reticularis. and Catecholamines are produces in the medulla.

 

B. Thyroid gland secretes thyroid hormones such as Calcitonin, Triiodothyronine T3 and Thyroxine T4 created from iodine and tyrosine. Note* hyperthyroidism most commonly caused by graves disease. Hypothyroidism most commonly caused by Iodine deficiency. 

 

C. Ant. pit. stimulated by the hypothalamus releases FSH, LH, Adrenocorticotropic hormone, Thyroid stimulating hormone, Prolactin, Endorphins, Growth hormone. Acronym FLAT PEG

D. Post. Pit release ADH and Oxytocin.

E. CORRECT Pineal gland makes melatonin from serotonin which makes you sleepy at night :)

Question: A young child has received the Polio vaccine. Serology results show they have produced IgG antibodies in response. Which of the following best describes the vaccination given?
Explanation:
Polio IM vaccine (SALK) = always inactivated whole cell >> produces IgG response   therefore correct answer is D

Polio oral vaccine (SABIN) = always live attenuated >> produces IgA response

Question: There are 5 dilatations of the primitive heart tube. From which dilatation is the SAN derived?
Explanation:
At week 5, cells of sinus venosus undergo spontaneous depolarisations at a faster rate than cells in other regions. Forming the SAN

 

Sinus Venosus becomes incorporated into right atrium during dextral looping. 

 

AVN and Bundle His are derived from cells in Sinus Venosus and Atrioventicular Canal
Tags: Anatomy, Cardiology, Heart, case 8, Foetal Development

Question: Which of the following is the most common congenital heart defect?
Explanation:
Found in 30-60% of newborns with a congenital heart defect (2-6/1000 live births)

 

Associated with other congenital conditions e.g. Down Syndrome 

 

Caused by incomplete looping of the heart during days 24-28 of development
Tags: Foetal Anomalies, Foetal Development, cardiovascular, Heart, case 8

Question: What is the effect of oestrogen on the breast during puberty?
OptionB: Formation of spherical masses of granular cells at the end of each duct
Explanation:
A - Correct

B - Caused by progesterone

Question: What 4 pathological changes constitute Teratology of Fallot?
OptionC:
Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

Aortic valve stenosis

LVH

Overriding Pulmonary trunk
OptionD:
Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
Pulmonary valve stenosis
RVH
Overriding pulmonary trunk

Question: A male patient presents with the following; gynaecomastia, tall stature, small testes, infertility, high levels of FSH and LH and low testosterone levels. Which syndrome is he likely to suffer from?
Explanation:
The correct answer is D. Klinefelter's syndrome is where there is an extra copy of the X chromosome. Patients have the karyotype (47, XXY). 

 

It is thought to affect 1-2 people in 1000. 

 

Males with the condition are infertile and have delayed or complete development of secondary sexual characteristics. 

 

Males who suffer from this syndrome are also more likely to suffer from health problems typically associated with females such as osteoporosis, autoimmune conditions and breast cancer. 

 

It can also have a consequence on development and learning - motor, language and reading delay is common.

Question: Which of the following conditions is an example of an X-linked recessive condition?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C - Duchene muscular dystrophy is an example of an X-linked recessive condition. 

 

A) Huntington's disease is an autosomal dominant condition 

B Sickle cell anaemia - autosomal recessive 

D) B-thalassemia - autosomal recessive 

E) Long QT syndrome - autosomal dominant 

 

Other X linked recessive conditions include red-green colourblindness and Haemophilia A. X linked recessive conditions usually only affect males. However, in many X-linked recessive conditions females can 'manifest' mild features. Often a mild, late-onset phenotype.

Question: Which of the following is not a feature of hyperkalemia on the ECG?
Explanation: The ECG in hyperkalemia may show tented T waves and small p waves at mildly raised K+ levels, but widening of the QRS complex (which eventually disappear) is particularly dangerous. Widening may become so severe that the ECG looks like sine waves. An increased RR interval is NOT seen in hyperkalemia.

Question: Macroglossia, large gestational weight, increased risk of cancer, neonatal hyperinsulinism and umbilical hernias are all features of what syndrome?
Explanation:
The correct answer is Beckwith Wiedemann Syndrome. This syndrome is considered an overgrowth syndrome. 

 

Paternal uniparental disomy 11 accounts for 20% of cases of Beckwith Wiedemann Syndrome. 

 

In contrast, Silver Russell Syndrome (SRS) can be due to maternal uniparental disomy 11. SRS results in child being small for gestational age rather than large.

Question: Which of the following statements are false about Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)?
OptionB: The risk of Down Syndrome increases with maternal age.
OptionC:
Lab findings include: 

- Reduced hCG and INH-A 

- Lower than average level of MSAFP and unconjugated oestriol
OptionD:
Lab findings include:
- Elevated hCG and INH-A
- Lower than average level of MSAFP and unconjugated oestriol
Explanation:
The correct answer is D. 

Lab findings would include an ELEVATED hCG and INH-A rather than REDUCED.

Question: Which ligament can patients with rheumatoid arthritis have laxity of, that can cause cervical spinal cord compression during neck extension?
What is the correct order of the layers of meninges? (superficial--> deep)
How can upper motor neuron facial palsy present?
Explanation: http://umqaa.blogspot.co.uk/2013/12/what-are-differences-between-upper.html
Tags: Cranial Nerves Examination, UMN Facial Palsy

Question: Lateral medullary syndrome occurs as a result of the blockage of which artery?
Explanation:
Lateral medullary syndrome occurs as a result of occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) causing:

- contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the body

- ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the face

- dysphagia, hoarseness, loss of gag reflex

- ipsilateral horner's syndrome

- vertigo, tendency to fall to ipsilateral side, diplopia

- ipsilateral ataxia

Question: Emma has recently been diagnosed with schizophrenia, after experiencing delusions and hearing voices talking about her. What type of schizophrenia does Emma have?
Explanation:
The correct answer should be B) Paranoid.

 

Types of schizophrenia:

  • Simple - slow progression of negative symptoms
  • Paranoid (most common) - delusions, auditory hallucinations (2nd or 3rd person)
  • Disorganised - disorganised speech and behaviour, patient finds it hard to do everyday tasks
  • Catatonic - disturbed movement, completely still or all over the place
  • Undifferentiated - a mixture of several types of schizophrenia
  • Residual - past history of episodes, but no current positive symptoms

Question: You are an F1 doctor in the middle of a rural hospital in Bronglais where a middle-aged man suffering from a traumatic head injury presents with a seizure lasting for 11 minutes. His temperature is 38.3 C and his O2 sats are 93%. BP is 132/92. Remembering the Pharmacology Lightbulb you read in Year 2 of medical school, you immediately give this gentleman a 10mg midazolam by buccal administration to acutely manage his seizure. What is the mechanism of action of midazolam?
OptionC: Increases K+ into neurones which hyperpolarize them to reduce impulse propagation
OptionD: Inhibits voltage-gated Na+ ion channels in the CNS
OptionE: selectively facilitating GABAa receptor function to increase suppression nerve activity
Explanation:
Midazolam is a benzodiazepines (Case 12)

It is indicated for (quoted from BNF) status epilepticus (seizure lasting for more than 5 mins), and febrile convulsions.

 

Act by selectively facilitating GABAA receptor function
Anxiolytic, sedative, muscle relaxant and anti-convulsant properties
Side effect : produce retrograde amnesia
Drugs with longer half-life preferred for general anxiety as both the parent compound and metabolites are active. E.g. Diazepam, chlordiazepoxide, flurazepam
GABAergic inhibition of other neurones may also contribute to anxiolysis

 

MIDAZOLAM: benzodiazepines increase GABA-ergic suppression of nerve activity
(Increases Cl- into neurones which hyperpolarise them to reduce impulse propagation)

Question: Which branch from the circle of willis supplies the temporal cortex
Explanation:
MCA supplies temporal cortex, basal ganglia and interanl capsules
ACA supplies frontal and superior part of temporal lobe
PCA supplies occipital lobe
Basilar a. supplies brainstem

Question: You are asked to identify which patient most likely has a viral meningitis CSF sample from a few samples in the lab. Which sample is most likely to belong to a patient with a viral meningitis
OptionB: Yellow and viscous, normal neutrophils, +++lymphocytes, normal protein, normal glucose
OptionC: Clear, Normal neutrophils, lymphocytes ++, Protein normal, glucose normal
Explanation:
A: TB

B: Fungus - similar to viral but yellow.

C: Viral
D: Bacterial

Question: Which of the following bacteria that cause meningitis are GRAM NEGATIVE and form pairs?
Explanation:
Gram +ve: Streptococcus and Listeria
Gram -ve: TB, Haemophilus and Neisseria

 

Neisseria is the one that floats in pairs.

Question:
There is an unconscious patient in ITU following cessation of sedation, you assess his GCS to see if his conscious level is improving.

His eyes only open in response to pain.
On application of pain he demonstrates abnormal flexion.
He also moans incomprehensibly.

What is his GCS
Explanation:
Eyes: Open to pain: 2
Verbal: Incomprehensible moans: 2
Motor: Abnormal flexion to pain: 3

7

The report says that the patient demonstrates a left temporal subdural haematoma, and that the cerebral contents have shifted. The coronal section of the CT demonstrates that the medial edge of the temporal lobe has been pushed below the tentorium cerebelli. What type of herniation is this?

Question: Which of the glial cell types is responsible for maintaining extracellular ion concentrations and deactivating neurotransmitters in the CNS?
Explanation:
Astrocytes perform this function, the most important ion [ ] seems to be K+
Oligodendrocytes myelinate in the CNS, Schwann cells do this in the PNS
Microglia are for defence and behave like WBC
Lymphocytes are WBC helpful for destroying viruses.

Question: You suspect a patient has bacterial meningitis, what IV antibiotics are indicated as first line whilst waiting for cultures to develop?
Explanation: Ceftriaxone is first line, +/- Ampicillin is Listeria infection is suspected (more likely if pregnant/elderly)

Question: You are an F1 doctor in the middle of a rural hospital in Bronglais where a middle-aged man suffering from a traumatic head injury presents with a seizure lasting for 11 minutes. Upon getting collateral history from his friend, you know that he is suffering from epilepsy for 3 years and is taking his medication. Remembering the Pharmacology Lightbulb you read in Year 2 of medical school, you immediately give this gentleman a 20mg midazolam by buccal administration to acutely manage his seizure. Focusing on this gentleman's presentation, which of the following will be the most significant side effect of midazolam?
Explanation:
Check your BNF! 

You wouldn't want midazolam's side effects to interfere with your clinical judgement when managing his traumatic head injury presentation so in this case retrograde amnesia is the most significant side effect. This is similar to not giving tropicamide to aid fundoscopy in a patient with head injury (as it might mask abnormal dilatation of the pupil as a result of uncal herniation (due to raised ICP) that compresses CN III.

Drowsiness is also a side effect of midazolam but not very significant in this case.

Question:
Uzair, a 32 year old man presents to A and E with a head injury from falling off a roof. Upon examination of his pupils the direct response in his left pupil is intact but there is no consensual response in the right eye.

Where is the lesion most likely to be present?
Explanation:
C is the correct answer.

 

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I26Crr1Z0y0&t=564s see youtube video for further clarification

Question: John, a 64 year old male, has been brought into the GP by his wife Mary. She says he isn't making any sense and yesterday for 4 or 5 hours he was unable to speak properly. She says he was responding to her but many of the words he was saying didn't make sense and often weren't even real words. You suspect he has had a transient ischaemic attack the previous day. What area of the brain do you believe has been affected?
Explanation: Wernicke's aphasia presents with fluent grammatical speech that doesn't make sense, often containing made up words.

Question:
On assessment of a patient with a head injury, you check their pupils.

 

When shining your pentorch in the left eye, there is no direct or consensual response (right pupil does not constrict)

When shining your pentorch in the right eye, there is a direct response, and a consensual response also (left pupil constricts)

 

Where is the problem most likely to be located?
Explanation:
The problem is the left optic nerve, no light is being detected by the left eye so a constriction response isn't being initiated

 

The left occulomotor nerve is functioning because the pupil constricts when the right eye is given light.

Question:
A patient, Mr Jones, presents with loss of pain and temperature in his right leg and severe paralysis on the left side of his face. Mr Jones is 78 years old and has a history of angina. His wife complains that she has to shout for him to hear her and that he gets dizzy suddenly. It is suspected that there is an occlusion of one of the arteries supplying the cerebellum and pons.

 

What artery is most likely affected?
Explanation:
Answer is D. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery 

While occlusion of this artery is rare compared to occlusion of posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), it results in lateral pontine syndrome (also called Marie-Foix syndrome). The main cause of AICA territory stroke is atherosclerosis (hence, the angina clue, pointing to possible ischaemic heart disease which later leads to an occlusion in his AICA) but can also be a lacunar infarct due to hypertension or thromboembolism though sometimes the cause is unknown.

AICA has an internal auditory branch (labyrinthine artery) which passes into the internal acoustic meatus which is why occlusion leads to cochlear symptoms. 

Lateral pontine syndrome, also known as AICA syndrome, is easily confused with PICA occlusion (lateral medullary syndrome) but PICA does not cause cochlear symptoms.

 

AICA syndrome presents with:

  • vertigo, tinnitus, ipsilateral hearing loss and nystagmus (CN VIII vestibular and cochlear nuclei)
  • contralateral hemiplegia/hemiparesis (corticospinal tract)
  • ipsilateral limb ataxia (cerebellar tracts)
  • contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tracts)
  • ipsilateral facial paralysis with loss in all sensory modalities (CN VII nucleus)

PICA syndrome/lateral medullary syndrome presents with:

  • contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract)
  • ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on face (trigeminal tract)
  • dysphagia, hoarseness, loss of gag reflex (nucleus ambiguus and roots of cranial nerves IX and X)
  • ipsilateral Horner's syndrome - hypothalamospinal fibres (dorsal longitudinal fasciculus - DLF)
  • vertigo, tendency to fall to ipsilateral side, diplopia (double vision) (vestibular nuclei)
  • ipsilateral ataxia - spinocerebellar tract

PICA information taken from Dr. Watson's lecture 'Functional Neuroanatomy and Nerve Cell Response to Injury in CNS'

AICA information taken from radiopaedia.org.

Question: You're an F1 doctor in a restaurant when a member of the public begins to choke on a piece of food. You do back slaps and the Heimlich manoeuvre but alas it has failed. You've asked a bystander to call 999 but they're still choking badly and unable to breathe. What procedure would you now perform and how?
OptionA: Tracheotomy. Use a pen to pierce between the tracheal cartilage.
OptionC: Tracheotomy. Use a pen to pierce between the cricoid and the thyroid cartilage.
OptionD: Tracheostomy. Use a pen to pierce between the cricoid cartilage and the thyroid cartilage
OptionE: Tracheostomy. Use a pen to pierce between the hyoid bone and the thyroid cartilage.
Explanation: C: tracheotomy is the procedure to pirce the windpipe. Tracheostomy is the hole created by the procedure.

Question: By giving a woman aspirin during pregnancy, what consequence does this have on the foetus?

Mr Jones suffered a fall on his head. He was admitted with a GCS of 14. 3 hours lated he starts having a severe headache, feels nauseous and also had 1 vomiting episode. His right pupil is blown and unreactive to light.
