You are asked to quickly get a GCS score. He opens his eyes only when you tell him to do so, when you ask him where he is he mutters something incomprehensibly and he withdraws slightly when you give him trapezius squeeze.

 

What is his GCS score?
Explanation:
• Headache + nausea + vomitting = triad of raised intracranial pressure
  • Blown right pupil and unresponsive to light = compression of right CNIII (NB/ ipsilateral pupil dilatation usually the first clinical sign in CNIII compression because the parasympathetic fibres are located on the outside of the nerve hence are first to be inactivated = pupillary dilatation)
  • GCS SCORING...
  • E = 3
  • V = 2 
  • M =4

Question:
A pregnant woman presents with a headache, neck stiffness and a temperature of 38.6. Upon examination you notice she has a petechial rash and when you check her pulse she is tachycardic. A CSF sample is sent to the micro labs.

Results are a high neutrophil count and identification of an organism. What is the most likely organism?
Explanation:
- TRIAD Headache + Fever + Neck stiffness is indicative of meningitis

- Petechial Rash and tachycardia are more common in BACTERIAL meningitis (rash is rarely seen in viral meningitis and pts with viral men are usually haemodynamically stable.

- High NEUTROPHIL also points towards bacterial meningitis (Lymphocytes = viral)

 

 

Neisseria meningitidis is usually the most common bacterial cause of meningitis BUT the woman here is pregnant in which Listeriosis is more common (listeria generally more common in immunocompromised pts)

Question: Two types of septae make up foramen ovalis. One of them is septum secondum. What is the other one called?
Explanation: Foramen ovalis is made by septum primum and septum secondum. It is between the two atrial in the foetus

Question: What process determines the position of the heart in the thorax, during the early developmental stages of the heart?
Explanation: Cephalo-caudal folding is the process that occurs at the early stages of development, by which the heart ends up where it is, in the thorax

Question:
Jane is a 21 year-old student. While out on a run, she falls and cuts her knee. As part of the wound healing process, collagen is secreted to aid the process.

 

What type of collagen is first secreted?
OptionA: Collagen is not part of the wound healing process
Explanation:
Type III is correct - forms reticular lamina and is the first collagen type secreted as part of the wound healing process

 

Type I – tensile strength, 90% of collagen - dermis, ligaments, bone

Type II – Hyaline and Elastic Cartilage

Type III – Reticular Lamina – first collagen secreted in wound healing

Type IV – Basal lamina

 

From Prof Wilson's PCS intro lecture to microanatomy

Question: A 23 year old woman presents to her GP suspecting that she might be pregnant. She takes a variety of medications because she is diabetic, suffers from severe acne and gets tired easily. The GP is concerned about one of her medications because it has been proven to lead to congenital defects if used at any point during pregnancy. Which of these medications is the GP most likely to be concerned about?
Explanation:
The correct answer is B. Accutane 

 

Accutane (active ingredient isoretinoin) is a prescription medication used to treat severe cystic acne. It is a vitamin A analogue. Evidence has shown that using Accutane at any point during pregnancy can lead to severe birth defects such as abnormalities in the face, eyes, ears, skull, central nervous system and cardiovascular system. Accutane also increases the risk of spontaneous abortion and premature births. Source: Langman's Embryology+ Dr Wilson's Lecture 

 

The other medications are common however they have no significant link to birth defects. 

 

It is important to remember that all medications should be avoided where possible in pregnant women, particularly in the critical period from weeks 3-11. If a drug must absolutely be prescribed, it should be prescribed at the minimum effective dose. Refer to Dr Wilson's lecture on Congenital Malformations and Teratology for more information
Tags: Foetal Anomalies, Foetal Development, Case 7, Pharmacology

Question: Follicular Helper T cells....
OptionA: Release perforins to induce apoptosis of infected cells
OptionB: Stimulate somatic Hypermutation of immunoglobulins on the surface of B cells
OptionC: Reside in lymph node as memory cells
Explanation:
Follicular Helper T cells reside in lymph nodes. Interact with B cells, stimulating somatic hypermutation of variable region of immunoglobulins on the cell's surface.

 

Initially, B cells only express IgA on their surface. On interaction with FH T cells, they can express other immunoglobulins with a higher affinity for the antigen.

Question: The Wakefield study suggested a link between the MMR vaccine, autism and which other condition?

A 38 year old patient has just undergone a spinal cord decompression and is now on the ward recovering. His consultant is treating his pain with a combination of analgesia but tells the F1 that he will not be prescribing steroids to this patient.

What was the most likely cause of the patient’s spinal cord compression?
Explanation:
“Steroids are useful in metastases, haematoma and tumours but NOT in trauma” – taken from the lecture ‘Neurosurgical Emergencies’.

 

Therefore, the consultant is not prescribing steroids because this patient must be a trauma patient. If the patient had any form of tumour, metastasis or a non-traumatic haematoma, steroids would be useful.

 

L x

Question: Perry has schizophrenia. He reports that his wife is recording his thoughts with a special device and selling them to the CIA. During the consultation, the psychiatrist notices that Perry has difficulty concentrating on what she is saying. According to the dopamine theory of psychosis, what is causing Perry's symptoms?
OptionA:
Delusion - hyperfunctional mesocortical pathway (D2 receptors)

Lack of concentration - hypofunctional mesolimbic pathway (D1 receptors)
OptionB:
Delusion - hyperfunctional mesolimbic pathway (D2 receptors)

Lack of concentration - hypofunctional mesocortical pathway (D1 receptors)
OptionC:
Delusion - hyperfunctional mesolimbic pathway (D1 receptors)

Lack of concentration - hyperfunctional mesocortical pathway (D2 receptors)
OptionD:
Delusion - hypofunctional mesocortical pathway (D1 receptors)

Lack of concentration - hyperfunctional mesolimbic pathway (D2 receptors)
OptionE:
Delusion - hypofunctional mesolimbic pathway (D2 receptors)

Lack of concentration - hypofunctional mesocortical receptors (D1 receptors)
Explanation:
The correct answer should be:

B) Delusion - hyperfunctional mesolimbic pathway (D2 receptors)

Lack of concentration - hypofunctional mesocortical pathway (D1 receptors)

 

This is because delusion is a positive symptom (think of positive symptoms as something being 'added' onto the patient's mental state) and lack of concentration/poor attention is a negative symptom (taking something away from patient's mental state).

  • INCREASED activity in mesoLIMBIC pathway (hyperfunctional)

This gives positive symptoms due to the overactivity of D2 receptors.

  • DECREASED activity in mesoCORTICAL pathway (hypofunctional)

This gives negative symptoms due to the underactivity of D1 receptors. It can also cause impaired learning and memory.

Question: During embryonic development the heart is formed by the coalescence of cluters of angioblasts from the mesoderm during the 17&18th day. These join to form the haert tube, which has 5 dilations. Which of the following is NOT a dilation of the heart tube
Explanation:
The 5 dilatations are:

Truncus Arteriosus (becomes aorta and pulmonary trunk)

Bulbus Cordis (also forms ventricle)

Primitive Ventricle (forms ventricle)

Primitive Atrium (forms atria)

Sinus Venosus (forms SA node, AV node and bundle of His)

 

Primitive Aorta is made up.

Question: Which hormone is produced by the placenta from 10 weeks gestation to relax smooth muscle and decrease excitability of the uterus (to avoid it expelling the fetus!)
Explanation:
This is the primary role of progesterone. It also produces Relaxin which does the same stuff and is important for relaxing pelvis and softening cervix for delivery.

Placenta takes over production of progesterone as corpus luteum degenerates

Question: What vessel carries oxygenated blood to the foetus from the mother?
Explanation:
Umbilical vein contains oxygenated blood from mother, at approx 80% oxygenation.

 

 It carries blood to the fetal liver

50% bypasses the liver via the ductus venosus, 50% goes to the liver to be used

 

From the liver the ductus venosus joins the IVC and goes into the right atrium.

 

Most of the blood here goes through foramen ovale to left atrium, some sticks around and goes down right ventricle up pulmonary artery. only some of this gets to lungs, as most joins descending aorta through ductus arteriosus.

 

 The blood that went to left atrium goes to left ventricle and up ascending aorta, the best bit of this goes to the upper limbs and brain before being joined by blood from ductus arteriosus and then supplying the lower half of the body and going back to placenta via umbilical arteries.

Question: Which is these ISN'T a correct description of a change that occurs at birth as part of the cessation of placental flow and start of respiration
OptionA: Closure of umbilical vein (becomes ligamentum venosum over 3 months) and Closure of ductus venosus (becomes ligamentum teres hepatis)
OptionB: Closure of ductus arteriosus (normally connects pulmonary artery to descending aorta)
OptionC: Closre of umbilical artery (forms median umbilical ligament) over 3 months
OptionD: Closure of foramen ovale (normally allows blood to flow from right atrium to left atrium) becoming fossa ovalis
Explanation: Closure of ductus venosus (becomes ligamentum venosum) and umbilical vein becomes ligamentum teres hepatis. They're the wrong way around in the question.

Question: Which of these is the most common congenital heart defect?
Explanation:
VSD (12/10,000): Usually the membranous part of the septum is the problem. Causes a pansystolic murmur and may lead to pulmoanry HTN
Valvular stenosis (3/10,000)

Tetralogy of Fallot (9/10,000):
 a ventricular septal defect, a hole between the two ventricles
 pulmonary stenosis, narrowing of the exit from the right ventricle
 right ventricular hypertrophy, enlargement of the right ventricle
 an overriding aorta, which allows blood from both ventricles to enter the aorta

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (1/2000) (ductus arteriosus normally shunts blood from pulmonary artery to descending aorta), increased in pre-term babies. cases weight gain and increased work of breathing.

 

From the lecture on heart develpoment.
Tags: Foetal Anomalies, embryology, Foetal Development, case 8

Question: Who needs Vitamin D supplementation whilst pregnant?
Explanation:
BMI >30, African/Asian, No sunlight.

 

At least I think so, from lecture on IU growth.

 

Supplementation is 10mcg per day.

 

FROM NHS WEBSITE:

If you have dark skin or always cover your skin

If you have dark skin (for example, if you are of African, African Caribbean or south Asian origin) or always cover your skin when outside, you may be at particular risk of not having enough vitamin D (vitamin D insufficiency). You may need to consider taking a daily supplement. Talk to your midwife or doctor if this applies to you.

Question: 400mg of Folic acid for mothers who are trying for a baby can help reduce the incidence of...
Explanation:
It's neural tube defects.

 

From NHS website:

You should take a 400 micrograms (mcg) folic acid tablet every day while you are trying to get pregnant and until you are 12 weeks pregnant.

 

Folic acid is important for pregnancy, as it can help to prevent birth defects known as neural tube defects, including spina bifida. If you didn't take folic acid before you conceived, you should start as soon as you find out that you are pregnant.

You should also eat foods that contain folate (the natural form of folic acid), such as green leafy vegetables. Some breakfast cereals and some fat spreads such as margarine may have folic acid added to them.

 

It's difficult to get the amount of folate recommended for pregnancy from food alone, which is why it is important to take a folic acid supplement.

 

Higher dose folic acid

Some women have an increased risk of having a pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect, and are advised to take a higher dose of 5 milligrams (mg) of folic acid each day until they are 12 weeks pregnant. Women have an increased risk if:

they or their partner have a neural tube defect
they have had a previous pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect
they or their partner have a family history of neural tube defects
they have diabetes

In addition, women who are taking anti-epileptic medication should consult their GP for advice, as they may also need to take a higher dose of folic acid. Find out about epilepsy, anti-epileptic medication and pregnancy.

If any of the above applies to you, talk to your GP as they can prescribe a higher dose of folic acid. Your GP or midwife may also recommend additional screening tests during your pregnancy.

Question: What might a vitamin D deficiency cause in pregnancy
Explanation: Rickets, because vitamin D is important for Calcium and Phosphate regulation which is important for bones

Question: What does a home pregnancy test detect, and when can it be detected?
Explanation:
hCG is detected. The ones we use in the ISCE's are >99.9% accurate.

Early pregnancy factor can be used 48hrs after fertilisation, but its expensive.

Question: What would an abnormal Nuchal Translucency measurement be?
Explanation:
A nuchal translucency of 2.5 - 3.5mm is normal, anything higher may indicate chromosomal abnormalities.

 

The screening test offered at 10-14 weeks is called the combined test. It involves a blood test and an ultrasound scan.

 

It is not always possible to obtain a nuchal transparency measurement, and depends on the position of the baby. If this is the case, you will be offered a different blood screening test to take place from weeks 14-20 (Quadruple test)

Question: Which are not features of high risk of Downs syndrome as seen on pregnancy screening/diagnostic tests?
Explanation:
Downs Syndrome:

Increased hCG
increase INH-A

Increased Nuchal Translucency measurement

Decreased MS-AFP

Decreased unconj. oestrodiol (uE3)

Question:
Bridget has somehow found herself pregnant, she has had the combined screening test at 11 weeks, and this showed an increased nuchal translucency measurement (>3.5mm) and a high level of free beta human chorionic gonadotrophin

 

Given that she is now at a higher risk of having a baby with Downs Syndrome, which diagnostic test would be the LEAST likely to cause a miscarriage
Explanation:
NIFTY (non-invasive fetal trisomy test) is non-invasive and therefore carries no risk.

 

 Interestingly, if you have twins, it can still work and will tell you if you have at least one baby with downs syndrome (the chance of having 2 is really low)

Question: Which is an autosomal dominant condition?
OptionA: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, Haemophilia A, Red-green colourblindness
Explanation:
A: X-linked Recessive

B: autosomal recessive

C: Autosomal dominant

D: Abnormalities of chromosomal number. (aneuploidy). I'm not sure how they'd be inherited - would every gammete have an extra-half chromosome - probably?

E: More abnormalities of aneuploidy, most of these are sterile. (XXY isn't)

Question: What's that ball of cells that'll someday be a human called on day 3, when it is a ball of 16 cells that have divided and divided after fertilisation without any growth (cleavage)  (within zona pellucida, cells inside are undifferentiated)
Explanation:
pre-embryo: from fertilisation to 2 weeks
zygote - days 1-3
morula days 4-7 (16 cell ball)
blastocyst- days 8-14 (has differentiated cells - trophoblast, inner cell mass and blastocyst cavity)

embryo - weeks 3-8
fetus- weeks 9-40

neonate - 1st month

Question: What is the Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium
Explanation:
p2 = number of AA
2pq = heterozygotes = carriers

q2 = aa = incidence

 

Relevant in AR conditions,

Question: Which antenatal investigation can be carried out the latest?
Explanation:
Combined test (11 weeks to 13 weeks and 6 days). Includes USS (NT), free beta-hCG and PAPPA
Integrated test (13 weeks 6 days and again between 15-20 weeks). Includes USS (NT) and PAPPA in 1st trimester, and hCG, uE3 and AFP in 2nd trimester
Quadruple test (15-20 weeks): 4 assays: hCG, uE3, AFP, Inhibin A

CVS (11-14 weeks) Needle through abdomen into placenta, risk of miscarriage >1%, offered if increased Down's syndrome risk or earlier USS abnormality.
Amniocentesis (16-22 weeks) USS guided needle through abdomen into amniotic sack to draw amniotic fluid. Tells foetal Karyotype

Question: What is the correct notation for a woman who is currently pregnant, and previously has birth to one live child and sadly had 2 stillbirths at term
Explanation:
In the UK, gravidity is defined as the number of times that a woman has been pregnant and parity is defined as the number of times that she has given birth to a fetus with a gestational age of 24 weeks or more, regardless of whether the child was born alive or was stillborn. So she is G4 (4th time pregnant), P3 (3 carried more than 24 weeks as the still births were to term)

 

https://patient.info/doctor/gravidity-and-parity-definitions-and-their-implications-in-risk-assessment

Question: You are in the anaesthetic room and after the Anaesthetist administers a neuromuscular blockade to the patient you notice muscle fasciculations. What drug was most probably given?
Explanation:
correct answer is SUXAMETHONIUM (D) which is a DEPOLARISING neuro-muscular blockade --> is a competetitve agonist and acts in addition to Ach. It is broken down slowly and causes fasciculations  

 

A)Botulinum = not used in the anaesthetic room BUT is also a muscle relaxant --> works by blocking Ach

B) C) Artacurium and Mivacurium are both NON-DEPOLARISING muscular blockades --> they are competetitbe antagonists and block the action of Ach. it is not broken down and fasciculations are NOT seen.

E) Bupivicaine is a LOCAL ANAESTHETIC not a neuromuscular blockade

Question: A 32 year old female is in labour, when it is decided that she needs an epidural. What is the order of the structures through which the epidural passes?
OptionA: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, intraspinous ligament, ligament flavum, epidural space
OptionB: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligament flavum, subarachnoid space
OptionC: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament,intraspinous ligament, intersspinous ligament, ligament flavum, epidural space
OptionD: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligament flavum, epidural space
OptionE: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, intraspinous ligament, ligament flavum, epidural space, dura
Explanation: The epidural goes into the epidural space, it doesn't pass the dura or doesn't enter the arachnoid space
Tags: Anaesthesia and Analgesia, labour, case 8, Pregnancy

Question: Which of the following is not measured as part of the quadruple antenatal test?
Explanation:
The quadruple test is carried out between 15-18 weeks. 

The biochemical markers measured are AFP, hCG, INH-A and uE3. 

Ultrasound measurements may also be recorded such as Crown rump length (CRL) or HC/ BPD (fetal head).

 

PAPP-A is measured as part of the combined test. The combined test is conducted between 11-14 weeks. This test would measure CRL and nuchal translucency.

Question: Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS) and amniocentesis are both antenatal methods of testing for Down Syndrome. When comparing the two methods which of the following statements is FALSE?
OptionA: Amniocentesis carries a lower risk of miscarriage.
OptionB: Amniocentesis is performed earlier on in the pregnancy than CVS.
OptionC: Amniocentesis is more likely to give a result than CVS.
OptionD: In CVS there is a higher risk that sample is not obtained.
Explanation:
The false statement is statement B. 

CVS can be carried out from 11 weeks whereas amniocentesis is carried out from 15 weeks. 

CVS has a higher risk of miscarriage than amniocentesis. 

With CVS there is a greater risk that the sample is not obtained and up to 5% of the tests will not give a result. With amniocentesis 1% of test will not give a result.

Question: Patient comes after being diagnosed with schizophrenia. She wants in on the cool newer antipsychotics, but you need to warn her of the side effects. What is the major side-effect you need to consider if prescribing risperidone?
Explanation:
sedation - relates to quietiapine

 

weight gain, high lipid and glucose levels - relates to olanzipine

Question: Your friend's finished exams and is all pumped to go to Parklife, they decide to tell you they plan on taking LSD. You as a medical student know what receptor this works its magic on, which is it?
Explanation:
5HT1 - related to being activated by triptans 

5HT2A - activated by hallucinogens like LSD 

5HT3 - related to anti emetics 

A-1 - SMC  contraction related 

 

If you didn't get it that's alright, you'll never be this bad

Question: You delivery a baby, you notice it has a particularly small head and a cat-like-cry, what chromosomal abnormality would explain this baby's appearance?
Explanation: the baby has cri-du-chat which is a partial deletion of chromosome 5

Question:
Miss Jones is a 30 year old lady who presents to her GP complaining of diarrhoea, weight loss, heat intolerance and missed periods. Upon examination she has visible exophthalmos and it is found that she is hypertensive and tachycardia. 

The week after blood work comes back showing the following....

  • High T3 and T4
  • Low TSH
  • TSH receptor antibodies (TRAbs)

Following a thyroidectomy, Mrs Jones begins to suffer from muscle spasms (tetany) and parasthesia around her mouth and feet. What is she now deficient in?
Explanation:
• Mrs Jones' early symptoms are indicative of HYPERTHYROIDISM
  • Exophthalmos and TRAbs (TSH receptor antibodies) are more specific to Grave's disease
  • Complication of thyroid surgery (iatrogenic) = injury to PARATHYROID glands = hypoparathyroidism 
  • This results in low PTH therefore low levels of Calcium --> HYPOCALCAEMIA symptoms include TETANY and PARASTHESIA therefore answer is (D)
  • C) PTH is also correct but the result of low PTH is low calcium hence calcium is more correct. (PTH is important in increasing calcium levels through exerting its effects on KIDNEYS (increases ca2+ reabsorption) and BONE (osteoclast stimulation))
  • B) vitamin D deficiency typically results secondary hyperthyroidism

Question:
A 65 year old female has suffered three fractures in the last 12 months and you suspect a bone disorder. She has a DEXA Z-score of 2 and biochemistry results are as follows...

 

  • Low calcium
  • Low Phosphate
  • Elevated Alkaline phosphatase

What is your diagnosis?
Explanation: DEXA Z score of >2.5 = osteoporosis

Question:
A GP refers a 14 year old patient to the Early Pregnancy Assessment Unit who suspects that she is 9 weeks pregnant. The nurse you are shadowing is tasked with providing the patient with information on the importance of taking folic acid supplements and informs the patient that folic acid reduces the risk of of birth defects such as Spina Bifida, which occurs due to failure of the neural tube to fuse.

 

Neurulation begins with the formation of the neural plate which requires inductive signals from the notochord. From which of the 3 germ layers is the neural plate derived?
Explanation:
The correct answer is A. Ectoderm . 

 

The ectoderm is the outer layer of the trilaminar embryo.

 

 

"At the beginning of the third week of development, the ectodermal germ layer has the shape of a disc that is broader in the cephalic than in the caudal region (Fig. 6.1). Appearance of the notochord and prechordal mesoderm induces the overlying ectoderm to thicken and form the neural plate"- Langman's Embryology

Question: Which day (after fertilization) marks the completion of embryological neurulation?
Explanation:
Day 16: Gastrulation (Day 16/17)

Day 20: Neurulation begins 

Day 22: The neural folds begin to fuse posteriorly at the cervical regin (5th somite position)

Day 28: CORRECT. Neurulation is complete by day 28 (marked by the closure of the posterior neuropore)

Day 30:Face develops

Question: Which day (after fertilization) marks the beginning of embryological gastrulation?
Explanation:
Day 16: CORRECT. Gastrulation begins on day 16/17 after fertilization 

Day 20: Neurulation begins

Day 22: Closure of the neural plates posteriorly at the cervical region (position of the 5th somite)

Day 28: Neurulation is complete 

Day 30: Face forms

Question: A 27 year old pregnant women walks into your clinic she's wants to discuss childbirth and its stages. You explain the process to her and describe cervical ripening she asks what causes cervical ripening, you tell her it is a prostaglandin. Which prostaglandin is the main cause for cervical ripening?
Explanation:
Cervical ripening is mainly caused by PGF2a . PGE2 also plays a smaller role.

This answer is taken from the one2one medicine textbook

Question: What is the function of the Sonic Hedgehog proteins (SHh)?
OptionA: Induction of ectodermally and endodermally derived tissues/organs
Explanation:
Wnt proteins are a family of proteins that contribute to the induction of ectodermally and mesodermally- derived tissues/organs.

TGF -Beta family of proteins (including BMP's) regulate cellular differentiation 

SHh protein is initially expressed in the notochord and plays a role in neural patterning and patterning of somites 

Neural tube fusion is facilitated by hindges known as cadherins (cadherin E and N, the former expressed in cells that contribute to the epidermis of the skin, and the latter expressed in cells which will differentiate into neural cells)

Question: A 30 year old female enters your clinic. You run some procedural blood tests and find she has thrombocytopenia which is a deficiency of platelets. Where in the bone marrow are platelets produced?
Explanation: Platelets are produced in megakaryocytes in the bone marrow

Question: You are currently a F1 doctor working on the wards. Recently someone has labelled a patients blood wrong and you are now all having a teaching session of the "Safety of Blood". What is the name of the confidential anonymous reporting scheme in the UK and Ireland?
Explanation:
SHOT= Serious Hazards for Transfusion- correct answer

TACO=Transfusion Associated Overload

TRALI- Transfusion Related Acute Injury

Question:
A 35 year old male has been suffering from migraines for the past year. He has not responded well to NSAIDs or other over-the-counter medications so he is prescribed Sumatriptan (serotonin receptor agonist).

 

Which specific serotonin receptor does it activate?
Explanation:
Sumatriptan belongs to TRIPTAN class of drugs (mentioned in neuropharmacology lecture 1 case 12)

  • Indicated for use in the Tx of cluster headaches and migraines
  • Agonist to 5HT1B and 5HT1D receptor --> activates these receptors therefore answer is (A)
  • B) 5HT 2A is activated by hallucinogenic drugs and is the receptor targeted in ATYPICAL ANTIPSYCHOTICS
  • C)  5HT 3 is the only INOTROPIC receptor (all other 5HT receptors are metabotropic), 5HT3 receptor antagonists = odansetron-like antiemetics

Question:
John is a 20 year-old male walking to his ISCE, and he is feeling nervous. As a result, his sympathetic activity has increased. He can feel his heart beating strongly. He decided against his morning coffee as he thought it would make him even more jittery.

 

He has no pre-existing cardiac conditions.

 

What is the primary autonomic-influenced mechanism that causes John's strong heart beat and increased contractility?
OptionA: A slower inactivation of cAMP due to phosphodiesterase inhibition
OptionB: An increase in cAMP that phosphorylates L-Type Calcium channels
OptionC: An increase in PKA that phosphorylates L-Type Calcium channels
OptionD: An increase in preload due to his walking
OptionE: An increased concentration of cGMP leading to vasodilation
Explanation:
C is the 'most correct' answer

 

A - This is an action of phosphodiesterase inhibitors like caffeine, but he has not consumed any.

 

B - the activation of beta-1 adrenoceptors does increase cAMP, but it is not cAMP that phosphorylates the channels (it is PKA further down the cascade)

 

C - PKA levels increase as a result of increased cAMP levels. This is because John's adrenaline levels are high, which activates cardiac beta-1 adrenoceptors. PKA phosphorylates L-type Calcium channels, which prolongs channel opening, increases calcium influx and has a positive inotropic effect.

 

D - He may have a slight increase in preload as a result of walking, but walking is unlikely to be intense enough in a normal young person to be the primary cause of increased contractility

 

E - this is another action of phosphodiesterase inhibition, which leads to vasodilation. Again, he has not taken anything to cause this.

Question: According to Sunderland's classification of nerve injury, what degree of injury is given when both the axon and endoneurium of the nerve are damaged (but the perineurium and epineurium are both still intact)?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C = third-degree injury

 

According to Sunderland's classification of nerve injury, there are 6 degrees of nerve injury:

 

1st degree: Loss of myelin around the nerve, conduction of action potentials is slowed, the nerve is able to recover on its own
(this is called 'neurapraxia' in Seddon's classification of nerve injury)

2nd degree: Axon is damaged but endoneurium, perineurium and epineurium are still intact, but there is no conduction (here, sometimes the nerve can recover on its own, as a new axon can grow down the hollow tube of the still intact endoneurium)

 

3rd degree: Axon and endoneurium are damaged and epineurium and perineurium are in tact, there is no conduction (resultant scarring means that often on its own, no axonal regeneration is possible)

 

4th degree: Axon, endoneurium and perineurium are damaged, the epineurium around the whole nerve is still intact, there is no conduction (here, resultant scarring means that often on its own, no axonal regeneration is possible)

(2nd, 3rd and 4th nerve injury degrees are all called 'axonotmesis' in Seddon's classification of nerve injury)

 

5th degree: Nerve trunk is completely divided (often the growth of a Neuroma occurs), there is no conduction and will not recover without surgery

(this is called 'neurotmesis' in Seddon's classification of nerve injury)

 

6th degree: Mixed nerve injury, varying from fasicle to fasicle of the same nerve

 

 

Information is taken from 'Normal Nerve Physiology and Response to Injury' plenary in Case 14

 

For more information see: http://www.gpnotebook.co.uk/simplepage.cfm?ID=x20091231011203724280

Question:
A 33 year old male says he finds no pleasure in life and is always tired. He can sometimes hear voices and thinks everyone around him is part of a conspiracy theory. 

He is admitted to an acute psychiatric ward and given a conventional anti-psychotic. His hallucinations and paranoia improve but now complains he has a tremor and cannot move about quickly. He is switched to another drug which resolves this but requires blood monitoring. What is thhe anti-psychotic he is now on?
Explanation:
A) Haloperidol = this is the drug he was given initially. It is a conventional/typical anti-psychotic which is a D2 receptor antagonist (treats positive symptoms which are caused by too much dopamine in mesolimbic pathway ) --> however ends up also blocking D2 receoptrs in the nigrostriatal pathway leading to the EXTRAPYRAMIDAL symptoms he experienced at first.

  • NB - typical antipsychotics also reduce dopamine levels in tuberoinfundibular pathway which is important to inhibit prolactin release = another important SE is hyperprolactinaemia

B) Chlorpromazine = this is another conventional/typical antipsychotic drug but tends to antagonise BOTH D1 and D2 receptors 

C) CLOZAPINE (CORRECT ANSWER) = this is an atypical antipsychotic --> blocks BOTH dopamine (D2) and Serotonin (5HT2) 

  • Clozapine rarely causes extrapyramidal symptoms BUT other SE include = sedation and weight gain - a more serious SE is that it can cause neutropaenia, agranulocytosis hence the importance of monitoring bloods in the question

D) Fluoxetine - NOT an anti-psychotic, it's an SSRI which inhibits serotonin reuptake and used in the Tx of depression

E) Benzodiazepine - NOT an ant-psychotic, benzo is an anti-anxiolytic which works by enhancing GABAA receptor activity

Question: In the regulation of sleep, melanopsin receptors in the eye respond to light by sending signals to which part of the brain?
Explanation:
Correct answer is SUPRACHIASMATIC NUCLEUS (SCN) which is in the hypotahalamus

 

Light --> melenopsin receptors detect this --> send signals to SCN --> prevents pineal gland from releasing melatonin --> less melatonin = promotes wakefulness

Question: In an EEG waveform for sleep. which stage is characterised by sleep spindles and k-complexes?
Explanation:
NREM 1 & 2 = shallow sleep

NREM 3 & 4 = deep sleep/slow wave sleep (SWS)

REM = dream state (closest stage to wakefulness)

 

EEG WAVEFORM 

  • NREM 1 = alpha waves, low amplitude
  • NREM 2 = still alpha waves BUT high amplitude/slower frequency PLUS sleep spindles and k complexes
  • NREM 3 = delta waves appear, v. large amplitude
  • NREM 4 = dominated by delta waves
  • REM = back to alpha waves, waveform similar to wakefulness

Question: Hormonal events during puberty have important effects on the brain. Which part of the brain is implicated in reproductive behaviour?
Explanation:
3 main effects of sex steroid hormones on behaviour...

1) Reproductive behaviour = hypothalamus

2) Reorganisation of sensory & association regions = visual cortex, amygdala, hippocampus

3) Motivation & reward related behaviour = Nucleus accumbens, dopaminergic pathways to prefrontal cortex

 

Case 12 - Adolescent Neurocognitive Development

Question:
A 17 year old young lass decides to go for a zoom around his town centre at 1am on his motorbike. Unfortunately he was too adventurous and his trick to impress another young lass failed miserably and drove into a pole, he fell of his bike and hit his head, luckily his beanie gave his head some protection and he only lost consciousness for a few seconds and was up speaking to his mates after. 

Around 4am he started to have fluctuating levels of consciousness, had a 'banging' headache and was vomiting all over his mothers clean carpets. 

 

The paramedics where called...

on examination he had 

- GCS 10/15 

- Right pupil was larger than the Left and had a sluggish reaction to light.

 

What does he most likely have?
Explanation:
Correct Answer C: extradural Haemorrhage 

 

A: subdural haemorrhage 

under the dura, usually unconscious straight away and dont regain until after operation. higher force trauma impact and its under the dura. often looks like a banana on CT scans and doesnt have a clear definitive edge as it is below the dura 

 

B: subarachnoid haemorrhage 

classic symptoms: sudden onset of "the worst headache of my life", vomiting and stiff neck 

Nimodipine is given 

 

C: correct answer Extradural haemorrhage 

classic history: short LOC, then few hours later (time for the haemorrhage to get bigger), vomiting, headache and LOC occurs again 

looks like a mango on a CT - biconvex - has a clear border as is on the border of the dura 

more common in the temporal region - often middle meningeal artery ruptured 

Mannitol needed to be given! 

 

D: intraventricular haemorrhage 

seizures, headache normally more older patients and hypertensive patients, patients have apnea and bradycardia 

 

E: hydrocephalus 

water/CSF on the brain - unlikely to be this due to nature of the accident

Question:
You are observing in a GP surgery. A 32 year old woman comes to see the GP having recently found out that she is pregnant and estimates that she is 14 weeks pregnant based on the date of her last menstrual cycle.

The doctorasks about her previous obstetric history. She describes how this is her 3rd pregnancy and she has 3 children already, as two of her children are twins. 

The doctor asks you to record her obstetric history in her notes using the gravida/ parity short hand system. What would be the correct way to record this?
Explanation:
G3 P2 is the correct answer. 

Gravida refers to the number of pregnancies, regardless of them being carried to full term. Here this would be 3 as this is her third pregnancy. 

 

Party refers to the number of pregnancies carried to a viable gestational age. In this case, she has only currently carried 2 of these 3 pregnancies to term hence P2 is correct. 

It does not matter that they are twins because it is the number of pregnancies carried to a viable age, not the number of children. 

 

If one of these pregnancies had ended in miscarriage/ abortion then you would record it as G3P2+1 or G3 P2A1 depending on whether using the American or English system.

Question:
Amy has passed her interview and is looking forward to starting her C21 course at Cardiff University

 

 As part of the immunisations required to become a healthcare worker, she has blood tests to be checked for Hepatitis B.

 

Her results are as follows:

 

Hbs Ag +ve

Anti HBs -ve
HBe Ag -ve
Anti HBe +ve
Anti HBc +ve
Anti-HBc Igm -ve

 

 How do you describe her hepatits B status
Explanation:
She have +ve antigens for HBs - antigens come from viruses, not vaccines, so we're not looking at a vaccinated case here...

 She has Anti-HBe and Anti-Hbc both +ve. The only way you can produce antigens to core and envelope proteins is through infection.

 

 The infection is chronic persistent, because she is producing Anti-Hbe at the moment, without any HBe Ag being positive (this would be a chronic ACTIVE infection). It isn't an acute infection because she isn't producting Anti-HBc IgM

Question:
Your patient has had a Hepatitis B vaccination, which provokes an Anti-HBs level in the serum which can be recorded. The other results are all -ve

 

 As there are only antibodies to Hepatitis B surface proteins, what can be deduced about the vaccine?

 (Multiple answers may be correct, but the above fact only leads you to one conclusion)
OptionA: The vaccine is given multiple times to produce immunity
Explanation:
It tells you that it is a Subunit vaccine, because only the surface proteins are given to the patient. The core and envelope proteins are NOT given, which can help when determining someones status on blood tests.

Anti-HBs ALONE is proof of vaccination (and usually levels have to reach a certain threshold to be considered successful - 100iu). If there was Anti-HBs with Anti-HBe and/or Anti-HBc this would show history of a hepatitis B infection

 

Acute Hep B would show +ve Antigens for s and e, with Anti-HBc IgM (first response)

 

Chronic ACTIVE shows HBs Ag, HBe Ag, Anti-HBc
Chronic PERSISTENT shows HBsAg, Anti-HBe (not active as we're destroying envelopes) and Anti-HBc (not active as not making IgM acutely)

Question: What is the incidence of VSDs?
Explanation:
The correct answer is A. Ventricular Septal Defects occur as an isolated condition in 12/10,000 term births. VSDs are considered the commonest congenital heart defect. 

B: Ductus arteriosus occurs in 1 in 2000 births

C: Teratology of Fallot (which is characterized by 4 cardinal features: 1. Pulmonary valve stenosis 2. RVH 3. Overriding aorta and 4. VSD) occurs in 9.6-10/10,000 term births

D: Valvular stenosis (congenital) occurs in 3-4/10,000 live births

E: Transposition of the great vessels occurs in 4.8/10,000 births

 

I appreciate that recalling the incidence of certain conditions is difficult and troublesome, but all  the condition mentioned above were included in Professor Wilson's lecture, and it may be worth knowing the incidences of some of them considering they are quite common. Hope this helps :)
Tags: Foetal Anomalies, Cardiology, Foetal Development, embryology, case 8

Question: If a diabetic patient is diagnosed with diabetic macular oedema, what treatment should they receive in the retinal clinic?
Explanation:
Focal laser is the correct answer.

 

All the others are treatments for proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation and focal laser are both laser treatments, but the area of use is different. Focal laser treats aneurysms near the macula to treat the swelling in the macula area.

Question: Which nerve hooks around the ligamentum arteriosum?
During which week of gestation do cells from the sinus venosus spontaneously depolarizen to form the SA node?
Explanation: During week 5 of gestation, cardiomyocytes of the sinus venosus start undergoing spontaneous depolarisations at faster rates. The cardiomyocytes eventually coalesce, forming the SA node, which becomes incorporated into the wall of the RA near the junction of the SVC.

Question:
A 20 year old patient, who is normally fit and healthy, presents to A&E after stabbing his hand whilst doing the knife challenge.You perform an initial assessment of the patient's condition and note that, due to significant blood loss,a red blood cell transfusion is indicated. You stabilize the patient and monitor him whilst his referral to the orthopedic department is processed. After 3 hours the patient complains of severe breathlessness. On examination the patient is hypoxic and a chest x-ray shows bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. 

 

Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to be suffering from?
Explanation:
The correct answer is D.

 

Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury should be suspected in cases where a patient presents  with acute dyspnoea, hypoxia and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates within 6 hours of transfusion with no other apparent cause. 

 

The condition is suspected to occur due to antibodies within the donor plasma reacting with the white blood cells within the lungs of the patient. 

 

 

Refer to the "Blood Transfusions" plenary from Case 8 for more information :)

Question: A 40 year old man with uncontrolled hypertension is currently on an ACE inhibitor. What is the most appropriate next step?
OptionB: Swap ACE inhibitor with an Angiotensin Receptor blocker
OptionC: Swap ACE inhibitor with a Calcium Channel Blocker
OptionD: Add Calcium Channel Blocker with ACE inhibitor
Explanation:
A) shouldn't stop unless side effects badly tolerated, if stopped needs to given alternative 

B) This would be the next appropriate step if ACEi not tolerated - side effects e.g (angioedema) 

C) D) CCB should be added with ACEi therefore D is correct answer

E) Beta blockers are fourth line

 

Algorithm for Tx of HTN from NICE guidelines

Question: Which current in a ventricular action potential is associated with LQT2 (Long QT syndrome 2)?
Explanation:
A) IK1 = phase 4 (maintains resting potential)

B) INa= Phase 0 depolarisation (rapid sodium influx through channels associated with LQT3)

C) Ito =  Phase 1 (potassium efflux through channels that inactivate quickly resulting in transient repolarisation)

D) IKs = Phase 2 (slow potassium efflux through channels associated with LQT1) happens alongside Calcium influx (ICa,L)

E) IKr = Phase 3 (rapid potassium efflux through hERG channels which are associated with LQT2) - CORRECT ANSWER  

           -Phase 3 involves IKr  IKs  IK1

 

currents affected in LONG QT SYNDROME...

LQT1/LQT2 = K

LQT3 = Na

Question:
It is 12pm on a Sunday, and John has finally woken up. He stands up and is about to walk to the kitchen.

 

What area of the brain controls the initiation and planning of his walk?
Explanation:
B is the correct answer

 

A - the PMC controls distal musculature and fine skilled movements (involved later in the sequence of movement of his lower limbs)

 

B - Correct - the SMA is involved in the initiation and planning of movement, as well as bimanual coordination

 

C - the PMC controls proximal musculature

 

D and E - both components of the basal ganglia, which are involved in motor sequence learning, e.g. learning to walk as a toddler

Question: A patient comes into AE requiring a neuromuscular blockade. You are thinking about the differences between atracurium and suxamethonium. Which of the following features is similar in the two
Explanation:
atracurium broken down faster than sux.

 

sux. causes fasciulations

 

atracurium is the antagonist. sux is an AGONIST

 

sux. causes initial flaccid paralysis

Question: What is the most common cause of surgical site infections after a spinal surgery?
Explanation:
staph auerus

enterococcus

e coli 

pseudomonas

 

strep doesn't fall into the category provided by spine dragon

Question: A patient comes into your clinic with unexplained weight loss and complains of lower back pain. After running many tests including use of tumour markers, you deduce they sadly have ovarian cancer that has spread to the spine. What tumour marker was present that allowed you to figure out that ovarian cancer was the primary cause?
Explanation:
From spine dragon's lecture

 

CA153 = breast

CA125 = ovary

AFP/HCG = testis

CEA = bowel

Question: NICE recommends the routine (antenatal) administration of anti-D during which weeks of pregnancy?
Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) mostly affects...
Explanation:
Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) usually affects frail, old people who are chronically anaemic. In chronic anemia, blood volume is usually normal and therefore patients can potentially be overloaded. The risk of TACO is also increased in: 

- Patients undergoing unnecessary transfusions

- Elderly/ co-morbidities 

- Small

- Rapid

-Overtransfusion

Question: The A and B genes encode for enzymes (transferases) which transfer the appropriate sugars to H substance, resulting in A and B antigens. The transfer of which sugar yields the B-antigen?
Explanation:
N-Acetyl-D-galactosamine is added to substance H to make the A-antigen.

N-Acetly-Cysteine is not a sugar, it is an antidote for NAPQI poisoning (usually secondary to paracetamol poisoning)

Question: During which week of gestation does the heart begin to pump?
Explanation:
-Heart developes (in cardiogenic regions of the mesoderm) from Week 3 of gestation

- Angioblastic cords (aggregates of endothelial cell precursors) develop and here they coalesce to form 2 lateral endocardial tubes

- During week 4, these tubes fuse together to form the 'primitive heart tube' and the heart begins to pump (around day 28)

- From week 5-8, the primitive heart tube folds and remodels to form the 4 chambered heart

Question: During which weeks of gestation does the 'truncus arteriousus' divide into two distinct parts, forming the aorta and the pulmonary trunk?
Explanation: During week 7-8, truncus arteriosus (the common outflow tract of the heart) is divided in 2, forming the aorta and the pulmonary trunk (simultaneously, the membranous part of the IV septum joins the muscular part, completing the separation of the ventricles).

Question: During which day of gestation does cephalo-caudal folding of the heart occur?
Explanation: During day 22 of gestation, the central part of the heart is anterior to the NT (which has begun to close), as the NS is growing, the heart tube and the pericardial cavity are pushed into the thoracic region.

Question: Cardiac looping occurs during which days of gestation?
Explanation:
Cardiac looping occurs during days 23-28 of gestation. The cardiac tube lengthens, which forms the RV and the outflow tract. Thee outflow tract lengthens and the cardiac tube begins to bend (day 23). Cardiac looping is complete by day 28.

 

NB. Genes involved in cardiac looping are the Wnt family of proteins (which are involved in the induction of ectodermally and mesodermally derived organs/tissues) and the BMP-2 (the latter belongs to the TGF-B family of proteins, which regulate cell differentiation)

Question: You and you're colleague are carrying out an experiment on sleep. You connect a patient, volunteer up to an EEG machine to record the electrical activity of their brain whilst they are sleeping. On observation, you can see that the patient is tossing and turning and the EEG shows low amplitude waves with moderate frequency. You identify that these may be alpha waves. What stage of sleep is the volunteer in?
Explanation:
The correct answer is A) Stage 1

 

Stage 1 - low amplitude and moderate frequency of waves - characteristic alpha waves - individual is drowsy 

Stage 2 - there are higher frequency and low amplitude waves and characteristic sleep spindles and k complexes present 

Stage 3 - there are delta waves present - big amplitude of slow waves of 1-2Hz

Stage 4 - deep sleep (lasts about 30 minutes)

REM - includes inhibited skeletal muscles so paralysis of muscles is characteristic - loss of muscle tone due to inwards inhibition of alpha motor neurones - REM EEG waves look similar to that of wakefulness but they are not as densely packed so look clearer (lasts 10 minutes)

Wakefulness - low amplitude of high frequency waves because individual is awake and moving around

Question: Which part of the brain is melatonin secreted from?
Explanation: Melatonin is synthesised from serotonin and secreted from the pineal gland in the brain. The concentration of melatonin increases during night and decreases during the day. Light inhibits the biosynthesis of melatonin

Question: What is the single best predictor of day time performance?
OptionB: Total hours of sleep, including naps, in the day
OptionC: Number of nights sleeping in the past week

Question: What is the most common cause of narcolepsy?
Explanation: Lack of hypocretin is the most common cause of narcolepsy. Hypocretin (orexin) is a neuropeptide in the brain, which regulates arousal, wakefulness and appetite.

Question: Which milk specific substances are produced during the first stage of lactogenesis (lactogenesis I)?
Explanation:
During mid-pregnancy, prolactin induces the mRNA transcription of milk proteins enzymes which are necessary for milk formation and secretion. During stage 1 of lactogenesis (from 4 months), lactose, casein and alpha -lactalbumin are produced. 

 

Birth is the main physiological stimulus for lactogenesis II (this occurs mainly 30-40 hours after birth), there is a subsequent increase in milk volume. lactose, IgA and lactoferrin. High oligosaccharide levels are protective against pathogens.

 

 

Functions of the following substances:

Lactoferrin: a globular glycoprotein with antimicrobial effects (bacterocide, fungicide), its primary role is to sequester free iron, and in doing so, deny the offending microbial agent from an essential substrate needed for growth and proliferation/mltiplication.

Alpha lactalbumin: It's expression is upregulated in response to the hormone prolactin and increases the production of lactose (synthesis of lactose is dependent on apha-lactalbumin). It also has an imunological benefit, as it promotes the growth of bifidobacterium (the same bacteria that is added to yoghurt) 

Lactose: a disaccharide sugar composed of galactose and glucose that is found in milk.50 different oligosaccharids are synthesized from lactose. Galactose, one of the digestion products of lactose, is an essential component of the myelin sheath.

Casein: inhibits adhesion of various bacteria in different epithelial sites and promotes the growth of bifidobacterium.

Question: What is the function of lactoferrin?
OptionB: Blocks adsorption/penetration of viruses and adhesion of bacteria
Explanation:
Lactoferrin is a globular glycoprotein with antimicrobial effects (bactericide, fungicide). It's primary role is to sequester free Fe, and in doing so, deny the offending microorganism from a substrate that is essential for growth and multiplication/proliferation. Lactoferrin is one of the transferrin proteins that transfer iron to cells and control the level of free iron in the blood.

 

Lactoferrin also blocks the adsorption/penetration of viruses and adhesion of bacteria to mucosal membranes. It also contributes to intestinal cell growth and repair (effective barrier) and decreases the production of IL-1,2,6 and TNF-Alpha.

 

Human colostrum has the highest concentration of lactoferrin (followed by human milk).

Question:
A lecturer is explaining to some medical students that a particular layer of the uterus hypertrophies during pregnancy. This layer is made up of 3 sub-layers (the outer longitudinal, middle crisscrossing and an inner circular).

Which layer of the uterus is he referring to?
Explanation:
The uterus has 3 layers (from outer to inner):

  • Perimetrium - outer, visceral layer
  • Myometrium - middle, muscular layer which hypertrophies during pregnancy. Has 3 layers within it (outer longitudinal, middle crisscrossing and inner circular)
  • Endometrium - inner lining made of stratum basilar, which proliferates to form the stratum functionalism (which is shed in menstruation).

'Ectometrium' is not a real layer of the uterus.

 

The peritoneum is a mesentery which lies over the top of the uterus. This is not a layer of the uterus.

 

L x

Question:
Angleman syndrome is caused by a deletion on chromosome 15 inherited from the maternal DNA.

Prader-Willi syndrome is also caused by a deletion on chromosome 15, but inherited from the paternal DNA.

What is the name of this phenomenon?
Explanation:
GENOMIC IMPRINTING = where a particular gene may only present if it is passed on by a certain parent. This affects 1% of genes.

 

Angleman syndrome - microcephaly, intellectual disability, gait ataxia

Prader-Willi syndrome - early poor feeding then hyperplasia and obesity, hypogonadism

 

Co-dominance - when two alleles are both fully expressed e.g. red gene and white gene will cause a pink flower. This is the case in the ABO blood grouping system (A and B co-dominant and O is recessive to both)

Somatic mutation - where only some cells have the mutation, leading to a milder phenotype

Polygenic inheritance - phenotype influenced by many genes

Uniparental disomy (isodisomy) - when both a child's chromosomes originate from one parent 

 

L x
Tags: Pregnancy, chromosomal abnormalities, chromosome abnormalities, Case 7

Question: A a pregnant woman comes into the GP surgery wanting to know more about the benefits of breastfeeding. Which of the following statements about the immunological benefits of breast milk is incorrect?
OptionA: Provides immunological protection whilst the infants immune system is maturing
OptionB: Lactoferrin increases the production of IL- 1,2,6 and TNF- alpha
OptionE: Casein inhibits adhesion of various bacteria in different epithelial sites and promotes the growth of bifidobacterium
Explanation:
Lactoferrin actually decreases the production of IL-1,2,6 and TNF-α (immune modulation)

 

 

 

Case 8, Anatomy of the breast, physiology and immunology of lactation lecture

Question: A 25 year old female is on Flecainide for her arrhythmia. How does this anti-arrhythmic work?
OptionA: Blocks fast path channels which reduces aberrant electrical excitability
OptionC: Blocks K+ channels thus prolonging refractory period of cardiac action potential
OptionD: Blocks calcium channels thus retarding calcium mediated impulses through AVN
OptionE: Activates A1 receptors which reduces cAMP levels and reduces calcium levels in AVN
Explanation:
5 specific antiarrhythmics mentioned in Dr Coffey's lecture: Flecainide, Bisoprolol, Amiadorone, Diltiazem, Adenosine...

 

A) Flecainide MOA described (VW class I = Na+ channel blockers, flec is class 1c)

B) Bisoprolol MOA described (VW class II)

C) Amiodarone MOA described ( VW class III = blocks K+ channels, prolongs phase 3, ^ERP, cardiac tissue won't be stimulated by aberrant impulses in this period)

D) Diltiazem MOA described (VW class IV/CCB = blocks Ca++ channels = phase 0 prolonged in pacemaker potential = resulting in slower SAN firing and slower AVN conduction)

E) Adenosine MOA described (VW class V = blocks A1 receptors eventually resulting in less Ca++ which slows conduction in AVN given via rapid IV bolus

Question: Prior to fertilisation, ovum are suspended in a particular stage of meiosis. Which is this?
Explanation:
Prior to fertilisation, the ovum are suspended in arrested metaphase II.

 

L x

Question: Your are a F1 doctor working on the wards one of your patients has been treated previously for HSV but keeps getting recurring herpes simplex encephalitis. What genetic defect is associated with this?
Explanation:
Recurrence of herpes simplex encephalitis is associated with genetic defects in TLR-3 signalling pathway

Taken from "Immunological responses to viral infection" lecture

Question: You are working at a GP clinic when a 5 year old girl walks in presenting with pyrexia, cervical lymphadenopathy and pharyngitis, she can't swallow anything and her mother wants to know what is causing her symptoms and to get her on some treatment as soon as possible. Which virus does this classic triad of symptoms indicate towards?
Explanation:
Epstein Barr classic triad of symptoms are pyrexia, persistent pharyngitis and cervical lymphadenopathy

 

Taken from "Immunological response to viral infection" lecture

Question:
A 14 y/o girl presents at your clinic with her mother who is worried about her being bullied at school. The girl is notably short in stature and has a BMI of 26. The girl describes 'not feeling happy with her appearance'. The lab results for her hormone profile are as follows:

 

LH (U/L):                    11   (1-10)

FSH (U/L):                 13   (1-10)

Oestrogen(pg/ml):     13   (32-500)

Serum T4 (ug/dL):      4    (5.5-15)

Serum TSH (UI/L):     0.5 (0.5-6.5)

 

What is your first course of action:
OptionA: Ask the mother to leave the room, discuss gender dysphoria with the girl and then refer to psychiatry
OptionE: Do nothing, the girl has not yet hit puberty
Explanation:
You may have guessed the girl has Turner's Syndrome, but to make it harder I made it a 'what would you do' question like in the progress test

Turners syndrome is primary hypogonadism (primary referring the fact its a problem with the primary sexual organs e.g. ovaries, and therefore Oestrogen)

 

• Raised/Normal serum FSH/LH

• Low serum Oestrogen

• Hypothyroidism 

 

 

A) Gender Dysphoria would not present with (significant) hormonal changes 

B) Hypothyroidism is a symptom of Turners

C) Though technically almost correct from an understanding point of view, the primary treatment is HGH in patients under 16

D) Correct

E) A thoughtful guess however serum FSH/LH in pre-pubescent girls would be at the lower end of the normal range, additionally obesity tends to cause precocious puberty due to more available cholesterol to convert to oestrogen. 

 

Hope the question helped, took me ages to type up the hormone values!

Love Sam
Tags: case 9, Child Development, endocrinology, Case 7, case 8

Question: A 28 year old pregnant female and her husband come to a geneticist to find out the chances of their child being born with any conditions. After an extensive history taking, the geneticist tells them that there's a 50% offspring risk of getting a particular autosomal dominant condition that the husband himself suffers from. Which of these could he mostly likely be talking about?
Explanation:
List of autosomal dominant conditions from case 7 lecture on "Family History and Probabilities" - slide 8.

 

  • Huntington disease
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Familiar hypercholesterolaemia
  • Spinocerebellar ataxia
  • FAP
  • Hereditary breast and ovarian cancer
  • Myotonic dystrophy
  • Long QT syndrome

Question: How many weeks after birth does the composition of human milk finally mature?
Explanation:
Colostrium refers to the human milk produced during the first week after birth. Approximately 40 ml of colostrum is produced each day. Colostrum has a characteristic sticky, yellowish appearance, and is relatively low in fats and lactose (rich in minerals and fat-soluble vitamins A,K,E,D). Colostrum also contains IgA and acts as a laxative facilitating the formation/movement of meconium through the neonate's GI tract. 

 

Human milk reaches it mature composition 3 weeks after birth. It's calorific value increases (75 kcal per 100 ml), so does its fat, lactose and amino acid content.

Question: During which weeks of gestation does the inter-atrial septum form?
Explanation:
During week 5-6, the septum primum and septum secondum grow to seperate the right and left atria. These septa are incomplete and have 2 openings: 1. Fossa Ovalis 2. Ostium Secondum. The septum primum grown downwards from the postero-superior wall if the IA septum. The formane/ostium primum it creates narrows as the septum grows, this eventuates in its closure. 

While the septum prium is growing, a thicker septum, the septum secondum also starts to form. This septum secondum does not meet the septum intermedium, leaving an opening called the foramen ovale near the floor of the RA at the level of the IA septum. The septum primum acts as a flap-like valve over the foramen ovale, allowing -oxygenated blood to be shunted from the RA to the LA.

 

NB. The foramen ovale closes at birth when the neonate takes his/her first breathe (the first cry). When the lungs become functional at birth, the pulmonary pressure decreases and the left atrial pressure exceeds that of the right. This forces the septum primum against the septum secundum, functionally closing the foramen ovale. In time the septa eventually fuse, leaving a remnant of the foramen ovale, the fossa ovalis.

 

NB. The atrioventricular valves (mitral and tricuspid valves) form during weeks 5-6 as well!

Question: The expression of which protein allows Cytomegalovirus (CMV) to escape immune surveillance?
Explanation: CMV expresses US6 protein, which prevents/ inhibits the peptide loading onto MHC class 1. A significant proportion of CMV genome gives rise to genes which express proteins that allow the evasion of MHC recognition (downregulation of MHC as a way of evading the immune system).

Question: Which of the following is an example of a (-)ssRNA virus?
Explanation:
Influenza virus is a (-)ssRNA virus.

 

Herpes Virus is a dsDNA virus.

Reovirus is a dsRNA

Poliovirus is a (+)ssRNA

HIV is reverse RNA virus (that is, utlizes  the enzyme reverse transcriptase, which is used to form a complementary DNA strand from the viral RNA strand)

Question: Which of the following Toll Like Receptors (TLR) used to detect pathogens is not found on the cell surface membrane?
Explanation:
TLR 1,2,4,5,6 are found on the cell surface membrane 

TLR 3,7,8,9 are located on the endosomes. 

 

Recurrent Herpes Simplex encephalitis is associated with defects in the TLR-3 signalling pathway. 

There are also cytosolic TLRs called Rig Like Receptors (RLRs) - These can produce Type 1 interferons (alpha and beta)

Question: According to the Baltimore classification system, classify the following virus: Reovirus
Which of the following is NOT an example of a live virus?
Explanation: Influenza (injected form) is not a live virus it is killed.

Question: According to the Baltimore classification system, classify the following virus: Poliovirus
Explanation: Other viruses which belong to class 4 (+ssRNA) are: Hep A, Hep C, Tagavirus and Foot - and- mouth disease virus

Question: Where is an ectopic pregnancy most likely to occur
Explanation: 95% of ectopic pregnancies occur in the uterine tube and can occur in the ampullary, tubal or interstitial regions of the tube

Question: When is the 5 in 1 vaccine administered?
Explanation:
B= CORRECT. 5 in 1 vaccine: Diptheria, tetanus, polio, whooping cough and Hib (haemophilus influenza B). Caused by Cornybacterium diptheria, clostridium tetani, poliovirus, bordetella pertussis and haemophilus infleuzna B respectively. Administered at 2,3 and 4 months of age (3 doses).

 

Diptheria = toxoid, Tetanus = toxoid, Polio = inactivated, Whooping cough = subunit or  conjugate. 

 

A = Rotavirus (Reovirdae rotavirus)

C= Pneumococcal 

D= MMR

E = Men C

Question: A 70 year old male patient with a history of COPD and a recent splenectomy requires which of the following immunizations?
Explanation:
Infleunza vaccine is indicated for all patients aged 65 and above. Clinical risk groups, such as patients with chronic respiratory disease (i.e COPD, asthma) is also an indication for influenza vaccine. 

Pneumococcal vaccine is also recommended for all patients who are 65 years and above, as well as for people with asplenia or splenic dysfunction (i.e sickle cell disease or severe coeliac disease).

Shingles (reactivation of Varicella Zoster Virus/ VZV many years after the original chickenpox episode) is a live -attenuated vaccine recommended for all people aged 70 years.

Question: Which combination of immunizations is recommended for Health Care Workers (HCW)?
Explanation:
B = Lab Staff

C= Prison staff

D = Social care staff

E= Animal handling (i.e vets, zoos etc..)

Question: Which one of the following drugs is a beta-adrenoceptor blocker?
What systolic/diastolic blood pressure is considered to be the cut-off/threshold for hypertension?
During adolescence, what white mater changes occur in the brain?
What is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain?
T cells are antigen specific, how is it ensured that the very few antigen specific T cells encounter the conventional Dendritic cell presenting the specific antigen?
OptionB: conventional Dendritic cells continuously traffic secondary lymph node
OptionC: Naive T cells continuously traffic secondary lymph node
OptionD: Cytokines released by the conventional Dendritic cell attract the specific T cell to the draining lymph node
OptionE: Large volume of space swept by dendrites of the conventional Dendritic cells
Explanation: A major challenge to the initiation of the immune response is that antigen-bearing cDCs and rare antigen-specific T cells have to find each other. In any given lymph-node there are estimated to be 100-1200 epitope specific T cells with the appropriate TCR. However, the large volume of space swept by dendrites of DC suggests a 95% chance that a single antigen specific T cell will encounter at least one DC as it it traffics through LN

Question:
After feeling quite unwell, Steve has been admitted to hospital. He has had a lumbar puncture and subsequent analysis of his CSF, which looks yellow and is quite viscous. You get the following results back:

 

Polymorphonuclear cells: + (slightly increased)

Lymphocytes: +++ (markedly increased)

Protein: +

Glucose: normal

 

What is causing Steve's illness?
Explanation:
The answer should be C) Fungus

 

A) Enterovirus can cause encephalitis or viral meningitis. If a patient has viral meningitis, their CSF will appear clear and the results will be as follows:

Polymorphonuclear cells + or normal

Lymphocytes +++

Protein + or normal

Glucose normal

 

B) Neisseria meningitidis can cause bacterial meningitis. Patients will have a yellowish, turbid CSF and the results will be as follows:

Polymorphonuclear cells +++

Lymphocytes + or normal

Protein +++

Glucose decreased

 

C) Fungus is as above

 

D) Herpes simplex virus can cause encephalitis

 

E) TB patients will have a yellowish, viscous CSF. Their results will be as follows:

Polymorphonuclear cells + or normal

Lymphocytes +++

Protein ++ (increased)

Glucose decreased

 

This is a bit of a mean question as TB, fungus and viral meningitis CSF results can look very similar. The way I like to distinguish them is that TB has increased protein (whereas fungus can have only slightly increased or normal protein), fungus can have normal or decreased glucose but TB will only present with decreased glucose and viral meningitis appears clear. Bacterial meningitis is a bit easier to spot as polymorphonuclear cells (neutrophils) will be markedly increased as opposed to lymphocytes which are more involved in the response to viral infection.
Tags: Infectious Diseases, Case 16, Meninges, Microbiology, investigations

Question: The FCyRIII receptor is most abundantly expressed on which type of cell?
Explanation:
FCyRIII is an activating receptor for IgG and is the only Fc receptor expressed by NK cells. Although also expressed by macrophages, neutrophils and eosinophils, the functions of FcyRIII are mainly associated with NK cells.

NK cells can kill and recognize human cells that have been coated with IgG1 and IgG3 antibodies. This mechanism is called antibody - dependent cell mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC).

Question: In what chromosome is there a default in Huntington's disease?
Explanation: Huntington's disease is an abnormal gene on chromosome 4 that is a dominant genetic disorder. It is a brain disorder that causes personality changes, involuntary movement and dementia. Children of an affected parent have a 50% chance of inheriting the disease.

Question:
Mr and Mrs Twinings are looking to have a baby and decide to get genetically screened first. They both have a family history of Angelman Syndrome and Prader Willi Syndrome due to deletion at 15q11-q13.

 

 

Mr Twinings asks the geneticist "if that gene is deleted in the child, which syndrome will the child have?"

The geneticist replies "I can't say which of these two syndromes the baby will have as the determination of this is dependent on another factor".

 

What factor is this likely to be?
OptionB: Which parent the deletion is inherited from
OptionC: If the father has a direct relative with Prader Willi Syndrome
OptionE: Penetrance of the syndromes within the respective families
Explanation:
This principle is called genomic imprinting

 

This is when a gene's expression is dependent on which parent it was inherited from. 

15q11-q13 deletion from MATERNAL chromosome 15 will lead to Angelman Syndrome

15q11-q13 deletion from PATERNAL chromosome 15 will lead to Prader Willi Syndrome.

 

For further guidance refer to Case 7's "Unusual Patterns of Inheritance" lecture.

Question:
You are a doctor in a GP surgery. A woman comes to your surgery as she is planning a trip to visit her husband's family in Malaysia and would like some vaccinations before she travels. You see she has some missing routine vaccinations.  She informs you that she is 12 weeks pregnant and is concerned about travelling due to this reason. 

 

Which of the following vaccines can she MOST LIKELY not receive and is contra-indicated?
Explanation:
C - BCG. 

This is contra-indicated because uniquely amongst these vaccines - BCG is a live attenuated virus. As a general rule we do not give these to pregnancy mothers due to increased risk of damage to foetus which is immuno-naive. However, sometimes the benefits can outweigh the risks and has to be taken on a case by case basis.

Question:
A mother, father and their 2 month old son come to the GP surgery for his first vaccination - the 5 in 1 vaccine which consists of DTaP, IPV and Hib vaccines. 

The mother expresses concerns because she has read somewhere that a live form of one of the diseases will be injected into her son and asks about the contents of the vaccine. 

You explain to her the types of vaccines which make up the 5 in 1.

 

What is the correct number of each type of vaccine which makes up the 5 in 1?
OptionB: 3 live attenuated, 1 sub unit and 1 inactivated.
OptionD: 1 live attenuated, 2 sub unit and 3 inactivated.
Explanation:
The answer is:D

 

It is called 5 in 1 because there are 5 diseases vaccinated against. 

Babies are given the DTaP - diphtheria, tetanus and acellular pertussis; IPV - injectable polio vaccine; Hib - haemophiliac influence type B. 

 

In fact, there are no live  viruses within this vaccine. It does contain inactivated polio viruses however. 

 

Injectable Polio: 3 strains of inactive polio. 

 

The rest of the vaccines are subunits and some are conjugated. 

 

Diphtheria:diphtheria toxoid

Tetanus: tetanus toxoid

Acellular Pertussis: purified pertussis antigens 

HiB: Haemophilus influenzae type b polysaccharide which is either conjugated to tetanus toxoid or is attached to aluminium phosphate (adjuvant).

 

http://www.medicines.org.uk/emc/PIL.26222.latest.pdf

Question: Miss Gibson has a lesion in one of the nerves in her CNS. Which of the following statements correctly describes a step in the CNS response to injury?
OptionA: Schwann cells phagocytose debris but also secrete trophic factors, promoting axonal growth
OptionC: Wallerian degeneration is triggered by extracellular and intracellular calcium ions entering the cytosol
OptionD: Sodium and calcium ions flow in through NMDA channels
OptionE: Astrocyte processes link together to surround the lesion
Explanation:
The correct answer should be E) Astrocyte processes link together to surround the lesion

 

The CNS response to injury is as follows:

  1. Blood borne monocytes and macrophages invade the injury site as the blood-brain barrier is breached
  2. Microglia multiply and activate to remove cellular debris
  3. From about 24hrs, oligodendrocyte precursors divide and hypertrophy - astrocytes do the same after a further 24hrs
  4. Astrocyte processes link together to surround the lesion
  5. Meningeal-like cells may invade the lesion cavity, forming a plug
  6. Glial scar formation is controlled by molecules such as cytokines (released by microglia, neurones and astrocytes)

A and C are steps from the PNS response to injury:

  1. Nerve injury occurs
  2. There is an initial reaction to the injury (inflammation) which lasts approximately 24hrs - Schwann cells phagocytose debris but also secrete trophic factors, promoting axonal growth (but only for 1-2 months)
  3. Macrophage recruitment and Wallerian degeneration occurs which lasts for 1 week - degeneration is triggered by extra and intracellular calcium ions entering the cytosol, activating the protease calpain which breaks down the cytoskeleton
  4. Schwann cell alignment and axon regeneration occurs which can last weeks to months - invading macrophages secrete factors (e.g. galectin-1) that promote Schwann cell migration and axon growth. Schwann cells also de-differentiate and start dividing but stay within the basal lamina tube that previously contained the myelinated/unmyelinated axon
  5. Successful target reinnervation which can take weeks to years to complete

B is just an incorrect statement regarding apoptosis. Apoptosis can occur due to a loss of trophic factors needed for cell survival (e.g. BDNF, NGF), or it can be triggered by extracellular ligands (e.g. TNF). Apoptosis is orchestrated by proteolytic enzymes (caspases) and DNAases. The resulting apoptotic bodies are phagocytosed in the CNS by microglia. Oligodendrocytes are actually the myelin sheath producing cells of the CNS.

 

D is describing a step in the opening of the glutamate receptor channel NMDA (important in excitotoxicity).

  1. At resting potential, NMDA is blocked by magnesium ions
  2. Depolarising the dendrite via the AMPA glutamate receptor unblocks the NMDA channel
  3. Sodium and calcium ions flow in through NMDA, causing further depolarisation. If this neurone also contains glutamate, more is released when action potentials are fired

I got all this information from Dr Watson's lecture on Functional Neuroanatomy and Response to Nerve Cell Injury in Case 16.

Question:
A mother who has been reading literature about vaccinations and the 'dangers' they pose comes to your GP surgery with her 11-month old daughter prior to her MMR vaccination. She has concerns over putting 3 different vaccines into her child's body at once and is very worried about the 'damaging effects' this might have. 

 

She demands to know why you will not offer the MMR vaccine as 3 separate vaccinations.

 

Why is this?
OptionA: By giving in three separate doses you are putting heightened toll on the child's immune system. It is better to do it all at once so the immune system is activated once and the child is not consistently creating a primary immune response.
OptionB:
For a month following the first vaccine interferons are produced which place the body in an anti-viral state. This means that the subsequent vaccine with a live attenuated virus may not be able to enter body cells and cause a primary immune response giving an immunological memory and hence will not work. 

If given a month apart this puts the child at risk of transmitting these diseases in the space between vaccines.
OptionC: It is entirely possible and potentially better, but it is not funded on the NHS because it is more expensive and time consuming.
OptionD:
The structure of the three viruses contained within the MMR vaccination are all very similar. They all contain the envelope glycoprotein Hemaggluttin but in slightly different forms.

 

This means that you have to give the three vaccines all at once you create high affinity antibodies for all three subtle forms of the hemeggluttin glycoprotein.

If you gave e.g. mumps first then this would result in B-cell memory to that hemegluttin glycoprotein which would then be stimulated to proliferate when the next two vaccines are given and you don't get very high affinity antibody production for these, resulting in reduced immunity.
OptionE:
The structure of the three viruses contained within the MMR vaccination are all very similar. They all contain the envelope glycoprotein Hemaggluttin. This means that the viruses are all uptaken into cells on this go and there is a heightened exposure to the Hemaggluttin protein. 

This creates heightened T cell response and therefore a larger primary immune response which correlates to a better secondary immune response.
Explanation:
B is the correct answer. 

As outlined in the question. 

 

A: I made this up. 

C: This is true, it is not funded on the NHS and it is possible. It is not right because it is not 'potentially better'

B: I also made this up. Hemagluttin is found on the measles virus and H-M glycoprotein is found on the mumps virus but apart from this its all lies. 

E: again this is not true.

Question:
A father comes into the GP surgery with his 2 year old daughter and there has been a mumps outbreak in her nursery. She has not received any MMR vaccinations. He is worried about the potential effects of the MMR but also worried about what the serious complications could be if his daughter contracts mumps. 

 

You describe to him a list of the most serious complications of the mumps virus..

 

Which of the following would be most similar to your description?
OptionA: meningitis, kidney stones, ovarian cysts, back pain
OptionB: meningitis, encephalitis, urine infection, ovarian cysts, blindness, pididymo-orchitis,
OptionC: meningitis, headache, infertility, oophoritis, gallstones, lung parenchymal disease

Question: What is the most serious long term complication of measles?
Explanation:
A is correct. 

The most serious long term effect. Occurs 7-10 years after the virus was caught. 1 in 25,000 cases.

Question: What type of rhythm is associated with the sleep cycle?
