Explanation: The sleep cycle is associated with an ultradian rhythm, a rhythm that lasts less than 24hrs because you pass through 4 stages of sleep and REM sleep approx every 90 minutes. A circadian rhythm is typically a 24 hour cycle, whereas an infradian rhythm lasts longer than 24hrs, for example the menstrual cycle. A circannial cycle is an annual cycle, e.g. the hibernation of some animals.

Question:
A 3-year old child presents to your GP surgery. They have not received their MMR vaccine. They have a 2 day history of a fever of 38.0, malaise and a lack of energy and a loss of appetite. They have developed a cough in the last day. 

On inspection, you see yellow-grey mouth ulcers with a red edge along with a rash on the back of his hand and a small blister on his toe. 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The Answer is A:

Lack of MMR not relevant once you see the examination. Rash is not maculopapular and erythematous so rules of measles. Do not tend to get this pattern of rash with rubella. 

 

HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE – name comes from the rash which is found on the hands, feet and ulcers that can appear in the mouth. Common in children under 10 and very contagious. Only found in children not adults. The skin rash can be itchy, while spots can be flat or raised someotimes with blisters and are smaller than that of chicken pox rashes. Can normally clear up on its own within 7-10 days and should be able to look after the baby at home.

Question:
A 4 year old child presents to the A+E department. They have a very high fever of 39 degrees and have been unwell for 2 days with malaise, a cough and cold like symptoms. 

Their mother has bought them into A+E due to the appearance of small greyish white spots on the inside of their mouth within the last 4 hours (Koplik's spots).

They are diagnosed with measles and admitted to an isolated ward room. 

Over the next 3 days, a maculopapular erythematous rash appears firstly on their face and neck and then spreads across their body. 

 

What is the case of this maculopapular erythematous rash in relation to the measles virus?
OptionA: The rash is due to the measles virus itself, bursting open endothelial cells as it infects them and then buds.
OptionB: The rash occurs because cytotoxic T cells attacks measles virus infected vascular endothelial cells in the skin.
OptionC: The rash occurs because of the heightened and large amount of circulating histamine as part of the immune response.
OptionD: The rash is due to NK cells breaking down the non-keratinising stratified squamous epithelium infected with measles.
OptionE: The rash is due to be breakdown of red blood cells infected by the measles virus.
Explanation: you can see when this occurs. this is when there is T cell involvement. The measles virus infects the endothelial cells and the break down of this causes the reddened, raised rash.

Question: On an ECG, absence of a P wave indicates what arrhythmia?
Explanation: Absence of a P wave from an ECG is characteristic of AF

Question: Mr Andrews, an 86-year-old pensioner, has heart failure. He presents to you with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, pulmonary congestion and on auscultation of his heart, he appears to have a murmur. Which sided heart failure does Mr Andrews have, and based on the fact he has an overload in volume, what murmur is he likely to have?
Explanation:
The correct answer should be D) Left sided heart failure, mitral regurgitation

 

Mr Andrews has left heart failure because he has pulmonary congestion (which leads to paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, orthopnoea, cough with frothy sputum) and decreased cardiac output (which leads to activity intolerance and decreased tissue perfusion --> cyanosis and hypoxia)

Aspects of left heart failure can also be caused by murmurs:

  • Volume overload can be due to mitral/aortic regurgitation
  • Impaired ventricular filling due to mitral stenosis

Left heart failure can also cause the development of right heart failure. Right heart failure causes congestion of peripheral tissues --> oedema + ascites, GI tract congestion (which can lead to anorexia, GI distress, weight loss), and liver congestion (which can lead to impaired liver function).

Aspects of right heart failure can also be caused by murmurs:

  • Volume overload can be due to tricuspid/pulmonic regurgitation
  • Impaired ventricular filling can be caused by tricuspid stenosis

Question: In a standard ECG, what is the normal paper speed?
Explanation: Standard ECG is measured with a paper speed of 25mm/sec - if the paper speed is faster, it makes it look like as if the heart rate is slower!

Question: In a standard ECG, what is the normal voltage that the ECG is recorded at?
Explanation: This should be seen on collaboration - decreasing the voltage can make the ECG waveforms less obvious and therefore more difficult to interpret

Question: A normal cardiac axis deviation is said to spread from the atria to the ventricles (from 11o'clock to 5o'clock). In this instance, if the aVR lead has a negative deflection, so the QRS waves a predominantly negative, which lead on the opposite side will have the greatest positive deflection?
Explanation: Lead II will have the greatest positive deflection - although Leads I and III will also have positive deflections, the positive deflection in Lead II will be greater as the depolarising wave is going directly towards this lead.

Question: What type of collagen is found within articular cartilage of bones?
Explanation:
TYPE I collagen is predominantly found in bone

TYPE II collagen is predominantly found in cartilages 

TYPE III is most commonly found along with Type I and in reticular fibres

TYPE IV is in basil lamina and epithelial-secreted basement membrane

TYPE V found in placenta, hair and cell surfaces

Question: The three of the four main symptoms of hypercalcaemia are: bones, moans (psychological), abdominal pain (groans). What is the fourth?
Explanation: Bone health and bone disease lecture from case 14

Question:
A 78-year old male attends a GP clinic, where you are shadowing the GP. He has come for a repeat prescription for his topical cream used to treat is haemorrhoids. He remarks how successful this treatment has been and wants to know how this cream is helping him. 

 

The doctor asks you to explain how this cream works. You know that it contains cinchocaine and you know that the MOA for this is.....
OptionA: Blocks voltage gated Na+ channels in nociceptive fibres forcing a prolongation of the refractory period - hence preventing pain transmission via action potentials to the CNS. It is also a long acting local anaesthetic making it suitable for use in haemorrhoids.
OptionB: MU-Opiod receptor antagonists which works on the myenteric plexus and reduces electrical activity of the smooth muscle in the anal region, hence reducing pain.
OptionC: M5-Ach antagonist. Reduces calcium entry into muscle cells hence reducing contractility and therefore painful muscle spams
OptionD: Glucocorticoid analogue- complexes with steroid receptor to act as a gene transcriptional regulator which increases anti-inflammatory protein production and reduces inflammation.
OptionE: Blocks Ca2+ in the synapse of the afferent nociceptive fibre in the region of the haemorrhoids.
Explanation:
The Answer is A. 

This is the mechanism of action of cinchocaine. 

 

B: this is wrong. This is the mechanism of action of loperamide which is an antidiarrhoeal agent. It does not reduce pain but the MOA is to educes electrical activity of the smooth muscle and reduce peristalsis and hence diarrhoea. 

C: this is the MOA for mebeverine which is an anti-spasmodic agent. Nothing to to with haemorrhoids. 

D: prednisolone MOA which is used in the treatment of IBD. 

E: I made this up. 

 

 

All information is from Case 11 Lightbulb.

Question: What hormone help protects bones?
Explanation: Oestrogen helps to protect bones - therefore reduced oestrogen in women is a risk factor against osteoporosis

Question: A child presents to your clinic. On observation you see that he has a short stature and single palmar crease. What condition is he suffering from?
Tags: Foetal Anomalies, Foetal Development, embryology, Case 7

Question:
A 32 year old  otherwise healthy man comes to your local A+E where you are an F1. He is complaining of a 3 day history of diarrhoea and vomiting.  He has no recent travel history abroad. He tells you that 5 days ago, he ate a chicken burger from a street food stand after a night out. He thinks this is the source of his D+V. 

 

You suspect so too and think that it is highly likely that he has contracted campylobacter. 

 

What is the next course of treatment?
OptionA: Send the patient home with oral replacement therapy and a course of co-amoxiclav.
OptionB: Send the patient home with oral replacement therapy and a course of amoxicillin
OptionC: Send the patient home to drink lots of water and rest with a course of co-amoxiclav.
OptionD: Send the patient home with oral replacement therapy and a course of metronidazole.
OptionE: Send the patient home with oral replacement therapy with instructions to rest and stay hydrated but do not offer antibiotics as it does not require them.
Explanation:
Campylobacter IID is often self limiting. Patients do not require antibiotics to resolve the infection. 

The symptoms can last for 2-7 days so the patient may be ill for a while yet.

Question:
A 6 year old girl is on a paediatric ward following an operation after she broke her arm. 3 days after her surgery, she develops severe watery diarrhoea and vomiting. 

What virus do you suspect has caused this infection?
Explanation:
Rotavirus is the most common cause of IID in children who are hospitalised. (Source: Case 11 Microbiology lecture).

Whilst noroviris is additionally a very common cause, rotavirus is more prevalent in children.

Question: Vitamin D deficiency causes...
Explanation: Vitamin D deficiency causes osteomalacia/rickets

Question: A 60-year old patient attends an eye clinic, upon examination it is found that the patient's retina shows signs of venous beading, cotton wool spots and microaneurysms. What is the likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Background retinopathy: retina would shows signs of dot and blot haemorrhages and hard exudates

 

Pre-proliferative retinopathy: retina shows signs of venous beading, cotton wool spots, IRMA, microaneurysms

 

Proliferative retinopathy: new vessels form on the optic disc due to increased production of VEGF. These new blood vessels can bleed and cause blindness

 

Diabetic maculopathy: signs of oedema as well as exudates

 

Papillodema: swelling of the optic disc due to increased ICP

Question:
A 18-year old male returned from his gap year in Laos 10 days ago.  He presents to your GP clinic with a 1 week history of diarrhoea which he describes as 'pale' and 'bulky', nausea and he notices that he has lost some weight. You ask about his activities whilst in Loas.  He tells you that on his last day he was in a river with some elephants. You send his stool away for culture and microscopy on the basis of this history and do a full blood count too. 

5 days later, the results are back and he is diagnosed with having a Giardia infection. 

 

You suspected this, so you prescribe him with a course of what and advise him NOT to do what?
OptionA: Ciprofolxacin and advise him NOT to drink alcohol.
OptionB: Amoxicillin and advise him NOT to smoke whilst taking it.
OptionC: Metronidazole and advise him NOT to drink alcohol.
OptionD: Co-amoxiclav and advise him NOT to drink alcohol.
OptionE: Amoxicillin and advise him NOT to drink alcohol.
Explanation:
The answer is C. 

 

Treatment for a Giardia infection (which is a protozoa) is a course of metronidazole. 

 

A little addition to the question - consumption of alcohol is typically advised against by patients during  metronidazole therapy and for at least 48 hours after completion of treatment as the two drugs interact and can cause nausea, vomiting, tachycardia and SOB. 

This is the classic do-not-drink antibiotic. 

 

This information is from the case 11 microbiology lecture.

Question:
Mr Barry is a 72 year old man who lives in a residential home.

A carer has called for an ambulance as she is concerned. Mr Barry has been passing bloody diarrhoea for 2 days and is feeling very dizzy on standing.

He is diagnosed in hospital with Clostridium Difficile infection, following stool culture, blood tests and eventually a sigmoidoscopy because of his worsening symptoms. 

This is an image taken of his colon. What is this complication of C.diff known as?
Explanation:
Pseudomembranous colitis is inflammation of the colon associated with an overgrowth of Clostridium difficile. 

Presents with adherent, yellow white plaques on the intestinal mucosa.

Question: What primitive reflex appears between 6-9 months and is responsible for the preparation of crawling in an infant?
Explanation: The primitive reflex responsible for preparation of crawling is the symmetrical tonic neck reflex.

Question: At what level is a lumbar puncture carried out?
Explanation: Lumbar puncture, epidural and spinal anaesthetic are all given below the conus medullaris, which is at level L1-L2
Tags: Anaesthesia and Analgesia, Spinal cord, case 14

Question: In osteomalacia, levels of what would be found to have decreased in a blood test?
Explanation: Calcium and phosphate levels in the blood decrease in osteomalacia (vit D deficiency) and ALP and PTH levels are either normal or increased

Question: In Paget's disease of the bone, levels of what in the blood would increase?
Explanation: All the other's remain normal but levels of alkaline phosphatase increase

Question: Levels of what, in the blood, would increase in primary hyperparathyroidism?
Explanation:
Primary Hyperparathyroidism caused by enlargement of one or more of the parathyroid glands. Additionally a benign adenoma may also cause excess parathyroid - leading to too much calcium.

The levels of calcium will be either normal or increased; levels of phosphate either normal or decreased and levels of ALP either normal or increased

Question: A patient who has been diagnosed with bone metastases has a blood test. Levels of what in the blood may have decreased?
Explanation: The levels of the other 3 increase and PTH levels decrease

Question: What nerve innervates the trapezius muscle?
What nerve innervates Latissimus dorsi?
Explanation: Lat dorsi is innervated by thoracodorsal - from case 14 anatomy of the superficial muscles of the back

Question: What nerve innervates, Levator scapulae, rhomboid major and minor?
Which of these muscles one of the intermediate muscles of the back?

You are a medical student on a psychiatric ward round. While reading one of the in-patient's notes, you notice that they have been diagnosed with schizophrenia and have been prescribed a drug that targets both serotonin and dopamine receptors, what is the name of this drug?
Explanation:
Clozapine is the correct answer.

It is an atypical antipsychotic that targets and blocks both serotonin receptors (5HT2A) and is a dopamine receptors (D2).

 

Citalopram is a benzodiazepine used for treating depression and anxiety disorders. It's greatest effects are on serotonin receptors.

 

Cetirizine is an anti-histamine (H1 receptor antagonist) - it is a treatment for hay fever and suppresses the hyper-sensitized immune responses to allergens.

 

Chloropromazine is a typical antipsychotic that bocks D1 and D2 receptors.

 

Carbimazole is a treatment for hyperthyroidism in Grave’s Disease (it is a pro-drug that in the body, is converted to methimazole which inhibits thyroid peroxidase, preventing this enzyme iodinating the tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin, reducing production T3 and T4).

Question: Which vaccination is NOT administered at 8 weeks of age?
OptionA: 5-in-1 vaccine: Diptheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis, polio and His
Explanation:
MenB is administered at 8 weeks of age and Men C is given at 12 weeks.

 

See immunisation lecture from case 9

Question: Mrs Jones, an 81-year-old lady, has fractured her ulna after a fall at home. The doctor suspects that she may have an underlying condition affecting her bones which has allowed them to fracture so easily, because Mrs Jones displays risk factors for the suspected condition - she is both female and post-menopausal. What condition does the doctor suspect Mrs Jones has?
Explanation:
The correct answer should be E) Osteoporosis

 

Osteoporosis affects trabecular and cortical bone equally. It is characterised by decreased bone mass and structural deterioration of bone tissue, leading to enhanced bone fragility and a consequent increase in fracture risk. People at increased risk of developing osteoporosis include:

  • Women
  • Post-menopausal women - due to their decreased levels of oestrogen
  • Genetically predisposed
  • People who use glucocorticoids long-term
  • Physically inactive

Treatment for osteoporosis includes:

  • Bisphosphonates (e.g. alendronate, ibandronate) - decrease bone breakdown by inhibiting osteoclast function and induce apoptosis of osteoclasts
  • PTH analogues (anabolic bone therapy e.g. teriparatide) - increase formation of new bone by increasing osteoblast activity

Osteomalacia is a vitamin D deficiency characterised by insufficient calcium and phosphate ions, so new osteoids cannot be mineralised, causing bones to be softer and more pliable. The amount of bone is normal, but the ratio of matrix to bone mineral is decreased. Rickets is the form of osteomalacia that occurs in children (before the closure of the epiphyseal plates) and can lead to bone deformities.

Treatment is vitamin D supplementation. Oral D2/D3 (oral 1-alphacalcidol, oral calcitrol) is given to patients with good renal function.

 

Paget's disease is disordered bone metabolism, caused by osteoclast overactivity and followed by compensatory osteoblast activity. It leads to the formation of disordered woven (weak) bone. Most patients are asymptomatic but symptoms can include:

  • Deep, constant, boring bone pain that is worse on weight-bearing
  • Pathological fracture
  • Sarcomatous changes (rare)
  • Increased cardiac output
  • Compression effects

Investigations show increased ALP and urinary hydroxyproline, and normal calcium ion, vitamin D, PTH and phosphate ion levels. There is also increased uptake on isotope bone scans. Treatment is with bisphosphonates, but this is only given to patients who are symptomatic, in danger of nerve compression, or is affected around a weight-bearing joint.

 

Bone metastases present with pain, pathological fractures and spinal cord compression. Investigations show increased ALP, calcium and phosphate ions, and decreased PTH levels. Treatment is with bisphosphonates, radiotherapy, surgery or chemo/hormone therapy.

 

I got all this information from the Normal Bone Health and Bone Disease lecture we had in Case 14.

Question:
Linda, a 34 year old molecular biologist, was recently reunited with her estranged father. He informed her that he has been diagnosed with a condition that increases his risk of colorectal cancer. Linda visits her GP to ask what her next steps should be. She does some research on the internet before her appointment and asks the GP how her father's condition differs to some of the more common causes of colorectal cancer.

 

The GP informs her that her father's condition is due to a mutation that leads to impaired DNA mismatch repair which causes microsatellite instability whereas the more common conditions that lead of colorectal cancer are most likely due to mutations in tumor suppressor genes. 

 

Given the above information, which of the following conditions is Linda's father most likely to have been diagnosed with?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C. Lynch Syndrome 

 

Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that occurs due to mutations in MMR genes that lead to defective DNA mismatch repair leading to microsatellite instablity in tumors. 

 

Microsatellite instability refers to the fact that microsatellites, which are naturally occurring highly repeated short DNA sequences, become shorter or longer than normal. It is thought that microsatellite instability occurs due to a defect in the ability of a cell to repair mistakes when DNA is replicated (Source: Kumar and Clark's Clinical Medicine, 9E. : Elsevier Health Sciences UK, 2016. PDF. https://elsevierelibrary.co.uk/product/kumar-clarks-clinical-medicine80515/422 ) 

 

Lynch syndrome leads to an increased risk of developing colorectal cancer. The average age at onset of colorectal cancer in individuals with Lynch syndrome is 42 years of age. The condition has a prevalence of 1/250. 

 

A,B, D and E are conditions that most commonly occur due to mutations in the APC gene which is a tumor suppressor gene. 

 

Lynch syndrome is different to the conditions in A,B,D and E because it does not tend to be associated with adenomas.

 

 The main line of treatment is surgery- colectomy. Aspirin has been shown to be effective in reducing risk of colorectal cancer. Other potential treatment options include vaccination with Frame shift peptides (FSP)

 

You might be wondering why the GP is giving Linda such a detailed answer- she is a molecular biologist so she probably understands what the GP is talking about 

 

Hope this helps :)
Tags: Lower GI, case 11, Genetics and the GI

Question:
Abby is a 7-year-old girl who comes in to see you with her parents, who are worried about Abby's legs. They visibly appear deformed and you request an X-ray:

 

 

Abby has good renal function. What treatment is Abby prescribed?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C) Oral 1-alphacalcidol

 

Abby has rickets - a vitamin D deficiency which causes insufficient levels of calcium and phosphate ions, so new osteoids cannot be mineralised which causes bones to be softer and more pliable. Abby has deformities because she is a child so the condition is affecting her epiphyseal plates, causing immature mineralisation and subsequent closure of the plates. Because rickets (and osteomalacia in adults) results from vitamin D deficiency, the treatment is vitamin D. This can be given to patients (with good renal function) in the forms of oral 1-alphacalcidol and oral calcitriol.

 

A) Alendronate is a bisphosphonate, indicated for use in osteoporosis, Paget's disease and treatment of bone metastases. The MOA of bisphosphonates is that it reduces bone breakdown by inhibiting osteoclast function and inducing apoptosis of osteoclasts

B) Teriparatide is a PTH analogue, indicated for use in osteoporosis. The MOA of teriparatide is that it increases the formation of new bone by increasing osteoblast activity.

C) The correct answer

D) Calcitriol is correct but it is given orally

E) Ibandronate is also a bisphosphonate

 

Osteoporosis affects trabecular and cortical bone equally. It is characterised by decreased bone mass and structural deterioration of bone tissue, leading to enhanced bone fragility and a consequent increase in fracture risk. People at increased risk of developing osteoporosis include:

  • Women
  • Post-menopausal women - due to their decreased levels of oestrogen
  • Genetically predisposed
  • People who use glucocorticoids long-term
  • Physically inactive

Treatment for osteoporosis includes:

 

Paget's disease is disordered bone metabolism, caused by osteoclast overactivity and followed by compensatory osteoblast activity. It leads to the formation of disordered woven (weak) bone. Most patients are asymptomatic but symptoms can include:

  • Deep, constant, boring bone pain that is worse on weight-bearing
  • Pathological fracture
  • Sarcomatous changes (rare)
  • Increased cardiac output
  • Compression effects

Investigations show increased ALP and urinary hydroxyproline, and normal calcium ion, vitamin D, PTH and phosphate ion levels. There is also increased uptake on isotope bone scans. Treatment is with bisphosphonates, but this is only given to patients who are symptomatic, in danger of nerve compression, or is affected around a weight-bearing joint.

 

Bone metastases present with pain, pathological fractures and spinal cord compression. Investigations show increased ALP, calcium and phosphate ions, and decreased PTH levels. Treatment is with bisphosphonates, radiotherapy, surgery or chemo/hormone therapy.

 

I got all this information from the Normal Bone Health and Bone Disease lecture we had in Case 14.
Tags: Child Development, Pharmacology, Bones, drugs, case 14

Question:
A 78-year old man is admitted to your hospital ward where you are an F1, following an acute decompensated episode of congestive heart failure. 

On arrival  you note that he has an irregularly irregular pulse and is tachycardic. 

On making a recovery back to stable and compensated cognitive heart failure, you discuss changing his mediation to alter his changing needs. 

 

You suspect that he had an episode of atrial fibrillation which precipitated his decompensation. You would like to place him on an oral anti-coagulant due to this. 

First you must CHADS2VASC/ HASBLED score him to see if this is appropriate. 

What is his CHADS2VASC score? 

 

NB this patient has a long history of hypertension, no previous episodes of stroke/TIA, or DM or vascular disease.
Explanation:
CHADS2VASC is outlined below. 

 

The patient has scored 4. He is over 75 years old, has hypertension, and has CHF. He has no other factors. 

 

A score of over 2 on AF indicates use for an oral anticoagulant. 

 

However you would also have to consider his HASSLED score. 

 

This takes into account - Hypertension (1); Liver renal failure (1/2); Stroke (1); Bleeding (1); Labile INR (high or unstable - 1); Over 65 (1) and drugs/ alcohol (1/2).

He would score 2 on the HASSLED score. 

 

A score of over 3 would make you reconsider oral anti-coagulant use as the risk of a bleed whilst taking the drug may outweigh the risks of stroke/ TIA/ thrombi-embolic event due to AF. 

 

Hope this helps :)

Question: Which of the following is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) which acts as a factor Xa inhibitor?
Explanation:
Apaxiban - this is a Xa direct inhibitor. 

 

Warfarin - indirect anti- coagulant because it is a vitamin K reductase inhibitor. Indirectly inhibits the production of factor X by reducing the recycling of vitamin K in the liver is reduced. This reduces the availability of vitamin KH2 therefore limiting the γ- carboxylation of clotting factors in the liver. 

 

Dabigatran - also a DOAC but is a direct thrombin inhibitor. 

 

The other two are made up drug names.

Question: Lou is a 56-year-old patient of yours that continuously comes to you regarding his low back pain. From his history you note that he has several yellow flag symptoms. Which of the following are red flag symptoms for low back pain?
OptionA: Patient is over 40 years of age with new pain
Explanation:
The correct answer should be D) Patient doesn't improve with treatment

 

A) Patient is over 40 with new pain - this would be a red flag symptom if the patient was either over 50 or under 16

B) Patient is under-supported by their family - this is a yellow flag symptom

C) Patient drinks 2 pints a week - this amount of alcohol is unlikely to be an abusive/addictive amount so this is not a red flag symptom. It would be a red flag symptom if the patient had a social history of alcohol or drug abuse

D) The correct answer

E) Patient has cervical spine pain - this is not a red flag symptom, the pain would have to be in the thoracic spine to be a red flag symptom

 

Red flag symptoms

  • < 16yrs with new onset pain
  • > 50yrs with new onset pain
  • Unwell/unexplained weight loss or pyrexia
  • History of cancer, AIDS or serious infection
  • History of Paget's or osteoporosis
  • Long-term use of steroids
  • End-stage renal disease
  • Social history of alcohol or drug abuse
  • Widespread neurological defects
  • Non-mechanical pain
  • Thoracic pain or spinal deformity that is rapidly progressive
  • History of significant injury or trauma
  • No improvement with treatment

Yellow flag symptoms - can help to explain the presence of chronic low back pain

  • Attitudes - towards the current problem
  • Beliefs - faulty beliefs e.g. patient incorrectly believes symptoms are due to cancer
  • Compensation - patient may be taken care of at home with financial compensation (think about sick roles)
  • Diagnosis - or iatrogenesis, inappropriate communication
  • Emotions - patients with other emotional difficulties (e.g. depression, anxiety) are at higher risk of developing chronic pain
  • Family - either overbearing or under-supportive
  • Work - the worse the relationship, the more likely the patient is to develop chronic low back pain

I got this information from Mr McCarthy's lecture on Metastatic Spinal Cord Compression and Spinal Infections and his case wrap up.

Question: Which of the following correctly describes Scheurmann's disease?
OptionA: Kyphosis causing a painless hunchback caused by the uneven growth of vertebrae
OptionB: Forward displacement of a vertebra commonly after a break or fracture
OptionC: Defect in the pars interarticularis of the vertebral arch (where the facet joints join)
OptionE: Radiation of pain down the leg from the lower back
Explanation:
The correct answer is A) Kyphosis causing a painless hunchback caused by the uneven growth of vertebrae - Scheurmann's disease is worse than postural kyphosis and requires surgical correction.

 

B) Forward displacement of a vertebra (especially L5) commonly after a break or fracture - this is spondylolisthesis. Hangman's fracture (C2) is a specific type of spondylolisthesis - symptoms include: kyphosis (compensatory), stiff back, waddle to decrease lumbar rotation, low back pain and sciatic nerve pain. Treatment of Hangman's fracture tends to be conservative with NSAIDs and physiotherapy. The X-ray and diagram below show Hangman's fracture.

 

C) Defect in the pars interarticularis of the vertebral arch (where the facet joints join), most common in L5. The pars interarticularis detach and there is also separation of the joint - this is spondylolysis. It can be a precursor to spondylolisthesis. It can lead to spinal stenosis, cauda equina syndrome and radiculopathy. It is a stress fracture so is more common in hyperextensible people e.g. gymnasts.

 

D) Joint disease of the vertebral column - this is spondyloarthropathy. An example would be ankylosing spondylitis, which is chronic inflammation that leads to the fusion of joints, particularly axial joints. As the inflammation settles, calcium ions are laid down.

 

E) Radiation of pain down the leg from the lower back caused by spinal disc herniation or spinal stenosis - this is sciatica. Symptoms include: pain that is made worse by sneezing, coughing or sitting down for long periods of time, numbness, tingling from the back to the foot or toes, weakness in the calf muscles. Treatment in the first 6-8 weeks should be conservative because if it is caused by herniation, most cases will resolve spontaneously over a period of weeks to months.

Question: Which of the following is the most common extra-intestinal manifestation of IBD?
Explanation: Refer to IBD lecture.

Question: Between which subunits of the GABA A receptor do benzodiazepines bind to have a positive allosteric modulating effect?
Explanation:
GABA binding sites are between Alpha and Beta

Benzodiazepine binding site is between Alpha and Gamma

Question: Which of the following describes the function of Wnt proteins in neurulation?
OptionA: Causes neural patterning and formation of somites
OptionC: Induction of the mesoderm and ectoderm to differentiate
OptionD: Formation of dorsal root and sympathetic nervous system ganglia
Explanation:
The correct answer should be C) Induction of the mesoderm and ectoderm to differentiate

 

A) Sonic hedgehog (Shh) proteins cause neural patterning and the formation of somites, and are expressed by the notochord

B) TGF-b proteins (including bone morphogenic proteins) regulate cell differentiation

C) Wnt proteins - the correct answer

D and E) These are actions of different domains of neural crest cells

 

Domains of neural crest:

The neural crest refers to cells arising from the ectoderm.

  • Cranial - forms cranial neurones, cartilage, bone, glia and connective tissues of the face, bones of the middle ear, tooth primordia
  • Trunk - forms dorsal root ganglia, sympathetic nervous system ganglia, sensory neurones, melanocytes (all pigment cells of the body)
  • Vagal/sacral - forms parasympathetic nerves of the gut
  • Cardiac - forms melanocytes, neurones, and the division between the aorta and pulmonary artery

I got this information from Prof Wilson's lecture on Early Human Development in Case 7.
Tags: Pregnancy, Foetal Development, embryology, Case 7, somitogenesis

Question: Which of the following drugs is used for the maintenance of remission in Crohn's?
Explanation:
CORRECT = E

 

Azathioprine: is a pro-drug that is quickly converted to 6-mercaptopurine via a non -enzymatic nucleophilic attack by glutathione (an anti-oxidant) present in RBC's. These purine antagonists interfere with nucleic acid synthesis in WBC, especially in T-lymphocytes, which are important in the production of mediators of inflammation. 

 

Mesalazine, contains 5-aminosailicylic acid, which is the pharmacological active component of the drug. Due to its low bioavailability, 5-ASA remains in the gut lumen, exerting a local anti-inflammatory effect (decreased synthesis of eicosanoids and cytokines), prior to elimination by the feces.

 

Budesonide: Locally active corticosteroid which is used to treat mild to moderate Crohn's disease.

 

Metronidazole: An antibiotic used in the treatment of Crohn's (NB. antibiotics are only used in the treatment of Crohn's!)

 

Methotrexate: An immuno-suppressive drug used to treat Crohn's

Question: Sympathetic nervous system stimulation of the SAN results in an increase in level of cAMP within myocytes. Raising the levels of cAMP results in the increased activation of which ion channel associated with If (funny current) which increases the entry of Na+ into cells, hence meaning the myocyte reaches threshold potential quicker?
Explanation:
The answer is HCN4.

 

HCN4 channels are Na+ channels associated with the funny current.

Question: What is the mechanism of action  of Aciclovir?
OptionA: Acts as a guanosine analogue blocking viral DNA polymerase
OptionB: Acts as a competitive inhibitor of viral neuraminidase
OptionC: Viral RNA nucleoside mimetic with base-pairing promiscuity, causing viral hypermutation
OptionD: Thymidine analogue that inhibits viral Reverse Transcriptase (RT)
OptionE: Reversible competitive inhibitor of the Cox domain of PSHS 1 and PGHS 2
Explanation:
Aciclovir: converted to acyclovir triphosphate inside the infected cells. Acts as a guanosine analogue blocking viral DNApolymerase (thereby limiting viral DNA replication and new virus manufacture)

 

B= Oseltamivir (hepatically converted into Oseltamivir carboxylate)

C= Ribavirin

D= Zidovudine (Limits the retroviral gene incorporation into host cell's nucleic genome)

E= Ibuprofin

Question: Betty is a 19-year-old student who had a TBI after she fell backwards off a trampoline and landed on her head. After Betty wakes up from surgery, she notices strange symptoms in her arms and legs and asks her surgeon what is causing them. The surgeon tells her she has an upper motor neurone lesion. Which of the following signs/symptoms are indicative of upper motor neurone lesion as opposed to lower motor neurone lesion?
Explanation:
The correct answer should be A) Plantar response present

 

The other options are all signs/symptoms of a lower motor neurone lesion.

 

Upper motor neuron lesion

  • More diffuse, severe weakness
  • Mild general atrophy
  • No fasciculations seen
  • Increased muscle tone
  • Increased muscle stretch reflexes
  • Clonus can be present
  • Plantar response can be present
  • Babinski sign is present - big toe extends rather than flexes upon stimulation of the sole of the foot
  • Pronator drift

 

Lower motor neurone lesion

  • More focal weakness
  • Severe focal atrophy
  • Fasciculations can be present
  • Decreased muscle tone
  • Decreased muscle stretch reflexes
  • Clonus is not seen
  • Plantar response is absent

I got this information from Mr McCarthy's tutorial on Cord Syndromes in Case 14.

Question: When a Dendritic cell gets activated which of the following causes their movement to secondary lymphoid organs.
Explanation:
MHCI - presented by cells and stimulates T cells CD8 

 

MHC II - presented by cells and stimulates T cells CD4

 

CD40-CD40L - connection between T and B cells leading to B-cells somatic hypermutation and isotope switching

 

CCR7 - expressed in various lymphoid tissues and activates B and T lymphocytes. CCR7 has been shown to stimulate dendritic cell maturation and cause them to move towards their secondary lymphoid tissue

 

CDRs - simply complementarity- determining regions - expressed by immunoglobulins ( B cells ) and receptors ( T cells ) which binds to antigens

Question: A patient enters your clinic with obvious valgus deformity of the knees and legs. After taking their history you diagnose poliomyelitis. When the patient asks about the condition, what do you tell them is affected?
Explanation:
B-cells are affected by EBV 

T-cells by HIV 

Plasma by polio 

myeloid by HCMV 

 

refer to case 9 lecture 'intro to virology'

Question: Which of the following is not a autosomal dominant disease?
Explanation:
D is an X linked recessive disorder.

 

Other autosomal dominant conditions include:

  • Hereditary breast and ovarian cancer
  • Marfans syndrome (a connective tissue disorder)
  • LQTS

Question: Which of the following is not a autosomal recessive condition?
Explanation:
C - This is an autosomal dominant disorder.

 

Another autosomal recessive disorder is spinal muscular dystrophy.

Question:
You are in a cardiology clinic shadowing a consultant. He asks you to interpret an ECG of a patient he has just seen. You notice the abnormalities below:

 

 

What is your interpretation?
Explanation:
Answer B.

 

Think LEGS TOGETHER LEGS APART. 

 

If QRS complex is positive in lead II and negative in lead I i.e. legs together = right axis deviation.

 

If QRS complex is negative in lead II and positive in lead I i.e. legs apart = left axis deviation. 

 

Normally would be positive in lead II and positive in lead I.

Question:
A patient presents to A+E with crushing central chest pain, SOB and is pale and clammy. 

You perform an ECG and he is showing ST elevation in chest leads in I,all, V5 + V6. 

 

What kind of MI is this and which artery is most likely being occluded?
Explanation:
RCA artery occlusion = II,III, avF and inferior MI. 

LAD occlusion = V1-V6 Anterior MI 

Cx = I, avL, V5 + V6 = lateral MI. 

 

Left circumflex/ RCA  = posterior = dominant R wave V1-2, ST depression.

Question: Which of the following best describes clostridium difficile?
Explanation:
A= Helicobacter Pylori

B= Chlamydia Trachomatis

D= Listeria

E= E.coli

Question: A 43 year old man presents to his GP with generalized weakness in his lower extremities, accompanied by occasional numbness and tingling in his feet. The GP suspects Gullain-Barre syndrome secondary to an infection his patient acquired 2 weeks ago. Which infection is the GP most likely suspecting?
Explanation:
Campylobacter Jejuni is associated with post-infection sequelae (approximately 1-2 weeks post infection); most commonly: Reactive arthritis and Gullain-Barre syndrome. (C.jejuni is also a RARE cause of outbreaks of meningitis and septicaemia on neonatal ICU)

 

NB. Campylobacter is a gram negative, flagellete (mobile), anaerobic curved rod. It is the MOST common bacterial cause of IID/gastroenteritis in the UK. (The most common VIRAL cause of gastroenteritis in the UK is Norovirus!)

 

Classic zoonosis, C.jejuni (poultry/birds) and C.coli (pigs). It is RARELY transmitted person to person. C.jejuni can also spread to the blood (bacteraemia) in individuals with AIDS (immunocompromsied) and C.lari is a known cause of recurrent diarrhea in children.

Question: What is the infective dose for Giardia?
Explanation:
Intestinal protozoa: Giardia lamblia. Has a 2 stage life cycle. Infective dose is 10-25 cyts. Has a worldwide distribution, common protozoal cause of diarrhea in returning travelers. It is the most COMMONLY identified GI parasite worldwide. Usually acquired via contaminated water. 

 

Clinical features:

Often asx, diarrhoea is the primary symptom: bulky, pale and offensive smelling. Abdominal bloating is common, as well as anorexia and nausea.

30-50% of patients progress to chronic diarrhoea. Half of these develop a malabsorption syndrome. 

 

Microbiology lecture, case 11

Question: Which of the following anitbiotics is used as a treatment for severe Clostridium difficile infection?
Explanation:
The first 4 options are all potential causative agents of C.diff. Quinolones (mainly ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin) and most penicillin based antibiotics such as ampicillin, cephalosporins and clindamycin are all common causes of C.dif. This is because these antibiotics cause the normal bacterial flora of the bowel to be altered. In particular, when the antibiotic kills off the other competing bacteria on the intestine, any bacteria remaining will have less competition for space and nutrients. The net effect is to permit more extensive growth than normal of certain bacteria (Clostridium difficile is one such type of bacterium).

 

In terms of the managmeent and treatment of C.diff infection; the initial step is to discontinue to offending agent (note: a risk-benefit assessment is often implicated at this point). 'Anti - C.dif' antibiotics, mainly vancomycin and metronidazole (vancomycin is better in SEVERE disease) are the most often used antibiotics, but other medications may also be used. 

Nutrition/fluid balance need to be adequately controlled and maintained. Surgery is (rarely) indicated if the infection is unresponsive to antibiotics.

Question: Which of these vaccines are not indicated for pregnant women?
Explanation:
No Live attenuated vaccines!

 

List of live attenuated

MMR
BCG for TB
Influenza (nasal)
Rotavirus (oral)
Typhoid (oral)
Varicella zoster (VZV)
Yellow fever

 

 

List of dead vaccines

DaPT
Hib, Men B, Men C
Influenza (injected)
Pneumococcal
Typhoid (injected)
Hepatitis A
Hepatitis B
HPV (human papilloma virus)

 

The more similar a vaccine is to the natural disease, the better the immune response

 

AW

Question:
You are a CT3 doctor (SHO) on call in a general medicine ward the middle of a rural hospital in Wales where you have to sort out influenza vaccines for new patients. You asked the head nurse to check for the influenza vaccine stock, remembering that you had given some to medical students on placement. Unfortunately, there are only 3 doses left, whereas there are 4 patients on the ward who have not yet been vaccinated. Patient 1 is an 11-year-old boy suffering from sickle cell anaemia, patient 2 is a 32 weeks pregnant woman with gestational diabetes, patient 3 is a 44-year-old diabetic male, patient 4 is a 55-year-old lady who stayed for recovery following ablation surgery for AF.

 

Which patient will you not give the vaccine to?
OptionE: This is a trick question.. All of them needs the vaccine?
Explanation:
You give influenza vaccine to:

all children aged 2-7 years
all people aged > 65 years
people in clinical risk groups (aged 6 m and over)
pregnant women
people in long-stay care
carers of elderly or disabled people
frontline health and social care staff (direct patient care)
community first responders

 

and the clinical risk groups consist of

chronic respiratory disease (inc. asthma)
chronic heart disease
diabetes (type 1 and type 2)
chronic renal disease
chronic liver disease
chronic neurological disease (stroke, MS)
weakened immunity (chemoRx, asplenia ++ splenic dysfunction; i.e. sickle cell and severe coeliacs, HIV)

 

Patient 4 just had surgery for AF > so she has not got any chronic heart disease anymore. Patient 1 has sickle cell (+ he is young) so has some form of splenic dysfunction, so it is safe to give him the vaccine.

 

AW

Question: Where in the GI tract is Vitamin C absorbed?
Explanation:
Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is absorbed in the proximal ileum.

Toxic megacolon can occur in patients with Crohn's disease, however it is less likely than the other options e.g. see NICE guidelines for comparison of complications of UC and CD

 

https://cks.nice.org.uk/ulcerative-colitis#!backgroundsub:4

https://cks.nice.org.uk/crohns-disease#!backgroundsub:4
