Question: Why one of the following cardiomyopathies is uncommon in children?
Explanation: A - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy - because children are going through a growth process

Question:
A 62 year old man presents to A&E with severe chest pain and shortness of breath.

An ECG is performed:

 

 

Which coronary artery is most likely occluded?
OptionE: Diagonal brach of left anterior descending artery
Explanation:
The ECG shows ST elevation in the inferior leads- II, III, avF

An inferior MI is most likely due to occlusion of the right coronary artery.  

Less commonly, this can be due to circumflex occlusion.

 

Anterior/ Anterolateral STEMI results from occlusion of the Left anterior descending artery.

Inferior-posterior-lateral: Left Circumflex occlusion

Isolated lateral: smaller branch arteries

Question:
An 62 year old man complains to his GP of chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion and sometimes feels a fluttery sensation of his heartbeat. 

 

On examination, a mid systolic murmur is heard. 

What is the most likely cause of the murmur?
Explanation:
Aortic stenosis would cause a mid systolic murmurs that would radiate to the carotids. 

All the other options would cause a mid diastolic murmur.

 

Systolic murmus: between S1 and S2--> Stenosis of semilunar valves or regurgitation of atrioventricular valves. 

Diastolic mumurs: after S2, Stenosis of AV valves, or regurgitation of semilunar valves.

Question: A man with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is expecting a child with his wife. They've just found out that they will be having a baby boy and want to know the risk of their son being affected? (assuming the mother is not a carrier)
Explanation:
Answer is 0

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is x-linked recessive 

The father is XY so only his X chromosome is affected which he inherited from his mother. Since they';re having a son, the son will have his Y chromosome not the affected X chromosome 

 

You could argue that the risk is never 0 as condition can arise spontaneously but in this case 0 is the SBA

Question:
A 21 year old male was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia and auditory hallucinations six months ago. His initial prescription of Haloperidol (conventional antipsychotic) didn't stop the auditory hallucinations so he is now taking an atypical antipsychotic.  However the patient now complains of:

 

Weight gain

lethargy

seizures

 

A full blood count reveals:

 

Agranulocytosis (Very low WBC count)

cholesterol 10mMol/L normal range (<5mMol/L)

glucose  6.5mMol/L normal range (3.9-5.5mMol/L)

 

What atypical antipsychotic was most likely prescribed?
Explanation:
A lot of the time an antidepressant or antipsychotic will not have a therapeutic effect. Psychiatrists may have to go through many different drugs before the 'right' one for the patient is found. All the drugs A-E are atypical antipychotics taken from the table in Neuropharmacology lecture 2. 

Haloperidol the conventional antipsychotic is a dopamine receptor antagonist.  It's therapeutic effect (D2 receptor antagonism) treats positive symptoms of schizophrenia.  However the antagonism of the D1 receptor inhibits executive function (often movement disorder). 

 

Most atypical antipsychotics work by blocking the D2 receptor and serotonin (5HT2) receptor among others. These often take weeks to work suggesting that there are changes in the neural network. These drugs rarely cause movement disorders but can still have substantial side effects.

 

A: Olanzapine this has very similar adverse effects to Clozapine. It  has a high frequency incidence of weight gain and sedation.  Plus it is known to cause high lipid and glucose levels in the blood.  However the agranulocytosis and seizures are only seen in Cloazapine.

 

B: Clozapine CORRECT:In the Neuropharmacology lecture 2 there is a table of atypical antipsychotic ADRs Clozapine is the only one with  Agranulocytosis or seizures. The agranulocytosis is usually reversible so this side effect is not life threatening. Patients with agranulocytosius will also suffer more from infections due to the impaired immune system so sore throat or 'very bad cough/cold' would be a telling sign that perhaps agranulocytosis is occuring.

 

C: Risperidone Will often cause Hyperprolactinaemia which can cause sexual dysfunction in men. But doesn't usually cause weight gain or sedation.     

 


D: Quetiapine doesn't usually cause weight gain or any other symptoms that clozapine does but frequently causes lethargy.

 

E: Ziprasidone: has a very low frequency of all the side effects of Clozapine however it elongates the QT interval of the heart which isn't fantastic. 

 

Keep up the good work. DB

Question: A baby is born with arthrogryposis, clenched hands with his index and fifth finger overriding his second and third finger. The sole of his foot is curved like a rocker and he has a prominent calcaneus. You suspect a chromosomal abnormality. Which of the following abnormalities is the baby most likely to have?
Explanation:
Chromosomal abnormalities lecture.

 

Edwards syndrome is the second most common autosomal trisomy abnormality. Only 5 - 10% of infants born with trisomy 18 will reach their first birthday.

Question: What is the function of the antidepressant Buproprion?
Explanation: Bupoprion  an atypical antidepressant that inhibits dopamine reuptake. It is also a weak noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor.

Question: Mr Pringles is a known asthmatic that presents to A and E with breathlessness which is not responding to salbutamol or nebuliser. You are an F1 doctor put in charge of him and are not sure whether he's having type 1 or type 2 respiratory failure. You decide to do a procedure on him to aid diagnosis. Which of these would you do?
OptionA: Pierce brachial artery to obtain arterial blood gas
OptionC: Take venous sample from brachial vein for blood gas analysis
OptionD: Pierce ulnar artery to obtain arterial blood gas
Explanation:
Acid-base metabolism lecture

You can do ABG by taking ARTERIAL sample from brachial or radial artery. This will tell you pH of the arterial blood, pCO2 and pO2 by direct analysis and will then estimate bicarbonate levels using this data. 

Type 1 respiratory failure is due to hypoxia so pCO2 is normal but oxygen levels is low.

Type 2 respiratory failure (aka ventilatory failure) is due to hypoxia AND hypercapnia.

Question: Which of the following describes Silver-Russell syndrome?
OptionC: Lack of expression of the paternal allele for the UBE3A gene due to deletion/mutation of chromosome 15 (maternal uniparental disomy)
OptionD: Growth disorder caused by a mutation at 11p15
Explanation:
The correct answer should be D) Growth disorder caused by a mutation at 11p15

 

Silver-Russell syndrome can also be caused when people inherit both copies of chromosome 7 from their mother (maternal uniparental disomy). Symptoms include:

  • Disproportionate head size compared to a small body
  • Recurrent hyperglycaemic episodes
  • GI system abnormalities
  • Low birth weight
  • Increased risk of delayed development, speech and language problems, and learning difficulties
  • Unusual curving of the 5th finger
  • Small, triangular face with a prominent forehead, narrow chin, small jaw, downturned corners of the mouth

A) Terminal deletion on 5p chromosome - Cri du Chat syndrome

Symptoms include:

  • Microcephaly
  • High-pitched, cat-like cry
  • Low birth weight
  • Delayed development and intellectual disability later in life
  • Hypotonia

B) Trisomy 13 - Patau syndrome

Symptoms include:

  • Microcephaly
  • Structural defects
  • Seizures
  • Severe developmental delay
  • Neural tube defects
  • Holoprosencephaly

C) Lack of expression of the paternal allele for the UBE3A gene due to deletion/mutation of chromosome 15 (maternal uniparental disomy) - Prader-Willi syndrome

Symptoms include:

  • Short stature
  • Neonatal hypotonia
  • Early poor feeding
  • Hyperphagia and obesity
  • Mild/moderate intellectual disability
  • Hypogonadism
  • Behaviour problems

Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome are examples of genomic imprinting - where certain genes are expressed in a parent-of-origin specific manner.

Angelman syndrome results from the lack of expression of the maternal allele for the UBE3A gene due to deletion/mutation of chromosome 15 (paternal uniparental disomy). Symptoms include:

  • Absent speech
  • Gait ataxia
  • Happy demeanour
  • Microcephaly
  • Severe intellectual disability
  • Seizures

D) The correct answer

 

E) Sex chromosome aneuploidy (47, XXY) - Klinefelter syndrome

Symptoms include:

  • Infertility
  • Pubertal gynaecomastia
  • Small testes
  • Delayed/incomplete development of secondary sexual characteristics
  • Primary hypogonadism
  • Relatively tall stature

I got this information from Dr Fry's lecture on Chromosome Abnormalities in Case 7
Tags: chromosomal abnormalities, chromosome abnormalities, Foetal Anomalies, embryology, Case 7

Question: Mrs Spoon is  excreting large amounts of bicarbonate leading to her becoming acidotic. This is down to a portion of her kidney not reabsorbing the bicarbonate as it should be doing. Where is the problem most likely to be?
Explanation:
85% of bicarbonate is reabsorbed in the PCT. Excretion of bicarbonate is essentially zero under normal conditions because of extensive reabsorption in the PCT. 

Refere to acid-base balance lecture in case 10

Question:
You are in a GP surgery. A 78-year old patient comes into your GP surgery complaining of breathlessness and has felt very faint at home. GP performs an ECG.

This is the rhythm strip:

 

 

 

 

What is your diagnosis?
OptionB: 2nd Degree Heart Block: Mobitz Type I
OptionC: 2nd Degree Heart Block: Mobitz Type II - Fixed Ratio 2:1
OptionD: 2nd Degree Heart Block: Mobitz Type II - Fixed Ratio 3:1
Explanation:
Answer is Mobitz II. 

 

Mobitz Type II = a constant normal PR with the occasional dropped beats. The dropped beat is random. 

 

Mobitz I = a progressively elongating PR interval until there is a dropped beat, then cycle is repeated. The dropped beat is predictable.

 

2:1 is when constant PR interval with predictability probability of P:QRS. 

 

3rd degree = no association between P waves and QRS.

Question: Where in the GI tract are fat-soluble vitamins absorbed?
Explanation:
Fat soluble vitamins (A,K,E,D) are almost entirely absorbed in the jejenum. A small proportion is absorbed in the duodenum/ileum. 

Ethanol is absorbed in the stomach.

Vitamin C is absorbed in the proximal ileum

Bile salts are absorbed in the distal ileum

B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum 

Monovalent ions, water are absorbed in the SI and colon (mainly colon)

Question: Jenny is 12 weeks' pregnant and has just had her early pregnancy scan. She gets blood taken and asks to book an appointment for next week to have other tests to assess if her baby has any abnormalities. Which of the following tests can Jenny have?
Explanation:
The correct answer should be B) Combined test

 

A) Amniocentesis - this can be performed from 15 weeks' gestation. Indications for amniocentesis include:

  • Increased risk screening result
  • Advanced maternal age
  • History of chromosomal abnormalities
  • Mother is a carrier of an X-linked disorder
  • Maternal choice

There are trans-cervical and trans-abdominal types of amniocentesis. It is usually available locally. However, 1% of tests will not give a result.

 

B) The correct answer - combined test. The combined test can be performed between 11-14 weeks. The ultrasound measurements taken are nuchal translucency (>3.5mm suggests Down's syndrome) and crown-rump length. The detection rate is 85% for 2.5% screen positive rate. The biochemical markers tested for are beta-hCG and PAPP-A (pregnancy-associated placental protein A).

 

C) Quadruple test - this is performed between 15-18 weeks. The ultrasound measurements taken are crown-rump length or HC/BPD (head circumference/biparietal diameter). The detection rate is 75% for 3% screen positive rate. The biochemical markers tested for are AFP (alpha foetoprotein), hCG, uE3 (unconjugated oestriol) and inhibin A.

 

D) Preimplantation genetic diagnosis is not a screening test. Eggs are collected, fertilised and allowed to develop, and on the 3rd day, a blastomere is removed - its DNA is extracted and tested. The embryos without the genetic disorder are implanted into the mother.

 

I got this information from the lecture on Principles of Antenatal Screening from Case 7.
Tags: Pregnancy, Foetal Anomalies, Foetal Development, Case 7, investigations

Question: What is the function of N-cells in the ileum?
OptionA: Release of neurotensin in response to fat
OptionB: Release of enteroglucan in response to glucose and fat
OptionC: Release of motilin in response to fat and acid
OptionD: Release of Seretonin to activate local motor reflexes
OptionE: Release of enkephalins to regulate peristaltic reflex
Explanation:
N cells in the ileum release neurotensin in response to FAT. Neurotensin acts to decrease motility and hence increase fat absorption (NB. Fat is normally absorbed before this section. It is almost entirely absorbed in the jejunum)

 

L cells in the distal ileum release enteroglucan, which is released in response to glucose and fat. Like neurotensin, enteroglucan acts to decrease motility and maximize glucose absorption. (NB. Monosaccharides are absorbed in the first 20% of the small intestine)

 

M - cells in duodenum release motilin in response to FAT and acidic chyme. Motilin acts to increase the sensitivity of smooth muscle to intrinsic nervous activity. It stimulates gastric emptying and migrating motility complex. During fasting has CYCLIC RELEASE.

 

ECcells: Seretonin activates local motor reflexes.

Question: Which of the following correctly describes/is an example of deformation?
OptionB: Occurs during organogenesis when structures are being formed
OptionC: Anything that disrupts development, producing birth defects
OptionE: Decreased amniotic fluid, causing mother's organs to press on the foetus and cause club foot
Explanation:
The correct answer should be E) Decreased amniotic fluid, causing mother's organs to press on the foetus and cause club foot

 

A) Foetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder is an example of a syndrome. Syndromes are malformations that occur together with a common cause. They require a diagnosis of associating factors.

 

B) Occurs during organogenesis when structures are being formed - this describes malformations. These mostly occur between 3-8 weeks.

 

C) Anything that disrupts development, producing birth defects - this describes a teratogen e.g. alcohol, nicotine, isotretinoin

 

D) Amniotic band syndrome is an example of a disruption. A disruption is altering already-formed structures through destructive forces.

 

E) Decreased amniotic fluid, causing mother's organs to press on the foetus and cause club foot - this is an example of deformation. Deformations occur due to mechanical factors.

 

I got this information from the lecture on Congenital Malformations and Teratology in Case 7.
Tags: Pregnancy, Foetal Anomalies, Foetal Development, embryology, Case 7

Question: A baby is born with sensorineural deafness, bilateral cataracts, and patent ductus arteriosus. The birth weight is low. How could the mother have best prevented these abnormalities from occurring?
OptionC: Avoiding alcohol during the first trimester pregnancy.
OptionE: Avoiding alcohol during the second trimester of pregnancy.
Explanation: The classic triad of symptoms of congenital rubella syndrome are, sensorineural deafness, eye abnormalities, and congenital heart disease. Congenital rubella syndrome could have been avoided if the mother were vaccinated.
Tags: Pregnancy, Infectious Diseases, Case 7, MMR, Teratology

Question: Which of the following is angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB)?
According to the Baltimore classification system, classify the following virus: Norovirus
Explanation:
Norovirus belongs to the family of calicivirdae, and its a (+)ssRNA virus.(Group 4).

NB. Rotavirus belongs to a different class of virus. It belongs to the Reovirdae family of viruses, and is a dsRNA (Class 3)

Question: Mrs. smith is a 42 year old female who have recently been diagnosed with lynch syndrome. Lynch syndrome predisposes to colorectal cancers. What genes are mutated in lynch syndrome?
Explanation:
From genetics and the GI tract lecture,  DNA mismatch repair genes (MMR genes) are respon for lynch syndrome. 

APC gene mutations are respossible for FAP syndrome, attenuated FAP, MYH-associated polypsis - these do lead to colorectal cancer

BRACA gene is responsible for breast cancer 

SMAD4 is juvenile polypsis. And causes gastro cancers 

CDH1 causes familial diffuse gastric cancer

Question: This pedigree maps the inheritance pattern for ocularcutanous albinism. What type of inheritance does this pedigree demonstrate?
Explanation:
At first, the condition appears to be autosomal dominant due to the presence of male-to-male transmission however, ocularcutaneous albinism is a autosomal recessive disorder (so B is correct but D is a more accurate answer).

 

Pseudo-dominance is where an autosomal recessive disorder is passed on through the generations in a way that makes it look like it is being transmitted dominantly. 

 

By chance the affected males (genotype: +/+, i.e. homozygous recessive) have all had children with female carriers (genotype: +/-, i.e. heterozygous). This means there offspring has a 50% chance of developing the condition, which makes it look like the disease allele is the dominant one. 

 

This type of inheritance is higher in consanguineous families where individuals who are homozygous recessive are more likely to meet heterozygous partners. It is also more common in conditions where carrier rate is high and so by chance people that are homozygous recessive meet heterozygous partners (regardless of whether they are related).

 

Another condition pseudo-dominance may appear in is cystic fibrosis, especially now medical advancement means that affected individuals are more likely to get to child-bearing age to pass on their faulty recessive alleles (women more so than men because CF causes reduced fertility in men).

 

Case 7: Unusual Patterns of Inheritance

Question: Which one of these conditions is NOT autosomal dominant?
Explanation:
1-4 are all autosomal dominant conditions. Spinal muscular atrophy is an autosomal recessive condition. 

 

Autosomal dominant: 

- multiple generations passed from parent to child

- men and women equally affected

- male to male transmission seen

- 50% offspring risk

- incomplete penetrance seen

- variable expression

- can be a new mutation in the family. 

 

(Family histories and probabilities lecture)

Question: Which one of these conditions is NOT autosomal recessive?
Explanation:
B-E are all autosomal recessive conditions. A is an autosomal dominant condition. 

 

Autosomal recessive:

- usually only one generation affected

- parents both asymptomatic carriers

- often childhood onset conditions

- 25% recurrence risk after having an infected child

- common in consanguineous families

 

(family histories and probabilities lecture)

Question: Which Dopamine receptor is mostly involved in vomiting?
Explanation: Dopamine acts on the chemoreceptor trigger zone to cause nausea and vomiting. D2 receptors are most abundantly found in the medulla (chemoreceptor trigger zone) associated with the initiation of vomiting, and are assumed to mediate this effect. Thus nearly all dopamine receptor agonists (i.e bromocriptine) and other drugs that increase dopamine release in the brain (i.e Levadopa) cause nausea and vomiting as side effects. While many dopamine antagonists (i.e metocloperamide) have anti-emetic activity.

Question:
A 26-year old lady with Type 1 Diabetes presented to A&E with nausea and vomiting for 4 days, with progressive weakness and lethargy. Upon initial check-up, you found out that her blood glucose is 5.1 mmol/L, BP of 98/64, RR 18. She was afebrile and you requested a U&E while taking further history.

 

Further history revealed that she has been losing some weight over the past 3 months. She also complained that she is having difficulty in engaging in sexual activity with her partner. Out of interest, you asked her whether she has had any previous infection recently, which she negated. However, she did mention that she had a tuberculosis infection as a teenager.

 

Anyway, U&E results came back:

Sodium         115       (135-145 mmol/l)

Potassium     8.6       (3.5-5.3 mmol/l)

Urea              6.5       (2.5-6.7 mmol/l)

Creatinine      89        (70-150 mmol/l)

 

What would you do next for this lady?
OptionA: Correct electrolyte imbalance by giving IV Saline 0.9%
Explanation:
So this lady has Addison's disease, and the presentation was based on these symptoms

Insidious onset
Progressive weakness & fragiability
Non-specific complaints (anorexia; N/V; WL)
Primary adrenal disease
Hyperpigmentation (increased ACTH)
Hyperkalaemia & hyponatraemia
Hypotension (volume depletion) & dehydration
Hypoglycaemia
Sexual dysfunction

Autoimmune adrenalitis can cause Addison's disease! TB is the most common cause of Addison's!

 

Primary causes of Addison’s disease
- Tuberculosis --> caseous necrosis of adrenal cortex
Autoimmune adrenalitis
Associated with e.g. pernicious anaemia; thyroiditis; Type 1 DM
Metastatic disease – breast cancer
Systemic amyloidosis
Fungal infections
Haemochromatosis
Sarcoidosis

 

 

Adrenal insufficiency can be specifically diagnosed by low cortisol and demonstrating failure to increase plasma cortisol levels, upon administration of ACTH. ACTH levels help distinguish between primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency, we have to find the level of plasma ACTH: primary shows increased, and secondary shows decreased level.

 

AW

Question:
A 27-year-old male presents to his GP with hypertension (155/98), intermittent headaches, excessive sweating, and palpitations. His skin appears reddened despite him staying indoors in his office most of the time. BP is 112 and you notice some orthostatic hypotension upon measuring standing BP. He has no family history of stroke or hypertension but he remembered that his dad has this funny named disease... Von-Hippel Lindau it was. You prescribed him some ramipril (remembering the NICE guidelines for new hypertensives, <55 yo, caucasian) and discharged him home.

 

He presents again in 2 weeks time with weight loss and palpitations, this time his BP being 172/100 despite taking the ramipril.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
OptionC: Not sure yet, continue ramipril and add amlodipine
Explanation:
Phaeochromocytoma is an endocrine tumour of the medulla of the adrenal glands, resulting in excess (and continuous) adrenaline release. So basically due to adrenaline, his BP and HR is always high. The symptoms that he presented with (++ the weight loss) are the main reasons.

 

The five P’s:
High BPressure (HTN) 90%
Pain (Headache) 80%
Perspiration 71%
Palpitation 64%
Pallor 42%
Paroxysms (the sixth P!)

 

The Classical Triad:
Pain (Headache), Perspiration, Palpitations
Lack of all 3 virtually excluded diagnosis of phaeochromocytoma in a series of > 21,0000 patients

 

Up to 25% of pheochromocytomas may be familial. Mutations in the genes VHL, RET, NF1 (Gene 17 Neurofibromatosis type 1), SDHB and SDHD are all known to cause familial pheochromocytoma, therefore this disease may be accompanied by Von Hippel–Lindau disease, neurofibromatosis, or familial paraganglioma depending on the mutation.

Question: Raised intracranial pressure can cause heart block. When intracranial pressure increases, Cushing's reflex can be observed. What does Cushing's triad consist of?
OptionA: Decraesed blood pressure, irregular bleathing and tachycardia
OptionE: Increased blood pressure, irregular breathing and bradycardia
Explanation: E- Cushing’s reflex = Raised intracranial pressure increased blood pressure, bradycardia and irrregular breathing

Question: Which of the following co-factors are needed for the conversion of dopamine into noradrenaline in the catecholamine synthesis pathway?
Explanation:
The correct answer is D. 

The catecholamine synthesis pathway is the pathway by which dopamine, adrenaline and noradrenaline are synthesised. 

 

The first step in this pathway is the conversion of tyrosine from the diet into L-DOPA using the enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase (this is the rate limiting step). This step required oxygen and iron. 

L-DOPA is converted into Dopamine in dopaminergic neurons by the enzyme L-aromatic amino acid decarboxylase. This enzyme requires Vitamin B6 as a cofactor. 

Dopamine is then converted to noradrenaline in noradrenergic neurones using the enzyme dopamine-beta-hydroxylase which required both vitamin C and copper. 

Noradrenaline is covered to adrenaline by an enzyme called phenyl-ethanolamine N-methyltransferase which requires a methyl donor.

Question: Which enzyme is responsible for the conversion of 5-HT into serotonin?
Explanation:
The correct answer is AADC.  

 

A) converts tyrosine to L-DOPA. 

B )is the correct answer. It is also responsible for the conversion of L-DOPA into Dopamine. 

C) converts dopamine into noradrenaline. 

D) converts tryptophan into 5-HT.

Question: An increase in 5-HT due to the actions of antidepressants can cause a number of side effects including sexual dysfunction. This adverse drug reaction is caused by an increase in the activity of which 5-HT receptor?
Explanation:
An increase in the activity of 5HT2A can cause sexual dysfunction. 

SSRIs can increase the activity of these receptors. 

5HT2A are also activated by hallucinogenic drugs and blocked by atypical antipsychotics. 

These receptors are metabotropic.

Question: 5HT3 receptors are inotropic receptors. An increase in serotonin can mediate which side effect through this receptor subtype?
Explanation:
The correct answer is B) nausea and vomting. 

 

Blockade of these receptors is the mechanism of action of odanestron like anti emetics.

Question:
Derrick, a 76 year old man comes to the GP surgery concerned about a few new symptoms. The GP has never met Derrick before, because he has no previous medical history and is pretty much fit and well.

 

He reports blood in his stool, it is red but looks mixed in, he doesn't think he's ever suffered with haemorroids.

He's having to go to the bathroom a lot more than normal.

He has lost a bit of weight in the past 4 months but he hasn't been trying to.

 

He's a bit confused because he doesn't have any pain.

 

The GP is concerned about Derrick and wants to do a special investigation, which would be most appropriate based on what we know about Derrick which might help with a diagnosis?
Explanation:
Derrick has RED FLAG signs for a colon cancer (blood in stool, altered bowel habit, unexplained weight loss -other red flags include abdominal pain and mucous in stool)

To rule this out he needs an investigation. Following the plan from the radiology lecture he should have a COLONOSCOPY as it is gold standard.

 

If he was extremely frail he could have a minimal prep CT

 

Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice for <40yrs old, or those that can tolerate it if cancer or colitis is suspected. It allows for biopsies, doesn't have any risk of radiation, and is the most sensitive and specific investigation (however it is expensive and time consuming)

Minimal Prep CT is useful if a patient is >80, old and frail or with limited mobility. You still need to be careful in renal impairment as contrast is required.

CT Pneumocolon is chosen if extra-colonic Ca is likely, or a failed colonoscopy

If a patient is young but unfit for full bowel prep a non-laxitive CTcolon would be indicated.

Question:
Adam has a list of gastro symptoms that he is concerned about, he discusses them with his GP. He's been onto google and think he has IBS because of this.

 

 His symptoms include:

Weight loss
Bloody stools

A feeling of needing to 'go' all the time

Abdo pain, relieved by opening bowels.

 The GP knows better and thinks most of these symptoms suggest an inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the symptoms can't be used to differentiate between IBS and IBD
Explanation:
The answer is D, both IBD and IBS have abdo pain and cramping, so it cannot be used to rule out either.

IBD symptoms which DON'T occur in IBS are:

Wt loss, fever, perianal disease, bloody stools, tenesmus (feeling the need to poo all the time)

So because he has these symptoms he may have an IBD.

Other investigation findings ruling OUT IBS are:

raised platelets and ESR
anaemia

reduced albumin

fecal wbc and fecal occult blood

fever

Question:
Ben has Ulcerative colitis which is currently affecting his descending colon (has not affected any further proximally yet).

His disease is currently not active.

 IF he was trying to get the most targeted treatment possible - which regime would be most appropriate?
Explanation:
Drugs used to maintain remission of UC are:
Mesalazine
Azathioprine

Azathioprine is taken orally only (its an immunosuppressant tablet). So that rules that out.
Corticosteroids are only indicated in active disease.

So the question is which kind of mesalazine would be best?
Oral targets whole colon
Enema gets to descending
Suppository is only useful for rectum

So a Mesalazine Enema would be the ideal choice in this case (although, in real life, he'd probably go for oral because thats much easier)

Question: Cerys is having her first active bout of Crohn's Disease for 14 months, her GP wants to try and induce remission. She has no other medical history and is age 28. What is the most appropriate first step?
Explanation:
According to NICE, first step is Oral prednisolone,

 

 If oral glucocorticoids c/i then next option is oral budesonide, but its not as effective...

 

Oral metronidazole is an option according to the lecture on treatment of CD, but NICE don't mention it unless there is fistulising disease.

 

Infliximab is a TNF-a blocker, and is a biologic, it could be used to maintain remission but its not the FIRST step for inducing remission.

 

Oral mesalazine in the lecture says is only for UC, but NICE say it can be used to induce remission in CD, but again its not the first step.

Question:
It is said that exercise protects you from getting type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Anyone ever wondered why?

Why?
OptionA: Exercise burns glucose as the energy source so it keeps blood sugar levels low.
OptionB: Adrenaline blocks insulin pathway, hence there isn't a lot of insulin spikes throughout the day.
OptionC: More GLUT 4 transporter appears in muscle cell membrane following exercise.
OptionD: Adrenaline release leads to stable low levels of blood glucose for a period of time following exercise.
OptionE: I don't know.. probably we don't really need to know this right?
Explanation: Mentioned by Dr. Andrew Shore during his Fuel Metabolism lecture in Case 10.

Question: Which of the following is not screened for in Wales?
Explanation:
Rubella is no longer screened for in Wales because the vaccination programme was so successful that the disease is no longer prevalent enough for the screening to be worth offering. 

 

Other screening tests offered are early pregnancy ultrasound scan, foetal anomaly scan & blood group and antibody screening. 

 

I know there is no negative questions in the SBA but thought it was a good way to learn what screening is offered in Wales!

 

Case 7: Antenatal Screening

Question: Whilst in the GP practice, a mother comes in with her 15 year old son and expresses her concern that he always seems to be thirsty and has lost some weight. Her son also mentions that his vision has recently become blurry. You suspect Type 1 diabetes but need to ensure the diagnosis is correct as it will have major implications for this 15 year old. Which of the following meets the criteria for a diagnosis?
OptionD: A fasting plasma glucose of more than 7.0mmol/L
OptionE: A random plasma glucose of more than 10.5mmol/L
Explanation:
According to the lecture by Colin Dayan in order to diagnose diabetes you need ONE of the following criteria:

- Fasting plasma glucose > 7.0mmol/L

- Random plasma glucose > 11.1mmol/L

- (2hr glucose post 75G GTT > 11.1)

- HbA1c > 6.5% (recent guidelines)* *Do not use if Hb may be abnormal

Question: Lily is a 25-year-old woman who is 11 weeks' pregnant. She presents to A+E with her father, complaining of sudden shortness of breath, haemoptysis and chest pain. You take a very quick history and find out that her father has had a DVT before - so you suspect Lily is having a pulmonary embolism. You need to anticoagulate her, so what do you use?
Explanation:
The correct answer should be D) Low molecular weight heparin

 

A) Rivaroxaban - this is a NOAC that works as an inhibitor of Factor Xa (similar MOA to apixaban). While they seem safer, there is not yet a large body of ADR information so you would avoid giving this to Lily as she is pregnant.

 

B) Protamine sulphate - this is not an anticoagulant, it is in fact an antidote for over-anticoagulation using heparin.

 

C) Warfarin - this is actually contraindicated for use in pregnant women as during the 1st trimester, it is teratogenic and may anticoagulate the foetus in the 3rd trimester. Warfarin is a vitamin K carboxylase inhibitor that prevents the formation of gamma-carboxylated blood clotting factors. The antidote for over-anticoagulation is vitamin K. Anti-coagulation using warfarin is monitored by regular measurement of prothrombin time via the INR. Warfarin is administered orally, at home by the patient.

 

D) Low molecular weight heparin - this is the correct treatment. Heparin activates anti-thrombin III which can inactivate thrombin and Factor Xa, but low molecular weight heparin only inhibits Factor Xa. Anti-coagulation is monitored by regular measurement of prothrombin time compared against activated partial thromboplastin time. Heparin is administered intravenously in hospital by health professionals.

 

E) Dabigatran is another example of a NOAC so wouldn't be used to treat Lily as she is pregnant. Dabigatran works as a direct thrombin inhibitor.

Question:
Dante is a vegan, and is concerned that because he doesn't like dark green leafy vegetables either, he isn't getting enough iron in his diet.

 As his medic bestie, which of his symptoms IS related to an iron deficiency?

BONUS QUESTION (answer in explanation): What would his FBC look like if he DID have an iron deficiency anaemia.
OptionA: Loss of vision due to an opaque cornea
Explanation:
BONUS ANSWER: An iron deficiency anemia would look like a LOW Hb, and a LOW MCV.

 

A = Vitamin A deficiency causing keratomalacia, the special epithelium of the eye is replaced with an inappropraite strat. sq. epi!
B = Vitamin B1 deficiency causing mental problems

C = Teeth falling out from Scurvy - vitamin C deficiency

D = Bone pain - from osteomalacia, from a vitamin D deficiency

E = Koilonychia -spoon shaped nails from an Iron deficiency DING DING DING. would also be pale, have low energy, and angular cheilitis

Question: Which part of the sarcomere decreases in length during skeletal muscle contraction?
Explanation: A bands do  not change length. The I band shortens and the Z lines come closer together.

Question: When would head circumference be used instead of crown-rump length to estimate gestational age during the dating scan at 8-14 weeks?
Explanation: Case 7: Antenatal Screening

Question: Regarding embryological development, which of the following regulates cell differentiation?
Explanation:
A) Primitive streak formation = first sign of GASTRULATION

B) Notochord signalling = NEURAL INDUCTION (neurulation starts by formation of neural plate and ends with closure of neural tube)

The following proteins are important in neural conduction...

  • C) Wnt family of proteins = inducers of ECTODERMAL and MESODERMAL tissues/organs
  • D) Shh protein = initially expressed in the notochord and inducer of NEURAL PATTERNING 
  • E) TGF-beta proteins = regulates CELL DIFFERENTIATION

Question: Which virus has the ability to down-regulate MHC1 expression and thus "hide" from the immune system?
Explanation: A is correct. HCMV downregulates MHC1 expression making it harder to target, as mentioned in one of the immunology lectures.

Question: Which agent is least likely to be released from CD8+ cytotoxic T cells?
Explanation:
perforins, granzymes and granulysin all play roles in caspase-mediated apoptosis of CD8+ cells.

IL-2 allows CD8+ cells to proliferate.

IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine as mentioned in Zarabeth's lecture from case 1!

Question: Which of these symptoms is not associated with viral croup?
Explanation:
Hemoptysis is not associated with croup.

 

Croup is often seen in children that acquire respiratory syncitial virus (RSV) or more commonly parainfluenza virus. These viruses are more likely to infect those with narrow airways.

Question: Which seretonin receptor subtype is activated by the anxiolytic Buspirone?
Explanation:
Buspirone is a non-benzodiazepine anxioltyic. It is a potent AGONIST of the 5-HT 1A receptor. It is an effective treatment for generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) but NOT phobias. The pharmacological activity of Buspirone takes weeks to manifest (it's effect is slow in onset - may take >2 weeks). 

NB. 5HT-1A receptors function as inhibitory auto-receptors, highly expressed in the cortico-limibic system circuits which are implicated in emotional behavior. Stimulating these inhibitory receptors will cause anxiolysis. 

Caution when prescribing Buspirone to patients with known suicidal thoughts as Buspirone has a much lower abuse potential.

Question: What is the ECG criteria for Left Axis Deviation (LAD)?
OptionB: Positive R waves in Lead 1 and negative R waves in the inferior leads (2,3, and aVF)
OptionC: Positive R waves in the inferior leads (2,3,,aVF) and negative R wave in Lead 1
OptionD: Dominant S wave in V1 with notched 'M-shaped' R wave in V6
OptionE: RSR’ pattern in V1-3 (‘M-shaped’ QRS complex). Wide, slurred S wave in the lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-6)
Explanation:
A= Normal cardiac axis

B= LAD

C= Right Axis Deviation (RAD)

D= LBBB

E= RBBB

Question:
Emma (24) has arrived at A&E complaining of cramps and stomach pain. She's had bloody diarrhea for a few months, but was too frightened to tell anyone. She's also been suffering with the need to 'go' frequently. She has turned up to A&E because she's been unable to get a GP appointment, and is worried that if she doesn't tell someone she'll avoid it again.

 

 The F1 requests an AxR and draws routine bloods. The AxR returns first, and is as above. What is the most likely diagnosis given the X-ray and presentation?
Explanation:
UC is the answer.

 

The radiograph shows 'thumb printing' of the colon which is a sign of mucosal inflammation.

 

Her symptoms of tenesmus and bloody stools also line up with this.

 

Her age makes colon malignancy less likely, and an IBD more likely

 

Appendicitis would have a different Sx presentation and wouldn't cause the thumb printing on AxR

Question:
You are a GP and a woman who has recently found out she is pregnant has come in to see you. She tells you she has read online that it is good to take folic acid supplements in order to prevent spina bifida and other defects. She asks you how much she should be taking. You check her medical records and you see that she has epilepsy, she also informs you that when her mother was pregnant with her younger brother she also had seizures. 

 

What dose of folic acid should this patient be taking daily?
OptionE: She shouldn't be taking folic acid because she is epileptic
Explanation:
Pregnant women are ordinarily recommended to take 0.4mg (400µg) of folic acid supplements in order to prevent neural tube defects. 

 

However this patient has  epilepsy and the fact her mother had seizures whilst pregnant with her brother suggests that this patient has a family history of eclampsia. Because of this, the patient would be recommended to take a higher dose of 5mg. 

 

Recommendations for 50% of the population may soon change: they too may be prescribed 5mg.

Question: Which of the following statements is incorrect about karyotyping:
OptionA: Karyotyping lets you see down to 5 million DNA bases different.
OptionB: Karyotyping cannot help you see if a patient has cystic fibrosis.
OptionD: Karyotyping can help you diagnose most single gene deletion disorders.
OptionE: You can have a normal karyotype but still have a genetic disorder.
Explanation:
A) correct statement

B) correct statement - cystic fibrosis may be due to a single base change which is far too small to be seen on karyotype.

C) correct statement

D) incorrect statement - most genes are 2 million bases long, seen as a karyotype can only see down to 5 million bases even if a whole gene was deleted karyotyping would miss this.

E) correct statement - lots of genetic disorders are missed by karyotyping because the gene changes are too small to see on karyotype as the resolution is not good enough. 

 

Case &: Chromosomal Abnormalties

Question:
Fran (22) is having some symptoms! She's come to A&E with severe abdominal pain, and presents with the following findings in her history.

 

Post-prandial pain

Weight loss

Feeling tired

Abdomen feels swollen and bloated

 

AxR shows multiple dilated loops of bowel and thumb printing. All of the affected area's of bowel have plicae circulares which stretch all the way across the dilated lumen, they are also positioned centrally.

 

Blood results show an iron deficiency anaemia, B12 and ferritin levels are also low.

 

Which diagnosis is most likely?
Explanation:
The answer is Crohn's

 

The AxR findings are all on the small bowel (plicae circulares and central position).

 

UC doesn't affect the small intestine, so the thumb printing can't be caused by this.

 

The Crohn's has caused malabsorption.

 

Acute infectious diarrhoea wouldn't give thumbprinting as a mucosal change, and it takes a long time to deplete B12 stores.

 

Colorectal cancer would be unlikely given her age, and again wouldn't cause thumbprinting in the small instestine.

Question:
You are an F1 doctor in A+E.

A 27-year old male is bought in following a traumatic injury where he was hit side on by a car.  He is shown to have 3 broken ribs, a pneumothorax and a fracture to the left pedicle of his T12 vertebrae.  Once stabilised, the patient is sent straight to surgery. 

 

Three days later you visit him on the orthopaedic ward and enquire about his most recent peripheral neurological examination as you would like to know his prognosis. 

The patient cannot move the left hand side of his body below his hips, he cannot feel light touch on  the left hand side of his body below T12 however he could feel pain with the neurotip.

However, he has a loss of pain sensation on the right hand side of his body, below the hypogastric region of his stomach but preservation of light touch sensation on the right hand side of his body. 

 

Which cord syndrome is this patient showing symptoms for?
Explanation:
The correct answer is E. 

 

Brown-Sequard Syndrome: characterised by ipsilateral paralysis and loss of vibration and light touch sensation, with contralateral loss of pain and temperature. 

 

This is due to the location of desuccation of the individual tracts. Corticospinal tracts and dorsal column tracts desiccate in the brainstem, above the spinal cord therefore a left sided spinal cord injury will affect the left hand side of the body resulting in ipsilateral symptoms.

Spinothalamic tracts however dessucate in the spinal cord, so the left sided in injury will injure the tract for the right hand side of the body. 

 

This patient is displaying all of these symptoms following his injury. In addition, the mechanism of his injury fits too - it is a side on injury resulting in a fracture to his pedicle which could have penetrated the left hand side of his spinal cord. 

 

Anterior spinal cord syndrome: Bilateral spastic paralysis where the tone of the muscles increases. Loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure sensation. Preservation of proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination

 

Posterior spinal cord syndrome: Loss of proprioception, vibration and two point discrimination. Motor preservation.

 

Central: Upper motor neurone: spastic paralysis mainly affecting the upper limb more than the lower limb due to tract lamination.

Question: By which day post-fertilisation is the blastocyst completely encased in endometrium?
Explanation:
General

Days 1-3 = zygote

Days 4-7 = morula

Days 8-14 = blastocyst

 

Specifics 

Day 6/7 = implantation begins

Day 10 = balastocyst is completely encased in endometrium at this point

Day 12 = primitive placenta

Day 16 = Gastrulation begins

Day 20 = Neurulation begins

Question:
Gabriel has got the runs! He complains of abdominal pain and feels like he has a fever. He's a poor student who let some chicken fillets sit in his fridge a little long but didn't fancy chucking it out.

 

He attends his GP who performs FBC, CRP and ESR, and sends a stool sample for microscopy on a blood agar plate.

 

The microbiologist looks down and see's the following:

 

 

 

Which organism has caused Gabriel's symptoms?
Explanation:
Campylobacter has the classic spiral appearance. It is the most common cause of bacterial gasteroenteritis in the UK, and is associated with undercooked meat.

 

Salmonella and E Coli and Listeria all look the same to me- they're flagellate bacilli. Listeria are gram +ve, the others are Gram -ve

 

E. Coli is more associated with beef that is undercooked

 

Salmonella is associated with chicken, dairy and eggs.

 

Listeria is associated with pre-packed sandwhiches and cheeses, its important for pregnant ladies to avoid it due to Listeriosis.

 

Of course Rotavirus and Noravirus are viruses!

Question:
Mrs Jones delivered a baby boy over 30 hours ago and since then the baby has not passed meconium (first stool passed) and has a very distended abdomen. A rectal biopsy is carried out and an absence of ganglionic cells is noted in the report. 

 

During embryological development in utero which of the following was affected?
Explanation:
The presentation of the baby is fitting with HIRSCHPRUNG' DISEASE

  • Disorder of the bowel causing intestinal obstruction
  • Male predominance 
  • 1/5000 births
  • Pathophys = failure of NEURAL CREST CELLS to migrate (in normal development NCC migrate to colon to form myenteric an submucosal plexus hence the lack of ganglion cells in the biopsy)
  • Sx = constipation, abdominal distention, failure of baby to pass first stool/meconium within 4h hrs post delivery

Question: Harry is a microbiologist, and he has a section of a healthy Ileum to look at taken from a biopsy. What structure is B
Explanation:
Peyer's Patches,

 

Peyer's patches are small masses of lymphatic tissue found throughout the ileum region of the small intestine. Also known as aggregated lymphoid nodules, they form an important part of the immune system by monitoring intestinal bacteria populations and preventing the growth of pathogenic bacteria in the intestines.

 

A = Mucosa

B = Peyer's Patches

C = Muscularis externa

D = Serosa

Question: During embryological cardiovascular development, cardiomyocytes of sinus venous begin to undergo spontaneous depolarisations eventually becoming incorporated into the right atrium and forming the SA node. At which week does this happen?
Explanation:
Week 4-7: heart divides into 4 chambers

Week 5: Conducting system of the heart forms

Question:
Liam has given up on medicine and decided to sell his soul to big pharma and make drugs. He's got a great one planned that makes you super smart for SBA questions, the only problem is, it irreversibly blocks the enzyme Tyrosine Hydroxylase.

 

 He knows this is important in the brain, if no where else, from his neuropharmacology lectures.

 

Which neurotransmitter(s) won't be produced if the Tyrosine Hydroxylase enzyme is blocked?
Explanation:
From the beastly neuropharmacology lecture.

 

DA, NA and Adren all share a common pathway, All are made from TYROSINE which crosses into brain by active transport (rate limiting step) and which is then converted by TYROSINE HYDROXYLASE to L-DOPA

L-Dopa becomes DA (by AADC)

 

DA becomes NA (by DBH)

 

NA becomes Adrenaline (by PMNT)

 

 In the neurons of that type, so if you knock out the L-Dopa you lose all 3.

 

 

Serotonin incidentally is made from tryptophan (diet) and hydroxlated by tryptophan hydroxlase to T-hydroxytryptophan-5HT

5HT becomes 5-HT (serotonin) by the enzyme L-aromatic amino-acid decarboxylase (AADC) (THIS IS THE SAME ENZYME THAT is used to turn L-Dopa to DA)

 

 I don't know why, or if, these links are important.

Question:
Michael has been diagnosed with depression, and has been placed on amitryptyline, a Tricyclic antidepressant to block uptake of 5-HT (Serotonin) and NA (noradrenaline) neurotransmitters.

 

 Which statement about side effects of TCA's is correct?
OptionA: Also block mACH to cause a dry mouth
OptionE: Also block alpha-1-adrenegic receptors causing weight gain
Explanation:
mACH – Drowsiness, blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation
H1 – Weight gain, drowsiness
A1 – Dizziness, hypotension

Dangerous in overdose due to voltage sensitive Na+ channel blocker which can cause arrhythmia

Question: What is the mechanism of action of Fluoxetine?
OptionA: SSRI: short -term increase in synaptic serotonin, long-term fown regulation of post-synaptic serotonin receptors
OptionB: Benzodiazepine: acting on GABA(A) receptor. GABA-ergic through increasing opening of Cl- channel, but only in the presence of GABA
OptionC: A reversible, selective monoamine oxidase inhibitor, preventing enzyme-mediated clearance of synaptic serotonin, NA and DA
OptionD: A tricyclic anti-depressant (TCA), which limits the serotonin and NA re-uptake by blocking transporters and blocking voltage-gated cation channels in the CNS
OptionE: Atypical antipsychotic: selective antagonist of D2 receptors, and a partial agonist of 5-HT1A
Explanation:
B= Lorazepam

C= Maclobemide

D=Amitriptyaline

E= Clozapine

 

Light bulb pharmacology, Case 12

Question: Haloperidol is an Antipsychotic, how does it work?
OptionB: Blocks D1 receptors more than D2 receptors
OptionC: Blocks D2 receptors more than D1 receptors
Explanation:
Haloperidol is a typical or conventional antipsychotic, in that is blocks BOTH D1 and D2 receptors.

 

Chlorpromazine blocks both equally.

 

Haloperidol blocks D2 more than D1.

 

 D2 receptors (generally inhibitory) are invovled in the mesolimbic pathway, and produce the +VE symptoms of schizophrenia (things you gain, like hearing voices)

 D1 receptors (generally excitatory) are involved in the mesocortical pathway, and produce the -VE symptoms of schizophrenia (things you lose, like pleasure and motivation).

 

In schizophrenia D2 are overactive, D1 are underactive.

 

Chlorpromazine isn't great because it reduces the effects of both (D1 are already low, so it can make things worse)

Haloperidol is slightly better, it reduces D2 more (good!) than D1, but it still does.

 

This can lead to SE such as tardive dyskinesia and acute dystonia.

Question: Which condition would be most appropriately treated with Benzodiazepine, such as diazepam?
Explanation: Also may be appropriate for Panic Disorder

Question:
Jim is buzzing his nut off and has taken a bunch of methamphetamine.

 

 After he comes down he feels super sad. Why?
Explanation: Meth-amphetamine and amphetamine (speed) cause DA and NA to be dumped into the synaptic clefts of your brain and make you feel just dandy. BUT afterwards you're all out of them so you get depressed. It might also take MORE of the same drug to reach the same high as previously.

Question:
Imogen is a 24yo female on the T&O ward at UHW. She's been admitted to IV antibiotics for a superficial wound infection she obtained whilst cutting vegetables.

 

 Unfortunately the T&O ward is quite noisy, patients are groaning throughout the night, and the nurse keeps on switching on the lights to sort out an adjacent patient.

 

 Which of the following medications might help to repair her natural sleep patterns with a short course of treatment on discharge.
OptionC: Morphine (she'll be having it for pain relief anyway)
Explanation:
Diazepam - benzodiazepine, doesn't induce natural sleep pattern but its a sedative, anxiolytic and anti-epileptic.

Morphine - sedative properties (as well as pain relief) but again not inducing a natural sleep pattern

Zopiclone - nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic, induces similar sleep pattern to a benzodiazepine. The most commonly prescribed.

 

Melatonin, hormone produced in pineal gland (from serotonin) in darkness. A short course can induce natural sleep pattern.

Question:
A 66 year old male attends A+E with thoracic severe back pain, which began 2 weeks ago and has got progressively worse.

You ask him about his past medical history and he tells you that he is a smoker and admits that he has had a persistent cough for around 2 months and has noticed some haemoptysis. He has not presented to primary care with these symptoms.

You order an X-ray of his spine (shown above).

What are your immediate concerns once you see this X-ray?
OptionA: The patient has spondylosis due to a weakness of their pars articularis causing their back pain and the lung symptoms are of separate aetiology.
OptionB: The patient has a primary osteosarcoma tumour in his vertebral body
OptionC: This is a normal radiological sign and you are concerned primarily about his back pain being due to other causes
OptionE: The patient has bone metastases secondary to a lung cancer
Explanation:
The correct answer is E.

 

The radiological sign is known as the Winking Owl where the pedicle is absent, almost always due to a bone metastases.

https://radiopaedia.org/articles/winking-owl-sign-spine

 

The answer is E due to the other worrying other symptoms he is showing and the fact he has a long smoking history.

 

The cause could be a primary bone tumour but the immediate concern is ruling out that this is a metastasis.

 

Answer A is wrong - the 'Scotty dog' sign is associated with a Pars defect.

Question:
You are a cardiologist and a 12 year old female is referred to you by her GP for an echocardiogram because she has the following symptoms:

  • Shortness of breath on exertion
  • Chest pain
  • Dizziness
  • Palpitations

The patient asks you what is wrong with her heart and you explain that one of her valves has a defect and to help explain you draw her this diagram:

The patient has other features that would suggest that this defect is part of a syndrome as a result of a chromosomal abnormality. Which syndrome is it likely to be?
Explanation:
On echocardiogram the aortic valve was found to be bicuspid, this is a defect because the aortic valve is meant to be tricuspid. Because there are only 2 valve leaflets instead of 3 this can result in obstruction of blood flow across the valve (aortic stenosis) and/or valve leakage (aortic valve regurgitation). These will result is less blood flow to the brain (resulting in dizziness), myocardial tissue (resulting in chest pain) etc. 

 

30% of patients with Turner's Syndrome have a bicuspid aortic valve. The patient would have had other clinical features such as webbing of the neck, short stature and a broad chest that the cardiologist may have noticed.
Tags: chromosomal abnormalities, chromosome abnormalities, Cardiology, Case 7

Question:
One of your female patients with known kidney disease comes into the surgery. You send off a blood sample to be tested. 

The only notable change in her blood sample is: 

Uric acid: 8.0mg/dL (2.4-6.0).

Which of the following is a common disorder resulting from high blood uric acid levels?
Explanation:
Normal Uric acid levels are 2.4-6.0 mg/dL (female) and 3.4-7.0 mg/dL (male).

Most of the uric acid is filtered out by the kidneys and passes out of the body in urine. A small amount passes out of the body in stool. But if too much uric acid is being produced or if the kidneys are not able to remove it from the blood normally, the level of uric acid in the blood increases.

High levels of uric acid in the blood can cause solid crystals to form within joints. This causes a painful condition called gout. If gout remains untreated, these uric acid crystals can build up in the joints and nearby tissues, forming hard lumpy deposits called tophi. High levels of uric acid may also cause kidney stones or further kidney failure.

Question: A patient presents to A and E very ill with an acid base imbalance. You discover from his history that he has COPD. Which type of imbalance is he most likely to have?
Explanation:
This is a respiratory acidosis because:

  • COPD means that he has a problem with ventilation (why it is respiratory)
  • This leads to an accumulation of carbon dioxide 
  • This reduces the pH making the blood more acidotic than normal (why it is acidosis) 

Will initially get bicarbonate buffering and haemoglobin acting as a buffer to attempt to restore the imbalance, however if carbon dioxide accumulation continues these mechanisms will become overwhelmed. It will then take a few days for the kidney's to start compensatory mechanisms. 

 

See Tim Johnson's recorded lecture in Case 10 for more details and for why it isn't the others :)

Question:
You are working in a GP's practice when a Type 2 diabetic woman comes in for her check up. Part of this involves fundoscopy. While examining her eyes you identify some white, fluffy marks as seen in the picture.

 

 

What stage of diabetic retinopathy does this sign suggest?
OptionA: Diabetic Retinopathy? I don't think so... these are completely normal!
Explanation:
In background DR:

  • Dot and Blot haemorrhages 
  • Hard exudates 

In Pre-Proliferative DR:

  • Venous bleeding
  • Cotton wool spots (the white fluffy marks)
  • Intraretinal Microvascular abnormalities 

In Proliferative DR:

  • Formation of new vessels
Tags: Cranial Nerves Examination, diabetes, The eye, case 10

Question:
A women presents to your GP's with fatigue, weight gain, constipation and menstrual irregularities. You send off for blood tests thinking it may be an endocrine problem. 

 

The results come back as:

  • Serum TSH = high 
  • Serum free T4= Low 
  • Serum T3= normal 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Explanation of Blood tests:

A) Hyperthyroidism would show:

  • Low serum TSH 
  • High serum free T4
  • High serum T3 

B) T3 toxicosis:

  • is a type of hyperthyroidism 
  • Low serum TSH 
  • Normal serum free T4 
  • High serum T3 

C) RIGHT ANSWER

  • Serum T3 could also be low 

D) Hypothyroidism secondary to pituitary disease:

  • Low serum TSH 
  • Low serum T4
  • Low/ normal serum T3

E) Grave's disease is a cause of Hyperthyroidism so would be the same as A

Question: Which of the following structures go through the carpal tunnel?
Explanation:
The carpal tunnel is an osseofibrous tunnel formed by the flexor retinaculum in the wrist.
The median nerve and tendons of the long flexor muscles of the digits pass through it.

Question:

Where is cortisol secreted from?
Explanation:
A) Zona Pellucida - your cortisol levels should rightfully be high... go back over case 7/8

B) Zona Reticularis - DHEA secretion

C) Zona Glomerulosa - Aldosterone secretion

D) CORRECT

E) Adrenaline

Question:
Ophelia is a GP and is just churning out prescriptions for Citalopram.

 

 What kind of drug is Citalopram, and how does it work?
OptionA: SNRI- blocks reuptake of 5-HT and NA in synaptic cleft
OptionB: MAOI:  Mono-amine oxidase inhibitor, blocks metabolism of neurotransmitters in synapstic cleft
OptionC: NRI - increases NA in synaptic cleft by blocking reuptake
OptionD: SSRI, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors increasing 5-HT levels in synaptic cleft
OptionE: TCA - inhibits 5-HT and NA reuptake (also blocks mACH causing dry mouth)
Explanation:
 TCAs - Tricyclic and related cyclic antidepressants: Amitriptyline
 SSRIs - selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors: Citalopram (also fluoxetine)
 NRIs - norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors: reboxetine
 SNRIs - serotonin/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors: Venlafaxine, duloxetine
 MAOIs - monoamine oxidase inhibitors - Phenelzine
 Atypical
Most INCREASE amount of NA/5-HT and DA by blocking reuptake. MAOIs inhibit monoamine oxidase enzymes.

Question: Where in the GI tract is Calcium actively(transcellularly) absorbed?
Explanation:
The active uptake (transcellular) in duodenum via TRPV channels. Calcium's active absorption in the duodenum is regulated by the hormone calcitriol, and requires the intracellular buffer calbindin. 

 

The passive (paracellular) absorption of calcium occurs in both the jejunum and the ileum.

Question:
A 35 year old patient comes in requiring stitches to a superficial wound on their anterior forearm.

You are a junior doctor who will be suturing the wound.

First you must inject a local anaesthetic to the area before you begin.

You decide to use lidocaine to do this and due to the location of the wound you decide against using adrenaline.

The patient is 56kg.

What dose of lidocaine can you give to the patient?
Explanation:
The Answer is C- 168mg. 

This is because the dose of lidocaine which you can give is 3mg/kg without adrenaline. 

3x56 = 168.

 

This is from the Nerve Anatomy and Injury Lecture in Case 14.

Question: If you have a Sunderland Class III and a Seddon Class Neurotmesis, which structures have been affected?
OptionA: Loss of axonal continuity. Endoneurium continuity lost.
OptionC: Loss of axonal continuity. Endoneurium continuity lost. Perineurium continuity lost.
OptionD: Loss of axonal continuity. Endoneurium intact. Myelin sheath damage.
OptionE: Endoneurium intact. No loss of axonal continuity.

Question:
The police have brought Peter to A&E because he has cut his hand whilst in a jail cell, you are asked to see him as an F1 doctor.

 

 Peter doesn't seem bothered that he cut his hand, he says that his blood has magical properties and can be sold for a high value. He thinks you should tell the policemen about the importance of this, because he could hang around the hospital and probably cure half the people here with a few drops of his blood if they are placed on their forehead. He quit his job 8 days ago because he needs more time to eat red meat to produce more of his healing blood. He's got all his notes with him and is keen to show you about the chemical components of his blood.

 

He is very talkative, and can't quite seem to sit still. He is wearing a pair of flowery swimming shorts (even though its the middle of winter) and three baseball caps on top of one another, if you ask him about this he'll tell you he's trying to start a new fashion trend. He hasn't been eating well, and refused food in the police station because he doesn't need it - it'll affect the composition of his blood. He can't seem to stop talking about his various plans, he thinks he might have had his blood altered by aliens.

 

What might your initial diagnosis be?
Explanation:
Depressive symptoms aren't quite the same as this, as is depression with psychosis. Psychosis in depression seems to have mood congruent delusions/hallucinations (so it's often negativE)

 

Hypomania is on the right track, he has elevated mood, less need for sleep and expansive plans and is over talkative.

 

Mania lasts more than a week, and would result in feeling elated, grandiose, with more energy, pressured speech, less need for sleep and a complete disruption of his life -- this all fits as he's quit his job and is burning bridges.

 

 This is mania with psychoses as he is out of touch with reality. He has mood congruent delusions (think's he's special), and a flight of ideas and self neglect.

Question: Whats the incidence of Schizophrenia
Which of the following malformations is not part of VACTERL?
Explanation:
VACTERL stands for: vertebral defects, anal atresia, cardiac defects, trans-esophageal fistula, renal abnormalities, limb abnormalities.

 

VACTERL is an association because it is a recognised pattern of malformations but the common initiating cause has yet to be identified (like it would have been in a syndrome) 

 

Duodenal atresia is a deformity that is seen in ~8% of Down's Syndrome patients and it picked up soon after birth when the baby is feeding poorly.

Question:
Queeny is a 68 year old lady who lives alone and is alcohol dependent. She was admitted to UHW under the medics when she was found collapsed in the garden by a neighbour.

 

 

 The admitting F1 forgot to prescribe a CIWA protocol, and Queeny is now withdrawing from alcohol. Along with the shakes, she's also screaming that the curtains (which, to be fair, have a fairly crazy geometric pattern) looks like they're covered in insects.

 

 

 What is the correct psychiatric description of this phenomenon
Explanation:
This is an illusion - she has a visual stimuli (the crazy pattern) but if percieving it wrongly.

 

Distortion just magnifies stuff (so colours appear brighter, food tastes extra good in mania)

Illusion has a stimuli but alters the perception

Hallucination is a false perception WITHOUT stimuli

Pseudohallucination is when you know it isn't real but still percieve it

Delerium Tremens is the syndrome of alcohol withdrawal including somatic and psychological manifestations.

Question: Which vitamin deficiency causes Queeny the alcoholic to develop confusion, an ataxic gait, and to fail to remember that she was admitted due to her alcohol dependance?
Explanation:
B1 thiamine causes Wernike-Korsakoff syndrome which is what is described here.

 

Admitted patients need Pabrinex for 3 days, then to be placed on thiamine supplementation

Question: Which of the following is helpful as opposed to essential in proving something is a teratogen?
OptionA: Association between the teratogen and malformation must make biological sense.
OptionB: There must be proven exposure to the teratogen during one or more critical periods of pre-natal development.
OptionC: Consistent finding must be found in 2 or more epidemiological studies linking the agent to the outcome.
OptionD: There must be carefully delineated clinical cases.
OptionE: Environmental exposure to this teratogen is rare and must be associated with a rare defect.
Explanation:
A is the only Shepard's criteria listed which is not essential but is helpful in proving something is a teratogen. 

 

Other helpful criteria are:

  • Teratogen has been shown to cause the effect in experimental animals
  • Proof in environmental system that agent acts in an unaltered state (not applicable for infectious teratogens) 

Case 7: Congenital Malformations

Question:
You are on placement in a community pharmacy and a lady comes in for some advice from the pharmacist. 

 

The lady explains that she is 6/40 weeks pregnant and has recently been getting awful morning sickness. She has recently returned from a holiday in Brazil and while she was there she picked up a drug called thalidomide which she thinks will stop her from feeling sick, but she wanted to check with the pharmacist because she can't read the instructions (as they are in another language) and she is concerned the language barrier mean the pharmacist in Brazil may not have understood her.

 

Which of the following reasons would the pharmacist not give this patient as to why she shouldn't take the thalidomide?
OptionB: Thalidomide has been proven to not be an effective anti-emetic which is why it is not used in the UK for this purpose.
OptionD: Thalidomide is particularly dangerous at this point in time of her pregnancy.
Explanation:
A = True, thalidomide causes congenital malformation.

B = False, thalidomide is a very effective anti-emetic and does prevent morning sickness. However, it is contra-indicated because the risk to the foetus outweighs the benefit to the mother.

C = True, thalidomide causes babies to be born with segments of limb missing so the hands/feet are attached closer to the trunk.

D = True, the patient is 6/40 weeks pregnant, the critical period for limb formation is 4-10 weeks so she is particularly at risk of having a child with phocomelia if she takes the thalidomide now. 

 

Although the use of thalidomide for morning sickness is not recommended in the UK, some countries such as Brazil do still sell it OTC.

Question:
A 45 year old woman presents to your GP surgery. 

She has been complaining of feeling vey tired, gaining around 2.5kg and feeling very low in the last 3 months. She also describes some vision changes and headaches in the last 2 weeks. 

 

On your examination, you note that she has very dry skin and has a HR of 55bpm. 

 

You order some urgent blood tests and these are the results:

 

Low TSH serum levels.

Low free T4 serum levels. 

Normal T3 serum levels. 

 

What is the likely diagnosis in your mind?
Explanation:
The Answer is D. 

The patient definitely has hypothyroidism - based on the serology results (a low T4), the clinical symptoms, her age and sex.  

 

HOWEVER The patients serology results indicate this is not a primary cause of hypothyroidism. A low TSH AND a low T4 indicate secondary hypothyroidism due to pituitary disease. 

 

This patient has also presented with headache and vision changes which suggests a pituitary lesion which could be an adenoma, therefore D is the answer. 

 

Atrophic hypothyroidism + Hashimoto's --> primary hypothyroidism due to auto-immune condition.  Serology: HIGH TSH and a low T4.

 

Toxic multi nodular goitre + Grave's Disease --> causes of hyperthyroidism. 

Serology: LOW TSH and a high T4.

Question:
You are a final year medical student and Lucy, a 32 year old primigravida who is 17 weeks pregnant, has come in for the Quadruple test. Before carrying out the test, the doctor asks you to measure her blood pressure which is 150/100 whilst he goes to get his equipment. 

 

What is the most appropriate explanation for this?
Explanation:
A) Criteria for pregnancy induced hypertension, also known as gestational hypertension is new hypertension (>140/90) AFTER 20 weeks WITHOUT proteinuria 

B) Pre-Eclampsia is characterised by ^BP +  PROTEINURIA

C) HELLP - considered a variant of pre-eclampsia, when severe. occurs during later stages and Tx is delivery of baby. There are 3 major elements of this syndrome = Haemolysis, Eelevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelet count

D) CORRECT ANSWER as Lucy is considered hypertensive with a BP >140/90 but is less than 20 weeks pregnant --> this excludes PIH (we are assuming this is not a new diagnosis)

Question:
A 15 year old boy comes into A&E after feeling unwell at school earlier that day. You notice severe eczema on his hands and his mother says he has been suffering with hay fever for a week. You notice that he is breathless, sweating and he says he has a very severe headache. You decide to take an ABG.

 

ABG Results:-

 

pH = 7.28                                     (7.35-7.45)

pO2 =3.7 kPA                              (4-5.3 kPa)

pCO2 = 6.8 kPa                          (4.5-6 kPa)

Bicarbonate = 22-26 mEq/L         (21 mEq/L)

 

What is the cause of these symptoms?
Explanation:
The eczema and hayfever is a hint that the patient is sufering from asthma. Asthma is one of the main causes of respiratory acidosis. An asthma attack can lead to hypoventilation and poor removal of CO2 from the body (high pCO2) and poor oxygenation (low pO2).

Buildup of CO2 in the blood can lead to a drop in pH as carbonic acid forms. 

 

We know that this is an acute presentation in 2 ways. The history states the boy had symptoms earlier that day, suggesting the symptoms are due to a possible asthma attack. Also the bicarbonate levels are low/normal, meaning there has not been enough time for the kidneys to compensate for the acidosis by retaining bicarbonate.

Question: A 24 year old male walks in to your GP practice presenting with symptoms of severe depression and you decide that the best treatment for this patient is to put him on phenelzine a MOAI. What type of monoamine oxidase enzyme does this drug inhibit?
Explanation:
MAOA - adrenergic and dopaminergic neurons = anti-depressant effect

MAOB– serotenergic and histaminergic neurons (Parkinson’s)

 

Taken from neuropharmacology lecture

Question: What is the name of the enzyme involved in Bicarboante (HCO3-) reabsorption in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule?
Explanation: Carbonic Anhydrase is present in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule and allows the formation of Bicarbonate ions from absorbed CO2 and O2. This Bicarbonate is then passed into the blood.

Question: In the ABO system what class of immunoglobulins are the antibodies?
Explanation:
CORRECT ANSWER = IgM (very potent antibodies hence why matching is critical)

 

IgA 

- found in fluids: saliva, tears, gastric fluid, mucosa

- breast milk

- Alternative pathway (complement cascade)

 

IgM

- immediate antibody made in infection

- pentamer

- receptor on B cells

- ABO antibodies

 

IgG

- most abundant in serum 

- Opsonin

- crosses placenta 

 

IgE

-allergies

- parasitic infection

Question: HIV is a...
Explanation: HIV is a virus

Question: What is the mechanism of action of Carbamazepine?
OptionB: Inhibits aberrantly active CNS voltage-gated Na+ channels and also is a GABA receptor agonist
OptionC: Transcriptionally UP-regulate anti-inflammatory proteins and DOWN-regulate pro-inflammatory mediators
OptionD: Osmotically draws fluid out from oedematous nerve tissue
OptionE: Inhibits aberrantly active CNS voltage-gated K+ channels and also is a GABA receptor agonist
Explanation:
See Case 16 pharmacology lightbulb

A- MOA of Midazolam

B- MOA of Carbamazepine

C- MOA of Dexamethasone

D- MOA of Mannitol
