Question:
A 57 year old smoker with long standing hypertension attends A+E and describes that 5 days ago as he was having his breakfast he suddenly started getting a severe headache mainly in the back of his head. He thought it was a migraine so didn't want to come to A+E and simply kept taking painkillers. As you take a more thorough history from him you found out that he has vomitted twice since the start of the headache and has been experiencing neck stiffness and photophobia. A CT scan is carried out but no abnormalities are seen. You are confused as you felt you had an idea of what to expect to see. 

 

What is the most appropriate next step?
Explanation:
In a patient with high suspicion of aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage with a normal head C >> a lumbar puncture is indicated to assess for xanthochromia.

 

Patients presentation is typical for SUBARACHNOID HAEMORRHAGE (sudden occipital headache, N/V, photophobia, neck stiffness) Also the fact he has hypertension and is a smoker ^ his risk.

 

If CT is carried out within 12 hours of onset of sympyoms, sensitivity to detecting SAH is pretty much 100%. But this decreases the longer it is left. he has been having symptoms for 5 days and so as a SAH will bleed in to CSF, LUMBAR PUNCTURE is most appropriate to detect xanthachromia

Question:
A patient comes into A&E having a past history of Left ventricular scarring, he has palpitations then loses consciousness. A DC shock is performed and he wakes up, an ECG is performed and the following is found: 

 

 

 

What medication would you prescribe this patient?
Explanation:
This patient has suffered a ventricular tachycardiac episode: 

 

A = class 1c, used for SVT, AVNRT, WPW

 

B = beta blocker, used for SVT

 

C = used for AV node dependant SVT

 

D = class 3, used for VT, Afib, WPW, Aflutter

 

E = class 4, used for paroxysmal SVT

Question:
A patient comes into your clinic complaining of breathlessness that has now become more frequent, they are currently on flecainide. An ECG is performed and the following is found: 

 

What is the next step in this patient's management?
Explanation:
This patient has come in and is presenting with 1st degree heart block. Normally they are asymptomatic, but in this case he is having worsening breathlessness.

 

Flecainide and any AV node controlling drug can result in 1st degree heart block and if symptoms such as these worsen, taking them off it is the best course of action. 

 

A = A. flutter 

B = 2nd or 3rd degree heart block 

C = CORRECT 

D = SVT treatment

E = would NOT do this definitely for this patient

Question: On which part of the kidney indicated does the anti-hypertensive drug furosemide work?
Explanation:
Furosemide works on the ascending loop of Henle 

 

7 = Loop of Henle

5 = distal convoluted tubule ( bendroflumethiazide would work here ) 

8 = collecting duct ( spironolactone would work here ) 

3 = Bowman's capsule

9 = Vasa recta

Question:
A patient presents with decreasing loss of consciousness, a blown left pupil that is un-reactive to light, contralateral hemiparesis and contralateral homonymous hemianopia. 

 

What is the most likely cause of this patients symptoms?
Explanation: Correct Answer: Uncal Herniation (A)

Question: What type of brain herniation can stretch and tear the basilar artery?
Explanation:
B: Central Herniation 

 

  • diencephalon (thalamus and hypothalamus) and parts of the temporal lobe of both the cerebral hemispheres are squeezed through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli 

 

  • this can stretch and tear the basilar artery --> fatal duret haemorrhage
  • causes dilated, fixed pupils and failure of the superior rectus -- eyes always look down 
  • compression of the pituitary stalk - diabetes insipidus

Question: What type of herniation can occur in addition to Uncal herniation?
Explanation:
Cingulate herniations

 

 

  • the medial part of the frontal lobe is pushed under and across part of the flax cerebelli 
  • caused by one of the hemispheres swelling and pushing the cingulate gyrus across 
  • occurs in ADDITION to uncal herniation 
  • presents with a coma and abnormal posturing

Question: in which phase of the cardiomyocyte action potential does calcium influx occur?

A 43 year old man had been complaining of a intractable headache during the day, 2 hours later his wife takes him to A&E, he has a decreasing GCS from 14 to 9, flaccid paralysis, a head tilt, his blood pressure is very unstable and he is having problems with his breathing. 

 

You being a brilliant medical student, think this could possibly be a type of brain herniation, but which type?
Explanation:
Correct Answer: Tonsillar 

 

Cerebelli tonsils move downward through the foramen magnum - lowering the brainstem and causing cervical spine compression 


this compression causes respiratory and cardiac dysfunction 

 

symptoms of Tonsillar herniations are: 

  • intractable headache 
  • head tilt 
  • neck stiffness 
  • BP instability 
  • respiratory and cardiac problems 
  • decreasing levels of consciousness 
  • flaccid paralysis

Question:
A patient presents to A&E with

 

  • right sided loss of pain and temperature sensation
  • left sided loss of pain and temperature sensation to the face 
  • dysphagia
  • left sided Horner's syndrome

What is the likely occluded artery?
Explanation:
Answer: occlusion of Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) 

 

also known as lateral medullary syndrome 

 

  • contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation --> spino-thalamic tract 
  • ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature to the face --> trigeminal tract 
  • dysphasia, hoarseness of voice, loss of gag reflex --> nucleus ambigous and roots of cranial nerves IX & X 
  • ipsilateral horners syndrome --> hypothalamic fibres (dorsal longitudinal fasciculus) 
  • vertigo, tendancy to fall to the ipsilateral side, diplopia (double vision) --> vestibular nucleui 
  • Ipsilateral ataxia --> spinocerebellar tract 

Horners Syndrome Triad:

  • miosis (contricted pupil) 
  • partial ptosis (Drooping of upper eyelid)
  • loss of hemifacial sweating (anhidrosis)

Question: A 24 year old lady presents with headaches for the past several days. On physical exam, all of the following could be seen in this patient with a cavernous sinus thrombosis EXCEPT
Explanation:
So cavernous sinus thrombosis was included in the Anatomy prac from Case 16, I didn't get it at first but it's actually quite systematic so here's how to break it down ...

 

  • First thing, need to know the CONTENTS of the cavernous sinus...
  • Internal Carotid
  • CN III, CNIV, CNV1, CNV2, CNVI
  • Look at the picture below (which also has a useful mnemonic) to visualise where this all is...

  • Now, how would this be put into a clinical scenario/why does it actually happen? >> Basically any infection (usually staph aureus) in the face or skull can spread to the cavernous sinus. The reason behind why it clots is to prevent the infection spreading further down the body. BUT the effect this has is that the contents are compressed HENCE why there are specific symptoms depending on what is being compressed
  • So if this was in an SBA I reckon they would put it into context by stating that the patient has had a recent infection e.g sinusitis, ear infection basically anything in the facial region (I'll put up another question after this one trying to put it in a clinical scenario)

 

  • So what are the specific symptoms? 
  • Firstly the classic triad is usually PERIORBITAL OEDEMA, HEADACHE, LOW GRADE FEVER (A/B not correct)
  • Then the rest of the symptoms correlate with the Cranial Nerves that are within the cavernous sinus....
  • Paralysis of extra-occular muscles CNIII, CNIV, CNVI (D/E not correct)
  • This now leaves CNV1, V2 so ophthalmic nerve and maxillary nerve distribution is affected (NOTE that V3 is spared b/c it is NOT in the carotid sheath hence C IS CORRECT

Question: Which one of these is not a feature of XXY syndrome?
Explanation:
XXY syndrome - Klinefelter's 

 

common features are

  • gynaecomastia 
  • infertility

Question: Which one of these is not associated with Pataus's?
Explanation:
Answer D: infertility is more associated with XXY klinefelters 

 

Patau - trisomy 13

  • most miscarriage still born 
  • severe developmental delays 
  • NTD's 
  • cleft palate

Question: Which of these facts is incorrect about Edwards Syndrome?
Explanation:
E: is incorrect

Question: A 24 year old lady comes in complaining of a headache she's had since yesterday. As you take a quick history she tells you she had an ear infection last week and suddenly proclaims she is seeing double of everything in the middle of the history. You check her vital signs which are as follows: Temp 38.4, HR 85, BP, 119. On physical examination, she has periorbital oedema and is unable to abduct her left eye when asked to look to the left. If her symptoms are due to the spreading of her ear infection, which other neurological sign are you most likely to see....
Explanation:
Scenario describes CAVERNOUS SINUS THROMBOSIS, I explained this in detail under a previous question so I will just copy and paste it below... 

 

 

So cavernous sinus thrombosis was included in the Anatomy prac from Case 16, I didn't get it at first but it's actually quite systematic so here's how to break it down ...

  • First thing, need to know the CONTENTS of the cavernous sinus...
  • Internal Carotid
  • CN III, CNIV, CNV1, CNV2, CNVI
  • Look at the picture below (which also has a useful mnemonic) to visualise where this all is...


Now, how would this be put into a clinical scenario/why does it actually happen? >> Basically any infection (usually staph aureus) in the face or skull can spread to the cavernous sinus. The reason behind why it clots is to prevent the infection spreading further down the body. BUT the effect this has is that the contents are compressed HENCE why there are specific symptoms depending on what is being compressed


So if this was in an SBA I reckon they would put it into context by stating that the patient has had a recent infection e.g sinusitis, ear infection basically anything in the facial region (I'll put up another question after this one trying to put it in a clinical scenario)

 

  • So what are the specific symptoms?
  • Firstly the classic triad is usually PERIORBITAL OEDEMA, HEADACHE, LOW GRADE FEVER (all of which included in the stem of the question)
  • Then the rest of the symptoms correlate with the Cranial Nerves that are within the cavernous sinus....
  • Paralysis of extra-occular muscles CNIII, CNIV, CNVI (hence why she is having diplopia and is unable to abduct her left eye)
  • This now leaves CNV1, V2 so ophthalmic nerve and maxillary nerve distribution is affected (THIS WOULD CORRELATE TO ANSWER D AS IS SUPPLIED BY V2)

A) HOARSE VOICE - recurrent laryngeal damage which is a branch of CNX vagus (not in cavernous sinus)

B) UNABLE TO SHRUG SHOULDERS - CNXI accessory damage which is not in cavernous sinus

C) DEVIATION OF TOUNGE - CNXII hypoglossal damage which again is not in CS

E) LOSS OF CHIN SENS - CNV3 mandibular branch damage which again NOT in CS

Question: Which of the following is not an indication to use irradiated blood products?
OptionC: Patient undergoing chemotherapy using a purine analogue (e.g. Fludarabine)
OptionD: Tranfusion is from someone that is not a close match.
OptionE: Is a bone marrow transplant donor or patient.
Explanation:
Why do we irradiate?

Donor WBCs can be recognised by the patients immune system as foreign material and this will set up an immune response against the WBC - Transfusion Associated Graft vs Host Disease. We irradiate the blood but the only constituent affected is the WBC because it is the only component that contains DNA. Healthy people would not produced Transfusion Associated Graft vs Host Disease but certain people do so require the blood to be irradiated.

 

Who needs irradiation?

  • Severely immunocompromised patients.
  • Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • Patient undergoing chemotherapy using a purine analogue (e.g. Fludarabine).
  • Patients who have received the donated blood from someone that is a very close match (family or same HLA)
  • Bone marrow donors/recipients.
  • Intrauterine tranfusions in foetal/neonatal immunodeficiency syndrome.

Irradiation is not good in an emergency as it delays transfusion.

Question:
A 32 year old male is brought to AE by his concerned fiance. She tells you he's been having a very bad headache for the past few days and has been acting abnormally and generally 'not been himself'. On examination he exhibits an altered mental status and vital signs are as follows: Temp 38.9, HR 110, BP 117/80. A lumbar puncture is carried out and these are the results....

 

CSF appearance -  clear

Opening pressure  - normal 

Polymorphonuclear cells  - normal

Lymphocytes  - high

Protein   -   normal

Glucose   - normal 

 

What is the most likely causative organism?
Explanation:
Patient Symptoms of...

Headache, fever PLUS cortical signs (mental status altered, personality changes) >>> indicative of ENCEPHALITIS - which is VIRAL in origin so don't really need the Lumbar puncture results really to work that out but I still included them to give a full clinical picture

 

CSF results confirm we have a viral infecttion = clear appearance, high lymphocytes

 

Technically could be HIV too but there is no clue to indicate this in the question so HSV1 is the best answer

Question:
A patient attends an oncology appointment following a colonoscopy which yielded a positive result for cancer. 

You have the pathology report which has the staging of their cancer. 

Fortunately, this patient has no metastases or lymph node involvement. You see that the pathology report has staged the cancer as T2 or Stage I, M0, N0. 

Which is the deepest layer of the intestinal wall that the tumour has invaded?
Explanation:
The Answer is D: muscular propria. 

 

The staging of colorectal cancer is as follows:

 

Stage 0/ Tis --> carcinoma in situ and confined to the mucosa 

Stage I/ T1 --> tumour invades the submucosa 

Stage I/ T2 --> tumour has invaded the muscularis propria


Stage IIa/ T3 --> tumour has invaded the subserosa

Stage IIb/ T4 --> tumour has invaded the visceral peritoneum 

Stage III/ T5 --> tumour  has directly attached itself to other organs. 

 

M = metastases, N = lymph node involvement. Both 0 as not involved.

Explanation: The rest belong to the SMA

Question: Mutations in which genes are associated with Lynch Syndrome?
Explanation:
The answer is A these genes encode DNA mismatch repair enzymes.

This is the pathophysiology of Lynch Syndrome. 

 

APC is associated with FAP - also associated with familial colorectal cancer BUT is of a different aetiology.

Question:
A 29 year old man who is HIV positive has been having a bad headache for the past few days. He is also feeling quite feverish and has started to experience neck stiffness. Your consultant asks you to interpret the following CSF analysis.

 

Appearance : yellow, viscous

Opening pressure: high 

Polymorphonuclear cells: slightly increased

Lymphocytes: markedly increased

Protein: Normal 

Glucose(compared to serum): normal 

 

What is the most likely causative organism?
Explanation:
HIV+ status should point you in the direction of the more rarer causes of meningitis (B, C, D)

 

B can be ruled out b/c CSF analysis would be typical of bacterial meningitis which the above is not 

 

This leaves TB and cryptoccus (both would cause a yellowish appearance to CSF and both would increase lymphocyte levels) >> the distinguishing factor is the protein and glucose > since TB is a bacterium then like normal bacterial meningitis it would increase protein levels and decrease the glucose the ratio BUT the above analysis shows that they're normal >>> CRYPTOCOCCAL MENINGITIS

Question:
A 84-year female patient who lives alone at home in a flat is admitted via emergency for removal of her appendix. 

A day post operation she is assessed by the F1 on the ward round - the F1 notes that this patient has significant oedema in her legs and ascites, and has failed to pass urine for the past 12 hours despite IV fluid therapy. 

He orders a full round of blood tests and they show that this patient has a low albumin level. 

You suspect that the patient had poor nutrition as she was underweight on admission.

 

What is your diagnosis?
Explanation:
The answer is A. 

The clue is in the patient history. This patient is an 84 year old woman who lives alone and was shown to have a very low weight on admittance (this is marasmus - metabolically stable, chronic reduced food intake) therefore she is likely malnourished. 

Following an emergency surgery, secondary to an acute infection of appendicitis this metabolically stable state of malnourishment has emerged into the metabolically unstable state of Kwashiorkor. 

 

The patient has symptoms of this - the low albumin (but this could be due to other reasons), urinary retention despite IV fluids (IV fluid use can sometimes precipitate this), significant oedema and a history of malnutrition.

Question: What are people with coeliac disease intolerant of?
Explanation: Celiac disease is an autoimmune disease of the small intestine It is caused by a reaction to gliadin- a gluten protein found in wheat. Upon expose to gliadin, the immune system causes atrophy of the villi which make up the brush border of the small intestine. This interferes with absorption in the small intestines and causes pale greasy stools, weight loss and inability to gain weight.

Question: A man presents to A&E with a suspected stroke. As you speak to him, he is having no trouble with speaking in full sentences but what he is saying makes no sense. Which artery is MOST LIKELY occluded?
Explanation:
• He is displaying WERNICKE'S APHASIA = fluent but incomprehensible speech 
  • Wernicke's area is found in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemispheres > this is suppled by MCA > since MOST people are left side dominant = occlusion is most likely to be Left MCA
  • Broca's area is found in the Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere > broca's aphasia = broken language, lack of fluency but still comprehensible >> also supplied by MCA usually again left b/c most people are left hemisphere dominant
  • BASICALLY both broca and wernicke = MCA = in most cases this will be left since most people are right-handed

Question: A 24 year old man has been rushed into A&E following a road traffic accident and has severe hemorrhage resulting in a large amount of blood loss. The patient has sustained an injury to his head and as a result will require neurosurgery. Before the surgery takes place the patient's platelet count is taken and he is found be thrombocytopaenic and hence requires a platelet transfusion. What platelet count would the patient most likely have had for this decision to have been made?
Explanation:
Normal platelet count is 150-400

 

Ordinarily you would only give platelets if your platelet count <50. This includes if you are about to go into surgery (except neuro).

 

If your platelet count is normally <10 you will be given routine platelets.

 

One exception is if you are about to go into neurosurgery where you will be given platelets if your count is <100.

 

1 adult dose of platelets contains 40-100 platelets.

Question: Which of the following best decribes the storage properties of platelets?
Explanation:
A = RBC, stores at low temps to prevent pathogenic infection

B = FFP, long shelf life because it is frozen

C = platelets, has to be stored near room temp so doesn't have a very long half life. Ideally would be used immediately/soon after donation to prevent clotting.

 

D&E are made up combinations.

Question: Which of the following channels are associated with LQT3
Explanation: INa channels are associated with LQT3

Question: Which of the following features best describes an arterial ulcer rather than  a venous one?
Explanation:
Arterial ulcers are non-pulsatile, as opposed to venous ulcers, which are.

B= Venous ulcers are often pink and granulating under green slough, whereas arterial ulcers are sloughly (green) or necrotic (black) WITHOUT granulation tissue.

C= Swelling is only a feature of VENOUS ulcers as opposed to arterial ulcers

D= Venous ulcers are WARM whereas arterial ones are relatively COLD

E= Lipodermatosclerosis (inflammation of subcutaneous fat that often occurs in patients who have venous insufficiency) is almost always present in VENOUS ulcers

 

I was reluctant to include pain in the options because even though arterial ulcers are VERY painful, patients with diabetic neuropathy do NOT experience the pain given the progressive destruction of axonal endings in the lower limbs owing to the hyperglycaemic state. But as a general rule, venous ulcers are relatively painless (only a third experience pain, and it is often described as MILD) whereas arterial ones are painful!

 

I got this information from Macleod's clinical examination 13th edition

Question: Which of the following pathogens is the most common cause of meningitis in the UK?
What type of vaccine is Haemophilus Influenzae type B?
Which of the following is the sugar added to the common precursor substance to produce the B antigen in the ABO blood system?
OptionE: No sugar is added for the B antigen.
Explanation:
The A antigen is produced by adding N-actyl D galactosamine (sugar) to the common precursor, this uses the enzyme A transferase. This enzyme is coded for by the A gene. This person will be blood group A and produce anti-B antibodies. 

 

The B antigen is produced by adding  D galactose (sugar) to the common precursor, this uses the enzyme B transferase. This enzyme is coded for by the B gene. This person will be blood group B and produce anti-A antibodies. 

 

If no sugar residue is added to the common precursor then the person's blood group is O. The O gene is an amorph so does not code for any transferases hence can not add a sugar group.

Question: Which of the following would be a presentation of an occlusion to posterior inferior cerebral artery?
OptionB: Ipsilateral loss of pain and sensation to the face and Horner's syndrome
OptionC: Dystonia, ataxia and loss of gag reflex
OptionD: Benign Positional Vertigo (BPV) and tendence to fall to the contralateral side
OptionE: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature with Horner's syndrome.
Explanation:
In Lateral Medullary Syndrome (Wallerberg), the PICA is affection

As PICA is a branch of posterior cerebral artery, most of the function of PCA will be affected

for example --> Contralateral loss of pain and temperature (carried by spinothalamic tract), Horner;s syndrome, and CN IX&X damage (resulting in dysphagia, hoarsness, and loss of gag reflex).

The other symptoms are

Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature of the face (carried by trigeminal nerve), ataxia (spinocerebellar tract), vertigo, diplopia (double vision) and tendency to fall to the ipsilateral side.

 

Hope this helps!

 

AW

Question: Which of the following arteries supply the ascending reticular activating system (ARAS)?
Explanation:
Paramedian penetrating arteries and circumferential branches of basilar artery supply the ARAS found in the brainstem.

Question: Damaged axons due to diffuse axonal injury are caused by high twisting forces that caused the excessive shear stress on the nerves. As a result, the nerves affected can be ruptured and release its contents. One of the neurones contents is highly excitotoxic to the cells in the CNS. What is it?
Explanation:
Despite being the main excitatory NT in the CNS, excess glutamate release (when neurones rupture) is excitotoxic [aka excited to death (Watson 2017)] to the CNS cells. 

 

AW

Question: Damaged axons due to diffuse axonal injury are caused by high twisting forces that caused the excessive shear stress on the nerves. As a result, the nerves affected can be ruptured and release its contents. One of the neurones contents is highly excitotoxic to the cells in the CNS. There are 2 particular receptors to this chemical. One is normally blocked by Mg2+ and can only be activated one the other receptor has been depolarised. What kind of receptor are we talking about?
Explanation:
NMDA is blocked by Mg2+ and can only be activated once AMPA has been depolarised. 

This channel (NMDA) are also linked with the further release of glutamate if Na+ and Ca2+ flowed into the channel the would result in further excitotoxicity of the CNS cells.

 

AW

Question:
Damaged axons due to diffuse axonal injury are caused by high twisting forces that caused the excessive shear stress on the nerves. As a result, the nerves affected can be ruptured and release its contents. One of the neurones contents is highly excitotoxic to the cells in the CNS. There are 2 particular receptors to this chemical. One is normally blocked by Mg2+ and can only be activated one the other receptor has been depolarised.

 

Given that the both the receptors has been activated, High Ca2+ released as a result of shear stress would lead to the activation of a specific type of proteases that breaks down the cytoskeleton. Which enzyme are we talking about?

A male, who is affected by Duchenne Muscular dystrophy, asks you what the outcome for his children would be with regards to carrying or presenting with Duchenne. His partner is not a carrier. What is your response?
OptionA: All daughters will be carriers, all sons will be unaffected.
OptionB: All daughters will have Duchennes. All sons will be carriers.
OptionC: Both sons and daughters will be carriers.
OptionD: Sons will present with Duchenne. Daughters will be carriers
OptionE: Sons will be carriers. Daugthers will not be affected.
Explanation: Duchenne's is an X linked recessive condition. Because the partner is not a carrier, the mothers X gametes will be normal, so no sons can have the gene for Duchenne's. All daughters will be carriers as they will all recieve a copy of the recessive x gene for Duchennes and a dominant X from the mother.

Question:
Case Group 39 Peer wise question.

 

A 5 year old boy with a mild trisomy goes to visit the speech and language therapist at an ENT clinic. Only a certain percentage of his cells present this trisomy. He had heart surgery before he was 5 months old to repair a septal defect. His IQ is in the normal range and his speech is improving quickly.

 

The medical student shadowing the speech therapist asks ‘what is the most likely mechanism for this genetic condition?’
OptionC: non disjunction during meiosis and trisomy rescue
OptionD: non disjunction during mitosis in embryonic development
Explanation:
Mosaic Down Syndrome has a highly variable phenotype. This affected boy has cells of both 46XY and 47XY+21 genotype hence his symptoms are milder than full trisomy. This can be caused in two ways:

1. non disjunction of chromosome 21 during meiosis which leads to the fertilised egg being trisomy 21. This is followed by trisomy rescue during embryonic development (when non disjunction leads to loss of the extra chromosome 21 in one cell line) leading to some cells being normal.

2. Normal fertilised egg but non disjunction during mitosis in embryonic development leads to trisomy 21 in some cells.

 

The most likely mechanism is option 2. Trisomy rescue is rare.

 

Balanced Translocation doesn’t cause Trisomy because two genes swap but no genetic material is lost or gained.

 

Robertsonian Translocation causing down syndrome occurs between chromosome 14 and 21. The two q arms fuse then a parent can carry this translocation. After fertilisation the zygote may have trisomy 21 ( 14,14/21,21,21). However this is NOT mosaic because all cells in the embryo are affected.

 

Non disjunction of chromosome 21 during meiosis leads to an extra chromosome 21 in the gamete then after fertilisation the zygote will have trisomy 21. This is the most common cause of Down Syndrome.

identify the genetic disorder shown by this karyotype.

Edwards

Trisomy 18

Multiple congenital malformations of many organs, low-set malformed ears, receding mandible, small eyes, mouth and nose with general elfin appearance, severe mental deficiency, congenital heart defects, horseshoe or double kidney, short sternum, posterior heel prominence

Patau

Trisomy 13

Severe mental deficiency, small eyes, cleft lip and/or palate, extra fingers and toes, cardiac anomalies, midline brain anomalies, genitourinary abnormalities

Turner

45,X

Female with retarded sexual development, usually sterile, short stature, webbing of skin in neck region, cardiovascular abnormalities, hearing impairment, normal intelligence

Klinefelter

47,XXY

Male, infertile with small testes, may have some breast development, tall, mild mental deficiency, long limbs, at risk for educational problems

Question:
Case 38:

 

You are on placement in Obstetrics and Gynecology and see the birth of a baby. The child has the following features : clenched hands with overlapping fingers, a shield chest and a cleft lip and palette.

 

The consultant requests a karyogram. Which of the following is the most likely result?
Explanation:
Edwards Syndrome is Trisomy 18. The characteristics described are common in babies with this Sydrome. 

 

Karyogram A is: Patau Syndrome

Karyogram B is: Klinefelter Syndrome

Karyogram C is: Downs Syndrome

Karyogram D is: Edwards Syndrome

Karygram E is: Healthy child

Question:
You see a pregnant woman who wants to have a screening test for Down Syndrome.

She is 26 years old, her BMI is 35 and is in her 2nd trimester.

What is most appropriate to do next?

Carry out:
OptionC: Chorionic villus sampling as soon as possible
Explanation:
Age: <35 so her age isn’t considered to increase her risk significantly

Obese: A BMI of 25 to 29.9 is considered overweight. A BMI of 30 or higher is considered obese - Combined test is more difficult in obese women

1st trimester: week 1 – 12

2nd trimester: week 13 – 28

3rd trimester: week 29 – 40

Screening tests: Quadruple 15-18 weeks & Combined 11-14 weeks

Diagnostic tests: CVS from 11 weeks & Amniocentesis from 15 weeks

Question:
A thirty nine year old pregnant woman visits her GP, worried about her baby having Down’s syndrome. She is not sure what Down’s syndrome is. Her doctor explains that it is usually caused by having an extra chromosome 21, however, it can also be caused by a Robertsonian translocation.

 

What is the most common chromosome on which this occurs?
Explanation:
Robertsonian translocations only happen with acrocentric chromosomes; 13, 14, 15, 21, 22. Acrocentric chromosomes have a centromere which is severely offset from the centre leading to one very long and one very short arm. For example, in chromosome 14 the ‘p’ arm is so short that little genetic information is carried on it.

In this case, the long arms of chromosomes 14 and 21 fuse to form a combined chromosome. The short arms are lost. This results in a gamete with both long arms of 14 and 21. This gamete, when fertilised, can survive to term.

A) 5 is associated with Cri du Chat

B) 13 is associated with Patau’s, the most common Robertsonian translocation

C) 14 is correct

D) Trisomy 18 results in Edward’s syndrome

E) 22 is acrocentric, therefore Robertsonian translocation is possible, also associated with mosaicism

Question:
Group 37:

 

A pregnant woman is returning to the antenatal clinic to receive results indicative of Trisomy 21. She is a 41-year-old woman with a BMI of 32.5.

 

What findings are most likely?
OptionD: Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A (decreased) + Beta-human Chorionic Gonadotropin (Increased)
Explanation:
(>3.5mm) Nuchal Translucency - Although this is an indicator of Trisomy 21, it cannot be measured here because she is obese.

 

Therefore a combined test cannot be offered which also excludes PAPP-A from the findings.

 

The appropriate test offered to obese women between 15-20 weeks would be the Quadruple test.

 

So answer A would be the most likely finding.

 

Combined Test findings for Down's Syndrome child

 

11-13 weeks

Nuchal Translucency, >3.5mm.

Beta-hCG increased

PAPP-A decreased

 

Quadruple Test Findings for Down's Syndrome child

15-20 weeks

Not offered to women with multiple pregnancies

Increased Beta-hCG

Decreased Alpha fetoprotein

Decreased Unconjugated Oestriol

Increased Inhibin A

Question: A new syndrome has had widespread devastating effects on a population. As the leading epidemiologist records that the incidence rate of the disease is 1 in 400 people, the genetics team try to identify what fraction of the population are carriers of the gene that has triggered this syndrome. Which of the following is the best guess of the carrier frequency of the disease?
Explanation:
p2+2pq+q2=1

Square root of 1/400 is 1/20 which equals q in the Hardy Weinberg Equilibrium Equation. Therefore p equals 19/20, as p + q must equal 1.

 

Therefore 2pq=carrier frequency=2 x 1/20 x19/20=19/200=0.095

 

If you used 1 as p instead, you get 2x1/20=2/20=1/10=0.1

Question: A young soldier is shot down in the battlefield and requires immediate blood transfusion to survive. You are only the only person with him and somehow have the equipment to make a transfusion. You are unaware of your blood type but know that the soldier wounded is a Universal Recipient. Which of the following is his most likely blood group, given this fact?
Explanation:
O - blood group is classified as universal donor.

AB + blood group is classified as universal donor.

Keep in mind that these terms are only generally true in the vast majority of donations.

Question: You want to give blood to a friend who has recently been involved in a car accident. You know that you have the only Blood type that your friend can receive. Which of the following blood group are you most likely to have?
Explanation: O- is the only blood type that can be given to a someone who is O-. This is because an immune reaction would occur in response to the Rhesus antigen if a positive blood group was given and if A, AB or B were given,  an immune reaction would also occur as someone with O blood has plasma antibodies for A and B.

Question:
Group 33. (case 8)

 

A 33 year old woman has spina bifida. She is at 36/40 and is filling out her birth plan and discussing analgesic options with her midwife. She has had a previous severe adverse reaction to an opiate alkaloid. What analgesic option is best in this scenario?
Explanation: As this lady has spina bifida, the two neuraxial options (an epidural or spinal) are not appropriate. Aspirin is an NSAID and these are not given during labour. Pethidine is an opiate, and she has previously reacted to an opiate, so entonox is the best option for her.

Question:
A 10 day old Trisomy 21 baby has been found to be born with a symptomatic patent ductus arteriosus. 

Clinicians are discussing the best method of pharmacological treatment.

Which drug would be best to prescribe?
Explanation: Prostaglandins keep the foetus' ductus arteriosus during pregnancy. After birth normally prostaglandins and prostaglandin receptors decrease in order to close the shunt. Failure to do this would keep the shunt open. Therefore treat with NSAIDs, as they stop prostaglandin production.

Question: Professor McGonagall visits the GP. Professor Flitwick and her are expecting a baby. The GP, Professor Snape, would like to give her the flu vaccine since winter is fast approaching and as we know it always snows at Hogwarts. What type of Vaccine would you give her and how would you administer it?
OptionE: Don't give her a vaccine, because she's pregnant
Explanation:
As Prof McGonagall is pregnant, she must not receive a LIVE vaccine. And so she cannot receive the muggle nasal spray (which is LIVE).

She can only have the INTRAMUSCULAR INJECTION as it is a killed vaccine.

 

Alternatively, Pg 706, Chptr. 54 in the Pocock Spell Book of Medical Wizardry (found in the restricted section) so that she can sort herself out. But tears of a phoenix are in short supply at the moment and so the vaccine might be an easier option.

Question: A 1-year-old male presents to his paediatrician for an assessment. Through a history from the mother and physical examination, the paediatrician learns that the baby babbles non-specifically, takes several steps independently, and picks up his cereal using two fingers. His weight is currently 10kg (birth-weight 2.7kg), and his height is 85 cm (birth length 45cm). Are there any aspects of this child's development that are delayed?
Explanation:
At one year of age, a child's expressive language skills should include use of at least one word, use of jargon, and repeating sounds to gain attention. As this child only exhibits non-specific 'babbling', he demonstrates a mild delay in expressive language skills.

 

 Common risk factors for language delay include male sex, poverty, family history of language delays, maternal depression, low birth weight, prematurity, and low parental education. 

 

At 1-year-of-age, a child should roughly triple his birth-weight and increase his height by 50%. 
 At 1-year-of-age, gross motor milestones include pulling to stand, walking while using furniture for support (cruising), and potentially taking a few unassisted steps. 
 At 1-year-of-age, fine motor milestones include using a pincer grasp, banging objects together, and placing objects in a container. T

Question:
You are called to see a 19-year-old male who is recovering from a tibial fracture suffered while playing rugby. His nurse states that he appears sleepy and is difficult to arouse. On physical exam, his vital signs are notable for

  • A Heart Rate of 60 bpm
  • Respiratory Rate of 6
  • Blood Pressure of 130/80 mm Hg,
  • A temperature of 37 C

His exam is also notable for pinpoint pupils and significant lethargy. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of the drug likely causing this patient's altered mental status?
Explanation:
Sleepiness, pupillary constriction, and respiratory depression are consistent with opioid toxicity, which was likely administered for pain control in this patient. Opiates cause neuron hyperpolarization due to potassium efflux.

 

The most likely drug given to this patient is morphine, a mu opioid agonist. Mu opioid receptors are G-protein coupled receptors that cause activation of potassium channels and lead to potassium efflux. The potassium efflux causes hyperpolarization (potential difference becomes more negative), and reduces the excitability of the neuron, thus decreasing pain transmission. Patients who are opioid naive-meaning they have not had opioids before- are more likely to experience the toxicities of opioid administration.
Tags: Acute Care, Pharmacology, Emergency Medicine, Respiratory Medicine, Case 8

Question: A 19-year-old Black female refugee  has been granted asylum in Stockholm, Sweden and has been living there for the past month. She arrived in Sweden with her 2-month-old infant, whom she exclusively breast feeds. Which of the following deficiencies is the infant most likely to develop?
Explanation:
Darker-skinned individuals who move from tropical climates exposed to high levels of sunlight to Northern latitudes are at risk of developing vitamin D deficiency. This especially relevant to their infants if they are being breast-fed.

 

The complete synthesis of vitamin D in the body first begins with 7-dehydrocholestrol in the skin.

  • Upon exposure to UV light, it is converted to cholecalciferol (D3).
  • This is then converted in the liver to 25-hydroxyvitamin D by 25-hydroxylase.
  • 25-hydroxyvitamin D is then converted to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, the active form of vitamin D, by 1-alpha-hydroxylase in the kidney.
  • Without sunlight, no active vitamin D can be produced.

 

Other sources of vitamin D, include ergocalciferol (D2), which can be converted to 25-hydroxyvitamin D by 25-hydroxylase in the liver. Darker-skinned individuals have higher levels of melanin in their skin which effectively acts like sunscreen and blocks UV light. Therefore, these individuals require sufficient light to produce vitamin D. If they do not receive adequate sunlight, they may develop vitamin D deficiency.

Question:
On a shift in Accident and Emergency, several arterial blood gasses are drawn from different patients at approximately the same time by a doctor. When preparing the tubes for transport to the labs, he accidentally mixes up the samples. One such sample had the following values:

  • pH 7.3 (normal range=7.35 to 7.45)
  • PaCO2 50mmHg (normal range= 4.7-6.0 kPa / 35-45 mmHg)
  • HCO3 25mmol/L (normal range 22-28 mmol/L)

Which of the following patients most likely had this result?
Explanation:
The values given represent an acute respiratory acidosis, which, of the options given, is most likely to be seen in an acute exacerbation of asthma.

 

Common causes of respiratory alkalosis include sepsis, PE, pain, anxiety, pregnancy, and salicylate intoxication.

Common causes of respiratory acidosis include exacerbations of COPD, severe exacerbation of asthma, and narcotic overdose.

In an cute asthma attack, there can be an evolution from a decreased PaCO2 in the initial presentation (hypoxemia-driver hyperventilation) followed by an increase in PaCO2 as the condition worsens.

Question: Two patients who have type 2 diabetes are hypoglycaemic and conscious. Mr Luke O'zade is given an oral load of glucose, whereas Miss Izzy Lynn is given an intravenous load of glucose (both given the same dose). Which route of administration will result in a greater insulin release?
OptionC: Both release the same amount of insulin
Explanation: Oral glucose will result in the greatest amount of insulin release due to the stimulation of two incretin hormones; GIP (gastric inhibitory peptide) and GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide). Both hormones are secreted by endocrine cells that are located in the epithelium of the small intestine. An increase of glucose in the lumen of the GI tract acts as a trigger for incretin release. Incretins are carried through the circulation to target tissues, one of which is pancreatic beta cells. Incretin stimulation of beta cells causes them to secrete MORE insulin in response to the same amount of glucose.

Question:
Patrick, a psychiatric nurse, is arrested under suspicion of having administered insulin to his wife, Berenice, who was admitted to hospital confused and semi-conscious. The doctors do a blood test to see if their suspicions are correct.

 

Which of these blood test results would confirm their suspicions?
Explanation:
Berenice is hypoglycaemic.

 

B is the correct answer because if insulin is released endogenously (ie from the endocrine pancreas), C-peptide will be present in high levels. As Patrick administered insulin exogenously (synthetic insulin), there are low levels of C-peptide.

 

Insulin is made from its precursor polypeptide, pro-insulin. C-peptide is a by-product of insulin production (this is cut out from the pro-insulin chain). C-peptide stands for 'connecting peptide'. Insulin and C-peptide are released into the blood stream by exocytosis. Measuring levels of C-peptide allows you to see whether the insulin in the blood stream is from an endogenous or an exogenous source.

Question:
A 53-year-old man comes to the GP complaining about chest pain, palpitations, dyspnoea and paresthesias. On examination the GP observes a depressed tendon reflex and some muscle weakness. The doctor orders a full blood count, dipstick urine test and an ECG.

 

What is the most probable diagnosis based on the ECG?
Explanation:
The ECG shows changes corresponding with Hyperkalaemia (at a serum potassium level of 6.5-8.0 mEq/L). The changes T wave changes are best seen in lead V3.

  • Most prominent change T wave peaked appearance with a greater amplitude and width than normal
  • Flattening of P wave
  • Prolongation of PR and QRS intervals

Management:

  • Calcium gluconate (doesn’t alter K+ but helps stabilise myocardium),
  • insulin and dextrose infusion,
  • calcium resonium,
  • iv fluids

Question:
A F1 junior doctor is stabbed in the back by Mr. Hunt. On assessment he appears to have lost motor function and proprioception on the left leg and is unable to feel temperature and pain on his right leg. 

what is the most probable diagnoses?
Explanation: Brown sequard presents with ipsilateral paralysis, proprioception and loss of contralateral pain and temp.

Question:
A 13 years old boy comes into A and E with Diabetic ketoacidosis. He is given Insulin and IV-fluid. After his pH comes back to normal, he becomes dizzy and faints. You perform an ECG which shows the following:

 

 

What is the most probable cause of this ECG abnormality?
Explanation:
In ketoacidosis, patient often present with high potassium levels in their blood. This comes from: the proton/potassium pump that pumps the excess H+ (as the patient is acidic) into the cell and potassium out of the cell, insulin usually activates NA+/K+ pumps which makes sure K+ present in the blood does not become too excessive and potassium follows water that goes out of the cell because of the glucose that is outside in the blood. This Means: High potassium in blood, low potassium in cell. The kidney try to excrete potassium but it is doing this at a low rate.  

When treated with insulin, Insulin directly activates the NA+/K+ pump and makes sugar and water and potassium (all following the other) go back inside the cell. This does not leave a lot of potassium in the blood. Further more, IV fluid dilutes the potassium and encourages urine production. This causes hypokaelemia. 

hypokaelemia can produce long QT syndrome in previously normal patient. Long QT syndrome can cause "Torsades de pointe" which is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

Question:
An 82 year old woman presents to her GP with a loss of coordination in her hands. Her husband is concerned that she keeps dropping things. She tells you that a few days ago she fell backwards over a washing basket.

 

You perform a basic neurological examination and find that her MRC power grade in her arms is a 4 and only a 2 in her hands. The examination for her lower limbs is normal.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: The answer is B, central cord syndrome. This is the most common kind of cord syndrome and is particularly seen in elderly people who fall and their head is thrown backwards. The hyperextension leads to narrowing and decreased blood supply to the middle of the spinal cord. The upper limbs are more affected than the lower limbs (due to the lamination of the spinal cord) and it is characterised by loss of motion and sensation in the arms and hands.

Question: A 12-year-old boy weighing 40kg is admitted to hospital for an emergency appendectomy. He must be given cefotaxime sodium (Claforan) 180 mg/ kg IM before his operation. The drug stock is 0.5 g/ml. How many millilitres will you give?
Explanation:
180 ml/kg needed, child weighs 40kg.

40x180= 7200mg needed for this patient

 

Stock solution is 0.5 g/ml

0.5 g/ml = 500 mg/ml

Patient requires 7200 mg

7200/500 = 14.4 ml required

 

 

Alternatively:

Stock solution is 0.5 g/ml

Patient requires 7.2 g

7.2/0.5 = 14.4 ml required

 

 

 

Extra information regarding this question:

Cefotaxime is an antibiotic used to treat gonorrhoea, meningitis, and severe infections including infections of the kidney (pyelonephritis) and urinary system. Also used before an operation to prevent infection after surgery.

Question:
A type 2 diabetic patient came to surgery on 1st of January suffering from NYHA stage 2 Heart failure. You therefore prescribed to him DRUG X. However, he came back on February the 1st, unhappy with DRUG X you prescribed for him. This medication, he says, provokes a continuous cough. You therefore prescribed DRUG Y. On March the 1st, the same patient comes back to you for regular checking and a note comes up on your screen stating that it was recently discovered that he developed renal artery stenosis bilaterally as his atherosclerosis developed. You therefore ask him to stop DRUG Y and make sure he does not come back to DRUG X as both are contra-indicated for bilateral renal artery stenosis. You therefore decide to put him on DRUG Z to make sure he still received appropriate vasodilation therapy. 

What could DRUG X, DRUG Y and DRUG Z be?
OptionA:
DRUG X: lorsatan

DRUG Y: perindopril

DRUG Z: Isosorbide mononitrate + hydrolazine
OptionD:
DRUG X: perindopril
DRUG Y: losartan
DRUG Z: Isosorbide mononitrate + hydrolazine
Explanation:
ACE inhibitors (e.g. perindopril) is a standart treatment for all Heart failure, it decreases Angiotensin II (vasoconstrictor -> reducing GFR) secretion and increase bradykinin production ( vasodilator -> increasing GFR). However, high levels of bradykinin can cause a persistent cough in some patients. This is why this patient was then put on an Angiotensin II receptor antagonist (ARA) (e.g. losartan) which does not affect the levels of bradykinin. 

However both, ACEI and ARA are contraindicated in bilateral renal stenosis. Why? Because BRS patients have a reduced flow because of the narrowing of the renal artery and therefore really need the action of Angiotensin II on the efferent arterioles to make sure the pressure is sufficient for the blood to pass inside the Bowman's capsule. Supressing Angiotensin II's effect would actually decrease the GFR because not enough pressure. 

To make it more clear, normally Angiotensin II consticts both the afferent and efferent arterioles. However, in BRS patients, it acts increasingly more on the efferent to keep some pressure. 

Finally, Isosorbide mononitrate decrease the preload by vasodilating the veins, and hydralazine decrease the afterload by vasodilating the afterload. These drugs are usually given in combinations and they improve the symptoms and mortality rates of HR patients.

Question:
You are on placement at an antenatal clinic and the doctor decides to quiz you on your knowledge of inheritance patterns. The following pedigree is shown:

 

Which inheritance pattern does this pedigree follow the most?
Explanation:
Process of elimination:

  • Cannot be Y-linked as there is no father-son transmission (so not C)
  • Unlikely to be autosomal recessive because in autosomal recessive, the condition usually skips generations. The parents are also usually asymptomatic rather than having the condition themselves (so not E)
  • Unlikely to be X-linked recessive as it is usually males who are affected with this inheritance pattern. Females are usually carriers and asymptomatic. Although the pedigree shows that none of the fathers pass on the condition to their sons, the other aspects of the pedigree mentioned earlier suggest this isn't an X-linked recessive pattern (so not A)
  • Autosomal dominant is highly unlikely due to the fact that all children are affected in the second generation. In an autosomal dominant condition you would expect around 50% of offspring to be symptomatic (so not B)
  • CORRECT ANSWER therefore is mitochondrial inheritance (D). The pedigree clearly shows affected mothers passing on the condition to all of their offspring. This is because only egg cells contribute mitochondria to the developing embryo- so only the mother can pass on this information.

Question:
You are on elective in nepal. A family brings a young child to your out reach clinic who has been generally unwell with a cough and flu like symptoms. The child also has a large swelling to the right cheek and neck. 

The consultant suggests it is a viral infection with potentially very serious complications. You have not seen a viral infection like this in the uk, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is classical mumps presentation of flu like symptoms and PAROTITIS (inflammations of the parotid salivary gland). The complications may include meningitis or hearing loss. Unfortunately there are no effective antiviral medications. 

 

Measles would present with flue like symptoms, high grade fever, red koplik spots followed by a brown maculopapular rash. Measles complications are Meningitis, SSPE and pneumonia. 

 

Rubella would present with flu and a rash but a fainter rash with less coalese (mass of papules). Also swollen and tender lymph nodes are a diagnostic feature. Rubella infection is a worry during pregnancy because of the risk of congenital rubella syndrome. 

 

Whopping cough is caused by a bordella pertussis bacterium. Initially presents with a a cold and cough for a few weeks but can be followed by serious fits, vomiting and exhaustion. Complications include pneumonia and encephalopathy. There has recently been a rise in the incidence of this disease. 

 

Sinusitis is a mild viral infection and very common in the uk.

Question:
You’re a GP and Mr Chaos, a 55 year old male, has come to see you saying that he feels very breathless and that his heart feels ‘funny’. He tells you that this started last night and has continued this morning. On further questioning, he tells you that this has happened before, around 2 months ago. You record an ECG and these are his results…

 

 

You refer him to a cardiologist. He questions Mr Chaos further and finds out he’s never had any other medical problems in the past. He has a blood pressure of 125/80 mmHg. Which treatment plan is the cardiologist most likely to choose?
OptionA: Prescribe him Bisoprolol to be taken if needed and Rivaroxaban
OptionB: Prescribe him Flecainide to be taken if needed and consider him for ablation
OptionC: Prescribe him Flecainide to be taken if needed, Rivaroxaban and consider him for ablation
OptionD: Prescribe him Digoxin to be taken if needed
OptionE: Prescribe him Amiodarone to be taken if needed, Warfarin and consider him for ablation
Explanation:
• Mr Chaos is showing symptoms of paroxysmal AF
  • In this case, treatment to control the rhythm is preferred over attempting to control the rate
  • Rate control is preferred when the patient has permanent AF (you would consider giving them beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin etc)
  • To control rhythm in AF – sodium channel blockers and and potassium channel blockers are preferred (these would be prescribed to be taken when needed - aka when Mr Chaos is symptomatic)
  • To control the rhythm: → Ectopic triggers are often found in the pulmonary veins → So a treatment option can be ablating these with radiofrequency and cryothermal energy → This is usually a consideration for someone with paroxysmal rather than permanent AF
  • Mr Chaos scores 0 on CHADSVASC so doesn’t require oral coagulation (so you wouldn’t give him Rivaroxaban or Warfarin)
  • Rivaorxaban is a NOAC (new oral anticoagulant)
  • Flecainide is a Na-channel blocker
  • Bisoprolol is a beta-blocker
  • Amiodarone is a K-channel blocker (this would be considered for rhythm control in Mr Chaos’ case – however (E) is wrong because Mr Chaos doesn’t need warfarin)

I got this information from a mixture of Kumar & Clarke as well as Dr William's lecture and other sources.

Case 13.

 

Mr Chaos.... chaotic baseline

Question: A man marries his female cousin, and they have 3 children together. Two of their children have cystic fibrosis and the other child is not affected. Neither the mother or father express symptoms of cystic fibrosis themselves. They would like to have another child and ask you, the genetic counsellor, if they were to have an unaffected child, what is the chance of he/she being a carrier for cystic fibrosis?
Explanation:
Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder. 

 

In autosomal recessive disorders:

  • Usually only one generation affected
  • Parents are both asymptomatic carriers
  • Often childhood onset conditions
  • Common in consanguineous families
  • Males AND females affected

Therefore, the parents in this scenario, although asymptomatic of cystic fibrosis, MUST be carriers for the disease because of the two children diagnosed with CF. 

 

The question asks, if they were to have an unaffected child, what is the chance of them being a carrier. We can see from the above picture, the chance of having an unaffected child is 3/4, and of that 3, 1 is unaffected and 2 are carriers. Therefore, the answer is 2/3 or 67%.

Question:
Your friend, Barry, tells you a very interesting fact; "oi mate, did you know that the prevalence of phenylketonuria (PKU) is 1 in 10,000 live births?"

 

You are taken back by this, and proceed to sit by the window sill staring at the stars wondering what the carrier frequency for PKU is? The constellations come together to tell you that the answer is..
Explanation:
Using the Hardy-Weingberg equation of:

 

p² + 2pq + q² = 1 and (p + q) = 1

 

where p² = frequency of unaffected individuals

2pq = carrier frequency

q² = frequency of affected individuals

 

If the prevalence of PKU is 1 in 10,000, we can say that q² = 1/10,000

q is therefore the square root, which is 1/100.

If p + q = 1, p = 1 - 1/100 = 99/100

 

Carrier frequency = 2(1/100)(99/100) = 99/5000 or 0.0198

Question: Julie Davies, a 26 year old woman, has just given birth to a baby boy. Julie's blood type is AB Rh negative, and her baby's blood type is AB Rh positive. In order to prevent haemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) in her next child, what can Julie be given?
OptionA: Anti-D can be given within 72h after childbirth
OptionB: Anti-D can be given anytime to the mother within the next year
OptionC: Anti-D can be given to the mother when she decides to conceive again
OptionD: Pertussis vaccine is given to mother within 72h after childbirth
OptionE: Oxytocin is given to help speed up the afterbirth
Explanation:
The most common problem with Rh incompatibility, haemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), may arise during pregnancy which at its worst can result in stillbirth. Immune anti-D antibodies are IgG and can therefore cross the placenta. If a small amount of Rh+ blood leaks from the foetus through the placenta into the bloodstream of an Rh- mother, the mother will start to make anti-Rh antibodies. Because the greatest possibility of foetal blood leakage into the maternal circulation occurs at delivery, the first-born baby usually is not affected. If the mother becomes pregnant again, however, her anti-Rh antibodies can cross the placenta and enter the bloodstream of the foetus. If the foetus is Rh-, there is no problem, however if the foetus is Rh+, agglutination and haemolysis brought on by foetal-maternal incompatibility may occur in foetal blood.

 

An injection of anti-Rh antibodies called anti-D can be given to prevent HDN within 72h after childbirth. All Rh- women should receive this soon after every delivery, miscarriage or abortion. These antibodies bind to and inactivate foetal Rh antigens before the mother's immune system can respond to the foreign antigens by producing her own anti-Rh antibodies. 

 

B and C are incorrect due to the delay in time, mother would have made her own antibodies by then.

C is incorrect, pertussis (whooping cough) vaccination, usually given in 28-32 weeks of pregnancy.

Oxytocin is incorrect as it has no relation to what's in question.

Question:
You are a pathologist looking at samples from a number of different colonoscopies. 

 

Which of the patients below are most likely to develop colorectal cancer?
Explanation:
Ademonas are polyps showing a degree of dysplasia and can develop into adenocarcinomas

 

Villous adenomas have a higher risk of developing into CRC. 

Adenomas >1cm have a higher risk of developing in CRC. 

Risk of colorectal cancer also increases with age.
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI

Question: You are the on-call doctor in A&E when you see a 25 year old patient, Rhodri Davies, who has come in with his mother. His mother tells you that Rhodri's behaviour has recently changed, as well as his intellectuality. You ask about Rhodri's past medical history, and his mother tells you that she had elected not to give Rhodri the MMR vaccine, and as a result, he was infected with measles roughly around 7 years ago. You decide to perform a GALS assessment on Rhodri and find that he has an unsteady gait and muscle twitching. Taking his previous medical history into account, what do you diagnose Rhodri with?
Explanation:
Rhodri has presented with a classical case of late infection due to the previous measles infection. Anyone who has suffered from the measles virus and recovered, there will be a defective virus leftover, which can later in life, result in slow degeneration of CNS known as subacute sclerosing panencephalitis.

 

SSPE is a rare complication of measles that results in symptoms such as:

  • Bizarre behaviour
  • Dementia (loss of mental, emotional, and social abilities)
  • Coma
  • Gradual behavioural changes
  • Myoclonic jerking (quick muscle jerking or spasms)
  • School problems
  • Seizures
  • Unsteady gait
  • Very tense muscles or muscles that lack tone, with weakness in both legs

SSPE tends to occur several years after an individual has measles, even though the person seems to have fully recovered from the illness. Males are more often affected than females. The disease generally occurs in children and adolescents. The condition is usually fatal.

Question: A patient, who was diagnosed with Crohn's disease a year ago, begins to notice her symptoms are worsening. At the same time, she notices red lumps on her shin. What are these called?
Explanation:
All the answers are complications of IBD.

 

Complications related to disease activity (so if the disease is flaring up these are flaring up):

  • Peripheral arthritis (D)
  • Skin lesions- erythema nodosum (C and correct answer, these are more common in Crohn's) and pyoderma gangrenosum (E, these are painful ulcers on the skin and are more common in UC)
  • Episcleritis (B)
  • Mouth lesions- apthous ulcers (A), angular chelitis and lip swelling. These are all more common in Crohn's

Complications unrelated to disease activity:

  • Central arthritis- ankylosing spondylitis and sacro-ilitis. These are associated with HLA-B27.
  • Type 2 arthropathy- type of arthritis affecting more that 5 small joints.
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis- affecting bile duct.
  • Anterior uveitis- inflammation of anterior uvea of eye, associated with HLA-B27.
Tags: Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Lower GI

Question: The results of Mrs Baker's Left Ventricular pressure volume test are as follows, which of the following conditions does this suggest about her heart?
Explanation:
Diastolic Heart Failure is Correct, all the others are causes of/are Systolic Heart Failure. 

 

Overall the curve represents Inotropy by the top End Systolic Function curved line and Compliance by the curved bottom End Diastolic volume line. As Inotropy decreases (Systolic heart failure) the gradient of the top line will reduce so the curve will appear to squash downwards. As compliance decreases (Diastolic Heart Failure) the gradient of the bottom curved line will increase (move upwards) so the curve again will squash. 

 

For the same volume value on the Red Line (End Diastolic Volume line) there is increased pressure- this is because there is diastolic failure so the heart is not relaxing properly therefore has more pressure in diastole. Hence in Diastolic Heart failure there is a shift in gradient of the red End Diastolic Function line. Whereas the gradient of the End Systolic Line stays the same, there is just a shift down the curve. 

 

 

Systolic Dysfunction would present as:

With an altered gradient for the curved End Systolic Volume line.

Question: You are a GP on a normal day of clinics when you are visited by a 35 year old lady, Mrs Allen. She tells you that a week ago she had a dental implant procedure, and since then has had problems with chewing her food properly. She also tells you that she can't feel anything when she touches her skin around her chin. You decide to perform a cranial examination on this patient, and when you ask the patient to open her mouth, you see a clear sign of pathology. What is the nerve most likely to have been affected in Mrs Allen?
Explanation:
Whilst B is also correct, D is the single best answer. 

 

The patient is presenting with damage to the Mandibular (V3) portion of the Trigeminal (V) nerve.

Name: Mandibular (V3) portion or Trigeminal Nerve (V)

Type: Mixed 

Function: 

  • General sensation of anterior 2/3 of the tongue, mandibular face and teeth.
  • Motor innervation to muscles of mastication (temporalis masseter, medial and lateral pterygoids) and anterior belly of digastric, mylohyioid, tensor tympani, and tensor palati.

Results of damage:

  • Loss of general sensation in skin over mandible, mandibular teeth, tongue and weakness in chewing.
  • Jaw deviation toward weak side (due to the unopposing action of the pterygoid muscle)
  • Some people may present with trigeminal neuralgia where there is intractable pain in the V2 (maxillary) or V3 (mandibular) territory.

Question:
A patient has presented at your practice with unusually tanned skin, and muscle weakness. They complain of feeling constantly exhausted and a persistently low mood, and express concern about a loss of weight. 

 

With a differential diagnosis in mind you decide to run a few investigations, which of the following test results are most likely to be observed.
Explanation: Addisons disease is characterised by low sodium, high potassium, low AM cortisol as this when cortisol is naturally at is peak in the day, high ACTH and low aldosterone.

Question: You are the on-call doctor in A&E, when ambulance brings in a 47 year old patient, Thomas Bennet, after falling down marble stairs and banging his head 5 hours ago. The patient complains of an intractable headache and you can see his head is tilted and his breathing is deteriorating. You perform an MRI scan, confirming your suspicions of an intracranial haemorrhage, but you also notice a change in brain tissue. Given the results of the MRI scan and his symptoms, what cerebral herniation has occurred in Mr Bennet?
Explanation:
The answer is C. The MRI shows a downward displacement (aka coning) of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This can lead to compression of the medulla, resulting in respiratory depression and eventually, cardiorespiratory arrest. The most common signs are intractable headache, head tilt, and neck stiffness due to tonsillar impaction. The level of consciousness may decrease and also give rise to flaccid paralysis.

 

A. Subfalcine herniation: this occurs when the cingualate gyrus is displaced under the falx and to the opposite side. It can result in the compression of the anterior cerebral artery.

B. Transtentorial (Uncal) herniation: this occurs when the uncinate process of the temporal lobe herniates into the anterior part of the opening of the tentorium cerebelli.

D. Central tentorial herniation: this occurs when there is symmetrical downward movement of the thalamic region through the opening of tentorium cerebelli.

E. Transcalvarial herniation: aka external herniation, this occurs when there is downward displacement of the brain through a defect in the skull such as a fracture site or following a craniectomy.

 

http://lifeinthefastlane.com/ccc/brain-herniation/ has a good diagram of the herniations and simple explanations!

Question:
Jack, a 25 year male is carried against his will to A&E complaining of severe headache, neck stiffness,fever and increased sensitivity to light over the past few weeks. He is referred for a lumbar puncture to collect CSF for testing. His results are back and shown below:

 

Glucose: 60mg/dL (Norm 45-100 mg/dL)

Neutrophils: <20%

Lymphocytes: >50%

Protein: 70mg/dL (Norm 15-50 mg/dL)

 

 His CSF is cloudy and viscous in appearance and during the lumbar puncture, a very high opening pressure of 45 cm H20 is observed. 

 

Jack has meningitis. Judging from his results, what is the most likely culprit of his infection?
Explanation: His results are indicative of fungal meningits, which is chronic, hence his experience of these symptoms over the past few weeks.

Question:
A 63-year-old woman suffers a distal left anterior cerebral artery stroke. She presents to you with motor function loss affecting a certain part of the body.

 

Which part of the body is most likely affected?
Explanation:
The part of the brain that controls the motor function of the legs is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.

The portion of the brain controlling motor function of the rest of the body is supplied by the middle cerebral artery.

The only possible answers are D and E.

Since the tracts cross in the brainstem, the left side of the brain controls the right side of the body.

An exception to this rule is the motor function of the face, since the tracts do not cross. The left motor function of the face comes from the left hemisphere.

Question: Sara, a newly pregnant woman attends the midwife clinic and has a blood sample taken to determine her blood type. The sample of patient red cells was mixed with Anti-A and Anti-B serums. The results showed agglutination with both serums. The plasma of the patient sample was then mixed with type A and type B blood. There was no agglutination observed. After determining her ABO type, you went on test her Rhesus system. When the red cells were mixed with Anti-D serum, there was no agglutination seen. What blood type is the woman?
Explanation:
The woman is AB-.

The first step of blood typing is ABO typing. The RBCs of the blood sample are mixed with antibodies against type A and type B blood and the sample is observed for agglutination (sticking/clumping together). If the cells do agglutinate, it means that the blood reacted with one of the antibodies:

  • If it agglutinates with anti-A serum, you have type A blood
  • If it agglutinates with anti-B serum, you have type B blood  
  • If it agglutinates with both anti-A and anti-B serums, you have type AB blood (as in this case)

The second stage is called back typing. The serum of the patient's blood is mixed with blood that is known to be type A and type B:

  • If the blood agglutinates only when B cells are added to the sample, the blood type is A  
  • If the blood agglutinates only when A cells are added to the sample, the blood type is B  
  • If the blood agglutinates when either types are added, the blood type is O
  • A lack of agglutination indicates AB blood (as in this case)

The Rhesus typing classifies blood as Rh positive or Rh negative based on the presence of Rh antibodies in the blood:  

  • If blood agglutinates when mixed with anti-Rh serum, blood type is Rh positive  
  • If blood doesn't agglutinate when mixed with anti-Rh serum, blood type is Rh negative (as in this case) - this is because the blood doesn't contain D antigen, so does not clump with anti-D antibodies

Question: You have joined Emily Lloyd for the afternoon. She is running a baking workshop after her heart cake became C21 famous. You ask Emily if she has remembered to bring the recipe with her to which she replies - "I do not need to write it down, it's all up here in my head. All you need is 500g butter, 250 g brown demerara sugar, 2 eggs and 3 tablespoons of cocoa powder". This is an example of what type of memory?
Explanation:
Mary is recalling specific facts and figures about how to make chocolate brownies in her memory and this is therefore an example of semantic memory.

Long term memories can be either declarative (memory with conscious recall) or non-declarative (memory without conscious recall.) Semantic and episodic memory are examples of declarative memory whilst procedural and classically conditioned memories are examples of non-declarative memory.

Implicit memory is synonymous for non declarative memory.
Semantic memory - recalling facts and figures.
Episodic memory - recalling on personal experiences.
Procedural memory - motor skills and habits e.g. brushing teeth.
Classically Conditioned memory - phobias

Case 6 - Andrew Lawrence Lecture

Question:
During placement, you're asked to give a baby an antibiotic suspension for a chest infection.
He weighs 15kg and has been prescribed a dose of 7.5mg/kg/day for 7 days. It is given as 3 injections a day, and the strength of the suspension is 250mg in 5mL.
What dosage should you put on the medicine label?
Explanation:
The individual dose needed is (15 x 7.5)mg / 3 = 37.5mg

The strength is 250mg in 5mL, which could also be thought of as 25mg in 0.5mL (simply divided by 10)

37.5mg can be divided into 25mg and 12.5mg to make it easier to 'split up' the solutions, i.e. the dose is 0.5mL (containing 25mg) and 0.25mL (containing 12.5mg):
0.5mL + 0.25mL = 7.5mL

Alternatively, once you have worked out the strength and individual dose, you could use:
(5 x 37.5) / 250 = 0.75
I've done this by cross multiplying (250/5) = (37.5/X)

Question: You are a medical student on placement in A&E. A 12 year old girl presents with vomiting, polydipsia, polyuria and pear-drop smelling breath. You suspect that this patient has diabetic ketoacidosis. You think back to your biochemistry lectures and try to remember the three main ketone bodies produced from fatty acids, which are..
Explanation:
During states of insulin deficiency (diabetes), lipolysis of triglycerides at the adipose tissue (stimulated by hormone sensitive lipase - normally inhibited by insulin) provides a huge fatty acid load to the liver. 

 

Once inside the mitochondria of the hepatocytes, the free fatty acids undergo beta-oxidation where the enzyme fatty acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (aka LCAD or MCAD) converts fatty acyl-coA into acetyl-CoA. During this conversion, one molecule each of NADH and FADH2 is formed, both of which enter the electron transport chain to form ATP (2 from FADH2 and 3 from NADH). Therefore, we can say that 5 molecules of ATP are generated in beta-oxidation.

 

In the liver mitochondria, acetyl-CoA has 2 pathways it can go into:

1) Under normal conditions, the acetyl-CoA would enter the Krebs cycle to get more ATP.

 

2) However, in states of starvation, it does no enter the Krebs cycle, as it must condense with oxaloacetate to make citrate. However, there is no oxaloacetate in the liver mitochondria when starving. This is because in starvation, oxaloacetate exits the mitochondria, goes into the cytoplasm and enters the gluconeogenesis pathway instead. Therefore, acetyl-CoA accumulates because it can't enter the Krebs cycle, and there it is all channeled into ketone body formation.

 

The acetyl-CoA, still in the mitochondrial matrix of the liver, is converted to HMG-CoA by HMG-CoA synthase, which is then converted to acetoacetate (1/3), under the action of HMG-CoA lyase.

 

Acetoacetate is inherently unstable, therefore the body puts an electron from NAD onto it to form B-hydroxybutyrate (2/3) (aka 3-hydroxybutyrate). 

 

What can also happen to the unstable acetoacetate, a carboxyl group can be removed from the molecule, therefore decarboxylating it, to form acetone (3/3).

 

Therefore, the three ketone bodies that move from the hepatocytes to the blood are; acetoacetate, B-hydroxybutyrate and acetone (note that acetone cannot be used as a fuel, it is diagnostically used by its distinct pear-drop smell).

 

All of the acetoacetate and B-hydroxybutyrate enter the extrahepatic cells from the blood (mainly muscle, renal cortex and brain in prolonged fasting). The B-hydroxybutyrate is reconverted BACK to acetoacetate by removing an electron to form NADH.

 

The acetoacetate is then activated by an enzyme called Thiophorase (which is not found in the liver), to form acetoacetyl-CoA. This molecule is then cleaved in the mitochondria to form 2 molecules of acetyl CoA, which then condenses with oxaloacetate to form citrate → Krebs cycle → generates ATP.

 

TLDR; ketones are made from fatty acids.

Question: A 70 year old man with Parkinson's disease comes into your surgery with his wife. She tells you that she is very worried as her husband has recently been telling her that ‘the government has been spying on him’ and that he can ‘hear ‘them' talking about him through the radio’. What is the most likely cause of these recent symptoms?
OptionA: Due to his age, he has started showing signs of Dementia
OptionB: He has accidentally taken too much of his medication for Parkinson's Disease
OptionC: His uncle had Schizophrenia and has subsequently inherited certain genes causing these Schizophrenic symptoms
OptionD: The decreased dopamine due to his Parkinson's has resulted in 'negative' schizophrenic symptoms
Explanation:
The answer is most likely to be B, as he has taken too much of his L-Dopa Parkinson's medication and the increased dopamine in his system has therefore resulted in positive schizophrenic symptoms. 

 

In normal physiology, Tyrosine (from the diet) is hydroxylated via a rate limiting step to form L-DOPA.

In DOPAMINERGIC neurones cytoplasmic L-DOPA → converts via AADC enzyme  (l-aromatic amino acid decarboxylase) to → DOPAMINE.

 

POSITIVE symptoms in Schizophrenia/ psychosis are due to changes in mesolimbic pathway from VTA to Nucleus Accumbens, amygdala and hippocampus – OVER ACTIVITY of D2 receptors

 

• NEGATIVE symptoms → UNDER ACTIVITY in mesocortical pathway – under activity of D1 receptors

 

Therefore, an ADR of L-DOPA for Parkinson's is POSITIVE schizophrenic symptoms or hallucinations, as you are increasing the amount of Dopamine and increased dopamine correlates with positive symptoms in schizophrenic symptoms.

 

D is incorrect as the symptoms stated in the question are of a positive nature (hallucinations an delusions) not a negative nature (avolition, anhedonia).

E is unlikely as you do not usually experience psychotic symptoms with normal cognitive decline or ageing
A and C could potentially be correct as he may have e.g. Lewy Body dementia, however no memory loss has been stated in the question.
Overall B would be the single best answer here

 

Information taken from Neuropharmacology - Lecture 1

Question:
Ellie presents to the doctor at 14 weeks pregnant. She was not planning to fall pregnant and is slightly worried that she has not been aware of her pregnancy up until now.

You run some blood tests, and find that her mean cell volume (MCV) is at 120fl (normal is up to 105fl in pregnancy). This, in conjunction with some other tests, suggests that she has a certain type of anaemia.

With this in mind, what are you most worried about for the newborn?
OptionE: You are not concerned about any problems
Explanation:
She has megaloblastic anaemia, caused by a deficiency of folate. This is a fairly common anaemia in pregnancy because folate requirements are raised to 300-400μg/day from 100μg/day. The diet is often inadequate to meet this demand, and so folate supplements are routinely given in pregnancy.

As she has presented late, the patient has not been taking folate supplements. Folate deficiency has been linked with an increased incidence of neural tube defects in the foetus, and so it has been recommended that folate supplementation starts prior to conception and then taken particularly in the first 12 weeks of gestation.

Therefore, you would be worried about neural tube defects as her clinician.

Source - case 8 lecture on haemotology in pregnancy
Tags: Nutrition, Pregnancy, Blood Results, Haematology, Case 8
