Question: A 60-year-old man who was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago presents with altered sensation in his hands and feet. He has difficulty discriminating between different coins. When walking, the floor feels different and tend to lose balance when walking up stairs. The most likely diagnosis is:
Explanation:
A) Autonomic neuropathy symptoms include:
• Cardiovascular System - Dizziness just after standing, Fainting just after standing, Irregular heart rate
• Digestive System - Bloating, Constipation, Diarrhea, Nausea, Vomiting
• Eyes - Vision trouble at night or during sudden light changes (e.g., when stepping into a dark building from the sunlight)
• Reproductive System - Sexual problems—erectile dysfunction in men; vaginal dryness in women
• Sweat Glands - Profuse sweating, especially at night or when eating particular foods (cheese commonly causes excessive sweating, for example, although that’s not true for every person with diabetic neuropathy). Reduced sweating, especially in the legs and feet
• Urinary System - Bladder dysfunction
• People with autonomic neuropathy may also have trouble figuring out when their blood sugar level is too low—which is particularly dangerous for people with diabetes. This is called “hypoglycemia unawareness,” and it occurs when the normal responses to low blood sugar (sweating, shakiness, etc.) don’t kick in because of nerve damage.

 

B) Diabetic amyotrophy involves weakness followed by wasting of muscles, and excruciating pain in the muscles of the shoulders, thigh, hip, and buttocks. The typical symptoms are fairly sudden onset and usually occur on one side of the body but may involve both sides. The weakness sometimes involves in thigh and leg, so patients have difficulty getting out of chairs and often require a cane or crutches. They also have diminishing knee reflex

 

C) Acute painful neuropathy
• Burning pain in feet, shins and anterior thigh, often worse at night.
• Often abrupt onset and can resolve completely

 

D) Symmetrical sensory polyneuropathy
• Affect hand and feet in ‘glove and stocking’ distribution
• Loss of vibration, pain and temperature sensation
• Later, loss of proprioception and balance

 

E) Multiple mononeuropathy
• External pressure or entrapment - eg, carpal tunnel syndrome.
• Isolated neuropathies of either the cranial or peripheral nerves. Mononeuropathies of cranial nerves III, IV and VI, intercostal nerves and femoral nerves are common.

Question: Which of the following is NOT a sign/symptom of raised intracranial pressure?
Explanation:
Raised ICP results in bradycardia.

 

This is part of cushing's triad

  • Bradycardia
  • Hypertension
  • Abnormal breathing

Question: Trevor is prescribed  Candersartan to help treat his hypertension having not responded well to Ramipril. You are a medical student on placement and the prescribing doctor quizzes you on the mechanism of Candersartan. Panicked, you think back to Dr Coffey's case 15 lecture... what do you say?
OptionA: Candersatan prevents the conversion of Angiotensin I -> Angiotensin II
OptionB: Candersatan limits sympathetic activity by reducing the slope of phase 4 potential and reducing Ca2+ entry into the myocytes.
OptionC: Candersatan inhibits the Na+-K+-ATPase in cardiac myocytes which in turn 'flips' the Na+-Ca2+ transporter; it traffics Ca2+ into the cell and Na+ out of it, increasing the amount of Ca2+ in the myocyte and thus force of contraction (positive iontoropy).
OptionD: Candersatan is highly selective for AT1R and can shift the balance of receptors Angiotensin II bind to, binding to AT2R receptors instead
OptionE: Candersatan acts on the thick ascending limb where it inhibits the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter (specifically the Cl- transporter component). This causes water in the blood to move into the highly concentrated urine.
Explanation:
A -  ACE inhibitor, e.g Ramipril 

B - Beta-adrenoceptor antagonist (beta-blocker), e.g Bisprolol

C - Digoxin 

D - Correct answer: Candersatan is an example of an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker. ARBs are used if patients do not respond well to ACE inhibitors.

E - Diuretic, specifically Furosemide acts on thick ascending limb.

Question: An 18 year old lad, Ryan Yates, has visited your GP surgery complaining of stomach pain, diarrhoea and vomiting for the last 2 weeks. He recently went on a lads holiday to Thailand and ate out most nights. You suspect he is infected with Helicobacter pylori, and so you send off a stool sample to the lab for testing. When the test comes back positive, you start him on a one week treatment of a PPI and 2 antibiotics, to take twice daily. What is the site of action of a proton pump inhibitor?
OptionA: H+/K+ - ATPase pump found on the parietal cell
OptionB: H+/Na+ - ATPase pump found on the G cell
OptionC: H+/Na+ - ATPase pump found on the parietal cell
OptionD: H+/K+ - ATPase pump found on the G cell
OptionE: H+/Cl- - ATPase pump found on the parietal cell
Explanation:
A is the correct answer. 

 

 

There are three natural substances that stimulate parietal cells:

  1. ACh, acting as a transmitter - neural stimulation
  2. Locally released histamine - paracrine stimulation
  3. Hormone, gastrin - hormonal stimulation

This explains why PPIs work much better than histamine as they block the effects of all 3 above, whereas H2 receptor blockers only intercept 1/3 of the 3 above.

Question: 75 year old Ben Matthews is a care home resident and has attended A&E complaining of diarrhoea, fever and abdominal cramps. He tells you that he has been taking an antibiotic, clindamycin,  for 2 weeks now for a persisting ear infection. You suspect this patient has pseudomembranous colitis. What is the most likely infectious agent causing his symptoms?
Explanation:
The answer is A, clostridium difficile.

 

Pseudomembranous colitis, aka as antibiotic-associated colitis, is an acute colitis characterised by the formation of inflammatory pseudomembranes in the intestines. The organism responsible is Clostridium difficile, which creates a pseudo membrane on the surface mucosa of the colon, preventing it from reabsorbing water, thus leading to the diarrhoea. The elderly, hospitalised patients and those on antibiotics are at greatest risk of disease C diff colonisation, this is because the antibiotics kill the normal flora of the gut, allowing C diff to grow. The rates can vary on the patient population, 3% ‘normal’ healthy adults, 7-30% care home residents and 20% elderly pts on long term wards.

 

C diff is spread through faecal-oral transmission, and so for those in healthcare professions soap and water is recommended for hand washing when seeing C diff patients as C diff spores can stick to alcogel and actually be spread between patients in this manner.

 

Case 11, Microbiology of the GI tract plenary.

Question: Ella Norbury, a 26 year old lady, attends your morning GP clinic. She is currently in the third trimester of her pregnancy and is complaining of itchiness around her anus, as well as pain during bowel movements. She has noticed spotting of blood on her underwear after going to the toilet, and yesterday saw bright red blood on the toilet paper. What is your most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Haemorrhoids occur when the external haemorrhoidal veins become varicose (enlarged and swollen), which causes itching, burning, painful swellings at the anus, dyschezia (painful bowel movements), and bleeding. Pain with bowel movements and bleeding are often the first signs of haemorrhoids.

 

Risk factors include:

  • Constipation and prolonged straining during bowel movements
  • Weight lifting
  • Pregnancy (as uterus enlarges, it can press on the vena cava thus decreasing the venous return - why pregnant ladies are advised to lay of their left side, to stay off the vena cava). It has been estimated that 25% to 35% of pregnant women are affected by this condition. In certain populations, up to 85% of pregnancies are affected by hemorrhoids in the third trimester.
  • Cirrhosis - causes portal hypertension decreasing venous return
  • Morbid obesity - due to the increased abdominal pressure

Question: Myofibrils are made from three kinds of proteins, contractile, regulatory and structural. In relaxed muscle, myosin-binding site on actin is blocking by tropomyosin. These tropomyosin strands are help in place by which molecule?
Explanation:
Myofibrils are made from 3 kinds of proteins:

  1. Contractile proteins - generating force during contraction
  2. Regulatory proteins - help switch contraction process on and off, and;
  3. Structural proteins - keep thick and thin filaments in proper alignment, give myofibril elasticity and extensibility, and link myofibrils to sarcolemma and ECM.

The 2 contractile proteins are ACTIN (thin filament) and MYOSIN (thick filament)

 

Myosin functions as the motor protein, it pushes and pulls various certain structures to achieve movement. It's tail points towards the M line, the centre of the sarcomere. And the myosin heads resemble two golf clubs twisted together.

 

Actin is anchored to the Z discs. Individual actin molecules join to form an actin filament twisted into a helix. On each actin molecule is a myosin-binding site, where the myosin head attaches. Smaller amounts of 2 regulatory proteins - tropomyosin and troponin - are also part of the thin filament.

 

In relaxed muscle, the myosin-binding site is blocked by tropomyosin acting on actin. Tropomyosin strands held in place by T-troponin molecule.

 

  1. At the onset of contraction, an action potential passes through the T-tubules causing Ca2+ to enter the cardiomyocte through L-type voltage gated Ca2+ channels in the sarcolemma.
  2. This Ca2+ then activates the Ryanodine receptors on the SR, causing it to release Ca2+ (Ca2+-induced-Ca2+-release - CICR) into the cytosol. There, Ca2+ binds to C-troponin, causing a conformational change, with a dissociation of I-troponin from actin, allowing tropomyosin to move from the myosin-binding site. 

 

Once the binding sites are free, the contraction cycle begins.

 

As the contraction ends, intracellular calcium returns to the SR via the SERCA calcium channels. (Note, I made up the last two options - not sure if they exist!)

Question:
Yograj presents to a+e with abdominal pain.

 

He tells you that at first the pain was diffuse and described it as aching

 

However, he informs you that now the pain is more sharp and localized to an area in the lower right area of his abdomen

 

What is the innervation of the peritoneum layers?
Explanation:
In this example, Yograj had appendicitis.

 

At first the inflammation just affected the visceral peritoneum which is innervated by C nociceptive fibres hence the aching, more diffuse pain

Later the inflammation affected the parietal peritoneum as well, which is innervated by A delta fibres hence the sharper, more localised pain (McBurney's point 1/3 of the way between the ASIS and the umbilicus)

Question:
You are the on-call doctor at A&E, when you see Linda McCartney, a 56 year old lady who describes experiencing the sudden onset of palpitations whilst cleaning at 10:30am that morning. She stated that the palpitations came on without warning and had not gone away after she ceased cleaning to lie down – they were ‘regular and extremely fast’. There were no associated symptoms of shortness of breath, dizziness or chest pain. Five hours later, upon her presentation to the Emergency Department, the rapid heart rate is still continuing. You perform some tests, and confirm that Linda has AVNRT.

 

You think back to the pathophysiology behind this form of supraventricular tachyarrhythima, which of the following is correct in regards to AVNRT?
OptionA: It involves a functional reentry circuit within the AVN, involving a slow (α) pathway and a fast (β) pathway
OptionB: It involves a functional reentry circuit within the AVN, involving a slow (α) pathway and a fast (γ) pathway
OptionC: It involves an anatomical reentry circuit with the AVN, involving a slow (α) pathway and a fast (β) pathway
OptionD: It involves an anatomical reentry circuit within the AVN, involving a slow (α) pathway and a fast (γ) pathway
OptionE: It involves an anatomical reentry circuit within the AVN, involving a slow (β) pathway and a fast (α) pathway
Explanation:
The correct answer is A.

 

AVNRT is typically paroxysmal and may occur spontaneously in patients or upon provocation with exertion, coffee, tea or alcohol. It is more common in women than men (~75% of cases occurring in women) and may occur in young and healthy patients as well as those suffering chronic heart disease. Patients will typically complain of the sudden onset of rapid, regular palpitations. The patient may experience a brief fall in blood pressure causing presyncope or occasionally syncope.

 

An ECG for AVNRT will be rapid, but have normal QRS complexes, followed immediately by P waves (this is because the atria are excited in a retrograde manner, and the reentrant circuit is show). The amplitude of the QRS complex increases on alternate beats. 

 

 

AVNRT involves a functional reentry circuit in or around the AV node, in which there are 2 pathways:

  1. Slow pathway (α): slow conducting and short refractory
  2. Fast pathway (β): fast conduction and long refractory

To briefly explain how a functional reentry circuit occurs:

 

In normal sinus rhythm, an impulse entering and passing through the AV node will pass through a fast (β) pathway and a slow (α) pathway. As the fast pathway is rapidly conduction, the impulse travelling through it will exit the AVN to the ventricles, and will also move around to the distal part of the slow pathway meeting its impulse, and they will both cancel each other out.

 

However, in AVNRT, as the fast pathway is still in the absolute refractory period (remember ARP is longer in the fast pathway than slow), an ectopic impulse arrives in the AVN and can pass through the slow pathway because it's refractory is over, but cannot pass through the fast pathway. By the time this impulse in the slow pathway reaches the end of the AVN, the refractory period of the fast pathway is over, and so it can enter the fast pathway distally and the impulse can go round and round in an AVN reentry circuit.

Question: You are the on-call A&E doctor, when you get a call from a GP who is worried about his patient, Dan Thomas, and you tell him to send the patient over. Once Dan arrives, you establish that he is a 53 year old man with a history of hypertension. He presents with palpitations, fatigue, mild dyspnoea and presyncope. You perform an ECG on Dan and below are his scan results, what do you diagnose?
Explanation:
The answer is B, Atrial Flutter with 2:1 block.

 

Atrial flutter is a type of supraventricular tachycardia caused by a re-entry circuit within the right atrium. The length of the re-entry circuit corresponds to the size of the right atrium, resulting in a fairly predictable atrial rate of around 300 bpm (range 200-400). 

 

Ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio (“degree of AV block”). The commonest AV ratio is 2:1, resulting in a ventricular rate of ~150 bpm. Higher-degree AV blocks can occur — usually due to medications or underlying heart disease — resulting in lower rates of ventricular conduction, e.g. 3:1 (~100 bpm) or 4:1 (~75 bpm) block.

 

Recognising what type of block this is from an ECG scan is by looking at how many flutter waves there are between each QRS/beat. As you can see in the above picture, there are 3, so this would be atrial flutter with a 3:1. Whereas in the ECG scan for Dan, there are 2 flutter waves between each QRS, therefore his was atrial flutter with 2:1 block.

 

Other points to make about the ECG for atrial flutter:

  • Narrow complex tachycardia
  • Regular atrial activity at ~300 bpm
  • Flutter waves (“saw-tooth” pattern) best seen in leads II, III, aVF — may be more easily spotted by turning the ECG upside down!
  • Flutter waves in V1 may resemble P waves
  • Loss of the isoelectric baseline

The most common form of typical atrial flutter is the anticlockwise reentry (90%), where the impulse runs anticlockwise around the atrium (usually the right) which stimulates the AV node every time it passes it. 

 

 

Clockwise reentry is uncommon.

Question: Holly, a 65yo woman, arrives at A and E with an ECG taken on the way in the ambulance. The ECG shows broad QRS complexes with evidence of a single foci in the ventricles. Which diagnosis is most likely?
Explanation:
Broad QRS complexes with evidence of a single foci in the ventricles is most suggestive of Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia. This is usually due to a stable re-entry pathway due to injury such as a scar from a previous MI that allows impulses to reach the ventricles causing mini electrical circuits. 

 

In General Broad Complex Tachycardia's have a broad QRS complex and should be assumed to be VT unless proven otherwise. Other causes include accessory pathways, especially antidromic ones (impulses go down the accessory pathway and up via the normal bundle to the AVN). 

 

Monomorphic VT presents as follows:

 

 

Polymorphic VT presents as follows:

- It is due to multiple ectopic foci and usually presents as a waveform such as that for TdP. TdP is associated with long QT syndrome which can be triggered by a  number of causes including anaesthetics, antihistamines, TCAs and antibiotics. One of the common iatrogenic causes of LQTS is amiodarone as this K+ channel blocking drug prolongs the effective refractory period and so prolongs QT interval- it can lead to TdP in those who already have LQTS. 

Ventricular Fibrillation presents as follows:

- It is a lethal state where ventricle contraction rate can reach 500bpm and so no blood is delivered to the body. It required immediate defibrillation. - - Defibrillation differs from cardioversion as it is one high energy shock that is given at a random time within the cardiac cycle rather than the cardioversion shock delivered at the peak of the QRS complex.

Question:
Gaby, 21 goes to her GP complaining of hip pain. She thinks she's overdone it with the pigeon pose in her Bikram yoga class. The GP asks about her diet. She's a vegan (reasons include: healthiness, compassion, sustainability and instagram). On examination of the hip, the joint is tender to touch.  

Gaby has her bloods taken: FBC, Thyroid function test, Bone profile. The key observations are:

  • PTH- high
  • Ca- low
  • PO4- low

 

Gaby is then sent for an x ray:

 

 

What is her most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Gaby's vegan diet has lead her to have vitamin D deficiency. 

 

Vitamin D deficiency can lead to insufficient calcium and phosphate absorption. This means new osteoid cannot be mineralised, causing bones to be softer and more pliable thus more prone to deformation. It is called osteomalacia in adults and Rickets in children. Osteomalacia may lead to osteoporosis. 

 

Typical bloods of osteomalacia patient:

  • Low PO4 and Ca
  • High/normal ALP
  • High/normal PTH

On x-ray:

  • diffuse demineralization: osteoporotic-like pattern
  • may show a characteristic smudgy "erased" or "fuzzy" type of demineralization
  • insufficiency fractures
  • pseudofractures (looser zones)

Causes of vitamin D deficiency:

  • Reduced sunlight
  • Inadequate diet
  • Malabsorption
  • Medication- rifampicin, phenytoin
  • Abnormal Vit D Metabolism- liver or renal disease
  • Hypophosphataemia

Treatment:

  • Oral D2/D3 e.g. calcichew
  • Stop being a vegan and eat oily fish & eggs

 

B- osteopaenia would be determined by DEXA scan

C- osteoporosis would be determined by DEXA scan

D- Primary hyperparathyroidism would have:

  • High/normal Ca
  • Low/normal PO4
  • High/normal ALP
  • High PTH

E- Primary hypoparathyroidism- PTH is high so cannot be hypo

 

If you want to nail the pigeon pose:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0_zPqA65Nok

Question:
The initial phase (extrinsic pathway) of coagulation, is initiated by the exposure of ______ in the subendothelial matrix (collagen), which binds to factor ___ in plasma.This complex then activates factor X → Xa (and IX → IXa in the intrinsic pathway). When tethered to platelets via phospholipid, factor Xa then converts ______ to _______.

 

Fill in the gaps.
Explanation:
Fibrin monomers are cleaved from fibrinogen by the protease thrombin, a key component in clotting. Activation of thrombin involves sequential conversion of proenzymes to active enzymes (e.g. factor X → factor Xa) in a coagulation cascade.

 

EXTRINSIC PATHWAY: 

  • This is initiated by the exposure of tissue factor (TF; thromboplastin) in the subendothelial matrix (collagen), which binds to factor VIIa in plasma, to form a TF:VIIa complex.

 

COMMON PATHWAY: 

  • The Tf:VIIa complex activates factor X → Xa (and factor IX → IXa in the intrinsic pathway).
  • When tethered to platelets via phospholipid, factor Xa converts prothrombin (II) to thrombin (IIa).

 

This initial phase of coagulation aka extrinsic pathway produces comparatively little thrombin. However, it initiates the amplification phase (intrinsic pathway), because thrombin activates factors XI, VIII, V and more platelets. 

 

(Note that Ca2+ is required for activation of factors X, XIII and prothrombin (II) - Ca2+ chelators e.g. citrate/EDTA can therefore be used to prevent clotting in stored blood)

Question: 57 year old, Michael Davis, is about to be discharged from hospital following a myocardial infarction. You, as his doctor, inform Michael that you will be adding aspirin to his repeat prescriptions. Michael tells you he is a retired pharmacist and would like a reminder of the mechanism of action of aspirin, to which you reply..
OptionA: Aspirin is an antiplatelet drug which irreversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting prostaglandin-I2 from platelets.
OptionB: Aspirin is an anticoagulant drug which irreversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting prostaglandin-I2 from platelets
OptionC: Aspirin is an antiplatelet drug which irreversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting thromboxane A2 synthesis from platelets
OptionD: Aspirin is an antiplatelet drug which reversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting thromboxane A2 synthesis from platelets
OptionE: Aspirin is an anticoagulant drug which irreversibly inhibits COX therefore inhibiting thromboxane A2 synthesis from platelets
Explanation:
Aspirin is an antiplatelet drug used as a preventative measure for arterial (white, platelet-rich) thrombi.

 

Risk factors for arterial thrombosis include:

  • Endothelial/endocardial damage:
  1. Atherosclerotic plaque/rupture
  2. MI
  3. Valve disease
  4. Atherosclerosis
  5. Hypertension
  6. Catheters

Aspirin is a unique drug in that it irreversibly inhibits COX, the first enzyme in sequence leading to formation of TXA2 and PGI2. (It is worth noting that aspirin irreversibly inhibits the COX-1 domain more specifically than the COX-2 domain). 

 

Thromboxane A2 is produced by platelets and is a key platelet activator, aggregator and vasoconstrictor. Whereas, PGI2 is endothelium derived, it promotes vasodilation, inhibits platelet activation and aggregation by increase cAMP.

 

Due to aspirin's irreversible inhibition, production of TXA2 can only recommence once a NEW COX enzyme has been made. This is because platelets have no nuclei and therefore cannot generate their own COX enzyme, therefore the levels of TXA2 remain low until new platelets are formed (takes about 2-3 days). However, as PGI2 is endothelium derived, these cells have nuclei and are able to make new COX within hours, allowing the level of PGI2 to remain high.

 

Therefore aspirin = sustained ↑ in PGI2:TXA2 ratio BLOCKS platelet activation and aggregation.

Side effects of aspirin: GI problems (PGs protective effect of GI tract removed) and haemorrhage.

Under 16 + aspirin = Reye's syndrome

 

Perhaps to just briefly go through physiology of the arachidonic acid cascade:

 

Arachidonic acid is cleaved off the cell membrane by enzyme phospholipase A2. It can then undergo 2 major pathways:

  1. The first is the less important one, where the enzyme lipoxygenase converts the arachidonic acid into leukotrienes.
  • Leukotriene receptors have roles in bronchoconstriction, vascular permeability and chemotaxis. Montelukast, a treatment for asthma, is a leukotriene receptor antagonist.

     2.  The next, and more important pathway, involves an enzyme called cyclooxygenase (COX) (also known as PGHS enzyme).

  • There are two isoforms of this enzyme, COX-1 and COX-2.
  • COX-1 is constitutive, and synthesised at a constant rate, whereas COX-2 is induced and therefore not always there.
  • COX-1 = required for maintenance of healthy gastric tissues, renal homeostasis and platelet aggregation.
  • COX-2 = required for inflammation, pain, heat and swelling (PGD and PGE).
  • The COX enzymes convert arachidonic acid into endoperoxides, PGG2 which is formed on the COX demain, and PGH2 which is formed in the peroxidase domain. PGG2 and PGH2 can then be modified into prostanoids.

This reaction occurring in platelets can lead to the production of thromboxane A2.

This reaction occurring in the endothelium of blood vessels results in the production of prostacyclin PGI2.

 


The PGH2 can also be converted into prostaglandins which are more stable, such as PGD2, PGE2, and PGF2. 

  • PGE2 - histamine, bradykinin, eosinophil, chemotaxis, vasodilation, used to induce labour.
  • PGF2 - bronchoconstrictor, uterine contraction
  • PGD2 - bronchoconstrictor, anti-platelet aggregation.

A lot of this was in Coffey's lecture last year in case 1 :)

 

(Thank you to the person who pointed out I had the wrong answer selected!)

Question:
Picture this: you are a second year medical student who, after a top night of boozy antics in the lash, is running late for placement. You rush onto the gastroenterology ward to find your placment group and see that they are shadowing the consultant on the ward round. You manage to slip into the group without being noticed. Phew! looks like you're off the hook.

 

But wait! The consultant decides to ask you "Which drug should we give this patient to maintain their remission?" In a panic, you steal a quick glance at the patient's notes and manage to see that they are a non-smoker with a recent episode of diffuse mucosal inflammation of the rectum, but before you can see more the consultant quickly covers the notes to stop you cheating. "Well? What's your answer then?" he says.

 

Which of the following is your best bet to get in the consultants good books and avoid his impending wrath?
Explanation:
The patient is most likely suffering from ulcerative colitis, since they had diffuse mucosal inflammation of the rectum (CD would present with patchy transmural inflammation). Drugs used in maintenance of remission of UC are:

  • Mesalazine (an aminosalycylate)
  • Azathioprine (an immunosuppressant)

So therefore the correct answer was E

 

As for the other drugs:

  • Antibiotics are given for active CD
  • Anti-TNF drugs are given for severe active CD or UC and maintenance of remission in CD
  • Corticosteroids are given for active CD and severe active UC
  • Diuretics are not routinely given in cases of IBD
Tags: Pharmacology, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question: Whilst on placement during your endocrinology case, you meet Geoff, a 43 year old man who comes to see his GP complaining of a recent loss of appetite and growing feelings of weakness. He also tells the GP that he has had some unintended weight loss recently. Upon examination, the GP notices that Geoff has hyperpigmentation of his palmar creases. Which of the following sets of lab findings would you expect to see in Geoff's case?
Explanation:
Geoff has Addison's disease caused by primary adrenocortical insufficiency, typically characterised by:

  • Progressive weakness
  • Non-specific complaints (loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, weight loss)
  • Hyperpigmentation of palmar creases
  • Hyperkalaemia and hyponatraemia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypoglycaemia
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Adrenal crisis (if severe)

In Addison's the typical lab finding is low cortisol with high ACTH (the high ACTH is what causes the hyperpigmentation, since ACTH and MSH are both produced fromthe same precursor molecule)

 

Therefore the answer is C

 

A represents Cushing's with a secondary pituitary cause

B represents Cushing's with a primary adrenal cause

D represents Secondary hypoadrenlism (would shown similar symptoms but no hyperpigmentation)

 

See lecture on the endocrine system in case 10 for more info

Question: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive disease. In the US the disease affects 1 in 10 000. Roughly, what is the carrier frequency?
Explanation:
We can calculate this using the Hardy Weinberg Equilibrium: p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1

  • p is the frequency of the dominant allelle
  • q is the frequency of the recessive allelle
  • p + q =1

 

p2  = frequency of homozygous dominant (AA)

2pq = frequency of heterozygous (Aa)

q2 = frequency of homozygous recessive (aa)

Question: Anaemia is usually defined as a decrease in the amount of red blood cells (RBCs) or haemoglobin in the blood. Therefore, from this we can say that anaemia decreases the viscosity of blood. What effect will this then have on the resistance of the vessel and the flow of blood respectively?
OptionA: Decreases resistance and increases the flow of blood
OptionB: Increases resistance and increases the flow of blood
OptionC: Decreases resistance and has no effect on the flow of blood
OptionD: No effect on resistance and increases the flow of blood
OptionE: Increases resistance and decreases the flow of blood
Explanation:
(Apologies for making a haemodynamics question!)

 

Poiseuille's Law states that there is a relationship between flow, pressure and resistance. The equation can be applied to a single vessel, organ or an entire circuit.

 

Q = △P/R 

Where;

Q = flow

△P = change in pressure/pressure difference

R = resistance

 

Therefore, if △P remained constant, we could say that Q is inversely proportional to R. So, any increase in flow would DECREASE resistance of a vessel.

 

Resistance of a vessel is determined by 3 major variables

 

R = vL/r^4

Where;

v = viscosity (higher the viscosity, thicker the liquid i.e. honey has a higher viscosity than water)

L = length of vessel

r = radius of vessel

 

Using this equation, and assuming all other variables remain constant, we can say that

  • Resistance is proportional to velocity
  • Resistance is proportional to length of vessel
  • Resistance is inversely proportional to radius^4

Therefore if we put all the equations together.. We said earlier that Q is inversely proportional to R. And we just said above that R is proportional to v.

 

(Let's pretend that this ∝ is the proportional to symbol)

 

So; Q 1/∝ R ∝ V

 

So therefore a decrease in viscosity, as is in anaemia would also decrease resistance of the blood vessel, but increase the flow of blood.

 

How do those with anaemia compensate? They increase their Cardiac Output.

 

CO = MAP / TPR .. Because their total peripheral resistance decreases, their CO increases to compensate (also increasing stroke volume and heart rate as          CO = SV x HR)

 

The opposite would be in polycythaemia where there is an abnormally high concentration of Hb in the blood, either through decreased plasma volume or increase in RBCs. This would increase the viscosity = increase in resistance = decrease in flow.

Question:
Oedipus, a young man, was travelling to the great city of Thebes. Before he could cross the wall into the city a great Sphinx blocked his path. The sphinx said "Tell me which of the below options act as an muscarinic Ach antagonist leading to dilation of the pupil? Answer incorrectly and I shall eat you." 

What should Oedipus say to avoid being eaten?
Explanation:
Dilators

Tropicamide - muscarinic Ach antagonist, stops Ach binding to M3 thus stopping contraction of the cillary muscles causing dilation. Used in eye exams and its effects last around 4-8 hours.

Phenlephrine - Activates Alpha 1 receptor leading to relaxation.

Cocaine - Stops the uptake of of Na. Na normally activates Beta 2 receptors leading to relaxation. Hence less uptake, cuaes more Na leading to more relaxation.

 

Contractors

Pilocarpine - Acts as a muscarinic Ach agonist on the M3 receptor. Causes pupil constriction. Used to treat dry mouth and glaucoma.

 

Anaesthetic

Tetracaine - prevents the release of IC Ca2+

Question:
You are a 2nd year medical student on placement at a GP surgery. One of the patients has kindly agreed to come in so you and the other students can practice an abdominal examination on him. When palpating the abdominal aorta, you are sure you can feel a large expansile pulsation rather than pulsatile. You tell the GP this, and she checks herself, and agrees that it is expansile. She auscultates the patients abdominal aorta and remarks that there is a bruit. She sends him to A&E immediately, suspected an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

 

Once everyone has recovered from the drama, the GP asks you why the aorta is predisposed to an aneurysm more than any other vessel in the body?
OptionA: Because the aorta is the longest artery in the body
OptionB: Because the aorta is the artery with the greatest wall tension
OptionC: Because the aorta is the most susceptible to damage from trauma
OptionD: Because coarctation of the aorta can lead to an aneurysm
OptionE: Because the aorta is the vessel with the greatest cross-sectional area
Explanation:
(Again, sorry for a haemodynamics question!)

 

LaPlace's Law states that in a cylindrical vessel

 

T is directly proportional to P r

Where T = wall tension, P = pressure, r = radius.

 

The aorta is the artery with the greatest wall tension (therefore greatest pressure and radius - in a person who is lying down). 

What is wall tension? Think of blowing up a balloon, as you increase the radius the wall tension also increases, and eventually it bursts.

 

Therefore if the radius, wall tension and pressure increase, eventually this will lead to an aneurysm.

Because the aneurysm has a great radius, its wall tension will be greater than that of surrounding normal vessel segments. 

 

If the vessel enlarges, wall tension increases and the vessel is more likely to burst, leading to a dissecting aneurysm which is a medical emergency.

 

Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs) are more common than their thoracic counterpart. One reason for this is that elastin, the principal load-bearing protein present in the wall of the aorta, is reduced in the abdominal aorta as compared to the thoracic aorta. Another is that the abdominal aorta does not possess vasa vasorum, the nutrient-supplying blood vessels within the wall of the aorta. Most AAA are true aneurysms that involve all three layers (tunica intima, tunica media and tunica adventitia). The prevalence of AAAs increases with age, with an average age of 65–70 at the time of diagnosis. AAAs have been attributed to atherosclerosis, though other factors are involved in their formation.

 

Before rupture, an AAA may present as a large, expansile mass above the umbilicus. A bruit may be heard from the turbulent flow in the aneurysm. Unfortunately, however, rupture may be the first hint of AAA. Once an aneurysm has ruptured, it presents with classic symptoms of abdominal pain which is severe, constant, and radiating to the back.

Question: Orthostatic hypertension occurs when a person moves from lying to standing; causing blood to pool in the veins, and therefore less blood returns to the heart. This decreases cardiac output and so, blood pressure decreases also. How does the body respond to this situation?
OptionA:
↑ afferent activity to the medulla

↓ parasympathetic activity

↑ sympathetic activity

↓ heart rate
OptionB:
↓ afferent activity to the medulla

↑ parasympathetic activity

↓ sympathetic activity

↓ heart rate
OptionC:
↑ afferent activity to the medulla

↑ parasympathetic activity

↓ sympathetic activity

↑ heart rate
OptionD:
↑ afferent activity to the medulla

↑ parasympathetic activity

↓ sympathetic activity

↓ heart rate
OptionE:
↓ afferent activity to the medulla

↓ parasympathetic activity

↑ sympathetic activity

↑ heart rate
Explanation:
The correct answer is E.

 

Baroreceptor reflex is responsible for the short-term regulation of blood pressure. These receptors are constantly monitoring the blood pressure and sending messages to the medulla. There are baroreceptors located in the;

  • Carotid sinus; at the bifurcation of the external and internal carotid sinuses. Baroreceptors located here fire impulses via its afferent fibres of CN IX to the nucleus tractus solitarus (NTS) in the medulla. 
  • Aortic arch; the baroreceptors here fire impulses via its afferent fibres of CN X to the nucleus tractus solitarus in the medulla.

 

Firing to the medulla via these afferent fibres stimulates the parasympathetic activity of the medulla which acts to decrease heart rate.

 

If there is no firing to the medulla, then sympathetic activity takes over which increases heart rate, increases the total peripheral resistance of arterioles, and promotes venous constriction.

 

Therefore to put it simply;

Firing to medulla = decreases blood pressure

No firing to medulla = increases blood pressure

 

If unable to prevent a change in MABP within several hours, the reflex will reset to maintain pressure are the new level. 

 

Keeping these 2 equations in mind: MAP = CO x TPR and CO = SV x HR, we can see how the MAP is controlled in 2 ways:

  1. Autonomic Nervous System

Parasympathetic - via M2 receptors in the heart, will decrease the HR (↓ BP)

Sympathetic - B1 adrenoceptors increase heart rate, increase stroke volume (by its stimulation of renin), and A1 receptors increase TPR as it causes vasoconstriction (↑ BP)

 

     2. Hormones

 

Angiotensin II - increases TPR by constricting vessels, increases aldosterone which increases Na+ and H2O retention therefore increasing preload, and increasing stroke volume (↑ BP)

ADH - facilitates retention of water, therefore increases plasma volume, increases preload, increases stroke volume (↑ BP)

ANP - produced by the right atrium, causes Na+ loss therefore decreases stroke volume (↓ BP)

 

If MAP = CO x TPR , if a person has low blood pressure (as is in the scenario), what can the medulla do?

 

  •  ↑ CO by ↑ HR (via the sympathetic B1) and inhibiting parasympathetic (via m2 receptors)
  •  ↑ TPR by stimulating a1 receptors

Question:
As an avid procrastinator, you decide to search the 'BBC Good Food' website (whilst you still can) for some recipes to rustle up. You come across some fantastic recipes from TV chefs.

Which of the following chefs is most likely to develop Type 2 diabetes?
Explanation:
Unfortunately, everyones favourite TV Chef, Ainsley, (who is famed for his spicy meat) is most likely to develop type 2 diabetes out of these.

Carribean people are three times more likely to develop Type 2 diabetes compared to a Caucasian population.

Men are also twice as likely to develop the condition as opposed to women, hence why Ainsley is correct and not Rusty.

 

Mary Berry could be correct as she does make some cakes which are packed with sugar (yet taste delicious).

Question:
You are the on-call doctor in A&E when you see Adam Reynolds, a 55 year old man, who presents with half and hour of "crushing" chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea and pain in his left arm. You suspect this man is having a myocardial infarction. You perform a 12 lead ECG on Adam, and it confirms that he has had an inferior myocardial infarction.

 

What is the most common vessel occluded in an inferior MI? And what leads would you see the ST elevation in?
OptionA:
Occlusion of RCA (right coronary artery)

STE in II, III & aVF
OptionB:
Occlusion of LAD (left anterior descending artery)

STE in V1 & V2
OptionC:
Occlusion of LAD (left anterior descending artery)

STE in V3 and V4
OptionD:
Occlusion of LCX (left circumflex artery)

STE in V1 & V2
OptionE:
Occlusion of RCA (right coronary artery)

STE in I, aVL, V5 & V6
Explanation:
• Inferior MIs account for 40-50% of all myocardial infarctions.
  • Generally have a more favourable prognosis than anterior myocardial infarction (in-hospital mortality only 2-9%), however certain factors indicate a worse outcome.

How to recognise an inferior MI on an ECG:

  • STE in lead II, III and aVF
  • STD in aVL

Which artery is the culprit?

  • The vast majority (~80%) of inferior STEMIs are due to occlusion of the dominant right coronary artery (RCA).
  • Less commonly (around 18% of the time), the culprit vessel is a dominant left circumflex artery (LCx).

An example of an ECG for an inferior MI (you can see the STE in II, III and aVF):

 

 

If you're like me and think how the bloody hell am I gonna learn leads and all that, i've found the combination of this table and (giant) picture quite helpful in understanding it!

 

 

 

B = septal MI

C = anterior MI

D = posterior MI (but should be STD in V1 and V2, not STE)

E = lateral MI (but should be occlusion of LAD not RCA)

Question:
You are on placement in a GP surgery and Jonathan Morgan, a 31 year old diary farmer comes in. He complains of increasing problems with feeling tired, long bouts of diarrhoea, flatulence, , frequent tingling in his hands and feet and has always struggled to maintain weight. After blood tests and a stool sample (which was found to have a high fat content), he was found to have microcytic anaemia. An endoscopy is performed and his duodenum is inflamed, red with raised patches but no cobbelstonning or ulceration (picture below). He doesn't get post-prandial pain and has been told he has a higher risk osteoporosis and has IgA deficiency.

What condition does Jonathan Morgan have?

 

Endoscopy:
Explanation:
Taken straight from the tutorial we had

 

Differentiating between Coeliacs and Crohns can be very difficult. After doing some looking into it, the biggest difference I can find are the appearance of the endoscope, IgA deficient and whether or not a gluten free diet help (or conversely whether he finds it gets worse after eating bread for example).

Here are two pictures of endoscopes, the one of the left is of Coeliacs Disease and the right being Crohns:

 

As you can see the Crohns looks far worse and has the cobbelstonned appearance due to large ulcerations. This ulceration is transmural, unlike Ulcerative Colitis which is much shallower and typically presents with bloody diarrhoea and more rectum issues as the rectum is always involved. People with Coeliacs often present with Lactose Intolerance as well the brush boarder is covered in inflammation in the duodenum meaning glucose isn't absorbed as well.

 

It can be hard to differentiate between the two so watch out. Good luck to everyone in their exams and any comments on how to differentiate between the two more would be great!

Question:
As the finest forensic pathologist in Westeros, you are often called in to the morgue at short notice to investigate high profile suspected murders. One day, whilst dining at the Westerosi branch of Kasturi, you receive a raven informing you that the boy king, Joffrey Baratheon (Lannister) has died, apparently poisoned, and that you have been requested to examine the body. As this is such a high profile case, you begrudgingly abandon your high quality and reasonably priced meal and at once ride to the morgue at UHW (University Hospital of Westeros) to investigate.

 

The body shows no signs of a struggle, with no broken bones or contusions, however, the toxicology report you ordered shows evidence of cyanide poisoning. Joffrey's incredibly irritating mother, who is also his aunt, Cersei Lannister, asks you how this poison works. You reply:
OptionA: Inhibition of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at motor end plates, preventing the movement of the respiratory muscles.
OptionB: Inhibition of cytochrome C oxidase (Complex IV), preventing the production of a proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane and therefore indirectly inhibiting ATP production.
OptionC: Abolishing the existing mitochondrial proton gradient thus uncoupling oxidative phosphorylation and bypassing ATP synthase.
OptionD: Inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase, reducing the production of acetyl coA from pyruvate and thus reducing the amount of ATP generated from the Krebs cycle.
OptionE: Inhibition of selenium dependent enzymes required for the function of various anti-oxidant molecules
Explanation:
B is correct, this is how the cyanide ion produces its toxic effects

 

A) - this is the mechanism of action of the curare toxin

B) - correct

C) - This is the mechanism of action of 2,4-dinitrophenol, once used in diet pills until it was found to be toxic

D) - This is one of the mechanisms of arsenic toxicity

E) - Is the mechanism of mercury poisoning

Question: What embryonic germ layer is the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc derived from?
Explanation:
I believe this was in Prof Dave Wilson's embryology lecture, but the notochord is an important director of what's happening in the embryo, it;

  • Forms the nucleus pulposus of the IV discs
  • Induces ectodermal cells over it to form the neural plate (which will later form the neural tube which forms the brain and spinal cord).

I'm going to write about gastrulation, just because it helps me remember it too, so if you don't want to read a long explanation then go to another question now lol.

 

Formation of the trilaminar embryo and body folding occurs in weeks 3-4 of embryonic development. 

 

So, in the picture on the left, is a view of the upper surface of the epiblast (remember the epiblast is above the hypoblast with space in between them, except at the prechordal plate where epiblast and hypoblast meet), the shape has changed from circular to an oval structure. So you can see the head end is considerably longer than the tail end. And forming in the midline of the epiblast is a groove called the primitive streak.

 

In week 3, the cells of the epiblast, from the right and left side, migrate towards the midline, primitive streak. When they get to the midline, they turn and go inwards and descend towards the hypoblast beneath it.

 

Some of the cells of the epiblast migrate through the primitive streak and all the way down to where the hypoblast cells are, they invaginate that layer and start to occupy it. As more and more of epiblastic cells do this, they displace the hypoblast cells which eventually die. This layer of epiblast cells forms the endoderm.

 

Other cells that migrate through the primitive streak migrate toward the hypoblast, but enter the space between the two layers, which forms the middle layer called the mesoderm.

 

Other cells from the epiblast migrate through the primitive streak, also become part of the middle layer but these cells stay right in the midline and form the notochord.

 

Lastly, we have cells of the epiblast that don't migrate through the primitive streak, but remain in the upper layer (epiblast) and form the ectoderm

 

Therefore, the trilaminar embryonic disc is formed with an outer ectoderm, inner mesoderm and notochord and innermost endoderm - all originally from the epiblast cells.

 

Different parts of the ectoderm will adopt different names depending on which part of the upper layer they occupy, for example;

  • Those that occupy the upper layer near the midline will form neural ectoderm cells
  • Cells that are right alongside that are called the neural crest cells
  • The remainder either become skin or surface ectodermal cells.

 

Neurulation

 

During development, the notochord releases substances into its surrounding area to direct the cells around it to differentiate in different ways. One such substance is  the Shh protein, which induces formation of the floor plate of the neural tube.

The notochord also induces ectodermal cells over it to form the neural plate. The lateral edges of the neural plate become more elevated and form a neural fold with a depressed midregion called the neural groove. The neural folds come together and fuse to form the neural tube, which later forms the brain and spinal cord.

 

Note that neural tube defects are caused by arrest of normal development and closure of the neural tube, resulting in conditions such as spina bifida or anencephaly.

 

----

 

So now that we have a flat 3 layered embryo, we need it to become 3D. Think of three papers all on top of each other, top paper is ectoderm, middle paper is mesoderm and the paper at the bottom is the endoderm. To make it a round 3 layered embryo, we need to fold it (4 weeks). Therefore, the edge on the left and right meet and fuse at the midline to form a tube. Once the tube is formed, the outer layer is ectoderm, middle layer is mesoderm and inner layer of endoderm, with the tube opened at front and back.

 

Therefore, we know the inner endoderm forms the lining of the gut tube, so one open end is for the mouth and the other is for the anus. The outer layer is the ectoderm, which we know forms the surface of the body, skin. And everything in between is mesoderm, which gives rise to cartilage, bone, muscle, connective tissue, blood etc. Which is in fact what we find between the surface of the body and the lining of the gut tube. 

 

What happens when the lateral body folds fail to fuse properly? You end up with a gap in the ventral body wall. This can allow structures that should be inside the embryo to escape and end up in the amniotic cavity. One such problem is gastroschisis, where abdominal viscera exits through a defect in the abdominal wall and is found in the amniotic cavity. Or omphalocele, a hernia in which abdominal structures move into the umbilical cord. 

 

Sorry for the super long explanation, but it just helps me to write it all out!

Question: Which of these statements regarding the male reproductive system is correct?
OptionA: At cold temperatures, the cremaster and dartos muscles relax, moving the testes away from the body
OptionB: Omphalocele occurs when serous fluid collects in the tunica vaginalis of the testes
OptionC: LH stimulates the sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubules secrete testosterone
OptionD: Via negative feedback, testosterone inhibits the secretion of LH and suppressed secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus
OptionE: In the external genitals and prostate, enzyme 5-alpha hydroxlyase converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT)
Explanation:
(A) Scrotum

  • Consists of loose skin and superficial fascia that hangs from the root of the penis
  • Single pouch of skin separated into lateral portions by a median ridge called the raphe (externally)
  • Internally scrotal septum divides the scrotum into two sacs, each containing a single testis.
  • The dartos muscle is composed of bundles of smooth muscle fibres, it is found in the subcutaneous tissue of the scrotum.
  • The cremaster muscle is associated with each testis, and is composed of a small band of skeletal muscle that is continuous with the internal oblique muscle.
  • Location of the scrotum and contraction of its muscle fibres regulate temperature of the testes.
  • In cold temperatures: cremaster and dartos muscle contract, moving the testes closer, and vice versa. (A)

(B) Testes

  • Develop near the kidneys, in the posterior portion of the abdomen and begin their descent into the scrotum through the inguinal canal in 7m of development.
  • Tunica vaginalis (derived from the peritoneum) partially covers the testes.
  • A collection of serous fluid in the tunica vaginalis is called a hydrocele, it can be caused by injury to the testes or inflammation of the epididymis. (B)

- Internal to the tunica vaginalis is the tunica albuginea, which is a dense fibrous capsule.

- The tunica albuginea extends inwards, forming septa that divide the testis into a series of internal compartments called lobules

- Each of the 200-300 lobules contains one to three tightly coiled tubules, the seminiferous tubules, where sperm are produced.

- The seminiferous tubules contain two types of cells: (1) spermatogenic cells and (2) sertoli cells

 

(C) - Large sertoli cells are embedded among the spermatogenic cells, and they join with other sertoli cells via tight junctions, forming a blood-testis barrier, as blood must first pass Sertoli cells before they can reach developing sperm.

- In the spaces between adjacent seminiferous tubules are clusters of cells called Leydig cells, which secrete testosterone (C).

 

(D) At puberty, certain hypothalamic neurosecretory cells increase their secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which stimulates the anterior pituitary to produce LH and FSH.

  • LH stimulates the Leydig cells to secrete testosterone (which is synthesised from the cholesterol in the testes), which readily diffuses out of the Leydig cell and into the blood.
  • Via negative feedback, testosterone inhibits the secretion of LH and suppresses secretion of GnRH from hypothalamic neurosecretory cells.

(E) In some places, like the external genitals and prostate, enzyme 5-alpha reductase converts testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT).

Question:
Jeremy Hunt is having back problems and goes to see his GP as he is struggling to stand up in lengthy debates in the House of Commons. He is also complaining of muscle twitching and numbness in his feet and around his mouth. The GP send him off for a lumbar/hip Xray which shows diffuse demineralisation. His blood test comes back with...

 

low Ca2+

low PO4-

high PTH

high ALP

 

What is wrong with Mr Hunt?
Explanation:
E is correct. Signs of hypocalcaemia and X-ray appearance and blood results. Caused as Hunt is Vitamin D deficient. He hides away from the public/press/junior doctors who all want his head on a stick, and subsequently does not receive enough sunlight to make Vit D. His wife also makes him follow a vegan diet in an attempt to stay healthy as to avoid interaction with healthcare professionals.

 

A= also correct

B= blood results would show normal Ca2+, PO4-, PTH but raised ALP due to increased turnover of bone (increased osteoclast activity with impaired compensatory osteoblast activity)

C= blood results would show raised Ca2+, PO4-, low PTH and high ALP

D= blood results show no abnormalities in osteoporosis

Question:
You are the on-call doctor in A&E, when the ambulance brings in 51 year old Sean Matthews who is suffering from angina, shortness of breath and syncope for the last half hour. He has a history of a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. You perform an ECG, and the results are below:

 

 

What do you think Sean Matthews has?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C, monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.

 

Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) is a broad complex tachycardia originating in the ventricles. There are several different varieties of VT — the most being Monomorphic VT. It is defined as a run of successive ventricular ectopic beats occurring at a rate of >100bpm (usually 12--200bpm). It is classified as non-sustained or sustained based on whether it lasts for >30s. 

 

Depending on the heart rate, VT can sometimes cause syncope, angina, SOB and if sustained can compromise cardiac pumping, leading to heart failure and death. 

 

Three mechanisms exist for initiation and propagation of ventricular tachycardia:

 

  1. Reentry: Commonest mechanism. Requires two distinct conduction pathways with a conduction block in one pathway, and a region of slow conduction in the other. Develops due to abnormal myocardial scarring usually due to prior ischemia or infarction.

2. Triggered activity: caused by an early after depolarisation (EAD) or late after depolarisation (LAD) (for example, Torsades or digitalis toxicity)

3. Abnormal automaticity: accelerated abnormal impulse generation by a region of ventricular cells.

 

ECG findings for VT:

  • broad complex tachycardia (i.e. QRS > 120ms).
  • bizarrrely shaped QRS complexes (abnormally broadened)

The QRS complex is used to classify VT into 2 broad categories:

 

Monomorphic VT:

  • Regular rhythm.
  • Originates from a single focus within the ventricles. Presence of a stable reentrant pathway, typically MI-related scar.
  • Produces uniform QRS complexes within each lead — each QRS is identical (except for fusion/capture beats).

 

Polymorphic VT:

  • Caused by multiple ectopic foci or reentry in which the circuit pathway is continually varying, occurs during/soon after an MI.
  • Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia has QRS complexes that very in shape and size.
  • If a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia has a long QT Interval, it could be Torsade de Pointes.

 

Torsades de Pointes, 'twisting of the points', is a type of polymorphic VT in which episodes of tachycardia, may give rise to fibrillation and sudden death, are superimposed upon intervals of bradycardia, during which QT interval is prolonged. ECG shows varying shapes and amplitudes of QRS complexes, waxes and wanes. (May be caused by drugs or conditions that delay ventricular repolarisation such as; class 1A & III antiarrhythmics, hypokalaemia and hypomagnesia).

Question:
Yograj and his lover Lizzie are getting ready for a mad night out. Yograj suggests to Lizzie that they should make this night "extra special" and from under his long over coat whips out a bottle of white pills. They both giggle and then decide to take one each. Yograj then leaves the room to fix his comb over. Lizzie (being a greedy girl) grabs the bottle and swallows all 30 pills. Yograj walks in to find a grinning Lizzie and an empty bottle, his face falls and he exclaims "no Lizzie". Lizzie asks "whats the problem Yog? We iz gonna partA tonight!". Yograj replies "I was trying to be cool and impress you, those pills were actually paracetamol............"

 

What is the Toxic metabolite of paracetamol and what is the antidote?
Explanation: Paracetamol (also known as acetaminophen) is broken down into the toxic metabolite N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPQI). This is usually de-detoxified by the bodys antioxidant glutathione. In an overdose glutathione is saturated leading to excess NAPQI which can damage liver cells. The antidote is acetylcysteine which is a precursor to glutathione, thus helps the body replenish its supply of glutathione.

Question: IFN-a and IFN-B are mediators released by virally infected cells in response to the presence of double-stranded viral RNA. Which of the following is mainly responsible for producing large amounts of these mediators?
Explanation:
Interferons are a family of eukaryotic cell proteins classified according to the cell of origin. IFN-a and IFN-B are produced by a variety of virally infected cells, but the plasmacytoid dendritic cells are responsible for producing the largest amount of IFN upon viral exposure. Any cell can produce IFN because any nucleated cell can be infected by a virus, but plasmacytoid dendritic cells have an increased capacity for producing IFN-a and B, and are have an abundance of TLR-7 and TLR-9.

 

A cell that is virally infected can take the heroic stand of saving its neighbouring uninfected cells. This infected cell makes interferon, which is released to the other cells, which if accepted, saves these cells from viral replication.

 

Cells that accept IFN can temporarily shut down protein synthesis, which stops the virus from replicating, as they need the host cell's machinery to do so. Therefore, the virus can still enter the cell but it cannot replicate. 

 

There are 2 mechanisms in which IFN inhibits viral protein synthesis:

  1. Through activation of an RNA endonuclease, which digests viral RNA
  2. By activation of protein kinase that inactivates eIF2 (initiation factors), thus inhibiting viral protein synthesis, this effectively interferes with translation.

IFN can also activate natural killer cells by increasing the expression of ligands for receptors for NK cells. 

 

Exogenous human IFN may be used in antiviral therapy for chronic, active Hep B and C infection.

 

Therapeutic Uses of IFNs

  • IFNs increase the expression of MHC I and II, augment NK cells, and increase the efficiency of presentation of antigens to cytotoxic lymphocytes and T helper cells.
  • IFN-a is an antiviral used in treatment for Hep B and C infections
  • IFN-b increases remission in multiple sclerosis

Note that conventional dendritic cells are responsible for the activate of naive T cell

Question: Which of the following is a 'flagellate trophozoite in host duodenum'?
Explanation:
Georgia is an intestinal protozoa with a 2 stage life cycle:

1) Flagellate trophozoite in host duodenum

2) Cysts passed in stool

Infectious dose 10-25 cysts

COMMON protozoan cause of diarrhoea in returning travellers.

Usually acquired by contaminated water

Bulky, pale and offensive smelling diarrhoea

Abdominal bloating as well as anorexia and nausea

30-50% progress to chronic diarrhoea- half of which develop malabsorption syndrome.

Question:
Yograj has finally decided to settle down, after a long and prosperous career as a forehead model in Abu Dhabi. Broody and eager to start a family, he decides to marry his lifelong sweetheart (and housemate) Alice, and the couple have a baby named Sujan.

 

They take Sujan for his routine vaccinations at a GP clinic when he is 2 months old. Sujan, a precocious young man and aspiring medic, quizzes the GP about the Rotavirus vaccine he is about to receive. He asks...

 

"Give me a reason why this vaccine is capable of inducing an effective immune response?"

 

The shocked GP manages to stammer...
OptionA: Rotavirus can replicate extracellularly, which means it can be presented by MHC II to T helper cells.
OptionB: Rotavirus can replicate intracellularly, which means it can be presented by MHC I to T helper cells.
OptionC: Rotavirus can replicate intracellularly which means it can be presented by MHC II to CTLs.
OptionD: Rotavirus can replicate intracellularly, which means it can be presented by MHC I to CTLs.
OptionE: Rotavirus can replicate extracellularly, which means it can be presented by MHC I to T helper cells.
Explanation:
Rotavirus is capable of replicating within cells, and can be broken down in the cytosol of cells into peptide fragments. 

 

All nucleated cells of the body express MHC-I molecules on their cell surface membranes. An exception to this is platelets/thrombocytes, which express MHC-I also.

 

Antigen presentation can occur as viruses are degraded in proteasomes within the cytosol. The resultant peptide fragments are transported into the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) via TAP (transport associated with antigen processing) proteins, and are complexed with MHC-I. The MHC I-peptide complex travels from the ER to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus, and the viral antigen is expressed on the cell membrane. This is called antigen presentation.

 

In the case of MHC I, all nucleated cells are capable of presenting antigens - therefore all nucleated cells can be termed non-professional antigen presenting cells (APCs).

 

This method of antigen presentation is called cytosolic/endogenous, due to the degradation of viral proteins occuring the cytosol of nucleated cells. 

 

MHC II can bind to TCRs on the surface of CD4+/T helper cells.

MHC I can bind to TCRs on the surface of CD8+/CTL/T killer cells. If the TCR is complementary to the epitope (antigen), apoptosis of the infected cell can occur.

 

 

Viruses cannot replicate extracellularly.

Question:
You are a medical student in a tutorial on placement. The consultant has given you the following case history of a patient:

 

Patient X, a 20 year history student, presented to A&E with headache, fever, neck stiffness and sensitivity to light. The patient presented with no focal neurological signs, and a CT scan of the head showed no cerebral herniations. A lumbar puncture was performed, and his CSF results were found to be:

 

Pressure: 35cm/H20 (5-20cm/H20)
Protein: 3.2g/L (0.18-0.45g/L)
Glucose: 1.5mmol/L (2.5-3.5mmol/L)
90% PMN

 

The patient was subsequently treated for the infection with benzyl penicillin, however dexamethasone was not used for this patient.

 

The consultant asks you what the patient was most likely infected with?
Explanation:
The patient is a university student (outbreaks of meningococcal disease, caused by N. meningitidis, have been reported from university campuses) presented with the classical triad of meningitis: headache, fever, and neck stiffness. 

 

The headache is a result of the nerve fibres surrounding the meninges being inflamed, resulting in pain. And the neck stiffness is due to the pain inflicted by bending the head which stretches the meninges.

 

The results of the CSF are indicative of bacterial meningitis:

  • Differential >90% polymorphs = bacterial and >90% lymphocytes = viral
  • Bacteria are protein and therefore result in markedly elevated levels of protein
  • Bacteria have a sweet tooth and eat glucose, resulting in low levels of glucose (note that TB eats ALL the glucose so would have a very low level), viruses do not.
  • High opening pressure is also present in bacterial meningitis

So from all of that we gather that the patient has bacterial meningitis. What differentiates between it being Neisseria (meningococcal) or Streptococcal (pneumococcal) is the use of dexamethasone in treatment.

 

Dexamethasone is good for streptococcal, and is bad for neisseria. Therefore, the fact that it was not used points more towards Neisseria than Streptococcal. 

 

Cefotaxime is used for pneumococcal meningitis.

Question: You have done a good hour's stint of revision. There is a packet of custard creams as a snack on your desk. Where in the brain decides whether you will treat yo self to five of these or not?
Explanation:
This question is discussing the reward regulation of appetite. 

 

  • Amygdala and hippocampus- remembers that the custard creams make you feel warm and yummy inside (classical conditioning)
  • Ventral tegmental area- the drive to eat the custard creams to make you feel good (hedonic response), release of dopamine to nucleus accumbens
  • Nucleus ccumbens- makes you feel warm and yummy inside when you eat your custard creams (pleasure centre)
  • Pre frontal cortex- decision making whether you're gonna treat yo self or not (nb. always treat yo self)

The hypothalamus is more involved in the homeostatic control of appetite. 

 

  • Ghrelin released in response to an empty stomach > signals with the ARC nucleus in the hypothalamus > releases NPY > signals with LHA in the hypothalamus > releases Orexin > hunger
  • Leptin released in response to a full stomach > signals with ARC nucleus in the hypothalamus > inhibits NPY release > no orexigenic hormones released so supression of hunger
  • Full stomach also releases anorexogenic hormones- GLP 1, CCK, PYY and insulin

Question:
GoT spoiler alert

 

Hodor (aka Hold the Door), a 45 year old man, is visiting your morning GP clinic. He reports of weight loss, decreased appetite, a gradual onset of weakness and shows you dark marks on his palmar creases, knuckles and elbows. He also says that when he stands up, he feels light headed and dizzy. You request for some blood tests to be taken and the results are:

 

Serum sodium: 127mmol/L (136-145mmol/L)

Serum potassium: 5.8mmol/L (3.5-5.1mmol/L)

 

What is your most likely diagnosis of Hodor?
Explanation:
The single best answer is D, primary Addison's Disease - a chronic adrenocortical insufficiency.

 

First, I'm just going to talk about the the adrenal cortex and the regulation of cortisol (it will be long, so feel free to just move onto the next question!)

 

The adrenal cortex is made up of 3 regions; and outer zona glomerulosa, middle zona fasciculata, and innermost zona reticularis. (Remember these by GFR)

  1.  The zona glomerulosa is responsible for the production of the mineralocorticoid aldosterone, and is controlled by Angiotensin II and [K+]. (salty!)
  2. The zona fasciulata is responsible for the production of the glucocorticoids such as cortisol, and is controlled by ACTH (sugar!)
  3. The zona reticularis is responsible for the production of androgens (sex hormones) and is also controlled by ACTH (sweetest!)

So remember the deeper you go through the cortex, the sweeter it gets! (Note that the medulla is responsible for noradrenaline production, regulated by the ANS).

 

We can see that aldosterone is the only one not controlled by the pituitary, so technically if your head was chopped off, your BP would still be maintained!

 

We can use the picture to understand the control of ACTH and cortisol.

  • In response to stress, the hypothalamus releases corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH), which stimulates the synthesis of anterior pituitary corticotrophs. This then synthesises pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC) (opio = endorphins, explains why one feels little pain during stress), which stimulates the production of 2 molecules: (1) ACTH and (2) B-lipotropin
  • The ACTH then stimulates the zona fasciculata to produce cortisol whilst the B-lipotropin enters a different pathway.
  • B-lipotropin stimulates the production of B-MSH (melanocyte-stimulating hormone) and endorphins (which modulate pain)
  • The B-MSH stimulates the pars intermedia (the boundary between the anterior and posterior pituitary gland) to secrete MSH.
  • Cortisol production provides negative feedback to the hypothalamus to stop producing CRH, and also negative feedback to the anterior pituitary.

Therefore, we can say that an increase in ACTH = an increase in MSH also.

The peak of cortisol is early in the morning (highest at 9am), and low in the late evening.

 

Now moving onto Addison's disease:

 

Chronic primary adrenocortical insufficiency caused by destruction of the adrenal cortex, leading to a deficiency of glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids and androgens

Aetiology: - autoimmune disorders (most common) - tuberculosis - metastatic cancer

Most commonly occurs between the ages of 30-50 years

Presentation: 

  • Gradual onset of weakness
  • Skin hyperpigmentation (insufficiency of the adrenal gland, therefore in response the pituitary releases a lot of ACTH which goes through the MSH tract, giving the patient hyperpigmentation. This is important for comparing primary adrenocortical insufficiency with secondary. In secondary, there is no hyperpigmentation as the problem is with the pituitary gland not making ACTH therefore, no MSH.) Usually occurs in regions where there is friction, i.e. armpits, elbows, knuckles, and palmar creases.
  • Decreased appetite, weight loss
  • Muscle cramps
  • Hyperkalaemic (therefore acidotic) and hyponatriemic (both due to the decrease in aldosterone)
  • Poor response to stress
  • Loss of libido
  • Women may lose underarm and pubic hair
  • Hypotension and hypoglycaemia (can lead to postural hypotension and dizziness) - another differential between primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency, as lack of aldosterone in primary results in the hypotension, and hypoglycaemia due to decreased gluconeogenesis.

Treatment: Usually steroid replacement (hydrocortisone, prednisolone or dexamethasone)

 

Can lead to life threatening adrenal crisis = vomiting, abdominal pain, back or leg cramps, and severe hypotension leading to shock. This can be triggered by a stresser such as trauma, surgery or infection. 

 

Associated genes: HLA (human leukocyte antigen) complex - which helps the immune system distinguish the body's own proteins from proteins made by invading foreigners. 

 

In autoimmune Addisons's; the attack is triggered by protein 21-hydroxylase which usually produces hormones in the adrenal gland. Prolonged attack damages the adrenal gland (specifically the cortex), preventing hormone secretion. 

 

Diagnosis: ACTH stimulation test, pt with Addison's with respond to synthetic ACTH with little or no rise in cortisol levels.

Question: Cystic Fibrosis is an autosomal recessive condition with an incidence of 1 in 2500. What is the carrier frequency of this condition?
Explanation:
Using the hardy-weinberg equation:

 

p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1

 

  • p2 = Frequency of homozygous dominant (AA)
  • 2pq = Frequency of heterozygous carrier (Aa)
  • q2 = Frequency of homozygous recessive (aa)
