Question: Mrs Lawrence is wondering whether she is a carrier for Duchenne's Muscular Dystrophy. She knows that her brother had the condition and that her mum was definitely a carrier, but none of her 3 sons have been affected with the condition. Given this fact, what is the chance that Mrs Lawrence is a carrier?
Explanation:
This is the explanation given in the lecture-but personally I find this quite time consuming and confusing so I will show my method below. Please don't stress too much over this-if it comes up it will be one question 

 

So DMD is an X linked recessive condition (which you would be expected to know) thus the father (not stated he has DMD) is irrelevant in this question. However, you know that her brother had the condition, so therefore the mother must be carrier. Knowing this, Mrs Lawrence has ½ of being a carrier as she would of have either receive the DMD X chromosome from the mother or the healthy X chromosome from the mother. You know also that her 3 children that are boys are all unaffected. If she were a carrier, the chance of her passing the DMD X chromosome on would be ½. If she weren’t a carrier the chances of her passing this DMD X chromosome would be 0, as she doesn’t have the affected X chromosome gene (throughout this question, you are assuming that there are no de novo DMD mutations which occurs in 1/3 cases of the disease) . Thus to calculate the total probability you supply multiple all the accumulative probabilities for both possibilities. From this you basically get 1/16 she is a carrier and ½ she is not a carrier. After this you can do an Odds Ratio. Basically a ratio of each probability to each you get 1: 8. To finally get the answer however, you need to add up the two numbers of the ratio (1+8=9) and then put the OR of her being a carrier (1) over the total (1/9)

Thus we can do this table 

Therefore 1/1+8 =1/9=Correct answer :) 

If I have confused you more, please comment and I'll try and explain it better. If your method got the right answer, ignore my method as I am doing what I find the quickest and easiest for me.

 

Thanks

Question:
Harry Potter has just been to McDonalds and had a double quarter pounder with cheese and an Oreo McFlurry, and has started to feel some pain in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen which radiates slightly into his right shoulder. Harry had a gallstone in the bit which nobody talks about, between the chamber of secrets and the prisoner of Azkaban. He has the occasional butterbeer but he never gets wasted. 

His inflammatory markers are not raised and he is not pyrexic. 

Harry tried doing some of his spells on it, but he's actually a pretty rubbish wizard, so they didn't do anything.  

What disease does Mr Potter most likely have?
Explanation:
A- acute cholecystitis --> is in the right upper quadrant, but this shows signs of fever (pyrexia) and raised inflammatory markers. It is  Inflammation/infection of the gallbladder secondary to impacted gallstones.

Murphy's sign positive (arrest of inspiration on palpation of the RUQ)

 

B- Acute Pancreatitis --> This pain does radiate to the back, but is usually in the epigastrium. Usually due to alcohol or gallstones, so the history with Harry sort of fits, but the pain is often very severe and there is a low grade fever present so it is not the best answer. 

 

C- Appendicitis --> The pain is initially in the central abdomen before localising to the right iliac fossa (RIF).

Anorexia is common. Tachycardia, low-grade pyrexia, tenderness in RIF

also shows Rovsing's sign: more pain in RIF than LIF when palpating LIF, which i found RATHER INTERESTING. 

 

D- Biliary Colic. this is CORRECT! WELL DONE. this is made worse by eating a fatty meal and presents in the RUQ. Caused by a gallstone getting lodged in the bile duct.

In contrast to acute cholecystitis no fever and inflammatory markers are normal. 

It is more likely with a history of gall stones aand the pain can radiate to the back. 

 

E- Renal Colic --> this presents with loin pain radiating to the groin so this isn't what Harry's got. Pain is often severe but intermittent. Patient's are characteristically restless.

Visible or non-visible haematuria may be present.

 

THE END.
Tags: Pain, Renal system, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 11, Lower GI

Question:
There is absolute pandemonium within the School of Medicine when news spreads that Ainsley Harriott will be attending Walkabout on June 9th. To try and impress the Lord, you decide to rustle up a delicious yet healthy meal (which follows the EatWell plate guidance). All your cookbooks are unfortunately at home, apart from the well-used C21 cookbook which you find under the bed.

After considering 'Andy's Meaty Balls' and Dr Keith Hart's 'Facili-Tater', you shortlist 5 possible recipes. Keeping in mind the EatWell plate, which of the following recipes would be most appropriate to cook for Ainsley?
OptionA:
Dr Tim Johnson's Six Minute Noodles

- 75% carbohydrate

- 15% vegetables

- 10% oils and spreads (fats)
OptionB:
Dr TJ Allen's Cheese and Tuna Medley

- 65% carbohydrate

- 10% vegetables

- 10% protein

- 15% oils and spreads (fats)
OptionC:
Dr Zarabeth Newton's Roast Dinner

- 35% carbohydrates

- 35% vegetables

- 15% protein

- 13% dairy

- 2% fat
OptionD:
Prof Dave Wilson's Stew

- 30% carbohydrates

- 20% vegetables

- 35% protein

- 15% fat
OptionE:
Ronnie's Red Lentil Soup

- 5% carbohydrates

- 20% vegetables

- 70% protein

- 5% fat
Explanation:
Zarabeth's Roast Dinner is the SBA in this question. The eatwell plate suggests that you eat roughly the following proportions per meal:

 

- 1/3 veg/fruit (5 a day) Fruit juice can only make up 1 of your 5 a day regardless how much you drink.

- 1/3 carbs

- 1/6 protein

- 1/6 dairy

- A small amount of fat from butters/spreads/oil.

 

Other notable points are that you should aim for at least 18g of fibre per day, and 6-8 glasses of water. Sugar free drinks (eg squash, tea/coffee) count towards this as well as low-fat milk.

 

The NHS is moving towards an EatWell guide which is in principle the same as above, but is thinking about getting the balance right over a day or a week. I've kept to the Plate as it's what came up in plenaries.

 

Good luck everyone!

Question:
A new drug has been discovered to help treat rheumatoid arthritis. However, it has been found to have a few side effects. The new drug affects proteasomes and makes them ineffective.

In a patient receiving this new drug, which out of the following are they most likely to experience as a result of this?
OptionA: The patient is at an increased risk of not producing an adaptive response to TB
OptionB: The patients NK cells are less likely to bind to antibodies, resulting in a decreased antibody-dependant cell mediated cytotoxicity response.
OptionC: The patient is at an increased risk of not producing an adaptive response to Norovirus
OptionD: A reduction in the amount of Interferons
OptionE: TRL 3 is less likely to recognise PAMPs
Explanation: Proteasomes are key in adaptive immune response because they break down intracellular antigens into peptides. This is key to antigen presenting in MHC Class I. As this is only done to intracellular antigens, it is far more likely to affect the processing of a virus than a bacteria. Therefore it would affect whether or not peptides from a virus could be presented on a cell surface thus leading us to the answer C.

Question:
Sleepy, the 5th dwarf from Snow White and the 7 dwarves, has grown increasingly tired recently. 

He has been feeling very down and withdrawn, but put it to the fact that he misses Happy and Dopey (who have gone to visit Snow White and the Prince at the palace). 

His skin has taken on an orangey tint (even brighter than Bashful's) and has sneezed even more than Sneezy (which Is really rather an achievement). 

 

As Doc, you think you have successfully come to a diagnosis. To confirm this, you whack out a syringe and take some bloods just to be sure. Grumpy is now complaining because there's blood on the table and Snow White would be well pissed. What are your most likely results?
Explanation:
Mirror Mirror on the wall, which is the SBA of them all? 

 

So B is correct: 

These symptoms (tiredness, hyper pigmentation, depression, cold intolerance) are all characteristic of Addison's - which is hypo secretion of the adrenal cortex, so low aldosterone (zona glomerulosa), low cortisol (zona fasciculatis) and low sex steroids. Because of this, you have positive feedback to the anterior pituitary causing increase release of ACTH. Aldosterone normally unregulates activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase in the kidney to raise blood pressure by retaining Na+, therefore, low aldosterone will mean this occurs less, causing less Na+ to be reabsorbed (I.e. Na+ is low) and less K+ to be excreted, (I.e. K+ is high) 

 

Note: the hyperkalaemia associated with Addisons is the most serious aspect (more serious than the witch outside with a shiny green apple) 

p.s. Sorry if you got wound up by the Disney jargon but I'm bored and fed up of revision and idc.

Question:
A patient comes into see you in your surgery.

 

He is complaining of feeling tired, a lack of energy, muscle pain and bleeding from his gums.

 

On observation and examination you see inflammation and bleeding of gums, he has lost a tooth, has foul smelling breath and has oedema.

 

When asking about his diet, he says to you that he is severely allergic to oranges. He has also been complaining of depression.

 

Hypothetically, what neurotransmitter/s is most likely causing his depression?
Explanation:
The answer is most likely D, Noradrenaline and adrenaline.

 

The patient seems to presenting with SCURVY - which is a deficiency of vitamin C characterised by:

  • feeling very tired and weak all the time (fatigue)
  • a general sense of feeling "out of sorts" – such as feeling irritable and miserable all the time
  • pain in your limbs – particularly your legs
  • inflammation of the gums – which become soft and vulnerable to bleeding (your teeth may feel loose or fall out)
  • severe joint pain, caused by bleeding inside the joints
  • shortness of breath – particularly after periods of physical activity
  • redness and swelling in recently healed wounds (new wounds may also fail to heal)
  • easily bruised skin

A lack of Vitamin C could be due to his allergy to ORANGES - he is not eating enough citrus fruits - vitamin C is found in Citrus fruits.

 

So moving on to his Depression (I don't know if a symptom of Scurvy is depression, so this could be a separate issue),

 

Depression is characterised by reduced levels of serotonin, noradrenaline and dopamine - known as the Monoamine theory of depression.

(Treatment would be to raise levels of 5-HT and NA – brain can form new connections and improve mood)

 

In the synthesis of Noradrenaline and adrenaline in the CNS: 

1. Tyrosine from food (milk is a major source) is actively transported into the brain through the BBB – it is fully saturated with typical daily intake – rate limiting step of the pathway.

2. Hydroxylated by tyrosine hydroxylase to form dihydroxyphenylalanine – requires Fe2+ , O2 and a H+ donor (tetrahydrobiopterin) to form L-DOPA – increased release of catecholamines → increase in TH activity – also rate limiting.

3. In NORADRENERGIC neurones in synaptic vesicles that store NA , DOPAMINE → converted via DBH (Dopamine-B-Hydroxylase) → NORADRENALINE. DBH requires Cu2+ and Vit C as co factors

4. In ADRENERGIC NEURONES in brainstem and ADRENAL MEDULLA, NA → converted via PNMT (Phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase) → ADRENALINE .A methyl donor is required as a co factor.

 

So hypothetically, reduced vitamin C , could reduce the amount of DBH, which could reduce the amount of both Noradrenaline and Adrenaline.

 

The SINGLE BEST answer here is D, A and E are also depleted in depression however he has no signs of reduced enzymes for conversion and production of these neurotransmitters. 

Glutamate and GABA are both derived from glucose from the Krebs cycle: GLUTAMATE from a-ketoglutarate via GABA-T • GABA from GLUTAMATE via GAD.

Glutamate is involved with Psychosis and GABA with anxiety.

Question:
You are a medical student on placement in a GP surgery, shadowing the diabetic nurse. She is seeing patients for their 6 month diabetic review. During this review, the nurse reviews the oral hypoglycaemic drugs each patient is taking. One patient, Mrs Nkem Obande, a 65 year old lady, complains that her medication is causing her to have headaches. You ask the nurse about this drug and she tells you that it works by inhibiting dipeptidyl peptidase (DPP-4), thus inhibiting the inactivation of GLP-1. 

 

What drug is the patient most likely taking?
Explanation:
The mechanism of the drug described in the question correlates with sitagliptin.

 

Sitaglipin is one of two agents which affect GLP-1. GLP-1 and GIP are incretin hormones, both secreted by endocrine cells that are located in the epithelium of the small intestine. An increase of substances in the lumen of the GI tract (like glucose) triggers the secretion of these hormones. Incretins are carried through the circulation to target tissues: pancreatic beta cells. The incretin stimulation of beta cells causes them to secrete more insulin in response to the same amount of glucose. 

 

GLP-1 is inactivated by an enzyme called dipeptidyl peptidase (DPP-4). This enzyme breaks down the incretin. Sitagliptin works by inhibiting DPP-4 and thus preventing GLP-1 from being inactivated, so more GLP-1 in the circulation allows for an increase in insulin release, decrease in glucagon release and thus an overall decrease in blood glucose.

 

The main side effect of DPP-4 inhibitors is headaches.

 

Exenatide is the other drug that works on GLP-1. It is a long-acting GLP-1 receptor full agonist used in type 2 DM in a combination with other agents. It is therefore a GLP-1 mimetic.

 

Side effects of exenatide are nausea (therefore not given to patient with gastroparesis) and hypoglycaemia when used with oral sulfonylureas.

 

 

In regards to the other drugs:

 

Metformin is a biguanide which works by decreasing hepatic gluconeogenesis and may involve an increase in tissue sensitivity to insulin. Its mechanism of action:

  1. It increases cytosolic AMP
  2. This leads to an activation of AMP activated protein kinase (AMPK)
  3. This causes a decreased expression of phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) and glucose-6-phosphatase
  4. This ultimately leads to a decrease in hepatic gluconeogenesis, increased insulin sensitivity and increased GLUT 4 activity
  5. All in all lowering plasma glucose levels

It is referred to as "euglycaemic", meaning it decreases postprandial glucose levels, but does not cause hypoglycaemia or weight gain.

 

Its side effects are lactic acidosis (as it forces tissues to pick up lots of glucose) and GI distress is common (diarrhoea).

 

 

Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinediones (i will never ever be able to say that). Its mechanism of action is:

  1. It binds to nuclear PPARs (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors) involved in the transcription of insulin-responsive genes.
  2. It acts on them to increase the sensitisation of tissue to insulin
  3. It also decreases hepatic gluconeogenesis and triglycerides
  4. It increases the insulin receptor numbers

Its side effects are: hypoglycaemia (but less than sulfonylureas), weight gain, oedema, and in severe cases an increased risk of pancreatic cancer. 

 

 

Gliplizide is a sulfonylurea, which mimics the release of ATP in the beta cell of the pancreas, causing K+ channels to close. 

 

In normal beta cell physiology, glucose enters the cell via GLUT2 transporters and through glycolysis produces ATP. The rise in ATP is detected by the sulfonylurea receptor subunit (SUR-1) of the K+ATPase channel and causes it to close. This increases the K+ inside the cell which depolarises the membrane, leading to opening of Ca2+ channels. Calcium influx into the cell causes insulin to be released from granules. Sulfonylureas bypass all of this and and bind to SUR-1 thus blocking the K+ channels, causing insulin release. 

 

A common side effect of sulfonylureas is hypoglycaemia, and a more severe side effect is cholestasis (where bile cannot flow from the liver to the duodenum).

 

 

Lastly, acarbose (not one of the options, but i've gotten this far explaining them all so might as well carry on!) works by inhibiting a-glucosidase in the brush borders of the small intestine. This enzyme usually breaks down complex sugars into small absorbable sugars. Therefore, by inhibiting it, there is a decrease in the formation of absorbable carbs, thus decreasing postprandial glucose, and hence decreasing the demand for insulin.

 

Its use should be restricted to those who have failed to respond to diet alone and cannot tolerate the conventional oral hypoglycaemics.

 

Its side effects are: GI discomfort, flatulence (bloating), diarrhoea (keeping sugars in the gut causes osmotic pull of water), and recent concern over potential hepatotoxicity.

 

 

That's all folks, sorry for the length of this, but gotta love some pictures in there! Hang on guys, almost done now!

Question:
Lesley Barnes, an 18 year old girl, has attended the sexual health clinic. She says a week ago she had unprotected sex and has since noticed a white, clear discharge on her underwear, she has also recently felt some discomfort when urinating. 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis of Lesley?
Explanation:
Chlamydia is the best answer, UTI could be correct, however it does not explain the discharge, and there are no symptoms of urgency.

 

Chlamydia is a gram negative bacteria, spread through sexual contact. The patient can present with dysuria, a white-ish, clear, and non-purulent discharge, and also abdominal pain. It is the most common STI in the UK and is treated with azithromycin or doxycycline.

 

Gonorrhoea is a gram negative bacteria. Males infected usually present with burning on urination, a green/yellow purulent discharge from the tip of the penis, and inflammation of the foreskin. Women infected usually present with an unusual discharge which may be thin/water and green in colour, dysuria, and possibly discomfort in the abdomen. The bacteria can also grow in the mouth and anus. Babies that are born from mothers infected with gonorrhoea may have ophthalmia which can rapidly leave to blindness if untreated. Gonorrhoea is treated with cefixime or azithromycin.

 

Trichomoniasis is caused by a tiny parasite called Trichomonas vaginalis. Symptoms include vaginal discharge which is offensive smelling and of yellow/green colour. Discharge can also be frothy. Patient may also have vulvovaginitis which is referred to as a "strawberry cervix". It is usually treated with metronidazole.

 

Vulvovaginal Candidiasis is caused by an infection from candida albicans associated with dermatitis of the vulva. Symptoms include cottage cheese-like discharge. Patients taking tetracyclines are at risk of developing this infection. Usually treated with clotrimazole cream or oral fluconazole.

 

Herpes simplex is a dsDNA virus. Resulting in inflamed papules and vesicles on the outer surface of the genitals resembling cold sores. Usually treated with aciclovir or valaciclovir (anti-viral meds).

 

Syphilis is caused by gram negative Treponema pallidum. Patients present with small painless ulcers, typically appearing on the penis, vagina or around the mouth/anus. A non-itchy blotchy body rash that often affects palms of hands or soles of the feet. May also have white patches in the mouth. Usually treated with penicillin.

 

Urinary Tract Infection, most commonly caused by E.coli. Patients present with dysuria, urgency and lower back pain or pubic pain. Elderly patients may also present with delirium. Usually treated with a short course of antibiotics, most commonly trimethoprim.

Question: A family has a child affected by sickle cell disease. Neither the father nor the mother have sickle cell disease; they have a 2nd unaffected child-what is the probability that he is a carrier of the sickle cell gene?
Explanation:
According to your punnet square, there are four possibilities for offspring. There is a 25% chance the offspring is normal, 2 out of 4 chances they are a carrier and a quarter chance they are affected.The previous affected child has no bearing on probabilities for this new offspring.

However, according to the question, the new offspring is not affected. There are now only two possibities for the offspring- carrier or healthy. Probabilites are now 2/3 that they are a carrier and 1/3 non-carrier. Sickle cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive condition, inherited via chromosome 11.

Question: As part of Angela Rippon's new series on BBC "The Truth About Dementia", the brains of those with Alzheimer's dementia were compared with healthy brains. Which of the following statements is true in regards to a brain belonging to a patient with Alzheimer's dementia?
OptionC: There are no findings of senile plaques (from deposition of amyloid)
OptionD: The will be lifted sulci (i.e. not flattened)
Explanation:
I've worded this really confusingly, im sorry!

 

Alzheimers disease accounts for roughly 50-60% of patient's with dementia.

Risk factors:

  • female
  • family history
  • head trauma
  • down syndrome (associated with the APP gene on chromosome 21)

 

Neuroanatomic findings:

  • cortical atrophy (global atrophy of the whole brain)
  • flattened sulci
  • enlarged ventricles
  • shrinkage of the hippocampus 

Histopathology:

  • senile plaques (deposits of beta-amyloid)
  • neurofibrillary tangles
  • neuronal loss
  • synaptic loss
  • granulovascular degeneration of neurons

General points:

  • Decrease in ACh (which is linked to memory) and noradrenaline
  • Deterioration generally linear (i.e. slow deterioration) or progressive, with average duration of onset to death being about 8 years.
  • Focal neurological symptoms or deficits are rare (this is what differentiates vascular dementia from alzheimers)

End stage:

  • Bed-ridden
  • No sphincter control
  • Cannot walk
  • Cannot care for themselves - basically like a child again

Treatment:

  • Includes long acting cholinesterase inhibitors such as tacrine or donepezil
  • Risperidone (atypical antipsychotic) and other high potency antipsychotic meds ma be helpful in low doses to decrease agitation

On a side note, the Angela Rippon series is brilliant, I'd definitely recommend it! Although I doubt anyone will want to be watching/doing anything medical after June 9th!

Question: what is the combination of the new drug which is used for dual neurohormonal inhibition?
Explanation: B) valsartan in the ARB and the sacubitral blocks the enzyme called neprilysin , which causes a release of more BNP.

Question:
An 18-year-old medical student decides he is going to get buff, so starts consuming protein shakes. Whilst drinking a shake after a massive session of squats in the gym, he contemplates the process of digestion. He recalls that one of the enzymes involved in protein digestion (a proteolytic enzyme) in the stomach is pepsin and it's inactive precursor (zymogen) is pepsinogen. But he can't remember which cells in the stomach secrete pepsinogen. He asks a fellow medical student who knows everything as she uses PeerWise everyday.

 

Which cells does she tell him are responsible?
Explanation:
Chief cells (found in the body of the stomach) are responsible for secretion of pepsinogen, which is converted into the active proteolytic enzyme pepsin.

 

Consumption of protein stimulates the production of gastrin, secreted by G cells. Gastrin then stimulates the secretion of both intrinsic factor and hydrochloric acid from parietal cells. The hydrochloric acid catalyses the conversion of pesinogen to pepsin. The acidic environment created and pepsin are both important for the hydrolysis of proteins. Intrinsic factor is responsible for assisting absorption of vitamin B12 found in proteinaceous foods such as meat, fish and eggs. D cells (found in the antrum of the stomach) are stimulated by Gastrin and secrete somatostatin, a hormone which inhibits Gastrin excretion from G cells and hydrochloric acid from parietal cells (a negative feedback mechanism presenting the stomach becoming too acidic).

 

Leydig cells are testosterone producing cells found in the testicles. They are important for getting buff but have little direct influence on digestion.

 

Random mnemonic: I remember that chief cells secrete pepsinogen and are found in the body of the stomach by picturing the image of a native American chief drinking pepsi, which goes into his body.  

 

Pepsi is the ancient Greek word for digestion.

 

Apparently the drink "Pepsi" is so named as it was initially marketed as a digestive aid (although the sources for this are dubious), other dubious sources claim that Pepsi is called Pepsi because Pepsin is involved or was involved in it's production (again, this is from dodgy internet sources, not necessarily true). The rest of the information in this question is true though! Sources include: " Marieb, Human anatomy and Physiology, 6th edition" and "Faller, The human body: an introduction to structure and function, 13th edition".

Question:
A 19-year-old medical student presents with pain and swelling at the base of his right thumb. He reports an amorous encounter on a MedSoc social with a fellow medical student, with whom he returned to his halls of residence. Due to the narrow beds, alcohol excess and obscure mid-coital positioning he fell onto his extended wrist, which resulted in severe pain.  

There is exquisite tenderness on palpation of the anatomical snuff box of his right wrist. He is told by the doctor that his wrist x-ray shows a fracture of a carpal bone.

 

Which bone is most likely to be fractured?
Explanation:
The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone. The usual mechanism of injury is a fall onto an extended wrist, typical history and examination findings include: pain and swelling at the base of the thumb and tenderness on palpation of the anatomical snuff box*.

 

The history of presenting complaint in this question is reminiscent of a mnemonic for remembering the carpal bones: Some Lovers Try Positions That They Can't Handle  = Scaphoid Lunate Triquetrum Pisiform Trapezium Trapezoid Capitate Hamate. 

 

*the anatomical snuff box is the depression between the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons at the base of the thumb. This recess is so named for it's use of holding snuff (ground tobacco) prior to nasal insufflation. 

 

Jason

Question:
You are presented with a patient that has suffered from a direct blow to the middle part of the lateral side of his left leg. His X-rays show a midshaft fibula fracture of the left leg. He's unable to evert his lef foot and also complains about loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot with the exception of the area between the great/first toe and second toe (first web space/ interdigital cleft) and the lateral side of the fifth digit. 

What nerve has been injured?
Explanation:
The answer is Superficial Fibular nerve. Here's why:

 

 

The 1st hint was the inability to evert the foot. The muscles responsible for foot eversion are: Fibularis longus and Fibularis brevis. These two muscles are supplied by the superficial fibular nerve. At this point you might be thinking "Hold on! What about Fibularis tertius?!" Well fibularis tertius only aids in the everting of the foot. It's primary function is ankle dorsiflexion (it's supplied by deep fibular nerve).

 

The 2nd hint is the loss of sensation. So it says he lost sensation over the dorsum of his left foot with the exception of the lateral side of the fifth digit and the first interdigital cleft. The first interdigital cleft is supplied by the deep fibular nerve and the lateral side of the fifth digit is supplied by the sural nerve. The rest (i.e. majority of dosrum surface) is supplied by the superficial fibular nerve, so here again you should be thinking "something's wrong with the superficial nerve."  (this link shows you the foot dermatomes, in case you're a bit lost: http://www.frca.co.uk/images/lowerlimb-fig8-small.jpg)

 

Now you can look back at the fact that his fracture is located at the midshaft of his fibula; what runs close along it there? The superficial fibular nerve!

 

Here's another link that talks a bit about superficial fibular nerve and potential damage: http://teachmeanatomy.info/lower-limb/nerves/superficial-fibular-nerve/

 

Another way of working this out is by ruling out answers:

1) The medial plantar, is a the larger branch of the tibial nerve, while the later plantar is the smaller branch. they both supply the skin of the plantar surface of the foot. Just look at their name: medial plantar, lateral plantar. The patient however suffers from loss of sensation on the dorsal surface!

2) As for the Saphenous nerve, it supplies the skin on the medial side of the foot as far as the head of the first metatarsal. It has no contribution to foot eversion. So it can't be this nerve.

3) Deep Fibular nerve doesn't contribute to foot eversion, but dorsiflexion and extension of the toes. It also supplies the skin at the first interdigital cleft, an area that the patient hasn't lost sensation in. So again it can't be this nerve.

 This leaves us with superficial fibular nerve as the only answer :)

 

*Additional info:

Something you might find interesting is that the deep fibular nerve injury causes a foot drop!
Tags: Foot, Anatomy, Innervation, Innervations, Lower Limb

Question: Samantha is a first year medical student on placement at a local eye clinic. At the start of the day she notices David in the waiting room who is shown below. From initial inspection, Samantha suspects that David has...
Explanation:
From the picture we can see that David has:

 

- a dilated pupil in his right eye.

- ptosis of his right eyelid.

- a depressed, abducted, laterally rotated right pupil.

 

This combination of signs suggests that he has occulomotor nerve palsy (CN III palsy) for the following reasons:

 

First, the occulomotor nerve has sympathetic fibres which innervate the levator palpebrae superiosis muscle responsible for raising the eyelid. If thiere is a lesion to this nerve, ptosis will occur due to unopposed action of the orbicularis occuli muscle innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII). 

 

The occulomotor nerve also supplies parasympathetic fibres to the pupillary sphincter muscle which constricts the pupil. If there is a lesion to CN III, the unopposed action of sympathetic fibres to the pupillary dilator muscle will cause the pupil to dilate.

 

Thirdly, the occulomotor nerve innervates superior rectus, medial rectus, inferior rectus and inferior oblique. If there is a lesion to this nerve then there will be unopposed action to superior oblique (innervated by CN IV) and lateral rectus (innervated by CN VI). As a result the pupil will be abducted, depressed and laterally rotated.

 

*Note: although answer E is also correct, since this is the single best answer, answer B is better since it explains all of the signs.

Question: While on placement with a community Midwife you meet an infant whose feet are pointed both downwards and inwards. Recognising the condition as clubfoot from your background reading in Langerman's Medical embryology you decide to further look into the condition. You discover:
OptionA: Clubfoot is a malformation caused by compression within the amniotic cavity
OptionB: Clubfoot is caused by a high calcium diet in the first trimester resulting in excess bone growth
OptionC: Clubfoot is an example of a disruption where the foot exits the amniotic sac early in the 2nd trimester and is constricted
OptionD: Clubfoot is a syndrome also associated with other symptoms including a tuft of hair behind the Calcaneal tendon and a spotting appearanceon the lateral side of the first toe
OptionE: Clubfoot is a deformity resulting from compression within the amniotic cavity
Explanation:
Clubfoot is an example of a deformity. Deformities result form mechanical forces acting on the fetus over a prolonged period which act to mold the anatomy in this case the amniotic cavity compressing the developing feet.

Malformations occur during the formation of structures that is organogenesis. theye can be caused by either environmental or genetic factors or a combination acting together. Most malformations have their origins in the 3rd-8th week of gestation.

Disruptions result from alterations to already preformed structures due to septructive processes such as amniotic band syndrome and limb amputations.

Syndromes are a pattern of malformations which occur in unison and are considered to have a known identified cause such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21). If the symptoms occur together but the cause is unknown they can be classed as an association which although does not provide a diagnosis allows sufferers and their families to find other like individuals

 

For reference either Dave Wilson's lecture 'congenital malformation and teratology' case 7 or Chapter 9 of Langerman's medical embryology

Question: A 25 year old nulliparous woman at 42/40 is given a vaginal PGE2 tablet in order to induce labour. What action does PGE2 have?
OptionA: Stimulates placental oestrogen secretion increasing myocardial contractility.
OptionB: Relaxes the smooth muscle allowing the cerix to dilate and the baby to descend.
OptionC: Increases gap junctions and stimulates the release of calcium ions causing muscle contractions, also it stimulates cervical softening and dilation known as ripening.
OptionD: Acts as an oxytocin agonist increasing its synthesis and therefore myocardial contractility and cervical dilation and sofetening known as ripening.
OptionE: Promotes relaxation of pelvic ligaments allowing the structures to stretch more easily and ease delivery.
Explanation: Prostaglandins are locally acting eicosnaoids theat regulate many bodily processes. Prostaglandin PGE2 is synthesized in the uterinje muscle cells in response to oxytocin. It increases gap junctions and stimulates the release of calcium ions causing muscular contractions in a si8milar fashion to oxytocin. PGE2 is also synthesized in the cervix where it stimulates cervical softenin and dilation known as ripening.

Question:
A 68-year-old man presents with severe central chest pain. The pain has been present for an hour, radiates down both arms and is not responding to sublingual nitrates. An ECG shows significant ST elevation in leads ii, iii and aVF.

 

What is the likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This man has classical symptoms of an acute myocardial infarction. The ECG shows ST elevation in the inferior leads, indicating an acute inferior myocardial infarction, which suggests right coronary artery involvement.
This patient should be given pain relief and treated immediately with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) or thrombolysis if PCI is not available.

 

References:
Kreines, K, (1957) Distribution of Pain in Myocardial Infarction. 15:348-352. Circulation.
Hampton, J. R.(2008). 150 ECG problems, Elsevier. Pg50.
NICE guidelines (2010). Chest pain of recent onset.

Question: Hazel Jones is a 9 year old has attended a busy school in Cardiff for the last year. However when she was 8 months old her parents joined the anti-vaccination campaign and she did not receive any further vaccinations. What is the most likely reason she hasn't developed measles, mumps or rubella?
OptionA: She picked up the attenuated strain of measles, mumps and rubella viruses contained in the vaccine from other children, and so developed immunity to these viruses.
OptionB: Hazel might be infected with measles, mumps or rubella but they have become latent infections.
OptionC: The vaccinations she received before 8 months of age can protect against measles, mumps and rubella.
OptionD: The majority of children in Hazel's nursery were vaccinated so this prevents Hazel from coming into contact with the viruses.
OptionE: The antibodies from her mother is providing protection to measles, mumps and rubella.
Explanation: Herd immunity has been established. This means that the infection cannot spread since there isn't a continuous chain of infection.

Question:
A patient suffers from bare lymphocyte syndrome, which means that they have a nonfunctioning TAP protein and as a result suffer from chronic respiratory infections. 

 

TAP is found on the endoplasmic reticulum and transports peptides. 

 

What is the immunological result of an non-functioning TAP protein?
OptionA: Low functioning CD4 cells as cells have very few MHC II molecules.
OptionB: Low functioning CD8 cells as cells have very few MHC I molecules
OptionC: Low functioning CD4 cells as cels have very few MHC I molecules
OptionD: Low functioning CD8 cells as cells have very few MHC II molecules
Explanation:
MHC I displays intracellular pathogens. 

Peptides that are formed in the cytosol are transported into the endoplasmic reticulum by TAP (Transporter associated with antigen processing)

Once in the ER it binds to the MHC I molecule, whilst it is part of a protein-loading complex

Once a complementary peptide binds to the MHC I molecule it is released from the protein-loading complex

The peptide:MHC I complex is then released from the ER in a membrane-bound vesicle before traveling through the Golgi stacks to the plasma membrane 

 

MHC Class II molecules are produced through a different intracellular pathway that doesn't include the ER or TAP protein so A is incorrect

B is correct.

MHC Class I molecules are expressed to CD8 cells so C is incorrect 

MHC Class II molecules are expressed to CD4 cells so D is incorrect

Question:
15 year old Milly has had type 1 diabetes for 7 years. She has not been going to clinic as she feels like she gets told off too much because of her poor diabetes control. Her mum finally manages to get her to go to clinic after not having been for 6 months. To find out how her diabetes control has been over the last few months, her HbA1c is measured.

 

The patient's HbA1c readings provides clinician with overall picture of average BGL over a period of weeks/months. This is done because measuring the amount of glucose that combines with the haemoglobin reflects the average blood glucose levels over that duration as it is directly proportional to the total amount of sugar that is in your system at that time. Just like haemoglobin, the amount of glycated albumin decreases when blood glucose levels are low and increases when blood glucose levels are high.

 

What is the best possible reason for why clinicians use the glycated haemoglobin over the glycated albumin?
OptionA: Albumin is more likely to bind to other molecules (unconjugated bilirubin, free fatty acids, drugs...), thus giving an inaccurate result
OptionB: Albumin doesn't bind as well to glucose as haemoglobin does. This would mean some high glucose episodes would not be picked up on.
OptionC: Albumin has a shorter half life than haemoglobin. As she hasn't been going to clinic for a while, testing the glycated albumin would only show the short-term changes in her average blood glucose levels.
OptionD: HbA1c is a better established test as it has been used much longer (since 1976!) than glycated albumin measurements.
OptionE: HbA1c is easier to measure as it is much bigger than albumin. Haemoglobin has 4 subunits. Each subunit has a molecular weight of about 16,000 daltons whereas albumin has a molecular weight of 62kDa.
Explanation: C is the correct answer.

Question: Margaret has developed anemia due to her folic acid deficiency. Which of the following types of anemia is she most likely to have?
Explanation:
• An MCV (mean cell volume) of 80- 100 is normal. In macrocytic anemia, the MCV is greater than 100. On the other hand, in microcytic anemia, the MCV is less than 80.
  • The correct answer is B. Folic acid deficiency leads to macrocytic anemia. The other deficiency that leads to macrocytic anemia is Vitamin B12 deficiency. Both folic acid and vitamin B12 are required for DNA synthesis. Thus, in the case of these deficiencies, DNA synthesis is impaired - the DNA which is required to instruct the RBCs to go further from the G2 phase into the M (mitosis) phase is unavailable. Therefore, the RBCs are 'stuck' in the G2 phase - they keep growing and hence we call it macrocytic anemia.
  • One of the causes of microcytic anemia is iron- deficiency.
  • If iron- deficiency (microcytic anemia) and folate deficiency (macrocytic anemia) are occurring simultaneously, the result could be normocytic anemia.
  • Sickle cell anemia, thalassemia etc lead to haemolytic anemia.

This question comes under Case 11 - maybe the Part II of this case. All information has been taken from a couple of Youtube videos.

 

Quick note: For this case, although 'an understanding of the different patterns of anemia' is required, we are not expected to know about anemia in great depth. For instance, we are not required to cover each type of haemolytic anemia in detail. All we are required to know is that certain vitamin deficiencies (.e.g folic acid or B12) or mineral deficiencies (iron) could lead to anemia; the anemia that folic acid deficiency produces is not the same as the anemia that iron deficiency produces - when you look underneath the microscope, the RBCs look different, of course, and the MCVs will be different. Coeliac disease is one of the gut conditions that could lead to anemia (micro or macro); the anemia is a result of the generalised malabsorption.

Question:
You perform thyroid function tests on a blood sample from a patient suffering with endocrinological symptoms. The test results come back as:

 

Lowered fT4 (free thyroxine)

Lowered fT3 (free triiodothyronine)

Elevated TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone)

 

 

Which thyroid condition does the patient have?
Explanation:
The tests measure free thyroid hormones in the blood, because some molecules are bound to other substances that are affected by physiological changes such as pregnancy.

 

Hyperthyroidism - the thyroid gland is in overdrive and producing too many thyroid hormones. Therefore fT4 and fT3 would both be elevated and TSH would be lowered due to negative feedback. 

 

TSH-Secreting Pituitary Adenoma - in this rare condition, a tumour secretes excess TSH (so TSH would be elevated). This TSH then stimulates the thyroid gland to produce more thyroid hormones, so fT4 and fT3 would also be elevated.

 

Primary Hypothyroidism - this is also called thyroid disease. The thyroid is underactive and therefore not producing enough thyroid hormones, so fT4 and fT3 are both lowered. TSH is elevated, however, in order to try and stimulate the thyroid to produce more T4 and T3.

 

Secondary Hypothyroidism - this is pituitary disease of the thyroid. Once again, the thyroid is underactive and not producing enough T4 and T3 (fT4 and fT3 are both lowered) but the cause is not within the thyroid gland itself, but because the pituitary gland is not producing enough TSH and therefore the thyroid gland is not being stimulated to produce its hormones. TSH is therefore also lowered in secondary hypothyroidism.

 

Sick Euthyroidism - as with secondary hypothyroidism, fT4, fT3 and TSH are all lowered. However, the cause here is systemic illness, and when the patient recovers from their illness then their thyroid function also recovers without thyroid treatment. The tests should be repeated after the patient's recovery in order to rule out secondary hypothyroidism.

Question: Elsie Cobbles, a 23 year old medical student, visits her GP after returning from her 8 week elective placement in East Africa. She is complaining of nausea and diarrhoea that started 4 days ago. The GP tells Elsie that she has contracted a protozoan infectious intestinal disease. What is the most common protozoan cause of IID in returning travellers?
Explanation:
Clostridium difficile is an anaerobic spore-forming Gram-positive bacterium, and is therefore not the cause of Elsie's infection. The organism is spread through the faeco-oral route.

 

Campylobacter is also a bacterial cause of infectious intestinal disease. It is a curved motile Gram-negative rod bacterium that is contracted through ingestion of contaminated food (usually chicken).

 

Rotavirus is a viral cause of IID, spread through the faeco-oral route.

 

Cryptosporidium is a protozoan cause of infectious intestinal disease, but it is not the most common cause in returning travellers. The disease used to be associated with AIDS because it is the most common cause of IID in immunocompromised patients. Transmission is through contaminated water.

 

Giardia is the correct answer - this is a worldwide protozoan cause of IID, which is the most commonly identified GI parasite around the world. Transmission is again through contaminated water.

 

Entamoeba histolytica and Cyclospora are two other protozoan causes of infectious intestinal disease.

 

 

Source: 'Infectious Diarrhoea' lecture in Case 11

Question: Mr Blake, a 40-year-old patient has just received the news that he has a disorder of his common myeloid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.  Which of the following is Least Likely be directly affected by this?
OptionA: Dendritic cell presentation of MHC to lymphocytes
OptionC: Macrophage recruitment of leucocytes to infected tissues through cytokine production
OptionD: Natural Killer cell recognition of IgG bound to virus-infected cells, leading to apoptotic cell death
Explanation:
The answer is the one involving Antibody-mediated cell mediated cytotoxicity whereby the Fc-gamma-RIII receptor on NK cells recognises the Fc portion of antibodies bound to infected cells leading to them being killed by apoptosis.  This process would not directly be affected by myeloid progenitor dysfunction, since both B cells, which produce antibodies and NK cells are from the common lymphoid precursor lineage.  However, this process could be affected as a downstream effect since presentation of antigen to B cells would be affected because dendritic cells are of the myeloid precursor lineage - specific antibody production would be impaired.

 

Each of the other alternatives directly involve cells from the common myeloid precursor lineage (Dendritic cells, Mast cells/basophils, Macrophages and Neutrophils respectively).

 

Sources: Parham, The Immune System, 3rd ed., Dr Matthews's lectures during case 9.

Question:
The arterial supply to the majority of the abdominal organs is from the three unpaired branches of the abdominal aorta: the coeliac trunk, superior mesenteric artery and inferior mesenteric artery. The areas that each artery supplies are related to their embryological origin. 

 

The superior mesenteric artery supplies the organs that originate from the embryological midgut. Which of the following abdominal organs is supplied by this artery, and therefore originates from the midgut?
Explanation:
The coeliac trunk supplies the embryological foregut, which comprises the oesophagus, stomach, proximal duodenum, liver, gallbladder, biliary tree and part of the pancreas.

 

The superior mesenteric artery supplies the embryological midgut which comprises the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, caecum and appendix, ascending colon, proximal 2/3rds of the transverse colon and part of the pancreas.

 

The inferior mesenteric artery supplies the embryological hindgut, which comprises the distal 1/3rd of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, proximal anal canal and rectum. 

 

 

Source: Essential Clinical Anatomy

Question: Owen Miller is taken to theatre after being involved in an RTC. He has lost a lot of blood and is in need of a blood transfusion. If Owen has blood group A-, what type(s) can he receive?
Explanation:
The ABO blood group system was discovered by Landsteiner in 1901.

 

The A and B genes encode enzymes called transferases, which transfer the appropriate sugars onto substance H, resulting in A and B antigens respectively. If a patient has neither A nor B genes, then neither antigen A nor antigen B will be present on the surface of their red blood cells. Patients with these genetics have blood group O. Within the serum of individuals, there are naturally occurring IgM antibodies to the antigens that are not present on their red blood cells. Therefore patients with blood group O have antibodies to antigen A and antigen B, and will attack any red blood cells containing these antigens. Patients with blood group O can therefore only receive blood from donors with the same blood type, whilst patients with blood group AB can donate to any blood group. 

 

The -ve sign refers to the Rhesus D blood grouping. Owen is RhD- because his blood group is A-. This means that his blood serum contains antibodies against the RhD antigen and if he were to receive RhD+ blood, his body would destroy it. All patients with RhD- blood must receive RhD- blood transfusions.

 

 

 

Source: 'Blood Groups' lecture in Case 8

Question:
This drug is used in cases of treatment resistant schizophrenia. It is usually effective, but carries significant potential ADRs, including agranulocytosis. 

 

What is it, and what is its class?
Explanation:
Citalopram is a SSRI, typically used as a first line drug for depression.

 

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic, usually used as a first line drug for schizophrenia.

 

Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic, effective in resistant cases of schizophrenia, but carries more risks than other antipsychotics.

 

Mesalazine is an aminosalicylate anti-inflammatory drug used in the treatment of IBD.

Question: Mr Davis is a 59 year old man from the welsh valleys. He has recently been prescribed warfarin as he has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. He comes to see you with an article from the Daily Mail with the headline "Novel Oral Anticoagulants - the new wonder drug". Mr Davis wants to know why he hasn't been prescribed Dabigatran, one of the drugs mentioned in the article, as it sounds much better than what he's on. You tell him that you are reluctant to start Mr Davis on Dabigatran rather than warfarin because....
OptionA: They are contraindicated in patients with atrial fibrillation.
OptionB: They may have many unknown adverse drug reactions.
OptionC: There is no known antidote for them and they are relatively new drugs with unknown adverse drug reactions.
OptionD: They can only be given if Mr Davis has a CHADS-VASC score of 4.
OptionE: The Daily Mail has yet again published a scientifically inaccurate article.
Explanation:
Dabigatran is classed as a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC) and directly inhibits thrombin. Apixaban and Rivaroxaban also belong to this class but inhibit factor Xa directly.

 

C is the correct answer.

 

A) Dabigatran is not contraindictaed in patient with atrial fibrillation. It has been licensed for: i) prophylaxis of venous thromboembolism in patients after hip or total knee replacement surgery and ii) for the prevention of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation. 

B) True however...

C) Is the single best answer as NOAC's also have no known antidote in the case of overdose.

D) Incorrect

E) Could also be argued to be true but is not the single best answer.

Question:
You give a woman in labour an opioid via the intramuscular route and this leads to an irritated baby that does not feel well. 

What is the most common opioid that we have learnt about given by this route that is a moderate analgesic?

What is the reversal agent that would be administered if the depression of the neonate was too severe?
Explanation:
A- incorrect, pethidine is an opioid not a reversal agent

B- incorrect, norpethidine is the active metabolite of pethidine that has a t1/2 of 20 hours in the mother but 60 hours in the fetus. 

C- Correct :D! 

D- Naloxone is a reversal agent not an opioid

 

Source - Labour Analgesia lecture in case 8

Question:
You are a year 4 medical student on psychiatry placement. A patient presents to you for the second time, after having an episode of mania last year. The patient informs you that they have been well since recovering from their manic episode, however over the last week the patient has been feeling extremely low, finds that they have a lack of energy and have lost interest in the things they enjoy. 

 

After the consultation the doctor you are shadowing informs you that the patient will be diagnosed with Bipolar Affective Disorder (BPAD), and asks you to write down the nomenclature of the diagnosis. Which of the following correctly describes this patients diagnosis?
OptionE: BPAD type 2, current episode mixed affective state.
Explanation:
BPAD diagnosis requires at LEAST 2 episodes of mood disorder, with recovery usually occurring in between episodes. The nomenclature for BPAD diagnosis is; BPAD type X, current episode X. 

 

BPAD 1 - One episode MUST be mania. Plus episodes of; depression, hypomania or affective state.

BPAD 2 - One episode MUST be HYPOmania. Plus episodes of depression / hypomania. BPAD 2 can NOT include episodes of mania or mixed affective states. 

 

A - Incorrect ( patient is obviously suffering a depressive episode, so although BPAD 1 is correct, current episode is incorrect) 

B - Incorrect ( patient has had PREVIOUS episode of MANIA, therefore cannot be BPAD 2)

C - Incorrect ( again, previous episode of mania excludes BPAD 2 and current episode is not mania.)

D - CORRECT ( Patients previous episode or mania indicates type 1 BPAD, whilst their symptoms are the 3 core symptoms of depression.)

E - Incorrect ( BPAD 2 DOES NOT include episodes of mania or mixed affective state and therefore this is obviously incorrect.)

Question:
A 17 year old male attends the hospital presenting with lower back pain. The pain usually spreads across the lower back, and feels like a muscle strain. The pain is worse with vigorous exercise or activity. After an X-Ray the patient is found to have a fracture in the L5 vertebrae. The fracture is in the region pointed to by the arrow. He has no neurological symptoms.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Spondylolisthesis: The forward displacement of a vertebra, especially the fifth lumbar vertebra, most commonly occurring after a break or fracture. Backward displacement is referred to as retrolisthesis.

 

Spondylolysis: A defect in the pars interarticularis vertebra (Shown by the arrow). Most commonly occurs in the L5 vertebrae but can occur in both the lumbar and thoracic vertebrae. Although it commonly occurs in after repetitive trauma during strenuous sport, studies have shown a strong genetic link.

 

Spondylolytic Spondylolisthesis: Spondylolysis which results in spondylolisthesis

 

Spondylosis: Pain caused by degenerative changes in the spine

 

Spondylitis: Inflammation of the spine

 

The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Spondylolysis. If neurological symptoms had been present a complication of spondylolysis could have occurred called Spondylolytic Spondylolisthesis.
Tags: Anatomy, Birth Defects, Neurology, Genetics, Case 14

Question:
Mr Moody, a 19 year old medical student presents to his GP. He tells his GP that over the last few weeks (3-4weeks) he has not been feeling himself. He explains how he feels down all the time, and has lost interest in his hobbies such as playing rugby and going to the Lash (aka YOLO).

 

When further questioned he describes how he has a sudden loss of concentration and attention throughout all aspects of his day. He also informs his GP that he has stopped eating due to a lack of appetite and is not sleeping at all. 

 

His GP tells Mr Moody that he is experiencing a depressive episode however which type of episode is he experiencing?
Explanation:
Mr Moody is experiencing an episode of MODERATE depression, showing 2 core symptoms (anhedonia and persistent low mood) and 3 associated symptoms (loss of appetite, insomnia, loss of attention/concentration). The ICD-10 states that for an episode to be classed as depression the symptoms need to be present for 2 weeks or more.

 

Mild - 2 core + 2 associated

Moderate - 2 core + 3 associated

Severe - 3 core + 4 associated.

Severe with psychosis - Severe + mood congruent delusions/pyschomotor change/ perceptual abnormalities.

Dysthmia - Milder form of depression, with long-term low moods - present for 2 years or more (ICD10)

Question: A 35 year old G2 P2 has two children both of whom have Down syndrome. Karyotyping of the father reveals a no abnormalities and of the mother reveals a Robersonian translocation between 21:21 what is the likelihood of any subsequent children having Down syndrome?
OptionB: ~1% or maternal age risk if greater
OptionC: ~10% or maternal age risk if higher
Explanation:
In Robersonain translocation of 21:21 all children will either inherit no maternal copies of chromosome 21 which will result in monosomy 21 a non viable outcome or will inherit the two fused maternal copies of 21 and another copy from the father resulting in trisomy 21 and Down syndrome. 

The most common translocation resulting in Down syndrome is that between 14 and 21 and can have a number of outcomes for future offsrping if assuin the other parent is normal:

  1. viable:
  • normal 14,14,21,21
  • normal carrier 14,14/21,21
  • Down syndrome 14,14/21,21,21
  1. non viable
  • monosmy 21
  • monosmy 14
  • trisomy 14

               The risk of recurrence

  • non disjunction-1% or age related risk if higher, 10% after 2 T21 pregnancies
  • translocation-10-15% dependent on translocation, low if the transloaction occurs in he male possibly as it is selectively disadvantageous, 100% if 21:21 as the offspring can only inherit either monosomy 21 therefore non viable or trisomy 21 therefore Down syndrome
  • mosaicism-1-2% or are related risk if higher

All information taken from Dr Andrew Fry's plenary in case 7 plenaries
Tags: Screening, Development, Birth Defects, Embryology, Genetics

Question: Which of these statements is true for the early antibodies in a newborn?
OptionA:
IgA is passed onto the infant in breast milk

IgG is the first antibody to start being made by the infant's own immune system and responsible for early stage of immunity.

IgM is transferred to the infant in utero via the placenta
OptionB:
IgA is passed onto the infant in breast milk
IgG is transferred to the infant in utero via the placenta
IgM is the first antibody to start being made by the infant's own immune system and responsible for early stage of immunity.
OptionC:
IgA is the first antibody to start being made by the infant's own immune system and responsible for early stage of immunity.
IgG is passed onto the infant in breast milk 
IgM is transferred to the infant in utero via the placenta
OptionD:
IgA is transferred to the infant in utero via the placenta

IgG is the first antibody to start being made by the infant's own immune system and responsible for early stage of immunity.
IgM is passed onto the infant in breast milk
OptionE:
IgA is transferred to the infant in utero via the placenta
IgG is passed onto the infant in breast milk
IgM is the first antibody to start being made by the infant's own immune system and responsible for early stage of immunity.
Explanation:
IgA: found in mucous, saliva, tears and breast milk. Protects against pathogens

IgD: part of the B cell receptor, activate basophils and mast cells

IgE: Protects against parasitic worms, responsible for allergic infections

IgG: Secreted by plasma cells in the blood. Able to cross the placenta into the foetus

IgM: May be attached to surface of B cell or secreted into the blood. Responsible for the early stages of immunity.

Question: Which of these foetal structures is obliterated, becoming the ligament (labelled as 7) of the liver after birth?
Explanation:
The umbilical vein (extra-hepatic portion of umbilical vein) will be obliterated after birth forming the round ligament (also known as ligamentum teres/ ligamentum teres hepatis).

The round ligament is a degenerative string of tissue that exists in the free edge of the falciform ligament of the liver. Anatomically, the round ligament divides the left part of the liver into medial and lateral sections.

Ductus venosus (also known as the intrahepatic portion of the umbilical vein) is obliterated to form the ligament venosum.

Both the left and right umbilical arteries proximal portions will form the umbilical branches of internal iliac arteries. Their  distal portions

will form the edial umbilical ligaments (medial)


In the anatomy practical I think we are only expected to know that the umbilical arteries will form the umbilical ligaments, the umbilical veins will form the round ligament and the ductus venosus forms the ligament venosum.

Here is a good link: http://www.med.umich.edu/lrc/coursepages/m1/embryology/embryo/18changesatbirth.htm

Question: Your patient requires a radical mastectomy to remove a breast cancer. During their surgery a nerve particular nerve is vulnerable to injury leading to which of these symptoms?
OptionA: An intense, sharp, shooting pain is felt in the chest, which radiates from the front to the back
Explanation:
The nerve that is most likely to be damaged by this procedure is the long thoracic nerve

A is likely to be due to an intercostal neuralgia

B is the most common sign/symptom of a phrenic nerve palsy

C is unlikely is as damage to the thoracic nerve will not usually be asymptomatic

D Waitors tip due to an Erp's palsy, paralysis of the arm caused by injury to the upper group of the arm's main nerves, specifically the severing of the upper trunk C5–C6 nerves.

E is the correct answer as this nerve evolves from the roots of neck vertebrae (C5-C7) and supplies to serratus anterior muscle that retains the scapula bone to the chest wall. May also have shoulder pain and reduced over head activity

 

I doubt we would have to know all of these conditions other than ones we have studied previously but I needed to find some other plausible answers.  A very similar question was in the anatomy practical in case 8

Question:
In case 8 we took part in a haematology practical to find out a patient's blood ABO and D typing. 
If your results were as follows:

 

  • Patient 3% PBS red cells were mixed with Anti-A, Anti-B and Anti-A,B reagents. Your results showed agglutination with Anti-A,B and marked agglutination with Anti-B. There was no agglutination with Anti-A. 
  • Patient plasma was mixed with Group A cells, Group B cells and their own RBCs (as a control). Your results showed agglutination with A cells but not with B cells.
  • Patients 3% PBS red cells were mixed with Anti-D reagent and there is no agglutination.
  • You carry out controls alongside these reactions which reacted appropriately.

 

 What blood group is the patient?
Explanation:
With this testing, agglutination will occur when antibodies in patient's plasma react with the corresponding antigen on the mixing blood cells or when antigens on her RBCs are mixed with corresponding antibodies the their RBC antigens. 

Because the patient's blood clotted with Anti-B antibodies this would suggest their RBCs have the B antigen

Because the results shows agglutination with the A cells, their blood must contain the Anti-A antibody therefore reacting with the A cell antigen.

This would mean her ABO blood group is B. 

 

Rh positive and Rh negative refer to the presence of the D antigen only. Her blood showed no agglutination with the Anti-D antibodies, therefore her blood does not contain the D antigen on her RBCs. This makes her blood type B- 

 

This is an extremely rare blood type, they can only receive blood from B- or O- donors. 

This patient, if female, should not be given D+ blood as this will sensitize her to the D antigen, therefore causing her to produce Anti-D antibodies. If she we to then conceive a child with a D+ father, the child may inherit the Rh factor from the father making them D+, because the mothers blood is already sensitized to the antigen her antibodies (IgG) will cross the placenta and react against the foetus. This sensitisation can occur anytime the foetus' blood is mixed with the mothers e.g. if she has an antenatal haemorrhage or has subsequent children that are also D+
Tags: Reproduction, Blood Groups, Haematology, Case 8, Pregnancy

Question: While in for routine maternal health checks a sample of blood is taken for typing. It is found that the sample agglutinated in the presence of Anti-B and Anti-D, no changes was seen in the presence of anti-A. Which ABO blood group is she and should she require a transfusion from which of the blood groups can she act as a recipient?
OptionB: A+: O-, O+, A-, A+
OptionE: AB+: O-, O+, A-, A+, B-, B+, AB-, AB+

Question: A 32 year old primigravida presents to health care services in her 17th week of pregnancy. Due to her late presentation she is offered the 2nd trimester quadruple screening test with results revealing there is a high risk of the baby being trisomic for chromosome 21, how would you expect the levels of the markers to deviate from that of the expected norm?
Explanation:
A INCORRECT These are the markers used for the combines screening test (11-13weeks 6days)

B INCORRECT These are the markers used in the cmbined test and would expect PAPP-A to be decreased and beta-hCG to be increased

C INCORRECT These are the correct biomakers but not the expected levels

D CORRECT CORRECT!!!

E INCORRECT Again correct biomarkers at the incorrect levels 

 

Combined test:

  • 11weeks-13 weeks 6days
  • nuchal translucency
  • PAPP-A
  • beta-hCG

Quadruple test

  • 14 weeks 2 days-20 weeks
  • beta-hCG
  • uE3
  • inhibin-A
  • AFP
  1. PAPP-A produced by placental syncytiotrphoblasts, levels decreased in trisomy 21
  2. beta-hCG produced by placental syncytiotrophoblasts, levels increased in trisomy 21
  3. AFP produced by feotal yolk sac and liver, levels decreased in trisomy 21
  4. uE3 produced by placenta and foetal adrenals, levels decreased in trisomy 21
  5. inhibin-A produced by placenta, levels increased in trisomy 21
Tags: Chromosomal Abnormalities, Investigations, Risk Factors, Screening, Biochemistry

Question: For autosomal recesssive disease X 1/10,000 are affected, what is the population carrier frequency?
Explanation:
frequency X = p

frequency x = q

 

p2+2pq+q2=1

 

q has the disease (square root 1/10,000)

q = 1/100

q has the diesease p doesn't therefore if q=1/100 p=99/100

2pq is the carrier frequency (2*1/100*99/100)= 198/10,000=~1/50
Tags: Risk Factors, Genetics, Case 7, Public Health

Question:
A 50-year-old man had been suffering from depression for some years. His condition was treated with _______. He developed a severe, throbbing headache and his blood pressure was found to be 200/110 mmHg. The only unusual occurrence had been that he had attended a cocktail party the previous evening at which he ate cheese snacks and drank several glasses of red wine.

 

What type of antidepressant was he taking?
Explanation:
The patient was experiencing a hypertensive crisis caused by an interaction between the food he had eaten and the drug he was treated with – a MAO inhibitor. This drug inhibits the main enzyme that catabolizes catecholamines. Several foods, including cheese, pickled herring and red wine, contain an amine called tyramine, which is similar in structure to natural amine transmitters and is also broken down by MAO. If this enzyme is not functional, the concentrations of tyramine increase and it starts to act as a neurotransmitter. This can cause a hypertensive crisis, as it did in this patient.

 

Source: Medical Biochemistry - Baynes and Dominiczak

Question: Luke is a 17 year old male who has been diagnosed with depression. You decide to prescribe him some medication to help relieve some of the symptoms that he is experiencing. What would be your first choice of drug treatment?
Explanation:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin re-uptake inhibtor (SSRI) and is the only SSRI licensed for use in adolescents as others can cause the individual to develop suicidal thoughts.

 

Citalopram = another SSRI

Venlafaxine = SSNRI

Moclobemide = MAOI

Amitrytptilline = TCA

Question:
In case 9 we heard that the infant Ruby Ola had developed a rash and a fever. Whilst on placement a mother brings in her child with the following rash

.

What kind of rash does this most look like?
Explanation:
This image shows a small boy with a violent case of chicken pox (they don't all get it this bad). Chickenpox (varicella), a viral illness characterised by a very itchy red rash, is one of the most common infectious diseases of childhood. It is usually mild in children but there is a risk of serious complications, such as bacterial pneumonia.

Note the reddest pox just above his belly button, you can see they're shiny and just about to ooze. 

Chickenpox appears as a very itchy rash that spreads from the torso to the neck, face and limbs. Lasting seven to 10 days, the rash progresses from red bumps to fluid-filled blisters (vesicles) that drain and scab over and drop off. Vesicles may also appear in the mouth, on the scalp, around the eyes or on the genitals and can be very painful. The initial infection generally starts as a fever, followed by cold symptoms and the rash.

This cycle repeats itself in new areas of the body until finally, after about two weeks, all of the sores have healed. The disease is contagious until all the spots have dried up. Unfortunately, the virus is also contagious for at least one day before the rash breaks out.

 

http://www.medicinenet.com/skin_pictures_child_pictures_slideshow/article.htm

This link is has a really good summary and some pictures of common rashes. 

 

Heat Rash ('Prickly Heat'):
Young babies often get heat rash. Blocked sweat glands cause heat rash, which results in a red pimply eruption on the head and neck. It's important to dress your infant appropriately (not too hot and not too cold) to prevent the eruption. Generally, heat rash resolves on its own.

Impetigo:

Impetigo can be confused with other skin infections, including cellulitis (a deeper infection) and even ringworm. Common bacteria found on the skin cause impetigo, and antibiotics easily treat impetigo. The rash itself looks oozy, blistery, and red initially and then may develop a yellowish crust. It spreads by contact, and scratching makes it worse. Impetigo can occur anywhere on the body, but it's commonly found around the mouth and nose.

Molluscum contagiosum (MC):

MC is a viral infection that affects the skin. It most commonly affects children, although it can occur at any age.
Usually, the only symptom of MC is a number of small, firm, raised papules (spots) that develop on the skin. They are not painful, but can be itchy.
Although the spots can look unpleasant, MC is generally a harmless condition that will normally resolve in a few months without any specific treatment.

Utricaria (hives):

Hives are the result of an allergic reaction. They appear as small red itchy bumps or welts, which may be painful as well. Exposure to an allergen, such as a food or medicine, may cause hives. Some common allergies include nuts, eggs, and shellfish, but certain viruses can also cause hives. Although hives alone are not dangerous, if your child develops breathing troubles, including cough and wheezing along with the hives, it might signal a more serious allergic reaction requiring immediate medical attention. Antihistamines are the standard treatment for hives.

Here is a really great algorithm for diagnosing rashes from Patient.co.uk, below I have defined some of the terms used in the algorithm:

 

Papular = A papule is a circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to 1 cm. They can be brown, purple, pink or red in color, and can cluster into a papular rash

Blanch/Blanching rash = will disappear when you press on it

Pustule: A pustule is a small collection of pus in the top layer of skin (epidermis) or beneath it in the dermis. Pustules frequently form in sweat glands or hair follicles. Pus is a mixture of inflammatory cells and liquid

Vesiculobullous rash: A vesiculobullous disease is a type of mucocutaneous disease that is characterized by vesicles and bullae (i.e. blisters). Both vesicles and bullae are fluid-filled lesions, and they are distinguished by size (vesicles being less than 5-10 mm and bulla being larger than 5-10 mm, depending upon what definition is used).

A papulosquamous disorder is a condition which presents with both papules and scales, or both scaly papules and plaques. Examples include psoriasis, lichen planus, and pityriasis rosea.

Purpuric: purplish discoloration of the skin produced by small bleeding vessels near the surface.

Question: A 23 year old female presents to you in A&E with severe diarrhoea, abdominal pain and dehydration. She has just returned from India and you suspect this may be an infection of cholera by the bacteria vibrio cholerae. In regards to her diarrhoea, which type is caused by the bacterium vibrio cholerae?
Explanation:
A - Osmotic diarrhoea - Not caused by cholera. This results from either ingestion of poorly absorbed substrate, or malabsorption of a substrate.

 

The answer is B - secretory diarrhoea.

Large volumes of water are normally secreted into the small intestinal lumen, but a large majority of this water is efficienty absorbed before reaching the large intestine. Diarrhea occurs when secretion of water into the intestinal lumen exceeds absorption.

 

Many millions of people have died of the secretory diarrhea associated with cholera. The responsible organism, Vibrio cholerae, produces cholera toxin, which strongly activates adenylyl cyclase, causing a prolonged increase in intracellular concentration of cyclic AMP within crypt enterocytes. This change results in prolonged opening of the chloride channels that are instrumental in secretion of water from the crypts, allowing uncontrolled secretion of water. Additionally, cholera toxin affects the enteric nervous system, resulting in an independent stimulus of secretion.

 

C - Infectious/inflammatory diarrhoea - Not caused by cholera. Disruption of the epithelium of the intestine due to microbial or viral pathogens is a very common cause of diarrhea in all species. Destruction of the epithelium results not only in exudation of serum and blood into the lumen but often is associated with widespread destruction of absorptive epithelium. In such cases, absorption of water occurs very inefficiently and diarrhea results. Examples of such infections come from E.coli, Campylobacter, and rotavirus.

 

D Immotility diarrhoea - Not caused by cholera. Disorders in motility that accelerate transit time could decrease absorption, resulting in diarrhea even if the

absorptive process per se was proceeding properly.

 

Source: http://www.vivo.colostate.edu/hbooks/pathphys/digestion/smallgut/diarrhea.html
Tags: Case 11, Gastrointestinal System, Case 3, Infectious Intestinal Disease

Question:
A 38 year old male presents with morning stiffness and pain in lower back/buttocks which improves on exercise. He has has a history of chronic back pain which also sometimes wakes him up during the night.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
A - Spondylosis - This is a condition which refers to the degenerative osteoarthritis of the joints between the spinal vertebrae/ facet joints. As it progresses the patient does have a stiff back/restricted movement. Pain is worse in the morning and evening BUT is made worse with extended activity

 

B - Herniates IV disk - Usually occurs in the L4/L5 OR L5/S1 vertebrae. Although it usually occurs in men and aged 30-50 the pain is of sudden onset, whilst twisting or lifting heavy objects. Also the pain is usually relieved with lying down flat.

 

C - Spondylolisthesis - Is a complication of spondylosis where there is a defect in the pars interarticularis which makes it become detached. This can then cause the vertebrae to slip out of place. Symptoms include lower back pain when standing or on activity, tenderness, stiffness and tingling radiating down legs.

 

D - Ankylosing spondylitis - The CORRECT answer - The symptoms fit within the classifications which is chronic back pain accompanied with 3/4 of the following - morning stiffness, improvement of pain with exercise, awakening at night because of pain, alternating buttock pain. Is characterised by inflammation of the spine, fusing of the sacroiliac joints which can progress to most of the spine (bamboo spine) and maintained lumbar lordosis in flexion. ALSO usually presents in patients under 50

 

E - Quada Equina Syndrome - Is caused by compression of the nerves in the cauda equina. Symptoms include 1 or more of the following: bladder dysfunction (urinary retention in 50-70%), reduced sensation in perineal area, sexual dysfunction, neurological defects in the lower limb.

Question:
A patient presents to the casualty unit after being shot in the back. After he has been treated and stabilized you talk to the patient and check his sensory functions. He cannot identify exactly where he is being touched on his right leg and cannot feel the prick of a needle on his left leg.

What is the most diagnosis and where has the bullet caused damage?
OptionA: Central Cord syndrome - lesion to centre of spinal cord
OptionB: Brown Sequard syndrome - lesion to right side of spinal cord
OptionC: Anterior Cord syndrome - lesion to anterior part of spinal cord
OptionD: Posterior Cord syndrome- lesion to posterior part of spinal cord
OptionE: Brown Sequard syndrome - lesion to left side of spinal cord
Explanation:
The correct answer is B - the patient has a lesion on the right hand side of his spinal cord caused by the bullet. He cannot feel exactly where he is being touched on his right leg as he has lost ipsilateral tactile sensation and proprioception - Supplied by the dorsal column medial lemniscal pathway which diccusates in the medulla.

He cannot feel pain on the contralateral side as that's supplied by the lateral spinothalamic tract which decussates at the level of the spinal cord.

Question: You are in a nursing home where you have been chatting to Mary - a 77 year old resident. You are watching the Great British Bake Off in the lounge with her when Mary recalls fondly of when she baked a 5 tier lemon drizzle cake for her best friends wedding anniversary. This is an example of what type of memory?
Explanation:
Mary is recalling about a personal experience in her memory and this is therefore an example of episodic memory.

 

Long term memories can be either declarative (memory with conscious recall) or non-declarative (memory without conscious recall.) Semantic and episodic memory are examples of declarative memory whilst procedural and classically conditioned memories are examples of non-declarative memory. Although declarative memory is an answer, episodic is the SBA and is therefore correct.

 

Semantic memory - recalling facts and figures.

Episodic memory - recalling on personal experiences.

Procedural memory - motor skills and habits e.g. brushing teeth.

Classically Conditioned memory - phobias

 

Case 6 - Andrew Lawrence Lecture
