Question: Still at Mary's baking workshop, you have managed to create something with a similar appearance to mud and are at a loss to how you will ever recover from this shameful bake. On the other hand, John, the local star baker opposite you has created perfect brownies. You had been admiring his whisking technique and pondered about how he remembers to perform this skill so perfectly. John's whisking technique is an example of what type of memory?
Explanation:
John's ability to whisk is an example of procedural memory - the ability to perform motor skills and habits without conscious recall.

 

Long term memories can be either declarative (memory with conscious recall) or non-declarative (memory without conscious recall.) Semantic and episodic memory are examples of declarative memory whilst procedural and classically conditioned memories are examples of non-declarative memory.

 

Explicit memory is synonymous with declarative memory.

Semantic memory - recalling facts and figures.
Episodic memory - recalling on personal experiences.
Procedural memory - motor skills and habits e.g. brushing teeth.
Classically Conditioned memory - phobias

 

Case 6 - Andrew Lawrence Lecture

Question: 45 year old Rhodri is now back to his old self following treatment for his Cushings and his leeks are back to their former glory ready for he giant vegetable competition in 2 weeks time. However disaster has struck again, as Rhodri was bent down to pull up a pesky dandelion his felt something 'go'. He now has pain, numbness and a tingling sensation that radiates from his lower back and travels down his left leg to his foot and toes. What has most likely happened to poor Rhodri?
Explanation:
A. Avulsion fracture 

  • An avulsion fracture is an injury to the bone in a location where a tendon or ligament attaches to the bone.
  • When an avulsion fracture occurs, the tendon or ligament pulls off a piece of the bone.
  • Avulsion fractures can occur anywhere in the body, but they are more common in a few specific locations.
  • Avulsion fractures are more common in children than adults.
  • In adults, the ligaments and tendons tend to be injured first but in children the bone may fail before the ligament or tendon is injured.

B. Cervical disk herniation

  • Arm pain from a cervical herniated disc is one of the more common cervical spine conditions.
  • It usually develops in the 30-50 year old age group.
  • Although a cervical herniated disc may originate from some sort of trauma or injury to the cervical spine, the symptoms commonly start spontaneously.
  • If your herniated disk is in your neck, the pain will typically be most intense in the shoulder and arm.
  • This pain may shoot into your arm or leg when you cough, sneeze or move your spine into certain positions.

C. Lumbar disk herniation

  • Leg pain (sciatica), which may occur with or without lower back pain. Typically the leg pain is worse than the lower back pain.
  • Numbness, weakness and/or tingling in the leg
  • Lower back pain and/or pain in the buttock
  • When the sciatic nerve is compressed or irritated, it can cause pain, numbness and a tingling sensation that radiates from your lower back and travels down one of your legs to your foot and toes.
  • Onset matches the sudden symptoms Rhodri is experiencing

D. Osteoporosis

  • Osteoporosis develops slowly over several years.
  • There are often no warning signs or symptoms until a minor fall or a sudden impact causes a bone fracture.
  • Healthy bones should be able to withstand a fall from standing height, so a bone that breaks in these circumstances is known as a fragility fracture.
  • The most common injuries in people with osteoporosis are:
  • wrist fractures, hip fractures, fractures of the spinal bones (vertebrae)
  • Sometimes a cough or sneeze can cause a rib fracture or the partial collapse of one of the bones of the spine.

E. Spondylosis

  • Spondylosis is a term referring to degenerative osteoarthritis of the joints between the center of the spinal vertebrae and/or neural foramina.
  • If this condition occurs in the zygapophysial joints, it can be considered facet syndrome.
  • If severe, it may cause pressure on nerve roots with subsequent sensory and/or motor disturbances, such as pain, paresthesia, or muscle weakness in the limbs.
  • It is typically age related wear and tear

Although some of the other conditions named share similar symptoms it is most likely disk herniation due to the onset and mechanism of injury, the fact that the leg is affected and not the arm indicted the herniation is in the lumbar region

Question:
A patient needs to receive 4mg/kg of a drug IV over the course of 4 hours, as a concentrate of 0.1mg/ml in isotonic saline.  

 

The patient weighs 80kg.  What should the drip rate be set at in ml/min?
Explanation:
There are a couple of routes to getting to the answer here, firstly:

4mg/kg x 80kg patient = 320mg in total needs to be given

320mg / 0.1mg/ml concentration = 3200ml of saline as a diluent

Being spread across 4 hours = 240 minutes: 3200/240 = 13.333 ml/min

 

Alternatively, though less directly:

4mg/kg / 0.1mg/ml = 40ml/kg of saline for each kilogram of patient

40ml/kg / 240 minutes = 0.1667 mg/kg/min

0.1667 x 80kg patient = 13.333ml/min

Question:
Mr Goldberg has been referred for a sigmoidoscopy as his GP believes that he may have inflammatory bowel disease. He has been experiencing episodic bouts of diarrhoea ( > 6 times a day) with increased urgency, and the bowel movements have blood. Additionally, Mr Goldberg also has crampy abdominal pain.

 

The endoscopy produces the image below.

 

 

Which option best describes Mr Goldberg's symptoms?
Explanation:
Considering both the stated symptoms and the endoscopy, Option D is the correct answer.

 

Symptoms

- Episodic or chronic diarrhoea is a common symptom of Inflammatory Bowel Disease, however the presence of blood makes it far more likely to be UC than Crohn's which is why Option E is incorrect.

- The OHCM states that more than 6 bowel motions per day is associated with severe ulcerative colitis (4 or fewer for mild; 4-6 for moderate)

- Crampy abdominal pain is another common symptom of IBD

 

Endoscopy

In the normal colon, the mucosa should be a shiny, pale pink and retain a delicate, reticulated vascular pattern (like a network of small vessels).

 

Mild ulcerative colitis:

- Dull and red mucosa

- “Granular” or fine sandpaper-like texture

- The veiny vascular pattern is obscured

 

Moderate ulcerative colitis:

- Pitting of the mucosa is seen

- The lining may crumble away and bleed at the lightest touch (friability).

 

Severe ulcerative colitis:

- Macro-ulceration

- Mucopurulent exudate (i.e. mucus and pus)

- Spontaneous haemorrhage

 

The image above features exudate as well as clear signs of haemorrhage.
Tags: Imaging, Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Case 11, Gastrointestinal System, Case 3

Question: A new test to screen for pulmonary embolism (PE) is used in 100 patients who present to the Emergency Department. The test is positive in 30 of the 40 patients who are proven to have a PE. Of the remaining 60 patients, only 5 have a positive test. What is the sensitivity of the new test?
Explanation: The answer is E - 75% because the question is asking for the sensitivity of the test i.e. the proportion of patients with the condition who have a positive test result. so that's 30/40 which is 75%
Tags: Maths, Year 1 Revision, Evidence Based Medicine

Question: The following ECG trace has an abnormality present. What condition is this abnormality associated with?
Explanation: The abnormality is the slurred upstroke of the QRS complex, known as a delta wave. This is a finding which is used to diagnose WPW syndrome.

Question: You are working in A+E when a 20 year old female comes in with symptoms indicative of Diabetic Ketoacidosis. You recall that this is a medical emergency and begin treatment. However you forget to add potassium to your 0.9% sodium chloride IV infusion. What could be the outcome of this?
OptionC: Nothing if the patient was not hypokalaemic on admission
Explanation:
A- This is incorrect as the patient will be Hypokalaemic due to low insulin levels and acidosis driving potassium out of the cells and then osmotic diuresis and possible vomiting leading to hypokalaemia. 

B- Correct as hypokalaemia is associated with long QT syndrome which can cause torsades de pointes

C- Even if the patient was hyperkalaemic on admission with Sodium chloride infusion and insulin infusion which is likely to drive potassium into the cells the patient will become hypokalaemic

D- Incorrect , even though hyperkalaemia is associated with complete heart block the patient will not be hyperkalaemic for reasons stated above

E- Incorrect as hypokalaemia is associated with long QT not complete heart block. 

 

Sources - Management of DKA found on learning central and the clinical features of arrhythmias from case 13.

Question: A 42-year-old man has had severe headaches for 2 weeks. The result of a computed tomographic scan of his head shows a meningioma that is blocking the intracranial opening of the foramen rotundum. A neurological examination would most likely demonstrate a lack of response from which of the following?
OptionA: Pain receptors in the membrane of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity
OptionB: Pain receptors in the mucous membrane of the ethmoidal sinuses
OptionC: Pain receptors in the skin of the chin
Explanation:
The answer is A - The clue is in the questions where it says that the foramen rotundum is obstructed, thereby compressing the cranial nerve that goeexits through here. The foramen rotundum is an opening in the middle cranial fossa through which the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve [V] passes. The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve carries sensory fibers from the middle part of the face, including the lateral wall and the septum of the nasal cavity. Thus, a tumor blocking the opening of the foramen rotundum would compress the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve [V], causing a lack of response from pain receptors in the membrane of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

http://teachmeanatomy.info/wp-content/uploads/The-Cutaneous-or-Sensory-Distribution-to-the-Head-and-Neck.png

Question: Which is the insulin-regulated Glucose transporter?
Explanation:
GLUT 4 is primarily found in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue and is the only one which interacts with insulin. Higher levels of insulin result in greater uptake by these transporters, hence partly why insulin decreases blood sugar. 
Diagram below shows this in simple terms

 

GLUT 1 is involved in glucose uptake in erythrocytes as well as blood brain barrier including astrocytes. It is also widespread in foetal tissues

GLUT 2 is found on basolateral (and possibly apical) membranes of enterocytes in SI. Also found in Liver and Pancreatic Beta cells. It has a low affinity for glucose so is used by the pancreas to detect when blood sugar has reached a high level. 

GLUT 3 is a high affinity glucose transporter which has is found most commonly in neurones. 

GLUT 5 is a fructose transporter which is how fructose is absorbed in the small intestine on apical membrane of enterocytes

Question: In Scrubs Season 5 Episode 20 "My Lunch" Dr Cox and JD tragically lose three patients following transplantations of infected organs. This episode culminates in Dr Cox's emotional departure from the hospital to "How to Save a Life" by the fray, providing undoubtedly one of the most powerful endings to a TV episode ever. The infectious organism responsible has a SS -ve RNA genome and migrates retro-axonally through the PNS to the CNS where it causes fatal CNS infections if left untreated. Which of the following best matches this description?
Explanation:
A- Bacteria usually affects meningies 

B- CMV usually asymptomatic infections, can cause pneumonia 

C- Can cause CNS infections leading to paralysis but not usually fatal and migrates to CNS via blood

D- yup. most commonly spread by animal bites

E- Parasitic worms 

Source: Case 16 infections lecture & Scrubs S5e20 (wasn't on the reading list but definitely worth watching)

Question: Which of the following statements regarding blood glucose control is incorrect?
OptionC: Glucagon is is produced by alpha cells in the pancreas
OptionD: A blood glucose of 9mmol/L is acceptable in a diabetic after a meal
OptionE: 50g oral glucose will cause a greater insulin response than an equivalent IV glucose infusion
Explanation:
Glycaemic index is a representation of how much a substance increases blood sugar. Glucose will cause the greatest rise so is given the value of 100. 

Glucagon-like peptide 1 is an incretin which are substances released from the GI tract following eating which increase beta cell sensitivity to glucose and as such increases insulin secretion following a meal. It also suppresses glucagon secretion, hence B is incorrect.

Glucagon is produced by alpha cells which form part of the Islets of Langerhans. Beta cells in the Islets secrete Insulin whilst delta cells secrete somatostatin. In an adult the target range after a meal is 9mmol/L and a child is 10mmol/L so 9 is probably acceptable.

Due to the effects of incretins (GLP-1 etc) there is a greater insulin response if glucose is consumed via the GI tract i.e. orally, as opposed to IV delivery. This is discussed in the "Insulin therapy in type 1 diabetes" lecture in Case 10.

Question: A 45 year old man comes into the GP surgery for his yearly check up. 6 months ago he had an inferior MI, but is otherwise healthy. Which of the following drugs would you not expect him to be taking?
Explanation:
Secondary prevention of MIs, according to NICE guidelines, involves pharmacological treatment with the following:

 

- ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) inhibitor

- Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus a second antiplatelet agent)

- Beta-blocker

- Statin 

 

Therefore, given the patient is otherwise healthy, you would not expect a diuretic such as spironolactone to be prescribed.

Question: Which of the following vaccines would you be most cautious in giving to a child who is severely immunocompromised?
Explanation:
In those who are immunocompromised, live, attenuated vaccines should be used with extreme caution as they could result in infection due an impaired response to the vaccine. 

Oral rotavirus is the only one listed which live attenuated.

 

IPV is the inactivated polio vaccine and is therefore an inactive vaccine.

DTaP is a combination of diphteria and tetanus which are toxoid vaccines and acellular pertussis which is an inactivated vaccine. 

Meningoccocal C and Pneumococcal (PCV) are both conjugate vaccines which are often given to immunocompromised patients of all ages to prevent a wild infection of the bacteria.

Question:
It is May 2016 and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have brought Princess Charlotte into your surgery for her first MMR vaccination. Wills says "One remembers George having two MMR vaccinations, how old will our little Princess be when she needs her second one?"

What do you answer the future King?
OptionE: She will not need a booster, her Royal Blood shall protect her from measles, mumps and rubella.
Explanation:
A) - wrong

B) - correct (sse below).

C) - wrong

D) - wrong, she may however have her HPV vaccine here.

E) - wrong, Royal blood does not protect against viruses.
Tags: Case 9, Infectious Disease, MMR, Vaccinations, Royal Baby

Question:
Which of the following AF patients has a CHA2DS2VASC of 1?

Note; all medical history is mentioned in options
OptionA: A 67 year old woman with no significant medical history
OptionB: A 50 year old man who suffered a stroke 2 years ago
OptionC: A 45 year old woman on ramipril for hypertension
OptionD: A 29 year old man with type 1 diabetes and untreated blood pressure of 150/90
OptionE: A 71 year old man with ankylosing spondylitis
Explanation:
CHA2DS2VASC score (out of 9) is used to evaluate stroke risk in AF patients. The scoring uses the following criteria:

A has a score of 2 due to being over 65 and being female

B has a score of 2 due to history of stroke

C has a score of 2 due to hypertension and being female

D has a score of 2 due to hypertension and diabetes mellitus

E has a score of 1 due to age over 65 but less than 75. AS is not part of the criteria so does not have a score.

Question: The closing of the tricuspid valve causes which wave on a JVP waveform trace?
Explanation: The waveform of a JVP can be hard to visualise in patients but has a double waveform. The first wave of increased pressure is the contraction of the right atria, this is the a wave. The x descent then follows as the atria relax and ventricles begin to contract. The c wave is a notch in the x wave and is the closure of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole. There is then a second increase in pressure, known as the v wave, which is due to increased filling pressure in the atria during the end of ventricular systole. The tricuspid then opens again and the pressure decreases, giving the Y descent (or wave).

Question:
Viral Dating

 

I'm a single stranded, positive sense RNA virus (Class IV) and I'm part of the Flavivirus family. I can be 4 different serotypes and I travel around in a mosquito. 

 

When I initially infect someone I can cause a high fever (I'm hot y'know) and an array of other symptoms including malaise and severe joint and bone pain referred to as 'Break-bone fever'.

 

Usually I'd then give my victim a break and they'll recover (Biphasic/Saddleback pattern), before I return and cause symptoms again but this time they're milder. After I'm finished, my victim feels severely tired for several weeks later. 

 

If one of my brothers/sisters (another serotype) then infects the same person then they are able to cause a more severe syndrome due to antibody enhancement. This involves high fever, haemorrhage from eyes, ears and shock, leading to death if untreated. 

 

There is no vaccine to stop me and no specific antiviral treatment. 

 

What virus am I..?
Explanation:
Correct!! The description describes the Dengue Virus and it's clinical syndrome. Important points include;

  • Carried by mosquito (Aedes Egyptii) - YFV or DENV
  • Causes a 'Break-Bone Fever' - High fever and arthralgia
  • Has a saddle-back or biphasic infection
  • Infection with second serotype causes worse disease due to antibody enhancement.
  • Second infection typically leads to Dengue Harmorrhagic Fever

Question:
Stimulation of beta adrenergic receptors via noradrenaline on ventricular myocytes causes a number of physiological changes. These include increased Ca2+ movement into the cell (Via L-type Ca2+ channels), causing increased Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR)

 

Which receptor on the SR is stimulated to cause this CICR (Calcium induced calcium release)?

What effect will this have on the cardiac cycle?
Explanation:
1. Sympathetic stimulation of the heart via beta adrenergic receptors activates the PKA signalling cascade, this causes phosphorylation of L-type Ca2+ channels,  increasing Ca2+ movement into the cell
  2. This Ca2+ binds to Ryanodine receptors on the sarcoplasmic reticulum (an intracellular store of Ca2+)
  3. This causes release of Ca2+ from the SR (CICR). This surge in Ca2+ in the myocyte causes increased contractility of the cell (increased inotropy)
  4. The PKA cascade also phosphorylates phospholamban, speeding up SR Ca2+ reuptake, this increased reuptake rapidly reduces Ca2+ in the cell after release, causing accelerated relaxation (Lucitropy)

 

Sources 

T.J Allen lecture 'Regulation of excitation & contraction in the heart'

Khan academy medicine 'Increasing ventricular contractility - inotropic effect' (the series on autonomic regulation of the heart is nice and simple, makes the TJ lecture a lot easier!)

https://www.khanacademy.org/science/health-and-medicine/circulatory-system/nerve-regulation-of-the-heart/v/increasing-ventricular-contractility-inotropic-effect

The second paragraph of this article explains the Lucitropy bit well

http://www.sci.utah.edu/~macleod/bioen/be6003/notes/1.Sympathetic-Activation.pdf

 

Learning objectives

  1. Describe, compare and contrast chronotropic and inotropic regulation in the heart
  2. Describe the regulation of lusitropy in cardiomyocytes

Question:
Paula, a 44 year old female has come to your GP surgery complaining of dyspepsia. After a full history and examination you arrange some tests:

 

Faecal/Stool Antigen Test: Positive

Urea Breath Test: Positive

 

From the results you think it is most likely that Paula has an infection of her stomach due to a bacteria. You prescribe Paula triple therapy to treat the infection. What is the most likely causative organism and what is included in the triple therapy that you have prescribed?
Explanation:
Helicobacter pylori is a gram -ve curved/spiral shaped bacterium which can cause infection within the stomach. It can be detected non-invasively by either performing a urea breath test or a faecal/stool antigen test. Triple therapy is the gold standard of treatment to try and eradicate H. pylori infection and consists of administering:

 

Omeprazole - Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) - to prevent excess acid production.

+ 2 antibiotics - usually clarithromycin and amoxicillin (or clarithromycin and metronidazole if allergic to penecillin.)

 

Triple therapy should be taken twice a day for a course of 1 week (Remember 3.2.1.)

 

~Cimetidine is a histamine receptor antagonist which blocks histamine receptors on parietal cells which secrete HCl.

~NSAID's usually worsen GI complaints since they inhibit the COX-1 enzyme which produces prostaglandins which help mucus production and sceretion which protects the stomach lining from stomach acid.

Question: Ed Miliband, having recently been embarrassed in the general election, lets road rage get the better of him and causes a ten car pile-up on the M1 on his way down to London. The paramedics arrive at the scene and assess his GCS score. They find that he has an abnormal flexor response to pain, makes incomprehensible noises and only opens his eyes in response to pain. What is Ed's GCS score?
Explanation:
The answer is C - Ed gets:

3 points for an abnormal flexor response to pain (motor response)

2 points for incomprehensible speech (verbal response)

2 points for opening his eyes in response to pain (eye response)

This gives Ed a total score of 7, probably a better result than he got in the election...

 

Source - http://www.patient.co.uk/doctor/glasgow-coma-scale-gcs
Tags: Head and Neck, GCS, First aid

Question: Which of the following statements regarding Labour is incorrect?
OptionA: The anterior shoulder exits the vagina before the posterior
OptionC: C fibres are main afferents in stage 2
OptionD: Pethidine is commonly used as an analgesia
OptionE: They achieved an embarrassing 232 seats in the 2015 general election
Explanation: C fibres, which gives a dull, crampy, visceral pain is common in stage 1 of labour. Stage 2 is characterised by a delta fibres which, transmitted by the pudendal nerve, cause a sharper, burning pain.

Question:
Nick Clegg, a 48 year old unemployed gentlemen, comes to the GP surgery as his wife is concerned he may be depressed. Recent issues with the electorate of the UK are thought to have caused this.

Upon performing a mental state examination you discover he is experiencing all 3 core symptoms of depression. What are they?
OptionE: 8 seats in parliament, 5 years of Tory government, getting less votes than UKIP
Explanation:
The three core symptoms of depression as defined by ICD-10 are:

Low mood
Anhedonia
Anergia

 

Given Nick is suffering from all three this would mean he is likely suffering from severe depression. Which is not surprising.

Question: Which of the following statements about leukocytes is correct?
OptionA: Lymphocytes are the commonest type of leukocyte seen in acute inflammation
OptionB: Basophils release histamine which is a potent vasoconstrictor
OptionC: Monocytes migrate out of the blood stream and differentiate into lymphocytes
OptionD: Dendritic cells are able to phagocytose pathogens and present their antigens
OptionE: Kupffer cells in the liver are a form of lymphocyte
Explanation:
The correct answer is D - Dendritic cells are professional antigen presenting cells.

A is incorrect - neutrophils are the commonest leukocyte seen in acute inflammation.

B is incorrect - basophils do release histamine, but it is a vasodilator and not a vasoconstrictor.

C is incorrect - monocytes differentiate into macrophages, not lymphocytes.

E is incorrect - Kupffer cells are a type of macrophage, not lymphocyte.

Question: Which of the following about Eccentric hypertrophy is CORRECT?
OptionC: It is due to pressure overload within the heart
Explanation:
The photo below explains it well.  Eccentric hypertrophy is seen more in systolic heart failure as it causes dilation cardiomyopathy, whereas concentric is commonly present in diastolic.

A is correct, as it is the only answer present in eccentric hypertrophy, the rest are seen in concentric.

Question: A 23 year old man is brought into the ED with a suspected spinal fracture following an RTC. An x-ray is performed and the result is shown below. What type of fracture does this most likely show?
Explanation: This is a distraction fracture as defined in the spinal trauma lecture of Case 14. It is also known as flexion-distraction fracture as it is common in individuals who are involved in RTCs and the seat belt fixes their pelvis but the force flexes their upper spine causing a ripping of the vertebra in a fashion which is shown in the X-ray.

Question: A patient is brought into the ED after an RTC. His breathing is heavy, his pulse is 130 and he has a BP of 120/60. The patient flexes to pain, does not open his eyes and is mumbling unintelligible words. What is an appropriate first step in management?
Explanation: This patient has a GCS of 6. This indicates airway management is needed as GCS is less than 8. A CT scan may well be needed however the airway is a more urgent concern. Cricothyrotomy could be used if intubation is unsuccessful as the upper airway is blocked, as may as tracheotomy, however neither would be performed before intubation. DC cardioversion may also be needed however not enough information is given here to indicate it.

Question: Whilst in the St David's Centre on a Saturday afternoon you encounter a member of the public who looks extremely confused and seems to be clammy and agitated. You ask them what is wrong and they say they are a diabetic and they may have forgotten to take their insulin. They don't have a blood sugar monitor on them but they do have a few preparations of insulin. Which of the following would be best to give in this situation?
Explanation:
The symptoms of this patient are more suggestive of a hypoglycaemic event. The fact that the patient is telling you that they missed their insulin is not enough of a reason to give insulin especially considering they are confused. If this patient was indeed having a hypo giving them insulin could kill them and so without a blood sugar reading giving insulin is a bad idea. Giving them lucozade will help bring them out of a hypo if that's what they have but even if they're having a hyperglycaemic event, lucozade will do little to exacerbate the condition. 

Calling 999 would probably be advised in this situation especially if they did not respond to the lucozade.

Question: A female patient comes to see you in your genetic counselling clinic. They are concerned about the risk that their offspring could develop a genetic condition. This condition is autosomal recessive, and from a family history, you deduce that their father has a 1/3 chance of carrying the condition. If the father is a carrier, then she has a 50% chance of also being a carrier. She has a genetic test which is 80% sensitive and 100% specific, to determine whether she is a carrier. The test comes back negative. What is the chance that the lady is still a carrier of the condition?
Explanation:
The way I lay out the solution to these sorts of question is different to the way we have been taught, so it may suit some of you but not others. If anyone studied statistics at A level, this might make more sense as it puts it in similar terms to what we learnt back then.

 

Let A and B be events, such that:

A = the mother is a carrier

B = the test is negative

 

These events are governed by the relationship : P(A given that B has occurred) = P(A and B) / P(B)

 

P(B) = P(mother is a carrier but the test is negative) + P(mother is not a carrier and the test is negative)

 

P(mother is a carrier but the test is negative) = (1/3 x 1/2) x 1/5 = 1/30

(1/3 x 1/2) is the chance the mother is a carrier

1/5 is the chance the test is negative when the mother is in fact a carrier (as the test is 80% sensitive)

 

P(mother is not a carrier and the test is negative) = (1/3 x 1/2) + 2/3 = 5/6

(1/3 x 1/2) is the chance the father is a carrier but this is not passed on to the mother, and therefore the test will be negative (as it is 100% specific)

2/3 is the chance the father is not a carrier, and therefore the mother is definitely not a carrier and the test will be negative (as it is 100% specific)

 

Therefore P(B) = 1/30 + 5/6 = 13/15

 

 

P(A and B) = P(mother is a carrier but the test is negative)

P(mother is a carrier but the test is negative) = (1/3 x 1/2) x 1/5 = 1/30

(1/3 x 1/2) is the chance the mother is a carrier

1/5 is the chance the test is negative when the mother is in fact a carrier (as the test is 80% sensitive)

 

Therefore, P(A and B) = 1/30

 

 

Therefore, P(A given that B has occurred) = (1/30) / (13/15) = 1/26

Question:
Mary is a 67 year old Type II diabetic with sensory neuropathy. Although you have explained to her the importance of checking her feet for sores each night before she goes to bed, Mary presents to the GP surgery with deep ulcers, shown below.

 

Which nerve provides cutaneous innervation to the area where Mary's ulcers have developed?
OptionC: Medial calcaneal branches of the tibial nerve

Question: Biological clocks are groups of interacting molecules in cells throughout the body, there is a master biological clock that co-ordinates all the body clocks in the body so they are synchronised. Where is this master clock?
Explanation:
The suprachiasmatic nucleus or nuclei (SCN) is a tiny region located in the hypothalamus, situated directly above the optic chiasm. It is responsible for controlling circadian rhythms. The neuronal and hormonal activities it generates regulate many different body functions in a 24-hour cycle, using around 20,000 neurons. The SCN interacts with many other regions of the brain. It contains several cell types and several different peptides (including vasopressin and vasoactive intestinal peptide) and neurotransmitters.

 

The amygdala are two almond-shaped groups of nuclei located deep and medially within the temporal lobes of the brain in complex vertebrates, including humans. These perform a primary role in the processing of memory, decision-making, and emotional reactions, the amygdalae are considered part of the limbic system.

 

The limbic system The limbic system is a complex set of structures that lies on both sides of the thalamus, just under the cerebrum. It includes the hypothalamus, the hippocampus, the amygdala, and several other nearby areas. It appears to be primarily responsible for our emotional life, and has a lot to do with the formation of memories. In this drawing, you are looking at the brain cut in half, but with the brain stem intact. The part of the limbic system shown is that which is along the left side of the thalamus (hippocampus and amygdala) and just under the front of the thalamus (hypothalamus)

The caudate nucleus plays a vital role in how the brain learns, specifically the storing and processing of memories. It works as a feedback processor, which means it uses information from past experiences to influence future actions and decisions. This is important to the development and use of language. Specifically, communication skills are thought to be controlled mostly by the left caudate and the thalamus.

Each of the brain's hemispheres contains a caudate nucleus, and both are located centrally and near the basal ganglia. They are also situated near the thalamus, which is deep in the brain, close to the midbrain.

See this link for 3D views of brain structures: http://www.healthline.com/human-body-maps/caudate-nucleus

 

Nucleus accumbens: is a region in the basal forebrain rostral to the preoptic area of the hypothalamus. The nucleus accumbens and the olfactory tubercle collectively form the ventral portion of the striatum, which is part of the basal ganglia.
The nucleus accumbens has a significant role in the cognitive processing of motivation, pleasure, and reward and reinforcement learning, and hence has significant role in addiction. It plays a lesser role in fear, impulsivity, and the placebo effect. It is involved in the encoding of new motor programs as well.

 

Pineal gland: The pineal gland/body is a small endocrine gland in the brain. It produces melatonin, a serotonin derived hormone, which affects the modulation of sleep patterns in both seasonal and circadian rhythms. Its shape resembles a tiny pine cone (hence its name), and it is located in the epithalamus, near the center of the brain, between the two hemispheres, tucked in a groove where the two halves of the thalamus join. (See first diagram for location)

 

 

 

 

 

More info on the hypothalamus:

The hypothalamus is a small part of the brain located just below the thalamus on both sides of the third ventricle. (The ventricles are areas within the cerebrum that are filled with cerebrospinal fluid, and connect to the fluid in the spine.) It sits just inside the two tracts of the optic nerve, and just above (and intimately connected with) the pituitary gland.

The hypothalamus is one of the busiest parts of the brain, and is mainly concerned with homeostasis. Homeostasis is the process of returning something to some “set point.” It works like a thermostat: When your room gets too cold, the thermostat conveys that information to the furnace and turns it on. As your room warms up and the temperature gets beyond a certain point, it sends a signal that tells the furnace to turn off.

The hypothalamus is responsible for regulating your hunger, thirst, response to pain, levels of pleasure, sexual satisfaction, anger and aggressive behavior, and more. It also regulates the functioning of the autonomic nervous system (see below), which in turn means it regulates things like pulse, blood pressure, breathing, and arousal in response to emotional circumstances.

The hypothalamus receives inputs from a number of sources. From the vagus nerve, it gets information about blood pressure and the distension of the gut (that is, how full your stomach is). From the reticular formation in the brainstem, it gets information about skin temperature. From the optic nerve, it gets information about light and darkness. From unusual neurons lining the ventricles, it gets information about the contents of the cerebrospinal fluid, including toxins that lead to vomiting. And from the other parts of the limbic system and the olfactory (smell) nerves, it gets information that helps regulate eating and sexuality. The hypothalamus also has some receptors of its own, that provide information about ion balance and temperature of the blood.

In one of the more recent discoveries, it seems that there is a protein called leptin which is released by fat cells when we overeat. The hypothalamus apparently senses the levels of leptin in the bloodstream and responds by decreasing appetite. It would seem that some people have a mutation in a gene which produces leptin, and their bodies can’t tell the hypothalamus that they have had enough to eat. However, many overweight people do not have this mutation, so there is still a lot of research to do!

The hypothalamus sends instructions to the rest of the body in two ways. The first is to the autonomic nervous system. This allows the hypothalamus to have ultimate control of things like blood pressure, heartrate, breathing, digestion, sweating, and all the sympathetic and parasympathetic functions.

The other way the hypothalamus controls things is via the pituitary gland. It is neurally and chemically connected to the pituitary, which in turn pumps hormones called releasing factors into the bloodstream. As you know, the pituitary is the so-called “master gland,” and these hormones are vitally important in regulating growth and metabolism.

http://webspace.ship.edu/cgboer/limbicsystem.html
Tags: Sleep, Endocrine, Case 12, Physiology, Head and Neck

Question: A patient comes in following a bike accident. As he walks into the room, you notice that he is dragging his toes along the ground. Upon neurological examination, he doesn't have any sensation in the webbing between his big toe and second toe. You conclude that he has damaged a nerve during the accident. Which nerve is it?
Explanation:
He is suffering from foot drop, which is a sign of paralysis of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg. These muscles are supplied by the deep fibular nerve.

The loss of sensation also directs you towards the deep fibular nerve; the rest of the dorsum of the foot is supplied by the superficial fibular nerve (labelled as superficial and deep peroneal on the diagram):

 

The other nerves:

  • Tibial nerve - supplies the muscles of the posterior leg (plantarflexion and inversion), and the skin of the posterolateral leg/ lateral and plantar surface of the foot 
  • Femoral nerve - supplies the muscles of the anterior thigh (extend knee) and the skin of the anteromedial thigh/ saphenous nerve (branch of femoral) supplies medial leg and foot
  • Sciatic nerve - supplies the muscles of posterior thigh (extend hip, flex knee) and the indirectly the skin of the lateral leg/heel/foot

Question: Barry the baroreceptor is having a hard time. He is living in the carotid sinus and has noticed increased stretch due to increased pressure. However he can't remember what he should do. Barry should...
OptionA: Decrease firing rate to decrease sympathetic drive
OptionB: Increase firing rate to increase sympathetic drive
OptionC: Decrease firing rate to decrease sympathetic drive and increase parasympathetic drive
OptionD: Increase firing rate to decrease sympathetic drive and increase parasympathetic drive
OptionE: Increase firing rate to increase sympathetic drive and decrease parasympathetic drive
Explanation:
Barry is an arterial baroreceptor located in the carotid sinus and has noticed an increased stretch in the vessel wall indicating an increase in blood pressure.

  • increase stretch = increased firing rate
  • increased firing rate = decreased sympathetic and increased parasympathetic drive
  • acts to decrease heart rate and decrease total peripheral resistance thus lowering blood pressure 

If however Blood pressure decreased

  • decrease stretch = decrease firing rate
  • decrease parasympathetic and increase sympathetic drive
  • results in increased heart rate and contractility, peripheral vasoconstriction and venoconstriction, catecholamine secretion, increased renin secretion
  • increased heart rate, peripheral resistance and circulating blood volume to restore blood pressure to normal values

carotid sinus = glossopharangeal nerve, aortic arch = vagus nerve

Question:
You see a patient with a popliteal aneurysm on your ward round. You see an obvious palpable pulsation in the popliteal fossa.

You know from your revision that due to the tough popliteal fascial layer, the aneurysm cannot expand fully and so has consequences for the other contents of the popliteal fossa. You suspect that the tibial nerve is compressed. 

How would the patient have presented if this was the case?
OptionA: Anaesthesia over the lateral leg and an inability to evert the foot
OptionB: Anaesthesia over the anterolateral leg and an inability to dorsiflex the foot
OptionC: Anaesthesia over the plantar surface of the foot, and an inability to plantarflex the foot
OptionD: Anaesthesia between the hallux and 2nd toe, and an inability to dorsiflex the foot
OptionE: Anaesthesia over the plantar surface of the foot, and an inability to dorsiflex the foot
Explanation:
• Anaesthesia over the lateral leg and an inability to evert the foot - this would be damage to the superficial fibular nerve 
  • Anaesthesia over the anterolateral leg and an inability to dorsiflex the foot - damage to the common fibular nerve 
  • Anaesthesia between the hallux and 2nd toe, and an inability to dorsiflex the foot - damage to the deep fibular nerve 
  • Anaesthesia over the plantar surface of the foot, and an inability to dorsiflex the foot - wouldn't necessarily occur, as the majority of the plantar surface of the foot is supplied by branches of the tibial nerve but the motor function is to the posterior leg which is responsible to plantarflexion

http://teachmeanatomy.info/lower-limb/vasculature/arterial-supply/

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the foot is correct?
OptionA: The tarsal tunnel contains the tendon of tibialis anterior
OptionC: The calcaneus and tibia form the ankle joint
OptionD: Dorsalis pedis pulse is palpated just posteriorly to the medial malleolus
OptionE: The tibial nerve provides sensation to plantar aspect of the foot
Explanation:
A is incorrect, the tarsal tunnel contains from anterior to posterior:

- Tibialis posterior tendon
- Flexor digitorum longus tendon
- Posterior tibial artery
- Posterior tibial vein
- Tibial nerve
- Flexor hallucis longus tendon

Can be remembered by Tom, Dick And Very Nervous Harry

 

B is incorrect as the big toe has only 2 phalanges just as the thumb does

C is incorrect as it the talus and tibia which form the ankle joint. The calcaneus forms the heel bone which bears the weight of the ankle bone

D is incorrect as this is the site of the posterior tibial artery. The dorsalis pedis pulse is palpated just lateral to extensor hallucis longus tendon.

E is correct the tibial nerve provides the majority of sensation to the plantar aspect of the foot.

Question:
Although she avoided being captured and phagocytosed, Velma the Virus accidentally triggers an alarm! Nearby cells start releasing interferons! Velma must escape before they trigger an antiviral state!

 

Which of these is not an effect of interferon release?
OptionA: Resistance to viral replication in nearby cells
OptionB: Increased expression of ligands for NK cell receptors
OptionD: Activation of movement of sentinel cells to the lymph nodes
Explanation:
The first three options are all effects of the release of interferons. 

 

Movement of sentinel cells to the lymph nodes is triggered when the cells' TLRs and LLRs are activated by an invading organism.

Question:
Mary is in labour with her first child, baby Jesus. She is in a lot of pain and screams at her husband to get her something to help with it. She and Joseph do not have access to any Entonox or Pethidine (two of the most commonly analgesics used in labour in the UK). Joseph did however, manage to bring a basic first aid kit with him on their trip to Bethlehem, which contains some household medicines such as Paracetamol and Ibuprofen. 

He tries to give Mary two Ibuprofen tablets but she remembers reading in "What to expect when you're expecting the Christ child" that NSAIDs are contraindicated after 30/40.

Why should NSAIDs not be used during labour?
OptionB: They can cause the foramen ovale to shut too early
OptionC: They can cause the ductus arteriosus to shut too early
OptionD: They can cause a potentially fatal drop in blood pressure in the mother
OptionE: They cause a dangerous increase in temperature in the baby
Explanation:
A - Aspirin can cause Reye's disease at any stage of pregnancy, until a child is 16 years old. It is not the main reason NSAIDs are contraindicated in labour though.

B - To my knowledge, there are no known effects of NSAIDs on the foramen ovale.

C - Correct. NSAIDs inhibit the production of prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are responsible for maintaining the ductus arteriosus by dilation of the vascular smooth muscles.

D - NSAIDs can cause hypertension if the patient has renal problems but are not linked to hypotension.

E - False.

Source: Question & Answer - Anaesthesia and Analgesia in Childbirth lecture, Case 8. Explanation - Wikipedia.

Question:
A man presents at A&E with paralysis of both legs. He is panicking because he does not know what has caused this- he has no history of trauma or previous medical problems. 

Upon neurological examination, the patient cannot feel pain or temperature change on his legs. However, he can recognise when you move his leg up and down, and is able to feel the vibration when you place a tuning fork on his medial malleolus. He also has intact 2 point discrimination.

You discern that he has a spinal cord syndrome. Which one do you think he has?
Explanation:
His symptoms point towards anterior cord syndrome. 

 

Anterior cord syndrome is caused by ischaemic injury to the anterior aspect of the spinal cord, due to occlusion of the anterior spinal artery. This is normally not a traumatic process, and may be as a result of atherosclerosis, aortic pathology or external compression. 

 

Patient present with following features:

  • complete motor paralysis below the level of the lesion due to involvement of corticospinal tract.
  • loss of pain and temperature at and below the level of injury due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract
  • intact 2-point discrimination, proprioception and vibratory senses due to intact posterior column.
  • autonomic dysfunction: orthostatic hypotension
  • bladder and bowel dysfunction and sexual dysfunction may arise depending on the level of the lesion

This is because the anterior 2/3rd of the spinal cord contains corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts. 

 

Prognosis of anterior cord syndrome is worst among all other spinal cord injury syndromes. It is associated with high mortality and poor functional outcome in terms of poor recovery of motor power and co-ordination.

 

P.S. I made lateral cord syndrome up!

 

http://radiopaedia.org/articles/anterior-cord-syndrome and lectures are the source!

Question:
A 30-year-old male patient weighing 85kg is to receive an injection of Lidocaine hydrochloride 0.5% as a local anaesthetic for a minor operation.  They are given 15ml as a starting bolus.  

 

Given that the maximum dose is 2.5mg/kg, how much more Lidocaine hydrochloride may be administered if it was deemed necessary?
OptionA: 0 ml - the patient has already received the maximum dose
Explanation:
For this question it is easiest to first convert the concentration from percentage w/w to concentration proper in mg/ml.  The percentage is the percentage mass of the drug by mass of diluent - i.e. for 0.5% in 1g of diluent there will be 1x0.005g = 0.005g of lidocaine.  The diluent will be water, and 1ml of water weighs 1g, so we can say that there is 0.005g lidocaine per ml of water.  0.005g=5mg, so the concentration is 5mg/ml.

 

The patient weighs 85kg and max dose is 2.5mg/kg so 85x2.5 = 212.5mg is the maximum amount of lidocaine to give.  212.5mg / 5mg/ml = 42.5ml lidocaine is maximum volume. 

 

The patient has already received 15ml, so 42.5-15 = 27.5ml still available.

 

With any concentrations expressed as percentages it will work to multiply the percentage by 10 to get it as a concentration in mg/ml.

Question: You are on placement, when the doctor in the ED spontaneously produces the scan above.He questions you what structures are indicated by 4, 5 and 6. What will be your answer?
OptionA:
4 is the thalamus

5 is the internal capsule

6 is the red nucleus
OptionB:
4 is the caudate nucleus

5 is the putamen

6 is the internal capsule
OptionC:
4 is the caudate nucleus

5 is the internal capsule

6 is the putamen
OptionD:
4 is the choroid plexus of the lateral ventricle

5 is the internal capsule

6 is the putamen
OptionE:
4 is the fornix

5 is the putamen

6 is the internal capsule
Explanation: C is correct, 4 would be the caudate nucleus, 5 is the anterior arm of the internal capsule and 6 is the putamen.
Tags: Anatomy, Investigations, Emergency Medicine, Case 12, Case 16

Question:
A newly pregnant woman attends the midwife clinic and has a blood sample taken to determine her blood type. 

 

The sample of patient red cells was mixed with Anti-A and Anti-B serums. The results showed agglutination with both serums. 

The plasma of the patient sample was then mixed with type A and type B blood. There was no agglutination observed. 

 

After determining her ABO type, you went on test her Rhesus system. 

When the red cells were mixed with Anti-D serum, there was no agglutination seen. 

 

What blood type is the woman?
Explanation:
The woman is AB-. 

 

The first step of blood typing is ABO typing. The RBCs of the blood sample are mixed with antibodies against type A and type B blood and the sample is observed for agglutination (sticking/clumping together). If the cells do agglutinate, it means that the blood reacted with one of the antibodies:

  • If it agglutinates with anti-A serum, you have type A blood
  • If it agglutinates with anti-B serum, you have type B blood
  • If it agglutinates with both anti-A and anti-B serums, you have type AB blood (as in this case)

The second stage is called back typing. The serum of the patient's blood is mixed with blood that is known to be type A and type B:

  • If the blood agglutinates only when B cells are added to the sample, the blood type is A
  • If the blood agglutinates only when A cells are added to the sample, the blood type is B
  • If the blood agglutinates when either types are added, the blood type is O
  • A lack of agglutination indicates AB blood (as in this case)

The Rhesus typing classifies blood as Rh positive or Rh negative based on the presence of Rh antibodies in the blood:

  • If blood agglutinates when mixed with anti-Rh serum, blood type is Rh positive 
  • If blood doesn't agglutinate when mixed with anti-Rh serum, blood type is Rh negative (as in this case) - this is because the blood doesn't contain D antigen, so does not clump with anti-D antibodies 

Hope this all makes sense, found this a confusing topic myself. Used this source:

http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/003345.htm 

Which explains it quite well, along with the case 8 lectures.

Question: A patient experiences rapid weight gain, they quickly go from a healthy weight to obese. Investigations show a lesion somewhere in the brain. Based on your knowledge of appetite regulation, where is the lesion most likely to be?
Explanation: The obesity is due to a lesion of the ventromedial hypothalamus. This is because this part of the hypothalamus contains the satiety centre. If there is a lesion here, the patient experiences hyperphagia (excessive eating) as they never feel full or satisfied from their food. A lesion in the lateral hypothalamus will lead to rapid weight loss and starvation. This is because this part of the hypothalamus contains the feeding centre. A lesion here means that the patient will not experience the urge to eat, leading to aphagia.

Question: What is the mechanism of action of Biguanides?
OptionA: inhibits DDP-IV, thus increasing the incretin response.
OptionB: Binds to the KATP effluxer, triggering Ca2+ release and increasing insulin response
OptionC: raises cytosolic AMP ultimately decreasing PEPCK and glucose-6 phosphatase to decrease plasma glucose
Explanation:
A- gliptin class e.g. saxagliptin. With DPP-4 no longer inhibited; insulin secretion increases, glucagon secretion decreases and ultimately plasma glucose decreases. ADRs: headache, nausea, possible increase in risk of pancreatic cancer

 

B - sulphonylurea e.g gliclazide and glibenclamide: binds to the KATP effluxer so K enters the beta cell. this causes depolarisation of the cell and therefore opens the voltage gated Ca channels allowing Ca to flood into the cell. This triggers the IP3 signalling cascade and causes insulin to be released. ADRs: hypoglycaemia, cholestasis

 

C - correct. e.g. metformin: raises cytosolic AMP, which activates AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPPK). this decreases the expression of phosphoenyol-pyruvate carboxykinase (gluconeogensis pathway) and glucose 6 phosphase (preventing glucose 6-phosphatase being dephosphorylated to become glucose). This results in:

  • a decrease in hepatic gluconeogensis
  • an increase in insulin insensitivity
  • an increase in GLUT4 activity

D- alpha glucosidase inhibitors e.g.acarbose competetivly inhibit alpha-glucosidases in brush borders on small intestines so limits how much glucose gets into the blood plasma. ADRs: flatulence and hepatitis

 

E-Glitazone e.g pioglitazone. agonist of the peroxisome-proliferator Activated Receptor gamma (PPRAgamme). This complex then acts as a transcriptional factor activating the nuclear hormone receptor in adipose tissue. this results in:

  • adipocyte differentiation
  • increased lipogenesis
  • increased FA uptake
  • increased glucose uptake

Question: Sue is a 68 year old female is suffering from hypertension and has recently started experiencing a 'crushing' chest pain during exertion. She is diagnosed with Angina Pectoris. She additionally has hypercholestrolaemia. In light of this new diagnosis, what is her updated CHADS-VASc score?
Explanation:
Her score is 4. 

C - Congestive Heart Failure

H - Hypertension 

A - Age (>75) - 2 points

D - Diabetes 

S - Stroke/TIA - 2 points 

V - Vascular Disease 

A - Age (65-74) 

S - Sex (Female) 

 

Sue therefore has a score of 4 for the hypertension, vascular disease (angina), age and being female.

Question: Whilst at the pub, the ginger bearded medical student pucks up the courage (as he is know backing himself) to chat up a girl.  He is successful and gets her number.  After numerous cheeky nandos, the ginger bearded medical student takes the girl home one drunken night and engages in sexual intercourse, however due to their state they are not very careful and don't use protection.  The next day they go to the GUM clinic to get the emergency contraception - levonorgestrel.  How does this work to prevent pregnancy?
Explanation: Coffeys lecture in case 2.  Levonorgestrel (a large dose of progesterone) is enough hormonal disturbance to stop fertilisation.  Can cause nausea, vomiting, headache and irregular bleeding - not for routine use.

Question: Which of the following epidemiological terms is correctly matched to its definition?
OptionA: Sensitivity - The proportion of persons with disease who are correctly identified by a screening test as having the disease.
OptionB: Negative predictive value - The proportion of persons without disease who are correctly identified by a screening test as not having the disease
OptionC: Prevalence - Rate at which new cases occur in a population during a specified period
OptionD: Incidence - Proportion of a population that are cases during a specified period of time
OptionE: Specificity - The number of true negatives out of all the negatives given by the test
Explanation:
A is the correct definition for sensitivity

B is the definition for specificity i.e. the true negative rate

C is the definition for incidence

D is the definition for prevalence

E is the definition for negative predictive value

 

The difference between negative predictive value and specificity is that negative predictive value is how many of the negatives from the test were actually negatives. Specificity is the percentage of those without the condition who were found to be negative.

Question:
A 28 year old male patient weighing 72kg undergoes minor surgery on his leg and requires an injection of 0.5% lidocaine as a local anaesthetic. The doctor gives him an initial dose of 10mL.

 

The maximum does is 2.65mg/kg.

 

To 1 decimal place how much more lidocaine can be administered?
Explanation:
A 0.5% lidocaine means that there is 0.5g per 100mL which works out as 500mg per 100mL.

At the moment he has taken on 10mL which is a 50mg dose.

 

He is allowed 2.65 x 72=190.8mg as a total dose due to his weight.

So if we take 50mg off this (what he has already taken) then he is allowed 140.8mg more lidocaine.

 

140.8mg divided by 50mg means that he is allowed another 2.816 times the dose he has already had so thats 10mL x 2.816 which is 28.16mL

 

Rounding to 1d.p. is 28.2mL.

Question:
A patient is being given Pilocarpine eye drops 0.5% for their glaucoma. 

How much drug is contained in 1 drop if each 1mL contains 20 drops?
Explanation:
0.5% = 0.5g per 100mL = 500mg in 100mL or 5mg in 1mL (just remember that 1% = 1g/100mL)

1mL contains 20 drops, and so 20 drops contains 5mg.

 

Therefore, (5/20)mg in 1 drop = 0.25mg = 250μg

Question:
Lets say that brown fur colouring is dominant to grey fur colouring in mice. If you have 168 brown mice in a population of 200 mice.

What is the predicted frequency of heterozygotes?

(To 2 significant figures throughout the question if needed).
Explanation:
Full disclosure, completely stole this question from this website because it caught be out: http://www.indiana.edu/~l111/handouts/hardy.htm (Q3).

 

Start with what you know -- if 168 out of 200 are brown, that means 32 mice must be grey. There are only two phenotypes (three genotypes). So the first step is to determine q2.

 

Why don't you start with p2 since I given you the frequency of the dominant phenotype?

Think about it -- you have two different genotypes that can give you the dominant phenotype. Homozygous dominant and heterozygotes.

 

So the frequency of the dominant phenotype would be:

frequency of dominant phenotype = p2 + 2pq

You can't solve for p, if both p and q are unknown. So solve for q first -

q2 = (32/200) = 0.16

q = 0.4

p = 1 - (0.4) = 0.6

What is the predicted frequency of heterozygotes?

2pq = 2 (0.6)(0.4) = 0.48

 

A good way of checking you've worked it out correctly is by putting your figures for p and q back into the good ol' Hardy Weinberg equation and checking that it equals 1. 

 

(Also, sorry for it not making the numbers about medicine, I didn't want to pick a dominant disease and have someone comment with actual facts about it).

Question:
A 68 year old female presents with thoracic back pain which started about 3 weeks ago. It is now so severe that she cannot attend her job, where she works in an office. 

She has a 20 pack year smoking history.

No history of malignancy or neurological symptoms. 

This is her X-ray:

 

What do you suspect is wrong with her?
Explanation:
Risk factors which indicated this woman for an X-ray: >50yrs with new onset pain and thoracic pain. 

The X-ray shows a winking pedicle at the left L1 level (See: http://radiopaedia.org/cases/winking-owl-sign) which is almost always a sign of a bony metastasis. 

Possibility that this woman's primary tumour is in her lung due to her smoking history as the most common sites are breast and lung however this cannot be decided without further investigation obviously. 

B - Osteosaroma is the most common primary bone tumour in the spine (in bony tissue as opposed to in the bone marrow). 

C - She could have postural back pain due to her office job however this is more likely to be lumbar rather than thoracic.

D - There is nothing in the history which would indicate an infection. 

E - symptomatic thoracic disc prolapses are less common than those related to the lumbar region and it would be likely to come on very rapidly due to trauma rather than over 3 weeks.

Question:
A patient walks into your surgery looking fairly jaundiced. On approach, you notice that he also he reeks of alcohol and he mentions to you that he just lost his job (which turns out to be 3 months previously) so decided to go on a bender since then.

 

Clearly he has alcohol dependency issues that seem to have an effect on his bile secretion. To figure out how much alcohol (in units) he is drinking to cause such damage, you ask him what he has a day.

 

He says, (as expected), 'not much doctor, just 2 bottles of vodka and 12 cans of cider. But it's not bad doc, I start off with the ciders and then have the vodka in between, like a water break... but with vodka...'.

Trying not to look shocked or judgemental, you tell him the total number of units he's consuming. What is the figure you told him?

 

Volume of vodka per bottle 1L, percentage of alcohol by volume (ABV) 40%

Volume of cider per can 500ml, percentage ABV 7.5%
Explanation:
Formula:

 

[(Total of volume in a drink in (ml) X Alcohol by volume (%))/1000]

 

So for vodka:

 

(2 x 1000) x (40) /1000 = 80 units

 

Cider:

 

(12 x 500) x (7.5) /1000 = 45 units

 

Total = 125 units

 

*ABV is the measure of a drink's strength. It's the amount of pure alcohol expressed as a percentage of the total volume of liquid in a drink.

Question:
A man presents to A&E with a suspected stroke. You attempt to speak with him, and despite his sentences being fluent, the words he is speaking are confused and don't appear to make much sense. 

 

What artery has been most likely occluded?
OptionE: Both right and left middle cerebral arteries
Explanation:
The correct answer is the left middle cerebral artery. 

 

The man is suffering from Wernicke's aphasia, characterised by fluent sentences but loss of comprehension. 

The middle cerebral artery serves both Broca's area (motor speech) and Wernicke's area, so really any kind of aphasia would indicate middle artery occlusion. 

 

It is most likely to be left because in the majority of people, the left hemisphere is dominant.

Question:
A patient comes in to A&E following a bang to the head with a GCS of 13. 

 

You test his pupillary reflexes. When you shine a light in his right eye, both pupils constrict. However, when you shine a light in his left eye, neither pupil constricts. 

 

What do you suspect has caused this?
Explanation:
This indicates a lesion to the left optic nerve. 

 

When light is shone in the left eye, it is not being perceived i.e. the optic nerve afferent is not transmitting the impulse to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus. 

 

You can rule out an oculomotor lesion because both eyes are able to constrict when the right eye is stimulated. This suggests that the efferent pathways are intact in both. 

 

A lesion of the optic chiasm would result in bitemporal hemianopsia (vision is missing in the outer half of both the right and left visual field).
Tags: Cranial nerves, Neurology, Eye, Trauma, Case 16

Question: If a patient was found to have poor homeostatic reserve across multiple physiological systems what would be the best description of this patient?
Explanation: Frailty is often defined as loss of physiological mechanisms required to maintain homeostasis in multiple systems. This includes immune system, musculoskeletal, cardiovascular etc. Whilst ageing could be considered correct, many old people are not frail and not all frail people are old. Sarcopenia specifically to loss of muscle mass and is a component of frailty. Some unwell patients could be frail and have loss of homeostatic mechanisms but this is not a description of all unwell patients. Deceased patients would have no homeostatic reserves...

Question: Mr Drake is a 40 year old who has been involved in a car accident. In A&E you examine him and find he is making unintelligible sounds. When pain is supplied, he appears to adapt the abnormally flexed (decorticate) position and opens his eyes. Based on his GCS score, what action needs to be taken?
OptionA: Call the anesthetist to let them know that intubation is not currently needed but may be needed soon
OptionB: Call the anesthetist to let them know that intubation is needed now
OptionC: Do not call the anesthetist as intubation is not needed due to a high GCS score
OptionD: Do a lumbar puncture to check for increased intracranial pressure
OptionE: Supply patient with analgesia and continue to monitor for the next 3 hours
Explanation:
Opens eyes to pain = 2

Unintelligible sounds = 2

Decorticate posture = 3

2 + 2 + 3 = 7

 

Less than 8 (or 8) intubate.

 

A - incorrect as he needs intubation now

B - correct as GCS is less than 8

C - incorrect as he needs intubation now and his GCS is low

D - incorrect..... just no!

E - incorrect, patient needs to be intubated now

 

As you've probably gathered, he needs to be intubated now

Question:
A 25 year old woman is thrown from her horse at a local festival. On the way to hospital she becomes increasingly drowsy. Paramedics have inserted an oropharyngeal airway and have given high flow oxygen (at 40%) via a face mask because of her obstructed airway. An arterial blood gas sample is taken. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals

 

Patients ABG values:                    Normal ranges:

 

PaO2- 18.8 kPa                             >10 kPa (75 mmHg) on air
pH- 7.19                                          7.35 – 7.45
PaCO2- 10.2 kPa                            4.7 – 6.0 kPa
Bicarbonate- 23.6 mmol l-1             22 – 26 mmol l-1

You try to determine what acid-base disturbance this woman has in order to manage and treat her appropriately. What acid-base disturbance is suggested by her ABG results?
Explanation:
C- The reduced level of consciousness and obstructed airway will impair oxygenation and ventilation, causing an increase in PaCO2, a respiratory acidosis. There's unlikely to be much compensation (change in HCO3- because of the acuteness of the situation. However, we would expect too see more compensation in chronic respiratory acidosis.

 

There are 5 steps to remember when faced with ABG results. (1) How is the patient? (2) Asess oxygenation (3) Determine PH (4) Assess PCO2 (5) Assess HCO3- or base excess.

 

E- mixed acidosis/alkalosis- If both respiratory and metabolic components are driving PH towards the same side of 7.4 (both acidic or both alkalotic) then this is classed as a mixed picture.

 

NB- the PaCO2 should be about 10KPa less than the % inspired O2 concentration. More than 10 signifies an issue with oxygenation.

 

See Case 10 plenary and http://www.resus.org.uk/pages/alsabgGd.pdf but try to answer the questions first because the answers are on this link.
Tags: Kidney, Arterial Blood Gas, Biochemistry, Case 10, endocrinology

Question:
A 17 year old boy named Tommen comes into A&E with his mother Cersei, he complains that his neck feels very stiff and you can see that he is looking away from bright hospital lights, however you cannot find any rash; because you weren't born yesterday you immediately think that he might have meningitis. You quickly bang out a lumbar puncture and send the CSF off to the lab. 

 

The results come back

 

- purulent CSF

- some mononuclear

- high polymorph cells

- high proteins

 

Which type of meningitis does this make you suspect and how would you manage it?
OptionC: Bacterial - probably nothing bacterial meningitis is normally self-limiting within 10 days
OptionD: Viral - probably nothing viral meningitis is normally self-limiting within 10 days
Explanation:
The broad three types of meningitis are bacterial (pyogenic), viral and chronic/TB.

 

The CSF can usually be used to distinguish between the three as follows 

 

 In Viral meningitis – clear CSF, some mononuclear and no polymorph cells
 In bacterial – purulent CSF, some mononuclear and high polymorph cells, high proteins
 In TB meningitis – purulent CSF, high mononuclear, some polymorph cells

 

If there was a rash and nisseria meningitidis was suspected then prophylactic antibiotics would be started before the lab results came back. 

 

Most cases of viral meningitis do not require treatment, are limiting within 10 days and have no long lasting effects.

 

Most cases of bacterial meningitis are treated with antibiotics - there are a wide range that might be used depending on the organism. 

 

Learning outcome for Case 16 - Outline the microbiology of central nervous system infections

 

You can sort of work this out if you remember the immunology behind it.
Tags: Immunology, Infectious Disease, Brain, Virology, Case 16

Question: An unfortunate Peerwise-troll was in the process of scuttling back up to its desk (probably on the 2nd floor of the Health Library) to produce another horrible and irrelevant question. However because its arms were full of irrelevant textbooks, when it tripped over it was unable to prevent itself from banging its head on a desk. The poor troll was taken to A&E and a GCS was calculated. The troll only opened its eyes in response to pain and when asked if it knew where it was replied with a mixture of inappropriate words. The Doctor assessed the trolls motor function and found that the troll moved its paw towards the painful stimulus. What was the trolls GCS at time of assessment?
Explanation:
E-2

V-3

M-5

 

Poor Peerwise-troll

Question: Kanye's mate Lil Wayne sure does love the codeine syrup!! The max dose Weezy can handle is 10mg/kg. He already took 100mg earlier. He weighs 42kg (he is lil). How many more ml can he take if the codeine syrup comes in 5mg/ml?
Explanation:
The max he can take is 420mg (42x10=)

He has already taken 100mg

Can take 320mg more, it is in 5mg/ml

That means its 64ml

 

DON'T USE CODIENE SYRUP TO GET HIGH, THESE FIGURES ARE MADE UP FOR YOUR BENIEFIT.
