Question: Kanye is walking down the street when is ushered over by a homeless man. The man wants another hit of heroine but doesn't know how much he can take as he has already taken 30mg, so asks Kanye for help. The max dose is 1.5mg/kg and the man weighs 56kg. This heroine is in a 12% solution with saline. How many more ml can he have?
Explanation:
Max. he can have 84mg ( 1.5 x 56 )

Already had 30mg

Can have 54mg more

 

 

TAKE HOME MESSAGE OF PERCENTAGE CONC QUESTIONS

 

Solution is 12%

This means in 100ml there is 12g of the substance

This means there is 0.12g in 1ml (/100)

Therefore there is 120mg in 1ml (g to mg x1000)

 

He can have 54mg more so

       54/120=  0.45ml

Question: When answering impossible questions and reading mean comments on peerwise, a medical student questions why there are so many arseholes using the site. Because it is the run up to the exam and her brain is fried, she suddenly panics that she has forgotten the dermatome that supplies the arsehole, which is it?
Which of these conditions is strongly suggested by the following xray?
Explanation:
The xray shows a winking owl sign/ winking pedicle which is due to destruction of the vertebral body and indicates malignancy 

The image below is a similar xray but with two blue owl signs on the vertebra below and an arrow pointing to the winking pedicle

 

  • Spinal infection may destruction of the IV disc on xray which is indicative of infection (good prognostic sign as infections generally treatable)
  • Xray is normal in simple low back pain, prolapsed disc but can also be normal in infection or malignancy too
  • There is no clear fracture on this xray
  • Other metasteses may also be seen on spinal xray e.g. lung
  • Spondylesthesis and spondylosis unlikely to be seen on xray especially at this angle
  • Spondylosis refers to degeneration of the spine, most often, the term spondylosis is used to describe osteoarthritis of the spine, but it is also commonly used to describe any manner of spinal degeneration.
  • As with many other terms to describe spinal problems, spondylosis is more of a descriptive term than it is a diagnosis.
  • The most common cause of low back pain in adolescent athletes that can be seen on X-ray is a stress fracture in one of the bones (vertebrae) that make up the spinal column. Technically, this condition is called spondylolysis (spon-dee-low-lye-sis). It usually affects the fifth lumbar vertebra in the lower back and, much less commonly, the fourth lumbar vertebra.
  • If the stress fracture weakens the bone so much that it is unable to maintain its proper position, the vertebra can start to shift out of place. This condition is called spondylolisthesis (spon-dee-low-lis-thee-sis). If too much slippage occurs, the bones may begin to press on nerves and surgery may be necessary to correct the condition.
  • X-rays of the lower back (lumbar) spine from the side (not AP) will show the position of the vertebra e.g. lateral X-ray of the lumbrosacral spine demonstrating the forward shift in the fifth lumbar vertebra on the sacrum (L5-S1 spondylolisthesis).

Xray below shows spondylolysis

 

The xray below shows spongdylolisthesis

Question: Fenrir undergoes a CT scan which shows an occlusion of one of the major arteries in the brain. He tells you in confidence that he noticed while urinating he had lost all sensation in his genitals and reported urinary incontinence. He has no other sensory deficits. From this information, which artery do you suspect may be occluded?
Explanation:
The image below shows which areas of the brain are supplied by which arteries

Symptoms of anterior cerebral artery syndrome e.g. occlusion: 

  • Hemiparesis or hemiplegia contralaterally, involving primarily the lower limbs and pelvic floor musculature - did not mention whether he had any motor symptoms or not but likely he would have
  • Sensory deficits contralaterally, involving primarily the leg and perineum - although he didn't have and sensory leg deficits he the only symptom he did have was linked to the ACA
  • Apraxia (due to branches to the supplementary motor area and corpus callosum)
  • Disconnection syndrome (due to callosal branches)
  • Anosmia (due to branches of the olfactory bulb and olfactory tract)
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Grasp reflex and or sucking reflex contralaterally (if circle of Willis compromised)

 

 

Signs and symptoms of MCA syndrome:

  • Hemiparesis or hemiplegia of the lower half of the contralateral face
  • Hemiparesis or hemiplegia of the contralateral upper and lower extremities*
  • Sensory loss of the contralateral face, arm and leg*
  • Ataxia of contralateral extremities*
  • Speech impairments/aphasia: Broca's, Wernicke's or Global aphasia as a result of a dominant hemisphere lesion (usually the left brain)
  • Perceptual deficits: hemispatial neglect, anosognosia, apraxia, and spatial disorganization as a result of a non-dominant hemisphere lesion (usually the right brain)
  • Visual disorders: déviation conjuguée, a gaze preference towards the side of the lesion; contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
  • *faciobrachial deficits greater than that of the lower limb

Signs and symptoms of PCA syndrome:

Peripheral Territory Lesions

  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
  • cortical blindness with bilateral involvement of the occipital lobe branches
  • visual agnosia
  • prosopagnosia
  • dyslexia, Anomic aphasia, color naming and discrimination problems
  • memory defect
  • topographic disorientation

Central Territory Lesions

  • central post-stroke (thalamic) pain: spontaneous pain, dysesthesias and sensory impairments
  • involuntary movements: chorea, intention tremor, hemiballismus
  • contralateral hemiplegia
  • Weber’s syndrome: occulomotor nerve palsy
  • Bálint's syndrome: loss of voluntary eye movements optic ataxia, asimultagnosia (inability to understand visual objects)

Internal carotid artery occlusion

  • The internal carotid artery provides blood supply to most of the brain's cortex on one side, including the frontal, parietal and temporal lobes. Only the posterior parts of the brain are supplied by different arteries. The internal carotid divides into two large branches, the middle and anterior cerebral arteries, and symptoms arise from disruption of blood flow to the areas they supply. If this was occluded the symptoms would likely be far more wide spread as both ACA and MCA affected
  • Though occlusion of this major artery can have devastating effects, no part of the brain is dependent solely on the internal carotid from one side so it may be asymptomatic. Each person is born with a different degree of communication between the large blood vessels. Symptoms, therefore, vary widely between different people. 
  • In addition, if occlusion develops gradually, the communicating arteries have more time to grow and to provide more blood to the other side, should it become occluded.
  • Occlusion of the internal carotid can lead to paralysis of the entire opposite half to the face and body. This is mainly due to disruption of blood flow in the middle cerebral artery, one of its two main branches, which leads to a stroke in the main motor area of the cortex.
  • The other large branch, the anterior cerebral artery, supplies blood to the areas that control the feet and lower limbs.
  • Paralysis may be complete or partial, may affect only an leg, or the leg and arm on the opposite side.
  • Occlusion of the carotid is often preceded by temporary blindness in one eye, a condition known as amaurosis fugax
  • Completed stroke can cause loss of half of the visual field or a smaller portion of it.
  • Sensation may be lost on the other side of the body, since the sensory part of the cortex is also supplied by the middle cerebral artery. As with motor symptoms, sensory disturbances can vary from mild to severe.
  • The patient might become completely mute. He might be able to produce speech but it will be unintelligible. His understanding of language might be intact or might be completely lost
  • Personality changes, including passivity and inability to plan ahead, may occur

Basilar artery occlusion

Arises the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (supplying the superior and inferior aspects of the cerebellum)

Acute occlusion of the basilar artery may cause brainstem or thalamic ischaemia or infarction. It is a true neuro-interventional emergency and, if not treated early, brainstem infarction results in rapid deterioration in level of consciousness and ultimately death.

Patients with acute occlusion of the basilar artery will present with sudden and dramatic neurological impairment, the exact characteristics of which will depend on the site of occlusion:

  • sudden death/loss of consciousness

top of the basilar syndrome:

  • visual and oculomotor deficits
  • behavioural abnormalities
  • somnolence, hallucinations and dreamlike behaviour
  • motor dysfunction is often absent

proximal and mid portions of the basilar artery (pons) can result in patients being 'locked in' 

  • complete loss of movement (quadriparesis and lower cranial dysfunction)
  • preserved consciousness
  • preserved ocular movements (often only vertical gaze)

Question:
An 18-year-old medical student decides he is going to get buff, so starts consuming protein shakes. Whilst drinking a shake after a massive session of squats in the gym, he contemplates the process of digestion. He recalls that one of the enzymes involved in protein digestion (a proteolytic enzyme) in the stomach is pepsin and it's inactive precursor (zymogen) is pepsinogen. But he can't remember which cells in the stomach secrete pepsinogen. He asks a fellow medical student who knows everything as she uses PeerWise everyday.

 

Which cells does she tell him are responsible?
Explanation:
Chief cells (found in the body of the stomach) are responsible for secretion of pepsinogen, which is converted into the active proteolytic enzyme pepsin.

 

Consumption of protein stimulates the production of gastrin, secreted by G cells. Gastrin then stimulates the secretion of both intrinsic factor and hydrochloric acid from parietal cells. The hydrochloric acid catalyses the conversion of pesinogen to pepsin. The acidic environment created and pepsin are both important for the hydrolysis of proteins. Intrinsic factor is responsible for assisting absorption of vitamin B12 found in proteinaceous foods such as meat, fish and eggs. D cells (found in the antrum of the stomach) are stimulated by Gastrin and secrete somatostatin, a hormone which inhibits Gastrin excretion from G cells and hydrochloric acid from parietal cells (a negative feedback mechanism presenting the stomach becoming too acidic).

 

Leydig cells are testosterone producing cells found in the testicles. They are important for getting buff but have little direct influence on digestion.

 

Random mnemonic: I remember that chief cells secrete pepsinogen and are found in the body of the stomach by picturing the image of a native American chief drinking pepsi, which goes into his body.  

 

Pepsi is the ancient Greek word for digestion.

 

Apparently the drink "Pepsi" is so named as it was initially marketed as a digestive aid (although the sources for this are dubious), other dubious sources claim that Pepsi is called Pepsi because Pepsin is involved or was involved in it's production (again, this is from dodgy internet sources, not necessarily true). The rest of the information in this question is true though! Sources include: " Marieb, Human anatomy and Physiology, 6th edition" and "Faller, The human body: an introduction to structure and function, 13th edition".

Question: In the schematic diagram of a human cell below, which label identifies the mitochondrion?
Explanation:
1 = cell membrane

2 = vacuole

3 = rough endoplasmic reticulum

4 = golgi apparatus

5 = cytoplasm

6 = lysosome

7 = ribosome

8 = centrosome

9 = smooth endoplasmic reticulum

10 = mitochondrion

Question: Emma comes to the doctor with a fractured surgical neck of the humerus causing her weakness when abducting the arm at the shoulder, which nerve does the doctor tell her she had damaged?
Explanation: As the axillary nerve is short it can be damaged by traction if the shoulder is dislocated, as it lies against the surgical neck of the humerus it can be damaged if this is fractured.

OptionD: superior and inferior thorax are seperated here

Question:
A GP is in their practice and wishes to listen to the mitral valve of a patient's heart.

Where is the best place to put their stethoscope?
OptionA: 2nd Intercostal space to the left of the sternum
OptionB: 2nd Intercostal space to the right of the sternum
OptionC: 4th Intercostal space to the left of the sternum
OptionD: 5th intercostal space, mid-clavicular line on the left
OptionE: 4th intercostal space, mid-clavicular line, to the left
Explanation: Here you listen through the apex of the heart to the mitral valve

Question:
A 26-year-old man reports numbness and tingling in his hands for the last 3 weeks. The numbness began during a 4 week cycling trip, he returned 1 week ago. On examination there is reduced or altered sensation in his little fingers, medial side of his ring fingers and the medial volar surface of both hands.

 

Which nerve is affected?
Explanation:
This man has a bilateral compressive neuropathy of his ulnar nerves. Likely to be caused in this case by compression of the ulnar nerve by the handle bars at the anatomic location of Guyon's canal at the base of the hand. Compression of the ulnar nerve can occur anywhere along it's course (from the shoulder to the hand) resulting in neuropathy, the most common location of compression is at the elbow.

 

Changing how he grips his handle bars (taking the weight off of his medial palm) should allow his symptoms to gradually resolve.

Question:
A 19-year-old medical student presents with pain and swelling at the base of his right thumb. He reports an amorous encounter on a MedSoc social with a fellow medical student, with whom he returned to his halls of residence. Due to the narrow beds, alcohol excess and obscure mid-coital positioning he fell onto his extended wrist, which resulted in severe pain.  

There is exquisite tenderness on palpation of the anatomical snuff box of his right wrist. He is told by the doctor that his wrist x-ray shows a fracture of a carpal bone.

 

Which bone is most likely to be fractured?
Explanation:
The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone. The usual mechanism of injury is a fall onto an extended wrist, typical history and examination findings include: pain and swelling at the base of the thumb and tenderness on palpation of the anatomical snuff box*.

 

The history of presenting complaint in this question is reminiscent of a mnemonic for remembering the carpal bones: Some Lovers Try Positions That They Can't Handle  = Scaphoid Lunate Triquetrum Pisiform Trapezium Trapezoid Capitate Hamate. 

 

*the anatomical snuff box is the depression between the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons at the base of the thumb. This recess is so named for it's use of holding snuff (ground tobacco) prior to nasal insufflation. 

 

Jason

Question: Jamie Roberts is playing against Australia on Saturday in the first Welsh autumn test match.  He has studying medicine here at Cardiff university. One of the older year students tell you of a rumour that once playing for uni he tackled someone so hard it dislocated their glenohumeral joint.  At A&E after relocation of the humerus, The F1 doc wants to check the auxiliary nerve function to see  where the dislocation damaged it. What should the doctor do to check the auxiliary nerve?
OptionA: See if the patient has claw hands
OptionB: Ask the patient to try and abduct the injured shoulder against resistance all the way to right angles with the body
OptionD: test small abduction of the upper limb under 20 degrees.
OptionE: order an MRI and see if damage can be seen on the scan.
Explanation:
The auxiliary nerve innervates the deltoid. This muscle is the main abductor of the shoulder joint from 18 to 90 degrees (from 0 to 18 by supraspinatus). Injury can result in a reduction in shoulder abduction.

 

So a test can be applied to a patient with injury of axillary nerve by trying to abduct the injured shoulder against resistance
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of the upper limb, Nerve innervation of upper limb

Question: What does the surftant secreted by alveolar type 2 epithelial cells do?
Explanation: Perfusion refers just to blood flow and it is not related to surfactant. The surfactant decreases the surface tension an alveoli and therefore a given amount of air volume can be accomodated with a lower transmural pressure difference.

Question: A pregnant woman is undergoing screening to see if there is a possibility that her child will have Down's syndrome. People with Down's syndrome have an extra chromosome 21. What happens during the formation of gametes to cause this?
Explanation:
Aneuploidy is defined as having a chromosome number that is not a multiple of the haploid number for the species.

 

Disjunction is the separation of chromatids or chromosomes during anaphase.

 

Nondisjunction is when two chromosomes or chromatids do not separate.

 

Nondisjunction leads to one daughter cell having too many chromosomes and the other having too few (in Down's syndrome the gamete has an extra chromosome 21), these daughter cells are aneuploid.

Question: You are a junior doctor working in a busy A&E department when a 26-year old male presents with pain during inspiration and breathlessness. He also has a sharp stabbing pain on the left side of his chest which has suddenly developed. Upon taking a patient history you discover he has recently been in a bar fight and has sustained a stab wound. What is the most likely cause of his breathing condition?
Explanation:
Pneumothorax - entry of air into the pleural cavity resulting in collapse of the lung on the affected side

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax - occurs in healthy people with no known history of lung disease, cause unknown

Traumatic Pneumothorax - follows a penetrating chest trauma such as a stab wound, gunshot injury or a fractured rib

Question:
A 57 year old male was admitted to intensive care after complaining of fatigue, loss of appetite and vomiting. An abdominal examination was performed which revealed signs of abdominal swelling. The patient also appeared jaundiced. The consultant requested a blood test for aspartate aminotransferase (AST). The results of the blood test showed very high levels of AST (more than 10 times the normal).

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The blood test for AST is usually used to detect liver damage. An AST test is usually ordered along with several other tests to evaluate a person who has signs and symptoms of a liver disorder such as fatigue and vomiting (as described in the question). Normally levels of AST in the blood are low and very high levels of AST are  usually due to acute hepatitis.

Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver that is most commonly caused by viruses but may also be due to chemicals, drugs, alcohol, inherited diseases, or autoimmune disease.

AST is an enzyme found in tissue of the heart, skeletal muscle, liver and brain and is used in diagnostic purposes to detect liver disease (Medical Biochemistry p61)

Prostate cancer, bone disease and lymphoma can be discounted from the list of answers because their symptoms do not match those of the patient.

The symptoms of acute pancreatitis are similar to those of acute hepatitis, but AST is not found in the liver so elevated levels of this enzyme would not indicate pancreatitis. Abnormally high levels of amylase and/or lipase would indicate pancreatitis.

Question: A 57 year old man comes into the clinic complaining of chronic acid influx. He states that he has never suffered from the condition before. Its revealed that he began experiencing this symptom after a incident at work where he strained himself whilst lifting a very heavy object. He also complains of dull pains in his chest. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
OptionA: Rupture of an artery in the proximal third of the duodenum.
OptionC: A tear in the arcuate ligament of his diaphragm
Explanation: Hiatus hernia is the term used to describe a condition where part of the stomach pushes up into the lower chest through a defect in the diaphragm. The diaphragm is the large flat muscle that separates the lungs from the abdomen, which helps us to breathe. Not everyone with a hiatus hernia develops symptoms. However, if you have a hiatus hernia you more prone to reflux acid into your gullet (oesophagus), which can cause heartburn and other symptoms. If symptoms do occur, treatment with acid-suppressing medication usually works

Question:
A 23 year old female presents at her local GP surgery complaining of bloating, prolonged fatigue, recurrent stomach pain and constipation. The GP requests a stool sample and blood test. The results of the stool sample reveal steatorrhoea (fatty stools) and the blood test reveals the presence of the IgA (immunoglobin A) form of tTGA (tissue transglutaminase) antibody. The GP refers the patient to a gastroenterologist.

What diagnosis does the GP suggest based on the symptoms and test results?
Explanation:
Coeliac disease is a hereditary chronic intestinal disorder of absorption caused by intolerance to gluten. Gluten is seen as a foreign invader and is attacked by the immune system.This immune system response in celiac disease involves the production of antibodies directed against an enzyme normally present in the intestines called tissue transglutaminase (tTG).In celiac disease, the body produces two types of antibodies that attack tTG, one of which is immunoglobulin A (IgA).

The diagnosis is unlikely to be appendicitis because it would not explain the presence of fatty stools and prolonged fatigue, appendicitis is also not an autoimmune disease so tTG antibodies will not be present.

In most cases gall stones would not cause any symptoms.

The symptoms of lactose intolerance and irritable bowel syndrome are similar to coeliac disease but the tTG antibody test is specific to coeliac disease and rules out any of the other diseases

Question: A 4 month pregnant women turns up to the GP with an infection. The doctor explains to her about the antibodies her body is making to protect the fetus. Which immunoglobuline molecule is more likely to be mentioned ?
Explanation: IgG antibody is the one that travels from the mothers blood supply into the fetus to protect it in case of an infection.

Question: As a junior Dr you see a female patient in A &E she is 63 and moved to the UK from Nigeria with her family a few years ago. She is a muslim and dresses very modestly. She has had a fall and fractured her wrist. What vitamin deficiency would you check for and what how would that deficiency contribute to her symptoms?
OptionB: Vitamin C, needed for maintaining healthy connective tissue
OptionC: Vitamin D, deficiency can lead to osteoporosis.
Explanation:
NHS choices says there is evidence to suggest too much Vitamin A can contribute to osteoporosis (not too little). Vitamin C does help keep connective tissue healthy, but the information provided doesn't suggest vitamin C deficiency as strongly as it suggests vitamin D.

 

Most of our vitamin D is produced in our body and its synthesis requires certain wavelengths of UV light. This patient from Nigeria is likely to have dark skin and if her skin is also always well covered due to modest dress she will not receive enough sunlight to synthesise enough vitamin D. Vitamin D deficiency can lead to osteoporosis, the patients age (at 63 she is probably postmenopausal) and sex also predispose her to osteoporosis.

Question: Winston, a 67-year old patient presents at his GP surgery complaining of regurgitation and heart burn. His BMI is 33 and he has pain whilst swallowing (odynophagia). Winston has a diet high in saturated fat and smokes 35 cigarettes a day. Based on the information above, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) is a condition where acid from the stomach leaks out into the oesophagus. If the lower oesophageal sphincter (LOS) remains relaxed for long periods or if the abdominal pressure exceeds that in the thorax, the stomach contents may enter the oesophagus. The LOS is a ring of muscle towards the bottom of the oesophagus which acts as a valve, remaining closed when food is not being swallowed and opening to permit entry of the bolus (food ball) into the stomach.

Treatments for GORD include lifestyle advice, antacids such as sodium bicarbonate (neutralise the acidic chyme) and drugs such as ranitidine and omeprazole, that inhibit gastric acid secretion.

Risk factors for GORD include being overweight or obese, eating large amounts of fatty foods, being pregnant and having a hiatus hernia

Question: Winston, a 67-year old patient recently diagnosed with severe gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) was found to have a hiatus hernia. What are the two types of hiatus hernia?
Explanation:
hiatus hernia - condition in which the proximal region of the stomach herniates through the opening in the diaphragm through which the oesophagus passes intro the thoracic cavity (the oesophageal hiatus)

Sliding hiatus hernia - the gastro-oesophageal junction slides up into the thoracic cavity (80% of cases)

Rolling hiatus hernia - the gastro-oesophageal junction remains in place but a part of the stomach herniates into the chest next to the oesophagus (20% of cases).

Question: A 19 year old student is admitted into the A&E with a chest wound. The doctor informs him he has a torn thoracic duct and lymph enters the pleural cavity. What medical condition is likely to be mentioned by the doctor?
Explanation: Chyle is a pale white or yellow lymph fluid in the thoracic duct containing fat absorbed by the intestines.

Question: When Ca++ levels in blood plasma decrease a hormone is released. This hormone stimulates Intestinal reabsorption of Ca++, prevents Ca++ excretion in the Kidneys and increases bone absorption and freeing of Ca++ by osteoclasts in bone. What is this Hormone?
Explanation: PTA stimulates bone reabsorption and decreases calcium excretion directly. It also increases 1,25 - dihydroxycholecalciferal (The activated from of Vitamin D) concentration in the blood which increases uptake of Ca++ in the small intestine.

Question: Wendy, a 32 year old mother of three presents at her GP surgery with fecal incontinence. She recently gave birth to her third child, weighing 9lb 4oz, and explains that the problem only started after the birth. The GP informs Wendy that she has most likely suffered nerve or muscle injury because of the delivery of a large baby. What muscle/muscles is he most likely to mention she has damaged?
Explanation:
The rectum opens to the exterior via the anal canal, which has both external and internal sphincters. The internal sphincter is not under voluntary control and is supplied by both parasympathetic and sympathetic nerves. The external anal sphincter is composed of skeletal muscle and is supplied by the pudenal nerve and is under voluntary learned control. The anal sphincter muscles won't open properly and close properly if the nerves that control them are damaged. 

Rectal sphincter muscles and colon sphincter muscles don't exist. The pyloric sphincter separates the stomach from the duodenum.

Question:
Brandon, a 21 year old patient is seen by his family practitioner because of constipation, nausea and itching around the anus. He explains that whilst at university he struggles to eat a balanced diet and often resorts to ready meals and Domino's pizza after a night out. The GP examines the anus visually and performs a digital rectal examination when he discovers the presence of haemorrhoids. 

What dietary advice is the GP likely to give Brandon to help alleviate his symptoms?
Explanation:
Humans are unable to digest dietary fibre so it remains in the intestine, adding bulk to food residues. The fibre exerts a hygroscopic effect, absorbing water so that stools with a high fibre content tend to be bulkier and softer making them easier to expel. Dietary fibre consists largely of indigestible cellulose. Good sources of dietary fibre are fruit and vegetables and wholegrain cereals.

Haemorroids (commonly known as piles) are swollen blood vessels in or around the anus and rectum. They are very common in elderly people and during pregnancy.

Dietary fibre has a pivotal role in preventing haemorrhoids and is very important to the passage of food through the large intestine. A shorter mouth-to-anus transit time is believed to reduce the risk of developing carcinoma of the large intestine and rectum. It reduces the time bacterial toxins and potential harmful metabolites are in contact with the gut wall.

Human Physiology, Pocock and Richards, p620

Question: 12 year old Harriet has been admitted to the paediatric ward for planned surgery to remove her appendix. The surgeon suspects she has appendicitis because she has complained of constant and severe pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen and has a temperature of 38.5C. During the laparoscopic appendectomy, the surgeon points to to a structure to which the appendix attaches and asks you to identify it. What part of the large intestine is the surgeon pointing to?
Explanation:
The appendix extends from the posteromedial aspect of the caecum inferior to the ileocecal junction. 

Essential Clinical Anatomy p156

Question:
Gary, a 66 year old patient presents at his GP surgery with pain in the epigastric abdominal region directly below the sternum. He explains that the pain comes and goes but it occasionally gets worse after eating. He has recently lost his job and admits to feeling very anxious about how he will pay the bills and support his wife. The GP refers Gary to the hospital for an endoscopy and collects a stool sample to send off to the lab. 3 weeks later and the results from the stool sample confirm the presence of H.pylori bacterium. 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: Peptic ulcers are open lesions of the mucosa of the pyloric canal or the duodenum. People experiencing severe chronic anxiety are prone to developing peptic ulcers. Gastric acid secretion rates are higher between meals which overwhelms the bicarbonate normally produced by the duodenum and reduces the effectiveness of the mucous lining. The most common cause of ulcers is infection of the stomach by Helicobacter pylori. Helicobacter pylori are bacteria that erode the protective mucous lining of the stomach and make it more vulnerable to the effects of gastric acid and pepsin produced by the stomach. Epithelial cells and the lamina propria (thin layer of loose connective tissue that lies beneath the epithelium and together with the epithelium constitutes the mucosa) die leading to the formation of a shallow ulcer.

Question: After a hard night on the town consuming an excessive number of vodka shots,19 year old Jason started to head home to his student residences when unfortunately he began to experience feelings of nausea. This was shortly followed by retching and the autonomic responses of copious watery salivation (waterbrash), sweating, dizziness and tachycardia (heart rate that exceeds the normal range). He quickly crouched behind a bin and vomited the contents of his stomach and duodenum onto the pavement. Luckily for Jason his vomiting reflex had kicked in to prevent the inhalation of his vomitus (vomited material). What area of the brain coordinates the vomiting (emesis) reflex?
Explanation:
Vomiting consists of three stages: Nausea, Retching, Vomiting

Vomiting is thought to have evolved as a defensive mechanism whereby potentially toxic substances are removed from the body.

Afferent neuron (neurons carrying signals TOWARDS the CNS) impulses arrive at the brain stem from many parts of the body including the pharynx and other areas of the GI tract.There are two medullary centres of vomiting in the brain known as the sensory chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) and the integrative vomiting centre.The integrative vomiting centre is activated by afferent impulses from around the body resulting in a reflexive activation. 

The CTZ  is sensitive to a variety of chemical agents including general anaesthetics and opiates. When activated the CTZ relays stimuli to the integrative vomiting centre which produces the actual act of emesis. 

The motor impulses responsible for the action of vomiting are transmitted from the medulla via the trigeminal, facia, glossopharyngeal, vagus and hypoglossal nerves.

During the act of vomiting the larynx is closed and the soft palate rises to close off the nasopharynx which prevents inhalation of vomited material. The stomach and pyloric sphincter relax, the duodenum contracts which forces the intestinal contents into the stomach. The diaphragm and abdominal wall then contract, lower oesophageal sphincter relaxes and the pylorus closes. This causes a rise in intragastric pressure leading to the expulsion of the gastric contents.

Question: During your rotation on the gastroenterology ward you are asked to examine 51 year old Arthur, a patient suffering from cirrhosis of the liver. Arthur has severe ascites (an accumulation of fluid) causing visible abdominal distention. In what space has this fluid accumulated?
Explanation: The space between the visceral and parietal layers of the peritoneum (the peritoneal cavity) normally contains very little free fluid but in certain diseases like cirrhosis of the liver, this space may become expanded by an abnormal accumulation of fluid.

Question: During the enzyme practical a student has to draw 2 double reciprocal plots: the first one represents a normal enzyme activity and the second one shows the enzyme activity with a competitive inhibitor. What will the student notice when he compares the two graphs?
OptionB: An apparent increase in Vmax in the second graph.
OptionC: An apparent increase in Km in the second graph.
OptionD: An apparent decrease in Km in the second graph.
OptionE: An apparent decrease in Vmax in the second graph.
Explanation: When a competitive inhibitor is added the slope of the graph increases while the Y-intercept stays the same. Hence, there will be an apparent increase in Km but no effect on Vmax.

Question: A man walks into A & E complaining of diffuse and colicky abdominal pain around the umbilicus area of the abdomen. After a few hours, the pain becomes more constant in the right iliac fossa and the patient is recommended to undergo surgery. What condition is likely he/she suffering from?
Explanation: The patient's first pain experiences is a type of referred pain as the visceral sensory fibres are stimulated due to inflammation of the appendix,  and enter the spinal cord at T10, the umbilicus region. This pain is colic and later when the appendix makes contact with and irritates the parietal peritoneum in the right iliac fossa, which is innervated by somatic sensory nerves. This produces a more prominent constant focal pain. Disorders of the bowel or pelvis may cause similar symptoms.

Question: A rugby player experiences a painful shoulder injury resulting from what appears to be excessive extension of the humerus from scoring a try. An x-ray reveals that the injury is indeed an anterior dislocation of the glenohumeral joint, but the patient begins to suffer shoulder muscle wastage weeks after the injury, with extreme weakness abducting the arm and experiences loss of sensation in the regimental band area of the shoulder. Which nerve has the patient most likely damaged and thus which muscle is most likely suffering from extreme muscle wastage and reducing the player's shoulder strength?
Explanation: A  glenohumeral dislocation is most likely to damage the axillary nerve, and can cause paralysis of the deltoid, loss of cutaneous sensation in the regimental badge area and severe weakness in the abduction of the arm, which past 15 degrees, is performed by the deltoid, a muscle innervated by axillary nerve. The patient's initial 15 degree abduction, performed by the supraspinatus, would be more likely unaffected.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of the upper limb

Question: What type of Connective Tissue is found in Tendons and Ligaments?
Explanation: In this type of connective tissue, collagen fibres are densely packed and arranged in parallel. This type of tissue is found in ligaments (which link bone to bone at joints) and tendons (connections between bones or cartilage and muscle). This tissue can withstand high tension and forces and is able to stretch a little. Hyaline Cartilage and Fibrocartilage are types of cartilage, a specialised connective tissue surrounding the surfaces of bones.

Question: In the Central Nervous System, axons are insulated by myelin sheaths formed by....??
Explanation: Myelin is formed by oligodendrocytes in the CNS and by Schwann Cells in the PNS

Question: Megan is 8 years old. Her mum has taken her to see the GP because recently she has started wetting the bed, something she hasn't done since she was very young. She is always thirsty, complains of being tired all the time, and is underweight. What autoimmune condition might she have and why does this cause lethargy, and weight loss?
OptionA: Type 2 diabetes, glucose is excreted in urine so there is never enough energy available.
OptionB: Coeliac disease, poor absorption of food and lack of iron means patients become underweight and lethargic
OptionD: Type 1 diabetes, lack of insulin means she cannot take up and conserve glucose derived from the products of digestion.
Explanation:
Megan's increased need to drink and pee combined with her other symptoms suggests she might have type 1 diabetes, this means her body cannot make insulin. Without insulin her body is unable to take glucose up from the blood, this means her tissues (importantly her liver) cannot absorb glucose after a meal so cannot store energy. This leads to weight loss as glucose can't be taken up and stored as fat, and amino acids are used as an alternative fuel source reducing muscle mass. Lethargy occurs as her energy stores are depleted.

 

She is unlikely to have type 2 diabetes due to her age, and excretion of glucose in urine is a result of uncorrected high blood glucose not cause for low blood sugar and energy.

 

Coeliac disease and hypothyroidism do not usually cause excess urination.

Question: What epithelial cell type functions as a mediator of filtration and diffusion?
Explanation:
only one cell thick so allows for movement of small molecules, oxygen and carbon dioxide can diffuse freely across the epithelia, ions utilise protein channels to move across the cell

simple squamous epithelium is found in locations where rapid diffusion or filtration takes place. In the kidney, simple squamous epithelium lines the Bowman’s capsule and the glomerulus.

simple squamous epithelium also makes up the alveoli in the lungs, where rapid gas exchange occurs, as oxygen enters the bloodstream through alveolar blood vessels and carbon dioxide exits as waste.

Question: Mr Griffiths has a lower motor neurone lesion and has come to visit his neurologist for a review of his symptoms. The consultant neurologist says you (a medical student) sit in on the consultation, at the start of the consultation he asks you to name the main symptoms associated with lower motor neurone lesions.
OptionA: Spasticity, focal weakness, fascilculations, muscle wasting, exaggerated reflexes, absent plantar reflex
OptionB: Flaccid focal weakness, fasciculations, muscle wasting, weak or absent reflexes, absent or normal plantar reflex.
OptionC: Spastic pyramidal weakness, absence of fasciculations, no muscle wasting, exaggerated reflexes, toes point up in plantar reflex
OptionD: Flaccid pyramidal weakness, fasciculations, muscle wasting, absence of reflexes, toes go up in plantar reflex
OptionE: Spastic focal weakness, absence of fasciculations, no muscle wasting, absence of reflexes, absence of plantar reflex
Explanation:
Lesions in upper motor neurone symptoms:

- high muscle tone (spasticity)

- pyramidal pattern of weakness

- lack of fasciculations

- no muscle wasting

- exaggerated reflexes

- abnormal plantar reflex (toes point up instead of down)

 

Lower motor neurone lesion symptoms:

- loss of muscle tone (flaccidity)

- focal pattern of weakness (often starting at the peripharies)

- fasciculations

- muscle wasting

 - weak or absent reflexes

- absent or normal plantar reflex

Question: β-oxidation is a metabolic process by which fatty acids are utilised to produce acetyl CoA for use in the TCA cycle, and to reduce FAD and NAD+ for use in oxidative phosphoylation.  What is the main limiting factor of this process?
Explanation:
The carnitine shuttle is a term used to describe the process of the molecule carnitine transporting fatty acids from the intermembranous space of the mitochondria to the mitochondrial matrix.  Without this shuttle, the fatty acids would not be able to be transported into the matrix, meaning fatty acids would not be available to be metabolised, making it the rate limiting factor.

Glycolysis is limited by phosphofructokinase, activated by high AMP concentration and inhibited by high ATP concentration. 

Acetyl CoA is produced in beta-oxidation but does not limit it.

Question:
A newborn presents with the symptoms of Klumpke's paralysis not long after birth. This includes paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand and presents like this:

What events may have occurred to cause these symptoms?
OptionA: Baby was delivered breech and excess pressure was put on the arms
OptionB: The head and neck were pulled while the shoulders were in the birth canal
OptionD: The upper limb was pulled during delivery
Explanation:
Klumpke's paralysis is an injury to the inferior part of the brachial plexus. The symptoms are caused by damage to the roots C8 and T1 of the plexus. Only pulling the baby's arms before the rest of the body has been delivered.

A, B and E are causes of Erb-Duchene palsy which is injury to the superior part of the brachial plexus.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of the upper limb

Question: You are in A&E and receive an injured 40 year old man who appears to have sustained a skull fracture. You take a history and observe that the fracture has occurred due to a baseball bat blow to the right  anterolateral side of the skull and that the patient only began experiencing symptoms an hour or so after the blow. He complains further of double vision, extreme pain and is bleeding at an alarming rate. Given the circumstances and the anatomy of the skull, what is the likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
A heavy blow to the anterolateral side of the skull is likely to have fractured the pterion area of the skull, a H shaped junction where the temporal, sphenoid, parietal and frontal bone sutures meet. This area is the thinnest part of the skull and can be easily damaged. Furthermore, it lies over the middle menial artery, which emerges through the foramen spinosum to supply the dura mater  and the calvaria (the superior aspects of the frontal bone, occipital bone, and parietal bones).

 

An epidural/extradural haematoma,  is a form of traumatic brain injury in which an accumulation of blood occurs between the dura mater  and the skull. The dura mater runs down to the spinal column; thus the epidural bleeds may also occur in the spinal column. These injuries commonly occur from ruptures of meningeal arteries, including the middle meningeal artery as in this example. The period of asymptomatic condition in the patient is the lucid period, and is commonly associated with the injury. The bleeding is rapid as from arteries at high pressure and around 1 in 5 cases are fatal.

Question: What is the complete set of roles of Aldosterone?
OptionA: Decreases NaCl reabsorption in the Distal Convoluted Tubule/Collecting tubule and duct
OptionB: Decreases phosphate absorption and increases calcium absorption in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule, Thick ascending Loop of Henle
OptionC: Increases H20 absorption in the Collecting tubule and duct/Distal Convoluted Tubule
OptionD: Increases NaCl, H2O reabsorption, and K+ secretion in the Collecting tubule and Duct
OptionE: Increases NaCl, H20 reabsorption, and H+ secretion in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule, Thick ascending Loop of Henle, Collecting tubule
Explanation:
A-ANP (Atrial natriuretic Peptide)

B- Parathyroid Hormone

C-ADP (Anti-diuretic Hormone)/Vasopressin

D-Aldosterone (the answer)

E-Angiotensin II

Question:
Lesions to the visual pathway can cause decreased vision in the eyes. The diagram above shows a bitemporal hemianopia. 

 

Where could the lesion have occured to cause this?
OptionC: In the midline of the optic chiasm
Explanation: If you compress the chiasm the fibers from the nasal side of the retina cross to the opposite optic tract. These fibers convey impulses from the temporal half of the image from both eyes. As shown above by the shaded area.

Question:
Hypoprothrombinoema is a bleeding disorder associated with the deficiency of a particular vitamin. 

 

Which vitamin is deficient in hypoprothrombinoema?
Explanation:
A - Night blindness

C- Scurvy

D - Rickets in children and Ostmalacia (Affects bone growth)

E Hemolytic anaemia the break down of Red Blood cell membranes 

 

K- is a vitamin needs for blood clotting hence a deficiency in vitamin K causes bleeding disorders.

Question:
The hypothalamus receive sensory input from the environment. This then causes the release of a hormone(s) that travel to the anterior pituitary. These hormone(s) then stimulate the release of a hormone from the anterior pituitary.

 

Which hormones from the hypothalamus control the release of Growth Hormone in the anterior pituitary?
Explanation:
GHRH (growth hormone releasing hormone) stimulate the release of growth hormone.

Somatostatin inhibits the release of growth hormone in the anterior pituitary.

Dopamine stimulates the release of Prolactin.

GnRH (gonadotrophin releasing hormone) stimulates the release of LH and FSH.

Question:
This is a histological slide of the trachea. 

How would you classify the epithelium here?

For extra, Identify A, B, C, D and the Red Arrow (answers will be in the explanation)
Explanation:
This is pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. 

This question was on the extra web pages Dr. Wilson has put on learning central for us.

For reference:

A - Basal Cells

B - Cilia

C - Goblet Cell

D - Connective Tissue

Red Arrow - Basal bodies to which the cilia are bound

Question:
Whilst on placement at the Sexual Health clinic, you are approached by a young male who randomly asks you which components of your Nervous system are responsible for:

A) Inducing an erection   and:

B) Causing ejaculation.

 

Although slightly taken aback, what are the correct answers?
Explanation: From the anatomy booklet given in case 2, the Parasympathetic part of the ANS is responsible for inducing an erection, with the Sympathetic branch causing ejaculation.

Question: The immune system helps defend the body against infections. Which of the following is an example of passive immunity?
OptionA: IgE binding to basophils to facilitate an inflammatory response
OptionB: IgD passing through the placenta to the foetus for antibody mediated immunity
OptionD: Transfer of IgA antibodies to a newborn baby via breast milk
OptionE: IgD and IgM forming a component of B cell antigen receptor
Explanation: Passive immunity is the transfer of active immunity in the form of ready made antibodies. Another example is IgG passing to the foetus through the placenta (not IgD). All the others are active immunity where antibodies are produced due to exposure to a pathogen.

Question: Mr Davies arrived in A&E with severe chest pain, central cyanosis, and  breathlessness. His troponin was raised and he was rushed to the cath lab for percutaneous intervention and a stent was put into one of his coronary arteries. After the surgery he is thankful to still be alive. The Dr tells him that if he wants to avoid another dance with death, taking the oral medications aspirin and clopidogrel would be a really good idea. Mr Davies wants to know what these drugs will do, what will his Dr tell him?
OptionA: Aspirin and clopidogrel are anticoagulants. They will prevent platelets adhering to each other in the coronary arteries.
OptionB: Aspirin and clopidogrel are antithrombotics. They reduce the amount of clotting factor in the blood.
OptionC: Aspirin and clopidogrel are anti-platelet agents. They will prevent the activation of platelets which might occur due to exposure of collagen during stenting.
OptionD: Aspirin and clopidogrel are anti-platelet agents. They will destroy platelets reducing the clotting ability of the blood.
OptionE: Aspirin and clopidogrel are anti-platelet agents. They raise the amount of Von Willebrand factor in the blood.
Explanation:
After an MI (which is what the question implies) and stenting of a coronary artery, the artery is held open but collagen and other endothelial components may become exposed to the blood in the process.

 

Collagen can form bonds with platelets via integrins and this starts the chain of activation. Once activated, platelets change shape allowing them to aggregate at the injury site, they also release substances that activate other platelets.

 

Two of the substances released by activated platelets are Thromboxane and ADP which stimulate activation of other platelets.

 

Aspirin prevents Thromboxane A2 production by platelets, preventing other platelets being activated.

 

Clopidogrel blocks ADP receptors on platelets, preventing other platelets being activated.

 

Together these drugs work synergistically to prevent the spread of platelet activation, and prevent a platelet plug forming and potentially causing another occlusion of an artery.
Tags: Biochemistry, Blood Cells, Haemostasis, Blood Circulation, Cardiology

Question:
A young man visits you with fears he may have contracted Hepatitis B. He was severely ill a few months ago after having unprotected sex on a night out. As the patient is unsure of his vaccination history, and his NHS record is missing, you run some serology tests and observe the results as 

HBsAg-negative

anti-HBc-positive

anti-HBs-positive

What is the best guess at the indication of these results given the rough history?
OptionA: The patient was not infected with hepatitis B but is susceptible to the infection, having no exposure, and is in desperate need of vaccination.
OptionB: The patent has received a Hepatitis B vaccination and is immune to infection
OptionC: The patient is in the stage of Chronic Hepatitis B infection
OptionD: The patient is in the stage of acute hepatitis B infection
OptionE: The patient is immune to Hepatitis B due to a previously resolved infection
Explanation: A negative HBsAg result indicates no infection, while a positive indication of anti-HBc and anti-HBs indicates that antigens have been produced in response to previous exposure to Hepatitis B virus. If only anti-HBc were produced, this would indicate a current infection and other serology measurements, such as IgM anti-HBc would be needed to more definitely determine the level of infection.

Question: A 58 year old man who experienced and survived a STEMI a few days ago complains of mild chest pain that is relived by leaning forward.  What further complication of a Myocardial Infarction is most likely causing this symptom?
Explanation: Fibrinous Pericarditis can cause a friction rub between the two layers of pericardium (visceral and parietal); pain is usually dermatomes of C3-C5 and is relived by leaning forward as the heart is lifted off the diaphragm. All of the other options are key follow ons from an MI and could all cause pain; the key alleviating factor selects E as the best option. Treatment could be pericardiocentesis or pericardiectomy depending on the patient.

Question:
The Adrenal Cortex is functionally and anatomically divided into 3 distinct regions.

What hormone class is synthesised and secreted In the middle cortex region, called the Zona Fasciculata?
Explanation:
Adrenal Cortex;

- Outer Cortex Zona Glomerulosa synthesises Mineralocorticoids (mainly aldosterone)
- Middle Cortex Zona Fasciculata synthesises Glucocorticoids (mainly cortisol)
- Inner Cortex Zona Reticularis synthesises Androgens (mainly DHEA) and Glucocorticoids

 

Adrenal Medulla;

- compromised of 2 neuroendocrine cell types;
1.) Noradrenaline secreting cells (make up 20%)
2.) Adrenaline secreting cells (make up 80%)
- Noradrenaline and Adrenaline are known as Catecholamines

Question: A recurrent patient presents with Alcoholic liver disease and wants to learn more about the pathology of his condition.You tell him that his condition is still reversible if he adopts certain lifestyle changes. Which of the following cannot be true given what you have just told him about his condition?
OptionA: There is likely steatosis in his liver
OptionB: There may be hepatitis present in his liver
OptionC: There is likely the presence of hepatocyte mallory bodies
OptionD: Micronodular fibrosis may be present in the liver
OptionE: Decreased levels of NAD are likely in the liver
Explanation:
D is the alcoholic form of cirrhosis-micronodulars of less than 3mm size are abundantly present in uniform size following severe metabolic insult. Fibrosis is irreversible liver damage,; steatosis liver damage is often a short term phenomena and this macrovesicular change can be reversed by cessation of alcohol. Alcohol induced hepatitis is often reversible with alcohol cessation and the damage is mediated by acetaldehyde in ethanol processing. Many years of alcohol abuse it takes to cause this hepatitis usually but cessation of alcohol can reverse its effects more often than not. Mallory bodies come oath this hepatitis; this are formed when hepatocytes are over filled with eosinophils and damage to cytokeratins occurs.

 

NAD levels drop as a result of alcohol over consumption as NAD acts as the limiting reagent in ethanol processing, becoming NADH first when ethanol reacts with alcohol dehydrogenase to become acetaldehyde, and again once acetaldehyde reacts with acetaldehyde dehydrogenase to become acetate. If ethanol levels are too high, NAD is often used up, being NAD levels will be low and will continue to be low unless one stops consuming ethanol.

Question: Smooth muscle contraction varies in signalling compared to cardiac and skeletal muscle contraction. A patient is having problems with relaxing her arterial smooth muscle due to her natural inability to produce one substance? From the following, which substance is she likely struggling to produce?
Explanation:
Nitric Oxide is a soluble guanyly cyclase that produces cGMP; this activates Protein Kinase G that thus causes phosphorylation of  Myosin light chain Phosphatase (the enzyme responsible for smooth muscle relaxation which stops myosin light chain binding to actin) that converts Myosin Light Chain to form inactivated MLC which causes relaxation. Calmodulin is the enzyme that binds to Calcium to activate MLC Kinase that phosphorylates MLC and allows contraction to occur. Myoglobulin is what Oxygen is stored within in muscle tissue, particularly type 1 muscle fibres.

Phospholipase C is activated by Gq protein coupled receptor and hydrolyses PI (4,5)P2 to IP3 and diacylglycerol, with IP3 allowing IP3-gated Calcium release channels to open on SR membrane, causing influx of Calcium into the cytosol of the muscle cell.
Tags: Microanatomy, Biochemistry, Case 1, Physiology, muscle contraction

Question: A 70-year-old male is rushed to A and E for what he believes is his second MI within 15 years. His medical history also highlights severe COPD. After receiving aspirin, morphine, and face mask oxygen in the ambulance, the patient arrives to A&E tachycardic with a normal blood pressure. A 12 lead ECG shows ST-elevation in leads  I, aVL, and V5-V6.  Which of following beta-blockers should be given to this patient and why?
OptionA: Metoprolol, because it is a non-selective beta-adrenoreceptor blocker
OptionB: Propranolol, because it is a non-selective beta-adrenoreceptor blocker
OptionC: Atenolol, because it is a selective Beta-1-adrenorecptor blocker
OptionD: Timolol, because it is a selective Beta-1-adrenorecptor blocker
OptionE: Timolol, because it is a non-selective beta-adrenoreceptor blocker
Explanation:
A-Right drug, but wrong type; Metoprolol is Beta-1 selective and not non-selective as the option states. So this drug could have been used but the option is wrong factually.

B-Propanolol is not the best drug as it is a non-selective Beta adrenoreceptor blocker

C-The best option; atenolol is Beta-1 selective and this drug should be used as the patient has a history of COPD, and a non-selective beta blocker could run the risk of bronchoconstriction caused by beta-2-adrenoreceptor activation

D and E-E is factually correct but this is not the best option given the patient's history of COPD.

 

The ECG readings were just used as part of the stem but for those interested, they leads were all LATERAL areas of the coronary anatomy, meaning that the thrombus causing the infarct was likely in the Right Circumflex Artery
Tags: Cardiology, Cardiovascular System, case 4, Pharmacology, Case 5

Question:
A patient is treated in A&E with a fracture to the surgical neck of the humerus. This is his xray. 

 

You notice he has sensory loss to the lateral surface of his upperarm, what nerve may have been damaged?
Explanation:
Axillary nerve - It comes out of the quadrangular sqaure below the teres minor and above the teres majore then wraps around the surgical neck of the humerus. As shown in the picture here. 

 

The radial nerve may be damaged by a humerus shaft fracture and which can lead to wrist drop.

The ulnar nerve is most likely to be damaged when there is a sharp blow to the 'funny bone' or the posterior side of the medial epicondyle. 

The median nerve is most commonly linked to carpal tunnel syndrome (tingling of the hands)
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of the upper limb

Question: A 17-year-old male presents to a geneticist for further evaluation. His doctor noticed he is tall for his age and has small testes and gynaecomastia. Upon further testing, what genetic finding will this patient most likely have?
OptionB: 46, XY, but a diagnosis of androgen insensitivity syndrome
Explanation:
This patient's presentation, though brief,  is most consistent with Klinefelter's syndrome; genetic disorder in which patients have a karyotype of 47, XXY.

 The presence of an additional X-chromosome means that affected individuals are typically asymptomatic throughout childhood and present in adolescence or early adulthood with includes tall stature, small testes, and gynaecomastia. Typically azoospermia (the absence of motile sperm) is also present, meaning most people diagnosed are infertile. Late onset of puberty should prompt further evaluation, however often by diagnosis, unfortunately any chance for any therapeutic interventions has passed. Testosterone replacement therapy can be used if diagnosed at a young age to help deal with the effects of the genetic disorder and may help fertility.
Tags: Sexual Health, Case 2, Puberty, reproductive system

Question: A patient is found to have abnormally high levels of hormone secretion by the S endocrine cells in her duodenum. Which of the following would you most expect to find in this patient?
Explanation:
The S endocrine cells in the duodenum produce the hormone secretin, which increases pancreatic HCO3- secretion.

There are 3 types of enteroendocrine cells in the duodenum, and each of them secretes a hormone that acts on the pancreas:

1. I Cells -> cholecystokinin (CCK) -> increase pancreatic secretions
2. S cells -> secretin -> increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion
3. K cells -> gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) -> increase insulin release

In addition to its action on the pancreas, secretin also decreases gastric acid secretion and increases bile secretion.  The release of gastric HCl into the duodenum is the most potent stimulator for secretin release. Increased levels of HCO3- act to neutralize gastric acid in the duodenum thereby allowing proper functioning of pancreatic enzymes.

Question: Robbie falls over whilst playing football. On X-ray he is found to have fractured his Hook of Hamate. Which nerve is most likely to have been affected?
Explanation:
Ulnar nerve turns around the hook of hamate. The hook of hamate is also the distal lateral border of the Guyon canal in which the ulnar nerve runs.

The other nerves do not run this close to the hook of hamate.

Question: Which of the following description is true when comparing the ileum to the jejunum?
OptionB: Ileum has longer vasa recta and more prominent plicae circulares
OptionC: The Ileum has a greater diameter and is thicker
OptionD: Only the Ileum is supplied by the Superior Mesenteric artery branches
OptionE: Only the Jejunum is supplied by the Ileocolic artery of the Superior Mesenteric Artery
Explanation:
A-Only true one

B-The opposite, the ileum has shorter vasa recta and less prominent plicae circulares

C-The opposite, the jejunum has a greater diameter and is thicker but the ileum has more mesenteric fat 

D-Both the ileum and jejunum are supplied by SMA branches

E-Only the ileum is supplied by the ileocolic artery; clue in the name.

Question:
Diana a 31 year-old patient is admitted into hospital with symptoms of involuntary contractions of her muscles. The doctor you are shadowing takes you to examine Diana and explains that she is suffering from hypocalcemia. 

What hormone is released to cause blood calcium levels to rise during normal calcium homeostasis?
Explanation:
Low plasma levels of calcium causes the parathyroid to release parathyroid hormone.

High plasma levels of calcium cause thyroid to release calcitonin

The involuntary muscle twitching the patient experiences is due to the role of calcium in muscle contraction.

A common cause of hypocalcemia is vitamin D deficiency, because it increases absorption of calcium in the GI tract

Question: A young woman visits her optician complaining of double vision and sight problems. She is caucasian and the optician refers her to a neurologist straight away as he see nothing wrong with her eyes. What cell type is likely causing the pathology here?
Explanation: This is classic case of Multiple sclerosis (MS) as described by Dr Santer; oligodendrocytes can lead to degeneration of myelin in pathology that can causes a wide range of symptoms including double vision and sudden outbursts of pain. MS is the most common permanently disabling disorder of the central nervous system seen in young adults; it is most common in caucasian females. Of the subtypes of MS, relapsing-remitting is the most common of which typical symptoms include sensory, motor and coordination disturbances, optic neuritis, as well as fatigue. Importantly, the course of disease is highly variable. . Diagnosis and response to therapy can be assessed with MR imaging, which is the gold standard diagnostic tool.

Question: An athlete is involved in a half-marathon competition that results in her tearing her semitendinosus muscle in severe extension of her leg at the knee in eccentric contraction of the hamstrings muscles. She is informed that the tear is towards the origin of this muscle. Which of these is the correct origin of the semitendinosus muscle?
Explanation: The semitendinous and semimembranous muscle both originate from the ischial tuberosity, part of the hip. The biceps femoris long head originates from the ischial tuberosity and the short head originates from the linea aspera of femur.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of pelvis and perineum, Anatomy of the lower limb, Case 1

Question: A 45-year-old man is brought to A&E after being found down in the middle of the street. Witnesses reported to the police that they had seen the man as he exited a local bar, where he was subsequently assaulted. He sustained severe facial trauma, including multiple lacerations and facial bone fractures.  Several days later, he complains of the inability to open his mouth wide or to completely chew his food, both of which he seemed able to do prior to surgery he had on the night of the attack. Where does the affected nerve exit the skull?
Explanation:
Thee man  likely suffered an iatrogenic injury to the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve. CNV3 exits the skull via the foramen ovale.

The divisions of the trigeminal nerve exit the skull via the superior orbital fissue (CNV1), the foramen rotundum (CNV2), and the foramen ovale (CNV3). CNV3 is composed of both motor and sensory components, the motor of which are responsible for the muscles of mastication. Injury to CNV3 would produce symptoms as presented in the question stem.
Tags: Cranial Nerves, Nervous system, Neuroanatomy, Case 6

Question: A 55 year old man comes into hospital with a suspected myocardical infarction. An ECG is performed which indicates an ST elevation. This elevation is in leads V1 to V4. Which artery is involved?
Explanation: If V1-V4 have ST elevation the MI has occurred in the anterior or anteroseptal area of the heart. The LAD supplies this region of the heart.

Question: A woman comes in with a bilateral loss of the temporal visual field. What could be causing her this visual deficit?
OptionA: Lesion of the retina or optic nerve before the chiasm
OptionC: A lesion in the lateral geniculate nucleus
Explanation: The chiasm sits over the pituitary and so tumours in this structures can compress the chiasm which would prevent transmission in the crossing fibres.

Question: You begin to notice pain during urinating and in your lower abdomen, as well as heavier periods and a change in discharge. After visiting a sexual health you receive a diagnosis and are prescribed a single dose of azithromycin. What is the organism causing this condition?
Explanation:
Human papillomavirus can cause genital warts.

Plasmodium ovale is a malaria causing protazoa.

Treponema pallidum causes syphillis,

Herpes simplex virus causes herpes.

 

Although the the symptons can be indicative of many conditions, chlamydia will have a change in discharge but is unlikely to be yellow/green (gonorrhea). Also, the antibiotic azithromycin is commonly used for Chlamydia.
Tags: Sexual Health, Pharmacology, Case 2, Lectures, reproductive system

Question: How does Noradrenaline cause smooth muscle relaxation?
OptionA: Via Beta-2 receptors: activates Gs which leads to Protein Kinase A inactivating Myosin Light Chain Kinase
OptionB: Via Alpha-1 receptors: activates Gs which leads to Protein Kinase A inactivating Myosin Light Chain Kinase
OptionC: Via Alpha-1 receptors: activate Gq leading to an increase in IP3, increasing Calcium levels in the cell
OptionD: Via M3 Muscarinic Receptor: Activates Gq leading to an increase in IP3, increasing Calcium levels in the cell
OptionE: Via beta-2 receptors: Activates Gi leading to depleted levels of Protein kinase A, which increases activation of myosin phosphatase
Explanation:
NA binds to the beta-2 receptor. A conformational change causes the Gs-alpha subunit to cleave and bind to adenyl cyclase, activating it. ATP is converted to cAMP which activates protein kinase A. Protein kinase A causes inactivation of myosin light chain kinase, and activation of myosin light chain phosphatase. This results in relaxation of the cell. 

 

Alpha-1 receptors bind NA to cause smooth muscle contraction. NA binds to Gq, this activates Phospholipase C which leaves PIP2 in to IP3 and DAG. IP3 interact with calcium channels of the endoplasmic reticulum, causing a release of calcium into the cell; and therefore the cell contracts.
Tags: Nervous system, Neurotransmitters, Pharmacology, muscle contraction

Question: An woman with frequent gastrointestinal complaints undergoes a bowel biopsy.  The pathologist observes that submucosal glands of Brunner are present in the specimen used for the biopsy? Which portion of the GI tract was most likely biopsied?
Explanation:
The duodenum is part of the small intestine contains the submucosal glands of Brunner, which secrete alkaline mucous.

 

It is worth knowing that only the duodenum and esophagus contain glands in the submucosal layer of the GI tract.

 

Secretions from Brunner's glands pass into the crypts of Lieberkuhn and are released into the lumen. Brunner's glands secrete neutral and alkaline glycoproteins and bicarbonate ions, a mixture that neutralizes the acidic chyme arriving in the duodenum from the stomach; in a way this supplements that bicarbonate secretions from the ducts cells, stimulated by secretin released by S cells in the duodenum. The increase in the pH protects the duodenum and brings the pH closer to the range needed for proper functioning of the pancreatic enzymes of digestion.
Tags: Anatomy, Functions of different tissues, Gastrointestinal System, Histology, Case 3

Question: Anna presents to her GP with complaints of a tight chest pain upon exertion which eases with rest. She says she is asthmatic, so the doctor gives her Ivabradine as an alternative to a Beta-Blocker. What is the mechanism of action of the drug?
OptionA: Liberates NO in the body which activates guanylyl cyclase to convert GTP to cGMP activating PKG which lowers intracellular calcium and phosphorylates and inactivates MLCK for smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.
OptionB: Diffuses through the membrane and binds to the intracellular part of calcium channels causing a conformational change to inactivate the channels thus cause a negative inotropic and negative chronotropic effects on the heart and cause vasodilation.
OptionC: Binds to B1-adrenoceptors in the heart to competitively inhibit the bidning of adrenaline or NA which prevents activation of adenylyl cyclase thus cAMP production would activate PKA to phosphorylate and open L-type calcium channels - it therefore has negative inotropic and chronotropic effects.
OptionD: Activates guanylyl cyclase to liberate cGMP thus PKG causing smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation as in A.
OptionE: Inhibits the mixed Na-K inward current which generates the 'funny current' in SA nodes to begin depolarisation - it therefore reduces the rate of depolarisation thus having a negative chronotropic effect on the heart.
Explanation:
A is the action of organic nitrates such as glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) or isosorbide mononitrate

B is a calcium channel block such as verapamil

C is a beta-blocker such as propranolol

D is the action of nicorandil

E is the action of ivabradine

Question: It has been found that, at its peak, Ndaba's voice can reach a sound intensity of 120 dB. For how long is it safe to be exposed to this intensity of sound in one day?
OptionE: It is not safe to be exposed to this much sound at all...Ndaba should keep his mouth shut
Explanation: At 85 dB (considered to be the start of the 'danger zone') safe exposure time is 8 hours. For every 3 dB increase in sound intensity the safe exposure time halves (or decreases by a factor of 10 for every 10 dB increase). Following this method, safe exposure time for 120 dB is roughly 7 seconds. This is not to be confused with dB measurements for sound pressure level (dB SPL) for which a 6 dB increase represents a doubling in pressure and a 20 dB increase represents a tenfold increase in pressure.

Question:
As a young F1 doctor you are told by your consultant to review a patient who has Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES). Luckily you had just read up on this condition the night before and are able to recall that it is caused by a gastrinoma and patients present with various symptoms including diarrhoea and vomiting blood.

Unfortunately for you the consultant is not interested in the symptoms you memorised in the Oxford Clinical Handbook and instead wants to know how gastrin indirectly causes HCl release.

What is your reply?
OptionA: acts on P cells to stimulate release of histamine which induces H+ secretion in parietal cells
OptionB: acts on ECL cells to stimulate release of histamine which induces H+ secretion in chief cells
OptionC: acts on ECL cells to stimulate release of somatostatin which induces H+ secretion in chief cells
OptionD: acts on D cells to stimulate release of histamine which induces H+ secretion in parietal cells
OptionE: acts on ECL cells to stimulate release of histamine which induces H+ secretion in parietal cells
Explanation:
Gastrin indirectly causes H+ release by binding to CCK2 receptors on ECL (enterochromaffin like) cells which stimulates the release of histamine. Histamine acts on parietal cells to cause release of H+ into the lumen of the stomach

Gastrin also has a direct effect by inducing insertion of K+/H+ ATPase pumps onto apical membrane of parietal cells

Question: Jo presents to her GP concerned that she is at risk of a heart attack after her mother recently suffered an MI. The GP explains to her that a high risk factor of atherosclerosis is high blood pressure. With high risk being around 130/80.  You are a medical student and the GP asks you to calculate the pulse pressure from this and then the mean arterial pressure. What are the correct values for these.
Explanation:
PULSE PRESSURE: this is calculated by (systolic)- (diastolic), in this case this is (130)- (80)= 50

MEAN PRESSURE: this is 1/3 of the pulse pressure (calculated above as 50) + the diastolic pressure, in this case (1/3(50)) + (80)= 97
Tags: Cardiology, Cardiovascular System, case 4, numeracy, calculations

Question: A 28-year-old male visits his GP because of fertility issues with his wife. Physical exam reveals bilateral gynaecomastia, elongated limbs, and shrunken testicles. Levels of plasma gonadotropins-FSH and LH- are elevated. Which of the following is also likely to be increased in this patient?
Explanation:
The clinical presentation is consistent with Klinefelter syndrome (of 47, XXY), which is characterized by elevated aromatase and is caused by a karyotype of two or more X chromosomes due to nondisjunction or translocation during meiosis.

Patients with Klinefelter syndrome have decreased testosterone levels due to Leydig cell dysfunction. Loss of Sertoli cells also occurs, and leads to decreased levels of inhibin. Thus plasma gonadotropin levels increase due to a lack of negative feedback. The increase in serum FSH up-regulates aromatase, which leads to increased conversion of testosterone to oestrogen. The estrogen:testosterone ratio is highly correlated to the degree of feminization in patients with Klinefelter syndrome, that is displayed in what the GP saw in the PE.
Tags: Anatomy, Sexual Health, Genetics, Case 2, Puberty

Question:
Mrs. Harris has a serious kidney infection. You are required to give her a 65g dose of antibiotic. The stock solution contains 500mg per 2ml. 

How many ml of the solution will you give to Mrs. Harris?
Explanation: If there are 500mg in 2ml, there is 1g in 4ml. Therefore for 65g, you will need 65x4ml = 260ml

Question: Which of the following would be expected to cause renal inulin (or creatinine) clearance to increase?
Explanation: E - Both dilation of the afferent arteriole and constriction of the efferent arteriole would increase glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure and thus increase GFR. (Note that inulin (or creatinine) clearance is a measure of GFR).

Question:
You are fortunate enough to watch Azeem's Senior Flute Recital. During his performance, your stereocilia are deflecting like mad. This causes the ion channels, governed by tip links, to open and the ions flow into the stereocilia due to the endcochlear potential.

What are these ions?
Explanation: Taken from Dr. Watson's plenary (Case 6, Plenary 3)

Question: Which of the following is NOT an action of angiotensin-II?
Explanation:
Angiotensin is a peptide hormone which is derived from the precursor molecule angiotensionogen (serum globulin released in the liver.

 

Overall the action is to increase blood pressure by various ways:

Reabsorption of Na+, H2O follows

Potent direct vasoconstrictors, constriction arteries and veins - increase the blood pressure

increases secretion of ADH in the posterior pituitary to increase water reabsorption

Angiotensin II has a direct effect on the proximal tubules to increase Na+ reabsorption

Angiotensin II acts on the adrenal cortex, causing it to release aldosterone, a hormone that causes the kidneys to retain sodium and lose potassium.
Tags: Blood Circulation, PCS, Hormones, Kidneys, Renal

Question: If a person takes 3 grams of salt with little water, what changes, if any will occur to the blood osmolality, ADH levels and GFR in a hydrated individual?
OptionA:
• Blood osmolality increases
  • ADH levels remains same 
  • GFR remains same
OptionB:
• Blood osmolality decreases
  • ADH levels decreases
  • GFR remains decreases
OptionC:
• Blood osmolality decreases
  • ADH levels decreases
  • GFR remains same
Explanation:
• Blood osmolality increases because blood solute concentration increases
  • ADH level increases to increase permeability of collecting duct to reabsorb more water
  • GFR increases as blood volume increases

Question: A 28-year-old woman presents to a GP with decreased appetite, malaise, and fever. Serologic tests reveal positive Anti-HBsAg and Anti-HAV IgM antibodies. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
Explanation:
IgM antibodies to hepatitis A (HAV) are indicative of recent or acute infection of HAV. HAV can be acquired via the faeco-oral route; also by contaminated food and water, and contaminated shellfish to those interested.

Hepatitis A is an ssRNA picorna virus that accounts for 30-45% of acute viral hepatitis. It is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, through contaminated food, water, and shellfish. The patient in the question stem has also been immunized against hepatitis B, as evidenced by her positive Anti-HBsAg serology.

Question: A 24 year old female presents to the surgery complaining that she bruises easily whilst playing netball. A history reveals she has a poor diet lacking leafy green vegetables. Following examination the GP suggests that vitamin K deficiency may be the answer. Vitamin K deficiency means several clotting factors cannot be made in the liver, but which of the following clotting factors is NOT Vitamin K dependent? Bonus points if you can name the drug which targets this pharmacologically.
Explanation: Factors 2, 7, 9 and 10 are all vitamin K dependent. Remember them as a pirated Taylor Swift album '1972' (10, 9, 7, 2). Warfarin, as a vitamin K reductase means fewer of these factors are made and as a result it takes longer for blood to coagulate. Green leafy vegetables are rick in Vit K

Question:
An elderly lady is addmitted after a heart attack. Her EDV is 105 and ESV is 65. Her blood pressure is 150/95.

You want assess the severity of her condition, what is her ejection fraction?
Explanation:
Ejection Fraction = (SV/EDV) X 100

 

Stroke volume is EDV- ESV and is equal to 40 ml ( 70 is normal)

 

Normal value is between 55-70%. After a heart attack ejection fraction is often low.

 

Blood pressure is high here but no needed to calculate her ejection fraction
Tags: Cardiology, Cardiovascular System, cardiac cycle, case 4
