Question: Mr Griffiths has a lower motor neurone lesion and has come to visit his neurologist for a review of his symptoms. The consultant neurologist says you (a medical student) can sit in on the consultation, at the start of the consultation he asks you to name the main signs associated with lower motor neurone lesions.
OptionA: Spasticity, focal weakness, fascilculations, muscle wasting, exaggerated reflexes, absent plantar reflex
OptionB: Flaccid focal weakness, fasciculations, muscle wasting, weak or absent reflexes, absent or normal plantar reflex.
OptionC: Spastic pyramidal weakness, absence of fasciculations, no muscle wasting, exaggerated reflexes, toes point up in plantar reflex
OptionD: Flaccid pyramidal weakness, fasciculations, muscle wasting, absence of reflexes, toes go up in plantar reflex
OptionE: Spastic focal weakness, absence of fasciculations, no muscle wasting, absence of reflexes, absence of plantar reflex
Explanation:
Lesions in upper motor neurone symptoms:

- high muscle tone (spasticity)

- pyramidal pattern of weakness

- lack of fasciculations

- no muscle wasting

- exaggerated reflexes

- abnormal plantar reflex (toes point up instead of down)

 

Lower motor neurone lesion symptoms:

- loss of muscle tone (flaccidity)

- focal pattern of weakness (often starting at the peripharies)

- fasciculations

- muscle wasting

 - weak or absent reflexes

- absent or normal plantar reflex

Question: A paracetamol overdose of >12g results in significant hepatocyte damage and is potentially lethal. This is because of the accumulation of what toxic substance?
Explanation:
Normal paracetamol metabolism

  • majority of the paracetamol is directed down the glucuronidation pathway
  • inactivating the drug and making it water soluble by sulphination.
  • this means it can be easily excreted
  • only very small amounts of paracetamol are involved with the cytochrome pathway,
  • with CYP1A2 and CYP2E1 generating the toxic NAPBQI.
  • this is very rapidly deactivated by conjugation to glutathione, an anti oxidant, so no net damage is done to hepatocytes. 

Overdose of paracetamol

  • the high concentration of paracetamol overwhelms the UGT enzyme in the glucuronidation pathway
  • so excess paracetamol is forced down the cytochrome pathway instead.
  • a much larger quantity of NAPBQI is generated
  • glutathione reserves rapidly depleted by liver
  • build up of NAPBQI in hepatocytes leading to necrosis

Depending on the concentration of paracetamol in blood and the time since consumption, NAC can be given by IV to replenish glutathione levels.

>15hrs --> irreversible damage to the liver --> internal bleeding as clotting factors aren't produced --> death

Question:
Duncan is a 56 year old man who was recently featured in a channel 4 series "Secret Eaters". It was revealed on the show that his BMI of 34 was down to his longstanding lifestyle choices; which included a calorific intake of 3600 calories a day and meals high in saturated fat. In his post- show medical checkup the doctor found that Duncan's serum cholesterol was high enough for him to be prescribed a drug to lower his cholesterol. 

 

 

The doctor considers several drugs. 

 

Which drug is matched to its correct mode of action?
OptionA: Fibrates: Competitive inhibitor of intracellular cholesterol pathway- leading to greater uptake of LDLs from plasma and therefore a decrease in serum cholesterol
OptionB: Bile Acid Sequestrants: Stimulate LPL and HDL activity
OptionC: Statins: Competitive inhibitor of intracellular cholesterol pathway- leading to greater uptake of LDLs from plasma and therefore a decrease in serum cholesterol
OptionD: Fibrates: Inhibit intestinal absorption of cholesterol by binding to components of bile
Explanation:
Statins: Competitive inhibitor of the rate limiting enzyme in the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway. By reducing the synthesis of cholesterol inside the cell it must get its cholesterol from the plasma. The cell removes cholesterol from the plasma and therefore reduces serum cholesterol levels 

 

Fibrates: Stimulate the activity of LPL so cells take up more triglycerides; by increasing HDL levels they promote the reverse cholesterol pathway which leads to more cholesterol being taken back to the liver for excretion in bile salts 

 

Bile Acid Sequestrants: Rarely used anymore but they work by binding to components of bile to prevent it from being reabsorbed from the gut. Less bile reabsorbed means less cholesterol reabsorbed

Question:
The heart has myogenic actvity which means that  it has an intrinsic ability to beat without an external nervous stimuli. 

 

The SAN is the pacemaker of the cell located in the right atrium 

 

Which statement is incorrect about the SAN ?
OptionA: Depolarization occurs via an influx of Ca2+
OptionB: The "funny current" is activated upon hyperpolarisation and leads to an influx of Na+
OptionD: There are 3 phases for a SAN action potential
OptionE: The pacemaker potential occurs between 2 action potentials
Explanation:
The three phases of an SAN action potential are 4,0 and 3

 

The "funny current" is responsible for the spontaneous depolarization stage (end of Phase 4) . After the end of an AP the membrane is hyperpolarised, this opens Na+ channels which leads to an influx of Na+ into the cell.

 

NOTE!: The Na+ influx causes the membrane to reach the threshold potential. Once the threshold potential has been met Ca+ open 

  • It is the influx of Ca+ in Phase 0 which causes depolarization of the membrane and the firing of an AP 

Phase 3 is repolarisation, it is caused by the closing of Ca+ channels and opening of K+ channels 

 

The cells of the SAN have no resting potential 

  • The resisting potential is the voltage difference across a membrane when the cell is unstimulated 

The SAN is never "unstimulated"; it generates spontaneous action potentials which means it is never at rest
Tags: Cardiology, Cardiovascular System, PCS Unit 3, case 4

Question: A 2 year old child presents with a fever, irritability, lack of response to quiet sounds and is continuously tugging and rubbing their ear. You inspect the patient's ears using an otoscope (see image below). How would you treat the patient?
Explanation:
The patient's symptoms suggest that they may have otitis media (an infection of the inner ear) - a common condition in young children as the eustachian tube is not fully developed and is easily blocked - leading to infection. In serous otitis media, fluid may build up in the middle ear which can be seen behind the tympanic membrane using an otoscope (usually bubbles). 

  • Antibiotics would be used to clear infection, grommets can be used in serous otitis media to drain fluid from middle ear 
  • Cochlear implants are inserted in patients who have lost hair cell function but still have functioning sensory neurones
  • Please don't remove a patient's pinna!
  • A Stapedectomy is used to treat otosclerosis - insertion of prosthetic stapes to replace calcified stapes causing conductive hearing loss
  • Earwax may be safely removed if it builds up and blocks the ear canal

Question:
The "Frank- Starling" mechanism is responsible for restoring the output and distribution of blood between the two ventricles. 

 

Let's say the output of the right ventricle increases...

 

Consider the 5 statements below and place them in chronological order of how ventricular output would be restored.

 

The seqence has been started and finished for you 

 

The output of the R. ventricle increases

 

1) Increased contractility of the L ventricle 

2) More blood returns to the L. ventricle 

3) Increased preload on the L. ventricle 

4)  More blood is in the pulmonary circulation

5) Larger stroke volume of L. ventricle  

 

The L. ventricles output now matches the R. ventricles
Explanation: The more blood that returns; the larger degree of stretch placed on the L. ventricle (preload). The more stretch the larger the force of contraction and therefore increased stroke volume :)
Tags: Cardiology, Cardiovascular System, cardiac cycle, case 4

Question:
You are in a long queue on a Monday night waiting to get into Glam. You start speaking to someone in the queue who explains that the bouncer at the door who is controlling who enters is actually an aspiring "transporter". The bouncer has always admired how efficiently the integral proteins in cell surface membranes control the flow of ions and molecules into and out of cells. 

 

Each week the bouncer alternates which protein transporter he wishes to become. 

 

You notice that for every 2 people that leave the club the bouncer will let one in. 

 

Which transporter is he admiring tonight?
Explanation:
Uniporter: Facilitated diffusion of one molecule 

 

Antiporter: Also known as an exchanger- exchange of two or more molecules in opposite directions 

 

Symporter: Two or more molecules in the same direction 

 

GPCR: Is a metabotropic receptor which does not actually allow anything to pass through it but relies on the binding of a ligand to initate further reactions (the bouncer hasnt refined his skills enough to do this one yet)

Question: Brian just passed his test, for the first time. As a 17 year old, he wanted to taste this 'freedom' that all his cool, driving test passing friends are chatting about. So, he ventured out alone in his turbo-engined, tinted windowed Renault Clio (in metallic blue) for the first time on the big old dangerous roads. Brian's bad-ass and he didn't want to use the green p plates (who wants to declare to the world that they've just passed their test?- lame).  Brian thought he'd better stick to the national speed limit of 60mph to gain the respect of others on the road. He took a scenic route where the roads were narrow and windy. He underestimated the bend ahead- silly Brian- so, he crashed. Yet another Renault Clio gone to waste (RIP). He was crying due to the shock of losing his Clio. He was also crying because he was in a lot of pain. It was determined that he had sustained a left brachial plexus injury. After initial recovery it was observed that  his diaphragm functions normally, there was no winging of the scapula but abduction cannot be initiated. However, if the arm is helped through the first 45 degrees of abduction, Brian can fully abduct the arm. So where on earth has Brian injured his brachial plexus?
Explanation:
Let's take the observations one by one to break down this question.

  • If the diaphragm is functioning normally, you know that the phrenic nerve is probably uninjured, which means that the C5 root has not been damaged.
  • Since the scapula is not winged, there was no damage to the long thoracic nerve or the C5-7 nerve roots.
  • Since the patient cannot initiate abduction of the arm, you know that the suprascapular nerve is injured and supraspinatus has been denervated. But, the patient can abduct the arm once it is lifted to 45 degrees, so the deltoid muscle and the axillary nerve must be intact.

Taking the answer choices one by one: The axillary nerve is ok, because deltoid is functioning. The posterior cord of the brachial plexus must also be intact, since this cord gives off the axillary nerve. The roots of the brachial plexus are ok, since the phrenic nerve and long thoracic nerve (which are derived from the roots) are still functioning. The superior trunk of the brachial plexus must also be undamaged, since this trunk contributes to the posterior cord which is intact. So, this means that the injury must be to the suprascapular nerve.
Tags: Anatomy, Nerve innervation of upper limb, Anatomy of the upper limb, Upper limb

Question:
You are standing in A&E discussing how quiet today's shift is with your colleague. Suddenly a man with a laceration to his thigh stumbles through the front door and collapses in front of you. He appears to have been involved in a chainsaw accident and blood is gushing out at an alarming rate. Your first priority is to control the bleeding but unfortunately his blood pressure is falling and he is rapidly becoming ischaemic. 

From what zone of the hepatic acinus would hepatocytes start dying from first?
Explanation: Zone 3 hepatocytes are less well oxygenated and more vulnerable to poor perfusion because they are furthest from the portal triad

Question: As a GP, you are reviewing one of your patients, Mrs Jones. She is 55 years old, overweight and smokes, and has been complaining of breathlessness and chest pain when she is walking to the shops. You decide that given her high risk of a cardiovascular event, she should begin aspirin. When you prescribe it, she is confused and says she thought aspirin was for stopping swelling. In fact, aspirin's anti-inflammatory and anti-platelet action comes from inhibition of the same thing; what does it inhibit?
Explanation:
A- Lipoxygenases- also act on arachidonic acid but they produce eicosanoids rather than prostaglandins. The eicosanoids can then be used to make leukotrienes.

B- the peroxidase domain of PGHS is the second part of the enzyme and converts prostaglandin G to prostaglandin H2.

C- the COX domain of PGGS- this isn't a real enzyme as far as I'm aware

D- phospholipase A2 is involved in the synthesis of prostaglandin H2 but is responsible for cleaving membrane phospholipids to produce arachidonic acid- an earlier step.

E- CORRECT- NSAIDs and aspirin both inhibit this, preventing the first step of PGHS in which arachidonic acid is converted to prostaglandin G. The production of prostaglandin H2 is involved both in platelet aggregation and inflammation.
Tags: Blood Circulation, Cardiology, case 4, Pharmacology, Coagulation

Question: A man comes into your neurology clinic who you suspect has a lesion to his upper facial nerve on the right side of his brain (in the corticobulbar tract). What would you expect to see?
OptionA: Total paralysis of the left side of his face
OptionB: Total paralysis of the right side of his face
OptionC: Paralysis of the lower part of the left side of his face, with forehead sparing
OptionD: Paralysis of the lower part of the right side of his face, with forehead sparing
Explanation:
-The lesion would affect the contralateral side of his face, ie the left side, because the facial nerves cross over to synapse on contralateral lower motor neurones in the pons

-The lesion would cause paralysis of the facial muscles

-The lesion would only affect the lower part of the face, with forehead sparing, because not all of the upper motor neurones cross over. Some synapse onto the ipsilateral lower motor neurones supplying the forehead, meaning that the facial nerve in the left side of the patient's brain can still supply his forehead with innervation. However the ipsilateral facial nerve does not supply facial expression muscles below the eyes so the lower part of the face would be paralysed. Hope this picture helps-
Tags: Neuroanatomy, Brain, Case 6, Clinical Skills, Cranial Nerves

Question:
Tim is having a wild Friday night in the disco room in Pryzm, when suddenly "Reach for the stars" by S Club 7 starts playing. As the chorus begins, his friend Alex knocks him out as he was attempting to reach for the stars, and Tim hits his head badly on the disco room floor. Tim wakes up, realising a drooping of his left eye, he holds his eyelid open, looks in the mirror and is greeted by this: 

Which cranial nerve has Tim damaged? (P.S. don't judge Tim by his age, the disco room is welcome to anyone and everyone.)
Explanation:
Tim has damaged his oculomotor nerve. This causes ptosis, drooping of the upper eyelid; strabismus, a deviation of the eye in which both eyes do not fix on the same object; dilation of the pupil; movement of the eyeball downward and outward on the damaged side; loss of accommodation for near vision; and diplopia, double vision.

 

A) Abducens (VI) Nerve damage would result in: affected eyeball unable to move laterally beyond the midpoint, eye is usually directed medially.

B) Facial (VII) Nerve damage due to viral infection (shingles) or a bacterial infection (Lyme disease) produces Bell's Palsy (paralysis of the facial muscles), loss of taste, decreased salivation, and loss of ability to close the eyes, even during sleep.

C) Optic (II) Nerve damage can cause visual field defects and loss of visual acuity. Blindness due to a defect in or loss of one or both eyes is called anopia. 

E) Glossopharyngeal (IX) Nerve results in difficulty swallowing; reduced secretion of saliva; loss of sensation in the throat, and a loss of taste sensation.

Question:
Below is a normal spirometry trace

 

Below is a second spirometry trace for a patient in your GP surgery. What condition could this patient potentially have based on the spirometry readings?
Explanation:
The spirometry trace shows a restrictive curve because both FEV1 and FVC are lower than normal but the FEV1/FVC ratio is almost normal.

A,C,E and D are obstructive conditions which give a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio on a spirometry trace. FEV1 would be greatly reduced, FVC would also be reduced but not as much as FEV1, affecting the ratio.

Question: A patient has damaged their anterior obturator nerve, which of the following muscles is most likely to be affected?
Explanation:
A - Sartorius - Femoral nerve

 

B - Gracilis - Anterior obturator nerve (CORRECT)

 

C - Rectus Femoris - femoral nerve 

 

D - Hamstrings  - Tibial nerve 

 

E - Gastrocnemius - Tibial nerve 

 

 

These are also the leg muscles that we have to know attachments for so hopefully the pictures are useful.
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of the lower limb, Case 2, Peripheral nerve, Lower Limb

Question: Which two following extra-oculor muscles are not innervated by the oculomtor nerve (CN III)?
Explanation:
The oculomotor nerve innervated: leator palpabrae superioris, superior, inferior and medial rectus and the inferior olique.

 

The superior oblique is innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV) and the lateral rectus is innervated by abducent nerve (CN V1).

Question: Which of the following muscles do NOT belong to the rotator cuff group?
Explanation:
A - Infraspinatus

B - Subscapularis

C - Supraspinatus

D - Teres Minor 

E - Pectoralis major
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of the upper limb, Upper limb, PCS, muscles

Question:
Down at a BioSci lab session you perform an experiement to determine the Vmax and Km for a particular substrate with a particular enzyme. Using your results you plot a double reciprocal graph of your results. As you get ready to pack up, one of the helpers approaches you and asks how the experiment and graph  would be affected if a competitive inhibitor was added. 

 

Which one of these statements is correct about the addition of a competitive inhibitor?
OptionA: The affinity of the enzyme for the original substrate will decrease
OptionB: Slope of the reciprocal graph would increase
OptionD: The y- intercept of the graph would remain the same
Explanation:
A competitive inhibitor binds to the active site of an enzyme preventing the binding of the original substrate. 

 

This means that the enzymes affinity for the original substrate will decrease

  • it is less likely the original substrate will bind to the enzyme to form a complex when a competeive inhibitor is present 

 

Km is a reflection of how well the enzyme binds to a substrate (affinity)

  • Km and affinity are inversley proportional 
  • A low Km reflects a high affinity 
  • A high Km reflects a low affinity 

 

Vmax is the maximum possible reaction velocity and is not affected by the addition of a competitive inhibitor.

  • The y- intercept on a double recirpocal graph is 1/Vmax 
  • If Vmax does not change neither will 1/Vmax and therefore neither will the y- intercept of the graph

Question:
A 15 year old boy falls off his skate board after attempting to pull a 'sweet trick' off a park bench.

 

Upon falling through the bench he sustains multiple abrasions across the anterior compartment of the knee and deep puncture wounds to the posterior compartment of the right calf. 

 

On examination he is unable to invert or plantar flex is right foot, and describes a lack of sensation across the sole of his foot.

 

What nerve has he most likely damaged?
Explanation:
The tibial nerve controls foot inversion and plantar flexion

 

 

Hip flexion ---- Iliopsoas ---- Femoral nerve, and L1-L3 nerve roots

 

Knee extension ----  Quadriceps -------- Femoral nerve L2, L3, L4

 

Knee flexion------- Hamstrings (semitendinosus, semimembranosus, biceps femoris) ------- Sciatic nerve L5, S1, S2

 

Leg abduction -------- Gluteus medius Gluteus minimus, Tensor fasciae latae ------- Superior gluteal nerve L4, L5, S1

 

Leg adduction--------  Obturator externus, Adductor longus, magnus, and brevis, Gracilis ------- Obturator nerve L2, L3, L4

 

Toe dorsiflexion -------- Extensor hallucis longus, Extensor digitorum longus------- Deep peroneal nerve L5, S1

 

Foot dorsiflexion -------- Tibialis anterior--------- Deep peroneal nerve L4, L5

 

Foot plantar flexion -------- Triceps surae (gastrocnemius, soleus) ----------Tibial nerve S1, S2

 

Foot eversion --------- Peroneus longus Peroneus brevis -------- Superficial peroneal nerve L5, S1

 

Foot inversion -------- Tibialis posterior ---------- Tibial nerve

 

source - http://www.neuroexam.com/neuroexam/content.php?p=29
Tags: Anatomy, Anatomy of the lower limb, Nervous system, Case 1, Lower Limb

Question:
7 year old Jack has been diagnosed with extrinsic asthma triggered by exposure to pollen. Although advised to reduce contact with the stimuli this can be difficult during summer months. The doctor prescribes him with a bronchodilator. 

 

Bronchodilators may be endogenous (naturally occurring in the body) or administered medicines and help to dilate the airways. 

 

The doctor decides to give Jack a beta 2 - agonist. Identify its mode of action.
OptionA: A steroid hormone that initiates a negative feedback mechanism on the immune system
OptionC: Reduce the effects of the vagus nerve
OptionD: Stimulate Gs to increase cAMP and PKA levels to increase heart rate
OptionE: Stimulate the adenylyl cylase pathway to increase cAMP and promote smooth muscle relaxation
Explanation:
A: Glucocoticoids increases the expression of anti- inflammatory proteins while down- regulating the expression of pro-inflammatory cells. They are used to treat disease caused by an overactive immune system (asthma allergies) but is not recommended for mild asthma. 

 

B: Methylxanthines inhibit phosphdiesterase which would normally break down cAMP. The drug therefore increases intracellular levels of cAMP. cAMP decreases the [Ca2+] in the cells and promotes myosin light chain phosphatase activity to cause smooth muscle relaxation 

 

C: Muscarinic Antagonists are derived from atropine (deadly night shade) and are competitive inhibitors of ACh. ACh is released from parasympathetic nerve fibers in the vagus nerve to cause bronchconstriction. By inhibiting this process; antagonsist cause dilation 

 

D: This would be a beta 1- agonist 

 

E: Beta-2 Agonist stimulate beta 2 adrenergic receptors on bronchial smooth muscle to cause relaxation. It activates the adenyly cyclase pathway to increase cAMP levels. cAMP decrease Ca2+ concentrations in the cell and activates myosin light chain phosphatase
Tags: Respiratory, Respiratory physiology, Case 5, Pharmacology, Pulmonary

Question: Bob is walking down the street and suddenly he spots the most attractive woman in the world. His sympathetic nervous system kicks into overdrive and his heart starts beating like crazy. He starts thinking about how his sympathetic nervous system can increase his heart rate, (and realises that thinking about science at moments like this, is probably the reason he is still single in the first place). Which of the below is INCORRECT about the sympathetic stimulation of the heart.
OptionC: It lowers the voltage at which funny channels can be activated.
Explanation:
A. It shows chronotropic changes- increases heart rate

and inotropic changes- increases strength of contraction

B. diastolic interval is decreased as action potentials are increased in frequency

D. Calcium uptake is increased as both T type Ca2+ channels and ryanodine Ca2+ channels (in the sarcoplasmic reticulum) are phosphorylated by PKA
E. There are lots of beta 1 receptors on the heart. They are Gs receptors therefore increase CAMP and then PKA.

C. This is a tricky one (sorry) as it isn't correct. Funny channels (which are Na+ channels) are triggered by hyperpolarisation. So instead of decreasing the threshold at which an action potential can be triggered, the sympathetic system increases the voltage at which the funny channels can open. Therefore they open at a lesser level of hyperpolarisation to increase heart rate.

Question: The brachial plexus is responsible for the muscular innervation of all muscles in the upper limb with the exception of
Explanation:
The trapezius muscle is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI)

 

Deltoid muscle is innervated by the axillary nerve

Levator scapulae is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve

Latissimus dorsi is innervated by the thoracodorsal nerve (middle subscapular nerve)

Pectoralis Minor is innervated by the medial pectoral nerve

Question: Considering the heart and the great vessels, identify the adult structures which, in an embryo, linked the pulmonary and systemic circulation.
Explanation: D is the correct answer as it indicates the adult remnants of the embryonic structures, as per the question. The foramen ovale in the atrial wall is closed after birth by the increase in pulmonary pressure forcing septal layers of the atrial wall together, which eventually fuse, forming the fossa ovalis. The ligamentum arteriosum is formed from the closure and atrophy of the ductus arteriosus between the left pulmonary artery and the descending aorta, shortly after birth.

Question: Dan Wride comes into A&E with the top of his right distal phalynx missing. What is the nerve that supplies the tip of this finger on the palmar aspect?
Explanation: This is Dan's Wride's Story. You need to treat him or he will die! Based on a series of true events!

Question: Which of the following is NOT a superficial muscle of the anterior compartment of the forearm?
Which group of cervical vertebrae listed below are ALL atypical?
Which group of ribs can be described as VERTEBROCHONDRAL?
Explanation: Vertebrochondral ribs or "false" ribs include ribs 8-10. This is because they are not directly attached to the sternum but are so indirectly with their costal cartilages by articulating with the costal cartilage with rib above.

Question: The phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm. However which three cervical nerves does it originate from?
Explanation: Remember the rhyme "C,3,4,5 keeps the diaphragm alive"

Question: A woman arrives at A&E with a deep laceration to the anterior forearm near the medial epicondyle of the humerus. What superficial muscles of the anterior forearm attach to the medial epicondle and in what order (from lateral to medial)?
OptionB:
Pronator Teres

Flexor Carpi Radialis

Palmaris Longus

Flexor Carpi Ulnaris
OptionC:
Pronator Teres

Flexor Carpi Ulnaris

Palmaris Longus

Flexor Carpi Radialis
OptionD:
Pronator Teres

Flexor Digitorum Superficialis

Pronator Quadratus

Flexor Carpi Ulnaris
Explanation: Remember Pass Fail Pass Fail from lateral to medial: Pronator Teres, Flexor Carpi Radialis, Palmaris Longus, Flexor Carpi Ulnaris

Question: During muscle contraction which of the following is true?
Which nerve innervates the 3 muscles of the thenar eminence and the 1st and 2nd lumbricals (most lateral lumbricals)?
Explanation:
The median nerve innervates the 3 muscles of the thenar eminence and the 1st and 2nd lumbricals, whilst the ulnar nerve supplies the 3rd and 4th lumbrical. An easy way of remembering this is MEAT LOAF.

MEAT = median nerve

L = 1st and 2nd lumbricals

O = oppenens pollicis

A = abductor pollicis brevis

F = flexor pollicis brevis

Not only does this allow you to remember the muscles of the thenar eminence but it also allows you to remember the nerves that supply the skin of the hand. The median nerve supplies the thumb, index finger and lateral half of the middle finger whilst the ulnar nerve supplies the medial half of the middle finger, the ring finger and the little finger.

Decent tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q6s1eHmsd5w
Tags: Anatomy, Upper limb, Muscles, Roots and Innervations

Question: Which type of heart block is shown above?
Explanation:
'Heart block' is an ECG phenomenon caused by an interference with the conduction process of the heart. The time taken for the spread of depolarisation from the SAN to the ventricular muscle is shown by the PR interval. If this is prolonged then the result is first degree heart block.

PR interval is typically 0.12-0.2 s long. 

Small Square- 0.04s

Large Square- 0.2s

Question: Which hormone is mainly responsible for emptying the gall bladder?
Explanation: Cholecystokinin is a gut hormone released after a meal, it helps with digestion and reduces appetite.
Tags: Gastrointestinal System, Human physiology, Digestive system

Question: Name the tissue:

Tijane Alan, Andrea Shaw and Ma Yang decide to go for a pint down a rural pub after a long day of work. Upon entering, they discover someone who is suffering from a sudden case of ethylene glycol poisoning. Tijane thinks they should let the patient drink a lot of water to dilute the ethylene glycol concentration, Andrea thinks they should make him drink a lot of ethanol and whereas Ma thinks they should call for an ambulance.


Whose suggestion would potentially bring about the most immediate help to cure the patient from the poisoning?
OptionD: any of their suggestions would be good!
Explanation:
Ethylene glycol poisoning occurs as the compound is acted upon by alcohol dehydrogenase, which gives rise to toxic products. This process can be quickly counteracted by giving the patient an intoxicating dose of ethanol, as the latter is also a substrate for the said enzyme, with a lower Km as well, so it can effectively act as a competitive inhibitor to prevent the enzyme from acting on ethylene glycol. Nowdays, many ethanol therapies are being researched on to bring about non-lethal inhibition of alcohol dehydrogenase to combat ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Diluting the patient's blood with mass water intake could bring about detrimental effects such as upsetting the physiological electrolyte concentrations of our bodies. Calling the ambulance is definitely a good option, but in this context, it may take a lot of time for the ambulance to arrive (as the pub is located in a rural area) and it's best and most effective to treat the patient with ethanol right away.

Question: What is the porta hepatis?
OptionA: The collective name for the hepatic portal vein, hepatic artery and bile duct.
OptionB: A transverse fissure that separates the caudate and quadrate lobes.
OptionC: The collective name for the hepatic portal vein, hepatic artery, hepatic nerve plexus, hepatic ducts and lymphatic vessels.
OptionD: The name for the hepatic biliary system.
Explanation:
According to pg. 167 of Essential Clinical Anatomy (Moore, 4th Ed.), the porta hepatis is the transverse fissure that separates the caudate and quadrate lobes. It gives passage to the hepatic portal vein, hepatic artery, hepatic nerve plexus, hepatic ducts and lymphatic vessels.

 

The portal triad is the collective name for the portal vein, hepatic artery and bile duct.

Question: Which of the following are secreted by the suprarenal cortex of the suprarenal gland?
Explanation: The suprarenal cortex secretes corticosteroids and androgens. The suprerenal medulla secretes epinephrine and norepinephrine

Question: Which enzymes catalyse the three regulatory, irreversible steps in glycolysis?
Explanation: PFK regulates the rate limiting step of the reaction, converting fructose-6-phosphate into fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. Hexokinase (or glucokinase in the liver) catalyses the first regulatory step, producing glucose-6-phosphate from glucose. Both of these steps involve the breakdown of ATP. Pyruvate kinase catalyses the final step in glycolysis, converting PEP (phosphoenol-pyruvate) into pyruvate. This final step produces ATP from ADP.

Question: What down regulates the activity of PFK1?
Explanation: low pH inhibits PFK 1. Lactate build up results in low pH, inhibiting PFK1, and therefore preventing further lactate production and further lowering of the pH. Citrate is produced in the TCA cycle. High levels of citrate indicate a high energy state. ATP binds to an allosteric site on PFK1, reducing its activity.

Question: Which of these is not a remnant of a foetal shunt?
Explanation:
Ligamentum Venosum- remnant of ductus venosus (shunts blood flow from umbilical vein to IVC, thus allowing oxygenated blood from placenta to bypass the liver)

Fossa Ovalis- remnant of foramen ovale (shunts blood from the right atrium to the left atrium, thus bypassing the lungs)

Ligamentum Arteriosum- remnant of the ductus arteriosus (shunts blood to/from the pulmonary trunk to arch of the aorta, thus bypassing the lungs)

The hepatorenal ligament is the pouch of peritoneum that extends from the lower posterior surface of the liver to the anterior surface of the right kidney and forms the right margin of the epiploic foramen.
Tags: Anatomy, Heart, Cardiovascular Physiology, Embryology, Liver

Question: The innermost layer of the gut (the mucosa) is divided up into which of the following?
Explanation: Serosa (most external) ---> Muscularis Externa containing longitudinal and circular smooth muscle--->  Submucosa containing glands, connective tissue, collagen/elastin fibres---> Mucosa (most internal) containing epithelia and their basement membrane  (the lamina propria), muscularis mucosa.

Question: What is the reverse complement of DNA sequence 5’-ATTGGCTCT-3’?
Explanation:
The sequence that would base pair with stem sequence 5’-ATTGGCTCT-3’ is 3’-TAACCGAGA-5’ so the answer is: 5’-AGACCAAT-3’

Answers A and B are built upon a misconception – A:G pairs and C:T pairs (sequence is ‘reverse complement’/’reverse’)

Answer C is the reverse of stem sequence – not complementary

Answer E has each base is complement of base in stem sequence BUT would not base pair with it as direction is 5’-3’ (not 3’-5’)

 

(taken from University of Glasgow student learning service)

Question: Identify the tissue below:
Explanation: This is from the oesophagus. Notice the stratified squamous non keratinised epithelia which offers protection against the abrasive action of food.

Question: Which of the following statements is false?
Explanation:
@ low [glucose]blood glucagon is released to increase [glucose]blood through various mechanisms:

One mechanism it uses is inhibition of glycolysis - ensuring less glucose is broken down, to maintain [glucose]blood

Another mechanism it uses is promotion of gluconeogenesis - making new glucose from glycerol, amino acids and pyruvate, to raise [glucose]blood

A further mechanism it uses is promotion of glycogenolysis - breaking down glycogen to form more glucose, to elevate [glucose]blood

 

@ high [glucose]blood, insulin is released to decrease [glucose]blood through various mechanisms:

One mechanism it uses is inhibition of lipolysis - decreasing the availability of free fatty acids and glycerol, which could otherwise be used in gluconeogenesis and ketogenesis (discussed below) as an alternative source of energy, thereby promoting the use of glucose as the primary energy source, decreasing [glucose]blood

Another mechanism it uses is inhibition of ketogenesis - reducing the availability of ketone bodies as an alternative source of energy, thereby promoting the use of glucose as the primary energy source, decreasing [glucose]blood

Question: Which hormone produced by the adrenal cortex is responsible for regulating electrolyte balance?
Explanation:
Anti-diuretic hormone does regulate electrolyte balance as it regulates blood osmolality. However, it is synthesised in the hypothalamus NOT the adrenal cortex.

Adrenaline and Cortisol are both synthesised in the the adrenal cortex and are the short-term stress and long-term stress hormones. Although synthesised in the adrenal cortex they regulate the basal metabolic rate NOT electrolyte balance.

Insulin is synthesised by the beta cells of the pancreas in the Islets of Langerhans and regulates blood glucose concentration.

Aldosterone is synthesised in the adrenal cortex and is involved in the reabsorption of Na+ from the kidneys into the bloodstream so fits both criteria for the question and is correct.

Question: Vitamin D can be classified as a hormone which similarly to parathyroid hormone regulates calcium concentration. However what hormonal class does vitamin D  belong to?
what are the two ducts that form the bile duct ?
OptionE: common hepatic duct and right hepatic duct
Explanation: The right and left hepatic duct unites to form the common hepatic duct. The cystic duct drains the gall bladder and it merges with the common hepatic duct to form the bile duct.

Question: Where would you auscultate to hear the mitral valve of the heart?
Explanation:
The mitral (bicuspid) valve is the atrio-ventricular valve between the left atrium and the left ventricle.

Therefore, since the heart is orientated anteriorly, inferiorly and to the left and the mitral valve lies between the left atrium and left ventricle, answers B and E are incorrect as they are on the right.

Answer A is the surface landmark for auscultation of the Pulmonary valve.

Answer C is a trick and is one intercostal space superior to the area for auscultation.

Answer D is therefore correct.

 

NOTE: The surface markings and points of auscultation in the heart are different.

Question: Which of the following statements about the white blood cell shown above is correct.
OptionB: It is responsible for the clearance of cellular debris
OptionE: It is responsible for protecting the body from multicellular parasites
Explanation:
The image shows an Eosinophil.
A is incorrect as Eosinophils are found primarily in the tissues. 

B is incorrect, this is one of the functions of macrophages.

C is incorrect, Eosinophils are granulocytes

D is obviously incorrect.

E is correct and is one the major functions of Eosinophils

The trick to identifying Eosinophils in images like this is to look at the bi-lobed nucleus and the granules which are more distinct than in neutrophils.
Tags: Blood, Immunology, Innate Immune System, Innate immunity

Question: Which type of epithelium characteristically lines the walls of the urinary tract?
Explanation:
Transitional epithelium a.k.a urothelium is a stratified epithelium lining the distensible walls of the urinary tract. 'Transitional' derives from the tissues ability to change its shape from cuboidal to squamous when stretched.

Stratified Squamous- protective function. The innermost layers constantly produce new cells and outermost layers may be keratinized. Found in skin and oesophagus.

Simple Columnar- involved in active secretion/absorption (may have cilia). Found in digestive tract and female reproductive tract.

Cuboidal- active 'pumps' e.g glandular ducts in kidneys

Simple Squamous- located at sites of rapid diffusion e.g lung alveoli

Question: Mr. Mann comes in to see you at your GP practice. He presents with numbness in the thenar eminence of his palm in addition to pain and tingling in his thumb and lateral two and a half fingers. You diagnose him with:
Explanation: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is caused by compression to the median nerve which runs in the carpal tunnel. The median nerve innervates the thenar region of the palm and the lateral three and a half digits (thumb, index finger, middle finger and lateral half of ring finger).

Question: Which two hormones are both secreted by the adrenal cortex?
Explanation:
The adrenal gland is a small, triangular gland which sits on top of the kidneys. It consists of an outer adrenal cortex and an inner adrenal medulla.

 

The adrenal cortex secretes: Cortisol, Aldosterone and Androgens.

The adrenal medulla secretes: Adrenaline and Noradrenaline.

 

Therefore answer B is correct.

Question: In the 'fight or flight' response, adrenaline released from the adrenal glands binds to membrane receptors on muscle cells. Which of the following events result from this ligand binding?
OptionA: G protein is binding ATP and causing adenylyl cyclase to produce the second messenger cAMP.
OptionB: An increase in cAMP, activates protein kinase A which causes a conformation change inhibits glycogen synthetase blocking glycogen synthesis.
OptionC: Protein kinase A activates phosphorylase kinase, which transfers a phosphate (Pi) that activates glycogen phosphorylase, leading to the breakdown of glycogen and the production of glucose-1-phosphate.
OptionD: Glucose produces from glucose-1-phosphate enters glycolysis, allowing production of energy for muscle contraction and a rapid response.
Explanation: This would be an example of a signal transduction cascade, resulting in a rapid response from the body. Here adrenaline (epinephrine) is released from the adrenal cortex in response to external stimuli. Here adrenaline is an example of endocrine signalling. Once the adrenaline reaches the target cells, which in this case is the muscle, it attaches to the adrenorecptor on the cell membrane, activating the G protein coupled receptor. G protein receptor will then activate adenylyl cyclase enzyme, which will bind with ATP to prodeuce cAMP + PPi (aka Pyrophosphate) The G protein acts as an intermediate between the receptor and the synthesis of cAMP. This increase in production of cAMP activates protein Kinase A. Protein kinase A then goes on to develop the cascade by activating or inactivatting certain enzymes, which causes the production of the product. In this particular case Protein kinase A inhibits glycogen synthetase but activates phosphorylase, by causing a confirmational change of the active site. This allows glycogen to be broken down into glucose (glycogenolysis) which can then be used as a source of energy in glycolysis.

Question:
A 26-year-old man reports numbness and tingling in his hands for the last 3 weeks. The numbness began during a 4 week cycling trip, he returned 1 week ago. On examination there is reduced or altered sensation in his little fingers, medial side of his ring fingers and the medial volar surface of both hands.

 

Which nerve is affected?
Explanation:
This man has a bilateral compressive neuropathy of his ulnar nerves. Likely to be caused in this case by compression of the ulnar nerve by the handle bars at the anatomic location of Guyon's canal at the base of the hand. Compression of the ulnar nerve can occur anywhere along it's course (from the shoulder to the hand) resulting in neuropathy, the most common location of compression is at the elbow.

 

Changing how he grips his handle bars (taking the weight off of his medial palm) should allow his symptoms to gradually resolve.

Question: The occulomotor nerve (CNIII) innervates several extrinsic eye muscles responsible for rotating the eyeball. Which of the following are ALL innervated by the occulomotor nerve ?
OptionA: Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus, Lateral Rectus and Inferior Oblique.
OptionB: Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus, Superior Oblique and Inferior Oblique.
OptionC: Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus, Medial Rectus and Inferior Oblique.
OptionD: Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus, Medial Rectus and Lateral Rectus.
Explanation:
Occulomotor Nerve (CNIII) - Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus, Medial Rectus and Inferior Oblique.

Trochlear Nerve (CNIV) - Superior Oblique

Abducens Nerve (CNVI) - Lateral Rectus

Question:
What is the name of the condition which produces the following losses to the visual field?

?
Explanation: Homonymous Hemianopia is caused by a lesion in the optic tract which causes the above loss to the field of vision.

Question: In series 3 of scrubs, Turk is gutted when he makes a mistake in surgery and leaves the medial part of the hand (both anterior and posterior) of Josh, a concert pianist paralysed. Which nerve is Turk likely to have cut by mistake?
Explanation: Ulnar in general supplies the medial part of the hand. The radial nerve supplies the lateral part of the dorsum of the hand though median nerve supplies the upper parts of the thumb, index finger, middle finger and half of the fourth finger. On the anterior of the hand, the median and ulnar nerve dominate. The ulnar nerve supplies the medial part from the pinky up to the middle of the fourth finger and the median nerve supplies all of the rest of the anterior of the hand apart from a small part of the base of the thumb which is supplied by the radial nerve.

Question:
A 72-year-old woman presents with drooping of her right eyelid and double vision. She has had type II diabetes for 30 years, peripheral neuropathy and a 50 pack year smoking history. On examination, she has right-sided ptosis, the pupil is responsive to light and the eye is deviated inferolaterally. Her left eye is normal.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This patient has a III nerve (occulomotor nerve) palsy. Patients who are diabetic and over 50 years old classically present with a pupillary reflex sparing occulomotor nerve palsy. Pupillary function fibres are thought to be arranged superficially on the nerve and diabetic ischaemic neuropathy affects deeper nerve fibres, so sparing pupillary function. III nerve palsy with mydriasis and loss of pupillary function is usually aneurysmal in aetiology.

 

Classical Horner’s syndrome can be remembered by the rhyming triad: ptosis, miosis and anhydrosis.

 

Cranial nerve IV (trochlear nerve) palsy causes weakness of downward eye movement and resulting vertical diplopia.

 

Cranial nerve VI (abducent nerve) palsy results in the eye deviating medially and resulting horizontal diplopia.

 

Link: http://legacy.revoptom.com/handbook/sect6c.htm

Question: What triggers the extrinsic pathway in haemostasis?
Explanation:
The extrinsic pathway results in fibrin clot formation in haemostasis. This is triggered by major vascular damage to deep blood vessels and tissues which release tissue factor triggering the extrinsic pathway.

 

A and B) Collagen exposure triggers the intrinsic pathway and the subsequent release of Von Willibrand factor from adjacent endothelial cells.

C) Correct

D) The intrinsic and extrinsic pathways both meet at factor 10a to form the common pathway.

E) Calcium release can help to localise factors to the site of injury.

Question: The levator ani muscle is innervated by...
Explanation: "S2, 3, 4 keep shit off the floor!" - from YouTube link on Learning Central on The Pelvic Diaphragm: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P3BBAMWm2Eo

Question: What effect does cortisol have on muscles?
Explanation:
Cortisol = stress hormone. 

When remembering what cortisol does think injured animals:

1) muscle catabolism- frees up amino acids to be used in repair (and gluconeogenesis). 

2) It increases blood glucose and gluconeogenesis. An injured animal probably won't be able to eat so needs to maintain its blood glucose through other methods.

3) It stimulates lipolysis and inhibits lipogenesis. Free fatty acids can be used for fuel to conserve glucose. 

 

NB cortisol is also needed for day to day functioning of the body. It is needed for example forheart contractility, maintaining GFR in the kidneys and adrenaline function.

In high doses cortisol is an anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressant.

Question: A woman is told that it is almost certain that any living children she has will be born with Down's Syndrome. Which of the following inherited chromosomal abnormalities could account for this?
Explanation: The long arms of the woman's two 21 chromosomes will be fused. When her chromosomes divide during meiosis the egg cell will either receive both of the chromosomes or neither because they are fused together. Assuming the sperm has no chromosomal abnormalities and so contributes on copy of chromosome 21 the zygote will have either three copies of chromosome 21 and therefore have Down's syndrome or it will have one copy and it will  not survive. (Having a monosomy of one of the autosome is fatal). I put almost certain because although it is very unlikely, if the sperm didn't have a chromosome 21 but was without any other chromosomal abnormalities then the child could be born without Down's syndrome.

Question: What muscle(s) of the orbit does CN VI innervate.
Explanation:
A- Superior Oblique is innervated by CN IV. The Trochlear or Pulley Nerve

B &C - Inferior Oblique is innervated along with Superior Rectus, Medial Rectus and Inferior Rectus by CN III. The Occulomotor

D - Levator Palpebrae Superioris is also supplied by CN III/ Occulomotor by it's sympathetic fibres.

E - The Lateral Rectus muscle is the only muscle of the orbit to be supplied by CN VI or the Abducens Nerve. So named because it abducts the lens of the eye.

Question: The dorsal interossei are responsible for the abduction of which fingers?
Explanation: The dorsal interossei abduct fingers 2-4. Abduction is separation of the fingers. The little finger, the 5th finger, is abducted by abductor digiti minimi which is one of the muscles of the hypothenar eminence.
Tags: Anatomy, Hand, Upper limb, upper limb muscles

Question: A doctor examines a patient's hand and diagnoses median nerve damage. Which of the following would allow the doctor to make this assumption?
OptionA: The patient has a claw hand affect fingers 4 and 5.
OptionC: The patient cannot touch the tip of their thumb and the tip of their little finger together.
OptionD: The patient struggles to adduct the hand at the wrist.
OptionE: The patient has lost sensation to the medial edge of the hand.
Explanation:
A, D and E are all signs of ulnar nerve damage. 

B is a sign of radial nerve damage.

The thenar eminence is supplied by the median nerve and therefore supplies opponens pollicis. Opposition of the hand relies on this muscle which is supplied by the median nerve.
Tags: Anatomy, Upper Limb Innervations, Hand, Upper limb

Question: Abdominal CT : Which number corresponds to the left kidney?
Explanation: 6, Left adrenal. 7, Left kidney. 8, Spleen. 9, Pancreas. 3, Right Adrenal

Question: CT of the thorax: Which number corresponds to the superior vena cava?
Explanation:
1 = root of aorta
2 = pulmonary outflow
3 = left atrium
4 = left pulmonary vein
5 = superior vena cava
6 = descending aorta

Question: A patient presents to their GP with a swelling on their neck. They say that they have been gaining weight, have fatigue and they always feel cold. Which of the following hormones could have directly caused the swelling on their neck?
Explanation: Thyroid stimulating hormone stimulates growth of the thyroid gland. Thyroid releasing hormone is released by the hypothalamus so enters portal circulation and not general circulation. It stimulates TSH hormone release. TSH stimulates the release of T4 into the bloodstream. T4 is converted into T3. The symptoms described are those of iodine deficiency or hypothyroidism. In iodine deficiency there is not enough iodine to produce enough T4 and so the body produces more TRH and TSH to try and stimulate the release of more. This results in growth of the thyroid. In hypothyroidism the thyroid also doesn't produce enough T4 but it is generally due to the immune system attacking the thyroid or damage to the thyroid.

Question:
18:2(n-6)

 

The above represents a fatty acid. According to this, how many carbon-carbon double bonds are present in the fatty acid?
Explanation:
18:2(n-6)

 

18 = number of carbons

2= number of double bonds

n-6 = the first double bond appears 6 carbons from the terminal methyl group (omega methyl group). Hence it is an omega 6.

Question: The macula densa directly affects what?
Explanation:
GFR= Kf x net filtration pressure. 

Net filtration pressure = glomerular hydrostatic pressure - bowman's capsule pressure - glomerular oncotic pressure. 

 

Bowman's capsule pressure and Kf are only altered by disease. The body cannot control them.

 

The macula densa detects sodium levels in the distal tubule. When these are low it cause the afferent arterioles to dilate, decreasing resistance. It will also stimulate the release of renin. Renin catalyses the conversion of angiotensin to angiotensin I. Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II by ACE. Angiotensin II causes efferent arterioles to contract, increasing resistance. The macula densa are indirectly causing efferent arteriole contraction.

Question: This image shows a person with excessive curvature of the spine. What is the name given to this type of abnormal curvature?
Explanation:
Lordosis is the opposite, where the spine curves inwards too far as opposed to protruding outwards. 

Scoliosis is an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine.

Question: This vertebra is from which region of the spinal cord?
Explanation:
Cervical vertebrae are characterised by a foramen in their transverse process.

They also have very large vertebral foramen. Some of the vertebrae have a split spinous process.

Question: Which of the following signs would be characteristic of someone with a suspected upper motor lesion?
Explanation:
C is correct. All of the other options are characteristic of a lower motor neurone lesion.

In normal individuals the Babinski sign is negative. Therefore when the sole of the foot is stimulated with a blunt instrument, the big toe flexes (downwards) and the other toes also flex and fan inward. In individuals with an upper motor neurone lesion there is a positive Babinski sign - the big toe extends (upwards) (dorsiflexon) and the other toes fan outward.

Question: Which of the following facts about the oculomotor nerve is INCORRECT?
OptionC: The nerve provides somatic motor innervation to sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscles which causes constriction of the pupil and accommodates the lens of the eye
OptionD: The nerve provides somatic motor innervation to the superior rectus, medial rectus, inferior rectus, inferior oblique and levator palpebrae superioris muscles of the eye.
OptionE: The nerve exits the cranium via the superior orbital fissure.
Explanation:
C is the one that is incorrect. The nerve actually supplies VISCERAL motor innervation to the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscles rather than somatic motor innervation. 

 

Acronym to remember which cranial nerves contain motor, sensory or both types of fibres. 

Some Say Marry Money But My Brother Says Big Boobs Matter More.

Words beginning with S=sensory, M=motor and B= both.

So as oculomotor is the third cranial nerve, you count along to the third word which is Marry therefore fibres present in the oculomotor nerve are motor.

Question:
Mr John Chattopadhyay has type 1 diabetes. He is on holiday abroad and has forgotten his insulin pen. 

He sees a range of unfamiliar foods with the following Glycaemic Indices, which option is best for John?

 

(Assume each product has the same serving size).
Explanation:
Glycaemic Index provides information on how food affects blood glucose levels depending on the type of carbohydrate present.

 

A low glycaemic index indicates the carbohydrate will be absorbed slowly and therefore affect blood sugar levels less

Question: A patient presents to his GP with ptosis, a fully dilated pupil and unreactive pupil and his pupil fully abducted and depressed as shown in the diagram. His GP suspects damage to one of the patient's cranial nerves. Which cranial nerve would the GP suspect had been damaged?
Explanation:
Oculomotor nerve palsy.

Ptosis occurs as levator palpebrae superioris is supplied by oculomotor nerve. The eye looks down and out due to the unopposed activity of superior oblique and lateral rectus as these are the only two muscles of the eye that are not supplied by oculomotor. The pupil is also fully dilated and unreactive as the parasympathetic nerve fibres that supply sphincter pupillae travel in the oculomotor nerve.

Question:
An 18-year-old medical student decides he is going to get buff, so starts consuming protein shakes. Whilst drinking a shake after a massive session of squats in the gym, he contemplates the process of digestion. He recalls that one of the enzymes involved in protein digestion (a proteolytic enzyme) in the stomach is pepsin and it's inactive precursor (zymogen) is pepsinogen. But he can't remember which cells in the stomach secrete pepsinogen. He asks a fellow medical student who knows everything as she uses PeerWise everyday.

 

Which cells does she tell him are responsible?
Explanation:
Chief cells (found in the body of the stomach) are responsible for secretion of pepsinogen, which is converted into the active proteolytic enzyme pepsin.

 

Consumption of protein stimulates the production of gastrin, secreted by G cells. Gastrin then stimulates the secretion of both intrinsic factor and hydrochloric acid from parietal cells. The hydrochloric acid catalyses the conversion of pesinogen to pepsin. The acidic environment created and pepsin are both important for the hydrolysis of proteins. Intrinsic factor is responsible for assisting absorption of vitamin B12 found in proteinaceous foods such as meat, fish and eggs. D cells (found in the antrum of the stomach) are stimulated by Gastrin and secrete somatostatin, a hormone which inhibits Gastrin excretion from G cells and hydrochloric acid from parietal cells (a negative feedback mechanism presenting the stomach becoming too acidic).

 

Leydig cells are testosterone producing cells found in the testicles. They are important for getting buff but have little direct influence on digestion.

 

Random mnemonic: I remember that chief cells secrete pepsinogen and are found in the body of the stomach by picturing the image of a native American chief drinking pepsi, which goes into his body.  

 

Pepsi is the ancient Greek word for digestion.

 

Apparently the drink "Pepsi" is so named as it was initially marketed as a digestive aid (although the sources for this are dubious), other dubious sources claim that Pepsi is called Pepsi because Pepsin is involved or was involved in it's production (again, this is from dodgy internet sources, not necessarily true). The rest of the information in this question is true though! Sources include: " Marieb, Human anatomy and Physiology, 6th edition" and "Faller, The human body: an introduction to structure and function, 13th edition".

Question: Which of the following nerves would pass through the foramen labelled 21 on this diagram?
Explanation: 21 = jugular foramen. CN IX, CN X and CN XI all pass through this. The internal jugular vein begins in this foramen from the joining of the sigmoid sinus and the inferior petrosal sinus.

Question: Which of the following corresponds to the optic canal?
Explanation:
25 = superior orbital fissure. 

12 = foramen rotundum.

13 = foramen ovale

24 = foramen lacerum

Question: When pancreas cells are stained some appear paler and some appear darker. What type of cells are the paler ones?
Explanation:
The lighter/paler ones are endocrine.

The darker ones are exocrine. 

 

I personally remember it as the light at the end of the tunnel.

Question: Which of the following is not present in the spermatic cord?
A patient falls back and hits their head at the occipital protuberance. Their brain is thought to be damaged from the impact. Which of the following is most likely to be affected?
Explanation:
The visual cortex is right at the back of the brain, in the occipital lobe.

Voluntary movement = motor cortex = back of frontal lobe. 

Olfactory Cortex = temporal lobe

Auditory Cortex = temporal lobe

Speech = Broca's area = frontal lobe

Question: Waiter's tip is caused by damage to what?
Explanation:
a) This is incorrect as damage to the radial nerve causes wrist drop 

b) This is correct YAY! Injury to superior part of brachial plexus is caused by an excessive increase in angle between shoulder and neck and leads to WAITER'S TIP- Gold star for you kids who got it right!

c) Injury to the inferior part of the brachial plexus causes claw hand rawrrrrrrrr

d) Injury to the axillary nerve causes atrophy of the deltoid sad face :( 

e) Injury to the median nerve causes inability to oppose thumb and wasting of the thenar eminence

Question:
A 19-year-old medical student presents with pain and swelling at the base of his right thumb. He reports an amorous encounter on a MedSoc social with a fellow medical student, with whom he returned to his halls of residence. Due to the narrow beds, alcohol excess and obscure mid-coital positioning he fell onto his extended wrist, which resulted in severe pain.  

There is exquisite tenderness on palpation of the anatomical snuff box of his right wrist. He is told by the doctor that his wrist x-ray shows a fracture of a carpal bone.

 

Which bone is most likely to be fractured?
Explanation:
The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone. The usual mechanism of injury is a fall onto an extended wrist, typical history and examination findings include: pain and swelling at the base of the thumb and tenderness on palpation of the anatomical snuff box*.

 

The history of presenting complaint in this question is reminiscent of a mnemonic for remembering the carpal bones: Some Lovers Try Positions That They Can't Handle  = Scaphoid Lunate Triquetrum Pisiform Trapezium Trapezoid Capitate Hamate. 

 

*the anatomical snuff box is the depression between the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons at the base of the thumb. This recess is so named for it's use of holding snuff (ground tobacco) prior to nasal insufflation. 

 

Jason

Question:
You are presented with a patient that has suffered from a direct blow to the middle part of the lateral side of his left leg. His X-rays show a midshaft fibula fracture of the left leg. He's unable to evert his lef foot and also complains about loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot with the exception of the area between the great/first toe and second toe (first web space/ interdigital cleft) and the lateral side of the fifth digit. 

What nerve has been injured?
Explanation:
The answer is Superficial Fibular nerve. Here's why:

 

 

The 1st hint was the inability to evert the foot. The muscles responsible for foot eversion are: Fibularis longus and Fibularis brevis. These two muscles are supplied by the superficial fibular nerve. At this point you might be thinking "Hold on! What about Fibularis tertius?!" Well fibularis tertius only aids in the everting of the foot. It's primary function is ankle dorsiflexion (it's supplied by deep fibular nerve).

 

The 2nd hint is the loss of sensation. So it says he lost sensation over the dorsum of his left foot with the exception of the lateral side of the fifth digit and the first interdigital cleft. The first interdigital cleft is supplied by the deep fibular nerve and the lateral side of the fifth digit is supplied by the sural nerve. The rest (i.e. majority of dosrum surface) is supplied by the superficial fibular nerve, so here again you should be thinking "something's wrong with the superficial nerve."  (this link shows you the foot dermatomes, in case you're a bit lost: http://www.frca.co.uk/images/lowerlimb-fig8-small.jpg)

 

Now you can look back at the fact that his fracture is located at the midshaft of his fibula; what runs close along it there? The superficial fibular nerve!

 

Here's another link that talks a bit about superficial fibular nerve and potential damage: http://teachmeanatomy.info/lower-limb/nerves/superficial-fibular-nerve/

 

Another way of working this out is by ruling out answers:

1) The medial plantar, is a the larger branch of the tibial nerve, while the later plantar is the smaller branch. they both supply the skin of the plantar surface of the foot. Just look at their name: medial plantar, lateral plantar. The patient however suffers from loss of sensation on the dorsal surface!

2) As for the Saphenous nerve, it supplies the skin on the medial side of the foot as far as the head of the first metatarsal. It has no contribution to foot eversion. So it can't be this nerve.

3) Deep Fibular nerve doesn't contribute to foot eversion, but dorsiflexion and extension of the toes. It also supplies the skin at the first interdigital cleft, an area that the patient hasn't lost sensation in. So again it can't be this nerve.

 This leaves us with superficial fibular nerve as the only answer :)

 

*Additional info:

Something you might find interesting is that the deep fibular nerve injury causes a foot drop!
Tags: Foot, Anatomy, Innervation, Innervations, Lower Limb

Question: Which two complement proteins are largely responsible for mast cell degranulation in the process of acute inflammation?
Explanation: When complement C3b binds to a microbial surface, it can join  with other complement (i.e factor Bb  in the alternative pathway) to form  a C3 convertase, converting more C3 into C3a and C3b. When the C3b binds another complement, C5 then the C3 convertase is able to cleave C5 into C5a and C5b. The C3a and C5a then go on to cause Mast Cell degranulation.

Question: The function of the anterior cruciate ligament is ?
OptionA: To prevent external rotation of the leg.
OptionB: To prevent internal rotation of the leg.
Explanation: The anterior cruciate ligament attaches the anterior part of the tibial plateau to the femur. It therefore prevents anterior tibial translation. If the anterior cruciate ligament is damaged a positive anterior drawer test is seen. This is where the tibia is pulled forward anteriorly with the knee fully flexed. In a positive test a greater range of movement in this plane is observed.

Question: Why is prothrombin a better measure of liver failure than albumin?
OptionA: Because prothrombin has a higher molecular weight (in daltons).
OptionB: Because prothrombin has a shorter half life.
OptionC: Because the liver synthesises more prothrombin than albumin.
OptionD: Because the albumin is "busy" trying to transport the unconjugated bilirubin into the liver.
OptionE: Because the albumin can be redistributed into the extracellular space during infection.
Explanation: The answer is B. The half life of albumin is 20-25 days compared to Prothrombin which is around 60 hours. This means that with an acute liver problem the albumin concentration is still normal as the half life is so long. However, with an acute liver disease the prothrombin levels with be noticeably lower sooner as the liver can't produce the clotting factor and the molecules that were already in the system start to reach their half life sooner.

Question: What represents atrial repolarisation in a normal ECG (recorded with the limb leads)?
OptionD: It isn't - it's actually masked by the QRS complex
Explanation:
The P wave reflects the atrial depolarisation, QRS complex corresponds to ventricular depolarisation and the T wave is the ventricular repolarisation.

Atrial repolarisation occurs during the ventricular depolarisation, and is therefore masked by the QRS complex.

      Human Physiology, Pocock and Richards, 4th Ed., pp. 394
Tags: The ECG, Cardiology, Cardiovascular Physiology, Heart, Human physiology

Question: Asking a patient to shrug their shoulders against resistance as part of a cranial nerve examination is testing which cranial nerve?
Explanation: Asking the patient to shrug against resistance is testing the trapezius muscle which is innervated by the accessory nerve. Another test would be to ask the patient to turn their head against resistance as this tests the Sternocleidomastoid muscle which is again innervated by the accessory nerve.

Question: Timothy is 16 years old, he visits his GP to discuss treatment for his acne vulgaris. Which structure, labelled 'A' in the diagram, is responsible for Timothy's condition?
Explanation:
"Sebaceous glands are compound alveolar glands based on their histology. Sebaceous glands are holocrine glands based on what they secrete, because they secrete entire cells! Once a cell is secreted, it finds itself in a pore, no longer surrounded by its normal environment. The new environment is disturbing to the cell, so it lyses and its contents leak out. This leaked out mixture of cell contents, cell membranes, and disruptive environment fluids (a fatty mixture) is then called sebum, and it is what gets to the surface of the skin.

Sebaceous glands secrete their sebum into hair follicles. The sebum then escapes to the surface of the skin through the same route that the hair uses-- out the follicle. This oily fluid on our skin helps to further protect our skin, coating it with a hydrophobic armor to keep out water and maintain our internal fluids.

Pimples and acne are troubles of the sebaceous glands. These occur when the sebaceous glands get clogged, by either sebum or cells, as too much secretion occurs."

 

http://faculty.stcc.edu/AandP/AP/AP1pages/Units1to4/skin/skin2.htm

Question:
A patient with a pituitary adenoma has bitemporal hemianopia.

 

 

Which structure is the tumour likely to be compressing to cause this?

One of the adductor group of muscles in the leg is relatively weak and can be removed without noticeable loss of its function in the leg. For this reason this muscle, or part of it, can be removed and used to replace a damaged forearm muscle or a non functioning external anal sphincter among other things. This muscle is supplied by the obturator nerve and is the only adductor in the medial compartment that assists in medial rotation. It is the only adductor that does not attach to the femur. What muscle is this?
Explanation:
Sartorius is not an adductor. It is an anterior compartment muscles that assists in abduction. 

Obturator Externus is not an adductor although it is in the medial compartment. 

Adductor Brevis and adductor longus are both adductors but neither is involved in medial rotation and both attach to the femur.

Question:
Trevor is diagnosed with Marfan syndrome. The doctor explains that Marfan syndrome is caused by a defective gene encoding the protein fibrillin. Fibrillin co-polymerises with elastin to form elastic fibres in connective tissue. 

 

Which structure is most likely to cause Trevor problems?
Explanation: The walls of major blood vessels contain elastic connective tissue to help recoil. Patients with Marfan syndrome are unable to form normal elastic fibres causing weakening of aortic walls; this can lead to conditions such as aortic dissection, aortic regurgitation and aortic aneurysm.

Question:
Calcium is removed from heart muscle cells against its concentration gradient using the Na+/Ca2+ antiport exchanger; this is an example of secondary active transport powered by Na+ (i.e. sodium moves into the cell, down its concentration gradient. This powers the movement of calcium out of the cell, against its concentration gradient).

 

Polly is prescribed digoxin. Digoxin is steroid molecule which inhibits the Na+/K+-ATPase antiport exchanger. 

 

What is the most likely effect of digoxin on Polly's heart?
Explanation:
Digoxin is used to treat atrial fibrillation 

 

If the Na+/K+-ATPase pump is inhibited then Na+ can't be pumped out of the cell.

 

This leads to an intracellular build up of sodium.

 

This means the concentration gradient of sodium used to pump calcium out of the heart cell is dissipated. 

 

Since calcium cannot be removed from the cell by secondary active transport, it builds up inside the cell. This means more calcium binds to troponin and facilitates cardiac muscle contraction.

Question: Samantha is a first year medical student on placement at a local eye clinic. At the start of the day she notices David in the waiting room who is shown below. From initial inspection, Samantha suspects that David has...
Explanation:
From the picture we can see that David has:

 

- a dilated pupil in his right eye.

- ptosis of his right eyelid.

- a depressed, abducted, laterally rotated right pupil.

 

This combination of signs suggests that he has occulomotor nerve palsy (CN III palsy) for the following reasons:

 

First, the occulomotor nerve has sympathetic fibres which innervate the levator palpebrae superiosis muscle responsible for raising the eyelid. If thiere is a lesion to this nerve, ptosis will occur due to unopposed action of the orbicularis occuli muscle innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII). 

 

The occulomotor nerve also supplies parasympathetic fibres to the pupillary sphincter muscle which constricts the pupil. If there is a lesion to CN III, the unopposed action of sympathetic fibres to the pupillary dilator muscle will cause the pupil to dilate.

 

Thirdly, the occulomotor nerve innervates superior rectus, medial rectus, inferior rectus and inferior oblique. If there is a lesion to this nerve then there will be unopposed action to superior oblique (innervated by CN IV) and lateral rectus (innervated by CN VI). As a result the pupil will be abducted, depressed and laterally rotated.

 

*Note: although answer E is also correct, since this is the single best answer, answer B is better since it explains all of the signs.

Question: Niall wakes up after a big night at the LASH and feels very dehydrated. The secretion of which hormone will most likely be increased as a result of Niall's dehydration?
Explanation:
• ADH is the right answer- it is secreted by the posterior pituitary gland in response to increased plasma osmolality- i.e plasma being more concentrated
  • ADH is responsible for increasing the permeability of the last third of the distal tubule and the whole of the collecting duct to water, therefore more water is reabsorbed
  • Aldosterone secretion is regulated by the macula densa; aldosterone increases reabsorption of sodium 
  • ANP is secreted by atrial myocytes and is responsible for increasing sodium excretion and causing dilatation of the renal afferent and efferent arterioles, thus augmenting renal blood flow and GFR. ANP inhibits the formation of aldosterone and secretion of ADH

Question: Mr Smith has come in to his GP surgery for an annual check up. After taking a thorough history and completing a chest examination it is thought that he is suffering from mitral valve stenosis. Where would this be best heard upon auscultation?
Explanation:
The auscultatory areas are:

 

Aortic Valve = Parasternal Right 2nd intercostal space.

Pulmonary Valve = Parasternal Left 2nd intercostal space.

Tricuspid Valve = Parasternal Left 4th Intercostal space

Mitral Valve = Midclavicular Line Left 5th intercostal space

Question: Which nerve of the brachial plexus illustrated below, is most likely to be damaged by a fracture to the neck of the humerus?
Explanation: The answer is 12, the Axillary nerve which is most likely damaged in a fracture of this kind.

Question:
A surgeon is performing a cholecystectomy and accidentally tears the cystic artery, which causes uncontrolled bleeding. To reduce the bleeding she places her index finger inside the omental bursa (through the omental foramen) and her thumb on it's anterior surface and compresses the vessels in between. 

 

Which vessel is the surgeon most likely compressing to control the bleeding?
Explanation: This is known as the Pringle manoeuvre, named after James Pringle. The cystic artery is a branch of the right hepatic artery which is a branch of the (common) hepatic artery. Therefore by compressing the hepatic artery in anterior aspect of the omental foramen (AKA foramen of Winslow) the surgeon is able to stop blood flow to the cystic artery.

Question: A patient has pain in the epigastric region. The patient tells you that it is a chronic condition. He has lost his appetite and lost weight. He drank alcohol last night which exacerbated the pain. He was recently diagnosed with diabetes and has come in today looking slightly jaundiced. What is the mostly likely diagnosis?
Explanation: Chronic pancreatitis is normally alcohol related (60-80%). It can causes episodic or unremitting pain. The pain can be exacerbated by alcohol. When abdo pain is present anorexia and weight loss are common. Due to exocrine/ endocrine insufficiency malabsorption and diabetes may be present. The fibrosed head of the pancreas can also obstruct the common bile duct and result in jaundice.

Question: Which number on this pressure-volume loop represents the closure of the aortic valve?
Explanation:
1 = mitral valve closure.

2 = aortic valve opens. 

3 = aortic valve closes.

4 = mitral valve opens.
