Question: What is the most important contribution of plasmacytoid dendritic cells in response to viral infection?
OptionA: Acting as "sentinel" within peripheral tissues and activation of T cells
OptionB: Induction of caspase-mediated apoptosis upon contact with infected cells
OptionC: Enhancement of macrophage phagocytosis via secretion of IFN-gamma
OptionE: Activation of complement system via the classical pathway
Explanation:
The correct answer is D. Plasmacytoid dendritic cells are circulating dendritic cells, present in plasma, and are especially imortant in response to viraemia (virus present in the blood). They express TLR-7 (recognises viral RNA) and TLR-9 (recognises viral DNA) and produce 1000x more interferon-alpha compared to other cell types. Type I interferons (alpha and beta) are important in response to viral infections since they induce an "anti-viral" state in cells (i.e. expression of genes that increase resistance to viral entry and replication and modification of cell metabolism to create a hostile environment for viruses).

 

Option A describes the function of conventional dendritic cells, which are resident sentinel cells in tissues and are part of the immediate innate immune response. They also act as a "bridge" between innate and adaptive immunity, since they are capable of migrating to the closest draining lymph node and presenting antigen molecules to naive T cells via MHC-II.

 

Options B and C describe a functions of NK cells. NK cells express a large number of receptors, which can be activatory or inhibitory. If an activatory receptor detects a change on the surface of the cell which means the cell is infected, it activates the NK cell to induce caspase-mediated apoptosis of the infected cell. NK cells and macrophages collaborate and activate each other: macrophages can secrete IL-12, which activates NK cells. NK cells, in turn, can secrete IFN-gamma, which enhances the macrophages' phagocytic function.

 

Option E is incorrect: the classical pathway of complement activation is initiated in response to Ig binding to pathogens.

 

Source: Case 9, Immunological Response to Viral Infection plenary.
Tags: case 9, Infection, immunology, Innate Immune System, Innate immunity

Question:
A 70 year old gentleman comes to the GP surgery for a routine checkup. He mentions that his fingers have gone a bit stiff over the last few years, but he is not in any pain. You saw his DIP are swollen.

His blood chemistry test reveals a slight increase serum ALP level.

He has some OA in his fingers, which is a normal process of aging

His OA might benefit from calcium (and vitamin D) supplement, but would advise him to take dietary calcium first

Question:
A physician discovers that his 72-year-old patient is leaking blood from a vessel that normally carries oxygen
depleted blood. Which of the following vessels is most likely damaged?
Explanation:
The right side of the heart receives oxygen-depleted blood from the systemic and coronary veins. The pulmonary trunk is the large artery that drains the right ventricle and sends that blood to the lungs for aeration. Remember, the critical difference between arteries and veins is that arteries carry blood away from the heart, whereas veins carry blood toward the heart. In the systemic vessels, arterial blood is typically oxygen-rich and venous blood oxygen-poor. However, in the pulmonary circuit, that
oxygenation relationship is reversed. Choice B (Pulmonary veins) is incorrect. The pulmonary veins carry oxygen-rich blood from the lungs to the left atrium. They represent the ﬁ nal step in the pulmonary circuit. Choice C (Abdominal aorta) is incorrect. The abdominal aorta conveys oxygenrich blood to supply the abdomen, pelvis and perineum, and lower limbs. Choice D (Coronary arteries) is incorrect. The coronary arteries convey oxygen-rich blood to supply the myocardium of the heart. Choice E (Common carotid arteries) is incorrect. The common carotid arteries convey oxygen-rich blood to supply structures of the brain, head, and neck.

 

Fake AJW

Question: Which drug forms a complex with the glucocorticoid receptor, acting as a transcriptional regulator to strongly reduce inflammation?
Explanation:
Dexamethasone is a steroid.

 

Mannitol is an osmotherapeutic agent.

Midazolam is a benzodiazepine and increases GABA-ergic suppression of nerve activity.

Carbamazepine inhibits aberrantly active CNS voltage-gated Na+ channels & also is a GABA receptor agonist.

 

Amiodarone is a class III (K+ channel blocker) drug.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the resultant imagery in standard CT (computerized tomography) ﬁlms?
Explanation:
Bone appears white. Both plain ﬁ lm radiographs and CT scans utilize X-ray beams to penetrate the body and measure different levels of radiodensity. Thus, both techniques produce similar images. More radiodense tissue (e.g., compact bone) appears white, whereas less radiodense substances (e.g., air) appear black. Tissues of intermediate degrees of radiodensity appear as varying shades of gray. Choice A (Air appears white) is incorrect. Air is the least dense (most radiolucent) substance. Therefore, air appears black. Choice B (Muscle appears black) is incorrect. Muscle is composed of an intermediate density compared to the extremes of air, which appears black because it is the most radiolucent substance, and compact bone, which appears white because it is the most radiodense substance. Therefore, muscle would appear as a shade of gray in a standard CT scan. Choice D (Fluids appear black) is incorrect. Fluids are composed of an intermediate density compared to the extremes of air, which appears black because it is the most radiolucent substance, and compact bone, which appears white because it is the most radiodense substance. Therefore, ﬂ uids would appear as a shade of gray in a standard CT scan. Choice E (Fat appears white) is incorrect. Fat is composed of an intermediate density compared to the extremes of air, which appears black because it is the most radiolucent substance, and compact bone appears white because it is the most radiodense substance.

Question: The given illustration shows a dorsal view of a human embryo. In the embryo, neurulation is well underway, and several distinct somites are present on each side of the neural tube. The development of the embryo depicted in this illustration is typical of which of the following embryonic periods?
Explanation:
week 4  :

The illustration shows a dorsal view of a human embryo at approximately day 24 (during the 4th week) of development. Week 4 is characterized by most of neurulation, much of somite differentiation, the appearance of the pharyngeal (branchial) apparatus, and the appearance of the upper limb bud. Neurulation (the process of formation of the neural tube) begins late in week 3 with formation of the neural groove and neural folds. However, most of the process, including formation and completion of the neural tube, occurs during week 4. Likewise, segmentation of the paraxial mesoderm into somitomeres and somites begins late in week 3, with 4 to 7 somites formed at day 21. That number increases to 26 to 29 during week 4. Because somites appear at a very speciﬁ c rate, their number can be used to determine the age of the embryo with great accuracy during weeks 3 to 5. This illustration shows nearly complete formation of the neural tube plus 17 deﬁ ned somites, indicating the embryo is well into week 4. The pharyngeal arches and upper limb buds are not seen here, as they ﬁ rst appear later in the 4th week of embryonic development

Question: A 43-year-old pregnant woman at 16 weeks of gestation comes to her OB/GYN for a normal examination. During routine blood tests, her serum a-fetoprotein (AFP) concentration is markedly decreased for her gestational age. Which abnormality or condition will the physician need to rule out based upon these low maternal AFP levels?
Explanation:
In the serum AFP test, sometimes called the maternal serum AFP (MSAFP), a blood sample is drawn from the mother to check the levels of AFP. This blood test is most accurate when the initial sample is obtained between 16 and 18 weeks of gestation.

 

AFP is a protein secreted by the fetal liver and fetal yolk sac and absorbed into the mother’s blood.

 

Decreased levels of MSAFP are associated with chromosomal defects, including Down syndrome (trisomy 21) and trisomy 18, which will need to be ruled out in this patient with additional tests, such as amniocentesis for chromosomal analysis. See the given ﬁgure of a karyotype of Down syndrome (trisomy 21), and note the encircled abnormality at chromosome 21. Pregnant women over the age of 35 have an increased incidence of having children with chromosomal abnormalities. Elevated levels of MSAFP are generally associated with neural tube defects.

 

However, raised levels may also indicate other anomalies, including abdominal wall defects, esophageal and duodenal atresia, some renal and urinary tract anomalies, Turner syndrome, some low–birth-weight fetuses, placental complications, and a multifetal pregnancy

Question: A male newborn suffers a complex of congenital defects involving malformation of the urinary and genital ducts. Examination of his family history reveals several members sharing a similar background of urinary and genital problems spanning three generations. These issues may be related to a genetic defect that is expressed in which of the following embryonic sites?
Explanation:
They love to ask kidney , my dear 

 

The answer is A: Intermediate mesoderm. The urinary and genital systems both develop from the intermediate mesoderm. The intermediate mesoderm is a small zone that connects the paraxial and lateral plate mesodermal areas and also forms a longitudinal urogenital ridge. This urogenital ridge gives rise to the excretory parts of the urinary system, the gonad, and much of the genital duct work. Thus, defects in genetic signaling and/or teratogenic agents acting on the intermediate mesoderm may express themselves as various defects in the urogenital tracts.

Which family of proteins are important for inducing ecto/mesodermally derived organs?
Explanation:
A common peerwise question, most commonly asked are inducing (Wnt) and SHh (patterning of somites).

TGF -Beta family of proteins (including BMP's) regulate cellular differentiation

Question: The given illustration represents a lateral view of an approximately 25-day-old human embryo. Disruption of further development of the structures indicated by the “X” could directly affect the formation of which of the following structures??
Explanation:
Its somites -> para-axial mesoderm -> myotome , dermatome , sclerotome -> muscles of upper limb

(cant wait for holiday)

 

the structures indicated by the “X” are somites, which ultimately give rise to most of the skeletal muscles of the trunk and limbs, plus numerous other structures. Recall that the mesodermal germ layer segregates into three portions: paraxial, intermediate, and lateral plate. Somites form from the paraxial mesoderm and differentiate into myotome, dermatome, and sclerotome. Each myotome splits into a more dorsal epimere and a more ventral hypomere. The hypomere gives rise to the muscles in the anterolateral body wall and the limbs, whereas the epimere is related to the intrinsic muscles in the back.

 

Thus, disruption of the development of the somites could cause malformations in the development of the muscles in the limbs. The dermatome forms the dermis and associated subcutaneous tissues of the skin. The sclerotome gives rise to the vertebral column, the anulus ﬁ brosus portion of the intervertebral discs, and the ribs.

Question:
A 28-year-old woman who does not know that she is pregnant undergoes a chemotherapy treatment at the end of her 1st week of pregnancy. Chemotherapy is associated with slowing the rate of mitosis in exposed cells, which is good in cancer treatment.

 

However, this treatment may also have a negative inﬂuence on the implantation and growth of an embryo. In which of the following layers would a lowered rate of cell division be most likely to hinder implantation of the blastocyst?
Explanation:
Good evening friends, Embryology is confusing but its ok , 1 week to go then summer is yours.

 

Cytotrophoblast is mitotically active whereas syncytiotrophoblast is not 

 

 

The trophoblast forms the fetal part of the placenta, so it is concerned with implantation. The cytotrophoblast is the mitotically active inner part of the trophoblast, and it forms the primary chorionic villi that extend into the syncytiotrophoblast. The cytotrophoblast also provides the cells that migrate into the syncytiotrophoblast and allow it to expand. Thus, chemotherapy may directly affect mitotic activity in the cytotrophoblast, causing stunted growth of both it and the syncytiotrophoblast and possibly hindering implantation

Question:
Case 7 (6/8):

What is the most common cause of Trisomy 21?
Explanation:
Many errors can occur during cell division. In meiosis, the pairs of chromosomes are supposed to split up and go to different spots in the dividing cell; this event is called "disjunction." However, occasionally one pair doesn't divide, and the whole pair goes to one spot. This means that in the resulting cells, one will have 24 chromosomes and the other will have 22 chromosomes. This accident is called "nondisjunction." If a sperm or egg with an abnormal number of chromosomes merges with a normal mate, the resulting fertilized egg will have an abnormal number of chromosomes. In Down syndrome, 95% of all cases are caused by this event: one cell has two 21st chromosomes instead of one, so the resulting fertilized egg has three 21st chromosomes.

 

Recent research has shown that in these cases, approximately 90% of the abnormal cells are the eggs. The cause of the nondisjunction error isn't known, but there is definitely connection with maternal age. Research is currently aimed at trying to determine the cause and timing of the nondisjunction event.


Three to four percent of all cases of trisomy 21 are due to Robertsonian Translocation. In this case, two breaks occur in separate chromosomes, usually the 14th and 21st chromosomes. There is rearrangement of the genetic material so that some of the 14th chromosome is replaced by extra 21st chromosome. So while the number of chromosomes remain normal, there is a triplication of the 21st chromosome material. Some of these children may only have triplication of part of the 21st chromosome instead of the whole chromosome, which is called a partial trisomy 21. Translocations resulting in trisomy 21 may be inherited, so it's important to check the chromosomes of the parents in these cases to see if either may be a "carrier."

 

The remainder of cases of trisomy 21 are due to mosaicism. These people have a mixture of cell lines, some of which have a normal set of chromosomes and others which have trisomy 21. In cellular mosaicism, the mixture is seen in different cells of the same type. In tissue mosaicism, one set of cells, such as all blood cells, may have normal chromosomes, and another type, such as all skin cells, may have trisomy 21.

Question: A 4-month-old male infant presents with a “growing sore” located posterior to his left ear. This sore is diagnosed as a postauricular hemangioma, as seen in the given photo with the auricle pulled anterior. The cells forming the hemangioma are derived from which of the following cell layers?
Explanation:
It's mesoderm , it forms blood island ->angioblasts

 

hemangioma is a vascular tumor in which an abnormal proliferation of blood vessels leads to a mass resembling a neoplasm. Hemangiomas are mesodermal in origin, as they are formed by embryonic blood cells and the vascular endothelium formed by angioblasts, and may be present at birth. The mesoderm forms during gastrulation when invaginating epiblast cells form an additional germ layer between the endoderm and the ectoderm. The mesoderm has many notable derivatives, including muscle, connective tissue, bone, cartilage, blood cells, dermis of the skin, and organs, such as the kidney, spleen, and gonads

 

Fake AJW

 

Case 7 ,prof DJ Wilson lecture

Question: A 2-month-old baby is diagnosed with a ventricular septal defect. This is due to a failure in embryological development of which cardiovascular structure?
Explanation:
Development of the heart begins at about day 18 in the embryo from the mesoderm from a group of cells from the cardiogenic area. Signals from the underlying endoderm result in the formation of a pair of elongated strands known as the cardiogenic cords. These cords fuse together resulting in the primitive heart tube.

At day 22, there is the development of five regions in the primitive heart tube: beginning superiorly, the 1) truncus arteriosus, 2) bulbus cordis, 3) primitive ventricle, 4) primitive atrium and the 5) sinus venosus. These later become the 1) ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk, 2) right ventricle, 3) left ventricle, 4) anterior atrial walls and appendages, and the 5) coronary sinus and sino-atrial node respectively.

Over the next week, the embryo's heart undergoes morphogenesis where it loops and twists from a vertical tube into the premature heart with atrial and ventricular orientation present by day 28. Thickenings of mesoderm in the inner lining of the heart walls (called endocardial cushions) appear and grow towards each other. They fuse and divide the atrioventricular canal into left and right sides. Failure of the endocardial cushions to develop properly will result in a ventricular septal defect.

By the end of the 5th week, the four heart chamber positions are complete. The atrioventricular and semilunar valves form between the 5th and 9th weeks.

 

AW

Explanation:

q = 1/100

q has the diesease p doesn't therefore if q=1/100 p=99/100

2pq is the carrier frequency (2*1/100*99/100)= 198/10,000=~1/50

Question: A 20-year-old man has a routine ECG as part of his new employee health check. The ECG shows varying P-P intervals with slight changes in the ventricular rate. The P waves have a normal morphology and the P-R interval remains constant. His only past medical history is that he is asthmatic and has been using his inhalers more frequently since increasing his running mileage. You reassure the patient that his ECG is normal and record the rhythm as sinus arrhythmia. What is the most likely explanation for this rhythm?
OptionC: Sino-atrial node firing has slight variation in fit patients
Explanation:
Sinus arrhythmia is a normal physiological phenomenon which is commonly seen in young, healthy patients. The heart rate varies with ventilation, inspiration increases heart rate and expiration decreases (only very slightly but detectable on ECG). This is because of vagal tone which is decreased in the inspiratory phase and vice versa. The P-R interval remains constant as there is no heart block, and the varying P-P intervals illustrate changes in the ventricular heart rate.

Anxiety could cause tachycardia but this would not account for varying P-P intervals. Likewise, salbutamol could briefly cause a slight tachycardia but this would have consistent P-P and P-R intervals. There should be no variation in sino-atrial node firing in healthy and fit patients.

 

AW

Question:
Case 7 (8/8):

 Which important step in fertilisation aims to prevent one of the mechanisms of diandry?
Explanation:
The cortical reaction is a process initiated during fertilization by the release of cortical granules from the egg, which prevents polyspermy, the fusion of multiple sperm with one egg.

iandry definition: the phenomenon in which an egg is fertilized either by two sperm or by a diploid sperm

Question: A 52-year-old woman is diagnosed with hypertension after ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) revealed her blood pressure to be 152/91 mmHg. The patient wants to know more about her condition so her GP explains some of the physiology involved in blood pressure. Where in the body are baroreceptors that detect blood pressure located?
Explanation:
The carotid sinus (just superior to the bifurcation of the internal and external carotid arteries) contains baroreceptors, which detect the stretch of the artery wall. These baroreceptors are innervated by cranial nerve IX (glossopharyngeal nerve). These neurones synapse in the solitary nucleus of the medulla, which modulates the activity of sympathetic and parasympathetic neurones here, indirectly affecting their action on the heart and blood vessels to change blood pressure.

There are also baroreceptors at the aortic arch and these are innervated by the aortic nerve, which combines with the vagus nerve (X) and also travels to the solitary nucleus.

The carotid body, adjacent to the carotid sinus, contains chemoreceptors, rather than baroreceptors, and mainly detects changes in the partial pressure of oxygen (but also carbon dioxide) in the blood.

 

AW

Question: A 78-year-old man is about to be started on warfarin. His other medications are checked to see whether there may be any contraindications. Which of his following medications may you want to reconsider or amend before starting warfarin?
Explanation:
Warfarin has many potential interactions with various medications, therefore it is important to check for these thoroughly before starting a patient on it. Warfarin is metabolised by cytochrome P450 enzymes in the liver, therefore medications which interact with this enzyme system will have an effect on warfarin metabolism.

Cytochrome P450 inhibitors decrease the speed of warfarin thereby potentiating its effects.These include NSAIDs, antibiotics such as erythromycin and ciprofloxacin, amiodarone and SSRIs (eg. fluoxetine).

Cytochrome P450 inducers accelerate warfarin metabolism by its enzymes and so decrease its effects. Examples are phenytoin, carbamazepine and rifampicin.

Statins (simvastatin), beta agonists (salmeterol), beta blockers (bisoprolol), and angiotensin-receptor blockers (losartan) do not interfere with warfarin.

 

AW

Question: A 50-year-old woman is found to have a valvular abnormality during an echocardiogram. Which of the following is the most common valve disease?
Explanation:
From most to least common, the valve diseases are mitral valve prolapse, aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation, mitral regurgitation and mitral stenosis. Right-sided valve lesions are less common.

The definition of a mitral valve prolapse is a 2cm or greater prolapse of one or both of the mitral valve leaflets during systole. Mitral valve prolapse has a prevalence of 2-3%.

 

AW

Question: You are a medical student in general practice. You see a patient with difficult to control hypertension, the decision is made to start them on Bendroflumethiazide. What is a reason not to start this medication?
Explanation:
Spironolactone and bendroflumethiazide are different classes of drugs, thus an allergy to one doesn't negate the other being given.

Bendroflumethiazide is a potassium wasting diuretic, thus refractory hyperkalaemia would be an indication, not a contraindication. Conn's syndrome often results in refractory hypertension and hyperkalaemia so again this medication would be more beneficial than harmful.

A side effect of thiazide diuretics is high calcium, thus hypocalcaemia wouldn't be a contraindication.

Thiazide diuretics can precipitate gout, thus a diagnosis of gout would be a reason not to start this medication.

 

AW

Question: A patient is prescribed clopidogrel after experiencing a transient ischaemic attack. How does clopidogrel work as an anti-platelet medication?
Explanation:
Clopidogrel is an ADP receptor antagonist thus inhibiting platelet activation and clot formation.

Inhibition of gamma-carboxylase blood clotting products is the MOA of Warfarin.

Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptors are found on platelet surfaces, and activation causes platelet adhesion and activation. Therefore, inhibition of the specific glycoprotein receptors is an antiplatelet mechanism. Examples include abciximab and eptifibatide.

Both increased expression of thrombomodulin and increase prostacyclin levels would achieve the opposite intended effect and increase blood coagulability and platelet production.

Question: Each one of the followings promotes the release of endothelin, except:
Explanation:
Endothelin is a potent, long-acting vasoconstrictor and bronchoconstrictor. It is secreted initially as a prohormone by the vascular endothelium and later converted to ET-1 by the action of endothelin converting enzyme. It acts via interaction with a G-protein linked to phospholipase C leading to calcium release. Endothelin is thought to be important in the pathogenesis of many diseases including primary pulmonary hypertension (endothelin antagonists are now used), cardiac failure, hepatorenal syndrome and Raynaud's

 

Promotes release

angiotensin II
ADH
hypoxia
mechanical shearing forces

Inhibits release
nitric oxide
prostacyclin

 

Raised levels in
MI
heart failure
ARF
asthma
primary pulmonary hypertension

 

AW

Question: A 37-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations and is found to have a monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. Which electrolyte maintains the resting potential of ventricular myocytes?
Explanation:
Potassium maintains the resting potential of cardiac myocytes, with depolarization triggered by a rapid influx of sodium ions, and repolarization due to efflux of potassium. A slow influx of calcium is responsible for the longer duration of a cardiac action potential compared with skeletal muscle.

 

AW

Question: A 56-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with central chest pain. The emergency medicine doctor takes a quick history and examines the patient, suspecting a myocardial infarction. On examination, the doctor hears a 4th heart sound. What is the cause of a 4th heart sound?
OptionC: Movement of blood across a ventricular septal defect
Explanation:
Heart sounds

The first heart sound (S1) is caused by closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves whilst the second heart sound (S2) is due to aortic and pulmonary valve closure

S1
closure of mitral and tricuspid valves
soft if long PR or mitral regurgitation
loud in mitral stenosis

S2
closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
soft in aortic stenosis
splitting during inspiration is normal

S3 (third heart sound)
caused by diastolic filling of the ventricle
considered normal if < 30 years old (may persist in women up to 50 years old)
heard in left ventricular failure (e.g. dilated cardiomyopathy), constrictive pericarditis (called a pericardial knock) and mitral regurgitation

S4 (fourth heart sound)
may be heard in aortic stenosis, HOCM, hypertension
caused by atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle
in HOCM a double apical impulse may be felt as a result of a palpable S4

Sites of auscultation

Valve Site
Pulmonary valve Left second intercostal space, at the upper sternal border
Aortic valve Right second intercostal space, at the upper sternal border
Mitral valve Left fifth intercostal space, just medial to mid clavicular line
Tricuspid valve Left fourth intercostal space, at the lower left sternal border

 

AW

Question: Occlusion of the PICA (posterior inferior cerebellar artery) causes which syndrome?
Explanation:
Occlusion of the PICA will typically present with:

 

Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sense in the face.

Ipsilateral Horners Syndrome (from loss of the dorsal longitudinal fasciculus)

Loss of gag reflex, hoarseness and dysphagia (loss of nucleus ambiguous)

Contralateral loss of pain and temperature in the body

Ipsilateral ataxia

Tendency to fall to ipsilateral side (damage to vestibular nuclei) with diplopia

 

This group of symptoms is called lateral medullary syndrome.

Question:
Case 12 (4/8):

 A patient has a vitamin B6 deficiency, and develops depression.

 

 Vitamin B6 is essential as a cofactor for the which neurotransmitters which could be indicated as having a role in the patients depression?
Explanation:
According to the lecturer, we are somehow expected to know the snythesis pathway and cofactors required for synthesis of neurotransmitters relevant to depression.

 

Tyrosine -> crosses blood brain barrier (Rate limiting step)

 

Tyrosine - tyrosine hydroxlase (+Fe) -> L-DOPA

 

L-DOPA - AADC (+B6) -> Dopamine

 

Dopamine - DBH (+Cu2+) -> NA

 

NA - PMNT -> A

 

----------------------

 

Tryptophan -> brain

 

Tryptophan - Tryptophan hydroxlase (+Fe) -> 5HT

 

5HP - AADC (+B6) -> 5-HT (Serotonin)

 

Serotonin becomes melatonin in pineal gland when it is DARK.

----------------------------

 

Knowing this, we know that AADC needs B6 to produce dopamine, (and therefore also noradrenaline) and also Serotonin.

-----------------------------

5HP becomes 5-HT via AADC (it was written as 5HT in the lecture but it was a typo.)

Question:
A patient presents of A&E complaining of a fluttering feeling in his chest and he feels dizzy, almost so much that he could faint. 

You carry out a cardiovascular examination and on auscultation you hear a mid-diastolic murmur. 

Which of the following is the patient most likely to have?
Explanation:
Systolic Murmurs:

 

Pansystolic (throughout the whole of systole):

  • Mitral regurgitation 
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Ventricular septal defect

Mid-systolic:

  • Aortic stenosis
  • Pulmonic stenosis

I always remember that these mumurs come half way through systole because isovolumetric contraction happens at the start of systole when these valves are closed and then when they open the turbulent blood flow through the stenosed valves can be heard.

 

Diastolic Murmurs:

 

Early diastolic:

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Pulmonic regurgitation

Mid-diastolic:

  • Mitral stenosis
  • Tricuspid stenosis

Again, there is isovolumetric relaxation at the start of diastole where the mitral and tricuspid valve are closed, it is only when these valves open mid diastole that the turbulent flow can be heard across the stenosed valves.

Question: Ocular bobbing can occur due to damage in which of the following structures?
Explanation:
Ocular bobbing also known as vertical nystagmus is brisk downward and slow upward movements of the eyes.

It is an indication of bilateral pontine damage.

Question: Which cranial nerve carries the afferent pathway for the corneal reflex?
Explanation:
Corneal reflex is mediated by the pons.

Afferent pathway: Ophthalmic branch of trigeminal nerve (V1) carries sensory info from the cornea to pons.

Efferent pathway: Facial nerve carry efferent fibres from pons to Orbicularis oculi and cause eyes to blink.

Question: Development in adolescence can be divided into adrenarche, gonadarche and growth axis activation. What are the predominant hormones responsible for gonadarche?
Explanation:
Adrenarche - DHEA/adrenal androgens

Gonadarche - FSH and LH

Growth axis activation - GH

Question:
John works on building site, and wears ear protection. The mean 8 hour working environment limit on sound intensity is 87dB.

 

If the sound increased to 90dB, how long would it be safe to work?
Explanation:
The correct answer is 4 hours.

 

For every 3dB increase, the sound energy doubles. It also halves the safe amount of time to be exposed to that level of sound intensity.

 

Here there was an increase of 3dB, therefore the safe time halved from 8 hours to 4 hours. If it was 93dB the answer would be 2 hrs.

 

From Case 6 - Auditory Pathways Lecture

Question: Jose and his wife, Jessie, have recently had a baby together named Paul. At 2 months, he is due his first set of vaccines, which are the first doses of pneumococcal and rotavirus as well as the 5 in 1. Which of these is not part of the 5 in 1 vaccine?
Explanation:
Meningitis C has 3 doses, given at 3 months, 12-13 months and 13-15 years. It's an inactivated vaccine.

 

Hib (haemophilia influenza B) is the other part of the 5in1
Tags: Adaptive Immunity, Vaccination, Vaccinations, Virology, case 9

Question: A man hits his head on the corner of a low-hanging object in his shed. He puts his hand on the top his head and finds it covered in blood. which artery supplies blood to this part of his scalp?
Explanation:
The external carotid artery supplies the areas of the head and neck external to the cranium. In the parotid gland, the external carotid artery divides into the maxillary (supplies deep structures of the face) and superficial temporal (supplies superficial areas of the face and scalp) arteries. Before it terminates here, it gives rise to the superior thyroid, lingual, facial (supplies superficial areas of the face), ascending pharyngeal, occipital and posterior auricular arteries.


Branches of the posterior auricular, occipital and superficial temporal arteries which supply blood supply to the scalp are prevented from constricting when cut by close attachment to the underlying connective tissue. Bleeding is made worse by many anastomoses. The scalp is highly vascularised, and a laceration should be stitched up quickly to stop the blood loss.

 

The bone of the skull receives its blood supply from the middle meningeal artery (a branch of the maxillary artery, so is not at risk of necrosis from a scalp laceration.

 

The bone of the skull receives its blood supply from the middle meningeal artery (a branch of the maxillary artery, so is not at risk of necrosis from a scalp laceration.
Tags: Anatomy, Blood Circulation, Case 16, Head, Head and Neck

Question: A 78 year old female patient presents to A&E with an episode of AF. The patient is given an IV-injection of heparin by the nurse after her risk of clotting was evaluated. The consultant asks you to take some bloods so that they can be sent off to the labs check the speed at which the intrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade are working. What is this test measuring?
Explanation:
aPPT is a measure of the time take for the intrinsic and common pathway of the clotting cascade to take place.

 

Prothrombin time is a measure of the time it takes for the extrinsic and common pathway of the clotting cascade to take place. 

 

When checking heparin therapy you often compare aPPT to the prothromin time.

 

International normalised ratio (INR) is just a special measure of prothrombin time which makes sure the measurement is standardised no matter what the testing method was, so again this measures the extrinsic and common pathway.  INR is used when a patient is wafarinised as opposed to when they are given heparin. Target INR for warfarinised patient is 2-3 seconds.

Question: One of the functions of bone is to regulate Calcium homeostasis. When Calcium levels get too high what substance is secreted to bring the concentration of Calcium down?
Explanation:
Parathyroid Hormone is secreted when calcium levels are too low. It brings about increased excretion of Phosphate and increased absorption of Calcium in the Kidneys and stimulates osteoclast secretion in Bone (so more Calcium is released from bone) 

 

Calcitonin is the right answer. It is secreted when Calcium levels are too high and inhibits osteoclasts to reduce Calcium release from bones.

 

Sodium ions play no role in calcium regulation. 

 

Cholecalciferol is the initial reactant in the 2 stage process of activating Vitamin D. It is then hydroxylised twice (first in the Liver then in the Kidneys) to result in 1,25-Di-OH-Cholecalciferol- the active form of Vitamin D. 

 

Phosphate ions are excreted by the kidney when Calcium levels are too low ( this is stimulated by Parathyroid hormone)
Tags: Vitamins and Minerals, Bone, case 14, Physiology, Homeostasis

Question: One of the functions of bone is to regulate Calcium homeostasis. When Calcium levels get too low which substance is secreted to increase the levels again?
Explanation:
Parathyroid Hormone is the right answer. It is secreted when calcium levels are too low. It brings about increased excretion of Phosphate and increased absorption of Calcium in the Kidneys and stimulates osteoclast secretion in Bone (so more Calcium is released from bone)

 

Calcitonin is secreted when Calcium levels are too high and inhibits osteoclasts to reduce Calcium release from bones.

 

Sodium ions play no role in calcium regulation.

 

Cholecalciferol is the initial reactant in the 2 stage process of activating Vitamin D. It is then hydroxylised twice (first in the Liver then in the Kidneys) to result in 1,25-Di-OH-Cholecalciferol- the active form of Vitamin D.

 

Phosphate ions are excreted by the kidney when Calcium levels are too low ( this is stimulated by Parathyroid hormone)
Tags: Vitamins and Minerals, Bone, case 14, Physiology, Homeostasis

Question: A woman presents to the GP complaining of a 3 day history of muscle spasms. When you inquire further into her medical history you find out she recently had thyroid surgery to remove a cancer. What is going on here?
OptionA: She is displaying hypercalcaemia due to an injury to her Parathyroid gland during thyroid surgery.
OptionB: She is displaying hypocalcaemia due to an injury to her Parathyroid gland during thyroid surgery.
OptionC: She is displaying hypercalcaemia due to the oral T4 she is taking after having her thyroid removed.
OptionD: She is displaying hypocalcaemia due to the oral T4 she is taking after having her thyroid removed.
Explanation: Muscle spasms (known as tetany) are a sign of hypocalcaemia. This is often due to hypoparathyroidism. The most common cause of hypoparathyroidism is injury to the Parathyroid gland during thyroid surgery.

Question: A student learning to cook for the first time has managed to cut themselves with a sharp knife (silly student). The cut is so deep he has to go to A and E to get it stitched. Unfortunately the knife managed to damage a nerve in his arm. The junior doctor looking after him is clever enough to know what sort of nerve injury it is. Whilst reporting to a senior they grade it as a IV. Which description best describes this grading?
OptionA: Loss of axonal and endoneurial continuity but preservation of the perineurium.
OptionB: Loss of axonal continuity but preservation of the endoneurium.
OptionC: Complete division of the nerve trunk with no conduction.
OptionD: Loss of axonal, endoneurial and perineurial continuity.
Explanation:
A is grade III 

B is grade II 

C is grade V 

D is grade IV

E is grade VI 

 

Grade I isn't and option however it is described as myelin damage with slow conduction.

 

For more information see the Nerve lecture. :)

Question: A 70 year old gentlemen is in the Oncology Ward due to Prostate Cancer. The most recent scan has found that it has metastasized in the spine. What was the likely route of the cancer getting there and which part of the spine is most likely affected?
OptionB: Pelvic Venous Plexus- affects the Thoracic Spine
OptionD: Pelvic Venous Plexus- affects the Lumbar spine
Explanation:
A is the route and the area affected by metastases from the lung.

 

C is the route and the area affected by metastases from the breast.

 

D is the route and the area affected by metastases from the prostate. 

 

The others are a random mix :)

Question: A patient presents to her GP with long history of palpitation. The GP performs an ECG which shows the patient to have a NCT. They prescribe the patient pharmacological treatments such as flecanide but they do not work. The GP refers the patient to you, a consulant cardiologist who works out she has an AVNRT and is eligible for AVN catheter ablation. In this procedure, the AVN is destroyed, but you need to make sure you destroy the right part of tissue. The antrioventricular node is located inside the triangle of Koch. Which of the following best describes the borders of the triangle of Koch and can guide you to ablate the right region of tissue?
OptionA:
Anterior: Ostium of coronary sinus 

Posterior: Tendon of Tedaro

Inferior: Septal leaflet of tricuspid valve
OptionB:
Anterior: Tendon of Tedaro
Posterior: Septal leaflet of tricuspid valve

Inferior: Ostium of coronary sinus
OptionC:
Anterior: Septal leaflet of tricuspid valve
Posterior: Tendon of Tedaro
Inferior: Ostium of the coronary sinus
OptionD:
Anterior: Septal leaflet of tricuspid valve
Posterior: Ostium of the coronary sinus
Inferior: Tendon of Tedaro
OptionE:
Anterior: Ostium of the coronary sinus
Posterior: Septal leaflet of tricuspid valve
Inferior: Tendon of Tedaro
Explanation:
Anterior boundary: Septal leaflet of tricuspid valve

Posterior boundary: Tendon of Tadoro 

Inferior boundary: Ostium of coronary sinus

 

The AVN can be further split into 2 parts:

  • Lower nodal bundle - cells are longer and parallel in orientation 
  • Compact node - cells are spindle shaped with random orientation

The central fibrous bundle marks where the AVN becomes the bundle of His.

 

It is important to know the anatomy of the AVN for catheter ablation in the treatment of AV node dependant re-entrant tachycardias. Often you ablate the slow (alpha pathway) so there is no way for a re-entrant circuit to be set up but an impulse is still able to get from the atria to the ventricle to allow for a coordinated heart beat. 

 

It is important you do not ablate the compact node because this can lead to complete heart block.

 

 

Case 13: Treatment of Common Arrhythmia

Question:
A gentleman walks in with his wife supporting on his right. He complains of difficulty when swallowing and seeing double images. The pupil of his right eye appears to be constricted. He has a loss of pain and temperature sensation on his left body and right face. 

 

Which artery is likely to be occluded?
Explanation:
He has lateral medullary syndrome, due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery supply the lateral medulla.

 

Patients will present with:

  • loss of pain and temperature sensation; contralateral body and ipsilateral face
  • dysphagia, hoarseness, loss of gag reflex
  • ipsilateral Horner's syndrome - constricted pupil, partial ptosis, anhidrosis
  • Vertigo, tendency to fall to ipsilateral side, diplopia
  • ipsilateral ataxia

Case 16 Plenary

Question: The bainbridge reflex is antagonistic to the baroreceptor reflex. When is it dominant?
Explanation: Bainbridge reflex is dominant when there is increased blood volume. So to counteract this, heart rate increases --> cardiac output increases --> renal perfusion increases --> H2O excretion increases --> ECF decreases --> blood volume decreases

Question:
Case 14 (4/8):

What does the radiograph most likely demonstrate
Explanation:
The parts of the dog are as follows: the transverse process-the nose; the pedicle-the eye; the pars interarticularis-the neck; the superior articular facet-the ear; the inferior articular facet-the front leg. A break in the neck of the dog, or a dog collar, corresponds to a fracture in the region of the pars interarticularis, which is specific for spondylolysis.

 

Spinal mets is the other classic sign- winking owl.


The spondy's...

Spondylitis - inflammation of the discs (e.g. ankylosing spondylitis)

Spondylosis - degeneration loss of disc space

 

Spondylolysis - pars interarticularis defect/stress # - SCOTTY DOG SIGN

 

Spondylolisthesis - anterior displacement of one vertebrae over another, lots of causes including trauma (hangmans fracture), and 'isthmic' if you get bilateral pars interarticularis defects.

Question: What is the major cation in ECF?
Explanation: Na+ is the major cation in ECF and the major anions are Cl- and HCO3-

A patient visits the GP and complains of lower back pain. After history an examination, the GP reassures the patient that the diagnosis is mechanical non-specific back pain, and the patient has no red flags for escalation/referral.

Explanation: For first line pain, NSAIDS are recommended. Paracetamol alone is NOT recommend. Current guidance doesn't recommend TENS machines or anything (SOURCE: Wrap up lecture). Opioids are not recommended either.

Question:
Case 14 (5/8):

A Consultant leads a ward round, and explains to a medical student that the patient has been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease. This puts them at risk of a particular problem with their calcium haemostasis due to the inability of the kidney to convert calciferol to calcitriol.

 

 What blood results would most align with the condition the Consultant is discussing?

(All results would represent a condition, so for more difficulty see if you can label them all)
Explanation:
The condition he is looking for is RENAL OSTEODYSTROPHY

 

A Osteoporosis (all normal)
B Pagets (all normal except high Alk Phos)
C Bone mets (all high except low PTH which is trying to drive everything down)
D Primary Hyperparathyroidism (massively high PTH causing high Ca, low P and high Alk phos)
E Renal Osteodystrophy (Low -could be normal- Ca2+, high P not being excreted, high alk phos and high PTH trying to bring up Ca2+)

Only one left we need to know of is Osteomalacia, see low vit D, casuing low Ca2+, low P, high alk phos and high PTH (both these last 2 can be normal)

Question: Which protein is needed for neuronal cell survival?
Explanation:
Programmed cell death (apoptosis):

  • Due to loss of trophic factors needed for cell to survive (e.g. BDNF, NGF) or triggered by extracellular ligands (e.g. tumour necrosis factor – TNF)
  • Orchestrated by proteolytic enzymes (caspases) and DNAses
  • Resulting apoptotic bodies are phagocytosed (in CNS by microglia)

 

Extracellular matrix molecules e.g. CSPGs inhibit axonal growth  in the CNS

 

Case 16 Plenary cellular response to brain injury

Question:
A 75-year old male presents to A and E with bilateral spastic paralysis after his daughter visiting him this morning and finding him unable to get out of bed. He has intact proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination.

 

Which spinal cord syndrome is likely?
Explanation:
Anterior cord syndrome:

- mostly vascular in origin

- bilateral spastic paralysis

- loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure with some degree of sacral sparing

- preservation of proprioception, vibration 2 point discrimination

 

Posterior cord syndrome:

- rare

- loss of proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination

- motor preservation

 

central cord syndrome:

- cervical spondylosis

- bilateral spastic paralysis

- sacral sparing

- upper limbs > lower limbs = cape distribution

- recovery pattern LL > bladder > UL > sensory

 

brown sequard:

- usually penetrating

- ipsilateral paralysis

- dissociate anaesthesia - loss of ipsilateral proprioception, vibration and contralateral pain, temperature, light touch, pressure

- best prognosis for ambulation

Question:
A 25-year old presents to A and E with signs of a gunshot wound to the back. He presents with ipsilateral paralysis, loss of ipsilateral proprioception and vibration as well as loss of contralateral pain.

 

Which is the likely spinal cord syndrome?
Explanation:
Anterior cord syndrome:
- mostly vascular in origin
- bilateral spastic paralysis
- loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure with some degree of sacral sparing
- preservation of proprioception, vibration 2 point discrimination

 

Posterior cord syndrome:

- rare
- loss of proprioception, vibration and 2 point discrimination
- motor preservation

 

central cord syndrome:
- cervical spondylosis
- bilateral spastic paralysis
- sacral sparing
- upper limbs > lower limbs = cape distribution
- recovery pattern LL > bladder > UL > sensory

 

brown sequard:
- usually penetrating
- ipsilateral paralysis
- dissociate anaesthesia - loss of ipsilateral proprioception, vibration and contralateral pain, temperature, light touch, pressure
- best prognosis for ambulation

Question: List the order of length for the segments of the small intestine from longest segment to shortest.
Explanation:
Answer: E - ileum, jejunum, duodenum 

 

Average length of small intestine: 6 m

  • Duodenum = 26 cm
  • Jejunum = 2.5 m
  • Ileum = 3.5 m 

 

Average length of large intestine: 1.5 m 

 

Note that these are approximate values that I found online; therefore the reliability is questionable and the exact lengths vary individually.

Question: How does Angiotensin 2 illicit SM contraction?
OptionA:
Angiotensin 2 binds to the receptor causes intracellular signalling using cAMP

this causes ca2+ release from the SR

Ca2+ calmodulin complex is formed

this allows MLCK to facilitate cross bridge formation
OptionB:
Angiotensin 2 binds to the receptor causing intracellular signalling using IP3

This causes ca2+ release from the SR

Ca2+ calmodulin complex is formed

this allows MLCK to facilitate cross bridge formation
OptionC:
Angiotensin 2 binds to the receptor causes intracellular signally using cGMP

This causes Ca2+ release from the SR

Ca2+ calmodulin complex is formed

this allow the MLCK to facilitate cross bridge formation

Question:
Case 13 (1/8):

A patient complains of palpitations, shortness of breath, and feeling generally unwell. On admission to A&E the following ECG is produced.



What is the Diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is my first question for Case 13 because I think most peerwise questions to go far, I try to start easy and make them harder through the series. This one is about AF.

AF - because there are no P waves on the ECG but there is background chatter. I honestly think this would be a reasonable question (as before this year many wouldn't have known it AND it came up in our first progress test just like this.) Simple -easy AF.

AFlutter is a type of SVT. It has a characteristic saw tooth baseline and regular Q waves (usually 150bpm 2:1 or 300bpm)

SVT is any tachycardia that comes from above the ventricles, you can tell if it is SVT based on how broad QRS is - it'll be a narrow QRS - Narrow complexes (QRS < 100 ms) are

supraventricular in origin. AFl is actually a type of SVT

WPW has short PR interval (no P's on this ECG) and a delta wave showing pre-excitement. It is potentially dangerous. The access path is called a bundle of kent.

3rd Degree heart block is where there are P waves but the ventricles don't care and beat on their own. Usually brady rather than tachy.

Question:
Case 13 (2/8):

An ECG demonstrates an anomaly on a young patient having a physical as part of joining a professional rugby team.



What is the cause of this anomaly?
Explanation: This shows WPW, so you have to know that to get the question right, then you have to know what it means! It means there is an accessory pathway between atria and ventricles. the mechanism of it can get quite complex, but the basics on an ECG are a shorter PR interval, and a 'delta wave' of pre-excitation in the ventricle as some areas start to depolarise before the rest as some of the excitation goes down the accessory path instead of the AV node.

Question:
Case 13 (3/8):

 A patient develops AF and a decision needs to be made on whether or not anticoagulation should be prescribed. What is the CHADSVASC score of the following patient:

Male
76
Previous Occupation: Coal Miner

MH:
Diabetes

 

Medications:
Insulin (basal bolus regime)
Simvastatin
Ramipril
Amitriptyline
Inadine dressings for ulcer on left foot


Allergy: Penicillin (Rash)


Smoker: 10/day for 30 years, 20/day for 20 years prior to this
Alcohol: 4 units per week

Findings on Examination:
Large body habitus
Absent dorsalis pedis pulse on left foot, dressing in place on heel, cold toes with poor cap refil
Irregularly Irregular pulse
Explanation:
CHA2DS2VASC

Congestive Heart Failure: Signs/symptoms of heart failure confirmed with objective evidence of cardiac dysfunction NO
Hypertension: Resting BP > 140/90 mmHg on at least 2 occasions or current antihypertensive pharmacologic treatment YES
Age >75 (2 points) YES (2 points)
Diabetic Fasting glucose > 125 mg/dL or treatment with oral hypoglycemic agent and/or insulin YES
Stroke/TIA/TE (2 points) NO
Vascular disease Prior MI, peripheral arterial disease, or aortic plaque YES
Age 65-74 NO
Sex: Female NO

TOTAL = 5

 He should probably be anticoagulated.

Question:
Case 13 (4/8):

 A patient has been anticoagulated but has attended A&E due to a fall, the warfarin was immediately stopped and a CT head performed as per the NICE guidelines. A significant subdural bleed was noted and the warfarin initially stopped. The clot was evacuated and she made a surprisingly good recovery, but her daughter wants to discuss starting the warfarin again on discharge as she doesn't think it is a good idea.

Her daughter is quite concerned. During the discussion a number of points are made:

Her mother is getting very old and just turned 69
She is likely to fall over as her diabetic neuropathy is getting worse, although today is the worst fall she has had

She isn't anticoagulated half the time anyway because she forgets to take her medicine sometimes, the rest of the time she tries to catch up and doubles the dose - her INR has been all over the place recently.

What would the HASBLED score for this patient be?
Explanation:
I had forgotten about HASBLED until I wrote the question, because everyone tends to focus on CHA2DS2VASC. Lets go over each element.



Hypertension
Uncontrolled, >160 mmHg systolic
Abnormal Renal or Liver function (1 point for each)
Renal disease
Dialysis, transplant, Cr >2.26 mg/dL or >200 µmol/L
Liver disease
Cirrhosis or bilirubin >2x normal with AST/ALT/AP >3x normal
Stroke history
Prior major bleeding or predisposition to bleeding
Labile INR
Unstable/high INRs, time in therapeutic range < 60%
Age > 65
Drugs or Alcohol:

Medication usage predisposing to bleeding
Antiplatelet agents, NSAIDs
Alcohol or drug usage history
≥ 8 drinks/week

Our lady is 65+, has labile INR, and has had 1 major bleed (today!). So her score is 3. A calculator tells you the percentage chance of another bleed within the year, but there is no strict guidance on stopping warfarin as far as I know.

Question:
Case 13 (5/8):

 In a cardiac myocyte action potential, which phase represents action of a transient outward potassium channel?
Explanation:
One of my weakest area's, I'll do my best to share what little I know

4: Baseline, -96mv
0: Fast Na channels causing Na to rush IN = depolarisation
1: Transient outward K+ causes small repolarisation
2: L-type Ca2+ channels and slow K+ channsl are open, Ca2+ IN, K+ out (slowly)
3: Rapid K+ channels open lot of K+ goes out causing repolarisation
4: Back to baseline.

 I think Jeff went overboard with this lecture, and I don't think more time devoted to untangling it will help me at all. I don't think we'd be expected to know more than this, because this knowledge allows us to use the VW drugs to change different parts in different ways and I think that is the key, if anyone has anything to add please comment. (Or if I have it wrong).

Question:
Case 13 (6/8):

Which of the following causes the ryanodine receptor to keep Ca2+ locked in the SR of the cell. Note that increased Ca2+ in the cell (ie. via L-type Ca2+ channels during a cardiac action potential) removes this effect and causes calcium-induced-calcium release
Explanation:
Another topic I barely understand (if anyone can help in comments I'd be grateful. Correct me if I'm wrong)

The RyR2 receptor keeps the Ca2+ locked in the cell

 

Some Ca2+ comes in as part of an action potential

This REMOVEs the INHIBITION of the RyR2 channel by Calsequestrin, allowing Ca2+ to flood out, causing a contraction.

 

Ca2+ goes back into the SR via the SERCA channel, which has a phospholamban attached, this inhibits the SERCA channel normally. Phosphorylating phospholamban (by SNS stimulation) removes it, and lets SERCA pump Ca2+ into the SR even faster. Which is good for enhancing lucitropy.

 

 Ca2+ is removed from the cell by the PMCA2 channel. This is activated by calmodulin, which helps it also to work faster. but I dont know what triggers it.

 

Calbindin is almost completely unrelated. It is something your epithelial cells in the SI have, and it is increased by vitamin D that has been activated (called Calcitriol, activated first in liver to cholecalciferol, then again in kidney to calcitriol). Calcium is actively absorbed in the duodenum and passively in the jujenum

SERCA has been explained above.

 

 I really found this lecture difficult. I might give a question like this a guess in the exam.

Question:
Case 13 (7/8):

Which class of drug acts to prolong the effective refractory period by extending Phase 3 of a cardiac action potential?
Explanation:
Class V doesn't exist, firstly.

 

 

Amiodarone is the drug in question, extending the ERF can be useful. It can be used in VT, AF, WPW and AFl, but it isn't often firstline as it can be quite nasty. Anytime you mess wit the ERF and prolong the QT period you can cause Long QT, this can go into TdP which can go to VF. So you gotta be careful. Also whilst on amiodarone you have to check thyroid and potassium levels as it can throw them out.

Question: Which cranial nerve innervates the Obcularis oculi muscle?
Explanation: Cranial nerve VII, facial nerve, innervates the obcularis oculi muscle, which is the muscle which closes the eyelids

Question: Where does the ascending reticular activating system sit in the brain?
Explanation: The ascending reticular activating centre sits in the pons where it projects to the thalamus and controls consciousness.

Question: Which cell in the CNS is responsible for removing and deactivating neurotransmitters like glutamate?
Explanation: Astrocytes are responsible for controlling the concentration of ions, especially K+, and removing and deactivating neurotransmitters

Question: Where does the olfactory nerve exit?
Explanation: CN 1 - enters through olfactory bulb and exits via foramen of cribriform plate

Question: Where does the optic nerve exit?
Explanation: CN II - enters via thalamus and superior colliculus and exists from optic canal

Question: Where does the oculomotor nerve exit?
Explanation: CN III - enters through midbrain and exits through supraorbital canal

Question: Where does the trochlear nerve enter?
Explanation: CN IV - enters through midbrain and exits from supraorbital fissure

Question: Where does the V1 division of the trigeminal nerve exit?
Explanation: CN V - V1 - enters from pons and exits through supraorbital fissure

Question: Where does the V2 division of the trigeminal nerve exit?
Explanation: CN V - V2 - enters through pons and exits from foramen rotundum

Question: Where does the V3 division of the trigeminal nerve exit?
Explanation: CN V - V3 - mandibular division - enters through pons and exits through foramen ovale

Question: Where does the abducens nerve enter?
Explanation: CN VI - enters through pons and exits from supraorbital fissure

Question: Where does the facial nerve exit?
Explanation: CN VII - enters from the pons-medulla border and exits from the internal acoustic meatus

Question: Where does the glossopharyngeal nerve exit?
Explanation: CN IX - enters through medulla and exits through jugular foramen

Question: In which of the following regions is the GI system most highly populated with bacteria?
Explanation: The correct answer is the large bowel. The further down the gut you go for more densely populated with organisms. There are far more anaerobes than aerobes.

Question: You have been given some eye drops to take, you are told that they act like a local anaesthetic so you will lose your corneal reflex. What is the main drug in the eye drops?
Explanation:
Tetracane is an Na+ channel blocker and causes loss of corneal reflex 

tropicomide is an mAch antagonist and causes pupil dilation and paralysis of the ciliary muscles 

cocaine is a sympathetic agonist causing pupil dilation, whitening of the sclera and loss of corneal reflex 

phenylephine is a alpha - adrenoceptor agonist causing pupil dilation and whitening of the sclera 

pilocarpine is an mAch agoni and causes pupil constriction, blood shot eyes and is used to treat glucoma
Tags: Year 1, Year 1 Revision, drugs, drugs in eyes

Question: A 75 year old immunosuppressed gentlemen who is currently on a course of antibiotics is suffering from an infectious cause of diarrhoea. Microbiology reveals that the causative organism is a anaerobic gram positive rod. What is the most appropriate management of this patient?
OptionA:
Stop any offending agents.
Isolate the patient and focus on HH e.g. use of alcohol before and after seeing the patient and PPE.
Use metronidazole/ vancomycin in some cases.
OptionB:
Isolate the patient and focus on HH e.g. use of alcohol before and after seeing the patient and PPE.
Use metronidazole/ vancomycin in some cases.
OptionC:
Stop any offending agents.
Isolate the patient and focus on HH e.g. wash hands with soap and water before and after seeing the patient and PPE.
Use metronidazole/ vancomycin in some cases.
OptionD:
Isolate the patient and focus on HH e.g. use of alcohol before and after seeing the patient and PPE.
Use metronidazole/ vancomycin in some cases.
OptionE:
Stop any offending agents.
Isolate the patient and focus on HH e.g. use of alcohol before and after seeing the patient and PPE.
The infection will be self-limiting so no need for antibiotics.
Explanation:
C is correct. 

The organism described is Clostridium difficile. The C.diff is likely to be caused by the antibiotics that the patient is on. 

It is important to stop any causative agents and isolate the patient to prevent person to person transmission. 

Soap and water hand washing is important, C.diff is spore forming and alcogel can facilitate spread by these spores. 

As the patient is immunosuppressed antibiotics are likely to be needed.

Question: A patient comes into your GP surgery complaining of numbness and pins and needles in his feet. You are concerned that the symptoms that the patient is experiencing could be related to an infective cause of diarrhoea that the patient was suffering from 2 weeks ago. What infective agent is likely to have been the cause of the patient's diarrhoea?
Explanation:
The symptoms being described are signs of Guillain Barre Syndrome. 

This is associated the post-infection seqeuelae in Campylobacter. 

 

Reactive arthritis can also occur.

Question: A patient is suffering from diarrhoea caused by Campylobacter after eating some poorly cooked chicken at his neighbour's BBQ. The doctor tells the patient that usually they would not treat this with antibiotics but because he is immunosuppresed he will prescribe him some antibiotics to shorten the duration of the infection. What antibiotic is the patient most likely to be prescribed?
Explanation:
Erythromycin is given in campylobacter infections if the patient is immunosuppressed. However, campylobacter is usually self-limitiing and so in a healthy individual antibiotics wouldn't be prescribed. 

 

Metronidazole and Vancomycin can be given in C.difficile infection.

Question: Which of the following heart sounds is associated with a dilated heart?
Explanation:
S1 and S2 are normal heart sounds

S3 is associated with a dilated heart

S4 is associated with a stiffened heart

Question: Which type of meningitis is more dangerous?
Explanation:
according to our second lecture in case 16: 'infections of the CNS', bacterial meningitis has a high mortality rate ~20%. Patients are often septic with low blood pressure, tachycardia and altered consciousness. A non-blanching petechial rash is seen in bacterial but not viral meningitis and is caused by abnormal clotting.

 

Viral meningitis is often self-limiting, patients are at a lower risk of shock and may present with flu-like symptoms.

Question:
A 5-year-old boy has a known mutation on chromosome 15q11-q13. He was a small baby ad had difficult in feeding.

His mother is concerned that he is now eating too much and gaining weight.

 

 

What is the neural mechanism underlying his hyperphagia?
OptionA:
Ghrelin level remains high 

Blunted 5HT2C receptor - decrease POMC
OptionC:
Ghrelin level remains high 

Normal 5HT2C receptor - decrease POMC
Explanation:
Ghrelin is orexigenic, it is secreted when your stomach is empty to tell you to eat.

Its level decrease when the stomach fills up.

In PWS, ghrelin level remains high.

 

In PWS, Snord115 is lost, so effect of 5HT2C receptor is blunted - thus decrease POMC and increase appetite

 

Locaserin, a selective 5HT2C receptor agonist is an anti-obesity drug that is used. 

5HT2C receptor activation - activates POMC - decrease appetite; increase satiety

 

 

Case 12 Plenary Neural control of appetite

Question: A patient presents with cough, constipation and fever. Which is the likely causative agent of his symptoms?
Explanation:
S.typhi is a type of Salmonella. It is associated with enteric fever and symptoms include fever, cough and constipation. It requires antibiotic therapy with fluoroquinolones, ceftriaxone or azithromycin. 

 

S.enteritides in contrast is a the most common type of salmonella which cause diarrhoea. This doesn't usually require antibiotics unless immunosuppressed. This type causes diarrhoea rather than constipation.

Question: A nerve palsy of which of the following nerves is most common in those with an ICP?
Explanation: CN IV has the longest course of any CN therefore it's quite vulnerable to damage from increases in pressure

Question: You are playing badminton when suddenly your friend gets breathless. He complains of a chest pain that feels like a knot for some reason, grading it 3/10. You are sure he cannot be in that much discomofort but you take him to A&E nevertheless. It turns out you were wrong and an ECG shows ST elevation in leads II, III and avf. Which coronary artery is blocked?
Explanation:
ST elevation in leads II,III and avf > inferior STEMI > RCA blocked.

 

JJ

Question:
A 45 year old Caucasian patient present to the GP for a medication review. During the appointment the GP checks the patient's blood pressure and finds it to be raised. He sends the patient away with an ambulatory blood pressure monitor to check that this result was not just due to "white-coat hypertension". The results of the ambulatory monitor showed an average blood pressure of 147/90 mmHg. You check the patients notes and his medical history is as follows: simple nephrectomy due to a renal carcinoma, unilateral renal artery stenosis. 

 

What would be the first step in the treatment of this patients blood pressure?
OptionE: He doesn't need blood pressure treatment, his blood pressure is within normal range.
Explanation:
This patient should not be given an ARB or an ACE-i (Losartan or Ramipril) due to the fact he only has one kidney and the renal artery to the only working kidney is stenosed. 

 

Angiotensin II normally acts on the glomerular vessels causing vasoconstriction, it causes the efferent artery to constrict more than the afferent artery which causes increased renal blood pressure and maintains the glomerular filtration rate. 

 

If you block/stop the formation of angiotensin II then the glomerular filtrate rate drops or is abolished which leads to renal failure. Normally in unilateral renal stenosis this wouldn't matter too much because the working kidney compensate but since he has had the other kidney removed stopping angiotensin action is dangerous. The same would be true if there was bilateral artery stenosis. 

 

You would therefore give the patient nifedipine (a CCB) which reduced blood pressure by blocking calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle, leading to vasodilation, decreased total peripheral resistance and therefore pressure. 

 

E is incorrect becuase this patient has grade I hypertension:

 

Normal: 120/80 mmHg

Pre-hypertension: 130/85 mmHg

Grade I: 140/90 mmHg

Grade II: 160/100 mmHg

Grade III (medical emergency): 180/110 mmHg

Question:
An elderly 84 year old patient with a history of AF has prevented to A&E after she fell down the stairs and hit her head. Her warfarin therapy was halted and a CT head showed a subdural haemorrhage. 

 

It is discussed whether this patient is at risk of futher serious bleeds if she is kept on her warfarin therapy. 

 

The following points were discussed:

  • Her blood pressure is 122/80mmHg
  • She has unilateral renal artery stenosis
  • She takes codeine for chronic lower back pain
  • Her INR has been outside the desired range near to 70% of the time 

What is this patient's HASBLED score?
Explanation:
Attribute 1 point to each of the following:

 

Hypertension

Abormal renal or liver function

Stroke 

Bleeding 

Labile INR (outside desired range >60% of the time)

Elderly (>65yrs)

Drugs (alcohol at least 8 drinks a week, antiplatelets and NSAIDs) 

 

This patient scores 1 point for having a renal abnormality, 1 point for having a recent bleed (this subdural one), 1 point for labile INR and 1 point for her age =  4 points

 

Her blood pressure is normal, and she takes codeine for the back pain which is an opioid, if she took Ibuprofen for the pain this would have increased her score by another point.

 

As far as I am aware, there is no cutoff score (like there is in the CHADSVASc)

Question:
A patient with known Type 2 Diabetes visits her optician.

Fundoscopy reveals dot and blot haemorrhages and hard exudates. 

What is the likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Background: Dot and Blot haemorrhages, hard exudates

Pre-proliferative: venous beading, Cotton Wool Spots

Proliferative: new vessels (categorised as NVD or NVE)

Maculopathy: Exudate, retinal thickening, micro-aneurysms or haemorrhage within 1DD of the Fovea

Question:
Following a meal, high glucose levels result in insulin release. 

Via which Glucose transporter can glucose enter beta cells of the pancreas, in order to signal release of insulin.
Explanation:
GLUT 1: all cells 

GLUT 2: liver, beta cells, hypothalamus 

GLUT 3: neurones, placenta, testes

GLUT 4: Skeletal/ cardiac muscle, Fat 

GLUT 5: mucosal surface in small intestine

 

 

Glucose enters the beta cells via GLUT2, Glucokinase activity then increases ATP, inhibiting K+ATP efflux channels.

Ca2+ influx results, causing insulin secretion via IP3 signalling pathways.

- Dr. Coffey- Drug Management of Type II Diabetes

Question: What is considered first line treatment for Type 2 Diabetes?
Explanation:
Diet and exercise is first line treatment 

Then: Metformin 

3rd line: Metformin and an addition of either a Prologitazine, Gliptin or sulphonylurea.

Question:
A drug used for the treatment of type 2 Diabetes works by inhibiting di-peptidyl peptidase IV (DPP-IV) which normally would otherwise degrade GLP-1.

Which drug does this describe?
Explanation:
Gliptinsinhibit DPP-IV so that GLP-1 has an extended effect on insulin secretion. 

 

Incretin mimetics e.g. Exenatide. Activates the GLP-1 receptor (resulting in increasing insulin, decreasing glucagon)

 

Metformin: activates AMP-dependant PK, increases insulin dependant glucose uptake. Also inhibits GI carbohydrate absorption and gluconeogeneis. 

 

Sulphonylurea e.g. glicazide blocks K+ATPase, blocking K+ efflux.
B-cell depolarises causing Ca2+ influx which triggers IP3 cascade to enhance insulin granule release.

 

Pioglitazone: forms a complex with PPAR gamma that acts as a Adipocyte gene transcription factor, increasing glucose uptake.

Question: which of these is not a feature of the affect of hypertension of renal arterioles
OptionA: Thickening of the smooth muscle in the tunica media
Explanation:
Hypertension;

thickening of SM in the tunica media causes luminal lamina

internal elastic lamina of the renal arterioles is reduplicated

hyaline degeneration causes toughening of the arteries causing decreased compliacne

Question: Dopamine acts as which Hypothalamic Releasing Hormone?
Explanation: Dopamine can be used to prevent women lactating following a miscarriage or abortion.

Question:
An elderly obese female becomes increasingly withdrawn, lethargic and confused. 

Her past medical history includes previous thyroid surgery, treatment with radio iodine and poor compliance with medication. 

 

This is a typical clinical picture for the end stage of which disease?
Explanation: This is a typical clinical picture of a myoedema coma associated with hypothyroidism.

Question:
A 45 year old woman presents to her GP with increasing fatigue, weight gain, depression, constipation and joint pain. 

On examination you note periobirtal puffiness, loss of outer third of eyebrow, delayed relaxation of ankle jerks and non-pitting oedema.

Her heart rate is 55 bpm. 

 

A Thyroid Function Test reveals high TSH levels and low Free T4 levels.

 

What is the most common cause of this patients condition? (in the UK)
Explanation:
This patient has Hypothyroidism.

 Hashimoto’s disease is the most common cause of this in the UK. This is an autoimmune condition causing chronic inflammation and failure of the thyroid glands.

 

Hypothyroidism can also  occur as a result of acute thyroiditis, a viral infection of the thyroid gland.

 

Treatments for Graves’ disease (hyperthyroidism), such as thyroidectomy and administration of radioactive iodine, also frequently cause hypothyroidism.

 

Iodine Deficiency is the most common cause worldwide but uncommon in the UK.

Question:
A patient presents with symptoms of Hypothyroidism.

 

Thyroid Function Test reveals

Serum TSH: high

Serum Free T4: Low

Serum T3: Normal

 

Which of these is not a clinical symptom of hypothyroidism.
Explanation:
Patients with hypothyroidism present with constipation, whereas patients with hyperthyroidism can have diarrhoea.

 

"Everything slows down except for periods"

Common Symptoms include, weight gain, cold intolerance, depression, constipation, joint pain, infertility. 

Menstrual Irregularities: longer heavier periods.
Tags: case 10, Practice Questions, endocrinology, Case group 57

Question:
A patient presents with constrictive pericarditis.

They have a positive Kussmal's sign.

Which answer best describes Kussmall's sign?
Explanation:
Kussmall's sign is a paradoxical increase in JVP during inspiration. This is seen in restrictive diseases such as constrictive pericarditis, Cardiac Tamponade and Restrictive cardiomyopathy.

During inspiration JVP usually falls. This is because pulmonary vascular resistance decreases during inspiration, therefore pressure is reduced in pulmonary arteries and therefore the RA, despite and increase in venous return. 

Absent A waves are seen in AF.

Large V waves are seen in tricuspid regurgitation.

Steep Y waves are seen in restrictive pericarditis et

Question:
A 40 year old woman has Graves Disease. 

Her TSH is low, T4 high and T3 high. 

 

Which of the following is NOT  a symptom.
Explanation:
"Everything speeds up except for periods" 

Symptoms of hyperthyroidism include: 

  • Excessive sweating 
  • Heat intolerance
  • Increased Bowel Movements 
  • Tremor 
  • Palpitations 
  • Weight loss with an increase in appetite 
  • Fatigue 
  • Increased anxiety 
  • Irregular periods

OptionA: Cumulative declines with age over multiple physiological systems causing decreased homeostatic reserve. This body is therefore less able to cope with stress.
OptionC:
A complex metabolic disorder due to severe wasting accompanying disease states such as cancer. 

can occur with or without fat loss

criteria for diagnosis

Question: Which salivary glands produce the most saliva?
OptionE: Minor Salivary glands within the oral mucosa
Explanation:
The parotid glands are the largest and produce around 25% of the saliva. 

The submandibular glands are smaller but produce around 70%. 

Sublingual glands produce around 5%. 

There are around 800-1000 minor salivary glands in the oral cavity. 

 

Von Ebners's glands produce a serous fluid that begins lipid hydrolysis and facilitates taste perception.

Question:
Histamine interacts with the H2-receptors on parietal cells to increase HCL production. 

Which cells of the gastric mucosa secrete Histamine?
Explanation:
S cells: Secretin (inhibits gastrin)

I cells: CCK

Chief cells: pepsinogen

Question: What is the role of Hepcidin?
Explanation:
Hepcidin: degrades ferroprotin so that iron cannot leave the cell and is lost to the GI tract when enterocytes are shed. 

 

Calcium levels are regulated by PTH and Calcitriol.

Question:
A patient presents to the clinic with an ulcer. It is on the dorsal of the food. There is grey granulation tissue, little exudate and they say the pain is worse at night. 

Which type of ulcer is most likely present?
Explanation:
Arterial ulcers typically present more distally. They have grey granulation tissue and little exudate. Noctural pain is often described and is relieved when leg out of the bed. They may also present with hairlessness, pale skin, absent pulses, nail dystrophy and wasting of calf muscles.

Venous ulcers tend to be large and shallow. They may present with dermatitis and haemosiderin deposits. They have venous blood excudate.

Diabetic ulcers present with neuropathy and are common in areas of pressure

Question: Which of the following acts on SERCA and increases Ca2+ reuptake in the sarcoplasmic reticulum during relaxation of cardiomyocytes?
Explanation:
Calstabin (aka FKBP) binds to sites on the on the subunits of the RyR inhibiting the movement of calcium out of the SR.

 

Calmodulin binds to the plasma membrane calcium ATPase (PMCA) which activates the removal of 1 Ca2+ ion per ATP molecule across the sarcolemma of the cardiomyocyte.

 

Phospholambin is phosphorylated by calmodulin kinase, when it is phosphorylated in binds to sarco/endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and encourages the return of  calcium into the SR of the myocyte. Unphosphorylated phosolambin inhibits SERCA

 

Calsequestrin inhibits RyR from releasing calcium from the SR.

 

The NCX channel in the sarcolemma exhchanges 3 sodium ions into the cell for 1 calcium ion out of the cell.

 

Beta-adrenoreceptor activation by NA (sympathetic nervous system) causes activation of Ga protein which activated adenylate cyclase. Adenylate cyclase increases cAMP which in turn activates PKA. This has 2 effects:

  1. PKA phosphorylates the binding site on the RyR receptor for calstabin which means calstabin cannot bind and have its inhibitory effect. The RyR is more likely to open and calcium leaves the SR. Increased intracellular calcium leads to increased inotropy (and increased chronotropy in pacemaker cells).
  2. PKA phosphorylates calmodulin kinase activating it. The calmodulin kinase can then phosphorylate phospholamban. The phospholamban can then bind to the SERCA and increase return of calcium into the SR. Therefore it leads to increased lusitropy. The cardiomyocyte relaxes quicker so can stimulated to contract again.
