Question: Where does the Olfactory nerve (CNI) exit the skull?
Explanation:
Correct! The Olfactory nerve exits the skull through the cribiform plate

 

Olfactory (I) - Cribiform Plate

Optic (II) - Optic Canal

Oculomotor (III), Trochlear (IV), Trigeminal V1 and Abducens (VI)  - Superior Orbital Fissure

Trigeminal V2 - Foramen Rotundum

Trigeminal V3 - Foramen Ovale

Facial (VII) and Vestibulocochlear (VIII) - Internal Acoustic Meatus (remember vestibulocochlear is for hearing so acoustic)

Glossopharyngeal (IX), Vagus (X) and Accessory (XI) - Jugular Foramen

Hypoglossal (XII) - Hypolossal Canal

Question:
47 year old Olivia presents to the antenatal clinic, concerned as her erratic party lifestyle has continued way beyond her acceptable university years, and has ended up pregnant after a night out in Magaluf. 
Having left the other 6 children at home she is in a rush, but before she goes she asks you about genetic testing. 

She wants to know how you genetically test blood. 

You explain to her the process but half way through you seem to have forgotten about the drugs used. 

Knowing there is another, more eager, medical student in the next room you go to ask her. 

She tells you about the drug used to disrupt mitotic spindles, preventing completion of mitosis. 

What is this drug called?
Explanation:
Genetic testing via blood: 
Take blood in anticoagulant. Purify lymphocytes. 

Culture cells for 3-4 days. 

Encourage mitosis using phytohemagglutin
Then disrupt mitotic spindles using colcemid, preventing completion of mitosis

Harvest cells, treat with hypotonic solution (so they swell) 
Fix cells on a microscope slide
Stain with Giemsa stain to show banding pattern 

Therefore correct answer - colcemid 

 

Inhibin A and MSAFP are used in antenatal blood screening for chromosomal abnormality 
For reference - 
MSAFP: decreased in T21, Turners, T18 ; increased in T13, NTD
Inhibin A - increased in T21 and Turners 

 

Information on genetic testing via blood - Chromosomal abnormalities lecture, Dr Andrew Fry

Question:
Sassy, a known drug abuser, comes into your clinic for a chat about his cannabis use. You tell him that it's bad for him and he says "Wadiyatalkinabeet?"

 

Which of the following facts about cannabis and associated physiology are FALSE?
OptionA: Stimulates GABA release therefore dopamine released in the nucleus accumbens
OptionB: Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) acts on CB1 and CB2 receptors
OptionC: Dopamine release is less extreme than in cocaine but still higher than normal
OptionE: CB1 receptors are found in the CNS and CB2 receptors are mainly found in the peripheries
Explanation: GABA release is actually inhibited not stimulated you druggo

Question:
A 24-year-old gentleman is brought in by his mum because he has been hurting himself recently. He was diagnosed with depression and was prescribed with Fluoxetine. He refused to let his mum to accompany him during the consultation.

 

After some difficult questioning, you found out he has not been taking the drug for a while because it caused erectile dysfunction and made him very embarrassed in front of his girlfriend.

 

How does Fluoxetine causes of this side effect?
Explanation:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor. It binds to 5HT reuptake transporter, so less 5HT is transported back into the pre-synaptic knob and accumulates in synaptic cleft.

 

Side effects due to:

  • wrong 5HT receptor stimulated 
  • correct receptor but wrong part of the brain

A - ADR of TCA: H1 blockade causes wight gain, drowsiness

 

B - Mirtazapine (atypical antidepressant) mechanism of action: a2adrenergic, 5HT2A and 5HT3 receptors antagonist

 

C - SSRIs mechanism of action: down regulation of 5HT1a autoreceptors secondary to increased 5HT availability, leading to increased 5HT tone

 

D - CORRECT: Sexual dysfunction (over-activation of 5HT2A receptors in spinal cord and nucleus accumbens)

 

E - Nausea/ vomiting (overactivation of 5HT3 receptors in the brainstem)

 

Case 12 Plenary and wrap up

Question:
Case 16 (5/8):

 Which collection of symptoms correctly describes cushings triad which represents raised intracranial pressure?
Explanation:
High BP
Low HR
Irregular breathing pattern is cushings triad. It's odd because you'd expect high BP to be caused by a HIGH HR. The Systolic part of the BP rises the most and this causes a widened pulse pressure (difference between Systolic and Diastolic)

I think A might be seen in DKA, as you often are dehydrated (low BP, high HR from hypovolaemic shock) and the kussmaul breathing is an attempt at respiratory correction of the metabolic acidosis.

Question:
Case 16 (2/8):

 A patient is in a coma on ITU and you examine their pupils. They're small and don't react. What is the cause of this?
Explanation:
I couldn't find any good pictures at all for a pupil question, poor google fu skills.

So, the first part is quite easy.
Mid brain = midsize, pontine = pinpoint (remember pinpoint can also be caused by opioid overdose and if you see this you grab the competetive agonist at the opioid receptor NALOXONE)

Then you need to remember what causes constriction and what causes dilation, because that will tell you what is lost.

SNS is fight or flight, and you want to see as much as you can, so SNS causes DILATION. So this has been lost!

Uncal herniation would cause a CN III palsy, which would only affect one eye and give you a fixed dilated pupil.

Metabolic suppression is another reason for small pupils but they would still be reactive.

Note that the especially astute of you might have noted exopthalmos in the picture (her eyes are BULGING.) This is a feature of GRAVES disease, a thyroid problem (hashimoto hypo graves hyper! Graves' disease, also known as toxic diffuse goiter, is an autoimmune disease that affects the thyroid.)

Question:
Case 16 (6/8):

A young university student comes to A&E complaining of a rash, feeling generally unwell, sickness, neck stiffness and he hates it when the lights are on?

What is the first priority?
Explanation:
I remember getting this wrong in the wrap up.

Antibiotics is the first line as this is most likely a bacterial meningitis which means we need antibiotics yesterday. What would you pick? Ideally Ceftriaxone. If suspecting Listeria add Ampicillin (or Amox).

Question: What is the role of CSPGs
OptionA: Produced by microglial cells in the CNS to inhibit CNS axonal growth
OptionB: Produced by Astrocytes in the CNS to inhibit CNS axonal growth
OptionC: Produced by Satellite cells in the PNS to encourage axonal growth
OptionD: Produced by microglial cells in the PNS to encourage axonal growth
OptionE: Produced by Satellite cells in the PNS to discourage axonal growth
Explanation: CSPGs or chondroitin sulphate proteoglycans is produced in the CNS to prevent axonal regrowth after injury

Question:
Ketan Singh was in bed suffering from a very serious bout of lateral medullary syndrome. You prod his cheeks with a large carving knife and he cannot feel it on his right cheek, you then prod each of his arms and he says he cannot feel it on his left arm. He says he is having difficulty swallowing and you notice his voice is very hoarse. 

Which of his blood vessels is most likely occluded?

AW
Explanation:
Ketan's right posterior inferior cerebellar artery is occluded causing ipsilateral loss of pain (and temp) sensation to his face and contralateral loss of pain (and temp) sensation to his body. Dysphagia and hoarseness are also some of the symptoms of a PICA infarct. 

You promptly perform decompressive surgery by suboccipital craniectomy and Ketan is right as rain in no time at all!



AW
Tags: Nervous system, Neurology, Brain, PeerwiseTrollSeries, Head

Question:
Case 16 (7/8):

 As part of the assessment of an unconscious patient you perform a doll's eye test.

 The nurse opens the unconscious patients eyes and tilts the head to the left and the right.

The patients eyes remain fixed towards you who is standing at the end of the bed during the movement. Even when the patients head is tilted to the right, both eyes move left to keep staring forward, and vice versa on the left.

What is your conclusion?
Explanation:
From Case 16 wrap up.

Doll's Eye:
NORMAL: Eyes stay forward
Sig brainstem injury: eyes roll towards direction head is turned

MLF lesion: One eye rolls towards direction head is turned, one eye does what it should and rolls medially to stay looking forward. (MLF coordinates eye movement)

Propofol is a common sedative used on ICU, Atracurium is from the Case 14 lectures, it is a non-depoliarising muscarinc antagonist. (Sux is depolarising and gives fasiculations.)

Question: Which of these is a cause of Pre-Hepatic Jaundice?
Explanation:
Pre hepatic jaundice is caused by the production of bilirubin at levels greater than the capacity of the liver to conjugate and excrete it. Therefore, there is a rise in unconjugated bilirubin.  

Caused by haemolysis e.g. Rh incompatibility, talassaemia, sickle cell, G6PD deficiency. 

 

Crigler-Najjar and Gilbert's syndromes would cause hepatic jaundice with a rise in unconjugated bilirubin, due to deficiencies in the conjugating enzyme. 

Viral hepatitis causes hepatic jaundice with a rise in conjugated bilirubin (leakage of bilirubin from hepatocytes)

 

Gall Stones is a cause of post hepatic (obstructive) jaundice. Rise in plasma and urine conjugated bilirubin.

Question:
Case 14 (8/8):

 

 

Patient has been feeling unwell quite a while, developed neck stiffness and photobhobia

 

An LP is performed


With the following CSF results, what would the most likely causative organism be?

Colour: Clear
PMNL: Low
Lymphocytes: High
Protein: Low
Glucose: simliar to plasma
Explanation:
I think they're will deffo be a question interpreting an LP

 

Low PMNL high Lymphocytes suggests viral, also with clear and

 

HSV1 more likely to cause encephalitis (symptoms of seizures and focal neurology)
 HSV2 slightly more likely to cause meningitis
BUT far more likely than both is an enterovirus species.

 

TB would have a yellow vicious CSF, with HIGH Lymphocytes, High Protein, LOW glucose, most likely in travellers
Bact would have yellow CSF, high PMNL, low gluc, high protein (most likely organism Neissera, then Strep pneumonia, then HiB (unless very young before immunisaitons)

 

Cryptosporidium more likely in HIV +ve patients

Question:
A med student has their first occupational health appointment. He explains to the nurse that he thinks he had the Hep B vaccination before going travelling in Africa a few years ago. The nurse takes a blood sample.

 

The results are:

HBsAg negative

anti-HBc positive

anti-HBs positive

 

what do these results suggest?
OptionA: susceptible to infection - needs course of HepB vaccinations
Explanation:
These results suggest that he is immune due to natural infection.

 

If he were to be susceptible to HepB his results would show:

HBsAg negative
anti-HBc negative
anti-HBs negative

 

if he were to be immune due to vaccination his results would show:

HBsAg negative
anti-HBc negative
anti-HBs positive

 

If he was acutely infected with HepB, his results would show:

HBsAg positive
anti-HBc positive

IgM anti-HBc positive
anti-HBs negative

 

If he were to be chronically infected, his results would show:

HBsAg positive
anti-HBc positive
IgM anti-HBc negative
anti-HBs negative

Question: Atypical antipsychotics block a wider range of receptors compared to conventional antipsychotics. Which 2 MAIN receptors do they block that contributes to their therapeutic effect?
Explanation:
Chlorpromazine, a conventional (1st generation) antipsychotic, blocks D1 and D2

 

Case 12 Plenary

 

Each drug also blocks a range of other monoamine receptors and we don't have to learn them at this stage...thankfully

https://www.evidence.nhs.uk/formulary/bnf/current/4-central-nervous-system/42-drugs-used-in-psychoses-and-related-disorders/421-antipsychotic-drugs

Question:
It is the 1st January 2017 and you are asked to see Ketan Singh, a 21 year old male, in A&E. He has been admitted following an RTC last night in which he was riding a motorbike without a helmet. You perform a GCS assessment on him. When you walk into the room you notice that his eyes are very swollen and he is unable to open them. You ask him his name, where he is and what month it is. He answers "Ketan, Hospital, December". You ask him to touch his nose and he is unable to, you then press your thumb into his superior orbital fossa and he flexes his neck away from the stimulus and promptly tells you to "piss off".

What is Ketan's GCS score?

AW
Explanation:
Ketan cannot open his eyes as they are swollen shut after the crash, this means you are unable to score him on the Eyes section of the GCS assessment and must record this as NT (not testable). 
Ketan recalls the month as December but as it is now January (only just) you must record this as confused, scoring him 4 points for the Verbal section.  
Ketan displays normal flexion away from a painful stimulus so scores 4 for the Motor section.

You must not report a total score for Ketan as his eyes are untestable. His score (8) could imply that he is more unwell than he actually is and could confuse medical colleagues.

Remember to wear a helmet next time Ketan!

 

AW

Question: What is the mechanism of action of clarithromycin?
OptionA: Protein synthesis inhibitor which binds to the 30s subunit of ribosomes
OptionB: Protein synthesis inhibitor which binds to the 50s subunit of ribosomes
Explanation:
Specifically a macrolide - all of these end in mycin (except for vancomycin which is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor) 

By binding to the 50s subunit it is known to block the binding of tRNA to the donor site and is useful in pneumonias and campylobacter

Question: What is the mechanism of action of ciprofloxacin?
OptionA: Blocks protein synthesis by binding to the 30s subunit of ribosomes
OptionB: Blocks protein synthesis by binding to 50s subunit of ribosomes
OptionC: Inhibits topoisomerase II and IV hence inhibiting DNA synthesis
Explanation:
Ciprofloxacin is known to be a quinolone antibiotic which functions by inhibiting topoisomerase II and IV 

It is useful for gram negative and gram positive bacteria including: psuedomonas, chlamydia, gonorrhoea and typhoid - however one of the serious side effects is that it has the potential to cause tendon rupture

Question:
The results of a patient's Hepatitis B Blood Test are:

 

HBsAG: +ve

anti-Hbc +ve

anti-HBs -ve

IgM anti HBc +ve 

 

What does this indicate?
Explanation:
HBsAg +ve = currently infected 

anti-HBc +ve= natural infection 

anti-HBc= immune either due to natural infection or vaccination 

 

IgM anti-HBc +ve= acute infection

Question: In a paracetamol overdose situation, a patient is given an IV dose of a drug that replenishes which substance?
Explanation:
OD: phase I (cytochrome p450 enzymes) pathway overwhelmed

Excess parecteamol forced down Phase 2 (UDP-glucuronosyl transferases) pathway, which generates n-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NAPBQI) which is toxic. 

GLUTATHIONE can deactivate NAPBQI but reserves are quickly depleted. 

 

IV n- acetyl cysteine replenishes Glutathione.

Question: Which of the following statements is true of thoracic vertebrae?
OptionA: Has foramina transversaria through which vertebral arteries and their accompanying veins and sympathetic plexus traverse.
OptionB: Has a mammillary processes on the posterior parts of the articular processes.
OptionC: One of the thoracic vertebrae has a process known as the dens.
OptionE: Has a short and sturdy spinous process.
Explanation:
Description of Cervical Vertebrae:

 

Atlas (C1):

  • No vertebral body
  • Transverse processes
  • Anterior and posterior tubercles
  • Articular facet on the anterior arch for articulation with the dens of C2
  • Superior facets for articulation with the occipital condyles
  • Foramina tranversaria

Axis (C2)

  • Dens (odontoid process) that projects from the vertebral body and articulates with atlas
  • Posterior articular facet on dens for articulation with the ligament of atlas
  • Superior articular facet
  • Foramina transversaria
  • Transverse processes
  • Bifid spinous process 

C3-7:

  • C3-5 have a bifid spinous process, C6-7 have a long spinous process (C7 = vers prominens because its so long)
  • Triangular foramen
  • Vertebral body which is wider medial-laterally than it is antero-posteriorly.
  • Foramina transversaria through which vertebral arteries and their accompanying veins and sympathetic plexus traverse (except C7)
  • Superior and inferior articular processes with articular facets for formation of zygopophyseal joints with adjacent vertebrae. 

Description of Thoracic Vertebrae:

 

T1-12:

  • Heart shaped vertebral body, bigger than cervical region but smaller than lumbar. 
  • Long spinous process that points infero-posteriorly therefore overlaps with adjacent vertebrae
  • Superior articular facet points postero-laterally, inferior articular facet points antero-medially - this restricts movement to just rotation.
  • Superior and inferior articular surfaces for costal cartilages
  • Transverse processes that point posteriorly and have an articular site for costal cartilage
  • Ribs 2-10 articulate with their corresponding thoracic vertebrae and the one above 
  • Ribs 1, 11-12 articulate just with their corresponding vertebrae because they only have one articular surface.
  • Limited movement so that ribs can move up and out in order to inflate the lungs. 
  • Pain in thoracic region = RED FLAG because limited movement means it is unlikely this is benign mechanical pain. 
  • Foramen is smaller than cervical and lumbar vertebrae, triangular. 

Description of Lumbar Vertebrae:

 

L1-4:

  • Kidney shaped vertebral body, wider 
  • Foramen is triangular bigger than thoracic region but smaller than cervical region
  • Short, sturdy spinous process
  • Mammillary processes on the posterior articular processes
  • Superior facets face postero-medially, inferior facets face antero-laterally - therefore allow flexion/extension but limits rotation

Question: Which of the following changes occur in grey and white matter structure during adolescent brain development?
OptionA: Steady, linear increase in grey matter volume
OptionB: Increase in grey matter volume pre-pubertal, decrease post-pubertal
OptionC: Higher order association areas matures earlier than motor and sensory systems
OptionD: Females tend to show a steeper age-related increase in white matter than males
Explanation:
White matter:

  • steady, linear increase in vol. due to progressive age-related myelination - greater connectivity
  • males tend to show a steeper age-related increase
  • difference partly due to rise in gonadal puberty hormones 

Grey matter

  • region specific, non-linear pattern of development
  • pre-pubertal increase, post-pubertal decrease in vol. = synaptic pruning, rarely used connections are eliminated
  • motor and sensory systems mature first, then higher order association areas to integrate the primary functions

 

Case 12 plenary

Question: How would the side effects of Clozapine place a patient at risk of developing metabolic syndrome?
Explanation:
Metabolic syndrome medical risk factors: (3 out of 5 to diagnose)

  • large waistline
  • high triglyceride level, bp, blood sugar
  • low HDL

A - ADR of Risperidone

B, C - ADR of Clozapine, but not a risk factor for metabolic syndrome

D - Clozapine causes hyperglycaemia, but not a risk factor

E - CORRECT, Clozapine causes hypertension, as well as hyperlipidaemia

 

Negative symptoms of psychosis e.g. anhedonia and avolition may also place them at risk of developing metabolic syndrome

 

Case 12 workbook on LC

Question: As Pia was finishing cooking the burgers on the barbecue, she heard a loud "phump". She found Lissie unconscious on the floor with a football next to her. Kieran looked guilty. Pia went up to Lissie and suddenly remembered her lecture about assessment of the unconscious patient. She asked Lissie where she was however, the girl only grunted in pain. Her eyes remained shut despite Pia's attempts to cause her pain. At the same time, Lissie's arms were flexed abnormally in front of her body. Pia asked Kieran, who still looked guilty, what Lissie's Glasgow Coma Scale is. What is Kieran's answer and how should he manage the patient?
Explanation: Glasgow Coma Scale is 6 because Lissie's response was grunting (2 - incomprehensible sounds), eyes remained shut (1 - no reaction) and flexed abnormally (3 - decorticate). Because it is < and including 8, intubation is required.
Tags: Trauma, Neurology, Case 16, Head, Head and Neck

Question: If the odds of me passing this exam are the same as the percentage of cases of Down's Syndrome caused by Robertsonian Translocation, what are the chances I'll be back here in August?
Explanation:
95% of cases of Down's syndrome are due to non-dis-junction. 90% of these non-dis-junctions happen in the egg

3-4% of cases are due to Robertsonian Translocation

 

therefore if there's a 3-4% chance of me passing, there's a 96-97% chance I'll be back in August for re-sits.

Question: During embryonic development, the primitive forming heart is composed of a heart tube, which shows five dilatations along its length. From the cells of which of these swellings does the SA node (intrinsic pacemaker of the mature heart) derive?
Explanation:
The correct answer is option E. Think of the name - SINOatrial node, and the answer is quite easy, SINUS venosus

Duiring week 5, the cardiomyocytes of the sinus venosus begin depolarising at a faster rate than the cells of the other regions. Cardiac dextral looping brings the sinus venosus to the superior part of the forming heart, where it is incorporated into the right atrium - location of the SA node in the mature heart.

 

Source: Case 8, Cardiovascular System Development plenary.
Tags: Anatomy, case 8, Cardiovascular system, Heart, Embryology

Question:
Mrs Jones comes into the GP with her daughter who is a little worried about her. At her 70th birthday party last week, she chatted to her daughter who organised for her to have an appointment. Mrs Jones' memory is starting to deteriorate and this means she often forgets she has taken her anti-coagulation tablets so sometimes takes more to catch up.

 

Mrs Jones' daughter says she is becoming increasingly concerned that her mother may have a stroke due to a bleed instead of a clot. She is also worried about her mother's drinking, saying she has 2 drinks each night with dinner.

 

What is Mrs Jones' HASBLED score from the information provided?
Explanation:
HASBLED of 3

 

Hypertension (1)

Abnormal kidney (1) or renal (1) function

Stroke (1)

Bleeding (1)

Labile INR (1) - Mrs Jones often takes too many anti-coagulants so her INR will be uncontrolled

Elderly (1) - >65. Mrs Jones is 70

Drugs (1) and Alcohol (1) - drugs include NSAIDs and anti-platelets. Alcohol is defined as 8 or more drinks per week (Mrs Jones if having 14)

 

Mrs Jones has a score of 3 or more so her anti-coagulation should be reviewed or have more regular monitoring.

 

Mrs Jones comes into the GP with her daughter who is a little worried about her. At her 70th birthday party last week, she chatted to her daughter who organised for her to have an appointment. Mrs Jones' memory is starting to deteriorate and this means she often forgets she has taken her anti-coagulation tablets so sometimes more to catch up.

Mrs Jones' daughter says she is becoming increasingly concerned that her mother may have a stroke due to a bleed instead of a clot. She is also worried about her mother's drinking, saying she has 2 drinks each night with dinner. 

 

If people are a bit confused like I was - the HASBLED is to assess risk of starting a patient on anti-coagulation but also to review safety. This means they can currently be on anti-coagulation and have labile INR. The drugs section is for anti-platelets (eg. aspirin, Clopidogrel) and NSAIDs, and does not include anti-coagulation - hope this clears things up :)

Question: A 54 year old male weighing 72kg comes in for surgery on one of the digital nerves in his hand. You are the anaesthetist and decide to give the local anaesthetic Bupivicaine without adrenalin. How much anaesthetic should you give this patient?
Explanation:
Without adrenalin:

  • Lidocaine - give 3mg/kg (3x72 = 216mg)
  • Bupivicaine - give 2mg/kg (2x72 = 144mg)

You would give adrenaline to cause vasocontriction of the blood vessels, this prevents bleeding and slows the flow of blood at the site which means the local anaesthetic stays there for longer and hence its effects last longer. 

 

In the past adrenalin was not indicated for regions such as the fingers, ears and tip of the penis because there is no collateral blood supply, so when you give the adrenalin the only blood vessel supplying that region constricts and no blood can reach the region. The region becomes ischaemic. Nowadays there are specially formulated local anesthetics that contain adrenalin for use in these regions which contain an amount of adrenalin which acts is a predictable way.

 

With adrenalin:

  • Lidocaine - 7mg/kg (7x72=504mg)
  • Bupivicaine - 5mg/kg (5x72=360mg)

It is important you do not give more than the allowed dose because local anaesthetics are pro-arrhythmic. They are also used as class Ib anti-arrhythmic drugs that work by blocking sodium channels and so, like all anti-arrhythmic drugs, they ironically have the potential to cause arrhythmia. 

 

When the patient has his surgery he might be able to feel the cold of the prep and the pressure of the knife but he would not be able to feel the sharp pain. This is because anaesthesia gets rid of sensation in the following order: sharp pain > cold > warmth > touch > motor.
Tags: Anaesthesia and Analgesia, Anaesthetics, Neurology, case 14

Question: A patient with heart failure complains of tinnitus and gradual hearing loss. Which drug is most likely to explain these symptoms?
Explanation: Furosemide acts by inhibiting the NKCC2 (Na+/K+/2Cl-) cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Prolonged use can affect the similar co-transporter responsible for regulating the endolymph in the inner ear, and can cause such symptoms (ototoxicity).

Question: Which biochemistry results best reflect those you would expect in a patient with Conn's syndrome?
Explanation:
Conn's syndrome - primary hyperaldosteronism, a cause of secondary hypertension. Often due to adrenal adenoma.

 

You also find a high aldosterone : renin ratio in Conn's as high aldosterone has a negative feedback effect on renin (whereas in secondary hyperaldosteronism e.g. due to renal artery stenosis or renin tumour, high renin causes high aldosterone, which has no negative feedback on renin)

Question: MODY 12 is caused by error in coding for the ABCC8 gene. What does this gene normally code for?
OptionA: KIR.6 channel on the islet potassium channel
Explanation:
MODY 12 is coded for ABCC8 and this codes for the SUR1 or sulfonurea receptor 1 on the beta cells in the islet.

MODY13 is coded for by the KCNJ11 channel. This codes for KIR.6 on the beta cells  which is a component of the K+ channel itself.

GCK is usually faulty in MODY 2 and results in a mild hyperglycaemia that is usually controlled with diet.

MODY 12 and 13 are usually neonatal forms of diabetes mellitus type 2. 

MODY type 1 is usually caused by error in the HNF4a gene and is a more severe from of MODY.

MODY type 3 is the most common form of MODY and is coded for by HNF1A.

Question: Which of the following is not involved in the process of Wallerian degeneration?
Explanation:
When a nerve is severed, Wallerian degeneration occurs at the site distal to the injury. Everything distal to the injury is dead because the nerve cell is completely separated from the cell body, isn't receiving nutrients and cannot carry out neuronal transport.

 

Macrophages break down axonal debris and ellipsoids (myelin) by phagocytosis. Schwann cells also help to phagocytose the debris. Intra and extracellular calcium concentrations increase which activates calpain (a protease) which breaks down the cytoskeleton of the axon (i.e. excitotoxicity).

 

Neurotropic factors are released by Schwann cells during the REGENERATION phase. Their role is to attract the filopodia sent out by the proximal part of the nerve to grow down the hollow tube (just the basal lamina) that has been left by Wallerian degeneration. Thus, promoting axonal growth.

Question: which mechanism of action best describes that of Metformin.
OptionA:
Inhibits mitochondrial respiratory chain complex 1 and therefore AMP-kinase.

This increases specific nuclear receptor expression and inhibits genes for gluconeogenesis.

This also increases peripheral insulin sensitivity, decreases intestinal carbohydrate reabsorrption, increases FA oxidation and decreases LDL and vLDL.
OptionB: activates PPAR-gamma complexed with a retinoid X receptor. PPAR-gamma is a transcription factor. Needed for things like lipoprotein lipase, adipocyte FA binding protein, GLUT-4 and FA transport protein.
OptionC: Inhibits DPP-4 which potentiates endogenous incretins which are usually degraded by DPP-4.
Explanation:
A- metformin

B- pioglitazone

C- gliptins 

D- GLP-1 e.g. liraglutide

Question:
Case 10 (1/8):

  A 68 year old man with a long history of COPD is reviewed on a medical ward before discharge. An ABG is performed with the following results:

 

 

Pa O2 8.9 (on 40% O2, N >10 on air)
pH 7.34 (7.35-7.35)
PaCO2 7.3 (4.7-6.0)
HCO3- 30.2 (22-26)
BE +5.3 (+/-2)

How would you summarise his acid base balance?
Explanation:
I think there WILL be an ABG interpretation on either the ISCE (I know we don't perform them so maybe next year) or the exam. At least 1.

How is the patient - long term COPD which is an OBSTRUCTIVE lung problem, probably has poor ventilation therfore.

 

Oxygenation - hypoxaemic (shold be like 30 if he's on 40% o2)

pH mildy acidotic

Resp: high CO2 = RESP ACIDOSIS
Metab: high HCO3- = Metab alkalosis

So we have a resp acidosis compensated by a metab alkalosis.

 I think, with the ABG alone and no background info, D could be correct, in any case, the history tells us the problem is likely to be respiratory in nature with a metabolic compensation, rather than some kind of metabolic alkalosis (e.g. ++vomiting?) compensated by respiratory acidosis (hypoventilation).

Question:
A woman is diagnosed with gastric ulcer caused by H. pylori bacteria. She is treated for a week with Omeprazole, Amoxicillin and Clarithromycin. 

Which of the following test is the most commonly used to confirm successful resolution of the condition?
Explanation:
The most commonly used test is carbon urea breath test. Enzyme urease is produced by H. pylori, it separates urea from the radiolabelled carbon. Radiolabelled carbon dioxide is excreted during expiration and detected = unsuccessful treatment.

 

Positive serum antibodies can be used for diagnosing, but not to check if the treatment is successful or not.

 

Other tests: faecal antigen teset, rapid urease test at endoscopy, histopathology of gastric biopsy specimen

 

Case 3 Anatomy practical
Tags: Digestive system, Gastroenterology, Gastrointestinal System, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 3

Question:
Case 10 (2/8):


At which site is aqueous humour produced?

(And if you want to be really clever, can you identify all the labels?)
Explanation:
Ciliary body produces Aq. Humour, which maintains the shape of the cornea and anterior chamber. It circulates from posterior chamber to anterior chamber and out by canal of schlemm (important for glaucoma)

They also RELAX to PULL the zonules which makes them TESNSE to produce an oval lense if an object is far away
They CONTRACT to cause the zonules to RELAX to produce a round lense is an object is close

Now for letters, I get very confused between CONJUNCTIVA, CORNEA and SCLERA. Sclera is the harder white covering and goes all the way around, cornea is only in front of the pupil/iris. Conjunctiva is see through and it lines eyelids and surface of the eye

A Virtuous Humour
B Choroid
C Retina
D Fovea
E Sclera
F Optic disc
G Optic n
H cornea
I ?also cornea?
J ant chamber
K migh be pointing to posterior chamber
L LensM Iris

N eyelid

O ciliary muscle
P zonule/suspensory ligament

Question:
A 12 year old girl has been referred to neurology following falling off her horse and fracturing her humerus. The fracture caused damage to a nerve and the patient has wrist drop. The neurologist performs Tinel's test and she shows a positive result. 2 months later (60 days) later she returns to clinic, she has not had surgery in this time, and you repeat the Tinel's test, you tap the area where you believe the nerve has grown to and again you get a positive result.

 

Which of the following statements is correct?
OptionA: The patient has a class V neurotmesis of the radial nerve with an advancing Tinel's of 60mm.
OptionB: This patient has class IV axonotmesis of the radial nerve with advancing Tinel's of 120mm.
OptionC: This patient has class II axonotmesis of median nerve with advancing Tinel's of 120mm.
OptionD: This patient has a class III axonotmesis of the radial nerve with advancing Tinel's of 60mm.
OptionE: This patient has a class I neuropraxia of the median nerve with advancing Tinel's of 60mm.
Explanation:
The patient has damaged her radial nerve, a common result of a fracture of the humerus and the cause of wrist drop. This discounts answers C & E.

 

This patient has an advancing Tinel's test which means it must be a nerve injury which regenerates on its own without surgery i.e. class II (axonal damage) or III (axonal and endoneurial damage) axonotmesis. Neuropraxia/class I doesn't show Tinel's test in the first place because the axon is not damaged. As class IV axonotmesis (axonal, epneurial and perinurial damage) and class V neurotmesis (axonal, endoneurial, perineurial and epineurial damage) don't show advancing Tinel's because they cannot repair themselves without surgery. This discounts answers A, B and E. 

 

The rate of nerve regrowth after injury is 1mm/day therefore within this 2 months the Tinel's positive sign will have advanced 60mm. This discounts B & C.

 

The correct answer is therefore D
Tags: Nerve innervation of upper limb, Nerves, Neurology, case 14

Explanation: You ain't alone - Good luck

What type of inheritance is demonstrated by the above pedigree

Question:
Case 10 (5/8):

Concerned that a patient has diabetes, you perform a blood test as the patient is reporting symptoms of frequent urination, feeling tired, weight loss and has had a hard to treat UTI recently.

Which test result would be most conclusive to give us a diagnosis of diabetes in order to start treatment?
Explanation:
So C has the highest glucose, but fingerpricks can be badly done, and should always be confirmed with a HBA1C also, so I tried to catch people out a little, but this is an easy question without a little distraction.

CRITERIA
Diabetes symptoms (e.g. polyuria, polydipsia and unexplained weight loss for Type 1) plus:

a random venous plasma glucose concentration ≥ 11.1 mmol/l or
a fasting plasma glucose concentration ≥ 7.0 mmol/l (whole blood ≥ 6.1 mmol/l) or
two hour plasma glucose concentration ≥ 11.1 mmol/l two hours after 75g anhydrous glucose in an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).


HbA1c > 6.5% or 48mmol/mol*

 

 

The criteria for diagnosing gestational diabetes is different. Gestational diabetes should be diagnosed if the woman has either:

a fasting plasma glucose level of 5.6mmol/l or above or
a 2-hour plasma glucose level of 7.8mmol/l or above.

Situations where HbA1c is not appropriate for diagnosis of diabetes: - I think this would be needlessly mean, maybe AW will make a question on it ;)

ALL children and young people
patients of any age suspected of having Type 1 diabetes
patients with symptoms of diabetes for less than 2 months
patients at high risk who are acutely ill (e.g. those requiring hospital admission)
patients taking medication that may cause rapid glucose rise e.g. steroids, antipsychotics
patients with acute pancreatic damage, including pancreatic surgery
in pregnancy
presence of genetic, haematologic and illness-related factors that influence HbA1c and its measurement (see annex 1 of the WHO report for a list of factors which influence HbA1c and its measurement)

 

CM

Question: In sinus arrhythmia, the longest RR interval exceeds the shortest RR interval by how many seconds?
Explanation:
In sinus arrhythmia, the longest RR interval exceeds the shortest interval by 0.16s.

All complexes are normal but the rhythm is irregular. 
Very common in all age groups. 

Young people: not considered a disease.
One origin for sinus arrhythmia may be the vagus nerve which mediates respiration as well as heart rhythm. The nerve is active during respiration, and through its effect on the SAN, increases heart rate during inspiration and decreases during expiration. 
This is particularly pronounced in children. 

We were shown this in lecture by breathing in quickly and measuring our pulses

inhibits peptidoglycan synthesis

Vancomycin inhibits bacterial wall synthesis as it inhibits peptidoglycan synthesis

isoniazid also used to treat TB inhibits mycolic acid

Question: If you have 1000 patients with a symptomatic tachycardia, approximately how many will drug therapy be effective for?
Explanation:
Knowledge that: Drug therapy is both effective and well tolerated in 1/3 of patients with symptomatic tachycardias

1/3 of 1000 = approx. 333

Question: Mo has a history of degenerative disc disease. He is sprinting in the park when all of a sudden he 'feels something go' in his back. He proceeds to get pain in his buttocks and down his legs, with numbness over his lateral malleolus. He is told he has a disc herniation at L5/S1. Which nerve has been compressed?
Explanation: Disc herniation at L5/S1 compresses the spinal nerve that exits below, which is S1.

Question: Jimbo is currently on an antidepressant. While leisurely browsing Cosmopolitan for his daily celeb news to find out who Brooklyn Beckham is dating now, he sees a section describing the wonders of halloumi on making gains in the gym. He immediately goes to Nando's for a few portions of some cheeky grilled halloumi. A few minutes later he enters a hypertensive crisis. Which antidepressant is most likely to explain this?
Explanation:
A and E are both NRIs.

B and D are SSRIs.

C is the correct answer - it is an MAOI (monoamine oxidase inhibitor) which can result in a life threatening hypertensive crisis due to a "cheese effect." MAOIs inhibit monoamine oxidase and therefore breakdown of noradrenaline. Consuming foods high in tyramine such as cheese, milk fish etc can cause displaced noradrenaline from vesicles which further increases the amount of noradrenaline and causes vasoconstriction. This can result in a hypertensive crisis (>180/110mmHg).

 

MAOIs work on two receptors:

- MAOA - adrenergic and dopaminergic neurons

- MAOB - serotonergic and histaminergic neurons (less cheese effect)

 

AW

B = Cheese effect

D = 5-HT, Melatonin synthesis

 

C + E are made up.

Question:
An 85 year old female patient is brought to A&E by her daughter because she can't feel or move her arms. 

You perform a neurological examination and you find the following:

  • Bilateral paralysis of the upper limbs
  • Loss of pain and temperature sensation in both of the upper limb and thoracic region
  • Loss of light touch and pressure sensation in both of the upper limbs and thoracic region
  • Loss of proprioception in both the upper and lower limbs
  • Loss of 2-point touch discrimination and vibration sense in both the upper and lower limbs. 

What is your most likely differential diagnosis?
OptionE: Bony met in the lamina of a cervical vertebrae
Explanation:
This patient has central cord syndrome. At her age it is likely she has stenosis of the cervical spinal canal, also known as cervical spondylosis. On bending and straightening her neck (flexion and extension of her cervical spine) she probably nipper her spinal cord, causing the blood vessels to be affected leading to ischaemia. Ischaemia affects the centre of the cord more than the periphery because blood supply to the cord goes from the outside in. 

 

Central cord syndrome affects all of the tracts. Depending on how big the area of ischaemia is will determine how big the region affected it. 

 

 

In this patient the ischaemia has affected the parts of the spinothalamic tract and corticospinal tract that supply the cervical and thoracic areas (this is known as cape distribution), and all of the dorsal column. 

 

The patient gets function back in the following order:

Motor function of the lower limb, bladder control, motor function in the upper limb, sensory function.

Question: What hormone is most responsible for apoptosis of chondrocytes to fuse epiphyseal plates?
Explanation:
Stages of endochondral ossification in brief:

- Perichondrium becomes periosteum

- Periosteum produces osteoblasts to secrete osteoid to form trabecula

- Chondrocytes undergo mitosis due to growth hormone, hypertrophy and produce ALP for mineral deposition

- ECM calcifies

- Osteoblasts break down trabecular bone to form bone marrow cavity

- Epiphyseal plates continue to form cartilage which is reduced by bone

- In puberty, oestrogen leads to apoptosis of chondrocytes to fuse plates

Question:
The results of a patients plasma glucose tests are as follows:

 

Fasting glucose: 6.1 mmol/L    (nr 4-6mmol/L)

2-hr glucose: 8.1                      (<7.8mmol/L) 

 

What does this suggest?
Explanation:
The normal ranges for fasting plasma glucose are 4-6mmol/L.     2-hr: under 7.8 

 

Fasting glucose >7.0mmol/l and 2-hr glucose >11.1 suggests Diabetes 

 

Pre-Diabetes can be further categorised into two types:

  • Impaired Glucose Tolerance:   Fasting <7  2hr: 7.8-11      (BOTH ARE ABOVE NORMAL BUT BELOW THE CUT OFF FOR DIABETES)
  • Impaired Fasting Glucose:   Fasting 6.1-6.8  2hr: <7.8     (FASTING GLUCOSE IS ABOVE NORMAL BUT 2HR GLUCOSE IS WITHIN NORMAL RANGE)

Question:
A 43 year old male patient comes into your GP surgery with complaints of hearing loss. You perform the Rinne's and Weber's test. 

The result is as follows:

 

Rinne's test - the sound is heard louder when the tuning fork is placed on the mastoid in the right ear and the tuning fork is heard louder when placed in air by the left ear. 

 

Weber's Test - the tuning fork is heard louder in the right ear. 

 

What is your diagnosis?
OptionB: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear
OptionC: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
OptionD: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Explanation:
The Answer is C: conductive hearing loss in the right ear. 

 

Rinne's: bone conduction is louder in the right ear than air conduction. This suggests a conductive hearing loss. 

 

Weber's: Weber's literalists to the right hand side - this would be suggestive of right conductive hearing loss. If it lateralised to the left - then it would be suggestive of a combined loss in the right ear. 

 

If you had a normal Rinne's test in both ears i.e. air conduction was louder than bone conduction and then you performed a Weber's test and it lateralised to one side  - this would suggest contralateral hearing loss .

Question:
You are an F1 working in a busy A&E department and you receive a phone call from the paramedic team who tell you they are bringing in a patient who they believe to have a spinal cord injury. The paramedic states the patient had abnormal neurology due to a gun shot wound. You suspect this patient has Brown-Sequard syndrome and the gun shot would has caused lateral hemisection of the spinal cord. 

 

When the patient arrives you not the gun shot wound is on the patient's right side. You carry out a neurological examination and you find the following....
OptionA: Loss of pain and sensation in the right leg but present in the left.
OptionB: Loss of light touch and pressure in the right leg but present in the left.
OptionC: Loss of motor function in the left leg but present in the right.
OptionD: Loss of motor function in the right leg but present in the left.
OptionE: Loss of proprioception, vibration sense and 2-point touch discrimination in the left leg but present in the right.
Explanation:
Brown-Sequard syndrome causes:

  • Ipsilateral loss of motor function
  • Ipsilateral loss of proprioception, discriminative touch and vibration sense
  • Contralateral loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure

This is due to the fact the cortical spinal tract (descending motor tract) has crossed over in the brain, the spinothalamic tract (ascending pain, temperature, light touch and pressure tract) crosses has already crossed over but the dorsal column (ascending proprioception, discriminative touch and vibration sense tract) crosses over after the injury. 

 

Therefore the patient will have:

  • Loss of motor function in right leg, present in left leg. 
  • Loss of pain, temperature, light touch and pressure sensation in the left leg, present in the right leg.
  • Loss of proprioception, discriminative touch and vibration sense in the right leg, present in the left.

Question:
Case 17 (2/8):

 A patient is a type 1 diabetic taking insulin and is struggling because she is waking in the early hours of the morning (~4am) shaking, sweating and feeling awful. Her partner has had to give her a rescue IM dose of glucagon and she finds her glucose is often too low in the morning.

She currently takes a long acting insulin at bedtime, and rapid acting insulin before mealtimes.

 How should she adjust her regime to try to avoid night time hypo's?
OptionA: Eat more slow release carbohydrate with the evening meal
OptionE: Reduce short acting insulin before evening meal
Explanation:
Ok, so I think E and A would both actually help a bit, but I certainly think the right answer is to reduce the long acting insulin that she is having at night.

Remember, hypoglycaemia isn't caused by being T1D, its caused by the TREATMENT of diabetes...like too much insulin, or glicazide or glibenclamide (sulphonylureas which squeeze more insulin out of your B-cells in a T2D by closing the potassium channel and causing a depolarisation causing Ca2+ in and then causing insulin release).

Question: Which of the following drugs is used only in the pharmacological management of Generalised Anxiety Disorder (GAD)?
Explanation: Neuropharmacology 2 lecture

Question: Which receptor does buspirone exert its pharmacological effect on?
Explanation: Buspirone - is a potent agonist at 5-HT1A receptor, it is an effective treatment for generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) but not phobias. It takes days to weeks for buspirone to exert its effects. 5-HTA1 receptors function as inhibitoryautoreceptors (abundantly expressed in serotenergic neurons in the cortico-limbic circuits and implicated in emotional behavior). Stimulating these inhibitory receptors will cause anxiolysis.

Question: Which of the following best describes a conjugate vaccine?
OptionA: A vaccine that is composed of fragments of DNA that encode specific proteins or markers
OptionB: A vaccine in which is created by covalently attaching a poor antigenic determinant (usually a polysaccharide) to a carrier protein to improve immunogenicity
OptionC: A vaccine which contains 'killed' microbes but still amounts a response due to the presence of virulence factors
OptionD: A vaccine in which the pathogen is still alive but its virulence factors have been reduced
OptionE: An injection in which antibodies for the pathogen are directly administered into the patient
Explanation:
A = DNA vaccine
DNA vaccines are a 3rd generation vaccine and are a form of gene therapy.DNA vaccines are composed of fragments of DNA that encode specific proteins or markers. Upon injection into the muscle or skin the DNA code is "read" and the protein is made. The result is that the protein is then presented to the immune system.


B = Conjugate Vaccine
A vaccine containing bacterial capsular polysaccharide joined to a protein to enhance immunogenicity. Some bacteria are coated with a carbohydrate capsule which means that immune response to carbohydrate antigens is poor and so no memory is generated. Conjugate vaccines are frequently given to children under 4 who cannot amount an effective immune response. E.G. Hib


C = Inactivated/Killed Microbe as an immunogen
Sometimes a dead form of the microbe is injected. It still has virulence factors which instigate an adaptive immune response but it is often less immunogenic than other types of vaccines. E.G. Salk Polio, IM Influenza


D = Attenuated Vaccine
The infectious agent is altered in these forms of vaccine but it is not 'dead'. It produces a good strong responses due to the replication cycle more closely resembling the natural course of infection and thus effectively stimulates adaptive immunity E.G. Mumps, Measles, Nasal Influenza


E = Passive immunization
Administration of a pre-formed anti-body provides immediate protection but the effect of which is short lived as the body is not producing its own

Question: Which of the following is false regarding the accomodation reflex?
OptionA: When looking at near objects the lens is more circular.
OptionB: When looking at far objects the lens is more oval.
OptionC: When looking at near objects the zonules (suspensory ligaments) are slack and relaxed.
OptionD: When looking at far object the ciliary muscles are relaxed and small.
OptionE: When looking at near objects the zonules (suspensory ligaments) are taut/tight.
Explanation:
When looking at an object that is far away, the ciliary muscles are relaxed and small, this means that the zonules are taught and tight and this pulls the lens into an oval shape. 

When looking at an object that is near, the ciliary muscles are contracted and large, this means the zonules are slack and relaxed and the lens is pulled less. This leads to the lens being a circular shape.

Question:
Chromic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) is malignant disorder characterised by an accumulation of functionally incompetent CD5+ B cells. A common categorisation of CLLs are those which have mutated immunoglobulin heavy chain variable regions and those which do not.

 

What anatomical location and what physiological process is responsible for the increasing affinity of B cells BCR/antibody for their antigen during an immune reaction?
Explanation:
Somatic hypermutation of the IgV regions occurs in the germinal centre of a lymph node during an immune reaction. Somatic hypermutation of the IgV regions alters the affinity of an Ig for its antigen, B cells with mutations that increase affinity are helped by T helper cells and this promotes proliferation of this advantageous subpopulation. In contrast, B cells with low affinity mutations die by apoptosis.

 

Reason C is correct and the rest are wrong


A: The main site of affinity maturation is not the bone marrow and class switching does not increase the affinity of an antibody for its antigen (class switching alters the effector function of the antibody) E.G. IgM -> IgG

B: Germinal centre is the correct location, but class switching does not increase the affinity of an antibody for its antigen (class switching alters the effector function of the antibody)

C: Correct :)

D: Thymus is the incorrect location and is the primary location of T cell development to include positive and negative selection

E: The main site of affinity maturation is not the bone marrow, but the mechanism is correct

Question: A lady who is 16 weeks pregnant has come in to discuss the results of a recent quadruple test she had done to know the risk of her baby having certain anomalies. You see the results and see that AFP is substantially high, although all the other biomarkers that this test picks up are normal. What is her baby most likely to have?
Explanation: Increased AFP is a marker of spina bifida. The quadruple test would have biomarkers like AFP, beta hCG, uE3 and inhibin A

Question: James is a 20 year old English student who contracted a bout of flu and has now got a soaring temperature of 40 degrees celsius. His flatmate, Matthew, being the keen medical student that he is, explained to James that there are "endogenous pyrogens" that mediate fever by acting on the hypothalamus. Which substance is released as a result of these pyrogens?
Explanation: Endogenous pyrogens IL1B IL6 and TNF-A released during infection and travel to hypothalamus where they mediate PGE2 release that causes thermogenesis and heat conservation i.e. shivering

Question: You are on placement in the Mother and Child block in Year 4. On your second week there, you witness a birth of a child who has a small weight, length and head circumference, cleft lip and posterior ear rotation. On further examination the baby is found to have a septal defect. The registrar you are shadowing tells you this is an example of the effects of a certain teratogen. What it is?
Explanation:
Smoking in pregnancy gives lots of effects (which are similar to alcohol consumption in pregnancy):

  • Placental issues
  • Intrauterine Growth Retardation 
  • Increased risk of child mortality 
  • Congenital abnormalities (this does include cleft lip and cleft palate but also includes limb defects)
  • Increased risk of perinatal mortality 
  • Preterm Delivery 
  • Spontaneous abortion

Smoking also makes it harder to conceive 

 

This case is an example of Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (part of Fetal Alcohol Spectrum disorders):

  • failure of growth- stunted for life so no environmental influences can reverse the effects
  • Craniofacial abnormalities e.g. microcephaly, cleft lip and palate, ptosis, short palpebral fissures and posterior ear rotation
  • Cardiac abnormalities (most common is a septal defect) 
  • urogenital and musculoskeletal abnormalities
  • Neurodevelopmental abnormalities e.g. low IQ, memory problems, speech and language delay, hyperactive and attention deficit disorder
  • If alcohol consumption occurs in the second trimester there is an increased rate of spontaneous abortion

Lack of folate leads to neural tube defects such as Spina Bifida 

 

Excessive Vitamin A supplementation in pregnancy can increase the risk of birth defects (also too little vitamin A can increase the risk of blindness or intrauterine growth retardation

 

Consuming soft cheese can lead to Listeria infection which can cause miscarriage 

 

I don't know if this is too much detail for smoking and alcohol but i thought it was worth a mention :)
Tags: Teratology, case 8, Case 7, Child Development, Clinical Examples

Question: One day the Doctor was fighting some Daleks, but he was unfortunately "exterminated" by a sneaky Dalek. In his haste to regenerate, the Doctor forgot to grow a new spleen. His companion Martha, being a doctor herself, quickly reminded him that he now needs a particular vaccine to protect him from Earthly bugs. Which vaccine does the Doctor need now?
Explanation: Spleen filters out encapsulated bacteria that includes Neisseria, Haemophilus and Streptococcal - amongst others. Therefore asplenics need pneumococcal vaccine as they are deficient in a spleen.

Question: During puberty, what hormone causes ductal elongation and bifurcation in the breasts?
Explanation: at puberty, oestrogen stimulates ductal elongation and bifurcation. Progesterone stimulates the formation of spherical masses of granular cells at the end of each duct.

Question: You are on placement in the Mother and Child block for Unit 4. You witness a premature birth (37 weeks). Some hours later the baby starts to display worrying symptoms. The baby's fingers and lips turn blue and their breathing becomes rapid and shallow. You also notice they make a grunting sound when breathing. What is happening to this baby?
OptionA: It is going into Infant Respiratory Distress Syndrome
OptionB: The mother consumed excess alcohol in pregnancy and this is one of the effects
OptionC: They have a congenital defect in their respiratory control center in the brain
OptionD: It is going into Sudden Infant Death Syndrome
OptionE: The mother smoked in pregnancy and this is one of the effects
Explanation:
This is the classic presentation of Infant Respiratory Distress Syndrome:

This is where there isn't enough surfactant in the lungs so they cannot inflate properly. 

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (part of Fetal Alcohol Spectrum disorders) would give these effects
failure of growth- stunted for life so no environmental influences can reverse the effects
Craniofacial abnormalities e.g. microcephaly, cleft lip and palate, ptosis, short palpebral fissures and posterior ear rotation
Cardiac abnormalities (most common is a septal defect)
urogenital and musculoskeletal abnormalities
Neurodevelopmental abnormalities e.g. low IQ, memory problems, speech and language delay, hyperactive and attention deficit disorder
If alcohol consumption occurs in the second trimester there is an increased rate of spontaneous abortion

I made up option C

 

Sudden Infant Death syndrome is an unexplained condition where a baby will die (usually whilst sleeping) with no apparent cause.

There is an increased risk of this if the baby is born premature with a low birth weight with a mother who smoked in pregnancy.

 

Smoking in pregnancy gives lots of effects (which are similar to alcohol consumption in pregnancy):
Placental issues
Intrauterine Growth Retardation
Increased risk of child mortality
Congenital abnormalities (this does include cleft lip and cleft palate but also includes limb defects)
Increased risk of perinatal mortality
Preterm Delivery
Spontaneous abortion
Smoking also makes it harder to conceive

Question: What word best describes the ejection of milk from the breast?
Explanation:
the physiological basis of lactation is divided into four phases:

1. preparation of breasts - MAMMOGENESIS

2. synthesis and secretion from the breast alveoli - LACTOGENESIS

3. ejection of milk - GALACTOKINESIS

4. maintenance of lactation - GALACTOPOIESIS

Question: Which factors increase during lactogenesis II in the breast?
Explanation:
Lactose, casein and alpha-lactalbumin are produced during stage 1 lactogenesis. 

 

There is an increase in lactose, IgA and lactoferrin during lactogenesis II

Question: Mr A. Hussain brings his child in to see you. He complains of his child, James, doing a 'commando crawl', where the child uses only its arms to crawl around. You ask Mr A. Hussain about family history. Mr A. Hussain recalls that his mother says he also used to be a weird child and would shuffle around on his backside. Would you be concerned about Mr. A. Hussain's child's development?
OptionA: No, every child is a special snowflake and unique and James is no exception
OptionB: No, it is normal in Mr. Hussain's family for babies to develop and crawl abnormally.
OptionC: Yes, this type of commando crawling is abnormal.
OptionD: Yes, both backside shuffling and commando crawl are abnormal.
OptionE: Call the Heddlu immediately - this crawling is a sign of neglect
Explanation:
From case 9 developmental lecture - backside crawling is a normal variation for some kids. Some children skip crawling all together. Commando crawling however, according to the lecturer is abnormal

 

JJA
