Question: Which incompatible transfusion has the largest antibody response?
OptionA: When a patient of group A is given group B
OptionB: When a patient of group B is given group A
OptionC: When a patient of group O is given group B
OptionD: When a patient of group O is given group A
OptionE: when a patient of group O is given group AB
Explanation:
These are all examples of incompatible transfusions. 

 

I don't know if we need to know this but it came up in a lecture and I thought it was quite a good thing to be aware of :)

Question: When an incompatible blood transfusion takes place, what is the correct description of what happens?
Explanation:
So when a haemolytic transfusion reaction occurs Properidin binds complement C3 in donor blood. This is part of the ALTERNATIVE pathway in the complement system. 

This stimulates the donor cells to be coated with IgG. 

End result= removal of donor cells by macrophages

Question: What causes closure of the ductus arteriosus after birth?
OptionA:
Bradykinin: Increased

PGs: Increased

Partial pressure of O2 in lungs: Increased

NO2: Increased
OptionB:
Bradykinin: Increased
PGs: Decreased
Partial pressure of O2 in lungs: Increased
NO2: Decreased
OptionC:
Bradykinin: Decreased
PGs: Decreased
Partial pressure of O2 in lungs: Increased
NO2: Decreased
OptionD:
Bradykinin: Increased
PGs: Decreased
Partial pressure of O2 in lungs: Decreased
NO2: Decreased
OptionE:
Bradykinin: Increased
PGs: Decreased
Partial pressure of O2 in right atrium: Increased
NO2: Increased
Explanation:
From anatomy practical in case 8.

4 main factors causing closure of ductus arteriosus:

 

Increase bradykinin 

Decreased PGs due to removal of placenta

Increased partial pressure of O2 in the lungs as they expand

Decreased NO2

 

The decrease in PGs explains why a patent ductus arteriosus can be treated with NSAIDs. If you wanted to keep it open during surgery due to a heart defect you would give the patients PGs.

Question: A patient in hospital has recently received a blood transfusion. When you as a third year medic go to check up on him, you notice he is showing signs of a fever as well as having a low blood pressure. When you inquire about how he is feeling he tells you he is feeling very anxious as he has noticed that his urine has a reddish tinge to it. You are instantly worried that this patient may have received the wrong type of blood and he is undergoing a haemolytic transfusion reaction. What are the clinical signs you are now looking out for that would suggest the patient is progressing into the later stages of the reaction?
Explanation: Answer E is what happens in the later stages of Heamolyitic transfusion reaction :)

Question: A 36 year old woman has recently become pregnant however because of her age she has been assessed as being at high risk of having a child with a chromosomal abnormality. She undergoes the quadruple test and gets a positive result for Down's Syndrome. What will the markers show?
OptionA:
Normal Inhibin A, Beta hCG and uE3 

Increased AFP
OptionB:
Normal Inhibin A and AFP 

Decreased uE3 and Beta hCG
OptionC:
Increased Beta hCG 

Decreased uE3, Inhibin A nad AFP
OptionD:
Increased Beta hCG and Inhibin A 

Decreased AFP and uE3
OptionE:
Normal Beta hCG, Inhibin A and AFP 

Increased uE3
Explanation:
Answer A is what would be seen in a test for Spina Bifida 

Answer B is what would be seen in a test for Edwards Syndrome

Answer C is made up 

Answer D is what would be seen in a test for Down's Syndrome

Answer E is made up 

 

I couldn't find results for Patau's in my notes anyway so if anyone knows them please feel free to add to the comments :) Thank you :)
Tags: chromosomal abnormalities, chromosome abnormalities, Case 7, Screening, Clinical Examples

Question:
Maths (1/?):

 A patient requires an infusion of 1L of 2% glucose as part of a sliding scale. Unfortunately Brenda used all the 2% glucose stock so you've got to make your own from the stock that you have, which is a 10% solution of glucose.

i. How much of the 10% solution will you need to make a litre of 2% glucose solution?
ii. How much water will you also need to dilute the solution to the right concentration?
Explanation:
Ok. So I really should be doing the normal questions and not maths ones, but I'm not fantastic at dilutions.

we have 10% stock, and want 2%

 Amount required = (desired/got) xvol
 Volume of water is = desired - amount from stock

(2/10) x1000 = 200ml of stock required.
1000ml - 200ml of stock = 800ml water

Easy. Next time Brenda be a little more considerate -_-

Question:
Case 17 (3/8):

 Which medication might be best to help a type 2 diabetic suffering from a painful neuropathic ulcer?
Explanation:
From our NICE friends: Offer a choice of amitriptyline, duloxetine, gabapentin or pregabalin as initial treatment for neuropathic pain (except trigeminal neuralgia)

Note that trigeminal neuralgia is facial pain that is sharp and stabbing and usually has a trigger point, the treatment for that is always Carbamazepine. But thats just for clever dentists *_*

Metformin might improve someones HbA1c and stop them developing more neuropathy, but it doesn't usually get better.

Question:
A 14 year old girl comes into the GP with her mum as she is worried because all her friends have started their periods except her. She also complains that all her friends are bragging about wearing bras but she hasn't noticed any change in her boobs. Its making her feel very insecure and worried there is something wrong with her. 

On assessment you note that she is small and stocky with slight webbing at the back of her neck. 

What genetic condition do you suspect?
Explanation:
This is characteristic of Turner's syndrome. 

 

In Down's Syndrome you would see a broad nose, a flat face, abnormal ears as well as noting the development of learning disabilities.

 

William's Syndrome shows a wide mouth with widely set apart teeth, a small chin and a small nose. There is also heart and circulatory problems. 

 

In Klinefelter's syndrome it is usually a male presenting and there would be lack of development of secondary sexual characteristics, small undeveloped testes and low testosterone. Later in life they would be found to be infertile.

 

Cri-du-Chat Syndrome is usually recognised at birth with the distinctive cat like cry. Other symptoms would be widely set eyes, folds of skin over they eye, microcephaly, a low birth weight and learning and behavioural problems. 

 

Turner's would be diagnosed with a karyotype of her bloods and then treated with:

Growth Hormone, Androgens and Oestrogen.

Question:
Case 17 (4/8):

 Incretins are important for glucose metabolism. Where is GLP-1 secreted from in the gut?
Explanation:
Duodenum L Cells, in response to CHO in the gut! GLP-1 does 4 awesome things:

Decreases gastic emptying

Reduces appetite

Increases insulin production

Decreases glucagon production

 

GIP is similarly, an incretin, but this one is released by the K-cells of Duodenum and Jejunum.

DPP-4 breaks them down and stops them doing their awesome job. DPP-4 inhibitors (such as SAXAGLIPTIN, but all gliptins really, stop this from happening.)

Or we can make fake Incretins that trigger the receptor, such as EXANATIDE. Both of these have risks of hypoglycaemia.

 I have yet to make a list of all the cells of the gut, what they produce, and why they produce it, lets see if i have time!

Question:
A 14 year old girl comes into the GP with her mum as she is worried because all her friends have started their periods except her. She also complains that all her friends are bragging about wearing bras but she hasn't noticed any change in her boobs. Its making her feel very insecure and worried there is something wrong with her.
On assessment you note that she is small and stocky with slight webbing at the back of her neck.

From the examination you suspect that she has Turner's syndrome. What treatment are you going to give her?
OptionA:
Growth Hormone (to help her to reach normal height)

Low dose of androgens (to help with hair and muscle growth)

Oestrogen (to help with sexual development)
OptionB:
Growth Hormone (to help her reach normal height)

Low dose of androgens (to help with hair and muscle growth) 

FHS and LH (to help with sexual development)
OptionC:
Low dose of androgens (to help with hair and muscle growth) 

Oestrogens (to help with sexual development) 

Supportive treatment (to help with psychological issues)
OptionD:
Low dose of androgens (to help with hair and muscle growth)
FSH and LH (to help with sexual development)
Supportive treatment (to help with psychological issues)
Explanation:
Answer A is correct, the others are variations I made up. 

There would probably be some supportive treatment also as this diagnosis could have huge psychological impacts for her.

Question: What is the classic presentation of a DVT.
Explanation:
Dyspnoea is present in a pulmonary embolism not a DVT.

Leg rash isn't one of the classic symptoms but the leg may be red as well has having pain, tenderness and swelling. :)

Question: What is the classic presentation of a Pulmonary Embolism?
Explanation: The first is the correct presentation. All the rest are variations I made up :)

Question: You're on placement on Obs and Gyne when a pregnant woman is rushed in with suspected placenta previa. The registrar you are shadowing suspects it could be a complication of an abnormal implantation. Which site of abnormal implantation is most likely to result in placenta previa?
Explanation:
Pouch of Douglas is most likely to result in haemorrhage 

Ampullary region and uterine tube implantation may result in miscarriage 

Ovarian implantation may result in the woman needing a hysterectomy

Implantation in the Internal Os means that the placenta will lie across the opening of the uterus (placenta previa) This is an emergency and stops the woman being able to have a normal delivery.

Question: You are on placement in Obs and Gyne when a woman is rushed in with a massive haemorrhage. The registrar you are shadowing suspects this is due to an abnormal implantation. Which site of abnormal implantation is most likely to lead to a haemorrhage?
Explanation:
The Pouch of Douglas is correct. 

This happens when the syncytiotrophoblasts implant too far into the uterus and results in the embryo implanting in the Pouch of Douglas (the cavity behind the uterus)

The embryo can successfully implant however it can only be sustained here for a short amount of time before haemorrhage occurs.

 

Ampullary and Interstitial implantation may result in miscarriage 

 

Implantation in the ovary may result in the woman needing a hysterectomy

 

Implantation in the internal os may result in placenta previa

Question:
A patient presents to A&E and a nurse routinely checks their blood glucose levels using a random blood glucose test.

The patients result was 32.1mmol/L.

 

What state would best describe the blood glucose levels being experienced by this patient?
Explanation:
Blood glucose levels are defined as below:

below 2.5mmol/L = hypoglycaemic coma. 

below 4.0mmol/L = hypoglycaemia. 

4.0-8.0mmol/L = Physiological.

Above 8.0mmol/L = raised. 

Above 11.0mmol/L = Hyperglycaemia. 

Above 30.0mmol/L = hyperosmolar coma. 

 

Blood glucose levels are heavily regulated by the body (despite our food intake, fasting and exercise) and hence they rarely stray out of physiological range.

Question: Which glucose transporter enables non-insulin-mediated glucose uptake into the brain and the placenta?
Explanation:
GLUT-1 = allows basal non-insulin stimulated glucose uptake into cells. 

GLUT-2 = transports glucose into beta cells as well as hepatocytes and renal tubules. 

GLUT-3 = enables non-insulin-mediated glucose uptake into the brain and placenta. 

GLUT-4 = glucose channel by which glucose enters the adipose and muscle tissues following stimulation by the insulin receptor. 

 

The insulin receptor is a tyrosine kinase receptor which when insulin binds to it causes:
- effects on lipid metabolism. 

- effects on growth. 

- effects on protein metabolism. 

- migration of GLUT-4 transporters to the cell surface for increased transport of glucose into the cell.

Question:
Case 17 (5/8):

How is most glucose reabsorbed from the lumen in the kidney?
Explanation:
Proximal Proximal convoluted tubule, SGLT2 brings glucose in from the lumen, and the basement membrane has Glut 2 which takes it away to the blood. This process reabsorbs 90% of the glucose that is filtered.
In the distal part of the PCT, its SGLT1 and Glut 1 working as a similar team, but they only reabsorb 10% of the glucose.

SGLT2 blockers such as GLIFOZIN lead to less being absorbed and make you pee out lots of glucose. I didn't write down any SE/CI of these, but I'd guess they could cause hypo's and UTIs?

Question:
Case 17 (6/8):

Which feature suggests an arterial ulcer?
Explanation:
Venous ulcers have heavy exudate, often occur between medial malleoulus and lower calf, have irregular sloping margins and are most often shallow, they have a normal capillary refil time.

 

Arterial have very regular margins which are sharp and punched out. They have an EXTENDED CAP refil time, there is often a history of smoking or intermittent claudication. They are often distal over bony prominences. The surrounding skin is often pale with hair loss.

 

Neuropathic ulcers are often found at sites of pressure and callus formation is a good clue, along with a history of diabetes. Capillary refil time is normal. History includes history of sensory loss, burning or paraesthesia.

Question: You are shadowing a midwife who is running a clinic for expectant mothers. A woman who is 25 weeks pregnant comes in for a check up and the midwife notices some oedema. On examination there is swelling of the feet, ankles and hands, her BP is 140/90 and when asked how she is feeling, the patient tells you she has had some bad headaches lately and some on an off pain below her ribs. The midwife does a urinalysis and discovers proteins in the urine. What is the diagnosis?
Explanation:
The answer is Pre-eclampsia.

The classic triad for pre-eclampsia is hypertension, proteinuria and oedema presenting in the second or third trimester.

Other symptoms are swelling of the feet, ankles face and hands, vision problems, severe headache and pain just below the ribs. 

 

Gestation hypertension is defined as hypertension in pregnancy without the proteinuria or oedema present in Pre-eclampsia 

 

Eclampsia is a severe complication of Pre-eclampsia which can result in seizures due to ischemia and oedema in the brain.

 

HELLP stands for:
Haemolysis (breaking down of red blood cells) 

Elevated Liver enzymes 

Low Platelets 

This is a life threatening complication of Pre-eclampsia and may also present with:

Headache 

Nausea and vomiting 

Abdo and Shoulder Pain 

Bleeding and Oedema 

It is life threatening as it can result in liver rupture or stroke. 

 

For Pre-eclampsia, eclampsia and HELLP, treatment is delivery of the baby. 

If the baby is too premature then the woman may be put in hospital for monitoring or given medication to lower blood pressure.

Question:
Case 17 (7/8):

 A woman is confused in the park, she slurrs that she 'thinks she's forgotten to take her insulin' and empties her bag on a nearby bench. She seems really annoyed. She's just twisting the dial on her syringe to select a dose when she drops the pen. She collapses to the floor.

You check for danger, call for help, and begin with an ABCDE approach. Her airway is fine but she is unconscious. She's breathing and has a pulse. A bystander puts her in the recovery position while another calls 999. You look at the contents of the bag spilt on the bench and think one of them might be quite useful.

 There's a lot of stuff on the bench, which is the most appropriate to use at this moment?
Explanation:
She needs glucose. Treatment for Hypoglycaemia is oral glucose (if conscious, so it isn't safe to use the dextrose tablets at this time). Failing that you can give a bunch of glucagon to release any glycogen from stores in her body. Hopefully the ambulance can give her some IV when they arrive.

Adrenaline would be used for anaphylaxis, but the symptoms are very different. She'd be swelling up with big fat lips and fingers and wheezing.

Insulin will make things worse, but diabetics are often confused during a hypo. She was also angry and shaky which was another glue. If she happened to be type 2 and in HHS pumping more glucose in wouldn't do much harm, but if you gave insulin to someone with a hypo you'll make things MUCH worse - so yea, don't do that.

hydrocortisone is useful in emergencies for patients with adrenal insufficiency such as in addisons disease. Man, this woman must have a horrible medical history to be carrying all this stuff!

Question:
Miss Sugar, a 23 year old female, presents to GP clinic complaining of frequent urination and trush infection. 

After a random blood glucose is performed you note her levels to be 12.3mmol/L and hence diagnose her with diabetes. 

After taking a urine dipstick you note no ketosis, her BMI is 23.

A few weeks later after having an autoantibody test (islet cell) you review her results and they are negative. 

 

Which of the following would be the most appropriate diagnosis to give to Miss Sugar regarding her diabetes?
Explanation:
Diabetes can be classified into many different types as follows:

 

Primary diabetes: chronically high blood sugar levels are caused by metabolic disease directly impacting upon insulin production and function. Types include:

  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus: immune mediated diabetes causing beta cell destruction and usually leading to severe or absolute insulin deficiency. This typically presents with weight loss, ketosis, in younger patients and with a low BMI. 
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus: Diabetes which results from a combination of insulin resistance and severe insulin deficiency. This typically presents with weight gain, non ketosis, BMI of over 25 and in people aged over 30. 
  • Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults: same as DMT1 but manifests later in life and is often commonly confused with type 2. 
  • Gestational diabetes: diabetes similar to DMT2 which is gained during pregnancy and resolves soon after birth. 
  • Maturity onset diabetes of the young: genetic defect in B cell function which is autosomal dominant form of DMT2. Generally occurs before age 25 and patients present with a normal BMI, no ketosis and no B cell autoimmunity. 
  • Maternally inherited diabetes and deafness: mutation in tRNA gene in mitochrondrial DNA where diabetes occurs before age 40 with variable deafness, neuromuscular and cardiac problems as well as pigmented retinopathy. 
  • Neonatal diabetes: IUGR with symptomatic hyperglycaemia which onsets before 6 months with ketoacidosis and a lack of insulin (permanent). If it presents before 1 month but resolves after 18 months it is a transient form but they have a risk at 50% of developing DMT2 in adulthood. 
  • Wolfram syndrome: Recessively inherited mutation in the transmembrane genes WFS1 which causes insulin-requiring diabetes, optic atrophy, diabetes insipidus and sensorineural deafness. this can lead to multiple neurological problems and few live beyond middle age. 

Secondary diabetes: chronically higher blood sugar levels which occur as a consequence of another medical condition.

Question:
Case 17 (8/8):

 Which patient is most at risk of having a hypoglycaemic attack?
OptionA: Type 1 diabetic young female who isn't using her insulin because she wants to lose weight
OptionB: Type 1 diabetic who is fasting pre-op, taking medications as normal
OptionC: Prisoner with no medical history 5 weeks into a hunger strike
OptionD: Type 2 diabetic who has accidentally taken twice as much metformin this morning
OptionE: Type 1 diabetic patient who has decreased their insulin dose to account for exercise today, but stopped halfway around the track for a sprained ankle
Explanation:
A: This patient is at risk of DKA and hyperglycaemia

B: DING! Dangerous situation. They're taking insulin but have no sugars to account for it. BADBADBAD

C: You can go a long time on hunger strike and maintain a glucose of 3.5mmol/l, until about 6 weeks, which is technically hypo, but it's not the SBA

D: Metformin shouldn't cause hypoglycaemia, most of the other T2DM drugs do though.

E: Exercise increases sensitvitiy to insulin, so a reduced dose without any exercise will probably result in HYPERglycaemia, not hypo

Question:
A patient presents to your endocrinology outpatients clinic at the hospital. He is 55 years old and has suspected type 2 diabetes mellitus.

He was referred by his GP for some tests to confirm his diagnosis, which of the following test results would be most likely be indicative of type 2 diabetes mellitus?
Explanation:
For type 1 diabetes mellitus you would find:

  • Younger in age (usually under 30 with peak age of diagnosis being 12).
  • Caucasians (northern European) are the highest risk group.
  • Lean with BMI under 25 (often present with weight loss).
  • Symptoms have has recent onset with a few weeks history of symptoms. 
  • Ketosis prone. 
  • C-peptide disappears (connects insulin chains together) due to insulin absence. 
  • HLA II gene positive in some cases.

For type 2 diabetes you would find:

  • Usually present over age 30. 
  • Higher risk ethnicity is Asian, African, Polynesian and native American. 
  • Usually overweight or obese (BMI over 25) with a history of recent weight gain. 
  • Symptoms usually have chronic onset over many years.
  • 50% are asymptomatic and are often diagnosed on routine testing. 
  • C-peptide persists as the person is insulin resistant.
  • Pancreatic development genes, obesity genes and insulin genes are usually found to be dysfunctional.

Question:
Case 8 (2/8):
 
 What is the correct notation for the following woman:

If a woman is currently pregnant, previously had 3 terminations and 3 live births
Explanation:
From patient.info:

 

In the UK, gravidity is defined as the number of times that a woman has been pregnant and parity is defined as the number of times that she has given birth to a fetus with a gestational age of 24 weeks or more, regardless of whether the child was born alive or was stillborn.

For example, a woman who is described as 'gravida 2, para 2 (sometimes abbreviated to G2 P2) has had two pregnancies and two deliveries after 24 weeks, and a woman who is described as 'gravida 2, para 0' (G2 P0) has had two pregnancies, neither of which survived to a gestational age of 24 weeks. If they are both currently pregnant again, these women would have the obstetric résumé of G3 P2 and G3 P0 respectively. Sometimes a suffix is added to indicate the number of miscarriages or terminations a woman has had. So if the second woman had had two miscarriages, it could be annotated G3 P0+2.

 

Also helpful from patient.info:

A nulliparous woman (nullip) has not given birth previously (regardless of outcome).
A primagravida is in her first pregnancy.
A primiparous woman has given birth once. The term 'primip' is often used interchangeably with primagravida, although technically incorrect, as a woman does not become primiparous until she has delivered her baby.
A multigravida has been pregnant more than once.
A multiparous woman (multip) has given birth more than once.
A grand multipara is a woman who has already delivered five or more infants who have achieved a gestational age of 24 weeks or more, and such women are traditionally considered to be at higher risk than the average in subsequent pregnancies.
A grand multigravida has been pregnant five times or more.
A great grand multipara has delivered seven or more infants beyond 24 weeks of gestation.

Question:
A 44 year old male presents to your GP surgery complaining of excessive urination and thirst, he has also found his feet are tingling a lot recently and has a BMI of 32. 

You suspect he has diabetes, which of the following correctly describes the WHO guidlines for diabetes diagnosis in this patients case?
Explanation:
The WHO diagnosis criteria for diabetes states to diagnose the condition you must firstly:

- test on two occasions if the individual is asymptomatic. 

- test on one occasions if the individual is symptomatic. 

The following tests can be performed to confirm:

- Fasting plasma glucose of greater than 7.0mmol/L. 

- Random plasma glucose over 11.1mmol/L. 

- HbA1C over 6.5%.

 

HbA1C: haemoglobin A1C is an integrated measure of an individuals blood glucose concentration over 12 weeks (because this is the life cycle of an erythrocyte). The uncontrolled amount of glucose in the blood will cause reactions (as they are chemically reactive) and haemoglobin glycation is uncontrolled and results in oxidative damage and impaired macromolecule function. Levels of glycalated haemoglobin are a standard measure of protein glycation and hence how much excess sugar/glucose in the blood.

Question:
Case 8 (5/8):

Which describes the production of breast milk from 4th month of pregnancy (secretion inhibited by progesterone/oesterogen high levels)
Explanation:
As far as I understand:
Mammogenesis is Oest/Progest job in early pregnancy to cause development of breasts ready for milk production, nipples get darker, seb. glands start keeping nipples healthy
Lactogenesis I is production of colostrum, for some reason mum is ready to deliver from 4/9, but its inhibited. Brought about by PRL. Inhib secretion by oest/progest
Lactogenesis II turns on 30-40/hrs after birth increasing milk volume, increase lactose, igA, lactoferrin and high oligosaccharide levels. It's also a switch from endocrine control to autocrine
Galactokinesis is ejection, oxytocin leads to contraction of myoepithelial cells to squeeze milk elt
Galactopoeisis is continued production of milk if the breasts are being drained. If you don't use it you'll lose it, and its controlled by PRL

I've no doubt someone will correct me if i have misunderstood.

Question: Pulmonary wedge pressure gives you an estimate of the pressure in the...

Case 8 (6/8):

 A pregnant patient develops a DVT and needs anticoagulation, what is your weapon of choice and how do you monitor the effect?
Explanation:
Well D and E are antiplatelet, not anticoagulant, lets remind ourselves how they work, but put them aside for post MI patients for their 12 month dual antiplatelet secondary prevention.
Aspirin:Non-selective, irreversible inhibitor of cyclo-oxygenase which catalyses the production of thromboxane and prostaglandins. Reduces thomboxane A2
Clopidogrel: Clopidogrel works by preventing a natural substance called adenosine diphosphate (ADP) from binding to its receptors on platelets.
Remember thomboxane A2 and ADP are both releleased from activated platelets to promote more adhesion.
I don't know how you monitor their effectiveness. I don't think you do.

A: Not warfarin, teratogenic
B: Heparin, you probably *could* use this, but its a nightmare as its IV and you have to monitor it super carefully, like, EVERY DAY. Not helpful for us.

C: LMWH options are displayed! Hurrah! thats what we need. Easy to use as a s/c injection.

NOTE, if a non-pregnant person had a DVT/PE they may need to start anticoag therapy with warfarin or one of the NOACs. If they go on warfarin they'll need to do their LWMH until they're in range because it takes a while to build up (at least 3 days usually).

Question:
A 22 year old diabetic presents to A&E with the a pulse of 105bpm, GCS below 12 due to confusion and hyperventilation.

You suspect diabetic ketoacidosis and perform some blood tests. Which of the following would be present with DKA?
Explanation:
Diabetic Ketoacidosis is a metabolic emergency where hyperglycaemia is associated with metabolic acidosis due to high levels of ketones in the body, known as ketosis. This is a hallmark complication of DMT1. 

It is often found when:

  • DMT1 is previously diagnosed and hence is the first presentation. 
  • DMT1 is poorly controlled. 
  • there has been an interruption of insulin therapy. 
  • Stress of infections has caused increased cortisol levels which raise insulin resistance. 
  • Heart attack. 

DKA is an uncontrolled state of ketone body production due to complete insulin efficiency (small amounts of insulin are enough to complete halt ketone body production).

Ketogenesis occurs when insulin is absent and causes hepatic glucose production from glycogen to be accelerated and peripheral uptake of glucose to be decreased. This causes rising blood glucose levels and loss of fluids/electrolytes which leads to dehydration. 

Rapid lipolysis occurs in the body to generate free fatty acids which are converted to acetyl CoA in the liver cells which is then converted to ketone bodies in the mitochondria. The ketones are primary produced as an energy source for the brain as they care the only fuel source which can cross the blood brain barrier. 

An increased level of ketones in the body causes metabolic acidosis and ketonuria (as the excessive ketones are excreted in the urine), you may also find the breath smells like ketones also. 

Respiratory compensation for this acidosis occurs leading to hyperventilation, this occurs because if acidosis causes the pH to fall to low then enzymes will be denatured and this can be fatal. 

Dehydration in DKA is caused by hypoglycaemia (leading to osmotic diuresis) and hyperketonaemia (resulting in acidosis and vomiting). 

 

To treat DKA you:

  • replace lost fluids (0.9% saline at 6 litres). 
  • replace lost potassium. 
  • restore acid base balance by giving bicarbonate. 
  • replace insulin deficit by giving IV insulin. 
  • Monitor blood glucose closely.
  • seek and treat underlying cause (could be an infection).

Resolution occurs when pH exceeds 7.3 and ketones are below 0.6mmol/L.

Question:
Case 8 (7/8):
 
 My Mum loves to give blood! She's O-ve and she loves how they stick the special neonatal sticker on her blood because it'll obviously be compatible with any of the little blighters.

 If you can, you should give blood today, which one of the following people CAN give blood?
OptionA: Someone who has had a tattoo 3 months ago
OptionB: A student back from their gap yah 3 months ago from india where they totally found themselves
OptionC: A lady who gave birth 5 months ago
Explanation:
This question is obviously easy. Sorry for wasting your time. It's getting late.

 Give blood if you can, you might need it some day.

Question:
Case 8 (8/8):

In the foetal circulation, what kind of blood circulates in the abdominal aorta?
Explanation:
Ok, so I do think this one is super hard.

 

Blood to the placenta has 80% oxygenation apparently, returning fetal blood (umb. v. remember!) has about 58% oxygenation. This will either go to fetal liver or bypass it and enter the right ventricle. By the time it enters the aorta, and then the abdominal aorta, it is completely mixed with deoxygenated blood making it <58%.

 It'll be completely deoxygenated by the time it has been through the circulation.
 
 This is not one of the fetal shunts I am familiar with.

 

 Sorry if this was a crap one. Losing the will. CM.

Question:
A 14 year old female presents to you unconscious with her mother. 

She was performing in a football game at her school when she began sweating and appeared confused when she came off at half time.

You understand from her mother that she is a type 1 diabetic, but has struggled coming to terms with her recent diagnosis and doesnt seem to be taking well to her insulin injections. 

Which of the following would be the first step in treatment for this patient?
OptionA: Consumption of 15-20grams of glucose via fruit juice.
OptionB: Consumption of 15-20grams of glucose via fruit juice + consumption of a slice of dry white toast.
OptionC: Consumption of a slice of dry white toast.
Explanation:
As the patient is unconscious A cannot be performed, B + C can also not be done when a patient is unconscious. D is correct.

Treatment for hypoglycaemia is as follows:

Conscious patient: 

  1. consumption of 15-20grams of glucose or simple carbohydrates such as fruit juice, glucose tablets, glucose gel or sweets. 
  2. recheck blood glucose after 15 minutes and repeat if necessary. 
  3. Once blood glucose has returned to normal eat a small snack of a complex carbohydrate such as dry white toast. 

Unconscious patient:

  1. give IV glucose alongside glycagon injection (to release glucose from the livers glycogen stores).
  2. check blood glucose levels after 10 minutes and if necessary give more IV glucose.

Question:
A 46 year old recently diagnosed type 2 diabetic male presents to A&E very disorientated with excessive urination and intense nausea. 

The patients tests results show:

- Random plasma glucose: high at 40mmol/L.

- FBC: normal ranges for ketones and pH is 7.36. 

You are aware that the patient is in a hyperosmolar hyperglycaemic state (HHS) and is at very high risk of entering a hyperosmolar coma. 

The patient is treated via fluid replacement and IV insulin. Which of the following is not likely to be a cause of the acute condition the patient has presented with?
Explanation: The patient is unlikely to be on insulin therapy if he has DMT2 and is recently diagnosed.

Question:
You are shadowing a midwife who is checking up on Helen, a 26 year old who is pregnant with her first child. You have a feel of her abdomen for the fundus of the uterus before measuring it properly from the pubic symphysis afterwards. You note to the midwife before measurement that the fundus feels as if it is just at/around the level of the umbilicus.

 

From this information, how many weeks is Helen most likely to be?

 

Also here is a nice picture of fundal height measurement just to liven things up a little bit (obviously not accurate representation of growth of Helen's baby)
Explanation:
Some key fundal heights to remember;

 

12 weeks >> fundus is just above the pubic symphysis

20-22 weeks >> umbilicus region

38 weeks >> xiphoid process of sternum

40 weeks >> regression below height at 38 weeks due to descent of the foetus in to the pelvis

 

 

Therefore Helen is most likely to be 20/40 weeks and so D is correct!

 

I hope this is helpful, it was covered in the case 8 anatomy practical & in the case 7-9 revision session some of the 3rd years said it came up in their S3/it was a good thing to know!
Tags: Development, Anatomy, Foetal Development, Obstetrics, case 8

Question:
Jane's son, Mateo, was born with a congenital heart defect. Her father, Rogelio, recently found out that his ex-girlfriend and almost wife is now 7 months pregnant. Rogelio is frantic with worry that his baby will have the same heart abnormality as his Matelio as he remembers that it is the most common congenital heart defect. He begs Jane to tell him the name of the condition so he can tweet it to his 6.3 million followers on Twitter so they can pray for his future child (#PequeñoRogelio).

 

What is the name of this cardiovascular abnormality?
Explanation:
Answer: D - Ventricular septal defect

 

Congenital heart abnormalities (from most common to least):

  1. Ventricular septal defect - 12/10,000
  2. Tetralogy of Fallot - 9.6/10,000
  3. Patent ductus arteriosus - 1/2,000
  4. Transposition of the great vessels (4.8/10,000)
  5. Valvular stenosis (3-4/10,000)

From Professor Wilson's lecture "Cardiovascular system development" in Case 8
Tags: Foetal Anomalies, Foetal Development, case 8, Cardiovascular system

Question:
A 27 year old male patient has been involved in a road traffic accident and is brought into hospital with suspected spinal cord injury. 

 

24 hours after the injury was sustained, long enough for spinal shock to subside, you are a neurologist and you check the motor function of the patient to try and find the level of the spinal injury.

 

The patient can flex the arm at the elbow against your full force.

The patient can extend the arm at the elbow against some force, but not your full force. 

The patient can extend the knee against gravity but not against any force applied by you. 

The patient cannot plantar flex the against gravity.

 

Which of the following is most likely?
Explanation:
Plantar flexion is controlled by S1/2. Inability to plantar flex  = 0/5

Extension of knee is controlled by L3/4. Ability to extend but only against gravity = 3/5

Extension of the arm at the elbow is controlled by C7(/8). Ability to extend against some resistance but not all = 4/5

Flexion of the arm at the elbow is controlled by C5/6. Ability to flex against total resistance = 5/5 

 

Level of injury is defined as there levels there is a motor power score of ≥3/5 (movement against gravity), in this case this would be spinal level L3/4.

Question: Which of the following mediators is responsible for regulating the peristaltic reflex?
Explanation:
Enkephalins are also responsible for Na+ and Cl- absorption.

Serotonin from EC cells is responsible for Cl- secretion and activating local motor reflexes

Somatostatin from D cells is responsible for Na+ and Cl- absorption.

Neurotensin is released from N cells in the ileum in response to fat (as fat should be absorbed by this stage) to decrease motility.

Enteroglucan is released from L cells in the ileum to act the same as neurotensin.

Motilin is released from M cells in the duodenum to stimulate gastric emptying and is responsible for the Migrating Motility Complex (MMC) in fasting.

 

Other mediators:

VIP - stimulates Cl- secretion and relaxation of smooth muscle. 

Mast cells - stimulate Cl- secretion.

 

Source: one of Jeff's many joyful lectures

Question:
An 18-year-old medical student decides he is going to get buff, so starts consuming protein shakes. Whilst drinking a shake after a massive session of squats in the gym, he contemplates the process of digestion. He recalls that one of the enzymes involved in protein digestion (a proteolytic enzyme) in the stomach is pepsin and it's inactive precursor (zymogen) is pepsinogen. But he can't remember which cells in the stomach secrete pepsinogen. He asks a fellow medical student who knows everything as she uses PeerWise everyday.

Which cells does she tell him are responsible?
Explanation:
Chief cells (found in the body of the stomach) are responsible for secretion of pepsinogen, which is converted into the active proteolytic enzyme pepsin.

Consumption of protein stimulates the production of gastrin, secreted by G cells. Gastrin then stimulates the secretion of both intrinsic factor and hydrochloric acid from parietal cells. The hydrochloric acid catalyses the conversion of pesinogen to pepsin. The acidic environment created and pepsin are both important for the hydrolysis of proteins. Intrinsic factor is responsible for assisting absorption of vitamin B12 found in proteinaceous foods such as meat, fish and eggs. D cells (found in the antrum of the stomach) are stimulated by Gastrin and secrete somatostatin, a hormone which inhibits Gastrin excretion from G cells and hydrochloric acid from parietal cells (a negative feedback mechanism presenting the stomach becoming too acidic).

Leydig cells are testosterone producing cells found in the testicles. They are important for getting buff but have little direct influence on digestion.

Random mnemonic: I remember that chief cells secrete pepsinogen and are found in the body of the stomach by picturing the image of a native American chief drinking pepsi, which goes into his body.

Pepsi is the ancient Greek word for digestion.

Apparently the drink "Pepsi" is so named as it was initially marketed as a digestive aid (although the sources for this are dubious), other dubious sources claim that Pepsi is called Pepsi because Pepsin is involved or was involved in it's production (again, this is from dodgy internet sources, not necessarily true). The rest of the information in this question is true though! Sources include: " Marieb, Human anatomy and Physiology, 6th edition" and "Faller, The human body: an introduction to structure and function, 13th edition".
Tags: GI Physiology, Gastroenterology, Gastrointestinal System, Gastrointestinal tract, Case 3

Question: Which of the following is inherited autosomal recessive?
Explanation:
FAP - autosomal dominant, mutation in APC gene on chromosome 5p. Fully functional APC gene would prevent beta-catenin from transcription, so this is affected. Characterised by thousands of polyps.

MAP is autosomal recessive, mutation in MUTYH gene involved in base excision repair.

Lynch syndrome - autosomal dominant, germline mutations in mismatch repair genes (MLH-1 and MSH-2), characterised by aggresslive polyps and micro satellite instability.

Juvenile polyposis - autosomal dominant, SMAD4 and PTEN mutations

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome - autosomal dominant, STK11 mutations, characterised by melanin pigmentation of lips, mouth, digits.

Question:
Case 8 (9/9):

 Which one of the following would be important to warning the expectant mother about when discussing neuraxial pain relief.
OptionA: Increased risk of C-section due to reduced sensation
OptionD: Reduced APGAR score for baby (baby may be sedated)
Explanation: Most importantly, there isn't an increased risk of C-section according to the lecture. There is an increased risk of instrumentation and prolonged second stage. There isn't a reduced APGAR score as there is minimal fetal transfer (APGAR decrease assoc with IM pethedine instead).

Question:
A patient presents to A&E after having sudden onset back pain whilst doing his supermarket shop. He was bending over to pick up his 2 year daughter who was having a tantrum on the floor when he "felt something go". You suspect the patient has had a disc herniation. 

 

You carry out a neurological examination and note that the patient has:

  • Reduced but not absent sensation in the medial part of the lower leg
  • Can dorsiflex his ankle against gravity but not against any resistance. 

Which of the following is most likely to be the correct description of the patients spinal problem?
OptionA:
Sensation: 0

Muscles power: 3

Spinal nerve affected: L3

Disc herniation at level: L3/4
OptionB:
Sensation: 1
Muscles power: 3
Spinal nerve affected: L4
Disc herniation at level: L3/4
OptionC:
Sensation: 1
Muscles power: 2
Spinal nerve affected: L4
Disc herniation at level: L3/4
OptionD:
Sensation: 1
Muscles power: 3
Spinal root affected: L3
Disc herniation at level: L3/4
OptionE:
Sensation: 1
Muscles power: 3
Spinal root affected: L4
Disc herniation at level: L4/5
Explanation:
How to score sensation:

0 = no sensation at all

1 = sensation present but impaired

2 = normal sensation 

 

How to score power:


0 = total paralysis

1 = palpable/visible contraction that brings about no movement

2 = full range of movement when gravity is eliminated

3 = full range of movement against gravity

4 = full range of movement against some resistance, but not total resistance

5 = full range of movement against total resistance

 

How to determine spinal nerve affected:

 

Look at the dermatomes and myotomes.. 

 

C2 - neck flexion

C3 - lateral neck flexion

C4 - shoulder elevation 

C5 - shoulder abduction 

C6 - elbow and wrist flexion

C7 - elbow and wrist extension

C8 - thumb extenstion

T1 - finger abduction 

L2 - Hip flexion

L3 - knee extension

L4 - ankle dorsiflexion

L5 - toe extension

S1 - hip exension

S2 - knee flexion

 

How to know which IV disc is affected:

 

 

95% of the time disc herniations press on the spinal nerve traversing the disc space NOT the spinal nerve that is exiting from that disc space. 

 

Now back to the case...

 

  • Patient has reduced but not absent sensation - 1/2
  • Patient can move his ankle against gravity but not any form of resistance - 3/5 
  • The L4 dermatomal region has reduced sensation and the L4 myotomal region has reduced motor power therefore the L4 spinal nerve must be affected.
  • 95% of the time the nerve affected is the nerve traversing the disc space, L4 would traverse the L3/4 disc space. 
  • 5% of disc herniations will move laterally and effect the spinal nerve exiting the disc space so answer E is technically also correct but the SBA would be B because it is more common.

Question:
A type-1 diabetic student forgets to eat anything after being too stressed and studying in the library for 6 hours. He is having palpitations, and has started sweating and having palpitations.

 

After eating a packet of sweets and a slice of toast, he ponders what caused his symptoms in his hypoglycaemic state?
Explanation:
autonomic symptoms result from activation of parts of the autonomic nervous system, while neuroglycopenic symptoms are caused by the direct effect of glucose deprivation on the brain.

 

Neuroglycopenic symptoms:

- confusion

- drowsiness

- odd behaviour

- speech difficulty

- incoordination

 

general malaise:

- headache

- nausea

Question:
A pregnant woman has her blood taken

results show

Increased inhibin A

Decreased Ue3

Decreased PAPP-A 

Increased HCG

Decreased AFP

what is the most likely diagnosis for the foetus
Explanation:
In downs syndrome HcG and Inhibin A are high

the rest are low

In Edward's syndrome or trisomy 18 they are all low

In Pataus syndrome there is only a raised AFP

philadelphia translocation between chromosomes 9 and 12 and causes chronic myelogenous leukemia.

Question: A foetus is thought to have spina bifida. What component of the blood test is most likely to be abnormal?
Explanation: AFP is high in neural tube problems and low in downs

Question:
A 52-year old presents to A and E with severe dehydration. A blood sample is taken and the results are as below:

 

Random Glucose 35mmol/l (< 11.1 mmol/L)

Ketones 2mmol/L (< 0.6 mmol/L)

pH 7.4 (7.35-7.45)

 

It is all noted that the patient is hypovolaemic.

 

What is the likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
A diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis would show a pH less than 7.3 and a value of ketones higher than 3 mmol/L. This is most common in T1DM.

 

The patient is in a hyperosmolar hyperglycaemic state. The diagnosis of HHS includes hypovolaemia, marked hyperglycaemia (30mmol/L or more) without significant hyperketonaemia (< 3mmol/l) and without acidosis (pH>7.3). this is more common in T2DM patients.

 

HHS is a complication of diabetes in which high blood sugars cause severe dehydration, increases in osmolarity and a high risk of complications, coma and death.

Question: Which area of the heart tube gives rise to the trabeculated parts of ventricles?
Explanation:
Truncus arteriosus - proximal aorta and pulmonary artery

Bulbus cordis - smooth parts of ventricles

Primitive ventricle - trabeculated parts of ventricles

Primitive atrium - atria 😲

Sinus venosus - coronary arteries, SAN

 

just remember bulbus cordis = smooth

primitive ventricle = trabeculated

Question: Which of the following is NOT a red flag symptom for back pain?
OptionD: New onset pain in an 56 year old
Explanation:
RED FLAGS are:

  • New onset pain in someone <15yr or >50yrs
  • History of malignancy
  • Unintentional weightless
  • Recent serious illness/infection
  • Drug/alcohol abuse
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Osteoporosis and Paget's
  • Thoracic spinal pain
  • Widespread neurological deficit
  • History of prolonged steroid use
  • History of significant spinal trauma/injury 
  • Spinal deformity 
  • Non-mechanical pain 
  • End stage renal disease

A little baby is born. However, it is cyanosed, squatting, shaking and keeps losing consciousness. On echocardiogram it is found to have right ventricular hypertrophy, and overriding aorta, pulmonary infundibular stenosis and a ventricular septal defect. 

What chromosomal abnormality is this little baby likely to have?

Question:
A 55 year old patient present to his GP with new onset lower back pain that is not relieved by rest and is worse at night. He says he's worried because the pain just won't go away and he's also noticed some dark red blood in his stools recently. The patient is a current smoker and has a BMI of 28 although this has come down from 30 in the past month despite an unchanged diet/exercise regime. 

 

The GP is worried about this patient and sends him off for blood tests as well as an lumbar XR.

 

The XR shows:

 

The patients blood results come back and the patient has raised levels of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA). 

 

What is your differential for this patient?
Explanation:
This patient has colonic cancer with metastatic spread to the lumbar vertebrae causing fracture of the pedicle. 

 

The patient has many red flag symptoms including:

  • New onset pain when he is over 50yrs
  • Non-mechanical pain (not relieved by rest)
  • Melena
  • Rapid, unintentional weight loss 
  • Smoking is bad (who knew)

The pain is also worse at night with is true in tumours because there is venous engorgement.

 

The XR shows a winking owl sign which indicates a fracture of the pedicle which would be secondary to a bony met. This fracture may be the cause of the pain. 

 

The blood test shows raised CEA, the tumour marker for bowel cancer. 

 

Other tumour markers include:

  • CA153 - breast cancer
  • CA125- ovarian
  • AFP/hCG - testicular

Lung cancer would have caused thoracic mets not lumbar mets and haemoptosis not melena. 

 

Bladder cancer would have caused haematuria not melena.

On a normal aXR there should be no gas present in the abdominal cavity.

Question: Why do live attenuated vaccines generate a better CD8 response than inactivated?
OptionA: Antigens are more easily presented from live virus
OptionB: They are more similar to the wild type virus
OptionC: Only live virus have the capacity to replicate intracellularly (in the cytosol) and be presented by MHC 1
OptionE: CD8 cells are more attracted to virally infected cells
Explanation:
Comventional Dendritic cells process antigens in a variety of ways

 

Remember MHC 1 presents to CD8 and MHC 11 presents to CD4

 

Macropinocytosis of viral parts generates an MHC 11 response.  This is what would happen with an inactivated vaccine

Viral Infection of cells leads to intracellular replication of the virus and an MHC 1 response. This is what happens with a live vaccine

 

Sometimes cross penetration occurs where the viral antigens in an inactivated vaccine enter the cytosol from the vesicle and can be presented by MHC 1 to recruit CD8 but this is poorly understood and dosen't always happen
Tags: T cells, Vaccinations, case 9, cell biology, immunology

Question: Where is vitamin C absorbed?
Explanation: vitamin C is absorbed in ileum while bile salts and B12 are absorbed in terminal ileum

Question:
Case 11 (1/8):

 A middle-age male patient attends the GP with the following:

Tired
++ Diarrhea
++Flatulence
Mouth ulcers
Tingling hands and feet

Special investigations:
Stool ++fat
Anaemia Hb 102
MCV 66 (microcytic)
Ferritin low

 

Total immunoglobulin A 2.8 (NORMAL)
IgA tissue transglutaminase tTG 90 (+ve test)

Endoscopy - Inflam and scalloped and red lumen

Biopsy taken - lymphocytosis, blunt villi which are irregular and loss of folds in ileum

What is the diagnosis?
Explanation:
So this is just to easy right? Lets look at some important points.

 Most of his symptoms are due to various deficiencies caused by his coeliac. Anaemic (iron deficiency) tingling (b12), diarrhea (all these solutes aren't being abs. and this is dragging water), flatulence (CHO not being absorbed and the bacteria are loving it).

The immunoglobulin assay is normal (if it was reduced, you couldn't use the second test as it may be a spurious result)
The tTG is +ve, indicated coeliac, but a biopsy is gold standard and he has had that as well.

 

I'm fairly certain this came up on the progress test but wasn't so nice, or it was at least similar.

 

Why isn't it crohns because that can occur anywhere?
Biopsy might have mentioned transmural inflammation

Endoscopy might have mentioned it being patchy or cobblestoned

The immunoglobulin results would probably not have been the same.

Question:
Case 11 (2/8):

 Which of the following is the correct action of I-cells (thats an i, not an L/l)

(All of the answers below -as far as I know- are correct answers for different types of cells, so once you've found the I-cell you could try to name the rest).
OptionA: Produce CCK in presence of Fat/CHO to reduce hunger, and stim pancreatic enzymes and gall bladder to release bile
OptionB: Produce Secretin in response to a lowered pH of the duodenum to delay gastric emptying and increase pancreactic buffer (HCO3-) secretion
OptionC: Secrete GLP-1 in presence of glucose to increase Insulin release from the pancreas, suppress appetite, delay gastic emptying and reduce glucagon release from pancreas
OptionD: Produce pepsinogen in the stomach to break down proteins
OptionE: Produce G.I.P to increase insulin in the presence of fat
Explanation:
A - I cells -> CCK
B. S-cell -> Secretin -> more alkaline
C. L-cells -> GLP-1
D. Chief-cells of stomach
E. K-cell -> G.I.P

Question:
Case 11 (7/8):

 Which of the following is more indicative of ulceractive colitis, as oppose to crohns disease.
OptionA: Symptoms of a B12 deficiency (tingling of hands and feet and a big beefy tongue)
OptionD: Patient describes faeces as watery with yellowy-white silme
Explanation:
Most questions will probably be the other way around so this was a bit of a challenge.

 Mucuous/blood/pus in diarrhead is UC.
Other Key features of UC that I can think of:
Colon/rectum only (almost always rectum) and contiuous

p. gangrenosum (look like nasty granulating strawberries)
less genetic

smoking PROTECTS

<20 appendectomy protects

mesalazine tx (accoridng to lecture, but nice says useful for Crohn's too)

ulcers/bleeding on scope


Crohns has lots more distinguishing features

patchy transmural inflammation

erythema nodosum skin lesions (look like bruises to me)

rectal sparing

fistula (anal issue, gas in urine pneumaturia)

effects small intestine (esp. terminal ilium and caecum common, terminal ilium is where you absorb B12 hence A.)
cobblestone mucosa

perianal disease

strictures

may be ASx.

MORE of a genetic componenent

smoking WORSENS

familial and polygenic

high  sanitation in childhood increases risk

biopsy shows transmural and granuloma formation.

 

If anyone can think of anymore i'd be greatful if you comment!

Question:
Case 11 (8/8):

A patient has infectious diarrhea and begins to develop Guillian Barre syndrome- with changes in sensation and pain, muscle weakness, beginning in the feet and hands. It then spreads up the arms. The Neurology consultant knows these two are connected.

 What is the likely causative organism?
Explanation:
There is GOING to be a question on infectious diarrhea. So lets revise the important bits!

C. Diff. -> pseudomembranous colitis.

Caused by antibiotics (most commonly co-amoxiclav, which MaxFax/ENT/GP's tend to overuse). It is GRAM +VE which I could see them asking. It is normally part of normal gut flora. Tx: Stop offending Abx, supportive care, mild-mod: oral metro, severe: oral vancomycin. ISOLATE AND WASH HANDS WITH SOAP AND WATER. You can do the fecal transfer in this one too, or even surgery.

 

Campylobacter most common cause of IID in uk
g-ve rod. 90% c Jujeni. toxin mediated, usually self limiting. complication: Guillian Barre or reactive arthritis.
Isolate and kitchen hygiene

 

Salmonella
g-ve rod
Enteritides in chicken/eggs poorly cooked meat or can get it directly from the chicken. Get ASx shedding (imp for public health) can take a long time to be culture -ve.

Question: What is the order of the meninges, from external to internal?
Explanation:
I know it's easy but was something I had forgotten.

 

Dura mater, Arachnoid mater then Pia mater.

 

The subarachnoid space is between the arachnoid mater and pia mater and contains ependymal cells in the choroid plexus which secrete CSF.

The arachnoid mater has projections into the dura (arachnoid granulations) which allow CSF to re-enter circulation in the dural venosus sinuses.

Question: You are a second year medical student on placement at a local GP practice. A mother brings in her 8 week old baby called Annie, concerned that she hasn't started smiling yet. At what age should the GP refer the child for not smiling?
Explanation: A child should start to smile at 6 weeks old. If they aren't smiling by 10 weeks then they should be referred.

Question:

He has had multiple similar episodes in the past, all of which lasted between 4 and 6 days. He adds that he finds it worrying he is able to feel and hear his own irregularly irregular heartbeats, some of which were heard as 'wubbalubbadubdub'.

His grandson Morty who is present, insists that these symptoms are unrelated to Mr Sanchez's heavy alcohol consumption and recreational drug use and are not due to environmental factors nor lifestyle choices. Aside from feeling light-headed and slightly breathless during episodes, no other significant symptoms are reported. 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: Refer to Clinical Presentation of Arrhythmias from Case 13 - the categorisation of AF is well explained under one of the AF lecture slides

Question:
Case 11 (3/8):

 What is the formal name of Vitamin B-12?
Explanation:
This question was in the quiz at wrap up. I tried to leave the other answers as vitamins we should probably know. I'll do a little rant about them now:

 

A. B1 Thiamine, Deficiency is beri-beri, which means 'i-can't i can't' I think. This is part of Wernicke's encephalopathy which is seen in alcoholics who withdraw, so if you admit an alcohol dependent patient you need to give them pabrinex and thiamine after (don't need to know this for year 2, but it'll be useful as a doctor I PROMISE)


B. Vit A - retinol, don't want too much of this in pregnancy! Related to accutane (anti-acne) isoretinoin, which is massively teratogenic (I heard a rumour if you're on it you also have to be on some form of contraception because if you have both it's super nasty.)

C. Folic acid, Vitamin B9. Obviously important in case 7/8 as given as a supplement to avoid neural tube defects, higher dose if history of NT defects, epilepsy, and maybe some other reasons i've forgotten. Deficiencyy leads to a macrocytic anaemia (too big! MCV too big!)

D. B12, Co-albumin. IMPORTANT: Remember that its bound to R-proteins in the saliva to protect it from stomach acid, NOT INTRINSIC FACTOR (thats in the stomach, from P cells). deficiency causes a macrocytic anaemia too, and neuropathy, and also mouth symptoms such as a BEEFY RED TONGUE. Deficiency is called pernicious anaemia.

E. Vitamin D! Deficiency leads to osteomalacia, which if you were doing Case 14 would have low Ca2+, but increased PTH on serum checks (probably high alk phos and low P too).


Only other things to note I think are:
Vitamin K important for clotting factors 2,7,9,10, you lose these when you take warfarin. so if you've got Vit K deficiency you'll have coagulation problems
B3 Niacin deficiency causes PELLEGRA - 3 d's, diarrhea, dementia, dermatitis.
Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy and your teeth will fall out which I just can't deal with!

Question: A mother brings her 8 week old daughter Annie into her GP practice for her routine immunisations. She has been reading up about the vaccinations Annie is due to receive today and remembers that one of them is a conjugate vaccine. Which of the following is she thinking about?
Explanation:
The vaccines given at 8 weeks are:

- DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis) - subunit vaccine

- IPV (polio) - whole inactive vaccine

- Hib (Haemophillus influenzae B) - conjugate vaccine

- Pneumoccoccal (PVC) - a conjugate vaccine

- Meningococcal B

- Rotavirus - a live attenuated vaccine

 

Examples of conjugate vaccines are:

- Meningococcal C

- PVC

- Haemophillus Influenzae B

 

Men C is given at one year

 

MMR is given at one year and 3 years 4 months

You are a fourth year medical student on placement with Obs and Gynae and you hear the term neonate being used a lot to describe babies but you are unsure exactly what this means so you ask a year two student who has just had the lecture from Professor Wilson, she tells you that a neonate is:
OptionB: a baby in the first week of life

Question: Which of the following is a stage of primary bone healing?
OptionA: Hyaline cartilage is converted into lamellar bone by the process of endochondral ossification.
OptionC: Fibroblasts in granulation tissue and periostial cells proximal to the fracture differentiate into chrondrocytes and lay down type II collagen to form hyaline cartilage
OptionD: Cutting cone carrying out resorption/bone formation remodels the fracture site.
OptionE: Periosteal cells distal to the site of fracture differentiate into osteoblasts which lay down haphazardous type I collagen to form woven bone.
Explanation:
Secondary Bone Healing:

 

Most common form of bone healing. 

  1. Inflammation at fracture site, haematoma formation, macrophages phagocytose debris, granulation tissue formation by fibroblasts.
  2. Fibroblasts in granulation tissue and periostial cells proximal to the fracture differentiate into chrondrocytes and lay down type II collagen to form hyaline cartilage. Meanwhile Periosteal cells distal to the site of fracture differentiate into osteoblasts which lay down haphazardous type I collagen to form woven bone.
  3. Woven bone and hyaline cartilage grow towards each other and unite to form the soft callus.
  4. Replacement of the hyaline cartilage and woven bone with lamellar bone which has a regular parallel alignment of collagen in sheets ("lamellae") and is mechanically strong. The replacement process is known as endochondral ossification with respect to the hyaline cartilage and bony substitution with respect to the woven bone. The lamellar bone begins forming soon after the collagen matrix of either tissue becomes mineralised. At this point, the mineralised matrix is penetrated by channels, each containing a microvessel and numerous osteoblasts. The osteoblasts form new lamellar bone upon the recently exposed surface of the mineralised matrix. This new lamellar bone is in the form of trabecular/spongy bone. Eventually, all of the woven bone and cartilage of the original fracture callus is replaced by spongy bone, restoring most of the bone's original strength.

Primary Bone Healing:

 

Uncommon because ends of the bones need to be exactly touching which only happens when the two ends of the fracture are surgically screwed together or in case with a partial crack in the bone, a so-called "unicortical" fracture, where the remaining bone holds everything rigid.

 

Cortical bone directly attempt to re-establish itself after interruption without the formation of a fracture callus. 
 
Primary bone healing is lead by the formation of a cutting cone across the gap. That is, the gap is so small the cutting cone doesn’t realise it is there and just continues to resorb and deposit bone across the fracture site (although I guess as there's technically nothing in the gap to resorb it just deposits the bone). 

 

Case 1 & Case 14

Question:
Annie has had a wild few nights trying to forget the upcoming S3 exam, but disaster strikes and she realises that she hasn't taken her pill for the last 3 nights! As a result of this there is a potential for a mini - annie, in order for this to happen the following has to occur:

 

The sperm buries into the corona radiata and hydrolytic enzymes are released from the sperm. These enzymes break down the zona pellucida allowing the nucleus of the sperm to enter the ovum.

 

Specifically what is being described?
Explanation:
Capacitation: a period of conditioning that lasts for about 7 hours and occurs in the female reproductive tract. It involves the removal of proteins from the plasma membrane of the sperm. Only capacitated sperm can undergo the acromosome reaction.

 

Acromosome Reaction: what is being described in the question

 

Cortical Reaction: prevents further sperm entering the ovum by the cross linking of the zona pellucida, prevents polyspermy

Question:
Case 9 (2/8):

 Which of the following vaccinations would be appropriate for a pregnant patient?
Explanation:
A Whooping cough vaccine is often given to help provide protection for the baby. It is given between 20 and 32 weeks. As there is no single whooping cough vaccine they get a 4 in 1 with diphtheria, polio, whooping cough and tetanus.  A pregnant woman would also be indicated to have the IM influenza vaccine as tis is not live.

The rest are all live vaccines and would be contraindicated.

 It'd be a good idea to make sure you've had your MMR before you get pregnant, because Rubella can be particularly nasty congenitally (sensoneurial deathness, congenital heart problems eye abnormalities).
Tags: case 9, Pregnancy, Pretend Exam, immunisation, immunology

Question:
Case 7 (2/10) 

 

What reaction is vital to happen before the Sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida?
Explanation:
Answer C capacitation 

 

Sperm Capacitation happens in the female genital tract, the plasma membrane of the sperm decreases the amount of cholesterol on its surface making it more flexible and allowing the acrosome reaction to occur. 

 

The fertilisation process usually takes place in the ampulla and the fertile window is between 9-14 days 

due to the capacitation of the sperm the sperm binds to the zona pellucida glycoproteins and causes an increase in calcium which causes the Acrosome reaction to occur, the enzymes released digest the glycoproteins and the sperm moves closer. 

 

Next the increase in calcium also causes the Cortical reaction which granules are released from the sperm which digest the remaining glycoproteins, hence no more sperm can bind. Cortical reaction, BLOCKS polyspermy. 

 

Consequently, the two membranes fuse and restore the diploid number, determine sex and induce cleavage of the zygote 

 

A x

Question:
Case 7 (3/10) 

 

By day 3 an 8 cell Morula is in the fallopian tube heading to the uterus, but what stages of the cycle cycle where inhibited to cause a rapid increase in cells but with no growth of the overall structure?
Explanation:
Answer: G1 + G2 

 

these stages in the cell cycle are stopped, for the time being, which causes a rapid increase in cells from 2-->4-->8 cell morula but without an overall increase in the size 

 

A x

Question:
Case 7 (4/10) 

 

What cells secrete hCG which is able to be detected on a pregnancy test?
Explanation:
Answer Synctiotrophoblasts 

 

At day 5 a blastocysts forms, made up of: an inner cell mass (embryo blast) and a outer cell mass (trophoblast) 

the blastocyst begins to embed at day 8-9 into the uterine wall

 

Synchitotrophoblasts, lack boundaries and secrete enzymes which allow for embedding, they also secrete hCG until the placenta takes over 

 

at week 2, the blastocysts is completely embedded and held in the lining by a fibrin clot, the amnioblasts above the epiblast become the amniotic fluid and trophblastic lacunae form which gives rise to the placenta. 

 

The Decidual reaction provides nutrients before the placenta forms: the stroma expansion + glycogen secretions increase giving all the nutrients a lovely blastocyst needs 

 

The bilaminar disc is made up of: epiblasts (columnar) and hypoblast (cuboidal) 

 

and the primitive yolk sac gives rise to the umbilical cord 

 

A x

Question:
Case 7 (5/10) 

 

Which is the most correct description of what occurs during gastrulation?
OptionA: The notochord signals to the epiblasts roll in and underneath and migrate laterally and invade the gap between the epiblast and the hypoblast
OptionB: The primitive streak + primitive node signals to the hypoblast roll in and underneath and migrate medially and invade the gap between the epiblast and the epiblasts
OptionC: The mesoderm signals to the epiblasts roll in and underneath and migrate laterally and invade the gap between the epiblast and the hypoblast
OptionD: The primitive streak + primitive node signals to the epiblasts roll in and underneath and migrate medially and invade the gap between the epiblast and the hypoblast
OptionE: The primitive streak + primitive node signals to the epiblasts roll in and underneath and migrate laterally and invade the gap between the epiblast and the hypoblast
Explanation:
E is the correct answer

 

The primitive streak + primitive node signals to the epiblasts roll in and underneath and migrate laterally and invade the gap between the epiblast and the hypoblast

 

Gastrulation occurs at day 16 (week 3) 

 

on day 14 the primitive streak forms and the primitive node (Hensons) at the cephalic end 

 

day 16, The primitive streak + primitive node signals to the epiblasts roll in and underneath and migrate laterally and invade the gap between the epiblast and the hypoblast

 

by day 17, 3 layers have formed

 

  • ectoderm (top) 
  • mesoderm (middle) 
  • endoderm (bottom) 

the notocord which has a short lifespan, forms in the layer of the mesoderm centrally and signals to the neural cells to start -> NEURALTION 

 

AG x

Question:
Mr Sabu smokes some weed, he would never normally do so, but he is feeling particularly daring for the last couple days. He is giddy and in high mood. He has increased concentration, is hypersexual, he is neglecting his sleep and not taking care of himself. He also has pressured speech. He is wearing a neon vest he stole off a builder.

 

What is this?
Explanation:
It is hypomania - these are symptoms of an episode.

 

It is not mania because it has only been a few days. manic episodes last over a week. He doesn't have symptoms such as irritation or grandiose delusions.

 

To diagnose bipolar:

 

Bipolar I is characterised by one or more manic episodes or mixed episodes (which is when you experience symptoms of both a mania and a depression). Typically a person will experience periods of depression as well. Bipolar I disorder is marked by extreme manic episodes.

 

Bipolar II disorder is diagnosed after one or more major depressive episodes and at least one episode of hypomania, with possible periods of level mood between episodes.

Question:

Which order best describes the role of WnT, Shh and TGF-Beta, all involved in neural induction?
OptionA:
Wnt: induce endoderm + mesoderm to differentiate into designated tissues 

Shh: expressed by the notochord: involved in neural patterning, neural induction and somite formation 

TGF-Beta: regulate cell differentiation
OptionB:
Wnt: induce ectoderm + mesoderm to differentiate into designated tissues
Shh: expressed by the notochord: involved in neural patterning, neural induction and somite formation
TGF-Beta: regulate cell differentiation
OptionC:
Wnt: induce mesoderm to differentiate into designated tissues
Shh: expressed by the primitive steak: involved in neural patterning, neural induction and somite formation
TGF-Beta: regulate cell differentiation
OptionD:
Wnt: induce ectoderm + mesoderm to differentiate into designated tissues
Shh: expressed by the notochord: involved in neural patterning, neural induction and somite formation
TGF-Beta: regulate neural tube closure
OptionE:
Wnt: induce endoderm + mesoderm to differentiate into designated tissues
Shh: expressed by the N-Cadherin: involved in neural patterning, neural induction and somite formation
TGF-Beta: regulate cell differentiation
Explanation:
Correct answer: 

 

B:

 

Wnt: induce ectoderm + mesoderm to differentiate into designated tissues
Shh: expressed by the notochord: involved in neural patterning, neural induction and somite formation
TGF-Beta: regulate cell differentiation

 

Neuralation 

  • the notochord also causes thickening of the ectoderm 
  • Neural plate cells invade the mesoderm and directly above the notochord is the neural tube 
  • as it zips up, some cells go to the mesoderm and other form neural crest cells

Primary Neuralation 

 

  • divides ectoderm + mesoderm = 3 layers 
  • E cadherin (end) + N cadherin (all) alter the adhesiveness - basically stick the two ends of the cells together creating the neural tube! 
  • the notochord remnant becomes the nucleus pulposus 
  • the somites form adjacent to the neural tube - the HOX genes give direct numerical values for the somites ]

the closure of the neural tube is from the neck downwards

Question: Which locally acting hormone in the small intestine will increase absorption of Na+, H+ and Cl-?
Explanation:
A brief list of all hormones mentioned in Jeffs lecture and their roles:

 

VIP - produced by NANC neurones - Cl- secretion and smooth muscle relaxation

5-HT - produced by enterochromaffin like cells - Cl- secretion and increased local motor reflexes to the bolus

Histamine - Produced by MAST cells - Cl- secretion 

Enkephalins - Na+/Cl-/H2O absorption and decrease peristalsis 

Somatostatin - see the question

Neurotensin - produced by N cells in response to fats in the ileum - decrease motility

Enteroglucan - Produced by L cells (as are GLP's) in response to fats and sugar in the ileum - decrease motility 

Motilin - Produced by M cells in response to acid and fats in the duodenum - increase smooth muscle sensitivity to the slow waves produced by the interstitial cells of cajal (part of the SIP syncitium) and also trigger the Migrating Motility Complex to move food throughout the intestine (seen as mass movements)

Gastrin/CCK - Increase colonic excitability 

Aldosterone - Increases Na+ reabsorption in the colon (which also brings with it H2O)

 

Hope this helps!

Question:
Mr sugar, a 66 year old male, presents to your GP surgery complaining of increased frequency of urination and increased thirst. He complains of no burning sensation when urinating and hence you decide to perform some tests to determine the cause of his symptoms, these are the results you obtain back from the lab: 

 

Blood test: Markedly reduced eGFR, HbA1C 7.9%.

Urine dipstick:  ACR high, glycosuria, proteinuria. 

 

you diagnose mr sugar with type 2 diabetes. You also note that he has heart failure from his previous history. Given his diagnosis and test results which treatment is the most appropriate to begin with?
OptionA: Lifestyle advice with follow up for possible pharmacological therapy in 6 months.
Explanation: Metformin is usually first line therapy for type 2 diabetics, but due to Mr sugars CKD metformin is contraindicated. The nice guidlines then state that the patient should begin on a DPP-4 (saxagliptin), sulonylurea (gliclazide) or a thiazolindendione (pioglitazone) along with lifestyle advice. Here piohlitazone is contraindicated due to the patients heart failure, and hence due to the options above this only leaves Gliclazide.

Question:
Case 7 (6/10) 

 

Which below are derived from the neural crest cells?
Explanation:
E: Adrenal Medulla 

 

Ectoderm deviates: essentially CNS + its communicating centres 

 

  • surface ectoderm (epidermis) --> epidermis, hair, nails, mouth + olfactory epithelium, lens, cornea, anterior pituitary, tooth enamel, cheek epithelium 
  • neural crest cells --> peripheral NS, schwann cells, neuroglia, SNS, PSNS, adrenal medulla, melanocytes, facial cartilage, dentine of teeth 
  • neural tube --> brain, neural pituitary, spinal cord, motor neurones, retina 

Mesoderm derivates 

  • somites form: 
  • dermatomes --> skin 
  • myotome --> muscle 
  • scleratome --> cartilage + bone 
  • + adrenal cortex 

Endoderm 

  • forms most of the interior body surface e.g. GI tract + mucosa 

AG x
