Question:
A 72 year old female patient presents to the A&E with a hip fracture after tripping over her cat. 

 

Because of her age you wonder whether this fracture may have been more likely due to a disease of the bone. 

 

You do a DEXA scan and blood tests and the following results come back:

 

  • Z score > 2.5 
  • Normal calcium
  • Normal phosphate
  • Normal PTH
  • Normal ALP 

You have a pretty good idea what this patient has and you prescribe her some medication you believe will help. 

 

What are you likely to have prescribed?
Explanation:
This patients DEXA scan results and blood results are textbook osteoporosis. 

 

Treatment of osteoporosis is bisphosphonates, a class of drugs that slow down bone resporption by inhibiting osteoclasts and causing them to undergo apoptosis. Answers B and E are both bisphosphonates but you would use Alendronate as the first line whereas Zolendronate is for special cases on osteoporosis (aswell as Paget's disease).

 

Oral alpha-calcidol, oral D2/3 and oral cholecalciferol are all treatments for osteomalacia/rickets. 

 

Zolendronate and Risedrondate are used to treat Paget's. 

 

Biochemical changes in other bony disease include:

  • Paget's disease: increased ALP, normal Ca, phosphate and PTH
  • Osteomalacia: high/normal ALP and PTH, normal Ca and phosphate
  • Bony mets: high ALP, Ca and phosphate, low PTH
  • Renal osteodystrophy: normal/high Ca, high ALP, phosphate and PTH 
  • Primary hyperthyroidism: high/normal Ca, low/normal phosphate, high/normal ALP, high PTH

Question:
Case 7 (7/10) 

 

What are the 3 principles of Teratogenesis + what weeks are the embryo most at risk?
Explanation:
C is the correct answer

 

dose
length of exposure/time
genotype
3-8 weeks

 

Foetal alcohol syndrome is one example of this

  • baby presents with 
  • epicanthal folds, small head, low nasal bridge, distinct philrium, thin upper lip, flat mid face + short nose 

Smoking also affects the foetus, but over a long period of time 

  • lowers birth weight by 200g 
  • nicotine is a sympathetic and vasoconstricts the uterine vein, therefore decrease o2 to the foetus 
  • decreases o2 delivery but a high carbon monoxide content in the maternal blood 
  • increased incidence of: SIDS, asthma, pneumonia and misscariage 

 

Different to teratogens are: 

 

Disruption: 

  • alteration to a pre exsiting structure due to a destructive process 
  • amniotic band syndrome 

Deformation 

  • change in normal structure due to mechanical forces 
  • clubbed foot 

Also up to 9 weeks a medical abortion can be performed 

 

  • Mifepristone - progesterone antagonist = decrease endometrial lining 
  • Misoprostol - prostaglandins = sensitises uterus to contractions 
  • Gameprost - PGE2 analogue - decreases bleeding 

Surgical > 9 weeks 

 

  • vacuum 7-15 weeks 
  • intrauterine dilation + extraction 16 weeks + 

 

AG x

Question: A patient presents with chronic type 2 diabetes and heart failure. You are aware of one drug which is contraindicated in this patients case for the treatment of diabetes. what is the mechanism of action of this drug?
OptionA: Activates AMP-dependant protein kinase hepatically to potentiate the effects of endogenously secreted insulin. This increases insulin-dependant glucose uptakes into tissues.
OptionB: Acts on beta cell K+ATP channels to block potassium ion efflux. This depolarisation of the B cells causes calcium influx and IP3 mediated enhanced insulin secretion from the pancreas.
OptionC: Work by blocking the enzyme dpp-iv which rapidly break down incretins such as GLP-1. this increases the half life of circulating incretins to enhance the secretions of insulin from the pancreas.
OptionD: Complexes with peroxisome-proliferator-activated-receptor-gamma (PPAR-gamma) which is an adipocyte gene transcriptional regular. This increases peripheral insulin sensitivity.
OptionE: Mimics incretins by activating GLP-1 receptors to cause enhanced insulin secretion from the pancreas.
Explanation:
A = metformin. 

B = Gliclazide. 

C = saxagliptin. 

D = piohlitazone. 

E = Exenatide.

Question:
Case 9 (7/8):

A Mother attends the GP with a bunch of Mumsnet printouts stating that she wants her child to have the vaccines, but would prefer to have single shots one day after the other. She thinks this will be safer and wants to know why we don't do this anyway?
OptionA: Multiple vaccines increase the risk of anaphylaxsis as the child is exposed to other chemicals in the vaccines which can provoke this reaction
OptionB: Single vaccines are not available in the UK
OptionC: It is cheaper for the goverment to do it this way as it takes up less of the doctors/nurses time, she can have what she wants if she pays privately
OptionD: After a live vaccine the body enters an antiviral state, meaning subsequent vaccines would be less effective in getting an enhanced immune response, you'd have to wait 30 days and the child would be vulnerable during this period
OptionE: The vaccine will only work if all 3 are given at the same time
Explanation: Maybe a little obvious, but D is the reason why the MMR is given as a single booster, and this'll no doubt be important to know as doctors.

A 23 year old lady presents to the antenatal clinic and she is offered a screening test, she is 16 weeks pregnant and wants to know if her unborn baby was to have Trisomy 21, what the tests would show. 

 

What screening test will she be offered and what are the results likely to be shown if her baby likely has Trisomy 21?
OptionE:
Quadruple 

 

Increased: Inhibin A, hCG
Decreased: AFP, uE3, PAPP-A
Explanation:
Answer A: 

 

Quadruple

Increased: Inhibin A, hCG
Decreased: AFP, uE3

 

The screening tests are Combines + Quadruple but the Diagnostic tests are amniocentesis and chronic villi 

 

Booking bloods: 12 weeks 

  • rhesus status of the mother 
  • anaemia 
  • haematology pathologies (sickle cell etc.) 
  • infection (HIV, hep, rubella) 

Ultrasound dating 

  • 11-13 weeks 

Anomaly scan 

  • 18-20 weeks 

Combined screening test 

  • 11-14 weeks 
  • CRL + NT 
  • hCG + PAPP-A
  • however can't be offered to overweight ladies as it is hard to determine the NT accurately 

Quadruple screening test 

  • 15 - 18 weeks 
  • CRL 
  • hCG, inhibin-A, uE3, AFP 
  • not recommended in multiple pregnancies 

Diagnostic tests 

 

Choronic villi 

  • from 11 weeks 
  • >1% miscarriage risk 
  • 5% won't give you a result 
  • vaginally 

Amniocentesis 

  • from 15 weeks 
  • 1% miscarriage risk 
  • 1% won't give you results 
  • abdominally 

Downs trisomy 21 

  • Combined test: NT >3.5mm + high hCG 
  • quadruble: high HCG + Inhibin A, all others down 

 

Neural tube defect 

  • increased AFP in quadruple 
  • this can be prevented if the mother takes folic acid B9, from before getting pregnant, or immediately as she finds out
  • essential to neural tube closure

Question:
Case 9 (8/8):

Which type of vaccine would be required for a pathogen producing lipopolysaccharide?
Explanation: Live attenuated vaccines are the best because they get INTO cells, which can lead to a CD4 response with T-cell help. It only works if the pathogen has proteins which can be presented on an MHC II though, which is why sometimes we have to cheat using conjugated vaccines if the pathogen normally has LPS instead (examples are all the meningitis vaccines).

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding lactation?
OptionA: When the baby is born there is a sudden increase in prolactin levels to allow milk excretion.
OptionB: After lactogenesis there is a switch from autocrine to endocrine control of lactation.
OptionC: Myoepithelial cells contract in response to the hormone prolactin to cause milk ejection.
OptionD: Feedback inhibitor of lactation protein (fil) increase in concentration when milk accumulates in the breast causing a decrease in milk production.
OptionE: After 3 weeks of lactation milk becomes sticky and yellow with low fat and high protein content.
Explanation:
Physiology of lactation:

Lactogenesis: 

  1. From 4 months gestation prolactin is secreted from the anterior pituitary gland to increase the mRNA for milk proteins (a-lactalbumin, casein, and lactose) and enzymes required for milk formation and secretion.
  2. A women cannot express this milk she is producing until the baby is born because high levels of progesterone and oestrogen suppress lactation, this means that the milk protein components are reabsorbed into the mothers blood.
  3. When the baby is born there is a sudden drop in HCG, hPL, oestrogen and progesterone levels, but prolactin levels remain high and lactogenesis II is initiated. 
  4. Lactogenesis II allows milk expression 30-40 hours after birth as it causes an increase in milk volume, IgA, lactoferrin and high oligosaccharide levels to be present in the milk composition. 
  5. After lactogenesis II there is a switch from endocrine to autocrine control of lactation and hence milk removal is now the primary control mechanism for milk synthesis meaning the breasts continue to produce milk as long as removal occurs within a 3 day period.

Galactokinesis: 

  1. discharge of the milk from the mammary glands depending on the secretion exerted by the baby suckling and the contractile mechanism which expresses the milk from the alveoli to the ducts (controlled by the neural reflex arc.). 
  2. sucking activates mechanoreceptors in the nipple which sends positive feedback responses to the hypothylamus. This firstly increases oxytoxcin secretions from the posterior pituitary to allow myoepithelial cell contraction and milk ejection. It also decreases the levels of dopamine to increase prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary to increase milk secretion. 

Galactopoeisis:

  1. Maintenance of lactation is controlled by prolactin, and suckling of the breast is essential for removal of milk from the alveoli and prolactin secretion. 
  2. FIL also regulates milk secretion and milk production slows when milk accumulates in the breast as more FIL is present and vice versa. 
  3. emptier breast means a higher fat milk.

Question: Sally is wanting to experiment with the old 'recreationals' but being a medical student she is very picky about which one she would like to give a go. She remembers sitting in a lecture once and they were talking about how a certain drug binds to 5-HT 2a receptors and acts as a psychotomimetic and she likes the sound of talking to a unicorn. However she cant remember which drug it was. What drug would the extremely educated dealer who knows exactly what she is talking about sell her?
Explanation:
Amphetamines act by disrupting vesicle formation or neurotransmitters and thus dumping noradrenaline and dopamine into the synaptic cleft.

 

Cocaine is a dopamine reuptake inhibitor, increasing firing of 5-HT neurones in the mesolimbic system and also acts as a sympathomimetic (causing tachycardia etc.). Similar to the atypical antidepressant buproprion but cocaine isnt a very good antidepressant. 

 

MDMA inhibits 5-HT reuptake and increases its release acting as a pyschotomimetic (similar to psychosis), empathogenic (feeling like a hippie with the love) and psychostimulant (feel wired).

 

LSD mimics 5-HT and binds to the 5-HT2a receptor which is the one implicated in pyschosis in schizophrenia (positive symptoms) and thus acts as a sympthomimetic.

 

Caffeine is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor and thus keeps levels of cAMP high while also acting on Adenosine (purine) A2 receptors. Although with the amount you consume around revision making you feel split off from reality, its unlikely to cause psychosis.

 

Extras:

 

Mephadrone (i.e. Meow meow) similar moa to amphetamines.

 

Ritalin (a.k.a. Methylphendiate) blocks noradrenaline and dopamine reuptake (psychostimulant)

 

Cannabis - acts on cannabinoid 1 (CNS)  and 2 (peripherally) which inhibits presynaptic ca2+ channels and thus GABA release (indirectly enhancing dopamine secretion)

 

Opiates - bind mu opioid receptor which leads to post synaptic K+ efflux and presynaptic inhibition of GABA release through cAMP inhibition (long term use upregulates cAMP through increasing PKA and thus leads to the withdrawal symptoms - mainly originating from the locus coeruleus (the NA centre)).

Which of the following drug treatments is first line therapy for pre-eclampsia?

A 16 week pregnant women opts for the quadruple test for her child.

The results come back showing a low concentration of AFP, which of the following is most likely to be present in the fetus?
Explanation:
Low AFP = trisomy, sex chromosome disorders and triploidy.

Question: A 19 week pregnant female would like to have some prenatal testing done, she is expecting twins. Due to her gestational age which test would be most appropriate?
Explanation:
Nuchal translucency: offerred to women between 10 and 14 weeks of pregnancy. It is used to screen for trisomy and can be measured during the dating ultrasound. It is a measurement of the nuchal fluid under the back of the babies neck, if this is more than 2.5mm then it is an abnormal measurement. This cannot be performed on obese individuals. 

combined screening test: performed between 10 and 14 weeks and combines the nuchal translucency measurement with a maternal serum test to detect PAPPA (low levels for trisomy) and bHCG (high levels for trisomy). 

Quadruple test: screens for AFP, bHCG, Ue3 and inhibin A levels at 15-20 weeks gestation. not suitable for multiple pregnancies. You would expect inhibin A and bHCG to increase and AFP and Ue3 to decrease with down syndrome. 

Chorionic villus sampling: carried out between 11 and 14 weeks pregnancy but can be performed earlier if necessary. It involves inserting a needle transabdomnally or transvaginally into the placenta to aspirate and test villus tissue. 

Amniocentesis: carried out between 15 and 20 weeks of pregnancy where a needle is inserted transabnormally into the amniotic fluid guided by ultrasound to amniotic fluid for testing of AFP and acetylcholinesterase. has a 1% risk of miscarrying.

In pregnancy, what 4 respiratory changes occur?

OptionA:
1. elevated diaphragm 

2. increased tidal volume 

3. decreased expiratory reserve volume 

4. increased total lung volume
OptionB:
1. elevated diaphragm
2. increased tidal volume
3. decreased expiratory reserve volume
4. decreased total lung volume
OptionC:
1. elevated diaphragm
2. decreased tidal volume
3. decreased expiratory reserve volume
4. decreased total lung volume
OptionD:

2. decreased respiratory rate 
3. decreased expiratory reserve volume
4. increased total lung volume

1. decreased respiratory rate 
2. increased tidal volume
3. decreased expiratory reserve volume

Explanation:
Correct Answer: B 

 

1. elevated diaphragm
2. increased tidal volume
3. decreased expiratory reserve volume
4. decreased total lung volume 

 

  • due to the increasing size of the foetus, the diaphragm is elevated
  • the tidal volume increases during pregnancy (tidal volume = the amount of air which enters the lung at rest breaths) 
  • there is also a loss of expiratory reserve volume due to the loss of space within the lung pleura, due to the increasing foetus size which also reduces the total lung capacity/ volume 

progesterone interestingly increases respiratory rate

 

Now for the case 5 revision:

 

 

A = inspiratory reseve volume 

B = tidal volume 

C = expiratory reserve volume 

D - residual volume 

E - inspriatory capacity 

F - expiratory capacity 

G - vital capacity 

H - total lung capacity

Question:
Case 8 (2/10) 

 

A man comes into the blood clinic and wants to know what blood type he is, being the polite person you are, you give it a go! 

 

On mixture with Anti-A and Anti-B  and anti-AB and the mans blood, there is a reaction with the anti-A but no reaction with anti-B and a partial reaction with Anti-AB. 

 

on mixture with his blood and plasma samples, AntiB-A antiB-B, there is no reaction with the AntiB-A but there is a reaction with AntiB-B 

 

on mixing with his blood and rhesus D serum, there is a reaction. 

 

What blood type is the man most likely to be?
Explanation:
Answer A: A + 

 

I apologise if Ive got this completely wrong but this is how I think of it: 

 

the mixing of the first agent relates to the antigens present on the RBC surface: it reacted with antigen A and partly with antigens AB and no reaction with antigen B, this means must be ANTIGEN A present on the surface 

 

next mixing the blood with the plasma relates to the antibodies found floating around in the plasma: there was a reaction with antibody B but not with antibody A, which means that antibodies against B must be present, so this leads us to assume he is type A 

 

Type A: A antigens present on cell surface and Antibodies against antigen B 

 

next rhesus, 

 

if he was rhesus negative and mixed with rhesus D there would be NO reaction, so as there is a reaction, we can assume that he is rhesus + 

 

so he is blood type A + 

 

Hope that makes sense :) 

 

more information 

 

Antigen A = N-acetyl-D- galactosamine 

Antigen B = D-galactose 

 

Blood transfusions:

 

type A --> antibody B --> accept A + O 

 

type B --> antibody A --> accept B + O 

 

type AB --> no antibodies --> accept A,B,AB,O 

 

type O --> antibodies A + B --> accept only O 

 

so if your type O like me, its great to donate, but were buggered if we need a transfusion! 

 

AG x

Question:
Case 8 (3/10) 

 

Which best describes why are NSAIDs contraindicated during pregnancy?
OptionA: NSAIDs induce early labour by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
OptionB: NSAIDs close the foramen ovale to early meaning blood flows into the foetal lungs
OptionC: NSAIDs keep the Ductus Venosus open after birth
OptionD: NSAIDs close the ductus arteriosus too early meaning blood travels to the lungs
OptionE: NSAIDs close both the foramen ovale and ductus arteriousus too early
Explanation:
Answer D: 

NSAIDs close the ductus arteriosus too early meaning blood travels to the lungs

 

I apologise for my awful spelling. 

 

basically prostaglandins keep the ductus arteriousus OPEN, NSAIDs which inhibit the COX (1+2) which mean that prostaglandins can no longer be produced. So the ductus arteriosus closes too early, and the blood travels to he lungs, which will be at such a high pressure, it will cause lung damage to the foetus. 

 

 

 

Now for some facts: 

 

Foramen Ovale 

  • connects the the Left atria to the Right atria so blood can bypass the lungs 
  • oxygenated blood flows from the umbilical veins pass to the IVC --> RA --> FO --> LA --> LV --> aorta
  • closure: on first breath: increase in venous return to the LA - increase LA pressure, therefore it shuts 
  • remenant: fossa ovalis 

 

Ductus Arteriosus 

  • connects the pulmonary trunk to the aorta 
  • lungs NEED to be bypasses 
  • deoxugenated blood from SVC --> RV --> pulmonary trunk --> aorta (via DA)
  • CLOSE: muscle contraction = bradykinin released from lung in first breath 
  • prostaglandins keep it open in pregnancy
  • remenant: ligamentum arteriosum 

Ductus Venosus 

  • connects umbilical vein + IVC 
  • oxygenated blood to foetal circulation 
  • close: after umbilical arteries 
  • remenenat: ligament venosum 

umbilical arteries: 

  • paired off branches of common iliac vessels 
  • deoxugenated blood back to the placenta 
  • close: muscle contraction - changes in o2 tension 
  • remaining: medial umbilical ligament 

umbilical veins: 

  • branches of the placenta + travels to the ductus venous 
  • brings oxygenated blood to foetus
  • close: after umbilical arteries 
  • remaining: round ligament of liver 

 

AG x

if a women has miscarriaged, you can give dopamine, as this will inhibit prolactin + milk secretion

Question:

E. Chicken pox would probably have vesicles (fluid filled blisters). Usually starts on the body instead. ITCHY as!

Question:
Case 9 (4/8) 

 

During the Induced Innate response what cytokines are released by macrophages to cause fever + inflammation?
Explanation:
Correct answer C: 

 

TNF alpha, IL-1B, IL-6 

 

these are cytokines / pyrogens which are released by macophages when a pathogen virus/ has entered the body, the complement system is also activated. the Alternative pathway of the complement system (C3b) is active when enveloped viruses / bacteria are involved. 

 

the progens travel to the hypothalamus where IL1b and IL6 are endogenous and cause PGE2 production which causes the SNS to vasoconstict the skin + cause shivering, also temperature rises and this reduces the chance of viral replication. 

 

if your inmate immune response fails, as in your resisdent effector cells (macrophages, mast cells, cDCs) or immediate barriers dont get rid of the pathogen / virus then induced innate (4hrs --> 4 days is initiated) 

 

Sentinel cells detect the presence of a pathogen (macrophages, DCs and NK cells) these detect a change in the PRRs present on every membrane, basically they are molecular trip wires. 

 

All your cells are capable of producing IFNs alpha + beta 

 

IFNs produce a systemic response - malaise, sleep, loss of appetite, fever + chills etc

Why aren't vaccines like the MMR given in 3 separate doses rather than together?
OptionA: Its too expensive, the NHS is broke already
OptionB: More painful and inconvenient for the child
OptionC: the 1st vaccine will induce an antiviral state, which will mean, the subsequent vaccines given in that short space will not produce the desired immune response

Correct answer is C: 

 

the antiviral state will be induced, which means that subsequent vaccinatations given will not be able to produce the desired immune response. 

 

all cells are capable of producing IFN alpha + beta, plus macrophages, fibroblasts, endothelial cells 

 

a virus infected cell comes along ---> IFN alpha + beta released and there is an increase MHC class displayed

  • there is an increase in resistance to viral replication in ALL cells 
  • increase expression of ligands for receptors on NK cells 
  • NK cells activated by IL-12 
  • IFN - gamma  activate NK cells to kill the virus infected cells + macrophaes involved to mob up after 

this induces the antiviral state 

  • IFN alpha and beta + IFN receptor cause the JAK/STAT to become activated which enhances the antiviral state further 
  • IFN stimulated genes (ISGs) decreased/reduce viral entry and reduce/decrease viral replication 

cytosolic detection of viral proteins by PRRs = RIG like receptors --> cells produce an interferon response

TRL 1,2,4,6 = recognise viral glycoproteins (proteins on the membrane) 

TRL 3.7.8.9= recognise on endosome (in NK cells, DCs, eosinophils, mast cells)

Question:
You are a GP and a A 75 year old patient presents complaining that he has to sleep with 3/4 pillows at night to stop him getting breathless, he also states he can't go for walks with his wife anymore because he gets breathless and has to stop, similarly he struggles when he is late for the bus. Although he states he's fine getting round the house at the moment. 

 

You carry out a full CV examination and you note that the patient has:

  • Bibasal crepitiations in the lungs on auscultation
  • S4 heart sound
  • There is no peripheral oedema at the present time 

You send the patient off for an CXR and the scan was as follows:

 

What is your differential for this patient?
Explanation:
This patient has Class 2b left sided diastolic failure. 

 

The S4 heart sound is indicative of a stiff heart (the sound comes from blood rushing into a stiffened ventricle). This indicated the patient has a diastolic heart failure. If the patient had a systolic heart failure you may have heard S3 which indicates a dilated heart. 

 

The CXR shows fluid in the lungs (white whispy stuff in lungs), more specifically the white arrows are pointing to Kerley B lines which are indicative of fluid in the lung interstitium. The bibasal crepitation are indicative of fluid in the lungs too. Orthopnea (breathlessness when lying flat) is as a result of fluid in the periphery moving back into the central venous system when you are lying down. In diastolic failure the ventricles are stiff so will not fill properly regardless of increased venous return which means there is a back up of blood into the atria, increasing the pressure in the atria. On the left side the increased pressure in the atria reflects into the pulmonary venous system and the pressure in the venous system increases to try and overcome the higher pressure in the atria. Increased pulmonary venous pressure leads to increased hydrostatic forces which push fluid from the blood into the tissue of the lung interstitium causing breathlessness. 

 

Considering the patient has pulmonary oedema and not peripheral oedema we can assume this is left sided heart failure (which may eventually cause right sided heart failure when the pressure in the lung venous pressure backs up into the right ventricle). 

 

The patient gets breathless on mild exertion but not on minimal exertion (e.g. walking from room to room) or at rest so the NYHA class that best described him is class 2b. 

 

The reasons for breathlessness on exertion are:

1. The patient has reduced filling of his ventricles which means there is less blood at the end of diastole (decreased EDV) to push out resulting in a decreased stroke volume. SV X HR = CO therefore a reduced SV will cause a decreased cardiac output to the muscles. The muscles don't get the oxygenated blood they need to respire which means they have to respire anaerobically which produces lactic acid, resulting in metabolic acidodis. The patient will start to compensate for this by increasing the ventialtion rate to blow off CO2 and reduce the amount of acid in the blood. Hence the patient appears breathless.

2. The fluid in the lungs causes the alveoli to collapse which reduces the area for gaseous exchange.

Question:
Laura, a 32 year old primigravida, comes to see the midwife for one of her antenatal checks. Laura enquired about breastfeeding and wanted to know more about how it worked.

 

Which of the following is incorrect?
OptionA: There are 10 major ducts that carry milk to the nipple
OptionC: Within each alveoli there are acini cells and myopeithelial cells
OptionD: In the breast, there are 10-15 lobes, which is separated by fibrous septa.
Explanation:
• In the breast, there are 15-25 lobes, which is separated by fibrous septa.
  • Each lobe is make up of lots of lobules.
  • Each lobule contains many alveoli.
  • Within the alveoli, there are acini cells and myoepithelium cells
  • The acini cells are columnar epithelium, which are involved in milk production.
  • The myoepithelial cells respond to oxytocin and contract 
  • This squeezes milk into the ducts (there are 10 of these)
  • The ducts (0.5mm diameter) open at the nipple
  • Longitudinal and horizontal smooth muscle at the nipple acts as a sphincter.

Question: What change in hormones causes lactogenesis II?
Explanation:
Lactogenesis I = from 4 months of pregnancy and is caused by prolactin. There is an increase of mRNA for milk proteins (lactose, casein and alpha-lactalbumin). Prevention of secretion is caused by oestrogen and progesterone.

 

Lagtogenesis II = occurs 30-40 hours after birth, caused by the SUDDEN DROP IN OESTROGEN, PROGESTERONE AND HUMAN PLACENTAL LACTOGEN. Results in there being an increase in milk volume, lactose, IgA and lactoferrin.

 

Galactopoiesis = this is necessary by day 3 for lactation to continue. Changes from endocrine to autocrine control (e.g milk removal). Constant suckling promotes the release of prolactin

 

Galactokinesis = this relies on sucking by the infant and contractile force (oxytocin causing my-epithelium to contract)

Question:
A patient known to have aortic stenosis and hypertension presents to his GP with all the stigmata of diastolic heart failure. To diagnose this as heart failure the GP sends the patient off for some blood tests which test for the levels of natriuretic peptide in the blood. 

 

The blood tests come back and the results are normal, the GP explains to the patient why this might not rule out diastolic heart failure. 

 

Which of the following reasons does not explain why the patient's levels of natriuretic peptide are normal?
OptionA: Increased afterload has lead to ventricular hypertrophy.
OptionB: The radius of the ventricular chamber has decreased.
OptionD: The burden on the contractile units is not great enough to have an effect on wall stress yet.
OptionE: The chamber has dilated out of proportion.
Explanation:
Natriuretic peptides are released from the atria (ANP) and ventricle (BNP) during heart failure due to increased wall stress. 

 

When there is increased afterload e.g. arterial HTN or aortic stenosis, the left ventricle will start to hypertrophy so that it can increase the strength of contraction to try and produce a pressure that will overcome the raised afterload. 

 

Wall stress is defined by LaPlace's Law:

 

Wall stress = ventricular pressure (P) x ventricular chamber radius (r) / 2 x ventricular wall thickness (h)

 

When there is increased afterload there will be increased P which in turn leads to increased wall stress. 

To compensate the ventricular muscle hypertrophies which leads to an increase in h and a consequent decrease in r. This brings the wall stress back down, that is wall stress has been compensated for. This may be a reason why in diastolic failure NP results may be normal.

 

After a while excessive burden on the contractile units in the ventricular muscle leads to excessive hypertrophy and this causes fibrosis of the heart muscle. Fibrosis means the walls of the ventricle become stiff and cant fill properly.

 

In systolic failure the decreased pumping action means that the heart can't push out the blood leading to decreased SV. Filling is normal though so the residual blood from the previous beat and the blood coming in from the atria add up to result in an increased EDV. This results in a reduced ejection fraction. In systolic failure there is dilation of the heart chamber (increased r) and thinning of the ventricular wall (decreased h), that is the chamber has dilated out of proportion to the wall thickness. This leads to increased wall stress and hence NP release. 

 

Measuring NP is more useful in HFREF than HFPEF.

Buiguanides- metformin 

  • rely on functional B cell insulin secretion (so they must still work!) 
  • activate AMP depemdent protein kinase (hepatically)

  • INSULIN release 
  • ADR: hypoglycaemia in overdose, haematological disorders

Question: How are different blood components stored?
OptionA:
RBCs at room temperature for up to 3 months

 

FFP at -30ºC for up to 24 months

 

Platelets at 4ºC for up to 5 weeks
OptionB:
RBCs at 4ºC for up to 35 days

 

FFP at room temperature for up to 24 months

 

Platelets at room temperature for up to 5 days
OptionC:
RBCs at 4ºC for up to 35 days

 

FFP at -30ºC for up to 24 months

 

Platelets at room temperature for up to 5 days
OptionD:
RBCs at -4ºC for up to 35 days

 

FFP at -30ºC and has no shelf-life

 

Platelets at 4ºC for up to 5 days
OptionE:
RBCs at 4ºC for up to 3 months

 

FFP at -30ºC for up to 24 months

 

Platelets at room temperature for up to 3 months
Explanation:
RBCs = kept at 4ºC for up to 35 days (maybe try and remember this by thinking about HbA1c and that the lifespan for RBCs is longer than this, but not as long as 3 months, which discounts options A and E) 

 

FFP = (Fresh frozen plasma) so needs to be at -30ºC. It has a shelf life of up to 24 months. Therefore, can discount B.

 

Platelets = room temperature for up to 5 days

Question:
Once a virus has entered the body and invaded host cells, the viral genetic information is made into viral proteins by the host. These proteins then go to infect other cells in the body. 


Which of the following best describes the use of a syncytium?
OptionA: This is where the virus is let out into the blood stream.
OptionB: This is where the virus fuses the cell membranes of neighbouring cells
OptionC: This is where the virus infects the neighbouring cell.
Explanation:
A - This occurs by exocytosis of the virus or lysis of the cell. The virus can then float off and may bump into another invadable cell in the body by change.

B - This is the correct answer. Means the virus can pass more easily though the cells.

C - This is cell-cell infection, and is often used by viruses as the neighbouring cells tend to be the same cell type.

Blister packs contain 14 tablets each tablet contains 55mg 

 

Your patient weight 88kg and given in does of 2.5mg/kg to be taken at night. 

 

How many tablets does the patient need to take at night and how many blister packs does the pt need to last 4 weeks
Explanation:
answer A: 

 

You need to prescribe Amityrptyline for neuropathic pain.
Blister packs contain 14 tablets each tablet contains 55mg

Your patient weight 88kg and given in does of 2.5mg/kg to be taken at night.

How many tablets does the patient need to take at night and how many blister packs does the pt need to last 4 weeks

 

so: 

88kg x 2.5 mg / kg = 220 mg nightly 

 

each tablet contains 55mg 

 

220/55 = 4 tablets nightly - answer 1 

 

so in 1 week the patient needs 220mg x 7 = 1,540 mg a week 

 

1,540/55mg (no of tablets) = 28 tablets a week x 4 

 

112 tablets in a month - blister packs are in 14 tablets 

 

112/14 = 8 blister packs needed 

 

AG x

> 2 lateral appendatures, 1 medial --> CSF fills subrachnoid space
OptionB:
choroid plexus --> Lateral ventricles --> intraventricular foramen --> 4th ventricle --> cerebral aquaduct --> 3rd ventricles --
> 2 medial appendatures, 1 lateral --> CSF fills subrachnoid space

> 2 lateral appendatures, 1 medial --> CSF fills subrachnoid space

Question:
Case 16 (4/8) 

 

Apoptosis in neurones is caused by what?
OptionA: shearing and twisting of the Reticular activating system
Explanation:
Answer C: loss of trophic factors 

 

Apoptosis is programmed cell death, break up into apoptotic bodies 

 

  • neurone I <--> neurone II 
  • when neurone II stops secreting trophic factors to Neurone I there is a disconnection and it will cause apoptosis 
  • enzymes; DNAases, capases
  • NO INFLAMMATION 

 

Necrosis on the other hand 

  • cell injury 
  • loss of membrane integrity 
  • conents breakdown + disperse 
  • rupture 
  • INFLAMMATION 

 

Excitotoxicity 

  • Astrocytes recycle glutamate normally 
  • if ASTROCYTE is DAMAGed - INCREASED GLUTAMATE 
  • increased glutamate - increased NMDA activation 
  • NMDA allows Na+ and Ca2+ into and Ca2+ increases in the cells
  • decrease ATP synthesis, swelling, necrotic enzyme activation 

Glutamate receptors 

  • AMPA slightly depolarises the membrane 
  • NMDA is blocked by Mg2+ at resting potential 
  • AMPA mediated deloparisation releases Mg2+ so Na+ and Ca2+ can freely flow in 

 

AG x

Question:
A patient presents to the GP surgery with stigmata of diastolic heart failure as well as complaining about a squeezing pain on exertion. The GP carries out a full CV examination and picks up on two important signs:

  • Bifid carotid pulse
  • Pansystolic murmur heard at 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line. 

The GP asks the patient if he knows of any family history of heart problems and the patient said that his uncle died very suddenly at the age of 22 due to a cardiac arrest.

 

The GP is worried that patient has diastolic heart failure secondary to a cardiomyopathy, which of the following is it?
OptionE: He doesn't have a myopathy, he has angina.
Explanation:
Hypertrophy of the muscle in the ventricles can result in stiffening of the muscle walls, this means the walls cannot relax and the heart cannot fill with blood. As a result there is a decreased EDV and because there is less blood present to pump out, the stroke volume is also reduced. This causes diastolic heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.

 

The most common site of hypertrophy is the septum, normally the septum is <12mm in thickness, hypertrophy is defined as at least 15mm. 

 

The hypertrophy of the septum makes the orifice through which the blood flows from the left atria to the left ventricle decrease. This narrowing of the orifice results in the Ventouri effect: flow velocity increases but pressure decreases. 

 

The Ventouri effect causes systolic anterior valve motion. This is where the mitral valve in pulled down towards the septum. This disrupts the competence of the valve which leads to the backflow of blood i.e. mitral regurgitation (responsible for the pansystolic murmur).

 

The Ventouri effect also affects the aortic valve, the blood flows into the aorta at a greater velocity creating one upstoke in the carotid pulse, there is a downstroke due to the decreased pressure. Then later on in systole there is a second upstroke: bifid pulse. 

 

The Ventouri effect also causes anginal attacks. The blood flowing through the aorta is sucked backwards due to the decreased pressure which decreased flow to myocardial tissue. The hypertrophophic muscle also has an increased oxygen demand. Cumulatively, these mean the oxygen supply of the tissue does not meet the demand and causes angina.
Tags: Cardiovascular Physiology, Cardiovascular system, Case 15, Heart

Question: Which of the following describes a oxygenation failure (type 1 respiratory failure) rather than a ventilation (type 2 respiratory failure)?
Explanation:
COPD

Obesity

Chest wall deformities 

Hypoventilation

 

These all give rise to a type 2 ventilation failure where you would have impaired ventilation of the alveoli leading to a hypercapnia and a hypoxia, this is usually treated with non invasive ventilation.

 

Pulmonary embolism 

Pulmonary fibrosis

Altitude 

 

Are examples of where gases can still flow into and out of the lungs and so there is no hypercapnia but there is impaired diffusion of oxygen into the blood and so there is hypoxia. This you would treat with high flow nasal oxygen (cannulae).

 

Just for added info:

 

Alveolar O2 = FiO2 (fraction of inspired oxygen e.g. 21%) - (PCO2/ 0.8 (the resp. quotient))

Question: What category of lung disease can asbestosis be placed under?
Explanation:
Pulmonary fibrosis due to asbestos aspiration has this timeline:

 

-The asbestosis particle is inhaled 

-This triggers an immune response in the alveoli and you get 'frustrated phagocytosis'

-This eventually strips away the basement membrane of the alveoli (denuded) 

- This allows fibroblast entry and proliferation into the alveoli and they secrete type 3 collagen fibres

- The type 2 pneumocytes also proliferate and surround the fibroblastic foci while the type 1 pneumocytes are lost

 

This is seen on xray as FIBROBLASTIC FOCI and HONEYCOMBING and you'll have bibasal fine inspiratory crackles.

 

This process is also true of the hypersensitivity pneumonitis' seen in bird fanciers lung, hot tub lung, farmers lung etc.

Question: Which of the following would be classic of asthma?
Explanation:
Asthma is characteristically seen with:

 

Basement membrane thickening

The smooth muscle layer in the bronchi and bronchioles may also increase

Goblet cell hyperplasia

Epithelium sloughs off due to damage

Eosinophilia and increase in mast cells

 

Further breakdown of asthma:

 

Typical ATOPIC asthma has a family history and is triggered by allergies (seasonal rhinitis, eczema etc.) with a allergen skin test giving a wheal and flare appearance.

The allergen triggers a TYPE 1 HYPERSENSITIVITY REACTION where TH2 is activated and releases cytokines involved in activating eosinophils and b lymphocytes to class switch and produce IgE.

IgE causes MAST CELL DEGRANULATION and thus you have histamine release potentiating the inflammation.

This all causes the lung parenchyma damage seen.

 

The type of sputum seen in asthma can be:

 

CREOLA BODIES - ciliated columnar epithelium sloughed off and now in the mucus

CURSCHMANN SPIRALS - spiral shaped mucous plugs from the submucosal glands

CHARCOT LEYDEN CRYSTALS - from broken down eosinophils

 

Finally ADAM 33 gene is thought to confer risk for asthma and the hygiene hypothesis states that due to decrease antigen exposure in childhood the TH1 cells in the lungs arent active and so the TH2 lineage predominates (and cause asthma).

Question: What is secreted by macrophages in the lung in COPD to inactivate Alpha 1 antitrypsin?
Explanation: This acts to increase neutrophil elastase and increase compliance of the alveoli to such as extent that air remains trapped (barrel chested).

Question:
Case 13 (8/8):

Which patient requires urgent defibrillation NOW?!
OptionB: The ECG machine is making a 'beeeeeeeeeep' noise like in the movies
OptionC:
ECG been blocked by lifeinthefastlane.

Ventricular tachycardia WITH a a pulse, but they do have chest pain
Explanation:
D Ventricular fibrillation (VF) is the the most important shockable cardiac arrest rhythm.
The ventricles suddenly attempt to contract at rates of up to 500 bpm.
This rapid and irregular electrical activity renders the ventricles unable to contract in a synchronised manner, resulting in immediate loss of cardiac output.
The heart is no longer an effective pump and is reduced to a quivering mess.
Unless advanced life support is rapidly instituted, this rhythm is invariably fatal.
a Defib shock jerks all the cells into one state in the hope they they get their shit together and start beating properly.

 

 

Onto the rest...

 

A. STEMI. Can't tell where because you've only got on lead, but probably inferior and RCA. Doesn't need a shock needs PCI and MONAC.
B. Asystole. This person needs CPR and adrenaline.
C. VT. Specifically with a pulse, this person might need a synchronised shock. If they lose their pulse THEN you can give them a defib shock.

E. AF, can be cardioverted (which is technically a shock) but not defib.

Question:
You are an F1 on call, it is 1:37am and you get called to a ward by a nurse because one of the patients in breathing abnormally. 

 

The pattern of breathing is as follows:

 

1. Breathing gradually slows

2. Patient becomes apnoeic 

3. Patient takes a big gasp

4. Patient starts to breath deep and fast 

5. Cycle starts again... 

 

Which of the following best describes the type of breathing this patient is demonstrating?
Explanation:
This is a description of Cheyne-Stokes breathing, it is often a result of cerebellar dysfunction and unfortunately often signifies the patient is about to die. 

 

The normal pattern of breathing is: inspiration, pause, expiration, inspiration, pause, expiration etc etc 

 

Hyperventilation = deep rapid breathing, this is non-specific but can be due to midbrain disorders. 

 

Role of apneustic centre = causes inspiration by stimulating the diaphragm and respiratory neurones

Role of pneumotactic centre = control rate and depth of breathing, inhibits apneustic centre to prevent respiration being too long. 

 

Apneusis = loss of pneumotactic inhibition of apneustic centre  leading to long inspiration, pause, short and ineffective expiration, long pause, long inspiration etc etc. Indicates pontine dysfunction (which is where the pneumotactic centre is located. 

 

Ataxic breathing= Loss of both apneustic centre and pneumotaxic centre function which means you have completely uncontrolled, unpatterned breathing. Long, short, deep and shallow breaths all mixed up. Indicates pontine dysfunction.

 

Respiratory arrest = cessation of breathing

Question:
A patient presents to A&E with a sudden onset chest pain, dizziness, light headedness and shortness of breath. 

The episode started with shortness of breath but they weren't that concerned about this as they have asthma so they are used to it. 

But when the other symptoms came they got more worried as they didn't stop spontaneously. 
Their heart rate is 160 bpm. 

Their ECG showed no visible P waves, as they are hidden by the QRS complex. 

You suspect a slow-fast AVNRT.

After a failed Valsalva manoeuvre, what is the next line of action?
Explanation:
Steps for paroxysmal SVT (AVNRT, AVRT [WPW]): 
Vagal manoeuvres then,

Adenosine then,
B blocker 

 

HOWEVER, this patient is asthmatic so can't give adenosine, must give calcium channel blocker: diltiazem (or verpamil) 
As adenosine causes bronchospasm, bronchoconstriction 

 

DC cardioversion - RHYTHM control in AF or flutter, if onset < 48 hr 
Rhythm control in structural heart disease: flecainide, amiodarone 

 

If AF or flutter, over 65 or can't have cardioversion: RATE control with B blocker, CCB or digoxin

Question: Which one of these would warrant a CT head before carrying out a lumbar puncture?
OptionB: Patient has a previous history of stroke.
OptionC: Patient' left pupil displays mydriasis and is unreactive to light.

Signs that indicate a CT head before attempting an LP (due to the risk of coning) are:

 

Decreased GCS.

New focal neurology.

Sings of increased ICP (i.e. papilloedema).

If the patient is immunocompromised.

 

And for E - technically you cant herniate if you dont have a brain to begin with...

Question: What would be the best way to diagnose DiGeorge Syndrome  - a 22q11.2 deletion?
OptionD: Wait for the baby to be born
Explanation:
Due to it being such a small deletion, FISH would be the best option as it can detect microdeletions.

 

Karyotype is a test to identify and evaluate the size, shape, and number of chromosomes in a sample of body cells - it has a 'limit of detection' of around 5Mb, which is too large to detect the small deletion on chromosome 22.

Question: Implantable defib works by:
What gene determines male sex?
Explanation:
Testis-determining factor (TDF), also known as sex-determining region Y (SRY) protein, is a DNA-binding protein (also known as gene-regulatory protein/transcription factor) encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination in humans.

Question: What are some symptoms of Angelman Syndrome?
OptionA:
- Changing muscle tone from floppy to rigid.
- Hearing loss that leads to deafness.
- Failure to thrive.
- Feeding difficulties.
OptionB:
- Deafness.
- Progressive blindness.
- Decreased muscle strength.

- Paralysis or loss of muscle function.
OptionC:
- Respiratory difficulties.
- Mouth, arm, throat or hand spasms.
- Frequent infections.
- Abnormal facial features including underdeveloped chin, low-set ears and wide-set eyes.
OptionD:
- Floppiness. 

- Obesity.

- Behavioural problems.

- Learning difficulties.
OptionE:
- Developmental delays
- Intellectual disability.
- No speech or minimal speech.
- Difficulty walking, moving or balancing well (ataxia)
- Frequent smiling and laughter.
Explanation:
A - Krabbe Disease (don't worry, we haven't learn about this)

B - Tay Sachs

C - DiGeorge Syndrome

D - Prader-Willi Syndrome

 

Both D and E are caused by a chromosome 15 defect. Prader-Willi from the father, Angelman from the mother.

 

It is easy to remember the difference as Prader-WILLi has a guy's name in it. and ANGELs are commonly thought of as being female. Also, Angels are a HAPPY thought with one of the main characteristic symptoms of Angelman Syndrome being the child has a happy demeanor and frequently smiles.

Question: You are an F1 on a 100 hour shift in A&E when a 76 year old lady with a BMI of 35, Mrs Jones, has been brought in by her daughter who tells you that her mother became increasingly withdrawn, lethargic, sleepy and confused. After further questioning, you learn that Mrs Jones has not been taking her thyroid medication. What is her diagnosis?
Explanation:
A- Hypothyroidism is slightly true as myxoedema coma is the result of end stage of untreated or insufficiently treated hypothyroidism.

 

B- Correct answer! Patient becomes increasingly withdrawn, lethargic, sleepy and confused and then slips into a coma. This typically occurs in the elderly, obese and in women. A history includes previous thyroid surgery, radioiodine and poor compliance with thyroid hormone therapy.

 

C- Symptoms of hyperthyroidism include excessive sweating, heat intolerance, increased bowel movements, tremor, palpitations, Weight loss with increased appetite, fatigue, poor concentration, increased anxiety, irritability, irregular/scant periods.

 

D- Addison's disease is an example of primary hypoadrenalism.

 

This was from the endocrine review lecture in case 10.

Which type of thought disorder is this patient exhibiting right now?

Question: How did yesterday's exam go?
What is a normal albumin:creatinine ratio (A:CR) for men?
Explanation:
Normal A:CR for men is <2.5 and for women it is <3.5.

 

Microalbuminuria is defined as: albumin:creatinine ratio >2.5mg/mmol (men) or >3.5mg/mmol (women) or albumin concentration >20mg/l.

Proteinuria is defined as: albumin:creatinine ratio >30mg/mmol or albumin concentration >200mg/l.

Question: What is proteinuria?
Explanation: Proteinuria is defined as: albumin:creatinine ratio >30mg/mmol or albumin concentration >200mg/l.

Question: What is the first line of treatment for interstitial cystitis?
Explanation:
The exact cause of interstitial cystitis isn't clear. Unlike other types of cystitis, there's no obvious infection in the bladder and antibiotics don't help. In some people with the condition, the bladder is inflamed, ulcerated, scarred or stiff.

 

Unfortunately, there's currently no cure for interstitial cystitis and it can be difficult to treat, although a number of treatments can be tried.

 

Lifestyle changes will usually be recommended first. Medications and other therapies may be used if these don't help, and surgery may be necessary as a last resort.

Question: What is the most common cause of cystitis?
Explanation: Uropathogenic E. coli from the gut is the cause of 80–85% of community-acquired urinary tract infections,[22] with Staphylococcus saprophyticus being the cause in 5–10%

Question: What is antigenic shift?
OptionA: A "point mutation" in a virus resulting in a small change.
OptionB: The formation of a new strain of a virus
OptionC: The passing on of a virus from mother to child
OptionD: The formation of a new subtype of a virus
OptionE: Infecting an organism within the same species
Explanation:
A = antigenic drift

B = antigenic drift

C = vertical transmission

D = antigenic shift in which Subtype A + Subtype B –> New Subtype (2 different strains or 2 different viruses combine to form a new subtype)

E = horizontal transmission

Question: What is the most common cause of croup?
Explanation:
All can cause croup, but croup is usually caused by a viral infection, the most common being HPIV - human parainfluenza virus.

 

NB croup is respiratory infection which results in a characteristic "barking" cough

Question: What is Oseltamivir?
Explanation:
Oseltamivir - sold under the brand name 'Tamiflu' is a neuraminidase inhibitor - it blocks the enzyme neuraminidase resulting in the virus no longer being released from the infected host cell. It therefore prevents new host cells from being infected.

 

Oseltamivir is an antiviral medication used to treat and prevent influenza A and influenza B (flu)

Question: What does Oseltamivir treat?
Explanation: Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase blocker --> results in virus not being able to leave the cell it is in to spread

Question: What is the MOA of Aciclovir?
Explanation: Aciclovir - used to treat Herpes Simplex and Viral Zoster - is converted to acyclovir triphosphate in infected cells. Acyclovir triphosphate blocks DNA polymerase resulting in the virus no longer being able to replicate in that cell.
